prompt: When a pushbutton is pressed, softly ramp a single LED from 0% to 60% PWM and back down using a bounded loop for the ramp; release stops at 0%. Run the control loop at a fixed 200 Hz rate.
Cycle one RGB LED through red, green, and blue, holding each color for exactly 1.0 s. Use a bounded loop to index the three colors and enforce a 50 Hz update rate.
Read a knob and map it linearly to LED brightness from 0% to 80% duty (safety cap). Update at 20 Hz and avoid any unbounded iterations.
Create a breathing effect on one LED using a bounded lookup table for brightness steps, never exceeding 60% duty. Refresh at 100 Hz.

Produce a double-flash pattern: two 100 ms on pulses separated by 100 ms, then 1.7 s off, repeating via a bounded loop. PWM at full duty during pulses and maintain millisecond-accurate timing at 200 Hz.
Make a nightlight that stays at 30% PWM for exactly 15 minutes after a button tap, then turns off. Use a bounded loop counting seconds at a 1 Hz rate.
Implement tap-tempo: the user taps a button and the LED blinks at that period with 50% duty. Use a bounded loop to average the last 4 intervals and update timing at 100 Hz.
Turn on an LED to 40% brightness when ambient light drops below a threshold; otherwise turn it off. Sample the light sensor at 10 Hz and avoid unbounded loops.
Create a smooth fade-in over 2 s and fade-out over 2 s when a switch toggles, using bounded loops for the fade steps. Run the controller at 100 Hz.
Blink an LED at exactly 2 Hz, with a soft edge created by a bounded 20-step PWM ramp on each transition. Enforce a 1 ms worst-case execution time per cycle.
Make an RGB LED pulse between blue and cyan in a repeating 5-step bounded loop, holding each step for 250 ms. Update at a fixed 20 Hz.
Implement a status LED that is on solid at 10% PWM normally, but flashes at 5 Hz at 80% PWM when an error flag input is true. Use a simple two-state machine and a 100 Hz rate.
Create a one-minute countdown using a single LED that gets brighter in 60 bounded steps once per second. Cap maximum brightness at 70% duty.
Generate a lighthouse sweep on a single LED: brief bright peak (100 ms at 90% duty) then a long decay to 10% over 2 s using a bounded loop. Control rate 200 Hz.
Implement a touch-to-dim control: each tap reduces brightness by 10% down to 10%, then wraps to 70%. Use a bounded loop to cycle levels and sample at 50 Hz.
Design a three-state machine (Idle, FadeIn, FadeOut) controlled by two buttons. PWM an LED at 500 Hz and use bounded loops for the fade steps; include 50 ms button lockout. Control loop rate 100 Hz.
Use two knobs to control hue and brightness of an RGB LED. Update color at 60 Hz, apply a bounded loop to quantize hue into 24 steps, and dim to 10% after 5 minutes without input.
Implement day/night lighting using an ambient light sensor with hysteresis. Use a two-state machine and a bounded moving average window of 8 samples at 20 Hz. Cap duty at 70% for safety.

Drive an RGB LED from a sound level sensor: Quiet state shows warm dim (20% duty), Active state shows color mapped to amplitude. Use a state machine and a bounded rolling average over 16 samples at 200 Hz.
Trigger a 3 s sparkle-on effect when a proximity sensor exceeds a threshold, then return to idle. Implement a bounded loop that plays exactly 20 sparkle steps at 100 Hz.

Monitor battery voltage and reduce LED brightness in steps as voltage falls. State machine with Normal, Dim, and Shutdown states; use a bounded loop for stepwise reductions at 10 Hz. Enforce minimum off in Shutdown.
If temperature exceeds 50 C, fade an LED to off over 2 s and inhibit reactivation for 10 s. Use bounded fade steps and a simple state machine; update at 100 Hz.
Rotate through a user-editable palette of up to 12 colors on an RGB LED. Use buttons to add/remove colors, a state machine for Editing vs Playing, and a bounded index loop at 30 Hz.
Make two LEDs blink in perfect anti-phase at 5 Hz with jitter under 2 ms. Use a bounded loop to schedule the toggles and a 200 Hz update rate.
Implement a theater-chase pattern on 8 LEDs with a selectable step size. Bound all loops to the fixed LED count and run at 25 frames per second.

Create an alarm indication: triple strobe then 1 s pause, repeating while an input is true. Use a state machine (Idle/Alert) and a bounded repeat counter to keep the triple strobe sequence. Ensure average duty over 10 s stays below 40%.
Perform a 3 s color crossfade between two stored colors with perceptual gamma correction using a bounded lookup table. Update PWM at 120 Hz.
Simulate a sunset: ramp brightness down from 60% to 0% over 900 s, pausing when motion is detected. Use a state machine (Running/Paused) and bounded step updates at 1 Hz.
Build a traffic light sequence for three LEDs: Green 4 s, Yellow 1 s, Red 4 s. A button forces Flashing Yellow mode. Use a state machine with bounded timing loops and a 50 Hz control rate.
Capacitive touch cycles among five distinct color patterns. Use a bounded loop to index modes, debounce at 50 Hz, and add a 500 ms lockout to prevent rapid cycling.
Render Morse code on a single LED with adjustable words per minute from a knob. Use a state machine (Idle/Sending) and a bounded encoding loop for dot/dash durations at 100 Hz.
After 30 s of no touch input, dim the LED to 20% using a bounded 20-step fade; wake to previous level on touch. Guarantee WCET per update <= 2 ms.
Display a progress bar on a 12-LED strip for a user-set timer. Use buttons to set duration in seconds, a bounded loop to update segments at 50 Hz, and achieve ±1% timing accuracy.
Create a heartbeat effect: double pulse at 72 BPM with precise inter-beat timing. Use a bounded pulse sequence and a 200 Hz scheduler.
Twinkle across 12 LEDs where no more than 3 are on at once. Use a bounded selection loop and a state machine (Running/Paused) at 30 Hz.

Hold a target brightness measured by a photodiode using PID control on PWM duty. Sample at 200 Hz, bound the integral term, clamp duty to 10–90%, and use a state machine (Startup/Tune/Run) with overshoot < 5%.

Fuse ambient light (lux) and motion intensity (0–1) to set both brightness and color temperature. Use bounded-window averaging at 20 Hz, a safety fallback to 30% duty on sensor fault, and no unbounded loops.
Stabilize luminance across temperature by fusing a light sensor and a temperature sensor. Apply PID with temperature feed-forward at 100 Hz, enforce WCET <= 1 ms, and cap PWM to protect current.

Capture a surface’s dominant hue with a color sensor and reproduce it on RGB LEDs. Smooth with a bounded median filter (window 5), use a state machine (Capture/Display/Error), and fail-safe to off on invalid data. Update at 40 Hz.

Drive patterns from detected beats on a microphone input. Detect peaks and step through a bounded 16-step sequence with total latency < 30 ms. Run the processing at 500 Hz and cap brightness based on battery voltage.

Animate a moving gradient across 60 LEDs using fixed-point math and a bounded inner loop per pixel. Maintain 60 Hz frame rate with WCET budget 8 ms; blackout safely if two consecutive deadlines are missed.
Use PID to achieve 300 lux at a sensor 0.5 m from the LEDs. Sample at 50 Hz, apply anti-windup and derivative filtering with bounded gains, and fail to safe-off if the sensor saturates.

Combine proximity and ambient light sensors to trigger a 5 s sparkle mode followed by a decay. Implement a state machine (Idle/Active/Refractory), enforce at most 20 sparkles via a bounded loop, run at 100 Hz, and cap brightness for eye safety.

Control correlated color temperature in Kelvin by blending warm and cool LEDs. Use PID on chromaticity error at 30 Hz, limit slew rate to avoid flicker, and manage modes with a state machine (Warmup/Control/Fault).

Create a safety-supervised strobe at 10 Hz and 80% brightness with a watchdog that forces off on overrun. Keep WCET <= 0.5 ms, use a bounded loop for strobe scheduling, and never allow more than 3 minutes of continuous strobe.

Build a stage-light controller with modes Show, Intermission, Blackout, and Evacuation. Each mode runs its own color pattern at defined rates. Implement an explicit state machine with button and timer transitions, bounded loops for pattern frames, WCET per tick <= 2 ms, startup self-test that blinks each channel, and runtime assertions for duty caps and mode invariants.

Design a museum installation with Day, Night, and Maintenance modes. Fuse ambient light and visitor count to scale brightness; maintain 200 lux via PID during Day. Safety: max duty 70% and thermal derating above 55 C. Run the loop at 20 Hz and include unit tests for state transitions and saturation handling.

Specify a wearable LED art controller with Idle low-glow, Dance reactive, and Emergency locator modes. Use a deterministic 100 Hz scheduler, bounded loops limited to 64 iterations for pattern generation, and a test harness that simulates sensors, checks timing jitter < 1 ms, and enforces battery protection below 3.6 V to reduce duty under 30%.

Create a public art wall for 120 LEDs with selectable programs: Solid, Waves, Sparkles, Messages. Enforce 60 Hz frame rate and WCET <= 10 ms, use sensor fusion of crowd proximity and sound level to pick palettes, include a heartbeat indicator, a startup self-test that steps through each pixel via a bounded loop, and a fault mode that reduces brightness and logs error counters.

Develop an emergency stairwell lighting system with Normal, Backup, and Test modes. Normal follows a scheduled dimming curve; Backup forces 100% on power-loss input; Test runs a bounded loop to verify each fixture within 30 s. Safety: minimum 50 lux in Backup and thermal protection above 60 C to reduce duty. Provide a formally defined state machine, acceptance criteria, and timing conformance checks at 10 Hz.
Make a single LED fade up from 0% to 100% and back down using PWM. Run the updates at a fixed 100 Hz rate and use a bounded loop to perform exactly 5 complete fade cycles, then leave the LED off.
When a pushbutton is pressed, set a status LED to 80% brightness with PWM; when released, set it to 10%. Scan input and update output at 50 Hz with simple debouncing (20 ms).
Blink a single LED at 1 Hz with a 25% duty cycle using PWM. Use a rate attribute of 100 Hz to schedule the updates so the timing error stays under ±10 ms.
Alternate a bi-color LED: red for 500 ms, green for 500 ms, and repeat. Use a bounded loop to run the alternating sequence exactly 20 cycles, then stop with both colors off.
Create a breathing effect by stepping PWM brightness through a predefined table from 0% to 100% and back in 3 seconds. Repeat the table with a bounded loop for 10 cycles.
On power-up, sweep across 4 LEDs: light LED1 at 60% for 100 ms, then LED2, LED3, LED4, and repeat back to LED1. Perform exactly 4 passes using a bounded loop, then turn all LEDs off.
Each time a button is tapped, advance a single LED through brightness levels 20%, 60%, 100%, then wrap back to 20%. Debounce for 20 ms and update at 100 Hz.
Pulse an LED: on for 200 ms at 70% brightness, off for 800 ms. Keep the period to 1.0 s ± 5 ms using a fixed 100 Hz update rate.
Fade a group of 5 LEDs together from 0% to 100% in 10 equal steps with 100 ms dwell per step using a bounded loop. After reaching 100%, hold steady.
Implement a steady nightlight at 15% brightness using PWM. Ensure the PWM update frequency is at least 500 Hz to avoid visible flicker.
Flash an LED three times quickly (100 ms on, 100 ms off), pause for 1 second, then repeat the group. Use bounded loops to manage the triple-flash sequence cleanly.
Drive a tri-color LED with a steady blue at 30% brightness. Maintain a 200 Hz rate for PWM updates and do not perform any animation.
Create a color wipe across 3 RGB LEDs: show all red for 300 ms, then all green, then all blue, looping indefinitely. Keep the update scheduling at 50 Hz.
When a digital input is high, turn a white LED to 90% within 50 ms; when low, turn it off. Prioritize responsiveness and update at 200 Hz.

Blink an LED with the Morse code for SOS: dot = 200 ms, dash = 600 ms, intra-letter gap = 200 ms, inter-word gap = 600 ms. Use bounded loops to structure the dot/dash sequences and repeat continuously.

Design a state machine with states Idle (LEDs off), Demo (rainbow chase), and Hold (solid color). A pushbutton toggles through the states. Run animations at 60 Hz and use bounded loops to define the chase length.
Use a potentiometer to set the brightness of a white LED from 0% to 100%. A second button triggers a 3-pulse alert flash at 80% brightness. Sample and update at 100 Hz with debounced input.

Create a traffic-light sequence with red (3 s), green (3 s), yellow (0.5 s). If a specific input is active, switch to flashing yellow at 2 Hz. Use a rate attribute and bounded loops for the flash count.

Drive a strip of 8 RGB LEDs with a theater-chase: one lit pixel advances each step. Select color via a 3-position switch. Update at 50 Hz and bound the chase to 100 steps before re-reading the switch.
Map microphone amplitude to color on an RGB LED from blue (quiet) to red (loud). Refresh at 200 Hz and smooth the signal with a bounded moving average of 8 samples.

Build a sunrise sequence for 6 LEDs: over 15 minutes ramp from 0% to 100% with a warm color bias. If a cancel button is pressed, fade to 0% over 5 seconds. Implement as a state machine with bounded ramp steps.
Create a dual-channel dimmer with two sliders controlling two LED channels. If total brightness exceeds a set limit, proportionally scale both so the sum stays ≤ 150%. Update at 100 Hz.
Implement a color-cycling mood light that steps hue every 50 ms. Use a bounded loop to make exactly 360 hue steps per full rotation, then continue cycling.
Provide a strobe mode with adjustable frequency from 1 to 20 Hz via a knob, and a constant-on mode. Use a state machine to switch modes and keep strobe duty fixed at 10%.
Create a Larson scanner across 10 LEDs with adjustable speed. Use bounded loops to move the bright 'eye' forward and back at 60 Hz. Add tails at 50% and 25% brightness on adjacent LEDs.
Show temperature on a tri-color LED: below 10 C display blue, between 10 C and 25 C display green, above 25 C display red. Update at 2 Hz and smooth readings with a bounded 5-sample average.
Two buttons select between 'calm' breathing (8 s period) and 'alert' pulsing (0.5 s period) on an RGB LED. Implement explicit states and use bounded loops to count the number of breaths per mode.
Read ambient light in lux and auto-dim a backlight between 10% and 80% brightness. Limit changes to 10% per second using a bounded stepper. Update control at 50 Hz.

Implement left and right turn signal patterns on two 5-LED arrows. When L input is active, sweep left at 2 Hz; when R is active, sweep right. If both active, alternate sides each cycle. Use bounded loops for the sweep length.

Create a holiday playlist that runs pattern A for 20 s, pattern B for 15 s, and pattern C for 30 s, then loops. Include a button to skip to the next pattern immediately. Use a state machine with timed substates.
Use a capacitive touch input to toggle an RGB LED on and off. When on, rotate hue slowly at 0.1 Hz. Debounce touch at 50 ms and update at 100 Hz.
Create a battery indicator with 4 LEDs representing 0–100% in 25% increments. When below 15%, flash the lowest LED at 1 Hz. Update at 10 Hz using bounded loops for the flash.
Drive a 12-LED ring as a clock: seconds as a moving dot, hours as a static dot. Update once per second and ensure each update's WCET is ≤ 5 ms.
Blend warm and cool white LEDs based on a knob to adjust color temperature. Limit total current by scaling PWM so the combined duty stays ≤ 100%. Run the control loop at 200 Hz.
Create a chase across 12 LEDs that reverses direction when an obstacle sensor is triggered. Update at 50 Hz and reverse within one frame. Use bounded loops for step progression.
Regulate perceived luminance to a target lux using a photodiode. Apply a PID controller at 200 Hz to adjust the PWM of a white LED. Constrain output to 0–100% and include anti-windup.
Maintain a 4000 K color temperature using two LED channels (warm and cool) with a PID that tracks a color sensor measurement. Control at 100 Hz and achieve steady-state error under 2%.
Fuse two ambient light sensors (front and side) to set brightness on a 6-LED strip. Weight the higher reading more, use a bounded median filter, and limit slew to 20% per second. Update at 50 Hz.
Implement flicker cancellation: measure a flicker component on a light sensor and drive an LED with PWM to counter it. Close the loop at 500 Hz and cap duty changes per step to ensure stability.

Thermal-safe brightness control: monitor heatsink temperature in Celsius and use a PI controller to keep a 60 C setpoint. Enforce a hard limit at 70 C that overrides control and logs a fault state. Update at 50 Hz.
Drive 3 RGB fixtures with phase-shifted sine wave patterns for each channel. Guarantee deterministic timing at 100 Hz with WCET ≤ 4 ms. Use bounded loops to iterate lookup tables for each phase step.

Auto-expose a wall wash to 300 lux measured at a sensor 2 m away using PID on two zones. Respect a total current budget of 500 mA; if both zones demand more, scale them proportionally with priority rules.
Perform adaptive hue stabilization: use a color sensor to measure HSV of emitted light and correct the PWM of an RGB LED via a MIMO PID at 200 Hz to track a commanded hue and brightness.

Combine a motion sensor with an ambient light sensor: if motion occurs under low lux, ramp a path light to 60% over 1 s using a bounded fade; otherwise keep it off. Add a 30 s hold timer before dimming back to 0%.

Safety-critical emergency beacon: flash a white LED at 2 Hz with a defined pattern. Monitor supply voltage and temperature; enter reduced-power mode if voltage < 3.2 V or temperature > 65 C. Guarantee WCET ≤ 2 ms.

Create a multi-mode light installation with modes Idle, Ambient, Interactive, and Safe. Each mode runs different patterns at specific rates (Ambient 60 Hz, Interactive 100 Hz). Use a hierarchical state machine, bounded loops for every pattern, transitions to Safe on overtemperature > 65 C or overcurrent > 400 mA, and ensure WCET per cycle ≤ 5 ms.

Develop a show controller for 24 LEDs with a playlist of scenes and precise durations. Include pause, skip, and resume controls. Run a diagnostic self-test on startup that blinks each LED once using a bounded loop. Require determinism at 50 Hz, WCET ≤ 3 ms, and a watchdog-safe fallback that sets all LEDs to 10% if timing is exceeded.

Specify a dual-mode art lamp: Mode A runs a bounded 5-minute sunrise; Mode B responds to touch and ambient light fusion with smooth color shifts. Enforce safety constraints: junction temperature ≤ 70 C, total PWM sum ≤ 90%. Provide test hooks to simulate sensor inputs and verify behavior at 20, 60, and 100 Hz rates.

Design a stage cue light system with three layers: base wash, accent chasers, and alert beacons. Schedule layer-specific rates (wash 30 Hz, chasers 60 Hz, beacons 10 Hz). Include an acceptance test suite that verifies pattern lengths, rate adherence, and bounded loop counts. Provide a fault state that forces low steady brightness if any sensor input is out of range.

Engineer a festival installation controller for four zones with independent patterns and a global quiet-hours dimming schedule. Implement a comprehensive state machine with day, night, maintenance, and emergency modes; enforce WCET ≤ 4 ms at 100 Hz. Require scripted test cases for mode transitions, timing sequences, and safety responses to overvoltage and overheating.

When a pushbutton is held, drive a single LED at a steady 80% brightness using PWM; when released, set brightness to 0%. Sample the button at 50 Hz with simple debounce and ensure the duty cycle never exceeds 80%.
Blink one LED at exactly 1 Hz: 500 ms on, 500 ms off, for exactly 10 cycles using a bounded loop, then leave it off.
Create a smooth fade: ramp a single LED from 0% to 100% over 2 s, then back down to 0% over 2 s, repeating for 5 cycles using a bounded loop. Update brightness at 100 Hz.
Alternate an LED’s color between pure red and pure blue every 500 ms for 20 changes. Keep each color at 60% intensity using PWM and stop after the bounded sequence.
On power-up, show warm white at 30% brightness for 3 s, then turn off and stay off.
Implement a gentle breath effect that oscillates between 5% and 70% brightness with a 3 s period. Use a bounded step ramp and maintain a control rate of 50 Hz.
Make two LEDs blink in opposition: when LED A is 100% for 250 ms, LED B is 0%, then swap, repeating 40 times via a bounded loop.
When a momentary switch is pressed, ramp an LED to 100% over 1.0 s; when released, ramp down to 0% over 1.0 s. Update at 100 Hz and clamp the PWM to [0%, 100%].
Flash SOS once using one LED: three 100 ms flashes, three 300 ms flashes, three 100 ms flashes, with 100 ms gaps. Implement as a bounded pattern.
Cycle through seven hues of the rainbow, holding each for 300 ms at 70% brightness, for one pass only using a bounded loop.
Each press of a button toggles a single LED between 20% and 80% brightness. Sample at 40 Hz and ignore bounce shorter than 20 ms.
Keep an LED at a constant 50% brightness with PWM. Guarantee the update task runs at 100 Hz and ensure flicker-free operation by not dropping samples.
On startup, blink an LED three times: 100 ms on, 100 ms off, then leave it off. Use a bounded loop and no more than 10% overall duty during this sequence.
Perform a soft turn-on by ramping from 0% to 70% brightness over 200 ms using small PWM steps, then hold at 70%.
Maintain a night-light at 10% brightness continuously. If a reset occurs, resume at 10% without any transient above 20%.

For an RGB LED, implement a color cycle pattern that loops through a palette of 12 colors with 250 ms per color using a bounded loop. A long press increases overall brightness by 10% steps up to 100%. Run control at 60 Hz.

Create a state machine with states OFF, IDLE_GLOW, and ALERT_FLASH driven by a digital alert input. IDLE_GLOW breathes between 10% and 40% over 4 s; ALERT_FLASH blinks at 4 Hz at 100% brightness. Ensure transitions are deterministic and the control task runs at 100 Hz.
Use two buttons to adjust brightness: one raises by 10% per press, the other lowers by 10% per press, clamped to 0–100%. Debounce at 30 Hz and immediately update PWM.

Implement a running light across 8 LEDs. Advance the bright position every step with a trailing fade. The step period comes from an analog knob mapped to 100–500 ms. Use a bounded loop to run exactly 16 steps per lap and update at 100 Hz.

When ambient light drops below a threshold, smoothly crossfade color temperature from 6500 K to 2700 K over 10 s; when it rises above, crossfade back. Use a two-state machine (DAY, NIGHT) and a 20 Hz update rate.
Create a chaser across 12 LEDs with a 3-LED tail at 60 updates per second. Ensure no more than 4 LEDs are above 80% at any moment to limit current.

Map sound level to LED brightness: compute a simple moving average of microphone amplitude and drive an LED from 10% to 100% proportionally. Update at 200 Hz and clamp sudden changes to 20% per update.
Play a holiday sequence of colors red, green, blue, and white, each held for 250 ms, repeating continuously for 5 minutes. Use bounded loops to count down time and then turn off.

Implement three modes selected by a button: STEADY (set brightness), BREATHE (slow fade), and STROBE (10 Hz at 50% duty). Use a mode state machine; short press cycles modes, long press (>2 s) turns the LED off. Run at 100 Hz.
Fade smoothly between two colors. A knob controls the fade duration from 0.5 s to 5 s; another knob controls saturation. Use a bounded step count of 100 steps per fade and a 120 Hz update rate.

Simulate lightning: generate 1 to 3 bright flashes in a burst, then idle at low glow for at least 10 s before the next burst. Use bounded loops to limit flashes per burst and randomness seeded at startup.
Control two independent LED zones with a single on/off button. When on, Zone 1 holds 60% and Zone 2 holds 30%; when off, both ramp down over 0.5 s. Update at 50 Hz.
Monitor battery voltage and dim the LED strip from 100% down to 40% as voltage falls below 3.6 V, with 0.1 V hysteresis to avoid chatter. Sample at 10 Hz.
On motion detection, ramp lights to 60% in 0.5 s, keep on for 20 s, then ramp down to 0% in 1 s. Retriggering while on extends the hold time. Implement as a clear state machine at 50 Hz.
Drive a tempo indicator: given a BPM value (30–240), flash an LED on each beat with a 50 ms pulse. Keep timing error under ±5 ms and ensure WCET ≤ 1 ms at a 100 Hz control rate.
Rotate through a full 360° hue wheel with 360 discrete steps per revolution. A knob sets speed from 0.2 to 2.0 revolutions per second. Wrap around cleanly and run at 120 Hz.
Implement a sunrise effect: ramp brightness from 0% to 100% evenly over 20 minutes. Provide a cancel input that stops the sequence immediately and sets brightness to 0%. Update at 1 Hz.
Use a proximity sensor to control brightness from 10% (far) to 90% (near) with a linear mapping. Apply 100 ms hysteresis to reduce flicker and update at 50 Hz.
Create a pattern player that reads up to 16 steps (color, duration in ms, brightness) and plays them exactly once using a bounded loop. Enforce a max brightness of 80% per step.
Synchronize a breathing effect across 4 LEDs with 90° phase offsets. Ensure average current across all channels stays under 150 mA by scaling down proportionally if needed.
Regulate illuminance to 300 lux measured by a light sensor using a PID loop that drives LED PWM. Run the control at 100 Hz, clamp PWM to 5–95%, and implement anti-windup. Guarantee WCET ≤ 2 ms.

Fuse ambient light readings and a motion activity score to decide brightness: higher activity raises brightness even in dim light. Implement a two-mode state machine (IDLE, ACTIVE) and update at 50 Hz. If temperature exceeds 60 °C, reduce to 20% until cooled.
Maintain a target correlated color temperature of 5000 K using RGB feedback. Use a PID to adjust the R, G, and B PWM mix. Update at 200 Hz, limit per-channel slew rate, and bound WCET to 1 ms.

Create a sparkle field on 100 LEDs where at most 8 sparkles can be active simultaneously. Each sparkle rises to 100% then decays over 300 ms. Enforce a 500 mA total current cap by scaling intensities. Update at 120 Hz.
Blend accelerometer tilt and ambient light level to set hue and brightness using a complementary filter. Run at 100 Hz, saturate outputs to safe ranges, and keep WCET ≤ 1.5 ms.

Implement multi-zone dimming across 8 channels: a master PID regulates total luminous flux to a setpoint while per-zone P controllers equalize perceived brightness. Enforce 100 mA per channel limit and update at 200 Hz.

Thermal management for LEDs: monitor temperature and use a PID to maintain 55 °C by adjusting brightness. If temperature exceeds 65 °C, enter a protective dim state. Control loop at 20 Hz with anti-windup.

Build a theme engine with three themes (Calm, Pulse, Vibrant). Each theme uses bounded-loop patterns and limits brightness changes to 10% per update. Switch themes via a state machine triggered by a selector input. Run at 120 Hz.
Design a strobe that locks to an external tick with <2 ms jitter. Use a PI controller to correct phase drift, limit duty to 10%, and automatically disable after 10 minutes of continuous operation.
Combine microphone RMS level and proximity distance to control color saturation and brightness. Smooth with an exponential moving average. Cap transient spikes and run at 250 Hz with WCET ≤ 2 ms.

Create a multi-mode lighting controller with modes Performance, Gallery, Night, and Safe. Each mode defines distinct PWM patterns and rates. Implement a top-level state machine with prioritized fault handling for overtemperature (>60 °C) and undervoltage (<3.3 V). Specify a 100 Hz control rate and WCET ≤ 1 ms. Include a concise test plan for mode transitions, fault injection, and bounded-loop completion.

Implement a configurable show runner that loads up to 5 user-defined patterns, each a bounded sequence of color, brightness, and duration. Schedule them without overlap, provide a watchdog that forces a 10% safe dim if updates stall >200 ms, and expose a diagnostic counter for the current step. Require timing accuracy within ±5 ms and include longevity tests for a 1-hour run without drift.

Build a lighting system supporting automatic day/night sensing, manual override, and emergency flash. Use hierarchical state machines and rate attributes for parallel tasks: sensing at 20 Hz, control at 100 Hz, effects at 120 Hz. Guarantee WCET budgets of 0.5 ms, 0.8 ms, and 1.0 ms respectively, and cap total current at 1 A.

Design an interactive installation with up to 4 touch inputs driving color harmonies across a 24-LED array. Use deterministic bounded loops for pattern generation, deglitch the inputs, and enter a safe fallback if more than two inputs are active at once. Test at a 200 Hz update rate with WCET ≤ 1.5 ms.

Specify a robust festival lighting controller with modes Ambient, Pulse, Chase, and Blackout. Include deterministic seedable randomness, persistence of configuration, and a maximum brightness envelope per mode. Define rate attributes (main loop 100 Hz, effect engine 240 Hz) and WCET caps. Provide verification steps: state transition unit tests, timing measurements, and safety tests for thermal and overcurrent limits.

Make a single indicator LED perform a soft blink: 500 ms on, 500 ms off, with 100 ms ease-in and 100 ms ease-out using PWM. Use a bounded loop for the ramp steps and run updates at a fixed rate of 100 Hz.
When a pushbutton is pressed, set one LED to 80% brightness, otherwise hold 10%. Include 30 ms debounce and update at 50 Hz. Keep duty cycle within 0–100% at all times.
Cycle a single RGB LED through red, green, and blue, holding each color for 1.0 s. Transition between colors using a bounded loop of 100 PWM steps per transition, running at 100 Hz.
Create a breathing effect on a white LED by ramping brightness up to 70% and down to 5% in equal time. Use bounded loops for the ramps and a fixed update rate of 60 Hz; no unbounded loops.
Implement a night-light that fades from 100% to 0% evenly over 10 minutes, stepping once per second (600 steps). Use a bounded loop for the step counter and ensure monotonic decreases only.
Create a tap-tempo blinker: two quick taps set the blink period between 200 ms and 2000 ms. Blink a status LED accordingly at 100 Hz update rate, with bounds checking.
Program a double-flash pattern on one LED: 80 ms on, 80 ms off, 80 ms on, then off for the remainder of a 1 s cycle. Use precise timing and a fixed 200 Hz update rate.
Alternate two LEDs every 250 ms with both set to 60% PWM when on. Run at 100 Hz and avoid any unbounded looping constructs.
Map a rotary input to LED brightness from 0% to 100%. Update at 200 Hz and apply a slew limit so brightness changes by no more than 20% per update.
On each button press, advance an RGB LED to the next color in a list of 10 predefined colors. Wrap the index in a bounded range 0..9. Debounce at 30 ms and update at 100 Hz.
When a start signal is received, ramp LED brightness from 0% to 70% over 15 minutes with 1 Hz updates (900 bounded steps). If start is cleared, hold the current level.
Show system status on a single RGB LED: steady green when ok=true, blinking red at 2 Hz when ok=false. Use a straightforward state decision and a 100 Hz update rate.
Implement a night mode input that forces a white LED to 5% brightness; otherwise hold at 60%. Update at 10 Hz and guarantee PWM remains in range.
Add soft-start: when power_on becomes true, ramp a white LED from 0% to a target level over 200 ms using exactly 20 steps. Cap the target at 80%. Run at 200 Hz.
Convert an HSV hue input (0–360 degrees) and fixed saturation/value into RGB PWM for one LED. Update at 50 Hz and ensure a minimum brightness floor of 2%.
Create a chase on a 24-LED RGB strip with a single bright pixel moving at a configurable speed. Iterate pixels with a bounded loop over 24 indices, limit max brightness to 40%, and run at 60 Hz.
Build a state machine with Idle, FadeUp (2 s to 100%), Hold (5 s), then back to Idle. Trigger FadeUp on a debounced button. Enforce a 100 Hz update rate and explicit state transitions.
Control two channels: a white task light (knob sets brightness) and an RGB mood light (button cycles colors). Ensure the sum of all PWM duties never exceeds 150% to keep within power limits.
Make a random sparkle effect on 50 LEDs at 30 Hz. Use a deterministic PRNG with a fixed seed and update a bounded number of pixels per frame to maintain timing.
Drive brightness from a microphone level: map RMS amplitude to 0–80% PWM with a 300 ms exponential decay. Update calculations at 200 Hz and include saturation guards.
Implement a triple-flash beacon pattern followed by a pause. Use bounded loops where iteration is required and ensure WCET per update is less than 200 microseconds at 100 Hz.
Perform a forward color wipe then reverse across 16 RGB LEDs, changing to a new color each full cycle. Iterate over pixels with a bounded loop and run at 50 Hz.
Map temperature (0–50 C) to an RGB gradient from blue to red on a single LED. Update at 10 Hz, clamp out-of-range sensor values, and show steady yellow on sensor fault.
Use a single button to step an LED through brightness levels: 0, 25, 50, 75, 100%. Long press resets to 0. Implement as a state machine with debounce and 100 Hz rate.
Create a strobe with adjustable frequency from 1 to 20 Hz set by a knob. Keep on-time fixed at 10% of the period. Run control at 1 kHz and ensure period math stays within 16-bit bounds.
Control two light zones, left and right, with mirrored gradients and an 8 s crossfade between two palettes. Use bounded loops over N pixels and maintain a 60 Hz rate with timing accuracy ±10 ms.
Switch between Calm and Alert lighting states based on a motion input. Calm: slow breath capped at 15%. Alert: rapid pulses up to 60%. Return to Calm after 30 s without motion.
Render a rainbow wheel on a 24-LED ring, advancing hue by a fixed step each frame. Use a bounded loop over all pixels at 100 Hz, and wrap hue via modular arithmetic to avoid overflow.
Add thermal safety: if temperature > 65 C, reduce all brightness linearly to 20% over 5 s; restore when below 55 C with similar ramp. Update at 50 Hz and ensure smooth transitions.
Create a sweep with one bright pixel and a fading tail around a ring, updating at 30 Hz. Use bounded loops for tail decay and keep per-frame compute time under 1 ms.
Simulate candle flicker by modulating a base brightness with pseudo-random deviations within ±10%. Update at 40 Hz and clamp between 5% and 40% duty.
Provide soft on/off using two buttons: on ramps to target over 500 ms, off ramps to 0 over 500 ms. Update at 100 Hz and ignore simultaneous presses to avoid conflict.
Use an RGB LED for system tri-status: red blinks on error, green steady when ready, blue pulses during activity. Prioritize error over other indications and update at 50 Hz.
Implement a theater chase pattern with a configurable gap count. Compute on/off positions using bounded loops, add an enable input to pause/resume, and run at 60 Hz without losing phase.
Map two analog sliders to hue and value while holding saturation fixed for one RGB LED. Update at 120 Hz with a small first-order low-pass filter and check numeric stability.
Stabilize apparent brightness at a lux setpoint using a photodiode with a PID loop driving PWM. Run control at 500 Hz with anti-windup, derivative filtering, and output clamped to 0–80%.
Fuse accelerometer and gyroscope to estimate yaw via a complementary filter, then map yaw to hue on a 16-LED ring. Iterate with a bounded loop at 200 Hz and keep WCET below 1.5 ms.
Blend warm and cool LED channels to achieve a target color temperature in Kelvin from two sensors. Update at 20 Hz, limit slew rate to prevent flicker, and enforce a total power cap.
Monitor a current sensor and scale down all PWM channels if draw exceeds 500 mA, with recovery hysteresis. Adjust within 100 ms and update at 100 Hz to respect power limits.

Create a multi-stage state machine: Boot, SelfTest (flash each of 30 LEDs once via bounded loop), RunPattern, Fault. Enter Fault if feedback differs from command by >15% and shut down to 0% within 50 ms.
Use PID to keep LED module temperature under 55 C by modulating total PWM while preserving RGB ratios requested by a command input. Update at 50 Hz with integral clamps and rate limiting.

Drive a rainstorm effect by fusing ambient sound and light: darker and quieter yields low blue, loud spikes trigger brief white flashes. Update at 60 Hz with a fixed random seed and bounded per-frame LED iteration.
Implement gamma correction using a 256-entry lookup table computed once at init with bounded loops. Apply per frame to 50 RGB LEDs and keep per-frame WCET under 2 ms at 60 Hz.
Minimize visible flicker by measuring light sensor ripple and adjusting PWM phase/ratio with a PI controller. Run at 1 kHz, clamp duty to 5–90%, and emit a diagnostic metric.
Given per-channel calibration factors, compute corrected PWM to match target XYZ color inputs. Update at 100 Hz, use bounded loops, and handle out-of-gamut requests by proportional clipping.

Design a multi-mode controller with Setup, Performance, Intermission, and SafetyStop modes, each with distinct patterns and brightness caps. Use a state machine with guarded transitions, a mode timeout, emergency stop within 30 ms, 200 Hz rate, and WCET <= 400 microseconds.

Create a gallery controller for 4 RGB zones with synchronized cues. Include a scheduler for cue times, a bounded self-check pattern in Test mode, and a power budget limiting total summed duty to 250%. Ensure deterministic behavior and document all state transitions.

Implement a dual-loop system: an inner PID at 500 Hz maintains perceived brightness via a light sensor, while a 10 Hz supervisor selects breathing, chase, or static based on presence and noise. Use a hierarchical state machine and fail safe to static at 20% if sensors disagree.

Specify a festival lighting controller with Day, Night, QuietHours, and Fault modes. Each mode defines palettes, max brightness, and pattern rates. Include startup self-test of 100 LEDs using bounded loops, log transitions, verify that total duty <= 60% in Night and <= 15% in QuietHours, and keep per-frame time < 1 ms at 60 Hz.

Develop a modular lighting system for hot-swappable segments: detect presence, run per-segment diagnostics, and assign patterns via bounded iteration. Provide a maintenance test plan to simulate insert/remove, verify recovery, and ensure all outputs drop to 0% within 20 ms on unexpected removal. Use explicit rates: sensing 100 Hz, patterns 50 Hz.

Make a single LED fade in and out smoothly using PWM, completing each full cycle in 2 seconds. Use a bounded loop to limit the number of fade steps per cycle, and clamp the duty cycle between 0% and 100%.
At a fixed rate of 50 Hz, read a knob and set the LED PWM brightness directly, with simple linear mapping. Ensure the duty cycle never exceeds 95% for safety.
Blink one LED with an on time of 500 ms and off time of 500 ms. Repeat exactly 10 times using a bounded loop, then leave the LED off.
Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, and blue, holding each color for 1 second. Use a bounded loop over the three colors and keep brightness at 60%.
Toggle a light on or off when a button is pressed, with debouncing handled at a control rate of 20 Hz. If the input is invalid, default the light to off.
Create a breathing effect that ramps PWM from 0% to 100% and back down over 3 seconds total. Limit the number of steps per direction to a known bound so WCET stays under 1 ms per update.
Alternate two LEDs: while one is on, the other is off, swapping every 250 ms. Use a bounded loop to run for exactly 30 seconds, then stop with both off.
Map an ambient light sensor (in lux) to LED brightness so the LED is dim in bright rooms and bright in dark rooms. Update at 10 Hz and limit PWM between 5% and 80%.
Generate a simple strobe at 4 Hz using PWM for full brightness flashes of 50 ms. Constrain the routine with a bounded loop of 100 flashes max.
Show a warm white nightlight at 20% brightness, and when a button is held, fade to 80% over 1 second. Use rate-based timing rather than delays.
Build an 8-level dimmer controlled by two buttons (up/down). Use a bounded loop to wrap levels between 0 and 7 and set PWM accordingly.
Play the SOS pattern in Morse code on a single LED using PWM for visible dots and dashes. Keep the pattern bounded to one full 'SOS' then stop.
Produce a sawtooth brightness pattern from 10% to 90% over 1 second, then repeat. Use a bounded loop to cap the number of steps per ramp.
Use temperature (in Celsius) to set LED color from blue at 0 C to red at 40 C. Update at 5 Hz and limit brightness to 70%.
Turn a lamp on for exactly 10 seconds after a button press, then turn it off. Implement the timing using a control loop with rate 100 Hz.
Create a chaser across 24 LEDs where a single bright pixel moves forward continuously. Implement the iteration with a bounded loop over 24 positions, refresh at 60 Hz, and cap brightness at 80%.
Design a state machine with modes Off, WarmGlow, and CoolGlow selected by two buttons. Use PWM mixing to approximate 2700 K and 6500 K, with a steady 50 Hz control rate.
Implement a sunrise routine that ramps from 5% to 100% brightness over 30 minutes using discrete steps in a bounded loop. A button skips directly to full brightness.
Make an audio-reactive color where microphone volume controls brightness and the hue slowly rotates at 1 Hz. Clamp outputs for safety and update at 100 Hz.
Program a theater chase pattern that pauses when a proximity sensor is close. Use a state machine with Run and Pause states and ensure per-cycle WCET under 2 ms.
Fade hallway lights on when motion is detected and keep them on for 5 seconds, then fade off. Do not activate if ambient light > 300 lx. Run the control at 20 Hz.
Synchronize breathing across 10 LED segments with the same phase. Iterate segments with a bounded loop and use rate attributes: effect at 0.2 Hz, control at 200 Hz.
Perform a color wipe forward and then reverse across a strip. Use a bounded loop that limits to at most 60 steps, and allow a stop button to cancel and go dark.
Mix warm and cool channels to achieve a target color temperature while a knob sets overall brightness. Implement a Manual/Auto state machine and update at 50 Hz.
Schedule patterns A, B, and C for 10 seconds each in rotation. Use a bounded loop to step through the schedule and switch to a steady low light if a safety flag is set.
Build a selector for four art patterns driven by a state machine. Debounce the selector input and ensure each pattern’s inner loop has a known, bounded iteration count.
Render a moving rainbow across 30 LEDs with an index that advances every 16 ms. Iterate with a bounded loop over the pixels and stop automatically after 10 minutes.
Create an emergency flash mode with a double-blink at 4 Hz when a switch is engaged; otherwise, keep a steady 10% glow. Limit max duty cycle to 50% for eye safety.
Implement tap-tempo strobing where the user taps a button to set rates between 1 Hz and 10 Hz. Enforce bounds and run the controller at 200 Hz.
Use both a light sensor and a motion sensor to trigger a 15-second wave pattern when it is dark and motion is present. Model the logic with Idle, Wave, and Cooldown states.
Apply gamma-corrected fade curves by stepping through a precomputed table in a bounded loop to avoid abrupt changes. Update PWM at 100 Hz.
Create a candle flicker effect using a bounded loop cycling through a deterministic 256-value sequence with min and max brightness clamps to look natural.
Drive a status beacon that indicates three levels by color and flash rate. Implement a Level1/Level2/Level3 state machine and keep worst-case update under 5 ms.
Map a rotary encoder to hue from 0 to 360 degrees while keeping brightness constant at 60%. Handle wraparound with a bounded loop and update at 50 Hz.
With two switches, define: if either is ON, ramp to 30% brightness; if both are ON, ramp to 100%; else fade off. Constrain ramp steps to finish within 1 second.
Use PID control to maintain 300 lx at a light sensor by adjusting LED PWM. Sample at 50 Hz, apply anti-windup, clip outputs, and enter a Fault state if the sensor reading is invalid.

Regulate color temperature using two PWM channels (warm and cool) with feedback from a color sensor reporting CCT in Kelvin. Update at 20 Hz, keep total brightness constant, and shut down if temperature exceeds 70 C.
Fuse accelerometer magnitude (m/s^2) and audio RMS to drive pattern intensity. Weight the signals and update at 100 Hz while a bounded loop draws a 60-LED moving effect.
Track a time-varying brightness profile defined in lux using PID, ensuring WCET per tick is under 2 ms and jitter is bounded. On any timing overrun, fall back to a safe 10% output.
Calibrate a photodiode at startup with a bounded loop of 128 steps, then run a closed-loop strobe that keeps perceived duty constant. Use a Calibrate, Run, and Fault state machine.

Implement thermal management where a PI controller limits PWM so the LED heat sink stays below 85 C. If over-temperature occurs, enter Cooldown. Control loop at 10 Hz; limit step changes to minimize flicker.

Combine an RGB color sensor and lux sensor to produce output that is the complementary hue while holding 200 lx. Provide Auto and Manual modes and fail safe to off if any sensor is stale for more than 500 ms.

Synchronize the brightness of two separate light channels so their measured lux match within ±5 lx using PID on each channel. Update at 50 Hz and cap the equalization routine to 100 iterations per command.
Stabilize hue using a simplified Kalman-like filter that fuses noisy color sensor readings before driving PWM. Run at 60 Hz, target WCET under 3 ms, and degrade to monochrome on filter divergence.
Drive a 100-LED moving pattern using a tightly bounded loop with a known upper limit, and guarantee WCET under 1 ms at a 1 kHz update rate. Clamp brightness to 70% for eye safety.

Design a multi-mode lighting controller with Gallery, Show, Emergency, and Sleep modes. Use a hierarchical state machine, bounded loops per pattern, 10 Hz control and 1 kHz PWM rates, diagnostics and startup self-test. Require WCET under 2 ms and graceful degradation on sensor faults, and outline a test plan with scenario checks.

Create a scheduled stage art system with crossfades, chases, and strobes executed on precise timelines. Use bounded loops and deadline checks to prevent overruns. Include a verification harness description with simulated inputs, and enforce: max 80% duty, thermal cutoff at 75 C, and eyesafe strobe limit of 10 Hz.

Build an interactive installation with touch and proximity control, sensor fusion for color themes, and PID brightness regulation to 250 lx in Auto mode. Include manual override, logging of rate overruns, a comprehensive Fault/Recovery state machine, rate groups (control 50 Hz, effects 100 Hz), and WCET budgets and tests.

Specify a wearable light art controller offering at least eight patterns selected via a finite state machine. Use bounded loops to limit per-pattern steps, include a calibration routine, auto-dimming via ambient sensor, motion-reactive color via accelerometer, thermal derating above 60 C, battery low-level dimming, and acceptance tests with performance metrics.

Architect a large LED mural driver for 256 pixels with layered effects: base gradient, overlay sparkle, and event-driven flashes. Require deterministic execution using bounded loops, render at 120 Hz and control at 30 Hz, a WCET proof under 4 ms, a fault-tolerant mode switching strategy, and a test matrix for edge cases.

Make a single LED ramp up brightness with PWM when a button is pressed, and ramp down when released. Use a bounded loop for the fade steps, run the control at 100 Hz, and clamp the duty cycle to a safe maximum of 60%.
Create a simple breathing effect for one LED: fade from 0% to 100% and back over a 3 s cycle. Implement the fade as exactly 120 bounded steps at 200 Hz to avoid flicker.
Map an analog level (0–100%) to a single LED's PWM brightness. Update at 50 Hz, saturate to the range 5%–95%, and ignore rapid jitter by holding values for at least 100 ms.
Blink one LED at 2 Hz with a 25% duty cycle using PWM. Enforce timing jitter under 5 ms and annotate the task rate.
Implement tap-tempo: each button double-tap sets a blink rate for a single LED between 0.5 and 5 Hz. Keep a bounded loop to flash the LED for exactly 3 pulses when a new tempo is learned.
Make a double-blink attention pattern on one LED every 5 s: two 50 ms flashes separated by 100 ms, then 5 s idle. Use a bounded loop for the two flashes and schedule at a fixed rate.
On power-up, soft-start a single LED from 0% to 40% PWM over 2 s with no overshoot. Run the ramp at 100 Hz in a bounded number of steps.
While a button is held, gradually increase LED brightness; when released, decrease it back to 0. Use bounded step increments at 100 Hz and ensure brightness changes are monotonic.
Continuously play a 64-step lookup-table fade pattern on one LED at 120 Hz. The loop over pattern indices must be bounded and wrap cleanly.
Implement a 10-second timer indicator on one LED: increase brightness by 10 equal steps, one per second, then turn off. Use a bounded loop for the 10 steps and enforce the 1 Hz timing.
Blink SOS in Morse code on a single LED using PWM for on/off. Encode the pattern as a bounded sequence and execute it at a fixed rate.
On startup, flash a single LED three times (100 ms on, 100 ms off), then hold steady at 20% brightness. Implement the three flashes via a bounded loop.
Drive one LED at a steady 70% PWM with a base frequency of at least 1 kHz, but delay turn-on by 100 ms after boot to avoid inrush.
When a button is pressed, strobe a single LED at 10 Hz for 500 ms and then return to the previous brightness level. Keep the 5 pulses in a bounded loop.
When a stop command arrives, fade a single LED down to 0 over 5 s; if a start command arrives during the fade, cancel and hold at 40%. Implement the fade steps as a bounded loop at 50 Hz.

For an installation with N LEDs in a line, run a color wipe pattern that turns on one LED at a time at 60 Hz until all N are lit, then clears and repeats. Use a bounded loop over N and limit brightness to 30%.
Make a small controller with a state machine: Off, Steady, and Breathe modes for an LED. A debounced button cycles through states; the breathe uses a bounded ramp. Annotate a 100 Hz update rate.
Create a three-LED 'traffic light' art sequence: Green 5 s, Yellow 1 s, Red 5 s, looping. In the last second of Green, blink at 4 Hz. Use a state machine and bounded loops for the blink counts.

On an RGB LED, crossfade through a six-color palette (red, yellow, green, cyan, blue, magenta), holding each color 1 s. Implement palette indexing with a bounded loop and cap maximum channel PWM to 50%.
Read two knobs: one sets global brightness, one chooses among four patterns. Use a state machine to select the current pattern, clamp inputs to valid ranges, and apply updates at 50 Hz.
Use an ambient light sensor to drive a lamp's PWM inversely: darker room, brighter lamp. Add an 8-sample bounded moving average to reduce flicker, cap output at 70%, and update at 20 Hz.
Run a chaser on 8 discrete LEDs at 5 steps per second. Reverse direction on button press. Iterate with a bounded loop over 8 positions and pause 200 ms at each endpoint.
Build a metronome light: given a BPM input, flash a LED pulse of width 50 ms on each beat. Enforce rate bounds 30–240 BPM, clamp out-of-range values, and keep jitter under 2 ms.
Map temperature in Celsius (0–40 C) to an RGB hue from blue to red and update every 500 ms. Limit total brightness to 40% and smooth transitions with a bounded 10-step crossfade.
Create a candle flicker effect using a precomputed 32-entry table of duty cycles, looping at 120 Hz. The loop must be bounded and repeatable for deterministic behavior.
Implement a sunrise routine: over 15 minutes, ramp from 0% to 100% PWM; if a cancel input is asserted, fade back to 0% over 10 s. Model behavior with a state machine and run at 10 Hz.
Detect a quick double-press to enter a strobe mode at 20 Hz for 2 s; otherwise hold steady at a user-set brightness. Use a state machine with timers and cap strobe duty to 30%.
Control three independent LED channels forming a scene. Long-press saves current levels as a preset; short-press recalls. Crossfade between scenes over 1 s using bounded step loops at 50 Hz.

Implement a 'sparkle' on an LED strip by lighting exactly 5 pixels per frame at random positions from a deterministic sequence. Constrain the loop to select 5 indices per 60 Hz frame and limit pixel brightness.
Build a bicycle safety light with Day and Night modes based on a light sensor threshold. Use a state machine with differing flash patterns per mode and ensure Night never drops below 5% PWM.
Drive an RGB LED with a slow 0.25 Hz breathing pattern. Ensure the PWM base frequency is above 500 Hz to prevent visible flicker, set a 100 Hz control rate, and verify WCET under 2 ms.
Schedule three different patterns sequentially: 30 s Breathe, 30 s Chase, 30 s Solid, then repeat. Use a state machine with timed transitions and ensure no rate overrun between tasks.
Crossfade two LEDs in opposite directions over 3 s. Implement a bounded 60-step ramp, and switch which LED is rising on each button press.
Program a theatre chase on a strip: exactly 3 on, 3 off repeating, advancing one position per frame at 30 Hz. Use a bounded loop over the segment length and wrap cleanly.
Indicate battery level on an RGB LED with five discrete colors and brightness levels. Add hysteresis so the indication only changes if level moves by more than 5% and update once per second.

Maintain 150 lux at a sensor using closed-loop dimming on one LED with a PID controller. Sample at 50 Hz, bound PWM to 0–80%, include anti-windup, fail safe to off on sensor fault, and keep WCET under 1 ms.

Control a tunable-white fixture to hit target CCT between 3000 K and 6500 K by mixing warm and cool channels. Use a PID per channel with feedback from a color sensor at 20 Hz, and limit total duty to prevent overcurrent.

Fuse ambient light (lux) and time-of-day to set an art lamp’s brightness: brighter in day, softer at night. Use a low-pass filter and bound the ramp rate to 10% per second. Update at 1 Hz and cap maximum at 60%.

Animate a moving highlight across an LED array of N elements at 100 Hz. The loop over N must be bounded. Enforce that total compute per frame stays under 2 ms and scale brightness so when N > 100, no element exceeds 40%.
Generate precise stroboscopic bursts at 1000 Hz for a visual illusion. Use a bounded sequence of bursts limited to 10 s total exposure, with each burst at max 50% brightness. Annotate rate and WCET.
Derate brightness based on temperature: above 60 C, linearly reduce allowed PWM from 80% down to 20% at 80 C; shut down at 90 C with hysteresis on recovery. Update at 5 Hz and log state transitions.

Coordinate four lighting zones with synchronized beats. Each zone runs its own state machine pattern, but a master limiter enforces a 2 A current budget by scaling PWM. Use bounded loops per zone and verify no limiter oscillation.
Keep perceived luminance constant while sweeping hue on an RGBW fixture using calibration LUTs. Use a bounded 32-step gamma-corrected table, run at 100 Hz, and ensure transitions have no overshoot.
Hold a display panel at 300 cd/m^2 using a photodiode and a PID at 200 Hz. Keep PWM base at 20 kHz, clamp integral rate of change per cycle, and detect sensor faults to fall back to 20% safe mode.

Enforce eye-safety by preventing steady flicker between 3–70 Hz. If a requested blink falls in that band, shift to the nearest safe frequency. Model configuration and enforcement as a state machine with defined timing.

Design a lighting controller with three modes: Setup, Show, and Safe. Show contains multiple patterns chosen by cues. Implement as a state machine, annotate task rates (30–120 Hz), bound all loops, and define tests that simulate 4 hours to verify max brightness ≤ 60%, no missed deadlines, and correct failover to Safe.

Create a stage controller with five scenes and two buttons for previous/next. Each scene runs at a specific rate (30, 60, 120 Hz) and includes chasers and breathers using bounded loops. Provide a test plan with trace assertions for scene transitions, timing, and brightness limits.

Build a gallery system with Day, Night, Emergency, and Maintenance modes. Emergency forces all LEDs to 100% for at most 10 minutes then drops to 30%. Enforce thermal and current limits, use bounded loops for patterns, annotate rates, and include comprehensive tests and fault injection.

Implement a multi-mode RGB controller that enforces a color-blind–friendly palette and constant luminance. Require gamma-corrected mapping via bounded LUTs, run at 90 Hz, and define acceptance tests ensuring no luminance step exceeds 15% and deadlines are met.

Program a 10-minute master timeline with scheduled cues that trigger per-cue patterns across three LED groups. Support pause/resume with deterministic replay. Specify rates, bound loops, ensure drift < 50 ms over 10 minutes, and include tests for fallback to steady 20% on fault.

Make a single indicator LED toggle between 0% and 100% PWM when a pushbutton is pressed. Debounce the button, run the control at 100 Hz, start safely with the LED off, and ensure the PWM never exceeds 100%.
Create a smooth fade-in/fade-out effect at 0.5 Hz that repeats exactly 20 cycles using a bounded loop. Limit brightness to 80% PWM and update the fade at 50 Hz.
Cycle a single RGB LED through solid red, green, and blue, holding each color for 2 seconds at a capped 60% brightness. Do one bounded pass through the three colors, then turn off.
Blink an LED at 4 Hz with a 25% duty cycle using PWM. Run continuously and enforce a safety limit so the duty cycle never exceeds 40% under any condition.
Map a rotary knob position linearly to LED brightness from 0% to 90% PWM. Update at 50 Hz, clip out-of-range inputs, and ignore tiny jitter changes below 1%.
If ambient light falls below a threshold, gently ramp a lamp to 40% brightness over 2 seconds; otherwise hold 5%. Sample the light sensor at 20 Hz and rate-limit brightness changes.
Use a touch input to toggle a white LED between off, 15% brightness, and 70% brightness. Reject touches closer than 200 ms apart and default to safe off on startup.
When a momentary switch is pressed, emit a 1.0 s flash at 80% PWM, then return to 10% nightlight. The pulse length must be strictly bounded and unaffected by repeated presses.
Program a heartbeat pattern: two short blinks followed by a pause. Repeat this sequence exactly 30 times using a bounded loop and cap brightness at 50% PWM.
On power-up, run a 3-LED chase at 5 steps per second for 10 steps, then turn all off. Guarantee worst-case execution time under 1 ms per step.
Blend warm and cool white channels to a user-selected color temperature, maintaining a total duty cap so the combined PWM never exceeds 85%. Refresh at 25 Hz.
Fade a single LED from 0% to 100% over 5 seconds and hold. Perform the fade once only, driven by a 100 Hz update rate.
While a button is held, sweep brightness up and then down once over 2 seconds. Releasing the button at any time cancels the sweep and returns to safe off.
Generate a sawtooth brightness from 10% to 60% repeatedly for 120 seconds. Update the waveform at 100 Hz and ensure the pattern duration is bounded.
Set an RGB LED’s static color using three sliders. Enforce that the sum of the channel duty cycles never exceeds 100%, and refresh at 20 Hz.

Build a state machine with modes OFF, FADE, and STROBE selected by a 3-position input. Each mode has its own timing rate; default to OFF. If an overcurrent flag is seen, enter ERROR and force all PWM to 0%. Use bounded loops for any timed sub-sequences.
Use two buttons to control an RGB LED: one cycles hue, the other scales intensity. Update at 50 Hz, debounce inputs, and maintain a power budget by limiting the sum of channel PWMs to 120%.
Create a sunrise: ramp warm white from 0% to 80% over 20 minutes. Pause the ramp if ambient light exceeds 300 lux, and cancel to OFF on user command. Run this at a steady 1 Hz control rate.
A hallway runner reacts to motion: IDLE -> RUN -> FADE -> IDLE. Light segments in order at 10 steps per second, then fade out over 1 second. Bound worst-case execution to <2 ms per step.

Create a sparkle effect across 10 LEDs: randomly choose one LED each second to flash to 70% for 200 ms, ensuring only one is lit at a time. Produce exactly 600 flashes using a bounded loop, then stop. Update at 100 Hz.
Make a nightlight that turns on to 20% when ambient falls below 50 lux and off otherwise. Smooth the decision using a bounded window averaging the last 10 samples. Run at 10 Hz.
Implement a pattern selector with three modes: CHASE, RAINBOW, and PULSE. Each runs for exactly 60 seconds then returns to OFF. Cap brightness at 75% and drive updates at 100 Hz.
Use a bicolor LED to show battery state: 3.3–3.6 V = green 50%, 3.0–3.3 V = amber mix, <3.0 V = red blink at 1 Hz. Add 0.05 V hysteresis to prevent chatter and sample at 20 Hz.
Program a color wipe across 8 LEDs, forward then reverse, advancing one LED every 100 ms. Loop for a user-set count between 1 and 20, enforcing bounds, and then stop.
Crossfade between two preset colors over 10 seconds, hold for 5 seconds, then fade back. Repeat this bounded cycle 10 times and limit each channel to 65% PWM.
Single-click sets a solid color; double-click starts a theater-chase for 30 seconds; long-press forces an ERROR state where all LEDs turn off. Debounce 30 ms and update at 50 Hz.
If a proximity value rises quickly, trigger a 0.3 s white flash capped at 60% PWM; otherwise show a slow 1 Hz breathing. Use a two-state machine with a 2 s cooldown enforced via a bounded loop.
Simulate candlelight by cycling brightness between 30% and 55% using a precomputed table of 64 values in a bounded loop at 40 Hz. After 15 minutes of operation, shut off.
Drive a 10-LED bargraph from a microphone envelope: map 0.0–1.0 to 0–10 lit LEDs and refresh at 25 Hz. Include a 0.2 s decay time and cap overall duty to prevent overheating.
Implement status indications with an RGB LED: IDLE = blue breathing at 10%, ACTIVE = green solid 40%, WARNING = yellow blinking at 2 Hz. Change states on command and keep WCET under 1 ms.
Create a phase-shifted wave around a ring where adjacent LEDs have 30-degree phase offsets and a 4 s period. Run continuously at 100 Hz, with a user-adjustable brightness scale bounded 0–100%.
Build a minute-long light routine: first 30 s rainbow at 0.1 cycles/s, next 15 s white pulse at 2 Hz, final 15 s off. Timing must be accurate within ±50 ms using bounded loops for each segment.

Two capacitive buttons control effects: one starts a 10-cycle strobe at 8 Hz, the other sets steady 20% brightness. If both touch inputs are active, enter a safe OFF state and latch until power cycle.
Add a night mode scheduler: from 22:00 to 06:00 cap brightness at 15%, otherwise allow up to 80%. Implement a DAY/NIGHT state machine running at 1 Hz, maintaining local 24-hour time.

For a 12-LED ring, rotate a single lit pixel at 6 steps/s, accelerating to 12 steps/s after 10 rotations. Complete exactly 60 rotations using bounded counting, ensure index wrap is safe, and run at 100 Hz.

Implement a PID controller that regulates a white LED to 300 lux based on a photodiode. Update at 50 Hz, clamp PWM between 0–70%, include anti-windup, and if the sensor is invalid for >200 ms, enter FAILSAFE and turn the LED off.

Fuse two ambient light sensors with outlier rejection (discard if one deviates by >40%) to estimate lux. Use the fused value to maintain perceived brightness at 150 lux while a knob selects hue. Control at 25 Hz, total RGB PWM capped at 80%; on fusion failure, default to 20% white.

Create a closed-loop color temperature controller for tunable white: hold 4000 K ±100 K with a PI loop at 20 Hz using a color sensor. Enforce 5% PWM per-update slew limits, clamp combined duty to 75%, and derate brightness above 60 °C while blinking amber to warn.

Use IMU fusion (complementary filter at 100 Hz) to estimate tilt angle. Map tilt to hue (0–360°) and angular velocity to brightness (10–70% PWM). Provide a SAFE mode forcing 0% if the IMU reports an error. Keep WCET under 2 ms.

Build an adaptive strobe targeting 20 lux peak using PID to adjust PWM pulse width at 200 Hz. Limit strobe frequency to 8–12 Hz selectable by a switch, and enforce eye-safety with a maximum 1.5 ms on-time per flash and a 50% duty ceiling.

Control a 4-zone light wall with a state machine: OFF, CALIBRATE, SHOW, THERMAL_LIMIT. In CALIBRATE, step each zone through 10 bounded intensity levels and measure, then run SHOW for 5 minutes at 60 Hz. If any zone exceeds 55 °C, scale that zone to 25%. Add a watchdog that forces OFF after 10 minutes of inactivity.

Maintain perceived brightness via gamma 2.2 mapping and a PI loop using a photodetector. Sample at 100 Hz, bound the integral term, cap PWM at 90%, and enter an ERROR state if the sensor saturates for more than 100 ms.

Detect beats by fusing two microphones’ envelopes (median over 3 samples per mic, then average) and drive a 16-LED ring with radial pulses on each beat. Run the visual pipeline at 200 Hz, keep WCET under 3 ms, and limit estimated total current to 500 mA.

Stabilize an RGB LED to neutral white by controlling CIE xy near (0.33, 0.33) within ±0.01. Use a color sensor and decoupled PI adjustments at 50 Hz, clamp the sum of channel PWMs to 85%, and if any channel saturates, fall back to the closest achievable white and blink a status LED at 1 Hz.

Design an adaptive hallway wave that uses occupancy and ambient light; fuse their readings by taking the maximum. If occupied and ambient <100 lux, animate a moving wave whose speed scales with motion intensity; otherwise hold 5% dim. Jerk-limit transitions to 10% PWM per 50 ms and fail off after 2 minutes without activity.

Develop a programmable controller with four patterns (CHASE, SPARKLE, WAVE, STATIC) selected by a dial. Each pattern runs exactly N cycles (1–100) via bounded loops, then returns to IDLE. Include a scheduler enforcing per-pattern WCET budgets (CHASE 1 ms, SPARKLE 1.5 ms, WAVE 2 ms, STATIC 0.5 ms) at 100 Hz, hard limits of per-channel PWM <=90% and aggregate current <=600 mA, and a verification harness with assertions for rate, cycle counts, and safety invariants.

Design a dual-loop tunable white controller: an outer 1 Hz loop sets a target lux following a sunrise/sunset curve with a 22:00–06:00 cap of 20%; an inner 50 Hz PID drives a photodiode to the target using warm/cool mix with sum <=80%. Include sensor-dropout fail dark within 100 ms, thermal derating above 55 °C, and a comprehensive test suite for steps, saturation, anti-windup, and timing margins.

Specify an interactive gallery light with layered control: BASE wash maintains 120 lux via PI; SPOT highlights trigger on proximity for a bounded 5 s with soft fades; ACCENT sparkles randomly up to 3 per second with a bounded queue of 5. Global constraints: 100 Hz updates, WCET <2 ms, total PWM budget 85%, jerk-limited transitions. Include a boot self-test and a structured test plan covering sensor spikes, simultaneous triggers, and thermal alarms.

Create a smooth fade-up and fade-down effect for a single LED using PWM at 200 Hz. Ramp from 0% to 90% duty in 2.0 s, then back to 0% in 2.0 s, repeating in a bounded loop exactly 5 times and then turning off. Ensure the duty cycle never exceeds 90%.
Blink one LED with precise timing: on for 400 ms, off for 600 ms (1 Hz overall). Use a rate attribute so timing is stable, and iterate in a bounded loop for exactly 60 cycles before stopping.
Make a button-controlled dimmer for a single LED. Each press cycles brightness through 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100%, then back to 25%. Include 50 ms debounce and hold the chosen level steadily.
Set an RGB LED to a solid color given three 8-bit intensity inputs (0–255) for red, green, and blue. Clip out-of-range values, apply the PWM levels, and hold indefinitely without flicker.

Implement a gentle breathing effect on a single LED: sinusoidal brightness from 5% to 70% over a 5 s period. Run the control loop at 100 Hz and keep the effect active for 10 minutes using a bounded loop, then shut off.
When a momentary button is pressed, flash an LED three times quickly: 100 ms on, 100 ms off, repeated exactly three times using a bounded loop, then return to steady off. Include 30 ms debounce.

On startup, perform a soft brightness sweep on a white LED: ramp from 0% to 80% over 1.0 s, then hold at 80%. Limit duty cycle to a maximum of 80% to respect a notional 20 mA current limit. Run the PWM at 500 Hz.

Use an ambient light sensor (0–1000 lux) to set LED brightness inversely. Map 0 lux to 100% duty and 1000 lux to 10% duty, clamped to that range. Update at 10 Hz, and limit brightness slew to 20% per second to avoid visible flicker.
Alternate two LEDs so that A is on while B is off, then swap every 250 ms. Run with a precise rate attribute and repeat for 40 swaps using a bounded loop, then leave both off.
Make a crisp strobe: drive a white LED with 30% duty at 2 Hz, using PWM for brightness and a stable timing loop.
Set an RGB LED to a static pastel mix: 60% red, 70% green, 90% blue. Apply these as PWM duty targets and hold without fluctuation.

Create a simple nightlight: if ambient light drops below 50 lux, pulse a warm LED gently between 20% and 50% brightness with a 6 s period; otherwise keep it off. Update at 5 Hz with smooth transitions.
Implement a millisecond-accurate strobe counter: emit 50 ms flashes at 120 BPM (two flashes per second), repeating for exactly 100 flashes using a bounded loop, then stop.
Turn an LED on when a switch is closed and off when open, but add a 100 ms confirmation delay to avoid chatter-induced flicker. Keep behavior deterministic.

Simulate a candle flicker around a 60% average brightness. Vary PWM randomly within ±10% at 25 updates per second, constrain changes to avoid spikes, run the effect for 30 s using a bounded loop, then hold steady at 50%.

Drive a row of 8 LEDs with a moving dot that scans left to right and back (“bounce” effect). Use a bounded loop to step at 20 positions per second and ensure the endpoints hold for 100 ms before reversing.

Provide two buttons: one cycles through three RGB patterns (solid, pulse, rainbow), the other adjusts pattern speed (slow/medium/fast). Implement as a state machine with debounced inputs and safe transitions. Use a rate attribute to keep timing stable.

Read a potentiometer to set overall LED brightness from 5% to 100%. A footswitch toggles enable/disable. Apply a 10% per second slew limit. Ensure that when disabled, PWM duty is forced to 0% within 50 ms.

Create day/night behavior for an RGB LED: Day mode shows a cool static color, Night mode runs a slow warm breathing pattern. Switch modes based on an ambient light threshold with 5 lux hysteresis. Model as a state machine and update at 20 Hz.

Detect single-tap vs double-tap on a button (double-tap within 300 ms). Single-tap toggles a steady white light at 60% brightness; double-tap starts a 2 Hz pulse. Debounce inputs and ensure deterministic timing.

Implement a traffic-light sequence using three LEDs: Green 5 s, Amber 2 s, Red 5 s, repeating. Use a state machine and assert an invariant that Green and Red are never on at the same time. Run for 5 full cycles using a bounded loop.
Cycle an RGB LED through the full hue wheel smoothly over 30 s, wrapping back to the start. Use a 100 Hz control rate and ensure consistent saturation and brightness. Repeat indefinitely.
Make two LEDs blink out of phase at 2 Hz: when A is on, B is off, and vice versa. Every minute, realign phases to correct drift so that perfect anti-phase is maintained.

Respond to external trigger pulses by producing a 150 ms bright flash on an LED. Ignore triggers that occur within 100 ms of the previous accepted trigger. Time-stamp events and ensure flashes do not overlap.

Use a motion sensor to control a warm white LED with these states: Idle (off), FadingUp (2 s to 80%), Hold (10 s), FadingDown (2 s to 0%). Retriggering in Hold extends the timer. Implement as a state machine with a 50 Hz update rate.

Create a four-LED “Knight rider” effect with a moving bright spot and a faint trail. Update at 60 Hz. The spot bounces at the ends and the trail decays over 300 ms. Use bounded loops to manage positions and intensities.

Control color temperature from 2700 K to 6500 K on an RGB LED using a rotary encoder. Map turns to CCT changes, apply smooth transitions, and clamp brightness to 80% max. Include push-to-toggle between warm and cool presets.

Implement a progress bar across 10 LEDs that fills linearly over 30 s, then resets. Provide a reset button to restart immediately. Ensure each LED’s brightness steps are synchronized and flicker-free.

Build a pattern library with three options: rainbow cycle, uniform blink, and random sparkle. Select pattern via a 2-bit input. Use a state machine for pattern selection and rate attributes per pattern for stable timing.

Run an LED pattern at a fixed 200 Hz control rate. If any cycle exceeds its 5 ms deadline more than 3 times in a 10 s window, enter a safe state with all LEDs off and a diagnostic indicator blinking at 1 Hz.

Monitor a temperature sensor to protect LEDs: above 55 C, linearly reduce brightness down to 20% by 70 C; below 50 C, restore normal operation. Apply 2 C hysteresis to avoid chattering. Update at 10 Hz.

Create a brightness ramp function that moves from the current level to a target level over a specified time in milliseconds. Ignore ramp times longer than 10,000 ms, and enforce a minimum of 100 ms. Ensure bounded slope and no overshoot.

Produce an emergency flash pattern on a single LED: three short 100 ms flashes separated by 100 ms off, then one long 500 ms flash, followed by a 1 s pause. Repeat for exactly 10 cycles using a bounded loop.

Implement a twinkle effect on 12 LEDs where at most 3 are twinkling at any time. Randomly select LEDs to fade up and down over 800 ms. Prevent the same LED from being chosen twice in a row and keep timing deterministic.

Synchronize an RGB breathing effect across multiple units using a periodic sync input. Lock phase on each sync edge; if no sync is received for 1.0 s, hold the current color steadily as a fault response.

Close the loop on LED brightness using a light sensor: maintain 300 lux at the surface with a PID controller running at 200 Hz. Constrain PWM duty to 5–85%, include anti-windup, and settle within 2 s. Ensure WCET per cycle is <= 4 ms.

Fuse ambient light and proximity readings to set color: when a person is near, shift toward warm (lower CCT); in bright ambient conditions, reduce overall brightness. Update at 20 Hz with bounded smoothing filters to avoid jitter.

Design a protective state machine for a high-power LED: states are Normal, ThermalLimiting, and Shutdown. Use temperature (Celsius) and estimated current (mA) to enforce a power budget, reduce brightness proactively, and only recover with hysteresis. Include a watchdog that forces LEDs off on missed deadlines.

Implement precise PWM dimming with perceptual gamma correction and time-dithering to achieve 12-bit effective resolution while keeping the PWM base rate at 1 kHz. Guarantee the control task’s WCET is under 1 ms and use bounded loops for lookup operations.

Create a step-sequenced color engine that executes a script of up to 20 steps, each with an RGB target and duration in milliseconds. Validate inputs, execute with bounded loops, and fail safe (all off) if a step is invalid.

Use a color sensor (X, Y, Z or similar) to stabilize an RGB LED at a target CCT of 4000 K ±100 K and 90% brightness. Update at 50 Hz, reject outlier readings, and enter a safe steady state if sensor consistency degrades by more than 10%.

Build a beat-synchronized strobe that locks to an external tick between 120 and 180 BPM. Compute phase and generate flashes with <= 5 ms jitter. If input is absent for 2.0 s, stop flashing and indicate fault with a slow blink.

Crossfade between two stored RGB scenes over a programmable time (0.5–10 s). Store each scene compactly (no more than 24 bytes), apply an ease-in/ease-out curve, and guarantee monotonic, flicker-free transitions using bounded loops.

Schedule multiple LED patterns on separate groups with rate-monotonic priorities. Define WCET budgets per group, detect overruns, and degrade gracefully by disabling the lowest-priority pattern first. Ensure a safe-all-off fallback.

Perform an auto-calibration of a light sensor against LED output by sweeping duty from 0% to 80% in 5% steps, measuring at each step, and fitting a linear model. Limit the routine to 10 s, store coefficients, then use them for accurate closed-loop brightness.

Design a multi-mode art lighting controller with modes: Install, Show, Night, and Safe. Each mode has distinct patterns and rates. Implement a supervisory state machine with health monitoring (missed deadlines, over-temperature), invariants (duty <= 85%, temp <= 60 C), manual override input, and a bounded 5 s self-test at startup.

Specify an interactive RGB installation with user tempo and palette inputs plus ambient brightness control and motion-triggered effects. Modes: Idle, Attract, Interact, Fault. Provide a full test plan: unit tests for state transitions, timing verification at declared rates, and proofs that pattern loops are bounded and deterministic.

Create safety-critical emergency lighting with dual redundant light sensors and a thermal sensor. Use sensor voting and cross-checks, define WCET <= 2 ms at a 500 Hz control rate, and assert that darkness-to-full-brightness latency is < 150 ms. Include an exhaustive test matrix and a fail-safe off state on disagreement.

Define a pattern engine that supports bounded user-defined sequences, per-pattern rate attributes, and seamless hot-swapping between patterns with no visible artifacts. Provide conformance tests, timing jitter specifications (< 1 ms), and resource budgets (CPU < 60%, memory < 2 KB). Default to a safe steady state on errors.

Design a distributed multi-zone lighting controller for 4 zones, each with its own state machine and safety constraints, coordinated by a global controller that enforces a total current cap of 500 mA and an emergency-off input. Include simulation hooks, fault injection tests, and acceptance criteria for latency, flicker, and thermal safety.
Create a PWM 'breathing' effect on a single LED that smoothly fades up and down over 2 s, running as a bounded loop for 60 cycles at a fixed update rate of 100 Hz.
When a pushbutton is pressed, toggle a single LED between 0% and 100% brightness with 50 ms debounce; execute the control at a steady 50 Hz rate and avoid unbounded loops.
Blink an LED at 1 Hz with 30% duty, maintain timing accuracy within 1%, and stop after 120 periods using a bounded loop at a 100 Hz update rate.
Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, and blue, holding each color for 500 ms and fading between them over 100 ms; run 30 cycles as a bounded loop with a 60 Hz update rate.
