Map a knob position to LED PWM brightness 0-100% with a small deadband; limit change to 5% per update at a control rate of 50 Hz.
Make a nightlight that turns on to 20% below 50 lux and off above 55 lux (hysteresis); sample the light sensor at 10 Hz and avoid unbounded loops.
Generate a simple strobe at 5 Hz with 10% duty and cap maximum brightness at 70%; execute 200 flashes using a bounded loop and update PWM at 200 Hz.
Create a single-pixel heartbeat: a double pulse every 2 s with gamma-correct PWM; use a bounded loop for 100 heartbeats at 60 Hz.
Use a two-state machine to toggle an RGB LED between warm white and cool white on button press; support press-and-hold to fade for up to 2 s; run at 50 Hz.
Make a breathing LED that pauses 1 s at peak brightness; enforce a 60 Hz update rate and stop after 100 breaths using bounded loops.
Flash an LED for 200 ms when an audio peak is detected, then decay smoothly; operate at 100 Hz and keep loops bounded to 90 seconds of runtime.
Implement a status LED that blinks three times quickly then stays off for 2 s; use a bounded counter for the 3-blink pattern and update at 20 Hz.
Drive LED brightness from a proximity sensor with cubic easing; clamp to 80% max and refresh at 100 Hz with no unbounded iteration.
If temperature exceeds 45 C, immediately turn the LED off; otherwise allow normal brightness; check temperature at 2 Hz and keep timing deterministic.
Add two buttons to step LED brightness up or down in 10% increments, saturating at 0% and 100%; process inputs at 50 Hz and avoid unbounded loops.
Create an 8-LED chaser that reverses direction on button press; run the pattern at 50 Hz with a bounded loop for 10 full passes and cap brightness at 30%.
Build a mode-based light with a state machine: Idle (solid low white), Rainbow (smooth wheel), and Wipe (left-to-right); button cycles modes; each pattern uses bounded loops and explicit rates.
Crossfade between two user-selected colors over 2 s with an ease-in-out curve, repeating for 120 cycles as a bounded loop at 60 Hz.
Implement a 10-LED VU meter from an audio level input with peak hold and slow decay; refresh at 100 Hz for 90 s using a bounded loop.
Control a tunable white LED: map a knob from 2700 K to 6500 K across warm/cool PWM channels; maintain a 200 Hz update rate to minimize flicker.
Create a palette switcher: short press toggles run/pause, long press selects next color palette; implement as a state machine; patterns run in bounded loops not exceeding 10 s per cycle.
Simulate a traffic light with pedestrian request: enforce min green 5 s, yellow 3 s, and a walk phase; implement as a timed state machine at 20 Hz.
Design a sunrise alarm that ramps from 0% to 100% over 20 minutes; a cancel button triggers a 500 ms fade to black; schedule using bounded loops at 10 Hz.
Make a strobe with knob-adjustable frequency from 1 to 10 Hz; hard-limit to 10 Hz for safety; update at 200 Hz and run for 300 s using bounded loops.
Produce a candle flicker using a seeded pseudo-random sequence with +/-20% brightness variation; update at 60 Hz in a bounded loop for 10 minutes.
Map audio amplitude to LED brightness and band energy to hue for an RGB LED; smooth with a short moving average; refresh at 100 Hz for bounded durations.
Run two patterns concurrently: center zone breathing at 30 Hz and edge zone chase at 60 Hz; guarantee combined WCET under 3 ms within a 20 ms frame.
Use a touch sensor to cycle brightness states low/medium/high; long press enters a color-rotate mode; implement transitions with a debounced state machine at 50 Hz.
Monitor battery voltage and dim LEDs from 50% to 10% as voltage drops from 3.6 V to 3.3 V; below 3.3 V turn off; update at 5 Hz with deterministic timing.
Reduce PWM duty by 1% per degree above 40 C, clamped to 30% minimum; sample temperature at 2 Hz while pattern updates at 60 Hz; keep loops bounded.
Trigger a ripple that propagates across 16 LEDs when proximity increases; define a bounded loop length for the wave and update at 100 Hz.
With two buttons, start a 120-step color chase or stop and fade to black over 500 ms; enforce input-to-output latency under 50 ms at a 50 Hz control rate.
Create a theater chase using a 3-color palette; switch to the next palette every minute; run as bounded loops and maintain a 30 Hz refresh.
Render a rainbow wheel across 12 LEDs with seamless wrap-around; verify index wrap logic; run for 5 minutes as a bounded loop at 60 Hz.
Implement a status indicator: green while running, red when stopped, blue when reset; blink at 2 Hz on error; define a state machine and a 20 Hz update rate.
Hold a target of 200 lux on a surface using a PID controller on PWM brightness with photodiode feedback; sample at 50 Hz, clamp 0-80% duty, include anti-windup, and ensure WCET under 1 ms.
Fuse ambient light and motion to adapt brightness: brighten only when motion is present and ambient < 30 lux; use a complementary filter at 10 Hz; drive fades at 100 Hz in bounded loops.
Match a target color using an RGB LED and a color sensor: iteratively adjust until within a DeltaE threshold; limit per-step change to avoid flicker; bound the number of iterations and run at 20 Hz.
Maintain LED case temperature under 60 C via PI control that derates brightness; sample at 5 Hz; if temperature exceeds 75 C, enter a fault state flashing red at 2 Hz; use a state machine.

Schedule a dual-pattern setup: a backlight gradient at 30 Hz and a sparkle overlay at 100 Hz; define deterministic rates and guarantee total WCET under 4 ms in each 10 ms frame; bounded loops for sparkles.

Provide flicker-minimized PWM dimming using a 1 kHz carrier with optional spread-spectrum; include a control to enable/disable it; sweep brightness 0-100% in bounded steps and verify no visible flicker.
Implement brownout-safe lighting: if supply drops below 4.5 V, fade to 10% within 100 ms and hold; after 2 s of recovery, restore the previous level; model behavior as a fail-safe state machine.
Create an orientation-reactive light: fuse accelerometer and gyroscope to estimate tilt, map tilt to hue/brightness, filter at 50 Hz, update LEDs at 100 Hz, and bound computation time per frame.
Enforce photosensitive safety for a strobe pattern: cap frequency to 8 Hz, duty to 20%, and brightness to 60%; reject unsafe parameters; include safety assertions and bounded loops for effect length.
Run a gamma calibration: show stepped brightness levels using bounded loops, accept user input via button to adjust the gamma curve, store the result, and keep step changes under 5%.

Design a multi-mode lighting controller with modes Gallery, Party, Night, and Emergency using a hierarchical state machine with timed substates; assign explicit update rates per mode and guarantee WCET < 2 ms within a 10 ms frame; assert brightness stays within 0-85%.

Build a four-zone scheduler where each zone runs its own bounded-loop pattern at 20, 30, 60, and 100 Hz respectively; add a watchdog, a startup self-test that exercises each LED, and a safe fallback if any task overruns.

Compose a 300 s light show using a cue list of colors and transitions; ensure deterministic timing; specify behavior on missed deadlines (skip to next cue); log all mode transitions and keep loops bounded per cue.

Implement a configuration-driven pattern loader that reads parameters from a small config block; validate bounds and lengths to prevent overflow; include tests for state transitions and prove no unbounded loops exist.

Create a redundant auto-dimming system using two ambient light sensors; fuse readings and if they disagree by more than 15 lux for over 3 s, enter degraded mode at fixed 40% brightness; run at 10 Hz with a WCET budget of 1 ms.

Make a single LED breathe smoothly forever using PWM: fade from 0% to 100% and back over 4 seconds total, updated at a control rate of 100 Hz. Use a bounded loop for the fade steps and ensure the duty cycle never changes by more than 5% per 50 ms to avoid flicker.
Blink one LED at 2 Hz with a 25% duty cycle for 10 seconds after power-on, then turn it off. Enforce a control rate attribute of 200 Hz and guarantee worst-case execution time below 0.5 ms per tick.
On startup, ramp a single LED from 0% to 70% brightness in 1.0 s, then hold 70% steadily. Use PWM and a bounded loop of exactly 50 steps, with monotonic increases only.
Create a gentle breathing effect on one LED: inhale in 1.5 s, exhale in 1.5 s, continuously. Keep the control loop at 120 Hz and limit instantaneous duty changes to prevent visible stepping.

Output the Morse code SOS on a single LED forever. Dots are 200 ms, dashes are 600 ms, symbol gaps are 200 ms, letter gaps are 600 ms, and word gaps are 1.4 s. Implement with bounded loops and maintain timing using a 100 Hz rate attribute.

Simulate candle flicker on one warm LED by varying PWM between 30% and 60% at 50 Hz updates. Use a bounded loop to apply 300 randomized steps per cycle, then reseed and repeat. No step may exceed a 6% change.
Flash a single LED once every 60 seconds for exactly 100 ms at 80% brightness, otherwise keep it off. Run the scheduler at 100 Hz and ensure WCET under 0.2 ms per tick.
Implement a repeating double-flash pattern on one LED: 100 ms on, 100 ms off, 100 ms on, then 2 s off. Use bounded loops to structure the sequence and keep the average brightness under safe limits.

Create an 8-step staircase brightness pattern for a single LED: 0%, 15%, 30%, 45%, 60%, 75%, 90%, 100%, each held for 300 ms, then return to 0% and repeat. Ensure a 100 Hz control rate and bounded indexing.

Build a night light that starts at 50% brightness and linearly dims to 10% over 5 minutes, then stays at 10% until power-off. Use PWM with bounded loop steps and no brightness excursions outside 10–50%.
Produce a sawtooth on one LED: ramp from 0% to 80% in 3.0 s, then immediately drop to 0% and repeat. Use a bounded loop with exactly 150 increments and a control rate of 120 Hz.
Toggle a single LED between 10% and 90% brightness every 250 ms continuously. Rate-limit changes to at most 40% per 25 ms and maintain a 200 Hz control loop.
Make a metronome LED that flashes at 120 BPM with a 50 ms pulse on each beat and a slightly longer 100 ms pulse on every 4th beat. Keep timing accurate using a fixed 100 Hz rate.
Within each minute, keep an LED on from second 0 through second 10, then off for the remainder. Implement a bounded loop for the 60-second cycle and update at 20 Hz.
Approximate a sinusoidal brightness waveform on one LED using a 32-entry lookup table. Step through the table at 50 steps per second, loop boundedly, and cap brightness at 85%.

Cycle a rainbow across an RGB LED strip of 30 pixels at 40 updates per second. Use bounded loops to traverse pixels, cap overall brightness at 80%, and add a start/stop input that pauses and resumes the animation cleanly.

Implement brightness up/down via two buttons for a single LED. Each press adjusts by 5% with bounds 10% to 90%. Smooth transitions with a 5% per 20 ms slew limit. Control rate 200 Hz and debounced inputs.

Crossfade an RGB LED through red, green, then blue, dwelling 3 seconds per color. Use a state machine for the three phases, bounded loops for fade steps, and enforce monotonic transitions without overshoot.

Create alternating blue and red flashes on two LED channels: deliver 3 flashes at 10 Hz, then pause 1 s, then switch color and repeat. Use bounded loops and ensure flash frequency never exceeds 10 Hz for safety.

Program a theater chase pattern with white dots moving over a colored background on a strip. Maintain exactly 3 moving dots, 25 updates per second, and a bounded 60-step cycle length. Guarantee WCET under 1 ms per frame.

Make a sound-reactive lamp: when microphone amplitude exceeds a threshold, boost brightness to 85% for 200 ms then decay back to 20%. Otherwise stay at 20%. Rate 100 Hz, with hysteresis to avoid chatter.

Design a sunrise effect: over 15 minutes, ramp total brightness from 5% to 80% while shifting from warm to neutral white (approx. 2000 K to 4000 K) via two LED channels. Use bounded steps (900 per ramp) and cancel cleanly to black if a user stop signal is received.

Implement path lighting triggered by motion: upon trigger, propagate a light ripple across 10 segments spaced 0.1 m at an apparent speed of 0.5 m/s, then fade out after 10 s. Use a 50 Hz loop and queue new triggers without overlap.

Play a fixed palette of 16 colors on an RGB lamp, each shown for 1 s, then wrap. Long-press input skips to the next color. Use a state machine with play, pause, and skip states, and a bounded loop over the 16 entries.

Create a fire-like effect using red and amber channels modulated by low-frequency noise at 30 Hz. Keep average brightness under 60% and resynchronize every 5 s to avoid drift. Use bounded loops for pixel updates.
Simulate a turn indicator: sequentially fill 8 LED segments over 0.8 s, hold full for 0.2 s, then off for 0.4 s; repeat. Implement with a 100 Hz control rate and bounded loops for the fill steps.

Build a light painting wand: while a trigger is held, stream rows from a stored 64-line RGB pattern at 100 lines per second. On release, enter idle. Ensure the line index loops in a bounded manner and timing stays constant.

Create a status beacon with three selectable modes: normal (slow green pulse), caution (steady amber at 40%), and fault (red triple-flash). Implement a robust state machine with glitch-free transitions at 50 Hz.
Make an ambient dimmer: read ambient light in lux and inversely map it to LED brightness from 10% to 80%. Update at 20 Hz with a 0.5 s smoothing time constant to avoid oscillation.

Implement tap-tempo pulsing: user taps a button, compute BPM from the last 4 taps, then pulse an LED at that rate with a 50 ms accent on the downbeat. Use a state machine to manage tap capture and running output with bounded buffers.

Schedule a color pattern on the top of each hour: run a 30-second sequence then revert to a steady 10% white. Ensure the sequence uses bounded loops, completes cleanly, and timing is driven by a fixed-rate clock.

Drive two LED strips with a mirrored gradient: the same color gradient scrolls left on strip A and right on strip B, both 50 pixels. Update at 60 Hz, keep indices bounded, and maintain synchronization across strips.
Render a 10-segment volume bar from an analog level input (0.0 to 1.0). Update at 25 Hz, apply a 100 ms ramp for changes, and cap the maximum at segment 9 to leave a headroom indicator.

Create a breath-with-hold pattern: fade up 3 s, hold 1 s, fade down 3 s, hold 2 s. Use a state machine with explicit timers, bounded loops for fade steps, and ensure PWM is high enough to avoid visible stepping.
Implement a button-controlled lamp: short press toggles steady 50% brightness; long press over 1 s toggles a pulsing mode. Debounce input, ensure only one mode active at a time, and run at 100 Hz.

Closed-loop brightness control: use a photodiode reading in lux to regulate an LED to 300 lux via PWM. Run a PID controller at 200 Hz with anti-windup, constrain duty between 5% and 90%, and limit slew to 10% per 50 ms. Include idle, track, and fault states.

Control a tunable white lamp using warm and cool channels to maintain 3500 K while holding total illuminance at 200 lux. Implement two coordinated controllers (outer loop for lux, inner mixing for CCT), run at 100 Hz, and enforce bounded duty limits.

Build a beat-reactive light using sensor fusion: combine microphone RMS and motion data to detect confident beats. Trigger a 300 ms brightness burst only when both agree. Run at 100 Hz, cap bursts to 4 Hz max for photosensitive safety, and manage envelopes with bounded loops.

Apply gamma-corrected brightness using a 256-entry LUT for an RGB LED to achieve perceptual linearity. Step through animations at 60 Hz with bounded pixel loops and ensure WCET below 0.5 ms per frame.

Implement thermal derating for an LED fixture: read temperature in Celsius; above 60 C linearly derate max duty from 80% down to 40% by 80 C; below 58 C restore gradually. Add 2 C hysteresis to prevent oscillation. Update at 10 Hz with a clear state machine.

Fuse two ambient light sensors (front and side) to control LED brightness to 150 lux. Use a complementary fusion scheme and a PID controlling PWM at 50 Hz. Bound outputs 10–85% and handle sensor disagreement gracefully.

Stabilize RGB color to a target chromaticity measured by a color sensor. Run a multivariable controller at 25 Hz to track target (x,y) while respecting PWM limits. Ensure transitions are continuous and verify steady-state color error under 2%.

Implement a compliant strobe effect with selectable rates 4, 6, or 8 Hz only and a duty cap of 30%. Validate configuration inputs, enforce a safety state machine, and fall back to steady 10% if any timing error or WCET over 1.0 ms occurs.

Control a 60-pixel installation under a 2.5 W power budget: dynamically scale PWM so the total stays within budget while prioritizing a primary channel. Update at 100 Hz using bounded loops over pixels and soft limiting to avoid visible steps.

Create a motion-activated sparkle field: up to 5 concurrent sparkles with 300 ms fade envelopes appear only when motion is detected. Manage sparkle lifetimes with bounded arrays, ensure no dynamic allocation, and keep WCET under 0.8 ms.

Design a multi-mode light installation with modes: daytime, evening, night, and maintenance. Each mode uses distinct patterns and max brightness policies. Provide smooth cross-fades on mode changes, run at 50 Hz, guarantee WCET under 0.8 ms, and include tests for all transitions using a clear state machine and bounded loops.

Build a show controller with 8 scenes. Each scene is a pattern of up to 20 steps with a max step duration of 2 s. Implement a playlist that loops scenes, supports pause/resume/skip, and assert that all loops are bounded and memory use is constant. Target 60 Hz updates.

Implement redundant ambient sensing for a lamp: fuse two lux sensors via median selection; if disagreement exceeds 15 lux, enter degraded mode and cap brightness. Closed-loop PID to 250 lux at 100 Hz. Provide a simulation run of 120 s verifying overshoot under 10% and WCET below 0.5 ms.

Create an adaptive stage light with three modes: automatic (sensor fusion of audio level and motion chooses color wash, strobe, or chase), manual (user sets color/brightness), and emergency (steady amber at 30%). Implement a preemptive state machine at 100 Hz and supply tests for preemption latency under 50 ms and strobe safety (<= 8 Hz, duty <= 30%).

Coordinate a modular art wall of 10 panels: each panel runs a local pattern at 30 Hz, while a global coordinator maintains a 120 BPM beat. Ensure panels lock to the beat within ±1 frame, enforce a total power cap of 15 W across panels, guarantee per-panel WCET under 0.7 ms, and use bounded loops for all pixel updates.
Make a single LED fade in and out using PWM at 200 Hz. Repeat the fade exactly 10 times with a bounded loop, then turn off. Limit duty cycle to 80%.
When a button is pressed, turn a white LED up to 60% brightness immediately; when released, ramp down to 0% over 300 ms. Run the control loop at 100 Hz.
Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, and blue, holding each for 1 second, repeating exactly 5 cycles, then remain off. Use a bounded loop and a 50 Hz update rate.
After power-up, blink an LED at 2 Hz for 30 seconds, then set it to 20% steady. Use explicit timing and a bounded tick counter.
Create a breathing effect with PWM steps that approximate a sine wave using a bounded loop of 64 steps, with PWM frequency at 500 Hz and a max duty of 70%.
Make a double-flash pattern: two 100 ms pulses separated by 100 ms, followed by a 1 s pause, and repeat 20 times. Stop afterward.
On short button taps, cycle LED brightness through 20%, 50%, and 100% levels in order. Debounce at 50 Hz and implement the selection with a bounded index loop.
Flash blue for exactly 100 ms on a rising edge from a motion input, otherwise stay off. Sample input at 200 Hz.
Fade to a target brightness set by a knob from 0% to 100%, limiting the slew to 10% per second. Update at 100 Hz.
Provide a nightlight that dims to 10% after 5 minutes without any input activity. Use a 1 Hz timer and ensure the counter is bounded.
Generate a strobe at 8 Hz for 5 seconds when a trigger is active, then enforce a 2 s cooldown with no strobe. Keep PWM at 1 kHz.
Create a red warning blink sequence of 300 ms on and 700 ms off, repeating 3 times when a fault flag goes high, then return to idle. Ensure the loop count is bounded.
Ramp LED from 0% to 50% linearly over exactly 2 seconds using 40 discrete steps. Tick at 20 Hz to step the bounded loop.
Implement a heartbeat pattern: 80 ms pulse, 80 ms gap, 200 ms pulse, then 1 s rest, and repeat 15 times. Keep maximum duty under 75%.
Turn the LED on solid when a sensor reading is above a threshold and off otherwise. Evaluate the threshold at 25 Hz.

Animate a 12-LED strip with a chasing dot that moves forward and then backward with a tapering tail. Use a bounded loop to step exactly N positions per cycle, and buttons to adjust speed between 0.5 and 10 cycles per second.

Design a state machine with modes Off, CalmFade, and Sparkle. Button clicks advance the mode; long press forces Off. CalmFade uses a 256-step bounded gradient; Sparkle shows random single-pixel flashes capped at 30% brightness. Run at 50 Hz.
Implement a traffic-light trio with exact durations: green 5 s, amber 1 s, red 4 s, repeating continuously. Include a Night flag that halves brightness when set. Drive the state machine at 10 Hz.
Build a rainbow cycle across an RGB strip, shifting hue by 3 degrees per tick so the cycle completes in exactly 120 steps. A potentiometer sets global brightness from 10% to 80%.
Drive two LED channels: one runs a sine breath and the other a sawtooth ramp, both sharing a speed input. Update patterns at 100 Hz with a 1 kHz PWM, and ensure all pattern loops are bounded.

Create a theater-chase pattern for 30 LEDs with a state machine selecting colors white, red, and blue. Each color runs for 10 seconds, then switches. A button skips to the next color. Bound the inner loop to 30 steps.
Make a Morse code flasher for SOS, repeated 3 times upon trigger, then lock out for 10 seconds. Implement symbol timings in milliseconds and bound the repeat loop.
Build a beat-synced flasher using a digital metronome input. On each beat, ramp to 100% over 50 ms and decay to 20% over 300 ms. If no beat for 2 s, fade to off. Tick the controller at 200 Hz.
Animate a comet with a tail length of 5 across a ring of 24 LEDs. The comet wraps around; bound the position loop to 24 iterations. Speed is adjusted by two debounced buttons.

Implement a soft start: after power-up, wait 1 s, then increase brightness to 70% over 4 s. If a fault input is asserted, fade to 0% over 200 ms immediately. Enforce a WCET of 500 microseconds per 100 Hz tick.
Create a palette-driven pattern that selects among 4 predefined RGB palettes. Each palette runs for 8 cycles of a 64-step gradient, then advances. Manage selection with a button and bound all loops.

Program an alternating left-right sweep on two LED rows. When the left row is at maximum, the right row is at minimum, swapping every 0.5 s. Index each row with bounded loops and cap brightness at 60%.
Design a dual-zone installation where Zone A runs a slow fade and Zone B runs a fast sparkle. A master button pauses or resumes both zones. Update at 50 Hz and ensure pattern loops are bounded.
Create a candle flicker effect using a constrained pseudo-random source with a seed input. Limit variation to plus or minus 10% around the base brightness and bound the noise update loop per second.
Implement a timed show that runs Pattern 1 for 15 s, Pattern 2 for 10 s, and Pattern 3 for 20 s, then waits for a restart button. Each pattern uses a bounded 128-step loop and PWM at 1 kHz.
Build a color temperature fade from cool to warm over 30 s using an RGB LED. A knob sets the speed from 5 s to 60 s. Run at 50 Hz and ensure combined PWM duty never exceeds 70%.

Create a tri-state indicator with Idle as blue breathing, Busy as amber pulsing at 1 Hz, and Error as red strobe at 5 Hz. Input bits select the state with priority Error over Busy over Idle. Use a 100 Hz state machine.
Make a gradient wipe that fills a bar of 16 LEDs left to right in 16 steps, pauses 500 ms, then empties right to left. Repeat exactly 4 times. Include a pause and resume button.

Synchronize two light sculptures via a sync input. On each sync pulse, reset the pattern phase to zero. The pattern is an 80-step bounded sine wave. If no sync for 10 s, enter a slow blinking standby.
Modulate LED brightness using a sound level input from 0% to 100%, with a floor and ceiling of 10% and 90%. Update at 200 Hz and limit decay to 20% per second.

Create a rainfall effect where one of 20 columns is randomly selected to start a droplet each tick, and each droplet falls over 10 steps. Ensure the droplet loop is bounded and limit to at most 5 active droplets at once.

Design a user-controlled tempo light with two buttons adjusting BPM from 30 to 240. The LED pulses on the beat with a double-blink accent every 16 beats. Keep counters bounded and wrap the bar count at 16.
Implement a sunrise alarm that, when a start flag is set, increases brightness from 0% to 100% over 20 minutes. If canceled, stop gracefully. Update at 10 Hz and cap duty at 85% for safety.
Create an RGB mood light where color slowly rotates in HSV space at 0.1 rotations per minute, and a proximity input raises brightness to 70% for 5 seconds. Use a bounded 360-step hue loop.
Compose a two-layer effect with a slow background breathing pattern and fast foreground sparkles, saturating the combined output at 80% brightness. Scheduler tick runs at 100 Hz.

Implement closed-loop brightness control using a photodiode in lux to regulate a white LED to a setpoint such as 200 lux with a PID at 100 Hz. Enforce PWM duty 0–90%, add anti-windup, and fail safe to off if the sensor is invalid.

Add thermal awareness to an RGB controller: read temperature in Celsius and linearly derate maximum PWM by 1% per degree above 40 C, with outputs disabled above 70 C. Preserve pattern timing with a state machine at 20 Hz.

Build an ambient-adaptive piece that fuses a light sensor and a motion sensor so brightness targets increase only when motion is present and ambient lux is below a threshold. Use simple complementary fusion, bounded pattern loops, and a 50 Hz rate.

Design a color-balancing controller that maintains a target chromaticity by adjusting R, G, and B PWM using a PID based on two filtered color sensor channels. Limit the integrator to prevent overshoot and meet a 1 ms WCET at 100 Hz.

Create a phase-locked installation where this unit locks its pattern phase to a received index from 0 to 127 with proportional correction, using bounded loops across 128 steps and a watchdog that blanks LEDs if updates stop for 3 s.

Write a safety-critical emergency beacon whose blink timing must hold within plus or minus 5 ms per interval at a 100 Hz scheduler. Include a health monitor that forces LEDs off if any task overruns or if supply voltage is low. Use bounded loops for the blink sequences.

Implement a power-limited show scheduler that starts and stops sub-patterns so the total estimated duty never exceeds a configured budget. If a new sub-pattern would exceed the limit, defer it. Make decisions at 20 Hz and bound all inner loops.

Provide gamma-corrected PWM mapping via a lookup table of 64 entries. Ensure interpolation uses a bounded loop and that updates never stall the 1 kHz PWM. Include a test mode that sweeps all 64 entries once and then exits.

Add glare control with feedback by limiting the rate of change of brightness to 15% per second and using a PI controller to reach the target smoothly. If the input setpoint jumps by more than 50%, split it into bounded increments. Run at 100 Hz.

Develop a multi-pattern orchestration with deterministic timing that runs chase, wave, and twinkle on separate zones under a top-level state machine with Show, Intermission, and SafeOff. Enforce a WCET of 500 microseconds per 100 Hz tick, run a startup self-test of LEDs with a 32-step bounded sweep, and include checks to verify that no PWM channel exceeds 85%.

Create a single LED fade effect using PWM that smoothly ramps from 0% to 80% and back to 0%. Use a bounded loop that repeats the full fade exactly 10 times and then stops. Run the update at a fixed rate of 50 Hz, and keep timing jitter under 2 ms.

Blink a status LED at 2 Hz with a 30% duty cycle. Clamp any requested duty cycle to a maximum of 40% for safety. Use a rate attribute to schedule updates and ensure worst-case execution time per tick stays below 0.5 ms.
When a button is pressed, set the LED to 80% brightness; when released, set it to 10%. Debounce the button with a 20 ms window. Update logic at 100 Hz to guarantee responsive transitions.
Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, and blue, holding each color for 500 ms. Use a bounded loop to repeat the entire sequence 20 times, then leave the LED off. Enforce a WCET under 1 ms per cycle.
Implement a breathing effect using PWM where brightness follows a cosine-like profile from 5% to 70%. Use a precomputed table and a bounded loop over its entries. Update at 60 Hz for smooth motion.
Map a knob input to LED brightness from 0% to 100%, but saturate at 90% to reduce heat. Sample every 10 ms and ensure stable updates without flicker.
On power-up, ramp a nightlight from 0% to 30% over 2 seconds, then hold steady, and automatically turn off after 10 minutes. Maintain timing accuracy within ±5%.
Produce a double-flash pattern on a white LED: two quick 80 ms ON pulses separated by 100 ms, followed by a 900 ms pause. Implement the pattern with a bounded loop and a total period of 1.2 s.
Create a single-pixel chaser on an 8-LED strip, advancing the lit pixel every 100 ms. Use a bounded loop that wraps cleanly after 8 steps.
Add a safety interlock: if the temperature sensor reads above 60 C, immediately set the LED off; otherwise operate normally. Check the temperature at 20 Hz.
Toggle a white LED between 0% and 50% brightness on each button release (detect the release edge). Implement with a simple two-state machine and run at 200 Hz. Include 25 ms debounce.
Implement a one-shot flash: on a trigger input, set the LED to 100% for 50 ms, then ignore any new triggers for 500 ms. Ensure deterministic timing and no retriggering during the lockout.
Track a target brightness input (0.0 to 1.0) with a slew rate limit of 5% per 20 ms tick, so changes are smooth. Use a bounded update loop per tick to enforce the limit.
Generate a linear ramp from 0% to 100% in exactly 100 uniform steps, then switch off. Execute one step every 40 ms using a bounded loop.
Pulse a beacon LED with 5 ms ON and 95 ms OFF. Guarantee the worst-case execution time per 100 ms cycle is <= 200 microseconds and maintain consistent timing.

Implement two-button brightness control: one raises and one lowers brightness in 5% steps, clamped to 10%–90%. Long-press repeats adjustments at 20 Hz. Use a state machine for idle and adjust states with 30 ms debounce.
Drive an RGB LED that smoothly cycles hue over 30 seconds while keeping perceived brightness approximately constant via a simple gamma curve. Use a rate of 100 Hz and a bounded lookup table.
Read an ambient light sensor and map 100–1000 lux to LED brightness 20%–80%. Update at 10 Hz with 5% hysteresis to prevent chatter. Use a small state machine to manage stable transitions.

Create a pattern selector: a button cycles through four modes (static, blink, breathe, chase). Implement as a state machine with a bounded loop inside each pattern. Debounce inputs and keep updates at 100 Hz.
Run a traffic-light sequence on three LEDs: Green 5 s, Yellow 1 s, Red 5 s, repeating. Use a rate of 50 Hz, ensure no overlap between colors, and maintain bounded timing for each phase.

Make brightness respond to microphone level between 10% and 90% with a simple low-pass filter to stabilize. Update at 200 Hz, saturate values to avoid clipping, and disable output if input is invalid.
Render a rainbow wipe on a 16-LED strip by shifting the color pattern by one pixel every 40 ms. Use a bounded loop over exactly 16 pixels and enforce WCET under 1 ms per tick.
Crossfade two LED channels every 2 seconds such that when one ramps up the other ramps down symmetrically. Use linear interpolation with a bounded number of steps at a 50 Hz update rate.

Output SOS in Morse code on a white LED: dot 200 ms, dash 600 ms, inter-symbol 200 ms, inter-letter 600 ms, inter-word 1400 ms. Implement with a state machine and a bounded sequence table. Run at 100 Hz.
Conserve battery by capping brightness at 40% when supply voltage is below 3.3 V, else allow up to 90%. Check voltage at 5 Hz and apply soft transitions using bounded steps.
Mix warm and cool white channels to achieve a user-selected color temperature while keeping total brightness constant. Update at 50 Hz and clamp each PWM channel to 0–90%.
Produce a strobe effect: 10 flashes at 15 Hz followed by a 2 second pause. Use a bounded counter for the 10 flashes and keep timing jitter under 2 ms.

With a presence sensor, fade to 70% over 30 s when occupied and fade to 0% when unoccupied. Build a state machine with occupancy and fade states, run at 20 Hz, and hard-off if temperature exceeds 70 C.
Implement a Larson scanner over 10 LEDs that moves one lit pixel back and forth, stepping every 80 ms and reversing at the ends. Use bounded indices and a 125 Hz update rate.
Button toggles day/night modes: day at 80% brightness and night at 20%. Include a 500 ms transition ramp handled by a state machine and debounce the button for 25 ms.
Play a 16-step color pattern where each step specifies RGB values and a hold duration in ms. Use a bounded loop to iterate steps and interpret durations on a 100 Hz tick.
If a fault input is high, flash a warning: triple-blink repeating every 1.5 s. Otherwise hold steady at 60% brightness. Implement with a rate attribute and a state machine.
Drive two LEDs with PWM such that their brightness waveforms are 180 degrees out of phase at 5 Hz while keeping their average brightness equal. Use a bounded cycle counter to maintain phase.
Approximate an exponential brightness transition using a piecewise linear table of 32 points. Step through the table using a bounded loop, updating every 25 ms.
Create a clocked color wheel where hue advances by 3 degrees each 20 ms tick and wraps at 360 degrees. Implement bounded wrap logic and keep WCET under 0.5 ms.

Maintain 300 lux at a surface with a photodiode feedback loop using a PID that adjusts PWM between 0% and 90%. Run at 200 Hz with anti-windup. Safety: reduce setpoint to 150 lux if temperature > 65 C. Keep per-cycle WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Implement an adaptive theater dimmer that reaches any target brightness using a jerk-limited S-curve over 1–10 s. Use bounded segments, a 100 Hz update rate, and never exceed 85% PWM for thermal safety.

Fuse ambient light and proximity sensors to set brightness: if proximity < 0.2 m, cap at 30%; otherwise map lux to 20%–80% and combine via a weighted average with hysteresis. Update at 20 Hz with a near/far mode state machine.

Control an RGBW LED with temperature-based derating: above 55 C, scale total output linearly down to 50% at 75 C, maintaining color balance. Hard-off above 85 C. Update at 10 Hz using bounded loops for four channels.

Build a music visualizer on 12 LEDs using microphone RMS and a simple band-pass estimate. Compute an envelope over a 100 ms window with a bounded buffer and update the display at 50 Hz. Safety: disable output if the input saturates for more than 1 s.

Create a heartbeat light synchronized to an external 1 Hz tick: two quick pulses then rest. Use a state machine, run at 200 Hz, enforce maximum WCET of 1 ms, and set an error flag if the budget is exceeded.

Perform color calibration: step through 6 primary/secondary colors, measure with a color sensor, and adjust per-channel gains to match targets within ±3%. Use a bounded loop over 6 colors and at most 3 adjustment iterations. State machine with measure and adjust states; time out after 60 s for safety.

Implement a daylight-compensated workspace light: PID maintains 500 lux with feedforward from an ambient sensor. Sample at 100 Hz, ramp up softly over 3 s, and cap PWM to satisfy an 800 mA equivalent current limit. Use bounded calculations.
Simulate fireworks across 24 LEDs with multiple bursts and fading sparks. Limit to at most 20 active sparks using bounded arrays, update at 60 Hz, and ensure per-tick WCET does not exceed 1.5 ms.

Create a thermal-aware strobe: 10 Hz flashes at 100% for 20 ms, but reduce duty dynamically using a simple RC thermal model to keep estimated junction temperature below 85 C. Update control at 200 Hz and enter a fault state if the model diverges.

Create a festival light controller with scheduled scenes by time-of-day: Morning, Evening, Night. Each scene defines brightness, color pattern, and transition rules. Implement a hierarchical state machine with bounded loops for sequence steps and a scheduler ticking at 10 Hz. Safety: cap PWM at 90%, reduce to 50% if supply voltage < 3.2 V, and hard-off on overtemp > 80 C. Provide a test plan covering transitions, timing accuracy ±2%, and fault injection for sensor failures.

Specify a stage-lighting engine supporting cue stacks up to 64 steps with per-step color, brightness, and hold time in ms. Parse and execute with bounded arrays and strict input validation. Use a 100 Hz rate and guarantee WCET <= 1 ms. Safety: reject cues that exceed 90% PWM or total current limits, and implement an emergency blackout input that preempts all cues within 20 ms. Provide conformance tests for edge cases and timing.
Fade a single LED from 0% to 100% brightness over 2 seconds after power-up using PWM, then hold steady. Run the fade as a bounded loop of fixed steps at a 100 Hz update rate.
Blink one LED at exactly 1 Hz with a 25% duty cycle using PWM. Keep timing precise with a rate attribute and saturate brightness to 100% max.
On a button press, toggle a single LED between 30% and 100% brightness. Include simple debounce (20 ms) and use PWM for brightness.
Cycle a tri-color LED through red, green, and blue, holding each color for 1 second. Implement the three-color sequence as a bounded loop that repeats indefinitely at a steady 10 Hz update schedule.
Create a gentle 'breathing' effect on an LED by ramping brightness up and down using a bounded list of 20 PWM steps. Update at 50 Hz and ensure the endpoints linger for 200 ms.
Implement a nightlight that linearly dims from 100% to 0% over exactly 10 minutes. Use PWM, step at 1 Hz, and stop at 0% with no wrap-around.
Produce a triple-flash strobe: three 50 ms flashes separated by 100 ms gaps, then idle for 5 seconds before repeating. Use a bounded loop to encode the flash sequence and a precise timing rate.
Map a touch sensor value (0.0–1.0) to LED brightness (0–100%). Update at 100 Hz, clamp out-of-range inputs, and drive PWM accordingly.
Read an analog knob and set LED brightness linearly (0–100%). Smooth changes with a simple rate limiter (max 10% per 100 ms) and update at 20 Hz.
Rotate an RGB LED through the color wheel over 30 seconds while capping overall brightness at 60%. Use a rate attribute to step hue changes smoothly.
Simulate candle flicker on a single LED by randomly varying brightness between 20% and 80% at 200 Hz, with bounded randomness and no steps greater than 15% per update.
Blink 'SOS' in Morse code on one LED. Use a bounded sequence where one time unit is 200 ms, and repeat with a 2-second pause between words.
When a boolean 'enable' input becomes true, fade the LED up over 1 second; when false, fade down over 500 ms. Execute fades via bounded step loops using PWM.
Set an RGB LED to white with user-provided brightness (0–100%). Validate the input, clamp to bounds, and hold steady at the target using PWM.
Give a short time marker: once per minute, smoothly pulse an LED up to 80% and back down over 2 seconds. Keep a stable 50 Hz update rate.
Build a mode-based light with a 4-position selector: Off, Steady, Blink, Breathe. Implement an explicit state machine and keep each pattern's timing via rate attributes.
Use an ambient light sensor to dim an RGB LED's white output: brighter in daylight, softer in darkness. Add a button that forces 100% for 10 seconds, managed by a state machine with timers at 50 Hz.
Create an 8-LED chase whose speed follows an analog input. Implement the index movement with a bounded loop across 8 LEDs at 100 Hz, wrapping cleanly.
Design a decorative 'traffic light' sequence: green 6 s, amber 1 s, red 5 s. Add a 'walk' input that extends red by 2 s once per cycle. Use a deterministic state machine.
Drive colors from microphone amplitude: below threshold, slowly pulse blue; above, flash colors mapped to loudness. Update at 200 Hz and ensure brightness never exceeds 90%.
Render a rainbow gradient across 16 LEDs and shift it left every 50 ms. Use bounded loops to update all 16 elements, with a 'pause' input to freeze the pattern.
Implement a twinkle scene: at most 10 LEDs out of 50 may be twinkling at any time. Each twinkle fades in and out over 300 ms. Manage lifetimes with a state machine at 100 Hz.
Make a button cycle through five color presets; a long-press (>1 s) toggles a night mode at 20% brightness. Include debounce (20 ms) and implement with a clear state machine.
Crossfade two independent light channels over 5 seconds when a 'scene' flag changes. Use linear interpolation at 100 Hz and preserve the last levels.
Blend warm and cool white LEDs to achieve a user-selected color temperature (2700–6500 K) from an analog input while holding total brightness constant. Update at 50 Hz.
Run holiday patterns selected by an integer 'day_index' (0,1,2). Each pattern is a bounded loop of colors with different timings. Ensure clean transitions when the index changes.
Alarm indicator behavior: flash red until an 'ack' input is received, then steady yellow for 10 seconds, then off. Use a timed state machine with precise 10 Hz updates.
Play a 12-step brightness sequence forward then reverse (ping-pong). Implement as a bounded 24-step loop stepping every 100 ms.
Create a 'knight rider' effect across 20 LEDs with an adjustable trail length. The head bounces between ends, and endpoints linger for 100 ms. Keep a 100 Hz update rate.
Generate a 'glitch art' stream: random colors with the constraint that successive frames differ by at least 20% in brightness. Cap brightness at 80% and update at 120 Hz.
Four-zone brightness control: each zone has its own setting, but a master dim scales all zones. Add an optional gamma correction toggle. Ensure updates are synchronized at 50 Hz.
Implement soft-start and soft-stop: when 'active' goes true, ramp brightness at 10% per second; when false, ramp down at 20% per second. Saturate within 0–100% and tick at 20 Hz.
If 'safe_mode' becomes true, immediately switch to 2 Hz blinking amber; otherwise render the selected palette. Model this preemption with a state machine.
Play a fixed-length light show lasting exactly 60 seconds at 50 Hz, iterating a bounded list of cues. Stop cleanly at the end and remain off.
Crossfade between two 5-color palettes over 8 seconds, looping through palettes A and B. Use bounded loops over the palette indices and keep a 100 Hz timing.

Maintain 300 lux on a surface using feedback from an ambient light sensor by adjusting PWM. Implement a PID controller at 100 Hz with anti-windup, limit brightness to 85%, and fail safe to off if the sensor is invalid.
Thermal derating: read temperature in Celsius and linearly reduce brightness starting at 60°C, with a hard shutdown at 75°C and 5°C hysteresis. Model fault and recovery states.
Fuse microphone level and accelerometer magnitude to drive LED intensity using a weighted average that adapts to signal quality. Normalize inputs, update at 200 Hz, and cap at 70% brightness.
Synchronize three independent light strips to a common heartbeat at exactly 100 Hz with jitter under 1 ms. If the heartbeat is missed for more than 200 ms, enter an all-off safe state.

Match ambient color temperature: read a CCT sensor (Kelvin) and adjust warm/cool channels via PID to stay within ±100 K of target. Sample at 50 Hz, clamp total duty to 90%, and prevent integral windup.
Constrain flicker: produce brightness modulation only above 200 Hz effective frequency. Add dithering at 1 kHz and ensure the control loop WCET stays under 1 ms per update.
Auto-exposure helper: keep exposure ratio E = brightness / ambient_lux near 2.0 using PID at 100 Hz. Limit step changes to 5% per 10 ms and fail to off on sensor faults.
Pattern player with fault tolerance: given a list of faulty LED indices, skip them in a chase pattern while preserving exact timing and speed. Use bounded loops and verify index bounds.

Distribute a given power budget (in watts) across N light channels to maximize overall visual uniformity using a simple constrained optimizer. Update allocations at 20 Hz and enforce per-channel caps.
Orient color by heading: fuse gyro and compass readings with a complementary filter at 100 Hz; map hue to yaw, with a fallback to solid blue at 30% if either sensor saturates.

Design a multi-mode lighting controller with modes Idle, PreShow, Show, and Emergency. Emergency preempts all others to flashing red at 4 Hz. Implement a deterministic state machine, run the scheduler at 100 Hz with WCET under 2 ms, and include a startup self-test that briefly exercises each LED.

Create a stage sequence engine that plays a playlist of patterns with explicit durations and supports a 'remote_command' input to jump to a cue. Guarantee deterministic timing, cap brightness at 80%, and provide a test plan covering cue changes, overruns, and end-of-show.

Build a safety-critical dimmer using two temperature sensors (°C). If readings differ by >5°C, enter SafeDim at 20% and latch a fault; otherwise derate smoothly above 60°C. Include fault injection tests and clear criteria to exit SafeDim.

Implement a 64-LED art wall with scenes Rain, Fire, and Wind. Transitions crossfade over 2 seconds. Keep a 200 Hz update rate, use bounded loops for all per-LED updates, add assertions on index bounds, and include tests that cover every scene transition.

Specify an installation controller that enforces no visible flicker: schedule tasks so no brightness modulation occurs below 90 Hz. Define explicit rates and WCET budgets per task, add a heartbeat indicator, and include tests simulating worst-case load.

Fade a single white LED from 0% to 100% and back over 3 seconds using PWM. Run the control loop at 50 Hz, use a bounded loop for the ramp, and cap maximum brightness at 80% for comfort. Repeat continuously.
Blink one LED at 2 Hz with a 30% duty cycle. Implement the on/off pattern with a bounded sequence and update at a 100 Hz control rate.

Create a breathing effect on a single LED using a precomputed bounded table that approximates a cosine curve. The full cycle is 5 seconds, updated at 60 Hz, and ensure WCET per tick stays under 0.5 ms.
Smoothly ramp one LED from 10% to 60% in 20 discrete steps every 50 ms, hold for 2 seconds, then ramp back down. Use a bounded loop for the step sequence and run at 20 Hz.
Generate a heartbeat pattern on a red LED: two 80% pulses 150 ms apart, then 2 seconds of off. Encode the pulses in a bounded pattern sequence and update at 200 Hz.
Simulate a sunrise on a single LED: linearly increase PWM from 0% to 100% over 10 minutes using a bounded loop of steps. Control rate 1 Hz, and limit changes to no more than 2% per second.
Display a progress indication on one LED by stepping through 11 brightness levels (0% to 100%) and holding each level 250 ms. Use a bounded loop and run updates at 40 Hz.
Toggle a single LED between 20% and 80% brightness with a pushbutton. Debounce within a bounded 50 ms window and run the control loop at 100 Hz.
Flash a single LED with the Morse code for SOS using PWM brightness levels for dots and dashes. Implement the sequence in a bounded loop and update timing at 100 Hz.
Cycle a single RGB LED through red, green, and blue, each color held for 1 second at 70% brightness. Use a bounded loop for color rotation at an update rate of 30 Hz.
On power-up, fade one LED to 50% over 1 second and then maintain. On reset, fade out over 300 ms. Use a simple two-state machine (Ramp, Hold) and a bounded ramp at 200 Hz.
Create a candle flicker on a warm LED by sampling a bounded pseudo-random lookup table. Clamp brightness between 20% and 80% and update at 120 Hz.
Flash a warning LED three times quickly (100 ms on, 100 ms off) followed by a 1 second pause. Use a bounded repetition count and run at 100 Hz.
Drive a single blue LED with a PWM carrier of 1 kHz, brightness fixed at 35%. Maintain a 100 Hz control rate and ensure WCET per loop is under 0.2 ms.
Fade a single LED up when capacitive touch is detected and fade down when released. Debounce touch within 40 ms, use 25 bounded fade steps, and run at 80 Hz.

Create a two-state machine for a 5-LED piece: Idle shows a 5-second white breathe; Active runs a left-to-right chase at 10 steps per second. Transition to Active on button press, and back to Idle after 30 seconds of inactivity. Use bounded loops and a 50 Hz control rate.
Implement a color cross-fade on a single RGB LED: cycle red→green→blue using 100 bounded steps per transition. A second button toggles pause. Limit total brightness to 70% and update at 120 Hz.

Build a theater-marquee effect for 12 LEDs where every third LED is lit at 60% and the pattern advances one position every 100 ms. Provide three selectable speeds via a state machine and a bounded index loop. Control rate 100 Hz.

Create a Knight Rider scan across 8 LEDs with a bright head and two dim trailing LEDs. Reverse direction at the ends using a state machine and step the head with a bounded loop. Update at 200 Hz and keep per-tick WCET under 0.4 ms.

Render a rainbow wave across 10 pixels where hue shifts by 3 degrees per frame and wraps at 360 using a bounded loop. A button switches between static and moving modes. Run at 60 Hz and cap overall luminance at 150 cd/m^2 equivalent.

Design a dual-zone lamp with two RGB LEDs: Zone A breathes slowly at 30% brightness, Zone B pulses synchronized every 2 seconds. Implement a Night mode in a state machine that halves brightness. Use bounded loops and a 50 Hz control rate.
Display an 8-bit binary counter on 8 LEDs, incrementing every 250 ms. Include a reset button and a hold switch via a small state machine (Run/Hold/Reset). Use a bounded loop for bit updates at 40 Hz.

Make a two-channel dimmer adjusted by a single rotary input: clockwise adds 5%, counterclockwise subtracts 5%. Wrap within 0–100% using bounded clamps. Include Adjust/Lock states and debounce edges in 10 ms. Update at 100 Hz.

Show color temperature on a bicolor LED: warm (amber) vs cool (white) based on a numeric selector. Fade between targets over 400 ms with a bounded ramp and ensure per-frame changes stay below 10%. Control rate 200 Hz.

Build a four-scene light sculpture: Scene1 steady blue 40%, Scene2 1 Hz pulse, Scene3 chase, Scene4 random sparkle. Cycle scenes with a momentary button; long-press (>1 s) powers off. Each scene uses bounded loops; control rate 60 Hz.

Create a metronome light with two LEDs alternating at a tempo set by a BPM value (40–208). Use bounded timing to achieve precise on/off durations and a state machine for Start/Stop/SetTempo. Update at 200 Hz with timing jitter under ±2 ms.

Implement a sunrise/sunset across 6 warm-white LEDs: ramp up over 900 seconds in 120 bounded steps and ramp down over 600 seconds. A switch selects Up or Down. Control rate 10 Hz and scale PWM to limit output to 500 lumens equivalent.
Create a sparkle effect on 20 LEDs where at most 3 pixels twinkle simultaneously. Manage a bounded pool of sparkle slots with finite lifetimes. A button sets density (1, 2, or 3). Update at 100 Hz.
Build an RGB mixer controlled by three sliders for R, G, and B. Apply gamma correction via a bounded 256-entry lookup and cap each channel's duty at 90%. Control loop runs at 120 Hz.

Design a party light with tap-tempo: user taps to set period, computed from a bounded rolling average of the last 4 taps. State machine handles Tapping vs Playback. Lights flash at that tempo with a 75% brightness limit. Update at 200 Hz.
Run a color wipe across 15 LEDs filling one pixel per frame until full, then clear in reverse. Use a bounded index loop and a Fill/Clear state machine. Control rate 60 Hz and ensure WCET < 1 ms.

Create an occupancy-responsive strip: when motion is detected, fade to 60% over 2 seconds; when inactive for 30 seconds, fade to 0% over 1 second. Implement Active/Idle states and bounded ramps at 50 Hz.

Build a day/night accent light using ambient lux to set target brightness between 10% and 50%. Smooth the input with a bounded 8-sample moving average and add a Manual Override state. Control rate 25 Hz and avoid visible flicker.

Rotate a four-color palette across 4 RGB pixels, advancing every 150 ms via a bounded index loop. A toggle input freezes/unfreezes rotation. Update at 100 Hz and limit total current by capping the sum of channel duties to 200%.

Create a status beacon: green slow pulse for OK, yellow 2 Hz blink for Warning, red triple-flash for Fault. Use a state machine with bounded patterns per state. Update at 120 Hz and fade transitions over 100 ms.

Implement closed-loop brightness control of a white LED to achieve 300 lux at 0.5 m using a light sensor. Use a PID controller on PWM with output bounded to 0–95%. Control at 200 Hz, WCET < 0.5 ms, and include Off/Regulate/Fault states for sensor timeout handling.

Calibrate an RGB LED to D65 using a color sensor and a bounded 3×3 correction matrix. After calibration, maintain either 4000 K or 6500 K selected by input. Limit any channel to 85% duty and run at 50 Hz.

Maintain constant perceived brightness despite supply voltage and temperature changes: estimate droop from voltage and temperature inputs and apply a bounded feedforward term plus PID trim to PWM. Run the loop at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.3 ms; fall back to fixed 60% if sensors fail.

Create a motion-reactive lamp using accelerometer and microphone inputs: intensity scales with a bounded RMS fusion of both signals, and hue maps to motion direction. Use Calm/Reactive/Muted states with hysteresis, update at 100 Hz, and cap average brightness to 12 W equivalent.

Implement thermal derating for an LED panel: reduce brightness linearly from 100% at 40 C to 30% at 80 C with a hard cutoff at 90 C followed by a 500 ms safe fade-to-off. Smooth temperature with a bounded 16-sample average and run at 20 Hz.

Build a constant-luminance desk light: fuse ambient and reflected photodiode readings to estimate task-plane illuminance and maintain 500 lux via a PID on PWM. Add Anti-Flicker limiting to 5% change per 100 ms. Control at 100 Hz with WCET < 0.8 ms.

Render a synchronized multi-pixel rainbow whose spatial frequency and phase are driven by a bounded low-frequency oscillator. Reduce saturation based on ambient lux feedback. Implement Auto and Manual modes in a state machine, cap brightness at 70%, and update at 120 Hz.

Implement a battery-saver for a wearable art piece: adjust global brightness based on estimated state-of-charge and temperature using a bounded schedule. Use High/Normal/Low/Reserve states. Maintain 60 Hz animation with WCET < 0.6 ms and shut down gracefully below 10% SoC.

Design a strobe light with precise frequency (1–20 Hz) and duty (5–50%) control using a bounded phase accumulator. Add feedback from a light sensor and run a PI loop to match target peak intensity. Control at 400 Hz and enforce maximum duty per eye-safety guidelines.

Create an auto-dimming RGB art lamp that keeps chroma constant while adjusting luminance based on ambient lux. Use a bounded HSL transform with output clamped to 0–80%. Include Auto, Manual, and Sleep states, update at 60 Hz, and ease transitions with 200 ms bounded ramps.

Create a stage light sequencer with four programmable scenes (A–D), each with a duration in seconds. Cycle scenes using a bounded timeline and allow a 'Blackout' command that fades to 0% in 250 ms and later restores. Implement a robust state machine, enforce a 200 Hz update rate with WCET ≤ 0.5 ms, and define verification: scene durations within ±10 ms, blackout latency < 50 ms, and no duty above 85%.

Design a wearable LED controller with modes: Performance, Ambient, Stealth. Enforce a power budget that limits average brightness to 3 W equivalent over a bounded 60-second window. Patterns use bounded loops; inputs select mode and intensity. Add diagnostics to detect channel saturation > 90% for > 2 s and automatically reduce output. Control at 120 Hz with WCET < 0.6 ms. Provide acceptance tests for mode persistence after reset and power-budget enforcement.

Implement a time-synchronized light show that follows a 60-second cue list at 120 BPM. Use a bounded cue array where each entry defines color, brightness, and duration in milliseconds. Maintain cue timing within ±5 ms while rendering at 240 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.4 ms. Include a fail-safe state that, on timing overrun, immediately reduces complexity (e.g., disables sparkle layer) and add tests to validate overrun handling.

Make a single white LED perform a gentle breathing effect: ramp brightness from 10% to 80% and back in a smooth triangle wave at 1 Hz. Use a bounded loop to run exactly 5 full cycles, then hold at 30%. Update brightness at a fixed rate (e.g., 100 Hz) with no blocking waits.

When a pushbutton is pressed, toggle a single LED between fully off and 50% brightness. If the button is held, temporarily dim to 30% while held, restoring the prior state on release. Debounce at 10 ms. Keep the control loop deterministic with a rate attribute.

Read a single analog control and map it linearly to LED PWM from 0% to 90% (cap for safety). Sample at 50 Hz and update the LED at the same rate. Include simple slew limiting so brightness changes by no more than 5% per update.

Blink an LED in a repeating pattern: three short flashes (50 ms on, 100 ms off) followed by one long flash (400 ms on, 400 ms off), then 1 s idle. Implement the pattern using a bounded loop over steps and run continuously at a fixed 200 Hz control rate.

Cycle a single RGB LED through red, green, blue, and off, each step holding for 2 s. Implement this as a simple state machine with four states. Use PWM to ensure full intensity and update with a rate attribute (20 Hz) for timing.
On power-up, flash an LED twice quickly (100 ms on, 100 ms off) using a bounded loop, then leave it steady at 50% brightness. Ensure timing is derived from a periodic task rate rather than delays.
When a button is pressed, emit a single 250 ms light pulse at 100% brightness on one LED, then return to off. Ignore additional presses during the pulse window. Use a fixed 100 Hz update rate.
Alternate two LEDs: A on while B off for 300 ms, then swap, repeating forever. Maintain precise timing using a periodic task and avoid blocking delays by counting ticks.
Create a soft-blink: for each cycle, ramp an LED from 0% to 100% over 1 s, then turn off and wait 0.5 s. Repeat exactly 10 cycles using a bounded loop, then stop with the LED off.

On startup, sweep the RGB LED color from red to magenta to blue to cyan to green to yellow to red over 5 s, then stop on cyan. Use bounded loop steps to approximate the hue sweep and PWM on three channels.
Create a hazard strobe: triple-strobe at 50 ms on / 50 ms off, then 600 ms off, repeat indefinitely. Run at a fixed control loop rate and implement the pattern as an indexed, bounded sequence.
From an initial 100% brightness, decrement an LED by 1% every 100 ms until it reaches 20%, then hold. Use a bounded loop to ensure at most 80 steps. Update via a periodic task.

Blink an LED at 2 Hz with 50% duty cycle, but enforce a safety constraint: cumulative on-time must not exceed 10 s per minute. If the budget is exceeded, automatically enter a 30 s cooldown with LED off. Use a rate-controlled task to track time.

Use a light sensor to control one LED such that darker ambient readings produce brighter output. Sample the sensor at 20 Hz, invert the mapping, and clamp the LED to a maximum of 80% PWM. Add mild hysteresis to reduce flicker.
Toggle an RGB LED between blue and amber every 5 s using a periodic tick counter. Keep the logic simple and non-blocking. Ensure stable timing with a rate attribute on the update task.

Provide two buttons to control an RGB LED: one cycles the pattern (solid, breathe, rainbow), the other adjusts speed (slow, medium, fast). Implement a state machine for modes and speed settings, and run the pattern steps with bounded loops at 100 Hz.

Build a dimmer for an RGB LED using a rotary encoder: rotation adjusts overall brightness (5–95%), short press toggles on/off, long press cycles color temperature presets. Use a state machine for input handling and update PWM at 200 Hz.

Create a left-right 'ping-pong' chaser on an 8-LED strip. The head advances one LED per tick, bounces at the ends, and brightness of the head is 100% while others are off. Speed is adjusted by a potentiometer. Implement the chaser using a bounded loop across indices at 60 Hz.

Using an ambient light sensor, implement three behavior states for a decorative lamp: Off (bright ambient), Twilight (gentle breathing at 20–40%), and Night (steady 60%). Use a state machine with hysteresis thresholds and evaluate at 10 Hz.

Implement tap-tempo color changes: two taps on a single button set the period; the RGB LED switches color at that interval cycling R→G→B. Time out after 3 s if only one tap is received. Use a rate-controlled task for timing and a bounded loop through colors.

Sunrise effect: when a trigger input goes high, ramp an LED from 0% to 100% linearly over 15 minutes, then hold until a cancel input is pressed. Ignore retriggers during the ramp. Perform updates at 10 Hz with precise timing.

Select one of five predefined color palettes for an LED art piece using three digital inputs (binary). Cycle through each palette in order with 2 s per step using a bounded loop. If an invalid combination is detected, fall back to a default palette. Update at 50 Hz.

Use a motion sensor to trigger a 30 s light scene: fade to 60% over 2 s, hold for 26 s, then fade to off over 2 s. Retriggering during the scene restarts the timer. Implement the behavior as a state machine and update PWM at 50 Hz.

Drive a color wash from an audio level sensor with smoothing: map audio amplitude to brightness 10–90% with a 0.5 s exponential smoothing window. Update mapping and PWM at 100 Hz; include a minimum update step to avoid visible stepping.

When a button is pressed, crossfade an RGB LED from its current color to a target color over 3 s with linear steps. Implement the fade using a bounded loop across a fixed number of frames and ensure the frame rate is steady (e.g., 50 Hz).

Create a 'theater chase' pattern across 10 LEDs: three-on, one-off repeating motif that advances one position per frame. Let a potentiometer set the frame interval between 20 ms and 200 ms. Use a bounded loop over LEDs and enforce a fixed update rate.

Build a breathing effect whose amplitude (20–80%) and period (0.5–5 s) are controlled by two analog inputs. Implement a state machine for Idle vs Active based on a toggle input, and compute the waveform with discrete steps at 100 Hz.

Simulate a traffic signal art piece: Green for 3 s, Yellow for 1 s, Red for 2 s, then repeat. In the last 0.5 s of Green, blink Green at 5 Hz. Use a clear state machine and tick-based timing from a periodic task.

Random sparkle on an 8-LED array: once per second, choose a single LED to flash at 100% for 100 ms while others stay off. Use a simple pseudorandom generator seeded at startup. Implement via a bounded loop over LEDs at 50 Hz.

Add capacitive touch input to cycle an RGB LED through four colors with each tap; holding the sensor for >1 s dims the current color toward 20%. Include debounce, hold detection, and a state machine for Tap vs Hold. Update at 100 Hz.

Create a red 'heartbeat' pattern: double pulse (on 80 ms, off 80 ms, on 150 ms), then pause to complete a 2.5 s period. Accept a heart rate input (40–180 bpm) to scale the timing. Implement the sequence as a bounded loop and constrain timing updates at 100 Hz.

Implement a priority indicator with two inputs: WARN and FAULT. FAULT flashes red at 2 Hz; WARN blinks amber at 1 Hz if FAULT is inactive. Use a state machine with priority resolution and ensure transitions are glitch-free at a fixed control rate.

Display a progress bar on a 10-LED strip based on an analog input (0–100%). Light N LEDs at 100% where N=round(value/10). Animate changes with a sliding effect that moves one LED per frame using bounded loops. Maintain a 60 Hz frame rate.

Implement a rainbow wheel on a 16-LED ring at a fixed frame rate of 120 Hz. A rotary encoder sets rotation speed and push toggles direction. Compute colors using a bounded loop over 16 positions; ensure wraparound indices are handled safely.

Drive a 7-segment style LED arrangement to display digits 0–9 based on an integer input. Include PWM brightness control (10–90%) and a fallback pattern for invalid inputs. Update outputs at 200 Hz with no flicker.

Use PID control to maintain perceived brightness corresponding to 300 lux measured by a light sensor. Update the control loop at 50 Hz, clamp output to 0–80% PWM, and include anti-windup and sensor fault detection that forces LED off on error.

Fuse two ambient light sensors (front and back) with a weighted average to drive display brightness. Sample at 20 Hz. If the sensors differ by more than 200 lux, enter a Disagreement state that holds the previous brightness; enter Fault if either sensor is invalid. Model with a state machine.

Implement thermal derating: read temperature in °C at 10 Hz and reduce LED PWM linearly from 100% at 60 °C to 10% at 80 °C. Hard cutoff at 85 °C. Guarantee worst-case execution time per cycle under 1 ms and maintain deterministic timing.

Protect against low supply voltage: monitor voltage; below 3.3 V, linearly reduce brightness; below 3.0 V, flash red at 1 Hz until recovery. Use a state machine with hysteresis and a 100 Hz control loop. Include soft-start on recovery.

Closed-loop color correction: read a color sensor and adjust RGB channels via three independent PID controllers to reach a target color. Update at 25 Hz, limit per-update change to prevent visible steps, and clamp each channel to 90% max for safety.

Schedule PWM updates for multiple LED channels to avoid simultaneous current peaks: phase-shift channel updates within a frame and enforce a safety rule that the sum of duty cycles across three channels never exceeds 180%. Maintain a fixed frame rate with a rate attribute.

Interactive wall lighting: each section lights based on proximity sensors; fuse three sensors per section using majority vote. Animate a traveling wave pattern using bounded loops, guaranteeing end-to-end latency under 50 ms. Include a Normal and Error state with safe fallback off.

Implement an emergency stop: when an E-STOP input goes active, set all PWM outputs to 0 within 10 ms and latch in a safe state. Require a separate reset input to resume. Run the main control task at 200 Hz and prove deterministic response timing.

Auto-calibration routine at startup: sweep an LED from 0% to 100% PWM in fixed steps while reading a light sensor to build a lookup table. Complete in under 5 s using a bounded loop. If sensor fault is detected, skip calibration and operate with a safe default curve.

Glare control with combined feedforward and PID: compensate LED brightness for temperature and supply voltage variations while tracking a target perceived brightness. Update at 100 Hz, specify WCET limits, and fail safe (LED off) on any arithmetic overflow or sensor fault.

Design a multi-mode light sculpture controller with states: Installation, Performance, Maintenance, and Emergency. Each mode enforces distinct patterns and brightness caps. Use a state machine with explicit transitions, timeouts, and manual overrides. Include periodic tasks with rate attributes (e.g., 200 Hz PWM, 20 Hz sensor scan), a bounded-loop self-test that flashes each of 24 outputs at startup, and a safety rule forcing all channels ≤5% within 50 ms in Emergency.

Create a stage lighting sequencer that plays a fixed cue list: up to 32 cues each with target color and duration. Iterate cues with a bounded loop, support pause/resume/skip inputs, and crossfade between cues over 1 s. Verify frame processing WCET ≤2 ms and include a test mode that plays back at 10× speed.

Architectural facade controller with Day/Night schedules, rain dimming input, and occupancy boosts. Enforce a power budget per zone so the sum of PWM duty cycles never exceeds a threshold. Implement deterministic periodic tasks, a mode state machine, a diagnostics heartbeat LED, and fault injection test hooks.

Interactive exhibit with four stations: states Idle, Attract, Engaged, Error. Each station has a local pattern generator; global sync coordinates scene changes. Fuse two sensors per station to detect engagement. Use bounded loops for pattern steps, include simulation inputs for testing, and ensure fallback to Idle within 100 ms on any fault.

Implement a color choreography engine with up to 10 scenes, each a bounded sequence of keyframes (color and duration). Schedule frames at 120 Hz with jitter <1 ms. Provide unit tests for scene transitions, saturation handling, and zero-duration keyframes. Enforce a safety rule that no channel exceeds 90% duty at any time.

Create a simple RGB LED behavior that fades through red, green, and blue using PWM. Hold each color for 1 s with a 500 ms cross-fade. Run the sequence exactly 6 times using a bounded loop, keep peak brightness at or below 60%, and update at a 50 Hz rate.
Make a single LED do a slow breathing effect with PWM: 0% to 70% in 2 s and back down in 2 s, repeating forever. Use a rate attribute of 100 Hz and ensure the duty cycle never exceeds 70%.
Blink a white LED twice quickly (100 ms on, 100 ms off), then pause for 1 s. Implement the two quick blinks via a bounded loop and keep brightness at 100% only during the on windows.
On a pushbutton press, toggle a status LED on or off. Debounce the button with 50 ms filtering. When on, hold a steady 40% PWM brightness.
Map an analog input to LED brightness from 0% to 100% using PWM. Update at 25 Hz and treat values below 5% as off to avoid faint glow.
On power-up, fade one LED from 0% to 30% over 2 s, then hold steady. Use PWM with a rate that avoids visible flicker and run the control loop at 200 Hz.
Set an RGB LED to purple by default. If ambient light drops below 30 lux, ramp brightness to 80%; otherwise dim to 20%. Apply 5 lux hysteresis and update at 10 Hz.
When a tap sensor is detected, strobe a single LED at 10 Hz for 3 s with a 20% duty cycle. Use a bounded loop to limit the number of flashes and return to off afterward.
Create a 5-LED chase where one LED at a time is on for 200 ms, advancing forward. Repeat the sequence for 4 full cycles using a bounded loop, then turn all LEDs off.
Implement a heartbeat indicator: one short 100 ms pulse to 100% every 2 s using PWM. Ensure a WCET of 1 ms per update and stable timing.
Provide two buttons for a dimmer: one increases brightness by 5%, the other decreases by 5%. Clamp between 10% and 90% and update at 50 Hz with debounced edges.
Fade an RGB LED between its current color and a target color over 1.5 s when a switch changes state. Keep maximum brightness at 50% to reduce glare.
Build a night-light: if ambient < 30 lux, ramp to 25% over 3 s; if ambient >= 35 lux, ramp down to 0% over 3 s. Sample at 5 Hz.
On a rising edge of a trigger signal, turn a red LED to 100% for 500 ms, then off. Prevent retriggering during the 500 ms window and ignore noise.
Simulate warm-white CCT steps by mixing two PWM channels (warm and cool). Cycle through six preset mixes with 2 s dwell per step using a bounded loop.

Define a state machine with modes Idle (off), FadeLoop, and Solid. A control input selects the mode with debounced transitions. In FadeLoop, step through 10 evenly spaced hues with 300 ms per step using a bounded loop. Run updates at 100 Hz.
Program a Larson scanner on an RGB strip with 12 virtual positions, 50 ms per move, and brightness falloff around the head. Ensure the head bounces at the ends and total output stays under 60%.

Control two lighting zones with PWM. Zone A approximates 200 lux using a proportional response to an ambient sensor. Zone B runs a slow warm–cool fade. Update both zones at 20 Hz and cap outputs at 80%.
Make a music-reactive color effect driven by a single audio level input: low levels map to blue, high to red, with brightness proportional to level. Smooth changes over 200 ms and refresh at 100 Hz.
Implement a theater chase on 9 LEDs where every third LED is lit. Advance the offset every 150 ms. After 30 advances, pause for 2 s, then reverse direction. Use bounded loops and explicit states.
Add a safety timeout: if no control message arrives for 2 s, force all LEDs off. Otherwise, run a rainbow cycle at 25 Hz with PWM.
Create a ramp controller that moves an LED array from current brightness to a target over exactly 60 steps with 50 ms between steps. Ensure monotonic change without overshoot.
Build a color temperature dimmer mixing warm and cool channels. A slider from 2700 K to 6500 K sets the mix, linearly mapped to PWM. Update at 30 Hz and limit max to 85%.
Implement a gesture control: a single tap toggles the last color, while a double-tap within 300 ms sets white at 60%. Provide a small state machine for timing, with 40 ms debounce.

Create motion-triggered path lighting: when motion is detected, ripple on LEDs sequentially with 100 ms spacing, hold for 20 s, then ripple off. Make sequences bounded and restart cleanly if motion reoccurs.
Program a tri-color beacon pattern: 3 quick amber flashes (100 ms on, 100 ms off), 1 long red (600 ms), then 2 blue blinks (200 ms on, 200 ms off). Repeat for 15 cycles using bounded loops.
Do daylight harvesting by adjusting five fixtures based on ambient lux to maintain perceived brightness. Enforce per-fixture limits 10%–70% and run the control loop at a fixed 10 Hz rate.
Implement a dimmer that ramps brightness up or down while a button is held (5% every 200 ms) and toggles on short press. Use edge detection and clamp between 15% and 90%.
Generate a trapezoidal pulse train: 200 ms rise, 400 ms hold, 200 ms fall, then 1 s off. Repeat continuously. Expose the durations as parameters and enforce them exactly.
Create status indications: solid green when OK, slow breathing blue when waiting, and rapid flashing red on fault. Use a state machine with priority so fault overrides all other states.
Drive an RGB LED by a color wheel input (0–360 degrees hue). Convert to PWM, update at 60 Hz, and low-pass the hue changes with a bounded moving average over 8 samples.

Run two synchronized LED strips with mirrored chases: left moves left-to-right and right moves right-to-left, stepping every 80 ms. Ensure their endpoints are never simultaneously above 50% brightness.
Simulate candle flicker by adding bounded random variations around a 30% base brightness. Limit changes to no more than 5% per 50 ms to avoid abrupt jumps.
Make a timer-controlled art piece: active from 18:00 to 23:00, run a pastel rainbow at 0.1 Hz; outside that window, dim to 5%. Include a safe override input that forces off.

Create a 3-state photo booth light: Attract (sparkle effect), Countdown (numeric-style blinks), Capture (white flash 80% for 200 ms). Ensure timed transitions and automatic return to Attract after Capture.
Implement PID control to maintain 150 lux at a sensor using two LED channels. Update at 50 Hz, apply integral anti-windup by clamping, saturate outputs at 0–75%, and flag when saturation occurs.

Fuse readings from two ambient sensors (weighted average after median filtering) to drive corridor lighting soft start/stop. Run fusion at 20 Hz with a bounded buffer of 9 samples and fail-safe to 20% if sensors disagree by more than 30 lux.

Create a color-follow effect that tracks a target hue velocity up to 90 degrees/s, with rate limiting. Use a bounded loop to compute 12 intermediate hues for smooth PWM transitions and keep all channels under 70%.
Design a deterministic multi-LED strobe: 5 bursts at 12 Hz with 30% duty, then 3 s dark. Guarantee WCET of 2 ms per cycle and jitter below 1 ms using a fixed update rate.

Implement adaptive dimming with gamma correction. At startup, run a bounded 16-step calibration routine (max 3 s); if calibration times out, fall back to defaults. Apply the gamma curve to PWM output.
Combine motion and proximity inputs: if both indicate presence, set bright white; if only motion, run a slow warm fade; if neither, go idle. Use a deterministic state machine at 100 Hz.

Drive a safety beacon with two lamps flashing in 2 Hz phase opposition (never on at the same time). Include a fault input that forces all outputs off within 50 ms and keep the max brightness under 70%.
Close the loop on color temperature: read CCT from a color sensor and adjust warm/cool mix to hold 4000 K. Use PI control at 25 Hz and ensure total power stays under 60%.
Implement a distributed sparkle effect with a bounded pool of 12 sparkles, each lasting 400 ms and ticking every 50 ms. Ensure that no more than N sparkles are active simultaneously.
Create a lighting control loop that runs at 100 Hz with watchdog integration. On a missed deadline or overrun, switch to a SafeDim mode at 15% and record a fault. Declare WCET as 5 ms.

Design a multi-mode art installation with modes Performance, Ambient, Maintenance, and Safe. Use a hierarchical state machine, per-mode rate attributes (e.g., 200 Hz Performance, 20 Hz Ambient), hard cap total brightness at 65%, and fail-safe to Safe on any fault or missed deadline. Include a bounded test pattern in Maintenance.

Create a choreography engine for 64 LEDs executing scenes with bounded loops, conditional jumps, and time-based fades. Require deterministic updates at 50 Hz, WCET 3 ms, and an emergency stop that forces 0% within 30 ms.

Build a system that blends closed-loop ambient control (PID to 300 lux) with user-selectable color scenes. Provide arbitration that enforces safety caps and limits transitions to no more than 10% brightness change per 100 ms. Run both at a fixed rate.

Specify a redundant-sensor lighting controller using two independent lux sensors and a heartbeat input. Use voting with plausibility checks, fail-operational at 30% when one sensor fails, and fail-safe off when both fail. Define scheduling at 25 Hz with WCET 2 ms and guarantee total power stays under 70%.

Define a verification-focused lighting facade: modes for Rain, Waves, and Pulse using bounded pattern generators; strict timing at 60 Hz with WCET 4 ms; test cases for state transitions, saturation clamps, emergency off, and worst-case loops. Require traceable safety requirements and clear acceptance criteria.

Create a single LED breathing effect using PWM that fades from 0% to 100% and back at a steady 50 Hz update rate. Use a bounded loop to step the brightness up and down and ensure the ramp never exceeds the limits.
