Implement a button-driven state machine with states Off, Low, Medium, and High that sets PWM brightness levels. Debounce the button with a 20 ms window and update outputs at 25 Hz.
Alternate two LEDs: A on for 1 s then off, B on for 1 s then off, repeating without overlap. Keep timing precise and drive PWM at a stable 10 Hz control rate.
Map an analog slider to LED brightness with PWM clamped to 5%–90%. Apply a small deadband to reduce flicker and run updates at 25 Hz.
Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, blue, and white, holding each for 2 s with a 0.5 s cross-fade. Use a bounded loop of fixed steps (e.g., 5% per step) and update at 50 Hz.
When a tap sensor triggers, play a 3 s sparkle sequence of exactly 6 PWM pulses on a single LED, then return to idle. Use a bounded loop for the 6 pulses and ignore re-triggers during the sequence.
Build a nightlight that sets PWM to 30% when ambient light drops below a threshold and turns off above it. Sample at 2 Hz with hysteresis to prevent chatter.
Create a strobe with precise timing: LED on for 10 ms, off for 90 ms, repeating forever. Ensure the duty cycle is exactly 10% and the control runs at a fixed rate.
Make a press-and-hold control where brightness increases by 5% every 100 ms while the button is held, and stays when released. Use a bounded loop to cap at 100% and update at 10 Hz.
Drive an 8-LED bar graph to display a brightness setpoint: light the first N LEDs solid based on the level. Refresh at 20 Hz and use a bounded loop to iterate 8 pixels.
Simulate a candle flicker on one LED by varying PWM between 20% and 60% at 30 Hz using a deterministic pseudo-random source. Keep the variation bounded to avoid abrupt jumps.
On startup, play a short sweep: ramp to 80% in 1 s, then ramp to 0% in 0.5 s, then remain off. Use bounded loops for each ramp and a 50 Hz control rate.
On a rising-edge trigger, flash an LED exactly 5 times with 200 ms on and 200 ms off. Ignore new triggers until the bounded loop of 5 pulses completes.
Display temperature on an RGB LED: below 10 C show blue, 10–25 C show cyan, above 25 C show warm white. Update once per second and clamp PWM between 0% and 80%.
When a power switch turns off, fade the LEDs to black linearly over 3 s with steps of about 2% per 20 ms tick. Ensure brightness never goes below 0%.
Create a color chase on a 16-LED strip where one bright pixel moves forward 10 steps per second with wrap-around. Use a bounded loop to update all pixels each 50 Hz frame.
Implement a state machine with Idle (dim static color), Demo (rainbow for 60 s), and Sleep (off). Transitions occur via button or timer, and the animation runs at a fixed 20 Hz rate.
Cross-fade between two chosen colors over 5 s, limiting each update to a 1% PWM change per channel. Compute steps with a bounded loop and tick at 100 Hz.
Use microphone amplitude to control brightness between 10% and 90% with hysteresis and a one-pole smoothing filter. Update at 100 Hz and never exceed 90% duty.
Mix warm and cool white channels to maintain a target color temperature while varying overall brightness. Constrain total PWM to 85% and refresh at 20 Hz.
Build a pattern sequencer that cycles through solid, blink, chase, and gradient every 15 s. Use a bounded loop index with wrap-around and run all animations at 25 Hz.
On motion, run a 10 s rainbow at 30 frames/s, otherwise hold at 10% warm white. While the sequence runs, ignore retriggers. Use bounded loops for per-frame pixel updates.
Create a sunrise effect that ramps from 0% to 80% brightness over 15 minutes with a maximum change of 0.5% per second. Use a state machine to start/stop and rate-limit at 1 Hz.
Implement a 24-LED VU meter with a peak hold and 1 s decay. Update levels at 60 Hz with bounded loops for both bar fill and peak decay.
Control a color wheel via a rotary encoder so each detent rotates hue by 5 degrees. Debounce at 2 ms, cap brightness at 70%, and update the display at 50 Hz.
Create a breathing wave that travels down a 32-LED strip with a fixed phase offset per LED. Compute PWM for each pixel in a bounded loop at 40 Hz.
Rotate through an 8-color palette with smooth 0.25 s cross-fades. Use a bounded loop over the palette entries with wrap-around and an animation tick at 100 Hz.

Make a sparkler effect that randomly selects up to two pixels per second to flare to 100% and decay over 300 ms. Use a fixed random seed, enforce a 60 Hz frame rate, and bound the number of concurrent flares.
Build a preset system where a short press cycles five color presets and a long press toggles power. Use a state machine with time-based transitions, debounce, and a 50 Hz update rate.
Gate brightness updates so changes are applied only every 50 ms to prevent flicker. Collect incoming changes and commit them on the schedule with a deterministic 20 Hz control rate.
Keep art visibility constant by inversely mapping ambient light to LED brightness. Clamp to 10%–70% PWM, sample at 10 Hz, apply smoothing, and use bounded loops for lookup table mapping.
Split a strip into left and right zones that run independent patterns but synchronize at pattern boundaries. Use bounded loops per zone and maintain a 30 Hz frame rate.
On each beat input rising edge, flash to white for 40 ms then return to the prior color. Ignore retriggers during the 40 ms window and keep timing precise within 2 ms.
Create a 10 s countdown that reduces lit LEDs from 20 to 0, stepping once per second. Ensure the per-second update uses a bounded loop and refresh the display at 10 Hz.
Implement an edge-triggered color invert: when a toggle changes state, invert RGB values for the next frame only, then resume the current pattern. Cap maximum brightness at 80% and run at 60 Hz.

Maintain 200 lux on the artwork using closed-loop PWM control with a PID sampled at 20 Hz. Include integrator clamping, anti-windup, and safety limits of 5%–85% duty. Indicate saturation with a status LED.

Fuse motion and ambient light using a complementary filter at 10 Hz to set a target brightness. If either sensor fails or goes out of range, fall back to a safe 30% brightness. Run animations at 25 Hz with explicit fail-safe states.

Choreograph three regions of a 60-LED strip with distinct color patterns synchronized to a master timeline. Guarantee WCET <= 2 ms per 20 ms frame using bounded loops and a timeline control state machine.

Adapt color temperature based on Celsius temperature and time-of-day input, transitioning smoothly from 6500K to 2700K over the evening while holding user-selected brightness. Limit per-update changes to avoid flicker and update at 2 Hz.
Use PWM dithering to approximate 10-bit brightness with an 8-bit base by cycling a bounded 16-frame pattern at 400 Hz. Ensure average brightness matches the setpoint and no frame exceeds 90% duty.

Match a target chroma using an RGB color sensor with PID adjustments per channel at 10 Hz. Saturate outputs safely, and if the sensor saturates or returns invalid data, switch to neutral white at 40% and enter an error state.

Implement auto-exposure lighting for camera capture: adjust brightness to hold a luminance target, sampling at 30 Hz with steps of no more than 2% per update and a small integral term. Meet a 1 ms WCET per frame.

Combine microphone energy and motion magnitude to modulate color saturation and brightness with weighted blending. Prioritize motion when sound is low. Execute at 50 Hz and fall back to a safe pattern if either input is missing for over 2 s.

Add thermal protection: read temperature and reduce PWM linearly above 60 C, with a hard cutoff at 80 C. Update at 5 Hz with hysteresis to avoid rapid toggling and cap normal operation at 70% brightness.
Generate repeatable sparkle and wave patterns using a seeded pseudo-random sequence. All per-frame operations must run in bounded loops at 60 Hz, and no channel may exceed 85% brightness.

Design a multi-mode installation with Ambient, Interactive, and Performance modes, each with distinct color patterns and rates (Ambient 20 Hz, Interactive 50 Hz, Performance 60 Hz). Use a top-level state machine with timed transitions and manual override, enforce a 75% global ceiling, and prove WCET <= 1.5 ms per frame.

Create a redundant-sensor controller that cross-checks two ambient light sensors. If they differ by >15%, enter Degraded mode at 35% brightness and show a fault pattern; otherwise run closed-loop brightness at 10 Hz. Use deterministic bounded loops and include a startup self-test.

Implement a field-updatable 16-entry color palette: receive data, verify checksum, and atomically swap at a frame boundary. Provide rollback on failure, a safe default palette, and test hooks for bad data injection. Maintain 30 Hz animation within a 2 ms WCET.

Build a formally timed light show scheduler that plays a 10-minute script of cues (color, brightness, duration). Guarantee a 100 Hz control loop with <=1 ms execution even at maximum LED count. Use bounded loops for cue parsing and per-LED updates and include a test plan with worst-case timing measurements.

Add an Emergency Dimming mode that detects low supply voltage and ramps all LEDs to 10% within 200 ms without oscillation. Integrate via a high-priority state machine path, include recovery with hysteresis, and provide unit-testable timing assertions.

Create a smooth PWM fade on a single LED that ramps from 0% to 100% and back to 0% repeatedly. Run the update loop at 50 Hz using a rate attribute, and use a bounded loop to step through exactly 100 brightness levels in each direction.
Flash a single LED in a 3 short, 1 long pattern (three 150 ms on pulses with 150 ms gaps, then one 600 ms on) and repeat this pattern exactly 10 times using a bounded loop, then stay off.
Cycle an RGB LED through six primary/secondary colors at 1 Hz total cycle time. Use a bounded loop to visit exactly red, green, blue, yellow, cyan, magenta in order, with PWM-based color mixing.
Toggle a single LED between 20%, 60%, and 100% brightness each time a button is pressed. Debounce the input and ensure brightness changes only on rising edges.
Map a knob (0–100%) to LED PWM duty (0–100%) linearly and update the LED at 100 Hz. Clamp out-of-range values and ensure no visible stepping.

Implement a breathing effect on one LED: smoothly increase brightness to 90% over 1.5 s and decrease back to 5% over 1.5 s, repeating indefinitely. Use a rate attribute of 200 Hz and a bounded loop for each fade segment.
Alternate an RGB LED between solid red and solid green every 500 ms. Use a bounded loop to perform exactly 20 alternations, then turn off.
When a button press is detected, pulse a single LED three times at 10 Hz (50% duty) and then stay off. Ignore additional presses during the pulse sequence.
Create a strobe light effect with a variable frequency input in Hz. Clamp the frequency between 1 Hz and 20 Hz and use PWM to ensure full on/off transitions with precise timing.
Perform a one-time PWM ramp at startup: increase brightness from 0% to 100% in 100 steps of 10 ms each using a bounded loop, hold at full for 1 s, then turn off.
Indicate a countdown timer on a single LED by setting brightness proportional to remaining time, updated at 20 Hz. At zero, blink rapidly for 2 s then turn off.
On power-up, fade an LED from 0% to 70% over 2 s using a bounded loop, then hold that brightness indefinitely. No other behavior is needed.
Display a solid color on an RGB LED based on an integer input: 0 = red, 1 = green, 2 = blue. Any other value should select white at 50% brightness.

Blink the Morse SOS pattern on a single LED, using precise dot and dash timing (dot = 200 ms, dash = 600 ms). Repeat the full SOS sequence with a 2 s gap, using a bounded loop to schedule on/off segments.
Flash an LED five times rapidly (100 ms on, 100 ms off) every 2 seconds. Implement the five flashes using a bounded loop for the on/off sub-sequence.

Animate a chasing dot across an array of LEDs at 60 Hz, with adjustable speed from a knob. Use a bounded loop to advance the index and wrap around the array, and clamp speed between 0.1 and 2.0 positions per frame.

Implement a state machine with three modes toggled by two buttons: steady white, breathing white, and rainbow cycle. Include debouncing and ignore simultaneous button presses. Update outputs at 100 Hz.
Dim a lamp based on ambient light: as ambient lux increases, reduce PWM duty to keep the scene comfortable. Update brightness at 10 Hz with a gentle ramp limit of 10% per second to avoid flicker.

Create a bouncing bargraph across 10 LEDs where the lit segment moves to the ends and reverses direction. Use a bounded loop to render segments and ensure WCET for each frame update is less than 2 ms.

Provide warm/cool white balance control using two sliders, and two modes (Day and Evening) in a state machine. Cross-fade between modes over 3 s using a bounded loop and maintain total brightness at a fixed 60%.

When motion is detected, play a 30 s warm gradient animation on an RGB strip, then return to a dim blue idle. Use timers for sequence durations and rate-limit re-triggering to at most once every 10 s.
Map an audio amplitude input to LED color from blue (quiet) to red (loud). Update at 100 Hz, filter out spikes, and interpolate color with a bounded loop for smooth transitions.
Play a scripted list of color/time pairs on an RGB strip. Iterate through the list using a bounded loop, apply each color for its duration, and loop back to the start when finished.
Control two lighting zones with independent PWM schedules. Ensure each zone follows its timing sequence without interference, and run updates at a steady 1 kHz using a rate attribute.
Render a clock on a 60-LED ring: a moving dot for seconds and a trailing tail for minutes. Update the second hand at exactly 1 Hz and the tail at 10 Hz. Use bounded loops to draw the trail.
Implement a state machine: short press steps through brightness levels (10%, 30%, 60%, 100%), long press enters a programming mode that times out after 15 s of inactivity back to normal.
Cycle through four seasonal color palettes. Each palette is an 8-color bounded loop with 2 s per color, and the active palette changes every hour using a monotonic timer.
Enforce a safety brightness cap based on battery voltage: above 3.7 V allow up to 100% duty, between 3.5 V and 3.7 V cap at 50%, below 3.2 V turn off. Update the cap at 5 Hz and apply immediately.
Accept simple text commands to set color and PWM duty (e.g., SET R,G,B or SET DUTY x). Implement a robust parser as a state machine, reject invalid inputs, and apply changes at 20 Hz.
Cross-fade between two user-selected colors over a configurable duration T in seconds. Use a bounded loop to compute gamma-corrected PWM steps and ensure the fade completes exactly at T.
Create a heartbeat pattern: two quick pulses (100 ms on, 100 ms off, repeat) followed by a 700 ms pause. Make the tempo adjustable from 40 to 180 bpm and clamp to that range.
Simulate daylight color temperature by ramping from 2700 K to 6500 K over 30 minutes with updates at 1 Hz. Use bounded steps and hold the final state until reset.
Combine a touch sensor and an ambient light sensor: touch toggles run/stop, ambient light scales brightness. Implement as a clear state machine and handle debounce and value clamping.
Build an alarm indicator: on alert, flash red at 2 Hz; on acknowledge, show yellow for 5 s then steady green. Model behavior as a state machine with precise timers.

Animate a corridor of 20 LED segments when motion is detected at either end. The light should move from the triggered end to the other over 2 s. Use a bounded loop to ensure no segment exceeds 80% PWM.
Maintain a target illuminance of 200 lux at a sensor using closed-loop PWM with a PID controller. Run the control loop at 200 Hz, limit duty cycle to 85%, and include anti-windup.

Control color temperature using warm and cool channels to achieve a target of 4000 K measured by a sensor. Use PID on the warm/cool ratio, enforce total current not exceeding 300 mA, and reduce output if temperature exceeds 60 C.

Fuse ambient light and motion sensing to set brightness: when motion is present, move toward a higher target based on ambient; when absent, decay toward a lower target. Update at 20 Hz and smooth transitions with bounded loops.
Compensate for external flicker measured by a sensor: apply feedforward plus PID to keep measured lux steady. Run at 1 kHz and ensure the control step WCET remains below 200 microseconds.
Implement thermal management for an LED array: use a PID loop to maintain 50 C at a temperature sensor by adjusting PWM, clamp brightness between 10% and 100%, and perform a safe shutdown above 70 C.

Perform color calibration using a color sensor to reach a target chromaticity. Iterate adjustments in a bounded loop of at most 30 iterations per attempt, updating at 25 Hz, and stop when the color error is within tolerance.
Maintain perceived brightness despite battery voltage droop by fusing voltage and current measurements and adjusting PWM at 100 Hz. Enforce a hard limit of 500 mA and reduce output if necessary.
Design a safety-critical beacon with Normal, Fault, and Emergency states. Run the main loop at 100 Hz with WCET under 1 ms, and fail-safe to off if a timing overrun or internal error is detected.
Synchronize a repeating light pattern to an external PPS signal. Adjust phase using a PID controller so the pattern frame aligns within 5 ms jitter. Render frames via a bounded loop at 50 Hz.

Implement a glare limiter: compute a comfortable brightness target from ambient lux and a user comfort setting, enforce a ramp rate limit of 20% per second, and manage transitions with a state machine. Keep WCET under 0.5 ms.

Create a multi-mode light installation with Setup, Rehearsal, Performance, and Emergency modes. Each mode runs distinct color sequences using bounded loops, with rendering at 60 Hz and supervision at 10 Hz via rate attributes. Define explicit transitions and safe fallback to Emergency on sensor faults or missed deadlines, with WCETs per task.

Implement a cue-driven show: interpret a time-stamped list of scenes with start times, cross-fades, and blackouts. Use a hierarchical state machine for show control, bounded loops for per-scene patterns, and guarantee cue application does not exceed a 2 ms WCET. Provide acceptance tests for boundary timing and failure injection.

Develop an energy-aware lighting canopy with Day, Evening, Night, and Battery-Save modes. Fuse ambient lux, battery voltage, and temperature to select mode and set PWM limits. Use PID to maintain illuminance in each mode, enforce duty caps, and include comprehensive tests to verify 100 Hz rate stability and safe behavior under sensor faults.

Build a public safety beacon with selectable regulatory flash patterns via commands. Implement a robust command parser state machine, bounded loops for pattern tables, and enforce hard constraints: maximum average optical output, minimum off-time per cycle, thermal cutback over 55 C, and immediate fail-silent on internal errors. Include a traceable requirements list and test plan.

Design an immersive LED tunnel orchestrator with multiple synchronized zones. Use a master tick to phase-align zones via PID, render at 120 Hz, and supervise with a 10 Hz safety task. The state machine must handle Maintenance, Live Show, and Evacuation modes. Specify invariants (no zone exceeds 85% duty for more than 5 s), WCET budgets, and end-to-end tests for jitter and failover.
Make one white LED breathe: fade brightness from 5% to 60% and back in a smooth triangle wave at 0.25 Hz using PWM. Limit duty cycle to a maximum of 60% and run the control loop at 100 Hz.
Blink a single status LED at exactly 2.0 Hz with 50% duty cycle. Keep timing jitter under 2 ms and ensure WCET <= 0.5 ms. Use a controller rate of 200 Hz.
On each pushbutton press, step a single LED brightness through 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100%, then wrap. Include 30 ms debounce. Drive the LED with PWM.
Cycle one RGB LED through red, green, and blue, each held for 1.5 s. Use a bounded loop of exactly three colors per cycle and repeat continuously.
Hold a fixed color on an RGB LED while a potentiometer sets overall brightness from 10% to 90% linearly. Update at 100 Hz and filter the input slightly to avoid jitter.
Implement a one-shot locator flash: when a momentary input goes high, flash a white LED for 120 ms at 80% brightness, then turn off and ignore further triggers until complete.
Create a night-light effect: when enable is true, fade from 0% to 30% over 10 s; when disabled, fade down to 0% over 5 s. Run at 50 Hz for smoothness.
Produce a heartbeat pattern on one LED: two short pulses (60 ms on, 60 ms off, then 60 ms on) followed by 700 ms off at 40% brightness. Implement as a bounded sequence and repeat.
Make a warning LED blink exactly 3 times quickly (100 ms on, 100 ms off) then pause for 1.5 s. Use a bounded loop of 3 iterations for the blink cluster and repeat.
Implement a simple PWM dimmer: a short button press increments brightness by 10% (wrapping at 100%), and a long press over 500 ms toggles full-on at 100%.
When a power-good input goes low, perform a smooth fade-out to 0% over 2 s; otherwise maintain steady 70% brightness. Update at 100 Hz.
Provide soft-start behavior: on enable, ramp brightness from 0% to a target 50% in 300 ms using PWM. Run the update loop at 500 Hz.
Toggle an RGB LED between solid amber and off every 3 s. Keep PWM carrier frequency above 500 Hz to avoid visible flicker.
Display battery level on a bar of 5 LEDs as discrete steps: each LED either off or at 60% brightness based on level. Refresh the display at 20 Hz.
Flash SOS in Morse code on a single LED at 40% brightness. Use a bounded loop to encode three short, three long, three short, then pause 2 s, and repeat.
Create a state machine with states Idle, FadeIn, Hold, and FadeOut to control an RGB strip showing cyan at 70%: FadeIn 1 s, Hold 3 s, FadeOut 1 s, Idle 2 s, then loop. Run at 100 Hz.
Design a color chaser across 12 LEDs: move a lit dot at 30 steps per second with a trailing fade across the previous 5 LEDs. Use a bounded loop over the LED indices and wrap around.
Implement a theater chase pattern that alternates red and blue on even and odd LEDs at a 5 Hz group update rate. Include a switch input to pause and resume.

Two-mode lamp: Mode A is warm white at 40% steady; Mode B is a rainbow fade cycling through 10 hues over 20 s using a bounded color list. A button toggles modes with debounce, and a long press powers off.
Audio-reactive brightness: given an analog level 0–1.0, scale LED brightness between 10% and 90% using an envelope with 50 ms attack and 300 ms release. Update at 200 Hz.
Ambient-reactive desk light: read light level in lux. If ambient is below 50 lx, ramp LED to 30% over 2 s; if above 200 lx, ramp down to 5%. Use 10 lx hysteresis and update at 20 Hz.
Apply a breathing pattern to all LEDs but stagger each LED phase by 50 ms using a bounded loop over LED indices. Ensure the overall cycle is exactly 4 s.

Tri-color status logic: green fast blink (4 Hz) for state ready, yellow slow blink (1 Hz) for state waiting, red solid for state error. Implement a state machine with priority error over ready over waiting.
Touch dimmer behavior: tap cycles brightness through 0/25/50/75/100%, double-tap toggles color between cool and warm white, and hold ramps brightness up then down until released.
Timed scene sequencer: run Scene 1 for 10 s (cool white 30%), Scene 2 for 6 s (magenta pulsing at 0.5 Hz), Scene 3 for 4 s (off). Loop scenes using a bounded list and update at 100 Hz.
Dual-channel crossfade: a knob controls a crossfade between two LED channels so that A% + B% always equals 60%. Update at 100 Hz and clamp each channel between 0% and 60%.
Rainbow wheel on a 16-pixel ring: rotate hue at one revolution per 8 s using a bounded loop over 16 indices. Provide a global brightness control from 0% to 80%.
Implement a safety timeout: if there is no user interaction for 30 minutes, fade all LEDs to 5% over 10 s. Any interaction resets the timer.
Create a candle flicker effect using bounded pseudo-random jitter: vary brightness between 20% and 45%, selecting a new target every 40 ms and slewing over 30 ms to avoid abrupt changes.
Provide color temperature control by mixing warm and cool channels to achieve presets at 2700 K, 3000 K, 3500 K, 4000 K, 5000 K, and 6500 K. Use a bounded preset list and default to 4000 K.
Metronome light: selectable tempo 40–200 BPM. On beat 1 of a 4/4 cycle, flash bright; on other beats, flash dimmer. Run at 1 kHz to minimize jitter and keep WCET <= 0.5 ms.
Sunrise alarm: over 20 minutes ramp from 0% to 100% brightness while shifting color temperature from 2700 K to 5000 K. A cancel input stops the sequence and turns lights off.

Traffic light sequence with a pedestrian request: green 5 s, amber 2 s, red 5 s, repeating. If a pedestrian request arrives during green, shorten the current green to 2 s before switching. Implement as a bounded state machine.
Music beat strobe: on each rising edge of a beat trigger, flash the LED array to 90% for 80 ms, then decay exponentially back to an ambient level over 600 ms.
Provide a color picker via three analog inputs (R, G, B) scaled 0–1.0. Constrain each channel to 0–80% and apply per-channel gamma of 2.0. Update at 200 Hz.

Closed-loop lumen control: use a light sensor in lux to regulate LEDs to 300 lx at the work surface using a PID at 100 Hz. Limit PWM duty between 5% and 90%, cap slew rate at 20% per second, and go to safe-off if the sensor is invalid for more than 100 ms.

Thermal-aware brightness control: read the heat sink temperature and maintain target brightness unless temperature exceeds 60 C. Above 60 C, use a PI controller to hold 58 C by reducing output. Hard cap brightness to 30% when temperature is over 70 C. Run at 50 Hz.

Flicker-safe dimming policy: ensure PWM base frequency is at least 2 kHz and disallow any blinking components below 100 Hz. Perform scene transitions via bounded step loops while meeting WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Sensor fusion for occupancy lighting: combine motion detection and ambient light in lux to decide lighting. If motion is present and ambient < 80 lx, set lights to 40% for 5 minutes; otherwise turn off. Implement a two-state machine and add confidence decay at 0.1 per second.

Color stabilization with current feedback: measure per-channel current for R, G, and B, and run a small PID at 200 Hz per channel to hold target currents while ensuring total current <= 500 mA and per-channel <= 200 mA. On overcurrent, enter safe-off.

Adaptive glare control: maintain eye-level illuminance at 150 lx using PID, but constrain brightness change to 10% per 100 ms to avoid discomfort. After sudden ambient spikes greater than 100 lx, freeze output for 2 s before resuming control.

High-precision stroboscope: allow adjustable frequency from 1 to 50 Hz and pulse width from 1 to 5 ms. Enforce timing accuracy of ±0.5 ms and prevent average duty cycle from exceeding 20% to protect the LED. Run the controller at 5 kHz.

Dynamic color balancer: measure chroma error from a color sensor and adjust RGB outputs via PID to reach a desired hue and saturation within 2 s. Update at 100 Hz, and if calibration fails, revert to neutral white at 50%.

Emergency egress mode: upon a power failure signal, enter a state machine that sets lights to 20% steady for 30 minutes while checking battery voltage every 1 s. If voltage drops below a threshold, step down to 10% and then 5% in bounded decrements. When mains returns, exit to normal.

Motion and sound fusion art piece: if motion is detected or sound level exceeds 60 dB, start a 15 s color wave across 24 LEDs moving at 0.5 m/s equivalent around the ring; otherwise stay at 5% dim. Use bounded loops and update at 100 Hz.

Design a three-mode lighting controller: Normal mode provides user dimming 0–80% and scene playback from bounded color lists, Party mode runs an auto color chase at 12 Hz segment updates, and Night mode holds 5% warm white with no motion wake. Implement a supervisory state machine with entry and exit actions, run at 100 Hz, WCET <= 1 ms, and define a test sequence covering mode transitions, debounce, and inactivity timeouts.

Implement an art installation with two operational modes and a maintenance mode: Mode A shows a rainbow wheel, Mode B plays scripted story beats across 32 LEDs using bounded loops, and Maintenance holds 10% white for inspection. Define fail-safe responses for sensor faults, overcurrent, and overtemperature, and outline tests for each fault path.

Create a multi-scene theater light controller with a scheduler: scenes have start times, durations, and crossfades. Enforce that total power usage never exceeds 70%. Include a state machine for Pause, Play, Skip, and an emergency Stop that forces safe-off. Provide functional tests for timing accuracy and power capping.

Build a safety-critical signal beacon with modes Standby, Beacon, and SOS. Beacon mode emits a 1 Hz flash at 80% with 10% duty; SOS emits Morse via a bounded pattern; Standby is off. Specify flicker-safe PWM above 1 kHz, battery protection that reduces to 30% below 3.3 V, WCET <= 0.5 ms, and define tests for timing, limits, and fault recovery.

Develop a museum light controller with Day, Evening, Cleaning, and Emergency modes. Day maintains 200 lx via PID; Evening runs a gentle color fade; Cleaning sets 100% white for 15 minutes; Emergency sets 20% red flashing at 0.5 Hz. Include supervision, safe-off on sensor failure, thermal and current limits, explicit update rates, a WCET budget, and a verification plan with edge-case tests.

Create a single LED breathing effect using PWM: smoothly ramp brightness from 0% to 100% and back to 0% over a 2 s cycle. Run the control update at a fixed rate (e.g., 100 Hz). Use a bounded loop to perform exactly 20 full breath cycles, then turn the LED off and stop.

When a pushbutton is pressed, toggle a status LED between off and a steady 70% brightness using PWM. Debounce the button with a 30 ms requirement. Keep the update loop rate fixed and ensure brightness always remains within 0–100%.

Blink two LEDs in alternation at 1 Hz with a 50% duty cycle. Execute the timing at a fixed rate attribute of 100 Hz, and use a bounded loop to run the alternating pattern for exactly 60 seconds before both LEDs are turned off.
Drive a single LED according to a slide switch: if ON, set PWM to 100% (full brightness); if OFF, set to 10% (nightlight). Ensure duty cycles never exceed bounds and update at a stable rate.

Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, and blue, holding each color for 1 s with smooth PWM fades between them. Use a bounded loop to repeat the 3-color sequence exactly 5 times, then set the LED to off.
On a button press, emit a white flash at 80% brightness for 200 ms, then return to the prior state (off). Debounce input for 30 ms and ignore additional presses during the 200 ms flash window.
Set a warm-white LED channel to a steady amber-like glow (target around 2000 K appearance) using PWM at 60% brightness. Update the PWM command at a fixed 500 Hz rate to minimize visible flicker.
Implement a heartbeat indicator on a single LED: a double pulse (two quick 80% brightness blips separated by 200 ms), followed by a 2 s idle. Keep timing jitter under 5 ms and repeat indefinitely.
Read one analog control input and map it linearly to a PWM brightness from 0% to 100%. Update the LED at 20 Hz, clamp out-of-range values, and smooth with a small slew limit to avoid abrupt steps.

Use an ambient light sensor to control a nightlight: if ambient is below 50 lux, turn the LED on at 40% brightness; otherwise keep it off. Sample at 5 Hz and include 5 lux hysteresis to prevent flicker.

When a trigger input goes high, strobe an LED at 10 Hz for exactly 5 seconds (bounded number of flashes), then return to off. Ensure accurate 50% duty timing and ignore retriggers during the strobe window.

Create a simple chasing pattern across 8 LEDs: one LED on at a time moving left to right at 5 steps per second. Use a bounded loop to perform exactly 3 full laps, then stop with all LEDs off. Avoid any wrap-around glitch.
Implement a sunrise effect: linearly ramp a white LED from 0% to 100% over 30 s, then hold steady. Use a fixed-rate update and clamp brightness to prevent overshoot.
On power-up, flash a status LED three times with 100 ms on / 100 ms off, then leave it steady on. Ensure the entire sequence completes in under 1 s total.
Detect a double-tap on a button (two presses within 300 ms) to toggle an RGB LED between blue and magenta. Ignore long holds and single taps. Keep PWM brightness at 60%.

Drive a 12-LED RGB strip with a looping rainbow pattern. At a fixed 50 Hz frame rate, use a bounded loop to update each LED’s hue per frame. Provide one analog input to scale global intensity from 10% to 100%.

Build a state machine with states: Idle, Animate, Alert. Idle holds 10% brightness; Animate performs a slow color wipe; Alert flashes red at 4 Hz when a digital alarm input is high. Define transitions clearly and ensure only one state drives the LEDs at a time.

Use two buttons to control an RGB pattern generator: one cycles between Solid, Fade, and Chase modes; the other sets speed from 0.5 to 5 Hz. Step frames at a fixed rate and use bounded loops for per-frame LED updates. Debounce inputs.
Create a breathing LED synchronized to a tempo input (1 pulse per second for 60 BPM). Sample the tempo input at 100 Hz and adjust the fade period dynamically to stay in sync.
Implement closed-loop backlight control: map ambient light from 10–1000 lux to 15–90% LED brightness with a 5 lux hysteresis band. Update at a stable 1 kHz PWM command rate to reduce visible flicker.

Create a touch-controlled white light with three modes: Cool (6500 K), Warm (2700 K), and Alternating (switch every 5 s). Use a state machine with debounced transitions and maintain total brightness at 60%.
Fade between two user-selected colors over 8 s, pause 500 ms at each target, then continue. Use a bounded loop to execute exactly 10 complete transitions and then hold the final color.

Program a 16-LED scanner (Knight rider) with a soft tail. At 60 Hz, use a bounded loop to compute 16 positions per frame, with an exponential decay on tail brightness. Sweep back and forth continuously.
Drive a strobe brightness from an audio peak input (0.0–1.0). Map to 20–80% LED intensity, apply a 200 ms hold after peaks, and include a slew limiter to prevent rapid flicker. Update at 100 Hz.

Implement a night mode controller: after 30 minutes with no motion detected, dim LEDs to 5%. On motion, return to the prior brightness. Use a state machine with a timeout and ensure transitions are debounced.

Create a tri-color status lamp: Green steady for OK, Yellow slow blink (1 Hz) for Warning, Red fast flash (4 Hz) for Fault. Only one pattern may run at a time. Use bounded loops within each pattern and a clean state selection.

Play a scripted sequence of 8 scenes, each with a color and a duration up to 15 s. Use bounded loops to realize linear crossfades between scenes at a fixed update rate. After the last scene, loop back to the first.
Make a breathing LED whose peak brightness scales with temperature: map 20–40 Celsius to a 30–90% peak. Update the mapping at 10 Hz and keep the breathing period constant at 3 s.

Implement a turn-signal effect with a finite state machine: states Off, Left, Right, Hazard. Left/Right animate a 6-LED outward sweep at 2 sweeps/s; Hazard drives both sides mirrored. Ensure exclusive control per state.
Add an emergency stop behavior: on a stop input, immediately turn all LEDs off within 10 ms and inhibit all patterns for 2 s. Afterward, resume the previous pattern from its last state.
Control an RGB LED with a rotary encoder: rotate to change hue 0–360 degrees, press to save the current color. Keep brightness at a fixed 60% and wrap hue at the ends.

Create a 24-hour circadian lighting schedule with 6 time blocks. Each block defines a target color temperature and brightness. Transition smoothly at block boundaries using crossfades and hold values between transitions.
Read a battery voltage (3.0–4.2 V) and map to LED color from red (low) to green (full). If below 3.2 V, flash red at 1 Hz. Update at 2 Hz with 0.05 V hysteresis to avoid color flicker.
Crossfade between two LED zones (A and B) using a slider input. Maintain the sum of outputs at or below 80% total by proportional scaling. Ensure smooth fades and clamp out-of-range input.
Render a sparkles effect on 30 LEDs: pick 3 random LEDs per second to light at 100% for 100 ms, then decay to 0 over 400 ms. Use bounded loops for per-frame updates at 100 Hz.

Maintain 300 lux on a surface using a photodiode and a white LED with PWM. Implement a PID controller with anti-windup, sample at 200 Hz, clamp duty to 0–95%, and achieve settling within 2 s with <10% overshoot.

Fuse ambient light and proximity data: if a person is within 0.5 m, increase the brightness target by 20% but cap at 90%; otherwise follow an ambient-to-brightness curve. Use a complementary filter (0.8 ambient / 0.2 proximity) at 50 Hz.

Regulate color temperature using warm and cool LED channels to achieve a target 2700–6500 K while maintaining constant luminous flux. Balance channels with a controller and indicate saturation when limits prevent reaching the target.

Build an adaptive strobe that locks to a beat detector and an accelerometer. Fuse both to estimate tempo in BPM, strobe at that rate, and apply phase corrections. Guarantee computation WCET under 1 ms per frame at 200 Hz.

Create a safety-critical cue executor: on a GO command, run a 12-step lighting sequence with exact durations. If an overcurrent flag rises, immediately transition to Safe state and set all channels to 0% within 5 ms, then log the fault code.

Control dimming to keep LED junction temperature below 60 Celsius using a temperature sensor. Use a PID that gradually reduces PWM as needed. Sample at 10 Hz, and turn off immediately if the sensor is invalid or temperature exceeds 80 Celsius.

Estimate ambient illuminance using two noisy sensors with a Kalman filter, then drive LEDs to reach 150 lux at the target surface. Update at 20 Hz and use bounded loops to update exactly 8 LEDs per frame.
Implement color fades with a per-channel slew limit: no more than 5% brightness change per 10 ms. Enforce a 100 Hz control tick via a rate attribute and ensure WCET stays below 0.5 ms.

Design a safety state machine with modes: Normal, Brownout, ThermalLimit, Fault. Each mode drives distinct LED patterns. Transitions must be debounced and time-qualified; any Fault must turn LEDs off within 2 cycles.

Control a 10x10 LED mural: use bounded double loops to update each cell each frame. Brightness responds to a 2D position estimate from multiple sensors. Enforce a total current limit equivalent to 1.5 A by scaling outputs proportionally.

Develop a multi-mode architectural lighting controller with profiles: Gallery, Lounge, Night, Emergency. Include a supervisory state machine, profile persistence, and a watchdog. Specify rate attributes per profile and WCET constraints (e.g., 1 kHz update, 0.8 ms worst-case). Provide built-in test sequences at startup to verify PWM channels, sensors, and timing.

Create a stage show light engine with a cue stack of 20 cues, each defining fade-in/out times, hold durations, and color palettes. Include Preview and Live modes with crossfading. Require deterministic timing, a bounded loop to iterate cues, a panic blackout input, max brightness 85%, and a test harness with acceptance criteria.

Build an interactive art wall with modes: Idle shimmer, Visitor attract, Performance synced, Maintenance. Use sensor fusion (vision trigger plus proximity) to select modes. Each mode uses its own rate attribute and pattern state machine. Enforce WCET under 1 ms at 200 Hz and include diagnostics that validate sensor ranges and LED mapping before enabling outputs.

Design an outdoor installation controller with modes: Daylight dimming, Evening ambiance, Night low-power, Storm alert. Define explicit transitions, failsafe rules for overcurrent and moisture detection, and current budgeting across 4 zones. Include a comprehensive test plan with simulated sensors, timing checks, and brightness ramp limits (e.g., 1% per 20 ms).

Implement a museum exhibit controller that orchestrates synchronized light patterns across three rooms using a time synchronization input. Use bounded loops to address up to 120 LEDs per room. Provide modes for Setup, Rehearsal, Show, and Emergency, each with distinct rates and strict WCET budgets. Include verification goals, runtime monitors for deadline misses, and a safe fallback that reduces all outputs to 10% within 2 cycles.
Blink a single indicator LED at 2 Hz using PWM with 50% duty cycle. Run the update logic at a fixed rate (e.g., 100 Hz). Cap brightness at 70% and ensure a safe current limit (do not exceed 20 mA).

Create a smooth fade in/out loop for one LED over 10 seconds total. Use a bounded loop with exactly 100 steps per half-cycle and PWM to control brightness. The fade should repeat continuously at a stable rate.
When a pushbutton is pressed, turn the LED on; when released, turn it off. Debounce at 10 ms granularity and ensure PWM brightness is set to 100% only while held.
One-touch night lamp: a touch sensor toggles the LED between off and a gentle 30% brightness. Ignore spurious touches shorter than 50 ms.
Use an ambient light reading (in lux) to switch a nightlight: below 20 lux, set LED to 25% brightness; otherwise, turn it off. Evaluate at 5 Hz.
Implement a breathing effect (soft inhale/exhale) for a single LED with a 4 s period. Shape brightness using a bounded lookup table of 20 steps and PWM.
Cycle a single RGB LED through red, green, and blue, pausing 1 s on each color. Use a fixed update rate of 50 Hz to interpolate transitions.
On receipt of a trigger pulse, flash the LED three times rapidly (100 ms on, 100 ms off), then stay off. Use a bounded loop for exactly three flashes.
Operate a status LED at 40% brightness, but if the temperature sensor reads 60 C or higher, immediately turn the LED off and latch it off until temperature drops below 55 C.
Map a potentiometer position to LED brightness (0–100%) via PWM. Sample at 100 Hz and clamp the maximum duty cycle to 90% to protect the LED.
When a rising edge is seen on a digital input, blink an LED for 200 ms. During that interval, ignore additional triggers (one-shot behavior).
Provide a heartbeat LED: 100 ms on, 900 ms off repeating at 1 Hz. Maintain timing accuracy within 10 ms.
After startup, ramp LED brightness from 0% to 100% over 2 s using a bounded ramp, then hold steady.
On low-voltage detection, immediately reduce LED brightness to 10% and keep it there until normal voltage returns. Update at 20 Hz.
A single button triggers a one-shot light: LED turns on for exactly 5 seconds, then off. Additional presses during the 5 s window do nothing.

Make a small color dial: a rotary control adjusts hue on an RGB LED, and a toggle switches between hue-edit and saturation-edit modes. Use a simple state machine for modes, a bounded loop over a 360-step color wheel, and a steady 100 Hz update rate.
Create a chasing pattern across 12 LEDs, with speed controlled by a potentiometer. Use a bounded loop to iterate exactly 12 positions and update the pattern at 50 Hz.
Two buttons control an RGB LED: one cycles color presets, the other steps brightness levels. Debounce inputs at 10 ms and handle with a small state machine. Long-press either button to turn off.
Map ambient light (lux) to LED brightness in four discrete zones: very dark, dim, normal, bright. Evaluate at 10 Hz. If ambient temperature exceeds 45 C, cap PWM duty at 80%.
Program a simple traffic light with three LEDs (green, yellow, red) that cycles through standard timings. Model it as a state machine with fixed dwell times and repeat the sequence continuously.
Drive LED brightness from an audio envelope input. Smooth the envelope with a short moving average and update brightness at 100 Hz. Switch color to red when the envelope exceeds a threshold.
When motion is detected, fade an RGB LED from idle blue to bright warm white over 3 s; after 10 s of no motion, fade back. Use a state machine and a 50 ms step timing.
Implement a theater marquee effect across 24 LEDs. Use a bounded loop to compute each frame, update at 30 Hz, and allow a switch to reverse the direction of motion.
Create a sunrise sequence that shifts color temperature from 2000 K to 6500 K over 15 minutes while increasing brightness from 0% to 100%. Update once per second with smooth interpolation.
Design a countdown indicator: in 'idle' the LED is off, in 'armed' it pulses at 1 Hz, and in 'active' it glows solid. Implement these as states with a 20 Hz update rate.
Make two LEDs breathe alternately with a 180-degree phase offset. Use a bounded 40-step waveform. If temperature rises above 60 C, force both off and only re-enable once below 55 C.
Flash a short predefined Morse code message on a single LED. Use bounded loops to render dots and dashes, operate at 5 words per minute, and ensure the message stops cleanly at the end.
Cycle through a palette of 8 RGB colors, fading between each over 2 seconds. Implement a bounded loop over the palette; a button press should skip to the next color immediately.
Single-button dimmer: single click toggles on/off, double click cycles preset levels (25/50/75/100%), long press turns off. Manage timing with a state machine and 10 ms debouncing.
Create a strobe effect with adjustable frequency from 1 to 20 Hz and a fixed 10% duty cycle. Ensure the underlying PWM carrier is high enough to avoid visible flicker and cap brightness at 70%.
Animate a wave across 10 LED segments. Compute intensities for each segment in a bounded loop and refresh exactly at 60 Hz. Provide a global brightness control.
Implement a color-chase pattern that wraps around a strip. Use a 100 Hz rate attribute, iterate over LEDs with a bounded loop, and keep the per-update WCET under 1 ms.
Use a bicolor LED as a status indicator: green fading when OK, red blinking when fault input is active. Latch the fault state until a clear signal is received.
Candle flicker effect: play back a pseudo-random brightness sequence from a 50-entry bounded lookup at 30 Hz. Limit the maximum change per frame to reduce harsh jumps.
Create a split gradient across 16 LEDs: left half blue, right half red. When a slider changes, crossfade to the new mix over 1 s. Apply approximate gamma correction via a 16-step bounded table.

Closed-loop brightness control: use a light sensor to maintain 200 lux on a surface by adjusting LED PWM. Use PID, sample at 50 Hz, clamp output to 0–90%, add integral anti-windup, and fail-safe to off on sensor fault.

Regulate color temperature by blending warm and cool white LEDs to achieve a requested CCT (in Kelvin) while maintaining a target illuminance. Update at 10 Hz, enforce per-channel current limit of 18 mA, and derate if temperature exceeds 70 C.

Fuse ambient light and proximity sensors to decide when to ramp up brightness: only brighten when it is dark (<50 lux) and motion is present. Use a simple weighted decision with time decay, a 20 Hz loop, and states for idle, waiting, and active.

Synchronize two LED strips to show mirrored patterns. Use bounded loops over 60 LEDs per strip, a 100 Hz timebase, and ensure jitter stays under 2 ms. If a cycle deadline is missed, skip a step gracefully to resynchronize.

Adaptive strobe art piece: keep perceived brightness constant using feedback from a photodiode while strobe frequency varies between 5 and 40 Hz. Apply PID to duty cycle, never exceed 80% duty, and block frequencies in the 15–20 Hz band.

Gamma calibration mode: step PWM duty from 0% to 100% in 32 bounded increments, pausing 200 ms each, while sampling a photodiode. Compute and store a 16-entry gamma lookup for use in normal operation.

Dynamic rainbow across 60 LEDs with continuous hue cycling. Use bounded loops per frame, a 100 Hz update rate, and when temperature exceeds 65 C, ramp brightness down to 30% and only recover below 60 C. Guarantee WCET <= 1.5 ms per update.

Color stabilizer: measure reflected RGB with a 3-channel sensor and adjust LED mixing to hit a target chromaticity. Run at 10 Hz, clamp per-channel PWM, and enter a safe amber mode if readings are inconsistent or saturate.

Beat-synchronized lighting: lock a pattern's phase to a 120 BPM reference using an audio envelope. Use a PI controller for tempo adjustment, update no faster than 200 Hz, and smoothly revert to default speed on missed-beat timeout.

Lux tracking wall wash: maintain 300 lux on a surface while slowly cycling color temperature. Use PID for intensity with feed-forward from prior steps. Include brownout detection forcing minimal safe brightness and keep computation WCET under 2 ms.

Design a multi-mode light sculpture with modes: Idle, PaletteCycle, Reactive, Calibration, and Fault. Use a hierarchical state machine, bounded loops for 72 LEDs, and a 100 Hz base rate. Define safety limits (per-channel <= 18 mA, duty <= 85%), handle brownout and over-temp, and run a deterministic startup. Provide test hooks to simulate sensors and a self-test that verifies each LED segment in under 3 seconds.

Create a show controller with schedules: Daylight, Evening, Night, and Maintenance. Each mode defines color patterns, brightness caps, and timing sequences with guaranteed minimum dwell times. Require WCET <= 1 ms at 100 Hz, bounded loops over 100 LEDs, and formal checks that no mode can command more than 6 W total power. Include assertions and a safe fallback that dims to 10%.

Implement gallery installation firmware with operator commands: Start, Pause, NextScene, PrevScene, and EmergencyOff. Scenes include wave, sparkle, and gradient. Enforce rate attributes (60 Hz visuals, 10 Hz supervision), bounded per-LED iteration, and a watchdog that switches to EmergencyOff if any task overruns. Provide a test plan with scenario coverage and timing margins.

Develop a multi-room lighting controller using shared ambient and occupancy inputs per zone. Modes: EnergySave, Presentation, Showcase, Evacuation. Use sensor fusion for transitions, PID to regulate lux per zone, per-channel current limiting, and strict per-cycle WCET budgets. Specify end-to-end latency limits and define verification cases for mode changes, fault injection, and recovery.

Specify a performance-critical interactive art piece where touch, audio, and light sensors drive 150 LEDs. Require a modular state machine with interruptible transitions, rate partitioning (visuals 120 Hz, sensors 200 Hz, logging 10 Hz), bounded loops for array updates, and comprehensive safety (thermal derating, current caps, duty clamps, emergency blackout). Include measurable acceptance criteria and a regression test matrix.

Create a smooth breathing effect on a single LED using PWM: fade from 10% to 90% and back using a bounded loop of 100 steps per half-cycle at a control rate of 100 Hz. Keep the PWM frequency steady and start with the LED off for a safe initial state.

Make a simple PWM dimmer that blinks an LED at a fixed 1 s period with an adjustable duty cycle (10% to 90%). Update the duty once per second and ensure the loop is bounded so the pattern repeats exactly 60 times then stops.
When a button is pressed, ramp an LED to 80% brightness over 500 ms; when released, fade back to 10% over 500 ms. Run the control at 100 Hz using a rate attribute, and clamp brightness within 0–100%.
Alternate two indicator LEDs: A on for 250 ms while B off, then swap. Keep precise timing, repeat continuously, and ensure both start off for a safe power-up.
Cycle a single RGB LED through solid red, green, and blue, holding each color for 3 seconds with no cross-fade. Use a bounded loop that repeats the 3-color sequence 5 times, then turns the LED off.
Implement a heartbeat LED pattern (short pulse, then a longer pulse) using PWM with maximum 100% brightness on peaks. The total cycle should be exactly 1.2 s and repeat indefinitely.
Map an analog brightness input to a PWM LED from 0% to 100%. Sample at 50 Hz and limit the slew rate to 5% per sample to avoid abrupt changes.
Use a light sensor to make a night-light: if measured level is below a threshold, set LED to 40% brightness; otherwise turn it off. Sample at 20 Hz and add 5% hysteresis to prevent flicker.
On a touch event, execute one breathing cycle (fade 10%→90%→10%) using a bounded loop of 80 steps total, then stop and wait for the next touch.

Flash a status LED N times to report an error code, where N is clamped to 1..5. Each flash is 100 ms on, 100 ms off, followed by a 600 ms pause. Repeat the sequence continuously at a 10 Hz control rate.
Given a 3-position selector, set an RGB LED to pure red, pure green, or pure blue at 100% per selected channel. Ensure all channels are off on startup and transitions are glitch-free.
Run a PWM-controlled LED at a steady 500 Hz carrier and update its duty cycle at 50 Hz. Keep duty within 5%–95% to avoid extremes, and guarantee that updates never disrupt the PWM cadence.
Create a candle-flicker effect by randomly varying LED brightness between 40% and 80%. Update at 25 Hz with a bounded pseudorandom sequence and a slight low-pass smoothing to avoid harsh jumps.
Implement a button-controlled LED that toggles between steady on (60% brightness) and blinking at 2 Hz. Debounce the button at 50 Hz and start in steady-off mode.
On a rising edge of a digital trigger, flash an LED to 100% for 50 ms, then enforce a 200 ms refractory period during which additional triggers are ignored. Keep the control loop at 1 kHz.

For a 10-LED strip, implement a theater chase (3 LEDs on, moving forward one position every 100 ms). Use a bounded loop to run exactly 300 steps when enabled by a button, then stop and turn all LEDs off.

Design a state machine with modes OFF, WHITE, and COLOR_CYCLE for an RGB lamp. Short press switches to the next mode; long press (>1 s) returns to OFF. Run at 50 Hz, cross-fade colors over 1 s in COLOR_CYCLE.

Read two digital inputs: OVERHEAT and FAULT. Drive an RGB LED with priority: red blinking at 5 Hz for OVERHEAT, yellow solid for FAULT, green solid when neither is active. Ensure only the highest-priority indication shows.
Drive an RGB LED breathing pattern with separate phase offsets per channel to produce a shimmering effect. Enforce a safety limit so the sum of RGB PWM duties never exceeds 180%.
Create a sunrise sequence: smoothly change from warm white to cool white over 30 minutes while increasing brightness from 0% to 100%. Update once per second and allow a pause/resume input.
Implement a beat-synced strobe: on each external pulse, flash an LED at 90% brightness for 20 ms. Cap strobe rate to 15 Hz for eye safety and ignore pulses that arrive too soon.
Use a motion sensor to trigger a light strip: ramp to 60% brightness over 300 ms, hold for 30 s, then decay to 0% over 1 s. Retriggering should extend the hold time. Control loop rate 100 Hz.
Show a progress bar across 16 LEDs based on a 0–100% input. Fill from left to right and change color zones: green up to 60%, yellow up to 85%, red beyond. Update at 20 Hz.
Map ambient light (lux) to an RGB LED from deep blue at low lux to white at high lux. Sample at 10 Hz and apply a 0.2 s low-pass filter to reduce flicker.
Create a Knight Rider bounce on a 12-LED bar: a bright dot moves back and forth with a trailing fade. Step every 50 ms using a bounded loop that defines the trail intensities.
Blink SOS in Morse code on a single LED using PWM for clear dots and dashes. Keep dot length 200 ms and enforce exact spacing. Repeat pattern with a 2 s pause and control at 100 Hz.
Drive two LED channels (warm and cool) to meet a target correlated color temperature while maintaining requested brightness. Update at 50 Hz and clamp the CCT between 2700 K and 6500 K.

Use two buttons: one cycles through a predefined color palette; the other adjusts animation speed (slow/medium/fast). Debounce inputs, remember the selection, and run the selected pattern with a rate attribute.
Generate a triangular brightness waveform at 5 Hz for an LED, constrained to 10%–90% duty. Guarantee a WCET under 1 ms per control tick at 200 Hz.

Split a strip into two zones (A and B). Zone A runs a breathing effect; Zone B runs a chasing effect. If a FAULT flag is set, immediately force both zones to off. Maintain timing separation so patterns don’t drift.
Implement a dimmer with soft transitions: when turning on, fade to the target brightness over 300 ms; when turning off, fade down over 300 ms. Ensure updates run at 100 Hz.
With a single pushbutton, adjust brightness in 5% increments per click; a long press (>1 s) sets brightness to 50%. Provide a confirmation double-flash at 30% duty for 100 ms.
Use two LEDs (warm and cool) to approximate a requested color temperature in Kelvin provided via input. Interpolate PWM levels and clamp to 2700–6500 K. Ensure sum of duties stays within 100%.

Build a traffic light sequence with red, yellow, and green LEDs: green 8 s, yellow 2 s, red 8 s. Maintain precise timing and allow a manual override that forces all off without breaking the sequence timing.
Create a mood lamp that steps through 8 preset colors, showing each for 10 s with a 2 s cross-fade. Use a bounded loop to run exactly 3 full cycles, then stop on the last color.

Maintain 300 lux at a light sensor by controlling LED PWM with a PID loop. Run the control at 200 Hz, limit integral windup, cap maximum duty at 80% for safety, and turn off if the sensor reading is invalid.

Stabilize perceived brightness using both a light sensor (lux) and a temperature sensor (°C) to compensate LED output. Fuse the sensors at 50 Hz, adjust PWM accordingly, and fail safe to 30% max duty if either sensor is out of range.

Control two light zones with independent PID loops to reach separate lux setpoints. If total estimated current would exceed a budget, proportionally scale both zones to stay within limit while prioritizing fairness.

Implement a stroboscope with user-selectable frequency from 1 to 50 Hz. Guarantee a minimum dark time of 10 ms, a WCET under 500 µs per tick, and enforce a safety cap at 50% duty to reduce seizure risk.

Reduce visible flicker by detecting ambient mains flicker with a light sensor and adjusting PWM frequency or phase to avoid beating. Maintain target brightness with a PI controller and keep updates bounded to prevent oscillation.

Use a 3-channel color sensor to measure output and adjust an RGB LED to a target chromaticity with three PIDs (one per channel). Update at 100 Hz and clamp outputs to remain within the achievable color gamut.

Create a sunrise effect whose ramp speed adapts to ambient light from an LDR. Maintain the overall profile shape while adjusting duration. If the sensor disconnects, revert to a fixed 20-minute schedule and log a fault via a red blink.
Map device orientation to color by fusing accelerometer and gyroscope to estimate tilt. Update orientation at 200 Hz, convert to a hue value, and ensure brightness never exceeds 70% duty for safety.

Estimate strip current draw from PWM duties across all channels and enforce a 1 A budget. If the estimate would exceed the budget, scale down all duties proportionally and indicate limiting via a status LED blink. Keep decisions under 1 ms per cycle.
Make an audio-reactive visualization: compute RMS amplitude over a 100 ms sliding window and map it to LED brightness at 20 Hz. At night (detected by LDR), cap brightness at 30% to reduce glare.

Build a multi-mode lighting controller with modes IDLE, SHOW_A, SHOW_B, and MANUAL. Define a state machine with events (button, timer, external trigger), use bounded loops for patterns, run the control at 100 Hz, and keep WCET under 2 ms. Safe default is all LEDs off.

For a theater installation, manage a 50-LED strip with a scene scheduler: cycle scenes with priorities and timed crossfades. An emergency-stop input must force all LEDs off within 50 ms. Specify invariants for max average power and safe PWM rates using rate attributes.

Create a smart lamp with AUTO and MANUAL modes. AUTO uses PID to hold 200 lux in daytime and 50 lux at night; MANUAL sets fixed brightness. Include a startup self-test that flashes red, green, blue in sequence using a bounded loop. Document the state machine; run at 100 Hz.

Design an interactive art wall where zones react to proximity and audio. Fuse the two sensors to drive color and brightness, include a calibration mode, and provide test hooks to simulate inputs. Constrain flicker index and use bounded loops for pattern generation.

Control an outdoor lighting piece that reacts to weather: if heavy rain is detected, enter SAFE mode with simplified patterns and reduced brightness. Define a formal safety rule: never exceed 70% duty per channel. Include a recovery sequence, a 100 Hz control rate, and WCET limits.

Create a simple breathing effect for one LED using PWM: fade from 0% to 80% and back to 0% with a 2 s period. Use a bounded loop to repeat exactly 10 cycles and run the update logic at a fixed rate of 100 Hz.
For a single RGB LED, smoothly breathe between deep blue and off over 5 seconds, capping brightness at 60% to avoid glare. Keep timing deterministic with a rate attribute and terminate after 8 loops.
Blink one LED at 2 Hz with a 30% duty cycle. Expose an integer parameter to adjust the duty from 10% to 50%. Maintain a 1 kHz PWM carrier and ensure the control loop runs at 100 Hz.
When a button is pressed, toggle an LED with a 200 ms ramp up or down using PWM. Debounce the button and keep updates at 200 Hz so there is no visible flicker.
Map a knob position to LED brightness from 0% to 100% using PWM, clamp to a maximum of 90%. Refresh the mapping at 50 Hz and ensure bounded arithmetic to prevent overflow.
Cycle a single RGB LED through pure red, green, and blue, holding each color for 1 s. Use a bounded loop to perform exactly 3 full cycles, then stop.
Drive two LEDs: LED1 shows a heartbeat pulse (quick double flash) every 1 s, LED2 stays steady at 25% brightness. Implement timing with a 100 Hz rate.
Implement a tap-tempo blinker. Measure the time between two button taps and blink an LED with that period, constrained between 200 ms and 2000 ms. Use a state machine for capture.
Create a breathe effect using a small lookup table approximating a sine curve. The LED should update at 120 Hz and repeat the pattern a bounded number of times.
Simulate a candle flicker on an amber LED. Randomize PWM within 10%–70% brightness at 90 Hz, using a bounded random sequence so the pattern is deterministic in length.
Blend two channels to emulate color temperature from 2700 K to 6500 K on a single RGB LED. Update at 20 Hz, limit total output to 70%.
Turn on an LED when an ambient light sensor falls below a threshold, and ramp the brightness to 60% over 1 s. Add hysteresis to prevent chatter.
Sweep the hue of an RGB LED from 0 to 360 degrees over 10 s at constant saturation, brightness fixed at 40%. Use a bounded loop to perform two full sweeps.
Detect a double-click on a button and trigger a 100 ms white flash at 80% brightness; otherwise keep the LED at a steady 10%. Ensure precise timing.
Implement a night light that slowly fades to off over 10 minutes, stepping down brightness every 30 s. Use rate-based scheduling, no blocking waits.
Build a small state machine with three modes: OFF, WARM, COOL. A button advances the mode; each mode sets PWM brightness and color. Run logic at 100 Hz with deterministic transitions.
On an RGB LED strip, create a chase where a 5-LED bright head moves along a dim background. Advance one position every 50 ms and wrap using a bounded loop sized to the strip length.
Make an audio-reactive white LED where microphone amplitude controls PWM brightness. Smooth with a first-order filter, update at 200 Hz, and cap at 70%.
Provide two buttons that select color and speed for a rainbow pattern on an LED strip. Implement a bounded menu state machine with clear timeouts and input validation.
When a motion sensor triggers, run a 5 s gradient wipe across 30 LEDs, then return to idle. Use a rate attribute of 100 Hz and prevent retriggering while active.
Create a theater marquee effect: alternating groups of three LEDs are on and off, advancing every 100 ms. After 60 steps, pause for 2 s. Use bounded loops only.
Design a sunrise sequence over 15 minutes: ramp brightness from 0% to 80% while shifting color from red to warm white. If canceled, ramp down in 5 s safely.
Use a bicolor LED to indicate system states: ERROR blinks at 5 Hz, STANDBY blinks at 1 Hz, NORMAL is solid. Model it as a state machine with explicit timers.
Read three knobs for R, G, and B levels and apply an approximate gamma correction via a piecewise mapping. Update the RGB LED at 60 Hz and limit total current budget.
Dim an artwork when a viewer approaches: use a proximity sensor to map distance to brightness, with bounds and hysteresis to avoid jitter. Refresh at 50 Hz.
Crossfade between two preset color scenes over 3 s when a button is pressed. Ensure monotonic PWM ramps and no overshoot or flicker.
Implement a configurable strobe: user sets frequency from 1 to 30 Hz and duty cycle from 5% to 50%. For safety, disable operation when frequency is between 3–8 Hz and duty exceeds 20%.
Program a bouncing dot with a fading trail on an LED strip. Update at 100 Hz, use bounded arrays for pixel data, and wrap cleanly at the ends.
Set up a simple scheduler: a fade task at 20 Hz and a PWM update at 100 Hz. Demonstrate the use of rate attributes without blocking calls.
Use an ambient light sensor to compute a global brightness multiplier so the average luminance in lux stays under a setpoint. Recalculate at 2 Hz and clamp to safe ranges.
Blink Morse code for a fixed message with dot = 200 ms and dash = 600 ms. Enforce a bounded maximum of 32 characters and correct inter-symbol spacing.
Create a random sparkle on 50 LEDs: every 40 ms, light up at most two new pixels to 100%, each decaying to 0 over 300 ms. Use a bounded random generator.
Derate LED brightness as temperature rises: above 45 C, linearly reduce maximum PWM; never exceed an 80 C limit. Update the limiter at 10 Hz.
Use one input pin to detect 1–4 clicks and select four distinct color patterns. Implement a robust state machine with timeouts and scan the input at 200 Hz.
Create a Knight Rider sweep with adjustable width and speed, maintaining constant perceived brightness using a gamma map. Avoid blocking waits by using rate attributes.
Maintain a target luminance measured by a photodiode using PID control of PWM. Sample at 200 Hz, constrain the actuator, and reject spikes.
Fuse microphone beat detection and motion sensing to trigger color bursts only when both exceed thresholds within a 200 ms window. Bound all buffers and timers.
Implement adaptive white balance for an RGBW fixture by measuring ambient color temperature and nudging output toward 5000 K using a bounded iterative algorithm at 5 Hz.
Estimate LED junction temperature from ambient and PWM duty, and reduce brightness if the estimate exceeds 85 C. Recompute at 2 Hz and log limit events.
Coordinate five zones of a light sculpture to pass wavefronts from one zone to the next with a precise 25 ms inter-zone delay. Guarantee worst-case execution time under 2 ms per tick.
Build a small pattern engine that plays a bounded list of timed color keyframes with linear interpolation. Tick at 100 Hz and validate lengths and value limits.
Use a color sensor to close the loop on RGB mixing, PID-controlling each channel to match a target chromaticity with error under DeltaE 3. Rate-limit updates.
Implement battery-aware dimming: read supply voltage and lower a global brightness scalar to keep power under 2.5 W, never below 20% output. Update at 10 Hz.
Enforce flicker safety by ensuring no channel changes by more than 10% per 10 ms. Add runtime verification and clamp deltas accordingly.
Create an interactive light painting: use encoder-derived position and velocity to deposit hues along an LED strip. Sample at 1 kHz, maintain deterministic timing, and use bounded buffers.

Compose a multi-mode installation with schedules: daytime shows subtle warm patterns, evening shows vivid chases, night is off. Model transitions and timers in a state machine, enforce safety caps, and keep WCET under 3 ms.
Add a power-on self-test that walks a test pattern through every LED, checks photodiode feedback against thresholds, logs faults, and then enters normal mode. Use bounded loops and strict timeouts.
Implement a show controller with four selectable shows. Each show defines sequences, rates, and brightness caps; support preemption and safe handoff between shows, with simple test hooks.

Provide redundancy for two mirrored light channels. If one fails based on missing feedback, switch to a safe reduced-brightness mode and signal an error blink. Include a diagnostic state machine with defined timing.

Design for compliance: set limits for maximum glare in cd/m^2, allowable flicker index, and color rendering targets. Implement monitoring and enforcement, plus a regression test mode that plays deterministic 60 Hz patterns.

Create a simple fade for a single LED: linearly ramp PWM duty from 0% to 100% and back down repeatedly for exactly 60 seconds, then hold steady at 20%. Use a 1 kHz PWM carrier and update the ramp at 50 Hz with a bounded loop so it cannot run beyond the 60 s window.
Make a status LED blink with a 100 ms on, 900 ms off pattern at 40% brightness. Keep the control loop at 10 Hz using a rate attribute.
When a pushbutton is pressed, toggle a white LED between off and on with a 200 ms soft-start or soft-stop fade using PWM. Debounce the button for 30 ms.
Use a rotary dimmer input to control LED brightness from 0% to 80% linearly. Sample the input at 50 Hz and clamp the PWM duty so it never exceeds 80%.
Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, and blue, each color held for 2 s, for exactly 3 full cycles using a bounded loop. After the cycles complete, hold at white (all channels 20% brightness).
Implement a gentle breathe effect: smoothly vary brightness between 5% and 50% at 0.5 Hz using PWM. Keep PWM frequency at or above 500 Hz to avoid visible flicker.
On startup, flash an LED twice quickly (two 100 ms pulses separated by 100 ms), then remain steady green at 30% brightness.
Alternate two LEDs: A on while B off for 250 ms, then swap, repeating for 30 s only, then turn both off. Use a bounded loop.
Create a candle flicker on a warm white LED by randomly jittering brightness between 30% and 60% at 20 Hz. Keep randomness bounded and deterministic with a fixed seed.
Single button selects between two behaviors: steady on at 25% or slow blink at 1 Hz. Start in steady mode and toggle modes on each valid press.
Blink a beacon at 2 Hz with 25% brightness using a 1 kHz PWM base. Ensure the control runs at 100 Hz and does not exceed a 0.5 ms worst-case execution time per cycle.
Drive a bi-color LED as a simple status indicator: show blue when ok is true and red when ok is false. Transitions should fade over 150 ms.
Ramp brightness smoothly from 0% to 100% over 5 s and then stop changing, holding at full. The ramp should be linear and implemented with a bounded loop.
When a trigger input goes high, run a strobe: 10 flashes per second, each flash 10 ms at 100% brightness, for a total duration of 5 s, then return to previous state.
Dim an LED based on ambient light: map 10 lux to 80% brightness and 500 lux to 10% brightness, clipping outside that range. Update at 5 Hz.

Build a small state machine with three modes for an RGB lamp: idle (soft white at 10%), warm glow (breathe between 10% and 40%), and alert (red flashing at 4 Hz). Select mode with a button; long-press 1 s advances to the next mode. Use rate attributes and bounded loops for each pattern.
Make lights react to sound level: measure a mic amplitude input at 200 Hz and map it to brightness between 10% and 70%, with an exponential smoothing time constant of 200 ms. Keep PWM at 1 kHz.

When motion is detected, turn on a pathway of 12 LEDs in sequence with 100 ms spacing, then after 10 s of no motion, fade them out over 1 s. Ensure the sequencing uses a bounded loop over exactly 12 positions.
Shift color temperature from cool to warm over the evening: interpolate from 6500 K to 2700 K across 2 h once started. Update the RGB mix every 1 min.

Create a pattern selector: a button cycles through five color patterns (solid, breathe, chase, rainbow, pulse). Implement as a state machine with debounced input and bounded loops inside each pattern so none can overrun.
Implement a theater chase on a strip: light every third LED and advance the offset by one position at 20 Hz. Limit the loop to the defined strip length and wrap cleanly.

Crossfade two lamps inversely based on a slider input: as lamp A increases from 0% to 80%, lamp B decreases from 80% to 0%. Apply a 100 ms fade time on any change and ensure the sum of their duties never exceeds 80%.

Combine an occupancy input and an ambient light level: if occupied and ambient < 50 lux, set 60% brightness; if occupied and ambient >= 50 lux, set 20%; if not occupied, set 5%. Update decisions at 2 Hz with hysteresis of 5 lux.
Run a rainbow wheel across an LED strip, rotating at a speed set by a knob from 0.1 to 2.0 revolutions per second. Update colors at 30 Hz and use bounded index loops.

Blink Morse SOS on a single LED when a button is held. Use accurate timings: dot 200 ms, dash 600 ms, intra-symbol gap 200 ms, character gap 600 ms, word gap 1.4 s. Loop the SOS sequence until release with a bounded sequence definition.
Blend RGB to reach a requested hue and brightness given as inputs (hue 0–360 deg, level 0–100%). Update at 20 Hz, clamp each channel to 90% max, and apply a gamma correction of 2.2.
Implement a smooth dimmer with a perceptual curve: map a 0–100% control input to PWM using gamma 2.0, updating at 100 Hz. Include a minimum floor of 2% to avoid cut-out.
Simulate a pedestrian crossing light: green 10 s, flashing green 3 s at 4 Hz, yellow 2 s, red 8 s, looping indefinitely. Model this as a timer-driven state machine.
Create a progress animation on 16 LEDs that fills one LED every 2 s until full, then empties at the same rate. Use bounded loops to iterate only across 16 positions.
Differentiate single-tap and double-tap on a button to choose between steady white and rainbow cycle. Single-tap threshold 300 ms; double-tap window 500 ms. Debounce 30 ms.
Drive two mirrored gradients on two LED strips so that they animate symmetrically from the center outward at 25 Hz. Use bounded loops over each strip length.
Stabilize auto-dimming from a light sensor using hysteresis: if brightness setpoint output changes by less than 3% within 1 s, hold the current PWM to avoid flicker. Evaluate the control at 10 Hz.

Firework effect: on trigger, ramp a center LED to 100% over 200 ms, then spawn 8 sparks that move outward, fading over 1 s. Use bounded loops to ensure exactly 8 spark computations and cap per-cycle work.

Sunrise routine: over 15 min, transition from 0% to 100% brightness while shifting from red to warm white. Run once on command, then return to idle. Use a state machine with rate-controlled updates at 2 Hz.
Notification pulses: emit 10 soft pulses at 1 Hz, each pulse a 0% to 60% to 0% triangle over 1 s, then remain off. Ensure the pulse count is bounded.

Closed-loop brightness control: use a light sensor to hold 200 lux at the target surface using a PID running at 50 Hz. Constrain PWM to 5%–85%, include anti-windup, and limit the step change in duty to 5% per cycle.

Fuse two ambient light sensors using a weighted average that ignores any sensor deviating by more than 20 lux from the other. Use the fused value to set brightness to maintain 100 lux at 10 Hz. Include hysteresis and rate limiting.

Thermal protection: monitor an LED heat sink temperature and reduce brightness to maintain 55 C using a PID at 10 Hz. If temperature exceeds 60 C, enter a safety dim mode at 10% until it drops below 55 C for 30 s.

Ensure flicker safety by keeping PWM carrier at 2 kHz and forbidding any pattern to modulate below 100 Hz except brief strobes under 20 ms. Validate that the control loop WCET is under 1 ms at 100 Hz.

Auto white balance: read a 3-channel color sensor at 10 Hz and adjust RGB gains to match a requested CCT and illuminance. Clamp channel currents to keep total current under 400 mA, redistributing proportionally if needed.

Power budgeting across 3 zones: enforce that the sum of currents stays under 500 mA. When a scene would exceed the budget, proportionally dim all zones while preserving color ratios. Update decisions at 20 Hz and use bounded loops over zones.

Interactive wave art: combine a distance sensor and sound level via a complementary filter (time constant 300 ms) to drive a traveling wave across 60 LEDs at 30 Hz. Keep per-cycle operations bounded by the strip length.

Safety state machine: normal operation runs the selected pattern; upon overcurrent or overtemperature, switch within 100 ms to a latched safe-low mode at 5% brightness and require a manual reset input to exit. Verify transition timing.
Procedural noise pattern: generate a 1D Perlin-like noise brightness pattern across 100 LEDs, updating at 25 Hz. Use a fixed seed and bounded loops, and cap CPU time so WCET stays under 2 ms.

Calibrate gamma and color balance: provide three test patterns that measure sensor feedback and compute updated gamma and RGB gain coefficients, then apply them. Ensure computations are bounded and run in a calibration state separate from run mode.

Design a multi-mode light sculpture controller with modes Idle, Show A, Show B, and Emergency. Each show contains a playlist of bounded-loop patterns with per-pattern durations. Include a top-level state machine, per-mode rate attributes, and a hard requirement that WCET is below 2 ms at 100 Hz. Emergency overrides any mode and forces 5% red.

Create a performance lighting system with three banks of LEDs and a master controller: provide Startup Self-Test (blink each bank, verify sensor ranges and button inputs), Run (execute pattern sets), and Safe (low-power). Include built-in test hooks and assertions for current limits and timing.

Implement an adaptive stage wash with sensor fusion: maintain 300 lux at the stage using a PID while blending to a warm CCT when sound level average over 10 s is low and to a cool CCT when high. System must operate at 50 Hz with WCET under 1 ms and include a faulted state when any sensor becomes stale for >1 s.

Develop a battery-aware art lamp: estimate remaining capacity from a voltage sensor and a current estimate, then schedule scenes so the average power stays under 3 W. Provide modes High, Normal, and Reserve with automatic downgrades, and a test mode that validates transitions and budget enforcement.

Build a deterministic color-choreography engine that schedules multiple overlapping effects on different LED groups with priorities. Use hierarchical state machines, bounded loops over groups, and rate-controlled updates at 60 Hz. Specify comprehensive tests for edge cases, including simultaneous triggers, priority inversion prevention, and timing budget adherence.

Make a single LED fade in and out smoothly using PWM at a 1 Hz cycle. The control task should run at 100 Hz (rate attribute). Use a bounded loop to step brightness up to 100% and back down, exactly 50 steps each way per cycle.
