When a pushbutton is pressed, set the LED to full brightness; when released, turn it off. Use PWM and keep the PWM carrier at or above 500 Hz to avoid flicker. Keep the logic straightforward and responsive.
Blink an LED with a 200 ms on, 800 ms off pattern, repeating continuously. Drive timing with a 10 ms rate attribute and use a bounded loop counting ticks to enforce the exact durations.
Create a gentle breathe effect that repeats exactly 8 times on startup (bounded loop of cycles), then stays at a steady 20% brightness until a reset signal arrives. PWM should run at ≥1 kHz.
Toggle between two brightness presets (30% and 70%) with a single button. Short press toggles; hold for >1 s forces 10% night mode. Update at 50 Hz and debounce the button.
Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, and blue, each for exactly 1 second. Use a bounded loop of the three colors and update the duty at 50 Hz for smoothness.
Implement a one-shot pulse: when a trigger input goes high, drive the LED at 80% for exactly 250 ms, then return to off. Ignore retriggers until the pulse completes. Timing task at 100 Hz.
Build a simple night light: if ambient light drops below 50 lux, set brightness to 30%; otherwise turn off. Poll at 10 Hz and include 5 lux hysteresis to prevent chatter.
On power-up, soft-start an LED by ramping from 0 to 40% over 500 ms using a bounded step sequence. Enforce a maximum slew rate of 20% per 100 ms for safety.
Create a candle flicker effect using a bounded loop of 64 precomputed duty steps updated at 20 Hz. Loop the sequence continuously to simulate natural variation.
Generate a strobe at 5 Hz with a 10% duty cycle. Keep the PWM carrier ≥1 kHz to avoid visible flicker, and hold timing jitter within ±2 ms using a fixed rate task.
Program a 'heartbeat' double-blink pattern: two quick 100 ms pulses with 100 ms gap, followed by a 1.2 s pause. Express this as a bounded list of on/off durations and loop it.
When a capacitive touch is detected, ramp brightness to 70% over 1 second; when not touched, ramp down to 0% over 1 second. Update at 50 Hz and rate-limit changes smoothly.
Implement a status LED with two states selected by a boolean input: OK = steady 20% brightness, ERROR = 2 Hz blink at 80%. Use a 100 Hz rate attribute for timing.
Perform a warm-to-cool color temperature sweep over 10 seconds on a tunable-white LED (two channels). Use a bounded loop of 100 steps and keep both channels under 80% duty. Repeat continuously.

Create an RGB strip controller with two buttons: one cycles pattern modes (solid, chase, rainbow) and the other adjusts brightness. Implement a state machine for modes, enforce a 60% max brightness for safety, and run animations at 50 Hz with bounded loops.

Build a traffic light with a pedestrian button. State machine timing: green 20 s, yellow 3 s, red 20 s. On button press, next red includes a 'walk' white for 10 s followed by 10 s flashing (bounded blink loop). Use a 10 Hz control rate.
Audio-reactive lamp: map microphone RMS level to brightness 0–80%. Smooth changes with a 20 Hz low-pass and cap slew to 10% per 50 ms. Keep PWM carrier ≥1 kHz.
Implement a 'theater chase' where N LEDs light in sequence. Use a bounded loop over N positions at 25 Hz. Accept three inputs for R, G, B (0–100%) to tint the lit LEDs.

Design a status beacon with three modes (idle, pairing, connected) as a state machine. Idle: slow fade. Pairing: rapid blue blink. Connected: steady green at 30%. Control loop at 100 Hz; worst-case execution time per tick must be ≤200 microseconds.
Two-zone dimmer: each of two LEDs has its own up/down buttons. Short press toggles on/off; long press ramps brightness. Update at 50 Hz, debounce inputs, and ensure independent operation.

Sunrise alarm: from a trigger event, ramp from 0% to 70% over 20 minutes via bounded steps. If a cancel input occurs, transition to a ramp-down over 30 seconds. Model as a state machine (idle, rising, canceling).

Make a breathing effect synchronized to a BPM input. Each breath spans one beat. Use a bounded loop of 32 gamma-corrected steps per breath and adjust the step timing as BPM changes. Rate enforce at 100 Hz.
RGB mood lamp that cycles through 120 hues. Provide a 'hold' input that freezes the hue. Use a 30 Hz rate attribute and a bounded hue index loop with wrap-around.

Safety dimmer: if temperature rises above 45 C, clamp all PWM to 40% and show a red warning blink for 5 s (bounded blink loop), then resume prior mode once temperature falls below 40 C (hysteresis). Implement as a state machine.
Create a sweeping amber turn-signal effect across 10 LEDs. Each sweep completes in 500 ms using a bounded loop of 10 positions. Shape each dot with a brief brighten-then-decay using PWM.

Design a light metronome: tempo 60–180 BPM from a knob input. Blink with 50% duty and highlight the downbeat every 4 beats by changing color. Maintain ±1 ms timing using a fixed-rate task and a bounded beat counter.

Reading lamp with ambient and proximity sensors. If proximity < 20 cm, enter 'interaction' mode and gently pulse ±10% around the set brightness; otherwise hold steady. Implement with a state machine and 25 Hz update rate.
When a toggle input changes, crossfade between two RGB presets over exactly 2 seconds. Use a bounded loop of 100 steps at 50 Hz and enforce a global brightness cap of 70%.
Emergency flasher: triple-strobe then pause. Do three bursts of 30 ms on, 70 ms off, then a 1 s pause. Represent the sequence as a bounded list of durations and loop it exactly.
Create a hallway guide wave across 8 LEDs that travels forward then backward. Use a bounded loop for 16 positions at 25 Hz. Provide an input to reverse direction immediately.
Two RGB fixtures should alternate colors every 2 seconds, swapping hues between them. Use a state machine to manage the swap and perform a 250 ms crossfade via bounded steps.
Implement a sparkle effect: at 10 Hz, randomly pick one of 20 LEDs to flicker to 100% for 50 ms then decay via a bounded step sequence. Limit to at most two concurrent sparkles.
Night-mode enforcement: after a 22:00 time signal, clamp brightness to ≤15% and fade down if higher; restore normal limits at 07:00. Model with a state machine and update at 1 Hz.
Provide a simple color picker: three inputs (R, G, B) in 0–100% directly set the color. Add a rate limit so each channel changes no faster than 20% per 100 ms. Keep PWM at 2 kHz.

Closed-loop brightness control: use a photodiode input to maintain 300 lux by adjusting PWM via a PID controller. Run the control at 200 Hz, PWM at ≥2 kHz. Include anti-windup, saturate output to 0–60% for safety, and verify with a bounded step test that settles within 2 s after a 50% disturbance.

Regulate a tunable-white lamp using two light sensors (warm and cool components). Control the warm/cool ratio to a target via PID and maintain total brightness via a separate loop. Control rate 100 Hz; bound per-tick WCET to ≤300 microseconds; cap duty at 80%.

Sensor fusion art: fuse accelerometer magnitude with microphone amplitude to drive hue (motion) and brightness (audio). Use a complementary filter (slow motion, fast audio). Update at 200 Hz, keep PWM ≥1.5 kHz, and enter a safety state that limits brightness to ≤50% if sustained high levels persist for 10 s.

Adaptive anti-flicker: monitor ambient light for mains flicker and adjust PWM frequency/phase to minimize beating. Keep PWM >1 kHz and adjust no more than once per second. Implement a state machine with monitor, adjust, and hold states.

Multichannel dimmer with current feedback: maintain 20 mA per channel using PI control at 1 kHz. Fail-safe to off if a sensor reading is invalid. Meet a step response under 100 ms using a bounded test profile.

Beat-synchronized strobes: detect beats from an audio envelope at 100 Hz and, on each beat, trigger a bounded 300 ms burst of color changes at 200 Hz. Ensure detection path WCET ≤500 microseconds and cap brightness at 70%.

Brightness PID with user setpoint: a knob sets 0–60% target; a photodiode closes the loop. Include derivative filtering, integral anti-windup, and output slew limits. Run the controller at 250 Hz with PWM at 3 kHz.

Orientation-aware table lamp: combine tilt (3-axis) and ambient light to choose warm vs cool palettes. Use a state machine to select palettes and animate transitions with bounded loops. For safety, if tilt exceeds 60 degrees for >2 s, dim to 20%.

Thermal protection using a simple model: estimate LED junction temperature from ambient readings and recent PWM duty (first-order model). Use a PI controller to keep the estimate ≤75 C, updating at 10 Hz, and never exceed 50% duty.
Compute a traveling wave brightness pattern across 30 LEDs using a bounded per-frame loop. Target 60 Hz frame rate and ensure per-frame WCET ≤1 ms. Provide inputs for wavelength and speed.

Design a multi-mode light sculpture with four modes—Idle, Performance, Ambient, Safe—using a state machine. Idle: 10 Hz breathe; Performance: 60 Hz chase; Ambient: steady 25%; Safe: solid red 15%. Include a 2 s debounce between mode changes, a safety override that forces Safe on diagnostic failure, bounded pattern loops for all animations, WCET budgets per mode (≤800 microseconds), and a 1 s startup self-test.

Create a stage lighting controller with 8 scenes, each defined as a bounded list of color/brightness steps with durations. Provide inputs to select scene, pause/resume, and step next/prev. Run at 100 Hz with deterministic timing and a global brightness cap from a master fader. Include a verification plan: check each step’s duration within ±5 ms and ensure the cap is never exceeded.

Implement a choreographed light show synced to an external 120 BPM clock. Use a hierarchical state machine for sections (Intro, Verse, Chorus) and bounded loops for intra-section patterns. Include a tap-tempo fallback, constrain per-tick WCET to ≤700 microseconds at 200 Hz, and on lost clock fade to 30% warm white within 1 s.

Develop a dual-zone architectural dimmer with daylight harvesting. Fuse two ambient sensors per zone, run a PID per zone to maintain 250 lux, and coordinate via a supervisory state machine with occupancy gating. Provide comprehensive tests: saturation handling, sensor fault injection, WCET checks (100 Hz control, ≤500 microseconds), and safe fallback to 20% if faults persist >5 s.

Specify a programmable art installation executing a weekly schedule of lighting modes. Each day is a bounded sequence of time slots with assigned patterns. Include manual override with priority, a rate-monotonic scheduler for periodic tasks (animation 50 Hz, sensors 20 Hz), and a safety rule that any conflicting command drops to off within 100 ms. Provide a test plan for timing, priority inversion avoidance, and state transition correctness.
Make a single LED blink at 2 Hz with a 30% duty cycle using PWM. Run the logic at a fixed rate (rate attribute 100 Hz) and keep timing jitter under 5 ms.
Create a breathing effect on one LED that fades from 0% to 100% and back to 0% over 2 seconds per cycle. Use a bounded loop for the fade steps and update brightness at 200 Hz.
Hold a single LED at a steady 75% brightness with PWM at 1 kHz. If the control loop overruns its rate, immediately force brightness to 0% (safety requirement) and latch a fault flag.
Implement a triple-flash pattern for one LED: three 100 ms pulses separated by 100 ms gaps, then stay off for 2 s and repeat. Use a bounded loop to count the three flashes per burst.
Turn a single LED on at 100% while a button is pressed and off when released. Debounce the button with 20 ms filtering and run the control at 100 Hz.
Map an analog knob (0–100%) to a single LED’s PWM brightness. Sample at 50 Hz, clamp the output to 0–100%, and drive PWM at 500 Hz.
Ramp a single LED from 0% to 100% over 5 seconds and then hold at 100%. Use a bounded loop with fixed steps so the ramp duration is deterministic.

Generate a slow pulse pattern on one LED: smoothly rise to 40% over 1 s, hold for 200 ms, then fall to 0% over 1 s, wait 8 s, and repeat. Keep the update rate at 50 Hz with bounded loops for the ramp segments.
Blink a single LED in Morse code for SOS (… --- …) using 200 ms dots and 600 ms dashes, correct intra-letter and inter-letter spacing, and repeat in a bounded, looping sequence.
Step a single LED through brightness levels 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, 100%, then back down to 0%, holding each level for 300 ms. Ensure the loop over steps is bounded.
Toggle a single LED at 1 Hz, but if a boolean safe_mode input is true, force it off. Evaluate the flag every cycle at 50 Hz and document the safety behavior.
On a rising edge of a button, emit a 250 ms pulse of full brightness on one LED, regardless of how long the button is held. Debounce for 20 ms and ensure the pulse duration is precisely timed.
Smoothly slew a single LED to a target brightness (0–100%) provided as an input parameter, limiting the change rate to 20% per second. Run at 100 Hz with a bounded slew calculation.
Create a strobe effect: 10 flashes per second with each flash 10 ms wide at 100% brightness. Constrain the control task WCET to under 500 microseconds per cycle.
Implement soft-on/soft-off for a switch-controlled LED. On switch close, ramp 0→100% in 300 ms; on open, ramp down 100%→0% in 300 ms. Use bounded loops and update at 200 Hz.
Cycle an RGB LED smoothly through a rainbow over 30 seconds with constant perceived brightness. Use bounded loops for hue steps, update color at 50 Hz, and drive PWM at 400 Hz.

Use two buttons to control an RGB LED: one advances to the next color preset, the other decreases brightness in 10% steps. Implement a simple state machine for current preset, with 20 ms debouncing and clamped brightness 10–100%.

Make a sound-reactive LED where microphone amplitude controls brightness from 0–100%, with a color that shifts from blue at low levels to red at high. Update at 50 Hz with a short bounded averaging window to stabilize readings.
Dim a single LED based on ambient light: brighter room → lower LED brightness, darker room → higher brightness. Apply hysteresis to avoid flicker, and refresh at 10 Hz.

Create a mode-selectable RGB LED: idle = soft blue breathing, alert = red flash at 2 Hz (50% duty), success = steady green at 80%. Drive a state machine from a 2-bit mode input and ensure clean pattern transitions.
Make a bouncing light on 8 single-color LEDs where one LED moves left to right and back, stepping every 100 ms. Use a bounded loop for the index and ensure only one LED is on at any time.
Let a knob set hue (0–360°) for an RGB LED while a button toggles auto-cycling. Convert H to RGB at fixed saturation/brightness, update at 20 Hz, and clamp PWM outputs.
Fade an RGB LED between two given colors over 5 seconds with gamma-corrected interpolation. Use bounded steps at 50 Hz and maintain constant overall brightness.
Drive LED brightness from a proximity sensor so that closer distance yields higher brightness. Clamp between 10% and 90% and apply a first-order smoothing filter with a 0.5 s time constant at 100 Hz.
Program a 12-step light show on three LEDs based on a predefined sequence. Advance one step every 250 ms, repeat in a bounded loop, and ensure deterministic timing.
Build a two-state indicator: standby (solid blue at 40%) and recording (blinking red at 1 Hz). Use a button with long-press (>1.5 s) to switch states, with 20 ms debounce and a clear state machine.

Make a dimmer controlled by button taps: single tap toggles on/off at last level; double-tap within 300 ms sets brightness to 100%. Implement a bounded timing window and a state machine for tap detection.
Map a temperature reading from 0–40 Celsius to an RGB gradient from blue to red. Limit brightness change to 5% per second and update at 5 Hz with clamped outputs.
Use two light sensors (left and right) to drive two LED segments so that overall brightness appears balanced. Sample at 20 Hz, average readings, and enforce a WCET of 1 ms per update.
Create a chaser on 12 LEDs where exactly three adjacent LEDs are lit and the group moves forward then backward. Step every 75 ms using a bounded pattern loop, with brightness fixed at 60%.

Design a motion-activated nightlight: when motion is detected, ramp to 20% brightness for 60 s, then fade to off. Retriggers extend the timer. Implement a state machine with idle, active, and fading states at 50 Hz.
Demonstrate PWM dithering to simulate 12-bit brightness using an 8-bit base at 1 kHz. Drive a single LED through a smooth ramp and ensure any accumulators are bounded.
Crossfade an RGB LED through three presets (A → B → C) repeatedly. Each transition lasts 3 s with a 1 s hold at each color. Use bounded loops and gamma-correct blended values.
Implement a two-group theater chase where groups alternate at 5 Hz with 90 ms on-time. Synchronize transitions across groups and maintain deterministic timing with a rate attribute of 100 Hz.
Add a thermal safety for LEDs: if a temperature sensor reads above 60 C, force all LEDs off and latch until temperature stays below 55 C for 10 s. Update at 10 Hz and log the latch state.
Maintain 200 lux at the artwork surface using a photodiode and a PID loop that adjusts LED PWM. Sample at 100 Hz, apply anti-windup, clamp 0–100% output, and keep WCET under 1 ms.

Fuse ambient light and microphone loudness to drive an RGB LED: compute a blended intensity I = 0.7·sound + 0.3·(1 − lux_norm), limit I to [0,1], and shift hue toward red when sound dominates. Update at 50 Hz with a bounded moving average to stabilize inputs.

Combine motion and distance sensors to select between two display modes on an LED strip: (a) near + motion → sparkles; (b) otherwise → slow breathing. Use a state machine with timed transitions, bounded loops for sparkle generation, and enforce a maximum per-LED on-time of 40% per second.

Blend warm and cool white LEDs to meet both target illuminance and color temperature using two PID loops (intensity and CCT) with dual photodiode inputs. Update at 50 Hz, detect sensor saturation, and fall back to off on fault.

Schedule three patterns (rainbow, chaser, strobe) in time slices: each runs for 100 ms in a 300 ms frame. Guarantee mutual exclusion on the LED buffer, set a rate attribute to 100 Hz, and enforce per-pattern WCET budgets.

Use two orthogonal light sensors to estimate a dominant light direction and set an RGB gradient that points toward it. Fuse readings with a low-pass filter, update at 20 Hz, and saturate outputs to safe ranges.

Regulate brightness to respect a 2 W thermal budget by estimating LED power from PWM duty and measured current. Use a PI controller on a 10 s sliding average (bounded window), update at 10 Hz, and gracefully reduce output when over budget.

Generate a palette-based light pattern choosing from 5 colors at random but never repeating a color more than twice in a row. Random hold times between 200–600 ms, bounded sequence management, and deterministic behavior when seeded.

Create a three-band music visualizer: map low/mid/high audio bands to RGB with automatic gain control via a slow PI loop. Compute RMS in bounded windows, update LEDs at 100 Hz, and include clipping protection.

Track a time-based brightness schedule (0% at 0 s, 50% at 10 s, 80% at 30 s, 20% at 60 s) using PID with feedforward to follow the profile. Ensure monotonic timekeeping, handle rate changes, and force off on sensor fault.

Design a multi-mode light sculpture with modes: installation (low-power idle), show (playlist of patterns), and maintenance (manual color). Use a hierarchical state machine with guarded transitions, a startup self-test flashing sequence (bounded loops), a 100 Hz rate attribute, and a safe fallback to all-off on any overrun.

Implement a stage lighting controller with two independent cue stacks and crossfades of configurable duration. Guarantee preemption-safe updates, a fixed 50 Hz control rate, WCET ≤ 2 ms, and include unit tests that verify cue timing and output clamping.

Create an interactive mural controller that fuses proximity grid and ambient sound to select among four major modes, each with its own sub-patterns. Schedule sub-patterns so each meets a 5 ms WCET, and provide a test plan for rate conformance, mode transitions, and overtemperature shutdown at 70 C with hysteresis.

Build an emergency signaling system: decorative patterns in normal mode, but on alert input, switch within 50 ms to a red–white strobe at 8 Hz with 40% duty. After alert clears, transition through a cool-down mode before returning to normal. Include safety features (debounce, watchdog heartbeat, stuck-on detection, bounded loops) and verification steps.

Implement a large-array LED controller with gamma correction, white balance, and per-segment current limiting. The pattern engine runs a playlist with time-based triggers and priority interrupts for user inputs. Use a hierarchical state machine, ensure all buffers are bounded, and provide comprehensive tests including worst-case pattern WCET and saturation handling.

Create a single LED breathing effect that ramps brightness from 0% to 100% and back using PWM. Use a bounded loop with 50 steps up and 50 steps down, updating at 200 Hz. Repeat continuously and ensure the duty cycle never exceeds 100%.
Blink one LED at 2 Hz with precise timing: 150 ms on, 350 ms off. Use a fixed update rate and guarantee worst-case execution time under 1 ms per tick. LED must default to off if timing is missed.
Set an RGB LED to a steady warm white by proportionally mixing channels via PWM. Keep the PWM frequency at or above 1 kHz and clamp each channel so the combined duty does not exceed 180%.
On power-up, fade a single LED smoothly from off to 60% over 1.5 seconds using a bounded loop of 30 increments at 50 ms per step. Hold at 60% afterward.
Implement a strobe effect: 10 ms on, 990 ms off (1 Hz). Maintain precise timing and ensure the LED is forced off if the control loop stops.
Every 5 seconds, produce three quick flashes on a single LED: 50 ms on, 100 ms off, repeated three times using a bounded loop. Then remain off until the next 5-second interval.
Cycle a single RGB LED through 12 discrete hues over 6 seconds using a bounded loop for hue steps and a 20 Hz update rate. Ensure smooth transitions without abrupt brightness jumps.
Read a single analog control (0–100%) and map it to LED brightness. Sample at 50 Hz and smooth with a bounded moving average over the last 4 samples. Clamp brightness between 0% and 100%.
When a toggle input is ON, set the LED to 90% brightness; otherwise keep it off. Default to off on startup and enforce a minimum on-time of 100 ms to reduce flicker.
Create a candle flicker on an amber LED: randomize brightness between 20% and 70% at 25 Hz, limiting consecutive changes to at most 15% difference. Ensure no full-off or full-on events.
Emit a heartbeat pattern on one LED: two short pulses at 100% (80 ms on, 120 ms off), then 800 ms off. Repeat continuously with consistent timing.
When a sleep signal is asserted, dim a single LED to 0% over exactly 2 seconds using a bounded loop with 40 steps at 50 ms each. Keep the LED off until the signal clears.
Invert a digital input onto an LED: input HIGH forces LED off, input LOW forces LED fully on. Include a 10 ms glitch filter on the input.
Track a target brightness command (0–100%) but limit the slew rate to 10% per 100 ms. Update at 100 Hz and avoid overshoot during step changes.
Blink an RGB LED by driving all channels together to 40% for 200 ms once per second; otherwise off. Keep PWM frequency at 1 kHz minimum to avoid visible flicker.

Design a two-state machine for one LED: Idle at steady 20%, and Alert that performs a triple-flash at 5 Hz for 3 seconds. A debounced button press enters Alert. Use a bounded loop for the flash count and a 100 Hz control rate.

Drive an RGB LED based on ambient light: in darkness, set warm white at 60%; in bright conditions, set cool white at 30%. Use a 1-second cross-fade between states with sensor sampling at 10 Hz and a bounded median-of-5 filter.
Sequence three LEDs in a chasing pattern: LED1 on 150 ms, then LED2, then LED3, with 50 ms gaps. When triggered, repeat for exactly 10 cycles using a bounded loop, then turn all LEDs off.
Implement a crossfade controller that blends between warm and cool white mixes based on a 0–100% input. Update at 50 Hz and cap each channel so the sum across channels stays below 90%.

Create a finite state machine with modes: Off, Dim (15%), Bright (70%), and Breathe (slow 5 s cycle). A short press advances to the next mode; a long press (>800 ms) jumps to Off. Use a 200 Hz loop and time guards to avoid bouncing.
Program a sunrise on an RGB lamp: over 20 minutes, ramp from deep red to bright white in 1-second steps using a bounded loop of 1200 steps. If a cancel input is received, abort safely to Off.
Make a sound-reactive LED: map an audio envelope (0–1) to brightness between 10% and 90% with exponential smoothing. Update at 200 Hz and enforce a minimum on-time of 20 ms to prevent shimmer.
Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, and blue with 1-second holds and 200 ms cross-fades. Implement the cycle using a bounded step counter and ensure monotonic transitions.
Create two alternating hazard flashers: channel A and channel B flash at 2 Hz, 60% duty, never overlapping. Enforce with a small state machine and precise timing.
On motion detection, fade an LED to 80% over 30 seconds, then down to 20% over 30 seconds. Additional motion restarts the sequence. Use bounded loops (60 steps each way) and cap max duty at 85%.
Rotate through a palette of 8 predefined RGB colors, holding each for 500 ms and cross-fading to the next. Implement color indexing with a bounded loop and ensure continuous looping.

Implement day/night modes: Day shows steady 40% cool white; Night shows a slow pulse between 15% and 25% over 8 seconds. Switch using an ambient threshold with hysteresis in a timed state machine (50 Hz).

Use three buttons: Up increases brightness by 5%, Down decreases by 5%, Mode toggles between solid blue and a rainbow sweep. Clamp 0–100% and support auto-repeat at 5 Hz with a bounded repeat counter.
Display a 0–10 scale on a 10-LED bargraph. Update at 20 Hz; when the input decreases, decay by one LED every 200 ms via a bounded timer rather than dropping instantly.
Create a synchronized RGB effect where brightness breathes while hue rotates 360° over 4 seconds. Use a bounded loop of 80 steps and keep combined RGB duty below 180%.
Make a two-channel cross-fader: as channel A goes from 100% to 0%, channel B increases from 0% to 100%. Enforce linear crossfade and limit rate to 5% per 50 ms.
Create a theater chase on a 6-LED array: light every third LED and shift one position every 120 ms using a bounded rotation loop. Stop after 300 shifts and turn all LEDs off.
Detect a double-tap on a button to enter a sparkle mode: random 100% flashes lasting 30 ms, limited to 5 per second. Otherwise remain at a steady 20%. Include a lockout to prevent reentrancy.
Implement a metronome light: flash at a tempo set by a control from 40 to 208 BPM. Accent beat 1 with a different color. Maintain timing accuracy within ±1 ms per beat at a 200 Hz update rate.

Drive two RGB LEDs so they mirror each other unless an invert flag is set, in which case the second shows complementary colors (per-channel 100% minus duty). Cross-fade updates at 100 Hz with bounded arrays for channel values.

Maintain constant luminous output using PID control: regulate LED brightness to a target (0–100%) based on a photodiode feedback signal. Run control at 500 Hz, PWM at 2 kHz, cap duty at 90%, and include anti-windup. Add a bounded step test from 20% to 80% and back.

Stabilize RGB color using per-channel PID loops to match a target chromaticity from a 3-channel color sensor. Run at 200 Hz, clamp each channel to 85% max, include anti-windup, and fail safe to off if sensor data is invalid.

Fuse microphone amplitude and vibration level into a normalized activity score (0–1) using a bounded moving average and max operator. Trigger LED bursts: 100% for 150 ms with at least 1 s refractory, limited to 5 bursts per second.

Render a rainbow wave across a 12-LED strip at 60 Hz: each LED phase-shifted by 30°. Use bounded loops for frame updates, guarantee WCET < 2 ms, and blank all LEDs if two consecutive frames miss deadline.

Build adaptive glare control: use ambient light to maintain a desk light equivalent of 300 lux via PID. Limit step changes to 10% per 50 ms, cap duty at 80% for thermal safety, and handle saturation gracefully.

Create a light sculpture with 4 zones and a 45-second narrative: ramp zone 1, then cascade to zones 2–4 with 3 s delays, plus twinkle overlays limited by a bounded random generator. Include a supervisory state machine and a safety timeout that forces off after 60 s.

Implement temporal dithering to achieve 12-bit effective brightness using 8-bit PWM by subdividing frames at a 400 Hz effective rate. Use a bounded subframe loop and ensure mean brightness error stays within ±1 LSB over any 100 ms window.

Protect against overheating: monitor an LED temperature sensor and use a PI controller to hold temperature below 60 C. Sample at 10 Hz, start derating above 55 C, hard cutoff at 65 C, and slow recovery ramp when cooling.

Build a beat-synced light show that detects audio peaks and schedules color changes on beats. Maintain a rolling BPM estimate using a bounded buffer of the last 8 intervals, keep latency under 50 ms, and include a catch-up if drift exceeds 100 ms.

Use a gamma-corrected mapping table (bounded size 256) to linearize perceived brightness. Apply it to all PWM updates at 1 kHz and include a self-test that scans 0–100% in 1% steps to verify monotonic output.

Create a multi-mode light installation with modes: Calm (10 s breathe 15–35%), Energy (rainbow hue sweep at 2 Hz), Focus (steady 45% neutral white), Night (candle flicker 10–20%). Provide a top-level state machine with short/long press handling, persist last mode, and child state machines per mode. Specify per-mode update rates (50–200 Hz), cap total RGB duty <= 180%, watchdog to force Night on fault, and a bounded test that runs each mode for 5 s and checks timing and bounds.

Develop a festival lighting controller for 24 LEDs in 6 groups. Support schedules: Intro, Build, Drop, Outro, each with distinct patterns and crossfades. Enforce a deterministic 100 Hz frame rate with WCET < 5 ms. Use constants-only configuration, bounded loops for patterns, and a diagnostics mode that logs frame overruns and verifies group exclusivity.

Design a dual-loop system: an outer mode selector (5 Hz) chooses warm or cool palettes based on ambient level; an inner PID loop (500 Hz) holds perceived brightness using a photodiode. Include anti-windup, saturation limits, fail-safe to zero if the sensor stalls >200 ms, and a structured test plan with step, ramp, and dropout cases.

Implement a choreography engine for an 8x8 LED matrix with preauthored scenes. Use bounded loops for scene steps, guarantee 120 FPS, and schedule per-frame budgets. Provide a test harness that plays Scene A (50 frames), Scene B (120 frames), and Scene C (30 frames), verifies seamless transitions, confirms frame time <= 8.3 ms, and blanks on any overrun.

Build an emergency signal light with modes: Beacon (1 Hz 100% flash), Strobe (10 Hz with 10 ms pulses), SOS in Morse, and Steady Low (20%). Implement a supervisory state machine with priority preemption (Beacon overrides all), enforce average power < 30% over any 60 s window, specify WCET <= 1 ms at a 1 kHz tick, and include a self-test for timing, preemption, and safety limits.
Simple: When the pushbutton is pressed, ramp a single LED from 0% to 100% PWM over 1 s and hold there; on release, ramp back to 0% over 1 s. Update brightness at a fixed rate of 100 Hz.
Create a blink routine that flashes one LED exactly 5 times at 2 Hz and then stays off. Use a bounded loop so the pattern cannot repeat beyond 5 cycles.
On a trigger pulse, strobe the LED at 10 Hz for precisely 3 seconds, then stop. Ensure timing is based on a rate-scheduled task.
Give one LED a smooth 'breathing' fade in/out between 10% and 80% PWM with a 0.5 Hz cycle. Run the fade computations at 50 Hz.
Map a single analog slider to LED brightness via PWM with a gentle low-pass filter so updates do not change faster than 10% per 100 ms. Keep the control loop at 100 Hz.
Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, and blue, staying 1.0 s on each color. Implement the 3-step sequence with a bounded loop and repeat after a 500 ms blackout.
Implement a one-shot flash: on a rising edge input, set LED to 100% PWM for 200 ms, then return to previous level. Debounce the input at 100 Hz.
Make a simple night light: turn the LED on at 60% PWM when ambient is below 50 lux, and off above 70 lux. Sample at 20 Hz with hysteresis.
Play the SOS pattern in Morse code on a single LED using bounded loops for the 3 short and 3 long pulses, with 100 ms units for timing.
Safety requirement: never exceed 80% duty cycle on the LED. Within that limit, allow a toggle input to switch between 0%, 40%, and 80% brightness.
When brightness setpoint changes, limit the slew to 20% PWM per second to avoid glare. Run the rate limiter at 200 Hz.
Implement press-and-hold brightness: while the button is held, ramp up from 0% to 100% over 2 s; if held at max, wrap to 0% and continue. On release, keep the current level.
Create a candle-flicker effect by stepping PWM within 30%–70% using a bounded pseudo-random sequence. Update at 60 Hz and ensure the sequence length is capped.
Provide a precise strobe at 25 Hz with 10% duty cycle. Document that the worst-case execution time per update is under 0.5 ms.
Design a 'sunrise' that linearly increases LED PWM from 0% to 100% over exactly 10 minutes and then holds. Allow a cancel input to stop the sequence.
Program an 8-LED chase that advances one position per tick with wraparound. Use a bounded loop over indices and make speed adjustable from 1 to 20 steps per second.
Build a tiny state machine with states Idle, Run, and Pause for an RGB LED that smoothly rotates hue. Single-click toggles Run/Pause; long-press returns to Idle. Update at 100 Hz.
Create a two-button menu for pattern select and brightness level across 5 scenes. Use a state machine and ensure the scene list is bounded to 5 entries.
When motion is detected, fade a light strip up to 70% over 1 s, hold 30 s, then fade out over 2 s. Afterward enforce a 20 s cool-down before it can trigger again.
Adjust color temperature by blending warm and cool LEDs based on a temperature sensor: at 0 C use 70% warm/30% cool; at 40 C use 30% warm/70% cool, with linear interpolation. Run at 25 Hz.
Alternate two strips: while A shows a gradient, B is off; then swap every 2 seconds. Keep both strips updated at 50 Hz with bounded loops over pixel indices.
Drive brightness from a sound level sensor. Map amplitude to PWM with exponential smoothing, and clamp to 60% maximum to limit current. Sample at 200 Hz.
Make a 'breath' pattern composed of 64 fixed steps stored in a bounded table. Iterate the steps at 100 Hz and assert the table never exceeds 64 entries.
Render a left-to-right color gradient across 16 LEDs and then reverse back to the start, ping-pong style. Use bounded loops for index traversal.
Implement a decorative traffic light: Red 5 s, Green 5 s, Yellow 2 s, looping continuously. Use a state machine with those exact timings.
Create a sunrise alarm that ramps from 0% to 100% over 30 minutes. Provide a cancel input and a snooze that pauses the ramp for 5 minutes. Update at 20 Hz.
Thermal safety: if the strip temperature exceeds 60 C, cap total brightness to 30% and set a warning color. Restore gradually once back under 55 C.
Light-painting mode: play a preset sequence of up to 64 color frames with per-frame durations in milliseconds. Validate the frame count and iterate with a bounded loop.
Show a binary counter on 8 LEDs at 4 Hz. Include a reset input that clears back to zero.
Sparkle effect: at each 50 Hz tick, randomly choose up to 10 distinct LEDs to blink briefly, ensuring a hard cap of 10 sparkles per frame to limit power.
Emulate 12-bit brightness using 8-bit PWM by time-dithering subframes at 1 kHz. Ensure the rate-scheduled subframes fit within the main frame budget.
Control 4 independent channels with their own PWM levels and a shared master dimmer that scales them uniformly. Changes should be applied atomically per frame.
Implement scene recall: short press cycles through 6 scenes; long press stores the current levels into the selected scene. Use a clear state machine and blink feedback.
Make a color wipe that gradually accelerates from 1 to 10 LEDs per second, but enforce a maximum brightness change of 20% per second for comfort.
Add tap-tempo: a button tap sequence sets BPM from 40–200, and the lights change color on each beat. Reject taps that violate bounds and update with <5 ms jitter.
Use PID control to maintain a measured illuminance at 300 lux by adjusting PWM. Run the control loop at 200 Hz, include anti-windup, and limit output to 0–90%.

Fuse ambient light and motion sensing to choose a brightness setpoint: dim to 20% when still and bright conditions, go to 70% on motion or low ambient. Smooth transitions and enforce a 1 A equivalent current cap.

Closed-loop RGBW: read a color sensor and drive LEDs to hold a target chromaticity and 200 lux intensity. Keep loop rates at 100 Hz and ensure WCET per cycle <2 ms. Use bounded iterations for solver steps.
Enforce an energy budget: ensure average LED current over any sliding 60 s window stays under a configured limit. Gracefully reduce brightness if needed and log when capping occurs.
Thermal derating curve: above 45 C linearly reduce allowable PWM to 50% at 70 C, and hard-shutdown at 80 C with a red blink fault indication. Recover only after dropping below 60 C.
Photography strobe: maintain a 500 Hz flash rate with adjustable pulse width so that reflected light meets a target level measured by a sensor. Keep timing jitter under 0.1 ms.
Lock lighting frames to an external clock input. Debounce the clock, and create a state machine that follows, holds on missing pulses for up to 500 ms, then falls back to an internal 100 Hz timer.
Schedule multiple patterns (chase, breath, sparkle) as separate tasks with explicit rate attributes. Guarantee no task overruns, keep CPU utilization under 60%, and bound all loops.
Use a joystick to control hue (X axis) and scroll speed (Y axis) of a chase across 24 LEDs. Apply a small deadzone, clamp ranges, and update at 100 Hz.

Compensate perceived brightness drift by integrating error between intended level and inferred output estimated from forward voltage and temperature. Tune gains conservatively and document stability margins.

Design a multi-mode light installation with modes Show, Ambient, Interactive, and Maintenance. Each mode has distinct patterns, update rates, and brightness limits. Implement a robust state machine with watchdog, WCET per mode documented, and comprehensive self-tests for LEDs and sensors.

Coordinate multiple LED strips in master/slave fashion with deterministic 200 Hz frames. Define fault containment zones, heartbeat supervision, and a test plan covering loop bounds, rate checks, and worst-case power analysis.

Implement an emergency override: on an alarm input, preempt all patterns and reach a safe egress illumination level (specify in lux) within 50 ms. Include verification scenarios for bounce, repeated alarms, and restore back to normal after clear.

Create a configurable pattern engine that interprets a bounded table (max 128 steps) of color and duration entries. Validate table size and values before use, run the interpreter on a fixed schedule, and include runtime assertions and tests for all bounds.

Build an interactive art wall with 64 zones, fusing proximity and ambient light sensors to decide which zones activate. Use PID per zone to meet local brightness targets, enforce a global power cap and thermal derating, and provide formal-style invariants with traceable tests.

Fade a single white LED from 0% to 100% over 2 seconds, then back to 0% over 2 seconds, continuously. Use PWM, implement the fade steps with a bounded loop, and run the update at 100 Hz using a rate attribute.
Blink an LED at 1 Hz with a 25% duty cycle using PWM, and ensure brightness never exceeds 60% under any condition.
Turn on a blue LED only while a pushbutton is pressed; otherwise keep it off. Debounce the input with a 10 ms filter.
On power-up, ramp brightness from 0% to 30% over 500 ms, then hold steady at 30%. If a secondary toggle is active at startup, skip the ramp and stay off.
Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, and blue, each for 500 ms. Use a bounded loop to repeat exactly 20 cycles, then stop and turn off.
Create a 'heartbeat' double-blink pattern at low intensity: two quick flashes at 5% brightness, then a pause so the total cycle takes 2 seconds, repeating indefinitely.
Make a breathing effect using a step table of 32 brightness levels to approximate a sine ramp. Iterate with a bounded loop and refresh at 50 Hz.
Toggle an LED between 0% and 100% brightness on each rising edge of a button press. Add a 50 ms hold-off after each toggle to avoid bounce re-triggers.
Flash an LED three times (100 ms on, 100 ms off), then pause for 1 second, and repeat the sequence continuously.
Set LED brightness proportionally to a 0–100% control input, clamped to an output range of 10% to 80%. Changes should take effect immediately.
Implement a strobe with 10 ms pulses every 200 ms. Enforce a safety rule that total on-time does not exceed 15 seconds per minute.
Drive an RGB LED to a warm white using a fixed R:G:B ratio and apply a smooth soft-start over 300 ms when turning on.
On startup, pulse an LED once for 200 ms, then remain off until a trigger signal arrives; upon trigger, pulse again and return to off.
Sequence through 8 predefined colors on an LED strip, each displayed for 250 ms. Use a bounded loop to run exactly one pass, then stop.
Provide a simple day/night mode indicator: when a digital input indicates daytime, set brightness to 20%; at night, set to 5%.

Design a state machine with states Idle, Fade, and Alert. Idle holds LEDs at 10%, Fade breathes between 10–60% at 2 Hz, and Alert blinks solid red at 4 Hz. Enter Alert on a trigger and return to Idle after 5 s of no triggers.
Run a color chase across 16 pixels at 100 Hz. Use a bounded loop to move a single bright pixel forward one position per tick and wrap at the end.
Create a crossfade between two predefined RGB colors over 5 seconds, using linear interpolation steps in a bounded loop.
Implement a sunrise effect: change color temperature from 2000 K to 5000 K and brightness from 0% to 70% over 20 minutes, updating at 1 Hz with a rate attribute.
Build a 4-zone dimmer with independent brightness inputs. Enforce a total current budget of 500 mA by proportionally scaling zones if the sum would exceed the limit.
Map ambient light (in lux) to LED brightness inversely so that brighter rooms yield dimmer LEDs. Update at 20 Hz and limit brightness change to at most 5% per second.
Implement a pattern selector driven by a rotary input. Use a state machine to switch among Solid, Blink, Breathe, and Rainbow modes only on detent events.
Create a rainbow that traverses hue from 0° to 360° in 60 steps using a bounded loop. Drive PWM at 200 Hz using a rate attribute.
On audio beat detection, flash all LEDs to 80% for 50 ms, then return to the previous pattern. Include a 150 ms cooldown to prevent rapid retriggering.
Create a theater-chase pattern with three-on, three-off repeating blocks moving right each tick. Stop after 10 full passes across the strip.
Apply per-channel gamma correction using a 256-entry lookup table before sending PWM outputs, ensuring smooth fades at low brightness.
Build a dual-button interface: one button increases brightness by 5%, the other decreases by 5%. Clamp between 0% and 100% and ignore repeat presses faster than 100 ms.
Add a long-press function: holding a button for more than 1 second triggers a 100% white flash for 200 ms, then returns to the previous brightness.
Design a traffic-light art piece as a deterministic state machine: green for 3 s, yellow for 1 s, red for 3 s, repeating with precise timers.
Create a twinkle effect by pseudo-randomly selecting up to 5 pixels to sparkle to 70% for 100 ms. Ensure a bounded loop limits selection work per frame.
Blend two concurrently running patterns A and B with a crossfade factor that ramps from 0 to 1 over 3 seconds, maintaining a 100 Hz output rate.
Create a pulse train where each subsequent pulse increases the peak brightness by 5% until reaching 50%, then resets to 10%. Pulses must occur every 300 ms.
Implement a color picker: convert a potentiometer reading (0–1023) to a hue angle (0–360°) and display the chosen hue at 40% brightness.
Provide a calibration routine that steps through R, G, and B at 20%, 50%, and 80% for 2 seconds each. Use bounded loops for step sequencing and end by saving the last brightness level.
Build a timer-controlled nightlight: after a trigger, fade to 15% over 5 seconds, hold for 30 minutes, then fade out over 10 seconds.
Use PID control to maintain measured illuminance at 300 lux by adjusting PWM duty. Sample at 50 Hz using a rate attribute, constrain output to 0–80%, and implement integrator anti-windup.

Fuse readings from an ambient light sensor and a proximity sensor to compute LED brightness: dim more when the viewer is closer and ambient is bright. Update at 40 Hz with bounded computation per cycle.
Implement thermal safety: monitor heat sink temperature and linearly reduce brightness from 60 °C to 80 °C, shutting off above 85 °C. Check at 10 Hz.
Create a color-cycling piece whose average power must not exceed 1.5 W at 5 V. Estimate current from PWM levels and enforce a rolling 60 s energy budget.
Render a deterministic rainbow wave around 64 pixels using only bounded loops, and guarantee WCET per frame under 1 ms at a 100 Hz rate.
Design a flicker-free dimmer at 1 kHz PWM with per-channel phase spreading to reduce instantaneous current spikes. Cap total current at 800 mA.
Implement a beat-synchronized strobe that uses a PID to lock strobe phase to an external 2 Hz reference signal. Limit brightness to 70% and prevent windup.

Add automatic gamma curve adaptation: periodically measure perceived brightness via a sensor and fit a piecewise-linear curve with bounded computation once per minute; use the current curve to map levels before PWM.
Control a two-ring LED sculpture where inner and outer rings run separate state machines but synchronize on a shared scene tick at 20 Hz.
Provide overvoltage fail-safe handling: if supply exceeds 5.5 V, enter a safe mode that sets all outputs to 0% and blinks a red indicator at 1 Hz until voltage returns to normal.

Design a multi-mode lighting controller with Normal, Show, and Emergency modes defined by a deterministic state machine. Use a rate attribute for a 100 Hz control loop, enforce a current cap and temperature limit, enter Emergency on a trigger, and include a startup self-test (RGB sweep) implemented with bounded loops. Specify WCET < 0.5 ms and provide test cases verifying mode transitions and timing.

Create a fault-tolerant auto-dimming system using two ambient light sensors. If readings disagree by more than 15% for over 2 seconds, enter a Degraded mode at fixed 30% brightness and blink a status LED. Include diagnostics counters, use rate attributes for periodic tasks with WCET < 0.3 ms, and add assertions that all loops are bounded and numeric ranges are clamped.

Implement a configurable pattern engine with a bounded list of 10 selectable patterns, each executed via bounded loops. Enforce SafePower = 600 mA and MaxTemp = 75 °C limits. Provide a test harness that runs all patterns for 60 s each at 100 Hz, reporting any missed deadlines or limit violations.

Build a time-of-day scene scheduler with modes Dawn, Day, Dusk, and Night, each with specified color temperature and brightness curves. Define preemption for a high-priority Alert that overrides with a 2 Hz red flash, and deterministic recovery back to the prior scene. Verify WCET < 1 ms, timing jitter < 200 µs, and no unbounded memory growth.

Develop a watchdog-supervised light show controller that must recover to a Safe state on any detected fault (sensor timeout, overvoltage, or temperature overrun). Define a startup Built-In Self-Test sequence lasting ≤ 3 s using bounded loops, periodic health checks at 10 Hz with rate attributes, and a traceable event log with bounded size and wrap-around. Include a checklist of unit tests.

Create a single LED breathing effect that fades from 5% to 70% brightness and back, using PWM. Drive it with a fixed update rate (100 Hz) and implement the fade with a bounded loop over a fixed number of steps (64). Stop after exactly 10 full cycles.

When a pushbutton is pressed, toggle the LED brightness between 0%, 50%, and 100%. Debounce the input. Flash a quick 3-blink acknowledgment using a bounded loop each time the mode changes. Run the logic at a fixed rate of 50 Hz.

Smoothly cycle a single RGB LED through the full hue wheel over 30 seconds. Use PWM with per-channel duty limited to 90%. Implement the color ramp with a bounded loop of 360 steps and update at 60 Hz.

Implement a 'breathing' amber LED whose period is controlled by a potentiometer. Clamp brightness between 10% and 80% and limit the per-tick change to avoid sudden jumps. Use a bounded loop to compute the waveform and a 100 Hz rate.

Create a tap-tempo flasher: each time the button is double-tapped, set the LED to flash at that tempo. Reject tempos faster than 10 Hz or slower than 0.2 Hz. Drive timing with a 100 Hz rate attribute, and use a bounded loop to emit exactly 6 flashes per activation.

Blink an LED in an SOS pattern (... --- ...) repeatedly using PWM for the dashes and dots, with a bounded loop enumerating the pattern. Guarantee that the control loop WCET stays below 500 microseconds per tick.
On power-up, ramp a single LED from 0% to 70% brightness over 2 seconds using a bounded step loop, then hold steady. Update at 200 Hz and ensure no duty cycle overshoot.

Use an ambient light input (in lux) to control one LED’s brightness: when lux falls below a threshold, increase PWM proportionally; add hysteresis to prevent chatter. Run at 50 Hz and clamp duty between 5% and 60%.

When motion is detected, run a 5-second rainbow chase across a short LED strip, then return to idle off. Use a state machine (Idle, Chase) and a bounded loop to step through the chase indexes at 100 Hz.
Implement a double-tap button that triggers a white strobe: on activation, flash exactly 3 times at 8 Hz using a bounded loop; otherwise keep the LED solid at 20%.

If no button activity is detected for 60 seconds, fade the LED to black over 1 second; any activity should cancel the fade and restore the previous brightness. Use a 100 Hz update rate and bounded loops for fade steps.
Alternate a bi-color LED between red and green once per second for exactly 10 cycles using a bounded loop. Keep per-channel PWM duty under 70%.
Map a 0–5 V analog input to LED brightness linearly, with a deadband around 0.1 V. Update at 200 Hz and clamp the PWM duty to the range 10%–90%.
Set an RGB LED to a warm white mix and gently pulse at 0.2 Hz. Use a bounded loop to shape the pulse and run the control at 100 Hz, constraining each channel’s duty between 5% and 60%.
Create a candle-flicker effect on a single amber LED by iterating over a 32-sample brightness table in a bounded loop and looping it. Keep PWM between 5% and 40% and update at 120 Hz.

Build a small RGB strip controller with a state machine: Idle (slow blue breathe), Chase (color chase for 5 s after a button press), then return to Idle. Use bounded loops to step patterns and run at 100 Hz.

Use two buttons to adjust LED brightness up and down in 5% steps, with press-and-hold auto-repeat at 5 Hz. Constrain brightness to 0%–80%. Provide a brief confirmation blink using a bounded loop on each change. Update at 50 Hz.

Make an audio-reactive RGB LED: map microphone amplitude to color from blue (quiet) to red (loud). Apply smoothing over the last 16 samples via a bounded loop, clamp per-tick change, and update at 200 Hz.

Drive 8 LEDs in a proximity-reactive sweep. Implement a state machine: Arm (waiting), Triggered (forward gradient sweep), Cooldown (ignore input for 2 s). Use bounded loops for the gradient and run at 100 Hz.

Program a traffic-light sequence (Green 6 s, Amber 2 s, Red 6 s) using a state machine. When an override switch is active, switch to flashing Amber at 1 Hz with 25% duty for 10 cycles via a bounded loop. Rate: 10 Hz.
Use a rotary encoder to adjust the hue of an RGB LED and a push to commit. Keep brightness constant at 40%. Debounce inputs, run at 50 Hz, and enforce bounded wrap-around when hue crosses 0/360.
Create a pattern player that cycles through Rainbow, Sparkle, and Wipe, each for 15 seconds. Provide a button to skip to the next pattern. Use bounded loops to render frames and run at 100 Hz.
Implement a simple white-balance control: a 'warm–cool' knob selects among 5 preset RGB mixes via a lookup table. Smooth transitions over 0.5 s using a bounded ramp at 100 Hz.
Crossfade between two LED strips with a slider (0–100%). Normalize outputs so their combined PWM duty never exceeds 160%. Apply a bounded ramp to changes and run at 100 Hz.
Make a theater chase on a 12-pixel ring with speed controlled by a potentiometer. Start/stop with a button. Use a bounded loop to step the pattern index and constrain speed between 0.5 Hz and 20 Hz.

Implement a binary clock using columns of LEDs. Update once per second from a tick input. Long-press enters Set mode; short presses increment hours/minutes. Model with a state machine and enforce bounded loops for display updates.
Create a color wipe that moves along a strip and reverses direction at the ends. Use a bounded loop for pixel updates, ensure indices stay within bounds, and run at 60 Hz.
Drive two separate LEDs with synchronized breathing patterns offset by 180 degrees of phase. Use a bounded loop waveform and a 50 Hz rate, with brightness limited to 70%.
Program a ping-pong effect on 16 LEDs with an adjustable tail. Use a bounded loop to compute trailing intensities and keep the per-frame compute bounded. Rate: 100 Hz.
On motion detection, strobe white at 8 Hz for 1 s; otherwise show dim blue. Use a state machine (Idle, Strobe) and limit strobe duty cycle to at most 30%. Update at 100 Hz.
Provide three buttons to select among RGB palettes A/B/C. Render a smooth gradient across 20 LEDs each frame using a bounded loop. Maintain a 100 Hz update rate.
Play a startup animation showing three brand colors for 0.5 s each, then settle to steady white. Ensure total startup time is <= 3 s and implement timing with bounded step loops at 200 Hz.

Create a brightness controller: short press steps by ±10%; long press toggles full on/off. Each change is acknowledged by a quick 2-flash sequence via a bounded loop. Clamp brightness to 5%–85% and run at 100 Hz.

Implement a 'meteor' effect where a bright head moves with an exponential tail. Speed is controlled by an analog input. Model Idle, Run, and Pause-after-20-bounces states, using bounded loops for the tail. Rate: 100 Hz.
Build a four-channel dimmer driven by four sliders. Apply first-order smoothing to each channel at 50 Hz. Guarantee WCET under 1 ms per update and keep each channel within 0%–90% duty.

Maintain a target of 100 lux on a surface by closing the loop on LED brightness using a PID controller. Sample ambient light and update PWM at 200 Hz with anti-windup, clamping duty to 10%–80%. Guarantee WCET < 500 microseconds.

Fuse accelerometer magnitude and microphone amplitude to drive an RGB pattern: more motion increases saturation, louder sound increases strobe intensity. Filter both signals with bounded windows, run at 100 Hz, and cap strobe to 10 Hz with max 20% duty for eye safety.

Implement temperature-aware dimming: above 45 C, linearly reduce the allowed max PWM; at 70 C, enter Overtemp and shut off until cooled below 60 C. Use a state machine and bounded ramp-down loops. Rate: 50 Hz.

Control color temperature to 4000 K using feedback from a simple color sensor. Use PID on the R/G/B balance while keeping total luminous output constant. Update at 100 Hz, limit per-step change, and avoid overshoot >5%.
Synchronize two LED strips to a master frame clock. Render frames with bounded loops and ensure each frame’s compute WCET stays below 2 ms. Provide two patterns (A/B) switchable via a button.

Mitigate visible flicker by sampling a mains-hum indicator and adjusting PWM phase and rate accordingly. Maintain a 1 kHz control rate with jitter under 50 microseconds. Use a calibration state machine and bounded loops for phase tables.

Design emergency signage lighting: on boot, run a 3 s self-test (all on, then chase) using bounded loops; Normal mode is steady green at 70%; Fault mode is red at 1 Hz with 10% duty. Include a watchdog behavior and run at 100 Hz.

Implement closed-loop color mixing by reading three photodiodes for R, G, and B feedback. Use multi-input PID to match a target color vector, clamp each channel’s PWM, update at 500 Hz, and enforce monotonic ramps.

Create motion-activated hallway lighting with sensor fusion of PIR and ambient light. Soft-start and soft-stop each zone using bounded ramps, rate 50 Hz, and limit total current by scaling when multiple zones are active. Include an overcurrent fault state.

Build a beat-synchronized light show: detect BPM from audio and drive patterns in Sync, Play, and LostSync states. Maintain a fixed 120 Hz frame rate with WCET under 1 ms. Enforce a global brightness cap and bounded loop rendering.

Specify a multi-mode architectural lighting controller with modes: Installation, Performance, Maintenance, and Emergency. Define a formal state machine with explicit transitions, per-mode rate attributes, power limits, self-test on entry, watchdog, and a simulation toggle. Include comprehensive test cases for timing, WCET, and fault handling.

Design a festival art piece lighting system that schedules scenes over 24 hours. Two knobs adjust tempo and palette. Use bounded loops for effect layers and enforce: total current cap, thermal derating above 50 C, and strobe limits for eye safety. Provide a detailed state machine and acceptance tests for timing and fail-safe behaviors.

Control an interactive wall of 100 LEDs grouped into 10 zones with modes Attract, Interact, and Sleep. Fuse touch-strip input and ambient sound. Guarantee a deterministic 120 Hz frame rate and WCET < 0.8 ms. Supply a test harness plan, stress tests for max inputs, and power budgeting.

Create a stage wash controller with Manual, Auto, and Safe-Dim modes. Support time-coded scene crossfades with S-curve easing using bounded loops. Enforce per-scene power limits, thermal derating, and an emergency Safe-Dim fallback. Include verification steps for rates, WCET, and mode transitions.

Specify a large-scale LED sculpture controller with deterministic scheduling and per-zone priorities across multiple patterns. Require bounded loops for all per-frame work, rate groups for 50/100/200 Hz tasks, overload handling (frame skip and safe-dim), and a full test plan covering WCET measurements, recovery from faults, and safety fallbacks.
Create a smooth RGB fade through red, green, and blue using PWM. Update at 40 Hz via a rate attribute, and use a bounded loop of 30 steps per color with 25 ms between steps.
Set a single white LED to 60% brightness when a touch sensor is active, otherwise off. Use PWM with a fixed rate and clamp duty to 0-60%. Include a rate attribute at 50 Hz.
Blink a status LED at exactly 2 Hz using a rate attribute. Keep a 30% duty cycle and ensure timing jitter is below 5 ms.
On power-up, perform a quick double-flash pattern (two 100 ms on pulses separated by 100 ms off) using a bounded loop of 2 iterations, then stay off.
Implement a sunrise ramp from 0% to 100% PWM over 10 seconds. Use a bounded loop for the ramp steps and enforce monotonic increase without overshoot.
Create a breathing effect on one LED: ramp from 10% to 90% and back to 10% continuously at 1 Hz. Use bounded step loops and keep the PWM frequency flicker-free.
Turn a LED on at 80% brightness when a debounced switch is pressed; turn it off otherwise. Debounce at 50 ms and update via a 100 Hz rate attribute.
Flash a single LED once per second with precise timing. Guarantee period 1000 ms +/- 5 ms and keep the code's worst-case execution time under 1 ms per tick.
When a button is pressed, fade a LED up to 70% over 500 ms; when released, fade down to 0% over 500 ms. Use bounded loops and linear steps.
Set an RGB LED to a specific color using 8-bit channel values. Clamp each channel to 0-255 and cap total duty to 90% to limit power.
Play a 3-step warm-white ramp (20%, 60%, 100%), holding each step 200 ms, then hold at the final level. Use a bounded loop of exactly 3 steps with a 50 Hz rate attribute.
Generate a repeating hazard blink: 75 ms on, 75 ms off, 75 ms on, 750 ms off. Implement the sequence with a bounded step list and continuous looping.
Create a soft strobe pattern at 10 Hz: 10 ms on, 90 ms off. Drive updates with a rate attribute and keep the WCET for each cycle under 0.5 ms.
At startup, blink a LED rapidly 5 times, then set steady 20% brightness. Use a bounded loop for the 5 blinks and ensure a minimum 50 ms off-time between blinks.
Map a potentiometer to LED brightness linearly from 0% to 100% at a 50 Hz update rate. Clamp noisy input and limit brightness change to 5% per tick.
Build a two-state LED controller: Idle (off) and Alert (blinking at 2 Hz). A button toggles states. Use a 20 Hz rate attribute, switch debouncing, and ensure deterministic transitions.
Cycle an RGB LED through a palette of 6 colors, each displayed for 300 ms. Implement a bounded loop over the palette and allow long-press to pause/resume the cycle.
Drive an 8-LED bar in a back-and-forth sweep at 60 steps per second, with a 200 ms dwell at each end. Use a bounded loop for positions and a state machine for direction.
Control two LEDs: a heartbeat at 1 Hz and an error indicator that blinks 1-4 times per cycle based on an error code. Implement the error pattern with a bounded blink loop.
Dim a light based on ambient lux: brighter when dark, dimmer when bright. Update at 25 Hz and smooth changes with a bounded ramp so step size per tick is limited.
Shift color temperature on a dual-channel (warm/cool) LED from cool to warm over 30 s when a switch is ON, and back when OFF. Cap PWM at 85% and rate-limit transitions.
Implement a color wheel on an RGB LED with speed set by a knob from 0.1 to 2.0 revolutions per second. Clamp speed, and use a bounded loop for the hue steps.
Program a traffic light with three LEDs (red, green, yellow) using a state machine: red 5 s, green 5 s, yellow 2 s. Include an all-off safe state on reset.
Show a comet across a 30-LED strip with a fading tail length of 5. Advance at 50 Hz using a bounded loop for tail intensity and wrap at the end.
On button press, trigger a sparkle effect: randomly select 3 of 20 LEDs to hit 100% for 100 ms, then fade out. Ensure selection uses a bounded loop and no repeats within an event.
Add brightness smoothing to prevent flicker: filter PWM targets with an exponential moving average at 100 Hz using a rate attribute, and cap per-tick changes.
Create a two-mode animation state machine: Mode A is a rainbow crawl; Mode B is a solid color pulse. Double-click toggles modes, single click adjusts speed, long-press turns off.
Enable night mode when ambient light drops below 50 lux and exit when above 60 lux. In night mode, run a warm dim pattern; otherwise, steady cool light. Update at 10 Hz with hysteresis.
Sequence four spotlights on one-by-one, each held for 1 s, then all off for 2 s. Loop this program exactly 10 cycles when a start signal is true, using a bounded outer loop.
Synchronize a breathing LED to a metronome input (60-180 BPM). Map beats to inhale/exhale durations and generate steps at 100 Hz with bounded per-step changes.
On trigger, crossfade between two predefined RGB colors over 3 s using linear interpolation in exactly 60 steps. Hold the new color afterwards.
Render a heartbeat double-blink pattern whose brightness scales with acceleration magnitude from an IMU. Update at 50 Hz and clamp brightness between 10% and 70%.
Control two LED channels via two sliders; if their combined duty exceeds 150%, scale both proportionally to stay within the limit. Recompute at 20 Hz.
Run a chase across 12 LEDs that reverses direction when a hand is detected by a proximity sensor. Limit speed to 5-30 steps per second and ensure bounded indices.
Play Pattern A for 10 s, then Pattern B for 5 s, repeating. Implement both with bounded loops and drive the scheduler at 25 Hz with a pause/resume input.
Maintain 300 lux at a sensor by adjusting LED PWM with a PID controller at 200 Hz using a rate attribute. Constrain duty to 0-90%, add anti-windup, and log saturation events.
Implement thermal derating: read temperature in Celsius every 100 ms; linearly reduce maximum PWM from 100% at 30 C to 40% at 70 C. Latch an error and force off above 80 C.
Use two PID loops to control warm and cool channels to achieve 200 lux at 4000 K based on ambient light and color temperature sensors. Update at 100 Hz with WCET < 1 ms.
Detect spins versus shakes by fusing accelerometer and gyroscope data, and select distinct LED color patterns accordingly. Use a 50 Hz rate attribute and bound classification time under 0.5 ms.
Limit average current by constraining the rolling 1-second average total PWM across 30 LEDs to 60%. Gracefully dim as the limit is approached and fail safe to off if voltage sags.
Apply gamma 2.2 correction to PWM targets using a bounded lookup table to ensure perceptual linearity. Guarantee monotonic output and prevent overflow.
Create an interactive rainbow where touch pressure sets saturation and microphone level (dB SPL) sets speed. Clamp spikes, use a 50 Hz rate attribute, and avoid unbounded loops.
Control 4 lighting zones with independent fades but a shared global power limit. Include recall of up to 8 scenes and cycle through them with a button using a bounded scene index.
Build a daylight-harvesting lamp: maintain 500 lux using a PID loop, with bumpless transfer between manual and auto modes and separated integral action. Update at 100 Hz.
Stabilize RGB output using a photodiode with color filters to hold channel ratios via a MIMO PID. Enforce per-channel duty caps and keep flicker rates above 200 Hz.

Design a multi-mode controller with Setup, Show, Intermission, and Emergency states. Define explicit transitions, timeouts, and an all-off safe state. Assign rate attributes per mode and keep WCET under 2 ms.

Create a show scheduler with a playlist of 5 patterns, each with duration plus fade in/out. Allow skipping and looping. Include a diagnostics mode for error code blinking and a test mode that sweeps PWM 0-100%. Add assertions on duty bounds and timing jitter < 1 ms.

Implement redundant safety lighting with dual-channel monitoring: compare commanded versus measured brightness and force off if error exceeds 10% for more than 200 ms. Add periodic self-test patterns via bounded loops and a latched fault state.

Build an audience-interactive light wall with modes: idle, vote, reveal, celebration. Fuse buttons, proximity, and a light meter to select patterns. Use rate-grouped tasks at 20 Hz and 100 Hz via rate attributes, with strict WCET budgets.

Define a comprehensive test harness for LED animations: test color transitions, ramp linearity, saturation limits, and thermal derating. Execute bounded loops to validate outputs against expected ranges, track pass/fail counters, and show a status indicator.
Make a single indicator LED turn on at full PWM while a pushbutton is held and turn off when released. Scan the input using a rate attribute of 100 Hz with debouncing, and keep idle CPU use low.
Create a gentle breathing effect on one LED by ramping PWM from 0% to 100% and back over a 3 s cycle. Use a bounded loop for the ramp steps and ensure LED current never exceeds 25 mA.
Flash a status LED exactly 10 times at 2 Hz, then leave it off. Implement the count using a bounded loop and run the scheduler at a rate attribute of 50 Hz.
Cycle a single RGB LED through red, green, and blue, holding each solid color for 1 s. Use a rate attribute of 50 Hz and a bounded loop to sequence the three states.
Implement a 10 Hz strobe on one LED that runs for 30 s and then stops. Use a bounded loop to count the strobe pulses and clamp PWM duty between 0% and 100%.

Build a simple nightlight: if ambient illuminance falls below 50 lx, set the LED to a steady 30% PWM; otherwise keep it off. Sample the light sensor at a rate attribute of 10 Hz with a small hysteresis band to prevent flicker.
Map a potentiometer to LED brightness from 0% to 100% PWM with saturation at the endpoints. Update brightness at a rate attribute of 20 Hz and ignore changes smaller than 1% to reduce jitter.
Using a debounced toggle button, switch a single LED between 20% and 80% brightness. Scan input with a 100 Hz rate attribute and keep a minimal two-state internal state machine.
Play an SOS pattern on an LED: dot=200 ms, dash=600 ms, with appropriate gaps. Express the pattern using a bounded loop over the durations and ensure average duty stays under 30%.
Create a single-pixel chaser across 8 LEDs, advancing one position every 100 ms and wrapping back to index 0. Use a bounded loop to index the LEDs and clamp PWM values.
On power-up, pulse an LED at 50% PWM for 500 ms once, then hold it at a steady 10%. Implement an Init and Run state machine and drive timing with a 100 Hz rate attribute.
When a digital input goes high, ramp brightness from 0% to 100% in 2 s; when low, ramp down in 1 s. Use bounded-step loops for the ramps and a rate attribute of 100 Hz to schedule updates.
Alternate warm and cool white LEDs every 0.5 s, exactly 10 times, then stop with both off. Implement this with a bounded sequence and ensure never both channels are on simultaneously.
Produce a smooth breathing effect where PWM changes are limited to 1% per 10 ms to avoid visible stepping. Use a rate attribute of 100 Hz and enforce the slew limit.
Blink an LED on for 100 ms at the start of every second and off otherwise. Use a rate attribute of 100 Hz and timers to achieve second boundaries with jitter under 10 ms.

Design a small state machine with modes Off, Dim (30%), and Bright (90%). A short button press advances the mode; a long press (>1 s) forces Off. Use PWM for brightness and a 100 Hz rate attribute for scanning.
Rotate a color wheel across a strip of N RGB LEDs, shifting hue one step per frame to create continuous motion. Use bounded loops over N and a rate attribute of 60 Hz for fluid animation.
Control two LED channels from two ambient light sensors: map illuminance to PWM inversely, clamped to 5%–80%. Sample at 10 Hz with a bounded 4-sample moving average per channel to reduce noise.
Create a stylized traffic light art piece that cycles Red (3 s), Yellow (1 s), Green (3 s). Implement as a state machine and guarantee only one color is on at a time. Use a 50 Hz rate attribute.
Display a 10-bit binary counter on 10 LEDs, incrementing every 0.5 s. Use a bounded loop to map bits to LEDs and reset the counter on a long button press.
Simulate a sunrise by ramping from 0% to 100% brightness over 15 minutes in equal steps. Implement 900 bounded steps at a 1 Hz rate attribute, cancellable by a button.
Map temperature from 15°C to 35°C into an RGB gradient from blue to red for a single LED. Update at 5 Hz and clamp values outside the range. Smooth PWM transitions to avoid flicker.
Provide three patterns—Solid, Fade, and Chase—selectable by a button. Implement a state machine to switch patterns, and express each pattern using bounded loops. Run the animation at 50 Hz.
Apply gamma correction to brightness using a bounded 16-entry lookup table, and control LED PWM perceived linearly with a knob. Update at a 100 Hz rate attribute.
Program a ping-pong bounce effect: a bright dot moves back and forth across a strip with a dim trail. Use bounded loops over length N and step every 50 ms (20 Hz rate attribute).
Make a candle flicker effect using a seeded, bounded pseudo-random sequence limited to 10%–40% PWM. Update at 25 Hz and avoid step changes larger than 10% between frames.
Build a simple audio level meter: map microphone amplitude to the number of lit LEDs on a bar. Use a bounded 8-sample moving average and refresh at 30 Hz.
Control brightness with two buttons: one increases and one decreases by 5% steps with saturation at 0% and 100%. Long-press after 700 ms repeats at 20 Hz. Scan buttons at a 200 Hz rate attribute.
Implement a day-night schedule: at 18:00 set warm white to 40% and fade to 10% by 22:00; at 07:00 turn off. Use bounded step fades of 60 s each and fail safe to Off if time is invalid.
Create a Knight Rider effect with adjustable speed via a knob and configurable trail length. Use bounded loops for per-LED intensities and a rate attribute of 200 Hz.
Morph between two user-selected RGB colors over 10 s using 100 linear steps. Express the interpolation with a bounded loop and allow cancellation via a button.
Show a circular progress indicator on a 24-LED ring for 0–100%. When reaching 100%, blink the ring three times using a bounded loop. Refresh at 60 Hz.
Decode a few IR remote codes to select preset colors and a blackout mode. Ignore unknown codes, default to a safe Off state on errors, and scan at a 100 Hz rate attribute.
Adjust white LED brightness based on proximity: closer equals dimmer using an inverse-like mapping. Limit between 5% and 80% PWM, update at 20 Hz, and rate-limit changes to 5% per 50 ms.
Implement a 15-minute timer light: when started, turn on to 60% PWM and automatically turn off after 900 s. Blink a status LED for 100 ms each minute using a bounded loop; cancel on button press.
Use PID control to maintain 200 lx on a work surface measured by a lux sensor. Sample at 50 Hz, limit PWM duty slew to 10% per 20 ms, and include anti-windup with duty saturation at 0%–100%.

Fuse ambient light and proximity readings with a complementary approach (weights 0.8 and 0.2) to set LED brightness. Update at 40 Hz, use bounded moving averages, and never allow full Off (<2% minimum).

Build an interactive art state machine with modes Idle, Attract, and Interact. Transition on motion and 10 s timeouts. Each mode runs a bounded-loop pattern, and the control loop must hold WCET ≤ 1 ms at 100 Hz.

Control color temperature by mixing warm and cool white channels to reach a target CCT between 2700 K and 6500 K using a color sensor for feedback. Update at 20 Hz, cap total current at 1.0 A, and fail safe to Off if the sensor is missing.
Animate a 16×16 RGB matrix with a diagonal runner synchronized to an external beat pulse. Maintain a 120 Hz frame rate, use bounded per-pixel loops, and update the display without tearing.

Implement an adaptive strobe that enforces an average duty ≤ 5% over any 1 s sliding window. Use a bounded accumulator for energy tracking, allow flash widths from 2–20 ms, and reject commands that would violate the limit.

Create a fault-tolerant dimmer: monitor current and temperature; derate brightness linearly above 45°C and force 0% at 60°C. Cap current at 1.5 A. Latch a fault state and require a reset to clear. Use a clear state machine.
Provide HSL color control with three knobs. Convert HSL to RGB each tick using bounded math and apply 8-bit temporal dithering to minimize banding. Run at a 100 Hz rate attribute.

Choreograph three LED strips with distinct patterns (chase, sparkle, fade) that stay in sync. Use bounded loops per strip length N and ensure each pattern step completes in ≤ 0.5 ms at a 200 Hz update rate.
Close the loop on fade timing: use an optical sensor to adjust the PWM ramp so the LED reaches 80% brightness in exactly 2.0 s. Limit controller iterations and enforce a maximum slew per tick.

Design a stage lighting controller with scenes, timed transitions, and cue triggers. Use a hierarchical state machine, run at 100 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.8 ms per tick, default to blackout on any fault, and implement patterns via bounded loops. Include a power-on self-test.

Create a comprehensive test harness for a color pattern engine. Generate randomized but bounded sequences of fades, chases, and strobes; assert invariants on PWM bounds and RGB sums; and measure timing jitter at 60 Hz, emitting a concise test log.

Implement an emergency-stop-aware lighting system. An e-stop input must force all PWM outputs to 0 within 50 ms. Verify with assertions, and provide normal modes Ambient, Task, and Accent via a state machine. Use deterministic bounded loops at a 200 Hz rate attribute.

Drive an interactive mural by fusing microphone, proximity, and accelerometer inputs with a simplified, bounded Kalman-style filter. Provide modes Calm, Reactive, and Alarm; render up to 500 pixels at 100 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.9 ms; and derate brightness above 55°C.

Develop a redundant lighting controller with dual-channel heartbeat cross-check. If heartbeat loss exceeds 100 ms, force blackout. Run scenes with bounded loops and timed transitions, include built-in diagnostics, and provide a scripted test to validate mode transitions and deadline adherence.

Create a single LED breathing effect that fades from 5% to 80% and back over a 2 s cycle, executed at a fixed update rate of 100 Hz. Use a bounded loop to repeat exactly 12 cycles, then leave the LED steady at 10%.

When a button is pressed, set LED brightness to 80%; when released, drop to 15%. Constrain PWM duty cycle between 5% and 90% for safety and keep the PWM frequency constant. Debounce the button and ensure updates run at 200 Hz.
Cycle a single RGB LED through red, green, and blue, holding each color for 1.5 s with a 300 ms crossfade. Use a bounded loop to run the full sequence 5 times and then stop on green.

Implement a simple pulse: ramp an LED from 0% to 60% in 250 ms, hold for 500 ms, then ramp down in 250 ms. Ignore retriggers while the pulse is active. Guarantee WCET under 0.5 ms per update at 250 Hz.

Provide a soft blink at 0.5 Hz with a 50% duty fade (1 s up, 1 s down) whenever an enable input is true; otherwise, ensure the LED is fully off. Use a bounded loop to limit maximum consecutive blinks to 100 before reevaluating the enable.
Map a 0–3.3 V analog input linearly to LED brightness 0–100% with clamping. Update at 100 Hz and ensure the PWM output never exceeds 95% duty to protect the LED.

While a momentary switch is held, ramp brightness from 0% to 70% over 2 s; when released, fade back to 0% over 0.5 s. Hold a constant PWM carrier frequency and run the control loop at a fixed rate of 250 Hz.

On receiving a trigger pulse, output a single trapezoidal LED pulse: 100 ms rise to 50%, 200 ms hold, 100 ms fall, then lock out for 300 ms. Enforce a bounded loop to prevent more than 20 pulses per minute.
Create a nightlight that stays at 10% brightness and briefly fades up to 40% for 1 s every 5 s to indicate heartbeat. Keep compute rate at 100 Hz and cap PWM duty between 5% and 60%.
Implement a simple fixed-rate dimmer: accept a brightness setpoint in percent (0–100) from a numeric input, slew-limit changes to 20% per second, and drive an LED via PWM at 1 kHz.
