Upon a tap input event, flash the LED at 30% for 200 ms and then return to the previous steady brightness. Rate limit tap handling to at most 2 taps per second using a bounded loop counter.
Create a gentle sunrise: linearly increase LED brightness from 0% to 100% over 10 minutes, then hold at 100%. Updates must run at 50 Hz with WCET under 1 ms.
Generate a 3-blink acknowledgement pattern: three quick flashes at 70% (150 ms on, 150 ms off), then idle. Use a bounded loop to ensure exactly three flashes per activation request.
Fade LED brightness according to a cosine curve over a 3 s period for smoothness. Limit the minimum brightness to 5% to avoid complete off. Run at an update rate of 100 Hz.
Implement a single-color LED with two modes: steady 30% and steady 80%, toggled by a button press. Debounce at 20 ms and ensure deterministic transitions with a fixed 200 Hz control rate.

Create a state machine with four modes for an RGB strip: solid color, slow rainbow, theater chase, and off. A short button press advances the mode; a long press (>1 s) goes to off. Each pattern uses bounded loops to limit pattern steps per cycle and runs at 60 Hz.

Design a dual-LED status indicator where LED A blinks a heartbeat at 1 Hz and LED B shows error codes via a bounded loop of N blinks corresponding to an error code input. Ensure no overlap by time-multiplexing at a fixed 100 Hz rate.

Implement a color temperature slider: map an analog input to a blend between warm white and cool white channels while maintaining total luminous output at a constant 60%. Update at 200 Hz with smooth transitions.
Create a two-LED crossfade controlled by a state machine: fade A up while fading B down over 2 s, hold for 1 s, then reverse. Repeat in a bounded loop for exactly 20 cycles before both go to 20%.
Implement a rainbow wave across 8 RGB pixels using HSV rotation at 0.2 cycles per second. Constrain the loop to exactly 256 hue steps per cycle, and run updates at a fixed 50 Hz rate.

Create a motion-reactive accent light: on motion input true, fade to 70% over 300 ms and hold for 20 s; if no motion, fade to 10%. Manage transitions with a state machine and a rate attribute of 100 Hz.
Drive a trio of LEDs to indicate battery level: 0–30% one LED at 30%, 31–60% two LEDs at 30%, >60% three LEDs at 30%. Blink the highest active LED once every 5 s for 200 ms using a bounded loop.
Program a breathing RGB pattern that changes hue every 4 breaths. Use a bounded loop to count breaths and a state machine to handle inhale, exhale, and color shift phases. Run updates at 120 Hz.

Implement a soft-start driver for two channels: on enable, ramp both channels from 0% to their setpoints over 1 s; on disable, fade to 0% in 200 ms. Both channels must respect a maximum of 85% duty for thermal safety.

Create a metronome light: blink at a BPM provided by an input (40–200 BPM), with an accent every 4th beat as a brighter flash. Use a bounded loop to count beats within the bar and a fixed update rate of 200 Hz.
Build a color picker with two knobs: one sets hue (0–360 degrees) and the other sets brightness (0–100%). Convert to RGB with gamma correction and output via PWM at a constant carrier frequency.

Develop a sunrise alarm sequence with three phases in a state machine: dawn (warm increase 0–50% over 10 min), rise (cool blend to 100% over 10 min), and hold (100% for 20 min). Maintain a 50 Hz update rate and bounded loop timers.
Create a two-button interface for an RGB lamp: one button cycles patterns, the other adjusts brightness in 10% steps. Enforce bounds 10–90% and implement long-press to return to a neutral white mode.
Implement a theater chase on 12 LEDs: light every third LED and rotate the pattern at 10 steps per second. Use a bounded loop to wrap after 12 steps and enforce a fixed 100 Hz control loop.

Design an audio-reactive brightness where a normalized level input (0.0–1.0) modulates LED intensity with a smooth attack (50 ms) and release (200 ms). Cap brightness at 85% and maintain a 200 Hz update rate.

Create a dual-strip mirror effect: two identical LED strips show opposite-direction sweeps. Provide a state machine to select speed: slow, medium, fast. Each speed uses bounded loops to define step counts per cycle.

Program an ambient indicator with three states: idle glow at 10%, notification pulse to 60% three times, and alert strobe at 5 Hz with 20% duty. Transitions are triggered by separate inputs, and the state machine must ignore lower-priority events during alert.
Implement a color wipe across 16 pixels that fills one pixel every 100 ms, then wipes off at double speed. Use bounded loops to enforce exactly 16 steps per pass and run updates at 100 Hz.

Create a safety dimmer that reads an overtemperature input; if high, reduce all channels by 50% within 200 ms, otherwise allow normal brightness. Rate limit adjustments to 30% per second during recovery.

Implement a heartbeat that encodes device status: normal is a double-blink at 1 Hz total, warning is triple-blink at 0.5 Hz total. Use bounded loops to produce exact blink counts and a fixed 100 Hz rate.

Maintain a target illuminance of 300 lux using an ambient light sensor and a warm-white LED channel. Use a PID controller on PWM duty at 50 Hz, with anti-windup, output saturation 10–90%, and a failsafe that sets 20% if the sensor signal is invalid for more than 200 ms.

Fuse a motion sensor and ambient light sensor to decide brightness: if dark (<50 lux) and motion, set 70%; if bright (>300 lux) or no motion for 30 s, set 10%. Ensure hysteresis and a fixed 100 Hz update rate with bounded loops for timers.

Control two LED channels to maintain a target correlated color temperature by blending warm and cool outputs while holding total illuminance at 400 lux. Implement a dual-loop controller: inner PID for illuminance and outer loop for CCT ratio, both bounded and rate-limited.

Implement a constant-current safety layer: estimate LED current from a sense input and limit PWM such that current never exceeds a configured threshold. If exceeded for >100 ms, enter a fault state and blink red at 2 Hz. Run at 1 kHz control rate with WCET under 0.3 ms.

Create an adaptive brightness controller using PID to reach a user-set target brightness in percent, with a max slew of 25% per second and integral clamping. Enforce stable behavior with a fixed 100 Hz rate and document bounds.

Use sensor fusion from two photodiodes placed at different angles to reject glare and control an LED panel to 200 lux. Blend the readings with a weighted average and update a PID at 50 Hz. If the sensors disagree by more than 2x for 500 ms, fall back to 30% brightness and flag fault via a blink code.

Design a temperature-aware RGB lamp: above 60 C reduce overall brightness linearly to 50% by 80 C. Ensure that color ratios remain constant during throttling. Update at 100 Hz and never exceed 90% PWM duty.

Implement gamma-corrected fades between scenes for a 24-LED installation. Each scene transition lasts 3 s with perceptually uniform steps. Use bounded loops to cap per-update work and maintain WCET under 1 ms at 100 Hz.

Create a glare-avoidance controller that reduces brightness when a proximity sensor reports a viewer within 0.3 m, and restores over 2 s when they move beyond 1 m. Run at 100 Hz with debounced proximity and a safety floor of 5% brightness.

Control a color wall to track a target hue while keeping total brightness constant. Use a PID on hue error computed from an HSV model; clamp outputs 5–85%. Ensure fault handling sets neutral white at 30% if hue is undefined.

Build a multi-mode light sculpture with modes: idle shimmer, interaction burst, night dim, and fault. Specify a state machine with explicit entry/exit conditions, per-mode rates (idle 50 Hz, burst 200 Hz, night 25 Hz), and WCET budgets per mode not exceeding 0.8 ms. Include bounded loops to limit burst duration to 10 s.

Create a festival light controller with a scheduler for five scenes, each running for a programmed duration, and transitions of 1 s. Provide a test plan: verify each scene starts and ends on schedule, transitions meet timing within ±20 ms, and per-update WCET < 1 ms at 100 Hz.

Design an exhibition piece that supports day, evening, and performance modes with different color palettes and brightness caps. Include a state machine with guarded transitions, a seeded pseudo-random shimmer that is deterministic across runs, and timing tests for a 60 Hz loop.

Implement a fault-tolerant LED controller: on startup, run a self-test that blinks each channel in sequence using a bounded loop; if any channel fails to respond, lock into an amber fault pattern. During operation, enforce deterministic timing at 100 Hz with WCET < 0.5 ms.

Create a stage lighting program with three layered patterns that can be enabled independently: base wash, moving sparkle, and beat strobe. Define a supervisory state machine, per-layer rate attributes, priority rules to prevent overbright overlap, and an acceptance test suite that checks pattern period accuracy within 1% over 5 minutes.

Create a simple breathing effect for a single LED that slowly fades from 0% to 100% brightness and back to 0% in a 2 second cycle. Use a bounded loop of fixed steps for the fade curve and run the update at a fixed rate (e.g., 50 Hz). Ensure the PWM duty cycle never exceeds 90% as a safety limit.

When a pushbutton is held, set one LED to 75% brightness; when released, turn it off. Debounce the button and check input at 100 Hz. Keep the logic minimal and safe with explicit bounds on PWM values.

Blink a status LED with a pattern of three short flashes then a 1 second pause, repeating forever. Implement the pattern using a bounded loop over a timing table and a rate attribute for consistent timing.
Map a rotary knob position (0–100%) to LED brightness using PWM. Update at 50 Hz and clamp the output strictly between 5% and 85% to protect the LED.
Cycle an RGB LED through solid red, green, and blue, holding each color for 500 ms. Use a small finite state machine for the three colors and a bounded loop to count the holds at a 20 Hz rate.

Implement a candle flicker on one LED by stepping the PWM duty between 20% and 60% with pseudo-random changes at 100 Hz. Use a bounded loop to index a precomputed randomness table so it never runs unbounded.
Create a heartbeat indicator LED: two quick pulses then a 1.5 second rest. Use a rate-controlled timing sequence and a bounded loop of brightness steps for each pulse.

Button toggles the LED on/off. On state should be a smooth 500 ms fade up to 80% brightness; off state should be a smooth 500 ms fade down to 0%. Implement fades with a bounded loop of steps at 100 Hz.

Make a simple sunrise ramp: increase LED brightness linearly from 0% to 100% over 60 seconds, then hold. Use a rate attribute of 10 Hz and ensure the loop that performs the ramp has a fixed number of iterations.

Tap-tempo blinking: each time the user double-taps a button, set the LED blink period to the measured interval (200–1200 ms). Use a small state machine to capture taps and a bounded loop to blink at 60% brightness.
Drive two LEDs: one mirrors a switch (on at 70% brightness when pressed), the other provides a steady heartbeat at 1 Hz. Enforce a maximum update WCET of 0.5 ms at 100 Hz rate.
Use a precomputed 32-step gamma-corrected table to fade an LED up and down repeatedly. Iterate the table using a bounded loop at 50 Hz and ensure the sequence restarts cleanly at the end.
Implement a simple on-hours indicator: keep an LED at 30% from a boolean "night" input; otherwise off. Check the input at 5 Hz and never exceed 30% PWM as a safety constraint.
Create a two-stage blink: LED on 200 ms, off 200 ms, on 800 ms, off 800 ms, repeat. Use a bounded loop over a timing array and maintain timing with a 100 Hz rate attribute.
Fade an LED from 0% to 50% over 2 seconds, hold for 1 second, then fade back to 0% over 2 seconds. Repeat this pattern for exactly 10 cycles using a bounded loop, then stop.

Build a finite state machine controlling an RGB LED with modes: idle (off), color cycle (step through a 16-color palette), sparkle (brief random twinkles). Modes change with a button. Enforce a 50 Hz update rate and bounded loops for palette traversal and sparkle selection.
Implement a color wipe across 12 LEDs: one LED lights to 100% per 100 ms from index 0 to 11, then all off, repeat. Use a bounded loop over the indices and must not iterate beyond 12.
Make a rainbow cycle for an RGB strip that advances hue by a fixed step every 20 ms. Use a bounded loop to update exactly 24 pixels, and cap brightness at 70% for safety.

Create a motion-triggered scene: when a motion input goes true, run a 30-second color fade program, then return to idle off. Implement a state machine with idle, active, and cooldown states. Update at 25 Hz and ensure bounded loops for color steps.

Design a crossfade between two RGB colors over 3 seconds. On button press, crossfade to the next color in a palette of 8 entries, cycling back after the last. Use bounded loops for palette indexing and a 100 Hz rate for smoothness.

Adjust a single LED’s brightness from a light sensor: brighter in the day, dim at night. Use a simple proportional mapping clamped to 10–80% PWM, update at 10 Hz, and ensure input values are validated.

Control warm and cool white channels to achieve a desired correlated color temperature setting from a knob (expressed as 2700–6500 K). Maintain total brightness at 60% max and update at 20 Hz using bounded loops for mixing.

Create a holiday scheduler: during a defined time window each day, run a 10-minute color pattern sequence; otherwise keep lights at 10% warm white. Implement a time-based state machine and fixed-length playlists using bounded loops.

Add a safety dimmer: if a temperature sensor reads above 60 Celsius, immediately reduce all LEDs to 20% and flash an alert LED at 2 Hz until temperature drops below 55 Celsius. Ensure rate-controlled updates and bounded error handling.

Implement a 4-channel theater chase pattern where each channel turns on at 50% in sequence with 100 ms spacing, looping continuously. Use a bounded loop to step through channels and a 50 Hz update rate.
Two buttons adjust brightness up/down in 5% steps with long-press repeat at 5 Hz. Enforce bounds between 10% and 90%. Display the current level on an LED bar using a bounded loop over 10 segments.
On a trigger input, run a 5-second strobe at 10 Hz on an LED, then revert to a calm 30% constant. Use a small state machine and a bounded loop to count exactly 50 strobe flashes.
Create a gradient across 10 LEDs from 20% to 80% brightness, recomputed every 200 ms. Implement with a bounded loop over the 10 elements and clamp values to safe limits.

Implement a twinkle effect for 16 discrete LEDs: at any time, up to 3 randomly chosen LEDs ease up to 70% and back down. Use a bounded loop over 16 channels, deterministic pseudo-random indexing, and a 50 Hz update rate.

Provide soft-start and soft-stop behavior: when power-enable goes true, fade all LEDs to the last saved level over 1 second; when false, fade to 0% over 1 second. Use bounded loops for fade steps at 100 Hz.
Implement a dimmer curve that approximates a theatrical (gamma) response using a 32-entry lookup table. Update output at 100 Hz and traverse the table with a bounded loop.

Design a palette-driven pattern engine with 6 predefined color patterns. Select pattern by a rotary input with detents. Each pattern runs a bounded loop over a fixed number of steps at 25 Hz. Include a state machine for pattern selection and execution.

Add an ambient-reactive mode where average room light controls the overall brightness of a 12-LED art piece. Limit updates to 5 Hz, include hysteresis to avoid flicker, and ensure the bounded loop over 12 LEDs is time-safe.

Implement a step sequence: for 8 steps, set an RGB LED to a specified color and hold for a specified time (100–800 ms each), then repeat. Store the steps in a bounded array and iterate with a fixed-rate scheduler.

Build a dual-mode controller: Mode A is a slow color crossfade, Mode B is a white dimmer with button-controlled levels. Use a finite state machine for modes, bounded loops for fade steps, and enforce a 1 ms WCET at 100 Hz.
Make an audio-reactive brightness bar using an external level signal (0–100%). Update 12 LEDs at 25 Hz with peak-hold decay. Ensure a bounded loop across the 12 LEDs and clamp to 80% max brightness.

Create a color chase that reverses direction each time a tap input is detected. Keep the chase length to 10 LEDs, stepping every 100 ms. Use a bounded loop for rendering and a state machine for direction and idle states.

Implement a warm-up routine: at startup, run a 3-second self-test that steps through red, green, blue, and white on an RGB LED at 50% brightness, then enter normal idle. Use bounded loops and a clear state machine for startup vs. normal.
Drive a 24-LED ring with a rotating dot and a trailing fade. Advance the dot every 40 ms. Compute the trail with a bounded loop and enforce a maximum brightness per LED of 70%.

Maintain a target illuminance of 300 lux at a photosensor using a PID loop controlling LED PWM (10–80%). Run the control loop at 50 Hz with anti-windup and a watchdog. If the sensor signal is invalid, fall back to 20% and flash a fault LED at 1 Hz.

Fuse two ambient light sensors to estimate illuminance and drive auto-dimming for a panel of 16 LEDs. Use a complementary filter updated at 20 Hz, then apply the fused value with saturation limits. All arrays and loops must be bounded; include a safety dim if sensors disagree by >30%.

Implement RGB color correction using a 3x3 matrix applied to desired color values before PWM output. Update at 100 Hz and iterate through exactly 3 channels with a bounded loop. Clamp corrected outputs to 0–85% for thermal safety.

Create a pattern sequencer that runs at 200 Hz with a guaranteed WCET under 2 ms. Sequence includes: strobe, fade, chase, and idle. Use a state machine for modes and bounded loops for rendering up to 32 LEDs.

Design a music-reactive effect using an envelope input. Scale to a 20-LED bar with a peak indicator and a slow decay (200 ms). Use a bounded loop across all LEDs and ensure that brightness never exceeds 80%.

Implement thermal derating: reduce maximum allowed PWM linearly from 80% at 50 Celsius to 30% at 75 Celsius, and hard cutoff at 85 Celsius with an error blink. Run checks at 10 Hz. Apply limits to all channels via a bounded loop.

Limit total power across 12 LEDs by ensuring the sum of PWM duties does not exceed a budget equivalent to 500 mA average. If over budget, uniformly scale down within a bounded loop each update at 100 Hz. Include a brief warning flash when limiting is active.

Create a scrolling text-like effect on 16 LEDs by lighting segments according to a fixed font map. Advance one step every 80 ms. Use bounded loops for glyph lookup and rendering, and ensure safe bounds on all indices.

Handle timing jitter by computing pattern progression based on elapsed time rather than tick count, keeping movement speed constant at 0.5 positions per 100 ms. Apply to a 24-LED chase and use bounded loops for updates.

Build a multi-mode lighting controller with modes: Installation (static scenes), Performance (live crossfades), and Sleep (low-power 5% glow). Each mode is a state machine with its own rate (Installation 10 Hz, Performance 100 Hz, Sleep 1 Hz). Enforce WCET under 1 ms and include comprehensive self-test steps using bounded loops.

Develop a fault-tolerant lighting system that uses redundant temperature and light sensors with majority voting. On sensor disagreement, enter a degraded mode that limits all channels to 30% and logs a fault via a blinking code. Use a top-level state machine for Normal, Degraded, and Fault states, bounded loops for 32 LEDs, and guarantee update timing at 50 Hz with WCET < 2 ms.

Make a single LED turn on only while a pushbutton is held, and off otherwise. When on, drive 100% brightness via PWM. Sample the button at 100 Hz using a rate attribute and include simple debounce. Keep the logic minimal and deterministic.

Blink one LED at 2 Hz with a 50% duty cycle using PWM. Use a bounded loop to count on/off ticks and a rate attribute to run the timing task at 100 Hz. Ensure the pattern repeats forever without drift.

Create a gentle fade-in/fade-out (breathe) effect for one LED over 3 seconds up and 3 seconds down, using PWM steps no larger than 2% per 50 ms. Implement the steps with a bounded loop and execute at a fixed rate.
Map a knob to LED brightness: 0% at minimum, 100% at maximum. Update at 50 Hz via a rate attribute. Clamp and linearly scale the reading, then set PWM to match. No flicker allowed.

Flash a Morse SOS on a single LED using PWM at full brightness for dots and dashes. Implement the dot/dash pattern with a bounded loop and precise on/off durations in milliseconds. Repeat continuously.
Cycle an RGB LED through red, green, and blue, holding each color for exactly 1.5 seconds. Use a simple state machine with three states and a rate attribute to tick at 100 Hz. No overlapping colors.

Auto-dim a single LED based on ambient light in lux: below 50 lx set PWM to 80%, above 300 lx set to 20%, with linear interpolation in between. Update at 20 Hz and apply a bounded loop to smooth changes.
On receiving a toggle input, ramp the LED to a target brightness over 1 second using bounded steps. Enforce a maximum slew rate of 10% per 100 ms and run at a fixed rate to avoid jitter.

Implement a button-controlled LED state machine: OFF -> ON (50% PWM) on short press, and ON -> MAX (100% PWM) on long press (>700 ms). Use a rate attribute for sampling at 100 Hz and handle debouncing.

Drive an LED with PWM but guarantee duty never exceeds 90% for safety. Run the control task at 1 kHz with a rate attribute, and assert that the worst-case execution time per tick stays under 200 microseconds.
Produce a 1 Hz breathing LED using piecewise-linear PWM steps implemented via a bounded loop. Update brightness every 20 ms at a fixed rate. Keep the waveform symmetric and repeatable.

Create a sparkle effect: brief flashes (100 ms) at random intervals on a single LED, not more than 3 flashes per 10 seconds. Control randomness with a bounded loop and ensure timing via a rate attribute.
Make the LED respond to sound level: map microphone RMS amplitude to PWM brightness from 0% to 100%. Update at 100 Hz using a rate attribute and clamp to avoid abrupt jumps. Keep computation bounded.
On startup, run a warm-up sequence that ramps LED brightness from 0% to 100% in 20 bounded steps over 2 seconds, then switch to solid 60%. Ensure the warm-up runs exactly once.

Create a heartbeat pulse on one LED: quick double pulse every 2 seconds. Use PWM with two short rises (80 ms each) and decays, controlled by a bounded loop at 100 Hz, driven by a simple state machine.
Implement a moving chase on a strip: light one pixel at a time at 100% with a trailing pixel at 40%. Advance every 50 ms. Use a bounded loop over N pixels and a rate attribute to tick at 20 Hz.
Provide two modes for an RGB lamp: solid user-selected color and continuous rainbow. Use a state machine with a button to switch modes. Update at 60 Hz; bound the rainbow loop so it wraps cleanly.
Crossfade between two RGB colors over 5.0 seconds using linear interpolation per channel. Execute steps at 25 Hz via a rate attribute, using a bounded loop to compute and apply each PWM update.
Adjust LED brightness automatically with hysteresis: increase to 80% when ambient <40 lx, decrease to 30% when ambient >200 lx. Update at 10 Hz and implement hysteresis as a small state machine.

When motion is detected, run a 10-second sparkle pattern then return to idle dim (10%). Use a three-state machine (Idle, Active, Cooldown), a rate attribute at 50 Hz, and bounded loops for sparkle steps.
Drive an LED bar’s brightness from microphone energy while enforcing a cap at 70% PWM. Compute a moving average over 200 ms with a bounded loop and update the display at 40 Hz using a rate attribute.
Animate a 12-pixel ring like a clock: advance the lit pixel once per second. Use a bounded loop to clear/set pixels, a modulo counter, and a 1 Hz tick derived from a rate-controlled task.
Create a theater chase pattern with three repeating colors. Ensure each update completes under a 5 ms WCET. Use a bounded loop over pixels and schedule updates at 50 Hz with a rate attribute.

Modulate LED brightness based on tilt magnitude from an accelerometer (in m/s^2): more tilt, more brightness. Update at 100 Hz with a rate attribute; low-pass filter with a bounded loop to reduce jitter.
Blink two LEDs at different rates (1 Hz and 3 Hz) without interference. Assign separate rate attributes and use a bounded loop to handle their phase counters. Behavior must be deterministic.
Each time the light turns on, apply a soft-start ramp: limit PWM increase to 5% per 20 ms until the target is reached. Use a bounded loop for step increments and a fixed update rate to avoid flicker.
Monitor supply voltage and dim the LED as voltage drops: below 3.6 V linearly reduce brightness to 0% at 3.3 V. Update at 10 Hz and use a graceful fade implemented by a bounded loop.
Simulate a traffic light for an art piece with a pedestrian button. Use a state machine for Green (7 s), Yellow (2 s), Red (7 s), and a Walk phase (5 s). Time using a rate attribute at 20 Hz.
Control color temperature of a tunable white LED pair from a knob: map 2700 K (warm) to 6500 K (cool) while keeping overall brightness constant. Update at 25 Hz; implement mixing with a bounded loop.
Play back a palette-driven pattern across 8 predefined hues. Step through the palette with a bounded loop at 25 Hz and wrap around cleanly. Each hue holds for exactly 200 ms.
If temperature exceeds 60 C, flash the LED at 2 Hz and throttle brightness to 30% for safety. Restore normal brightness when below 55 C. Update at 10 Hz with a small state machine for fault handling.
Implement a random twinkle on a strip with at most 10 concurrent sparkles. Use a bounded loop to iterate pixels and a rate attribute at 60 Hz. Ensure no more than 10 sparkles are active at once.

Use three buttons to select among four LED patterns (solid, breathe, chase, rainbow). Implement a debounced menu state machine, update patterns at specified rates, and keep loops bounded for each effect.
Fade an LED in response to proximity: when a hand is closer than 0.2 m, ramp to 100% over 0.5 s; otherwise ramp to 10%. Update at 50 Hz and limit steps with a bounded loop to prevent abrupt changes.
Regulate perceived brightness to a target of 150 lx using PID control on PWM. Run the PID loop at 100 Hz via a rate attribute, include anti-windup, and cap PWM at 85% for safety.

Fuse accelerometer tilt and microphone level: tilt controls hue, sound amplitude controls brightness. Update at 60 Hz with a bounded loop that blends inputs (weighted average). Clamp PWM to avoid glare.
Apply gamma correction to RGB PWM using a small lookup table. Use a bounded loop to map linear brightness to corrected values each frame at 60 Hz. Keep memory usage fixed and predictable.
Run two concurrent timelines: a slow background breathe and a fast sparkle overlay. Schedule both with rate attributes (5 Hz and 50 Hz). Guarantee WCET per cycle under 2 ms and keep loops bounded.
Make a rainbow pattern whose speed adapts to ambient light: dim room slows the sweep to 0.1 cycles/s, bright room speeds to 1.0 cycles/s. Update at 30 Hz and use a bounded loop to step the hue.

Thermal compensation: adjust PWM down as temperature rises from 40 C to 70 C to maintain safe operation. If above 70 C, enter a fault state that blinks red at 1 Hz. Implement with a state machine and bounded loops.

Use several IR proximity sensors to shape a gradient across an LED strip, fusing their readings into position weights. Update the gradient at 50 Hz and ensure each frame’s loop over pixels is strictly bounded and under 5 ms.
Maintain a white point using an RGB color sensor: PID-balance the R, G, and B channels to target ratios. Prevent channel saturation and handle sensor fault with a safe fallback state. Run at 25 Hz.

Create a comet effect with a rolling trail of 64 intensity steps. Manage the trail with a bounded circular buffer and update at 100 Hz. Include a watchdog that detects overruns and reduces update rate if needed.

Detect beats in an audio stream (simple peak over threshold) and trigger a strobe flash at 100% PWM for 80 ms per beat. Limit strobe frequency to 5 Hz. Use rate-controlled sampling and bounded computations.

Design a multi-scene lighting controller with five modes: Calm, Dynamic, Reactive, Night-Safe, and Diagnostics. Use a state machine with timers and inputs (button, light, motion). Assign rate attributes per scene and keep WCET under 3 ms.

Implement comprehensive safety: monitor temperature, battery voltage, and a simulated overcurrent flag. On any fault, gracefully dim to 10% then shut down LEDs. Provide a bounded self-test pattern at startup and a recovery path when conditions normalize.

Control an LED art wall up to 200 pixels with configurable palettes and patterns. Accept configuration commands to change palettes between frames. Guarantee a 60 Hz update rate with bounded per-frame loops and explicit WCET limits.

Select ambiance by fusing three sensors: lux, proximity, and temperature. Use a PID loop to hold brightness at a target lux, and a state machine to choose color themes. Ensure the temperature rise never exceeds 40 C and keep loops bounded.

Prioritize safety indicators over decorative patterns: when a fault is active, override to a high-visibility blink while maintaining a 10 Hz heartbeat LED. Enforce WCET budgets per task and keep all iteration loops bounded.

Provide three operational modes—Demo, Calibration, and Maintenance—with comprehensive built-in tests. Include rate conformance checks, state transition coverage logging, and bounded-loop verifications. All updates must remain deterministic.
Create a single LED breathing effect using PWM: ramp duty 0% to 100% then back to 0% over a 4 s cycle. Use a bounded loop for the ramp steps and run the update at a fixed 100 Hz rate.
Turn on an LED at 75% PWM brightness only while a pushbutton is held; when released, turn it off. Debounce the input and keep the control loop running at 50 Hz.
Cycle one RGB LED through pure red, green, and blue, holding each color for 1 s and using bounded loops to ramp between colors smoothly at a 50 Hz update rate.
Read a knob and map its 0–100% position to LED PWM brightness linearly. Clamp output strictly to 0–100% and refresh at 20 Hz.
Implement a simple night light: hold 20% brightness steady; when a switch turns it off, fade to 0% over 10 s with bounded steps.
Generate a strobe: produce exactly 5 flashes at 10 Hz at 100% brightness, then pause for 2 s, and repeat. Use a bounded loop for the 5-pulse burst and a stable 100 Hz timebase.
Every 500 ms, choose a brightness from the set {10%, 30%, 60%, 90%} and apply it to a single LED via PWM. Ensure the selection loop is bounded and time-deterministic.
Drive one LED with PWM but cap brightness at 80% to keep average current under 15 mA. Any command to exceed the cap should be clamped. Update at 100 Hz.
On startup, soft-start an LED to 60% brightness by ramping over 1 s in bounded steps, then hold steady.
When a rising edge is detected on a digital input, emit a single 200 ms light pulse at 100% brightness, then return to off. Guarantee WCET per cycle below 1 ms.
Define a two-state machine for a single LED: Idle (off) and Glow (breathing). Toggle states with a button press. Use bounded loops for fades and keep updates at 100 Hz.
Create a 1-second heartbeat: a short 80 ms burst at 100% followed by a low 10% glow for the remainder, repeating continuously with precise timing.
Implement a color temperature slider for an RGB LED: map an input range of 2700 K to 6500 K into warm/cool channel PWM values, updating at 20 Hz.
Dim the LED gradually to 0% if no button activity occurs for 30 s; reset the timer on any press. Use bounded fade steps.
Generate a triangle-wave PWM on a single LED: duty smoothly increases from 0% to 100% and back to 0% over 2 s. Run the controller at 200 Hz and bound the number of steps.
Create a chase on a 12-LED strip: one bright LED moves forward, then reverse back. Use bounded loops over LEDs and keep the animation tick at 60 Hz.

RGB lamp with three modes (Static, Breathe, Off) implemented as a state machine. Short-press cycles modes; long-press lets the user pick a color. Debounce inputs and ensure no unbounded loops; run at 100 Hz.
Use an ambient light sensor to auto-dim an LED strip inversely to ambient lux: brighter room -> dimmer LEDs, with output clamped between 10% and 90%. Update at 10 Hz and add 5-lux hysteresis.
Pattern selector via rotary encoder: choose among 4 bounded-loop patterns (solid, blink, chase, rainbow). Ensure pattern rendering runs at a fixed 50 Hz regardless of input events.

Two-zone lighting (front and back): both fade in a sinusoidal pattern but 180 degrees out of phase. Provide a state machine with On, Sleep (10% brightness), and Off, with a 2-minute idle timeout into Sleep. Update at 60 Hz.
Sound-reactive brightness: compute RMS microphone level over a bounded 100 ms window and map it to PWM brightness, capped at 70%. Run sensing at 200 Hz and rendering at 60 Hz.
Render a rainbow gradient on a 30-LED strip and move it by one pixel every 50 ms. Iterate LEDs with a bounded loop and guarantee WCET under 3 ms per frame.
Theater chase: 3 LEDs on, 3 off, repeating along the strip. Change the color every 5 s. Implement using bounded loops and a 100 Hz control rate.
Implement a 3 s crossfade between two preset colors when a button is pressed. Use a bounded number of ramp steps and avoid blocking other tasks.
Motion-triggered warm glow: when motion is detected, fade to 3000 K at 40% brightness and hold for 15 s, then fade out if no further motion. Rate 50 Hz.
Apply gamma correction to brightness using a bounded lookup table (e.g., 16 entries). Map input 0–100% to corrected PWM duty.

Comet effect on a 60-LED ring: a bright head with 5 trailing LEDs decaying exponentially. Use bounded loops over the ring, wrap around, update at 40 Hz, and scale global brightness to keep total current under 200 mA.
Sunrise routine: over 15 minutes, ramp brightness from 0% to 100% while shifting color temperature from 2000 K to 6500 K. Use bounded step increments and allow cancel via a button.
Three-button RGB mixer: increase or decrease each color channel in 5% steps per press, bounded between 0% and 100%. Long-press repeats at 10 Hz. Apply changes immediately.
Alternate flashing between two LED groups at 1 Hz, each at 70% brightness. Align toggles to a 1 ms timebase for consistent phase.
Breathing effect with asymmetric timing: inhale 1.2 s, exhale 1.8 s. Implement with bounded steps and ensure the visible modulation frequency stays above 120 Hz to avoid flicker.
Day/night mode using a light sensor threshold of 50 lux with 5 lux hysteresis. In night mode, cap brightness at 30%. Implement as a state machine running at 20 Hz.
Color wipe forward across the strip, pause 500 ms, then wipe backward. Use bounded loops and precise timing, and allow pausing/resuming via a toggle input.

Sequence three scenes with exact durations: A) 10 s solid blue, B) 5 s magenta pulsing at 2 Hz, C) 8 s warm white at 40%. Repeat continuously; ensure total cycle timing stays within 23 s while rendering at 50 Hz.

Sparkle on touch: a capacitive touch input triggers up to 10 simultaneous white sparkles at random positions for 300 ms each. Keep the number of active sparkles bounded and ensure the sum of PWM duties across the strip stays <= 300%.

Closed-loop brightness control: use a light sensor to maintain 200 lux on a surface using PWM of an LED strip. Implement a PID controller tuned for 20 Hz update, clamp output 0–100%, avoid integral windup, and provide a safety fallback to 20% if the sensor fails.

Thermal management: regulate LED heat sink temperature to 55 C using PWM duty with a PID loop running at 10 Hz. Read temperature in Celsius, limit ramp to 10% per second, and enforce a hard safety where temperature > 70 C forces Off and latches until reset.

Sensor fusion for motion-driven color: combine accelerometer and gyroscope to estimate orientation via a complementary or Kalman approach, then map pitch to hue (0–360°) and roll to brightness (20–100%). Update at 100 Hz with fixed-size buffers and bounded loops.

Power budgeting: measure supply current in mA and dynamically scale global brightness to keep the average below 500 mA over any 1 s window. Use a bounded moving average, update at 200 Hz, and include a safety cap at 90% brightness.

Noise-robust sound reactive color: estimate beat energy from a bounded 256-sample window at 1 kHz, map beat strength to saturation and brightness, and ensure compute WCET < 2 ms. Render updates at 60 Hz.

Multi-zone wall wash with auto white balance: track a target color temperature in Kelvin from a sensor and blend RGB accordingly. Apply PID control on CCT error at 5 Hz, limit dBrightness/dt to avoid flicker, and fail-safe to neutral white if the sensor is invalid.

Rolling rainbow on 100 LEDs: advance hue by 1 step per tick. Iterate a bounded loop over 100 elements, guarantee a 120 Hz frame rate with jitter under 2 ms, and use a precomputed sine lookup for smooth transitions.

Adaptive flicker avoidance: ensure that no PWM frequency or visible pattern produces modulation in the 3–70 Hz range. Shape brightness ramps with bounded steps so effective modulation remains above 200 Hz.

Calibrated brightness: run a brief test pattern to measure per-channel gains and build a bounded correction table. Apply corrections in real time at 100 Hz and ensure corrected PWM duty never exceeds 100%.

Implement a small, bounded scene scripting engine (up to 64 commands: fade, hold, color) that executes deterministically for light shows. Limit loops to fixed counts and guarantee WCET per tick under 1.5 ms at a 60 Hz update rate.

Design a multi-mode lighting controller with modes: Show, Idle, Safe, and Test. Build a state machine with deterministic transitions (e.g., overheating or sensor fault enters Safe). Each mode runs specific bounded-loop patterns at set rates (Show: 60 Hz animations, Idle: 10% warm glow at 20 Hz, Safe: solid red 20%), and Test runs a self-check sequence. Specify WCET per task < 2 ms and document timing budgets.

Create a stage light system with three scenes (Intro, Main, Finale) and a Maintenance mode. Include a scheduler that guarantees 100 Hz updates and logs any missed deadlines. Add built-in tests: verify RGB PWM ranges, run a pixel-walk, confirm sensor inputs, and ensure all loops are bounded to declared limits. Enforce safety: current limit 1 A and over-temp shutdown at 65 C.

Implement a festival installation controller with day/night automatic mode, manual override, and emergency Off using a hierarchical state machine. Constrain memory for pattern buffers, bound loops over up to 300 LEDs, require a deterministic startup self-test, provide timing conformance reports (frame time, jitter), and a recovery path after sensor failure. Keep PWM updates at 120 Hz with WCET per cycle <= 2 ms.

Develop a wearable LED art controller with Performance, Power-Save, and Diagnostic modes. Set rate attributes for sensing at 50 Hz and rendering at 90 Hz. Use bounded sensor fusion of accelerometer and gyro for effects. Require unit-testable pattern functions, coverage of all state transitions, and safety limits: surface temperature 45 C max and brightness 80% max.

Build an architectural light controller that sequences weekly schedules, live triggers, and a safety curfew. Implement a robust state machine with explicit time-of-day transitions and a SafeShutdown state. Constrain all loops to fixed upper bounds for up to 8 zones, guarantee WCET 3 ms at 60 Hz, include a test harness that runs deterministic pattern demos and verifies current never exceeds 2 A.
Make a single indicator LED turn on while a button is held and off otherwise. Drive it with PWM at a fixed 80% duty when on. Run at a steady 100 Hz update rate.
Create a smooth breathing effect on one LED using PWM. The brightness should ramp up and down over a 4 s cycle using a bounded loop of steps. Never exceed 90% duty.
Blink an LED at 2 Hz with a 25% duty cycle, and let a knob set overall brightness. Clamp PWM between 0% and 100% and update at 1 kHz.
Cycle a single RGB LED through red, green, and blue, 500 ms per color, repeating via a bounded loop over the color list.
Toggle a status LED on each button press using a debounced state machine with Pressed and Released states. Use PWM to apply the current brightness preset.
Use an ambient light reading to inversely control LED brightness with PWM: darker room, brighter LED. Sample at 20 Hz, limit brightness slew per update, and cap duty at 85%.
Implement a staircase fade: step brightness from 0% to 100% and back to 0% in equal increments using bounded for-loops. Step every 10 ms via PWM.
Create a simple night light that turns on at 20:00 and off at 06:00 with a steady low PWM brightness. Check time at a 1 Hz rate and ensure deterministic switching.
Make a strobe sequence that emits exactly 10 quick flashes and then returns to idle. Use a bounded loop for the 10 flashes, PWM for intensity, and keep WCET under 0.5 ms per update.
Rotate hue on a single RGB LED like a color wheel with smooth PWM transitions. Update at 100 Hz and keep channel values within 0–255 with optional gamma shaping.
Alternate two LEDs every 300 ms. Execute exactly 20 alternations using a bounded counter, then stop with both off. Use PWM to set a fixed brightness.
On power-up, fade in an LED from 0% to a target brightness over 3 s using PWM, then hold steady. Run the fade as a bounded step loop at a 200 Hz update rate.
Use a button to cycle through four brightness presets (10%, 30%, 60%, 100%) on a single LED. Implement a finite state machine for preset selection with wrap-around and a long-press to reset to 10%.
Add a safety feature: if supply voltage drops below a threshold, immediately turn LEDs off and blink a low-power warning at 1 Hz. Sample voltage at 10 Hz and use PWM for the blink.
Create a theater chase with one bright pixel moving across 10 positions and repeating. Implement the pattern using a bounded loop over the positions with 50 ms steps via PWM.

Build an RGB mood light with three patterns selectable via two buttons: Solid, Breathe, and Rainbow. Use a debounced state machine for pattern selection, update at 100 Hz, and use a bounded loop for rainbow steps.
Drive 8 LEDs with synchronized PWM fades where each adjacent pair is 90 degrees out of phase. Iterate channels via a bounded loop and ensure no channel exceeds 85% duty.
Simulate a traffic signal with Red 10 s, Amber 3 s, Green 10 s, plus a pedestrian request button. Implement as a state machine with deterministic timing at 50 Hz and WCET under 2 ms.
Create a metronome light: flash at a BPM set by a rotary input (40–200 BPM). Update at 200 Hz. Long-press enables an accent on every 4th beat using a bounded loop over the 4-beat cycle.
Control color temperature for a warm and cool white LED pair. Map a slider from 2700 K to 6500 K, blend channels with PWM, clamp total power, and limit ramp rate. Update at 100 Hz.
Emulate candle flicker using a pseudo-random but bounded brightness sequence. Update PWM every 30 ms and maintain an average duty between 30% and 40%.
Create a schedule-driven wall wash with distinct weekday and weekend color themes. Use a state machine to change themes at local midnight and blend over 5 s using a bounded step loop.

Design an LED alarm that simulates sunrise: increase brightness gradually for 20 minutes before the set time. Use a bounded loop of 1200 steps, a cancel button, timekeeping at 10 Hz, and PWM updates at 100 Hz.

Make a reactive light where microphone amplitude controls color saturation. Sample audio at 1 kHz, update LEDs at 100 Hz, process the latest 100 ms via a bounded buffer loop, and cap brightness at 70%.

Implement motion-triggered hallway lights: on PIR activation, light segments progressively over 2 s, then fade. Use a state machine (Idle, Triggered, Decay), run at 50 Hz, and extend Decay on retrigger.
Create a dual-zone lamp where one knob sets brightness and another sets hue. Apply gamma-corrected PWM and update a bounded list of 12 LEDs without flicker.
Add battery safety: if voltage < 3.4 V or temperature > 60 C, dim to 20% and blink red as an alert. Sample sensors at 10 Hz and run PWM at 500 Hz.
Program bike light modes: Steady, Slow Blink, Fast Blink, and SOS. Use a button-driven state machine, enforce 100% brightness only in Steady, and implement SOS with bounded loops.
Control step lighting with zone occupancy: when entering, progressively light the next 5 steps via a bounded loop and PWM. Fade out after 30 s idle. Update at 25 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Drive an RGBW strip with white balance support: when the user sets RGB, add white to maintain target luminance while respecting a current limit. Update at 200 Hz and iterate per pixel via a bounded loop.
Build a sunrise/sunset controller using a light sensor to decide day vs night with hysteresis. Ramp transitions over 60 s with bounded steps and update logic at 20 Hz.
Implement a party sequencer: run up to 16 stored patterns with durations. Iterate through the list via a bounded loop, support pause/resume, and ensure no missed transitions at a 100 Hz update rate.
Show speed as a bargraph: map 0–10 m/s to 0–10 LED segments. Update at 20 Hz, blink the top segment if speed exceeds 9 m/s, and use a bounded loop to set segment states.
Create a failsafe dimmer: if a control signal is stale for more than 200 ms, enter Safe state with 10% brightness and flash amber every 2 s. Implement Normal and Safe as a state machine at 100 Hz.
Change color on beat: accept an external tick and switch color every 8 beats using a bounded counter. If ticks stop, fall back to 120 BPM. Monitor ticks at 1 kHz.

Maintain 200 lux at a sensor using PWM brightness control with a PID loop. Update at 200 Hz with anti-windup and clamped output. Detect sensor failure and fall back to a safe fixed brightness. Keep WCET under 0.5 ms.

Thermal management for a high-power LED: if temperature exceeds 55 C, reduce brightness using a PI controller to restore safe thermal conditions. Sample at 10 Hz, smooth transitions, and hard-off above 80 C.

Orientation-reactive sculpture: fuse accelerometer and gyroscope with a complementary filter to estimate tilt and map tilt to hue. Update at 100 Hz, process buffers via bounded loops, and avoid blocking operations.

Audio visualizer: process 256-sample frames at 8 kHz in a bounded loop to derive energy bands and drive colors and PWM brightness. Output updates at 100 Hz and limit average power to a configured cap.

Network-synchronized color cycle: phase-lock the cycle to an external PPS signal using a PID that adjusts the internal rate. Use a state machine for Acquire, Locked, and Lost states, and keep WCET < 0.2 ms.

Emulate runway edge lights with deterministic sequencing and redundancy. Maintain a heartbeat; on loss, enter a steady amber at 40% PWM. Update at 200 Hz and iterate a bounded list of 50 lights with max duty 80%.

Closed-loop color constancy: read a color sensor and adjust RGBW PWM to match a target CIE xy. Use a bounded iterative correction (max 20 iterations) or stop when within tolerance. Update at 20 Hz without visible flicker.
Implement temporal dithering to achieve 12-bit effective brightness from 8-bit PWM. Keep the primary PWM above 400 Hz, use a bounded frame length of 16, and ensure WCET under 0.3 ms per frame update.

Add protection: monitor current (A) and temperature (C). If current > 1.5 A or temperature > 65 C, use PID to reduce PWM and meet limits; hard cutoff above 2 A or 80 C. Sample at 100 Hz and log state changes.
Use two ambient sensors plus a reference for brightness control with median voting. Run bounded loops for filtering, drive PWM to a setpoint, and enter degraded mode if disagreement exceeds 15%.

Stage lighting controller with modes Rehearsal, Performance, and Blackout. Implement a hierarchical state machine, run updates at 200 Hz with WCET <= 0.5 ms, perform startup self-test, include a deterministic test mode, and assert that total channel power never exceeds the configured limit.

Public art installation with Day, Evening, Night, and Maintenance modes. Schedule transitions, log all mode changes, feed a watchdog, enforce the property that duty never exceeds 85% for more than 5 s, and provide a 24-hour simulation test with bounded iterations.

Emergency signage lighting with Normal, Evacuation, and Test modes. Guarantee a 1–2 Hz blink in Evacuation, WCET 0.2 ms at a 500 Hz update rate, and comprehensive unit tests for state transitions and safety interlocks.

Interactive exhibit using motion, ambient, and touch sensors to drive an LED array. Provide Idle, Engage, and Sleep modes with sensor fusion to decide transitions, track deadline misses at fixed rates, restrict bounded loops to 64 LEDs, and define a safe fallback on sensor failure.

Architectural facade controller with seasonal playlists and live override. Implement prioritized modes with preemption and rollback, a deterministic scheduler with rate attributes, WCET analysis per task, logging, fault injection tests (sensor stuck, clock drift), and bounded per-segment update loops.
Blink a single status LED at 2 Hz with a 50% duty cycle. Drive it via PWM and schedule updates using a rate attribute so timing stays stable.
Turn one LED on when a pushbutton is pressed and off when released, with simple debounce and no unbounded loops. Keep PWM at a fixed 100% when on.
Create a continuous fade: ramp brightness from 0% to 100% over 2 s, then back to 0% over 2 s, repeating. Use a bounded loop for the steps and run the update at 100 Hz.
Cycle a single RGB LED through red, green, and blue, holding each color for 1 s before switching. Use PWM channels and a bounded loop over the three colors.
On a rising edge input, flash a white LED at 80% brightness for exactly 200 ms, then return to off. Drive timing via a rate-controlled task.
Implement a breathing effect between 10% and 60% brightness with a 5 s period. Ensure the PWM never exceeds 60%.
Make a heartbeat pattern: two 100 ms blinks separated by 200 ms, then a 1 s pause. Use the rate attribute to keep the pattern accurate.
Build a nightlight that starts at 40% brightness and linearly dims to 0% over 10 minutes, then stays off. Implement the ramp with a bounded loop.
Alternate two LEDs at 5 Hz with no overlap so exactly one is on at any time. Keep the update loop at 100 Hz.
Provide three fixed brightness levels on a single LED (20%, 50%, 90%) and advance to the next level on each button tap using a simple three-state machine.
On power-up, blink an LED three times (150 ms on, 150 ms off) and then leave it off. Ensure the sequence uses a bounded count of three flashes.
Set the color of an RGB LED from three numeric inputs representing 0–100% channel levels. Clamp values to the valid range and update at 50 Hz.
Map a single analog input to LED brightness linearly, updating at 50 Hz. Constrain the output between 10% and 90%.
When an ambient light sensor falls below a threshold, turn a white LED on at 30%; otherwise, keep it off. Sample at 10 Hz with hysteresis to avoid flicker.
After power-on delay of 2 s, turn an LED fully on and keep it on. Ensure the wait uses non-blocking timing driven by a rate attribute.
Make an RGB hue wheel: smoothly rotate through the color spectrum over 30 s with gamma-aware PWM. Use a bounded loop for discrete steps and update at 100 Hz.
Design a simple traffic-light-style art cycle using a state machine: Red for 3 s, Green for 3 s, Blue for 3 s, with a 500 ms all-off between each.
Drive LED brightness from microphone amplitude. Smooth the signal and update at 200 Hz, capping the PWM at 80% to reduce glare.
Create a motion-activated light with a state machine: Idle, FadingIn over 2 s to 60% on motion, Hold for 10 s, then FadingOut over 2 s if no motion.
Implement a strobe whose frequency is set by an analog input from 1 Hz to 20 Hz, with a fixed 10% duty cycle. Enforce bounds and schedule via a rate attribute.
Show battery status with LEDs: below 3.3 V blink red at 1 Hz, otherwise solid green. Include 0.1 V hysteresis and update at 50 Hz.
Create a random sparkle on a 16-LED strip where at most 5 LEDs twinkle at any time, each twinkle lasting 500 ms. Use bounded loops over LED indices and run at 60 Hz.
Build a Knight Rider scanner across 8 LEDs with soft PWM tails. Sweep end to end in 1 s and reverse smoothly with no pauses.
Color picker: three sliders drive RGB channels in real time, with clamping to 0–100%. Add a long-press button to toggle a demo mode that auto-cycles colors. Use a state machine.
Program a sunrise simulation that ramps warm white from 0% to 100% over 30 minutes and then holds. Allow cancel via a button and handle cancel with a clear state transition.
Two-button interface: one button toggles on/off with a smooth 300 ms fade, the other cycles through three color presets. Preserve the current selection across toggles.
Mirror a chase pattern across two LED groups A and B with a 500 ms phase offset. Iterate positions with a bounded loop and update at 50 Hz.
Emergency blink sequence: when a fault input is high, emit exactly 4 quick red flashes (100 ms on, 100 ms off), then pause 1 s, repeating the burst. Ensure the burst count is bounded.
Footswitch fade: on press, ramp brightness to 70% over 1 s; on release, ramp to 0% over 300 ms. Debounce the input and update at 200 Hz.
Night mode: when a time-of-day input indicates 22:00–06:00, cap brightness at 15%; otherwise allow full control from a knob. Change limits immediately on boundary crossings.
Shift color temperature based on ambient light level: in bright conditions bias toward cool white; in dim conditions bias toward warm white. Update at 2 Hz with hysteresis.
Execute an 8-step scene list where each step has a color and duration. Use a bounded loop to walk the steps, maintain precise timing, and support pause and resume.
Tri-color beacon using a state machine: Red for 1 s, Yellow for 1 s, Green for 1 s, unless an override input selects steady red that takes immediate precedence.
Run synchronized breathing on two LED groups at 0.2 Hz, but with different amplitude ranges. Ensure both patterns share the same phase reference.
Use an ambient light sensor to set LED brightness from 0 to 1000 lx mapped to 10–90% output with 0.5 s slew limiting. Update at 20 Hz.

Implement closed-loop brightness control using PID to reach a target illuminance in lux measured by a light sensor. Run the loop at 200 Hz, use anti-windup, and cap PWM at 85%. If the sensor is missing, fall back to 20% brightness.

Perform sensor fusion of two light sensors (front and side) to estimate ambient lux, rejecting outliers and applying hysteresis. Use the fused estimate to regulate LED brightness to 200 lx at the surface, updating at 50 Hz and keeping changes smooth.
Maintain a constant perceived color by adjusting RGB PWM based on LED temperature in degrees Celsius. Derate total brightness above 60 C and hard-cut off at 80 C to protect hardware.

Produce a flicker-free breathing light: keep effective PWM at or above 500 Hz while modulating brightness at 0.1 Hz. Use the rate attribute to guarantee timing and ensure per-tick work meets a WCET under 500 microseconds.

Drive a color chase whose speed depends on motion sensed by an IMU. Fuse accelerometer and gyroscope with a complementary filter, update at 100 Hz, and limit the acceleration of brightness changes to avoid glare.

Regulate LED current to 15 mA using a PID controller with feedback from a current sensor. Enforce an immediate shutdown if measured current exceeds 18 mA, and implement a soft-start on enable. Run at 1 kHz.
Apply gamma correction to RGB channels using a bounded lookup and ensure the total power stays under 1.5 W by scaling outputs. Update at 120 Hz and keep the control loop WCET below 1 ms.

Design an adaptive strobe that avoids photosensitive epilepsy risk: do not emit repetitive flashes in the 3–60 Hz range for more than 20 s. Track exposure time and switch to a continuous fade mode when the limit is reached. Use a clear state machine.

Adapt brightness and color temperature using sensor fusion of ambient light and proximity: reduce brightness more aggressively when people are close. Update at 10 Hz, and fail safe to 20% brightness if fusion inputs are invalid.

Maintain constant chroma with variable luminance by closing the loop on a color sensor. Use PID at 100 Hz to hold hue while adjusting brightness; if the sensor saturates or times out, freeze output and signal a fault LED.

Build a multi-mode installation with modes Idle, Attract, Interactive, and Safety. Define an explicit state machine, run at 100 Hz with a WCET of 0.5 ms per tick, and include a startup self-test that blinks each channel once using bounded loops. On temperatures above 70 C, enter Safety and limit brightness to 10%.

Create a stage lighting controller with two modes: Manual, where sliders set RGBW levels, and Show, which plays a timed scene list. Use bounded loops for scene traversal, enforce a deterministic 200 Hz update rate, cap duty at 90%, and limit total power to 2 W. Include tests that verify scene transitions and clamping.

Control an LED matrix with a library of patterns such as plasma, rain, and sparkle. Schedule patterns over a 5-minute cycle, supervise with a top-level state machine (ModeSelect, RunPattern, Error), blink a watchdog LED at 2 Hz, and assert that all pattern loops are bounded and WCET stays under 2 ms.

Implement an emergency egress lighting controller with modes Normal, Dim, and Evac Blink. Inputs are ambient light, battery level, and an alarm. On battery below 20% switch to Dim, on alarm switch to Evac Blink at 1.5 Hz with 30% duty. Run at 50 Hz and include tests for all state transitions and overtemperature shutdown above 65 C.

Design a museum lighting controller with two top-level modes. Lux mode uses PID to maintain 300 lx at the artwork; Art mode plays a 12-scene color show. Supervise with a state machine that soft-starts outputs, monitors temperature and current, and forces a Safe mode on any sensor timeout. Use bounded loops for scene steps, update deterministically at 100 Hz, require a 60 s transition test sequence, and keep WCET under 1 ms.
Blink one LED at 2 Hz with exactly 50% duty cycle. Use a rate attribute to run the task at 100 Hz and a bounded loop to count and stop after 10 blinks. On completion, leave the LED off.

Create a smooth PWM fade-up then fade-down on a single LED from 0% to 100% and back in 2 seconds total. Constrain updates to a fixed 200 Hz rate. Repeat the fade exactly 5 times using a bounded loop, then hold at 0%.
When a pushbutton is pressed, turn a single indicator LED on; otherwise keep it off. Include 50 ms debounce logic and a 100 Hz control rate. If the input is noisy, fail safe to off.

Cycle a single RGB LED through red, green, and blue, each color held for 1.0 s. Use a bounded loop to repeat the 3-color pattern exactly 4 times, then stop on black. Maintain timing accuracy within ±5 ms.
Implement a gentle 'breathing' effect on one LED by linearly ramping PWM brightness between 10% and 90% over a 3 s period. Update at a fixed 250 Hz rate. Ensure no value exceeds 90%.
Produce a strobe on one LED at 10 Hz with maximum 20% on-time per cycle. If the scheduling rate slips or an overrun occurs, immediately force the LED off for safety.
Flash the SOS Morse pattern exactly once on a single LED using precise on/off durations in milliseconds. Use a bounded loop for the dot/dash sequence and a 100 Hz timing base, then turn off.
On enable, ramp one LED from 0% to 60% over 3 s, then hold at 60%. Use PWM and a fixed 500 Hz update rate. Ignore subsequent enables until the ramp completes.
Every 10 s, perform a quick triple-blink pattern on a single LED (3 blinks at 8 Hz) then return to off. Use bounded loops for the three blinks and keep the main loop at 50 Hz.
On startup, run a 2 s rainbow fade across a single RGB LED, then set steady white at 30% brightness. Use a fixed 100 Hz update rate and a bounded loop for the fade steps.
Each time a button is tapped, toggle a single LED between 10% and 90% brightness with a 200 ms soft transition. Debounce at 30 ms and run the control at 100 Hz.
Blink a single LED exactly 7 times with 100 ms on and 400 ms off periods, using a bounded loop. After the sequence, leave the LED off. Maintain a fixed 1 kHz timing tick.
Generate a sawtooth brightness pattern on a single LED: step PWM from 0% to 100% in 5% increments every 50 ms, then wrap to 0%. Repeat exactly 3 cycles using a bounded loop at 100 Hz.
After power-up, keep one LED at 50% for 60 s, then fade to 0% over 2 s and stay off. Use a deterministic 100 Hz control rate and ensure no task exceeds 1 ms WCET.
Implement a soft-start: when an enable input goes high, fade a single LED from 0% to 40% over 1 s; when it goes low, fade to 0% over 0.5 s. Run at 200 Hz and require monotonic brightness changes.

Drive a 16-pixel RGB light bar with a 'color wipe' pattern across the strip at 20 pixels per second. Use bounded loops for index iteration, a 100 Hz update rate, and a knob input to set brightness 0–100%.

Build a state machine with modes: idle (off), pulse (breathing), and solid. Two buttons select the mode; a third button toggles pause. Enforce debouncing and use rate(100 Hz). Ensure transitions are only on rising edges.

Create a theater-chase pattern on a 24-LED array with 3-phase moving spots. Implement bounded loops for phases and indices. Allow speed selection via a potentiometer (0.5–10 Hz). Cap brightness at 70%.

Use an ambient light sensor to adjust an RGB lamp’s brightness inversely to measured illuminance in lux. Update at 50 Hz. If the sensor reads out of 0–2000 lx, hold last valid value and indicate error by a brief red blink.

Implement a two-zone lighting scene: left and right groups of LEDs. When motion is detected, fade the nearest zone up to 80% over 0.8 s; after 15 s of no motion, fade both down to 0%. Use bounded loops over each group and a 100 Hz rate.
Make a rotating rainbow on a ring of 12 RGB LEDs at 30 degrees per second. Use a bounded loop for pixel updates and a second bounded loop for hue steps. Provide a global brightness slider input.

Design a state machine for a wearable: states are 'charging' (amber pulsing), 'ready' (green solid), and 'low' (red blinking at 2 Hz). Input is a battery percent value. Update at 50 Hz; ensure correct entry/exit actions.
Create a dual-button dimmer for a white LED strip. One button steps brightness up by 10%, the other steps down, with a 300 ms repeat when held. Enforce 10%–90% limits and a 100 Hz control rate.

Implement a 'sparkle' effect where at most 3 random LEDs out of 32 briefly flash to 80% for 100 ms. Use a bounded loop for selection and duration tracking. Keep the update at 200 Hz and avoid overlapping on the same index.

Sequence three scenes—warm white, cool white, then rainbow—each for a programmable duration in seconds. Use bounded loops to count seconds at rate(50 Hz). Provide a cancel input to abort and turn off.

Build a traffic-light style controller for three LEDs (red, amber, green) with configurable durations. Use a clear state machine and bounded loops for countdowns. Rate is 20 Hz; guarantee transitions are deterministic.

Add an audio-reactive brightness gate: when a microphone level exceeds a threshold, start a 500 ms white flash on all LEDs, then return to the previous pattern. Debounce triggers and cap duty to 50% averaged over 10 s.
Create a progress bar across 10 LEDs that fills to match a 0–100% input value, updating at 60 Hz. Use bounded loops for the segment fill and smooth PWM for partial segments.

Implement a sunrise effect: over 15 minutes, transition from 0% to 80% brightness with a warm-to-neutral color shift. Maintain 10 Hz updates using bounded loops to step time. Provide a stop input to abort to off.
Make a 'Knight Rider' scanner on 20 LEDs with a soft trail and a controllable speed (0.2–2.0 m/s equivalent tip speed along the strip). Use bounded loops for head and trail computation at 100 Hz.

Control an RGB lamp such that temperature (in Celsius) above 40 C forces color to blue and limits brightness to 30%. Normal operation is user-selected color. Update at 50 Hz; on sensor fault, blink red at 1 Hz.

Use two buttons to navigate through five preset color scenes. Implement a finite state machine with wrap-around indexing, 80 ms navigation debounce, and a 50 Hz update rate. Long press should return to scene 1.

Implement a beat-synchronized strobe that triggers every 500 ms from an external tick input. Use bounded loops to enforce exactly 3 on-pulses per trigger with 30 ms on, 70 ms off. Keep steady at other times.
Drive two independent LED groups with different PWM rates (e.g., 500 Hz and 2 kHz) while keeping one master update loop at 100 Hz. Ensure neither group exceeds 60% duty and both patterns are bounded.

Build a color temperature slider (2700 K to 6500 K) controlling a tunable white LED pair. Map slider position to warm/cool PWM channels with gamma correction. Update at 100 Hz and enforce 10% minimum per channel to avoid flicker.

Regulate perceived brightness to a target 300 lx measured by a photodiode using a PID controller on PWM duty cycle. Run control at 200 Hz, constrain duty to 0–85%, and handle sensor dropout by freezing output and blinking an error LED.

Fuse accelerometer tilt (degrees) and ambient light (lux) to select both hue and brightness for an RGB art piece: tilt maps to hue, lux maps inversely to brightness. Update at 50 Hz. Validate inputs and fall back to neutral white at 30% if either sensor is invalid.

Implement thermal derating: monitor LED heat sink temperature in Celsius and apply a smooth reduction of brightness starting at 55 C, reaching 30% at 75 C. The main pattern is a rainbow swirl at 60 Hz. Ensure WCET under 1 ms per update.

Use a PID loop to track a user-set brightness setpoint (0–100%) while compensating for supply voltage variations measured on an ADC. Control loop at 500 Hz with anti-windup and a hard duty cap at 90%.

Create a color stabilization loop that holds chroma within a small delta by adjusting RGB ratios using feedback from a simple color sensor. Run fusion and control at 50 Hz. On sensor saturation, enter a safe solid-white at 20%.

Design a flicker-safe dimming system that guarantees no perceptible flicker by keeping the effective modulation above 120 Hz and limiting sudden brightness steps to 10% per 20 ms. Use bounded loops for step schedules and enforce rate(1 kHz) PWM updates.

Implement ambient-compensated nightlight: fuse a proximity sensor with a light sensor so that close movement at <0.5 m triggers a warm fade to 40%, but only if ambient < 20 lx. Update at 100 Hz; if readings conflict, choose the safer (dimmer) output.

Build a dual-loop controller: outer PID maintains target lux at 200 lx; inner loop shapes PWM slew to limit dI/dt and avoid audible noise. Outer runs at 100 Hz, inner at 1 kHz. Enforce a 0–80% duty range and fail-safe to off on any fault.

Create a reactive art wall using sensor fusion: combine microphone RMS (dB) and accelerometer activity to drive both brightness and sparkle density across 64 LEDs. Update effects at 60 Hz with bounded loops and cap average power to 2.5 W.

Add brownout protection: monitor supply voltage and, if it drops below 4.5 V for >50 ms, gracefully fade all LEDs to 0% over 200 ms. Resume prior pattern when voltage is stable for 2 s. Maintain deterministic timing and WCET < 0.8 ms.

Implement a multi-mode light sculpture with modes: attract, calm, interactive, and fault. Each mode has distinct color patterns and brightness limits. Use a hierarchical state machine, bounded loops for pixel updates over 128 LEDs, rate(60 Hz), and explicit guard conditions. Include a safe default if any subtask overruns.

Design a show controller that schedules scenes over a 24-hour cycle: sunrise, day, sunset, night. Each scene defines target brightness and color gradients. Use bounded loops to step minutes, enforce a master update at 10 Hz, and include manual override and fault mode with red pulsing. Provide verification steps that assert scene timing boundaries.

Create a performance lighting system with two synchronized channels and a cue list of 20 steps. Each cue specifies fade time (ms), target colors, and brightness caps. Implement a robust state machine for cue progression, bounded iteration over cues, timing accuracy ±5 ms, and built-in self-test that briefly exercises all colors at startup.

Develop a resilient interactive installation with sensor fusion (light, proximity, microphone) to select between four behaviors. Define strict safety: never exceed 70% duty, average current capped to 500 mA, and fail-safe to black on any sensor fault. Use rate attributes per task, WCET analysis under 1 ms, and bounded loops for all pattern scans.

Specify a modular lighting engine with pluggable patterns (wipe, chase, sparkle, rainbow), a scheduler to switch patterns based on external triggers, and a diagnostics mode. Use a top-level state machine, strictly bounded loops over up to 256 LEDs, per-pattern update rates, and a comprehensive test sequence that validates timing and safety constraints.
Make a single LED fade up and down between 0% and 100% brightness using PWM at 200 Hz, repeating every 2 seconds. Keep the pattern loop bounded and avoid drift over time.
Toggle a single LED on button press; when on, hold brightness at 80% PWM. Debounce the button and ensure the output never exceeds 90% duty.
Use a knob to control LED brightness linearly from 0% to 100% PWM. Clamp out-of-range inputs and update at a steady rate of 50 Hz.
Blink an LED in a pattern of 3 short pulses (100 ms on, 100 ms off) followed by 1 long pulse (600 ms on), then a 1 second pause. Implement the pattern with a bounded loop.
Cycle an RGB LED through solid red, green, and blue, each for exactly 1 second, using a bounded loop to sequence the colors.
Create a gentle breathing effect on one LED by stepping brightness up and down in 32 discrete levels at 50 updates per second.
Flash an LED at 2 Hz with a 25% duty cycle. Ensure the update task has a fixed rate attribute and remains jitter-free.
On a rising edge input, produce a single 200 ms full-brightness flash, then lock out for 800 ms before it can trigger again.
Implement a soft-start where the LED ramps from 0% to 60% over 500 ms after power-up, then stays steady.
Alternate two LEDs: A on for 250 ms while B is off, then B on for 250 ms while A is off, repeating in a bounded loop.
Drive a warm and cool white pair so a slider blends between them from 2700 K 'warm' to 6500 K 'cool'. Keep total brightness constant.
Make a night-light that turns on to 20% PWM when ambient light is below a threshold and turns off above it, with 5 lux hysteresis.
Implement a tap-tempo blinker: each tap sets the period; the LED flashes on the beat at 70% brightness with a minimum period of 250 ms.
Cycle through three brightness presets (10%, 40%, 100%) each time a capacitive touch is detected. Ignore repeated touches within 300 ms.
Show a fixed bar of five blinks, then stop until a reset input is received. Use a bounded loop so the sequence cannot run indefinitely.

Build a state machine with states idle, chase, and sparkle for a small LED strip. A button advances the state. Each state's pattern should run at 60 frames per second using bounded loops for per-LED updates.
Create a rainbow gradient that moves along a strip of 24 LEDs at 10 pixels per second. Use a bounded loop to update each LED and cap brightness at 70%.
Use microphone amplitude to set an LED's brightness with exponential smoothing. Update at 100 Hz and cap changes to 20% per second.
Program a sunrise sequence that ramps from 0% to 100% over 15 minutes. Allow a cancel button to stop the sequence. If temperature exceeds 60 C, abort and dim to 10%.
Implement a traffic-light art piece with a state machine: Green 5 s, Yellow 2 s, Red 5 s. A pedestrian button inserts a 3 s 'walk' white state after Red, then returns to Green.
When motion is detected, run a color wipe across 16 LEDs, then fade out over 2 seconds. Enforce a 10 second cooldown before retriggering.
Provide three sliders for RGB values (0–255). Smoothly fade to new targets over 300 ms at a fixed 100 Hz update rate.
Implement a strobe with adjustable frequency from 1 Hz to 20 Hz and fixed 10% duty. Reject settings outside the safe range.
Drive four independent PWM channels with separate brightness curves. Ensure the sum of all duties never exceeds 250% to meet a power budget.
Create a candle flicker: random but bounded brightness steps at 120 Hz with a floor of 15% and ceiling of 60%. Reset the PRNG seed at startup.
Theater chase on a 12-LED strip: 3-on, 3-off moving forward at 8 steps per second; repeat the sequence exactly 4 times, then pause for 2 seconds.
Map a temperature sensor reading in Celsius (0–40 C) to a color gradient from blue to red. Sample at 10 Hz with 2-sample hysteresis to reduce flicker.
Two buttons control patterns: Button A starts a rainbow sweep; Button B starts a white sparkle; both together trigger a full-white 100 ms flash.
Auto-off after 10 minutes with no user input. Any button press resets the timer and gently fades the current light back to its prior level.
On each external clock pulse, rotate the hue by 30 degrees, keeping brightness at 70%. Ignore spurious pulses closer than 20 ms apart.
Crossfade two lighting zones over 5 seconds when a trigger occurs. Maintain linear brightness curves and ensure updates at 50 Hz.
Implement an LED bargraph for a 0–100% input. Light up to the corresponding level and make the top LED blink at 2 Hz when above 90%.
Create a random sparkle effect where at most 3 LEDs are sparkling at any moment. Each sparkle ramps up and down over 400 ms.
Design a simple color wheel control: a knob selects hue (0–360 degrees) and a slider selects brightness (0–100%). Update at 60 Hz with bounded math.
Sequence a 'meteor' tail across 20 LEDs with decay. The meteor head advances 5 LEDs per second; tail decays exponentially. Use bounded loops for per-LED updates.
Closed-loop brightness: use a photodiode input to control PWM via a PID so measured illuminance tracks a setpoint. Run the control loop at 200 Hz with anti-windup and clamp output between 5% and 90%.
Fuse two ambient light sensors to estimate room light level: take a weighted average but drop outliers that deviate by >30%. Adjust display brightness at 20 Hz with 0.5 s time constant.
Thermal protection for a high-power LED: linearly derate brightness starting at 55 C down to 20% at 70 C, and hard cutoff above 75 C. Sample temperature at 10 Hz.
Color calibration loop using a color sensor: adjust RGB PWM to reach a target D65 white within 500 ms. Limit iterations in a bounded loop and enforce a 100 Hz update rate.
Schedule a precise fade program with multiple cues (e.g., 0%→50% in 2 s, hold 3 s, 50%→0% in 1 s). Keep timing error under 2 ms and declare WCET constraints for the update task.
Manage power by measuring current and limiting total PWM so current never exceeds a configurable budget. When over budget, proportionally reduce all channels with smooth transitions.
Implement adaptive strobing that avoids medically risky frequencies: ensure no flashing occurs between 3 Hz and 60 Hz, and document this safety requirement.
Apply gamma correction using a lookup table of 64 entries to linearize perceived brightness. Use bounded loops for table access and update at 100 Hz.
Use a PID to control correlated color temperature (Kelvin) by mixing warm and cool channels based on an ambient color sensor reading. Update at 10 Hz with clamped outputs.
Create a POV-style light arc that requires frame updates at 500 Hz; ensure WCET per frame is less than 1 ms and that patterns are generated using bounded loops.

Develop a multi-mode light installation with modes: Gallery, Performance, and Maintenance. Use a state machine to manage modes, each with distinct patterns and rate attributes. Include a safe fallback that dims to 10% if any sensor fault is detected, and specify tests for all mode transitions.

Design a show controller for 8 LED segments with a scene manager. Scenes are scheduled cues with precise timing; updates run at 1 kHz with a WCET budget of 500 microseconds. Provide a test plan that verifies cue timing, scene transitions, and that per-segment loops remain bounded.

Create a redundant safety system for lighting that reads two temperature sensors and two ambient sensors, using voting and plausibility checks. Define a fail-safe state that cuts brightness to 0% within 50 ms on disagreement, and include tests that inject sensor faults.

Implement an emergency stop input that preempts all patterns and forces all channels to 0% within 50 ms. The stop is latched until a reset is held for 2 seconds. Provide verification steps for the preemption latency and latch behavior.

Build a configurable art light with user-selectable pattern packs. Each pack is a bounded collection of patterns with per-pattern rates. Include property-based tests asserting brightness never exceeds 85%, color sums remain within a power budget, and all loops are bounded.
Turn on the red alarm indicator whenever temperature exceeds 50 degC; turn it off when temperature is at or below 50 degC.
If relative humidity rises above 80%, assert the alarm output; otherwise keep it deasserted.
When ambient light drops below 10 lux, set a 'night' flag high; clear it when light is 10 lux or higher.
Activate a low-pressure warning output when barometric pressure falls below 95 kPa; clear the warning when it returns to 95 kPa or above.
Trigger an air quality alarm if CO2 concentration exceeds 1000 ppm.
Raise a frost warning when temperature is below 0 degC; clear the warning at 0 degC or above.
If illuminance exceeds 20000 lux, beep the buzzer until it falls back to or below 20000 lux.
Assert a VOC alarm output when the VOC index is greater than 150; otherwise keep it off.
If PM2.5 concentration is above 35 ug/m3 continuously for 300 s, turn on the warning light; turn it off if it stays at or below 35 ug/m3 for 300 s.
Set a comfort indicator high when relative humidity is within 40% to 60% inclusive; set it low otherwise.
Drive a fan relay on when the temperature exceeds 30 degC and off when at or below 30 degC.
Illuminate the filter-clog indicator when differential pressure across the filter exceeds 50 Pa.
Turn on a UV alarm when the UV index is greater than 8; turn it off when 8 or less.
When humidity exceeds 90%, turn on a 'wet' indicator for 10 s; ignore further triggers while the indicator is on.
If the temperature reading is invalid or outside the valid range [-40 degC, 125 degC], assert a sensor fault output.

Monitor temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%]: raise WARNING when temperature is 30-35 degC or humidity is 75-85%; raise ALARM when temperature > 35 degC or humidity > 85%. Apply hysteresis of 2 degC and 5% to avoid chatter, and drive separate WARNING and ALARM outputs.
Combine light and temperature: set a 'cold and dark' indicator when illuminance < 20 lux and temperature < 15 degC; otherwise clear it.
