Create a humidity state machine with states NORMAL, DRYING, and HUMID. Enter HUMID when RH > 70%; transition to DRYING when RH drops below 50%, and stay in DRYING for 10 minutes before returning to NORMAL if RH remains < 60%. Drive an output per state.
Sample barometric pressure at 1 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms. If pressure drops faster than 1 kPa per 10 minutes, assert a storm warning; clear it after pressure is stable (change < 0.2 kPa) for 30 minutes.

Implement a CO2 monitor with a 60 s rolling average and a sensor watchdog. If the sensor has not updated for 5 s or reports an error, assert a fault. Raise an alarm when the rolling average exceeds 1200 ppm for at least 2 minutes; latch the alarm until a manual reset input is pressed.
Estimate dew point from temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%]. Assert a condensation risk alarm if dew point exceeds 18 degC.
Control a 'lights-needed' output with hysteresis: turn it on when illuminance < 50 lux and turn it off when illuminance > 150 lux. Run at 10 Hz with WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Use two temperature sensors to improve reliability. If their readings differ by more than 2 degC, assert a sensor disagreement fault; otherwise average them and raise an overtemperature alarm if the average exceeds 60 degC.

For PM2.5 [ug/m3], apply a median-of-5 filter and turn on a purifier relay when the filtered value is > 25 ug/m3 for at least 60 s. Impose a minimum on-time of 120 s before turning it off once levels are <= 25 ug/m3 for 60 s.
Monitor two humidity sensors (Zone A and Zone B). If either exceeds 80% RH, assert a global alarm and drive a zone-specific indicator to identify which zone triggered.
Map PM2.5 concentration [ug/m3] to three air quality categories: Good (<= 12), Moderate (12-35), Unhealthy (> 35). Blink a status LED with 0, 1, or 3 blinks per 2 s for these categories respectively.

Integrate light exposure: compute the running sum of illuminance [lux] over time to estimate exposure in kilolux-hours (klx*h). When the 24 h total exceeds 5 klx*h, assert a notification; reset the total every 24 h.

Estimate altitude from barometric pressure [kPa] using a specified sea-level reference. If altitude changes by more than 100 m within 10 minutes, raise a rapid-change warning and clear it after 10 minutes of stability.
Detect thermal runaway: if temperature > 40 degC and its rate-of-change exceeds 0.5 degC/s for more than 5 s, assert a pre-alarm; escalate to alarm if temperature exceeds 60 degC.

Stabilize humidity readings by rejecting spikes: if RH changes by more than 10% within 1 s, ignore the spike unless it persists for 3 s. Then evaluate comfort: set COMFORT when RH is 40-60%, else NOT_COMFORT.

Compute a 'safe to ventilate' flag using three sensors: CO2 < 800 ppm, PM2.5 < 15 ug/m3, and outdoor temperature between 10 and 25 degC. Only set the flag true when all conditions are met for 60 s; clear immediately if any condition fails.

Monitor TVOC [ppb] and CO2 [ppm]. Raise a WARNING if either exceeds TVOC > 500 ppb or CO2 > 900 ppm; escalate to ALARM if TVOC > 1000 ppb or CO2 > 1200 ppm. Apply 30 s persistence to warnings and 60 s persistence to alarms.

At startup, calibrate a baseline for the light sensor by averaging 5 s of readings. During operation, flag 'rapid dimming' if illuminance drops by more than 30% from baseline within 2 s; clear after 10 s above 90% of baseline.
Implement a latching humidity flood alarm: when RH exceeds 95%, assert and latch ALARM. Only clear after RH stays below 80% for 10 minutes and a manual acknowledge input is received.

Cross-check barometric pressure for plausibility: compute implied altitude and assert a sensor fault if it is outside -100 m to 5000 m. Otherwise, output tendency arrows: UP if pressure rising > 0.2 kPa/3 h, DOWN if falling, else STEADY.

Maintain indoor air quality by modulating a ventilation output using PID control to hold CO2 near 800 ppm. Limit output between 0% and 100%. Safety: if CO2 exceeds 2000 ppm, override to 100% until below 1500 ppm. Run the controller at 5 Hz with WCET <= 2 ms.

Fuse two temperature sensors and one humidity sensor to compute heat index [degC]. Use weighted averaging with automatic exclusion of any temperature sensor that deviates by > 3 degC from the median. Raise a heat stress alarm when heat index > 40 degC.
Estimate altitude and vertical speed by filtering barometric pressure. Provide a smoothed altitude and vertical rate; raise a rapid-descent alarm when descent rate exceeds 3 m/s for at least 5 s.

Compute a composite indoor air quality index from PM2.5 [ug/m3], CO2 [ppm], and TVOC [ppb]. Classify into five levels with hysteresis between adjacent thresholds. For levels 4 and 5, assert a latching safety alarm that requires manual reset after 10 minutes below level 3.

Prevent condensation using dew point control: estimate dew point from temperature [degC] and RH [%], then drive a dehumidifier output using a PID to keep dew point below 16 degC. Safety: if the RH sensor is faulted, force the output off and assert a fault alarm. Execute at 2 Hz with WCET <= 2 ms.

Use triple modular redundancy on temperature: read three sensors, compute the median as the trusted value, and flag any sensor deviating by > 3 degC from the median as failed. Raise an overtemperature alarm when the trusted value exceeds 60 degC.

Estimate safe sun exposure time by combining UV index and visible light [lux]. Integrate dose and predict remaining time to a chosen MED. Issue warnings at 10 min and 5 min remaining, and an alarm when the safe dose is exceeded.

Fuse CO2 readings from an NDIR sensor and an equivalent-CO2 estimate derived from VOCs. Weight the sources based on recent consistency; if either source is faulted, rely on the other. Drive alarms at 1000 ppm (warning) and 1500 ppm (alarm) using the fused estimate.

Implement a storm alert state machine using barometric pressure absolute level and trend. States: CLEAR, WATCH, WARNING. Enter WATCH on a fall > 1 kPa in 3 h; enter WARNING on absolute pressure < 98 kPa or continued fall > 2 kPa in 6 h. Include 15 min debouncing between transitions.

Control a heating element with a PID to maintain ambient temperature at 22 degC +/- 0.5 degC. Safety: cut power and assert alarm if temperature exceeds 60 degC or if any sensor fault is detected. Run at 10 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Design a multi-sensor environmental monitor with modes BOOT, NORMAL, ALERT, and EVACUATE. Inputs: temperature [degC], RH [%], CO2 [ppm], PM2.5 [ug/m3], and light [lux]. Define thresholds for ALERT and EVACUATE (for example, CO2 > 2000 ppm or PM2.5 > 150 ug/m3 triggers EVACUATE). Prioritize alarms, ensure latching behavior in EVACUATE, and specify a 10 Hz task rate with WCET <= 2 ms.

Create a power-aware monitoring system with two modes: NORMAL and LOW_POWER. In NORMAL, sample temperature, humidity, CO2, and PM2.5 at 10 Hz; in LOW_POWER, sample at 1 Hz with relaxed filtering. Automatically switch to NORMAL if any measurement crosses a pre-alarm threshold (such as RH > 85% or CO2 > 900 ppm). Include watchdogs for stale sensors and fail-safe alarm defaults.

Provide a commissioning mode for baseline calibration of CO2 and light sensors. Require stable readings for 5 minutes before accepting baselines, persist them, then transition to MONITOR mode. In MONITOR, compute deviations from baseline and raise alarms at CO2 > baseline + 600 ppm and lux < baseline x 0.2. Include acceptance criteria and a manual exit path.

Implement a greenhouse environmental monitor with DAY and NIGHT modes. Configure different safe ranges: DAY temperature 20-28 degC, NIGHT 16-22 degC; RH 40-70% both. Raise warnings when leaving ranges, and alarms at T < 10 degC or > 35 degC or RH > 90%. Switch modes using a schedule input and provide latching alarms that require acknowledgment.

Specify a multi-room air quality aggregator. For each room, monitor CO2 [ppm], PM2.5 [ug/m3], and RH [%]. Compute room-level alarms and a building-wide alarm that activates if any two rooms are in ALARM or three in WARNING. Include majority voting to mask a single faulty sensor per room, periodic self-tests every 6 h, unit tests for threshold edge cases and hysteresis behavior, and enforce a 5 ms WCET per cycle at 5 Hz.
Create a simple temperature alarm: if ambient temperature exceeds 45 degC, turn on the alarm LED; turn it off when temperature falls below 45 degC. Sample at 2 Hz.
Monitor relative humidity and activate a buzzer when RH rises above 80 %. Clear the buzzer when RH falls back below 80 %.
Raise a visual alert if barometric pressure drops below 95 kPa. The indicator should remain off at or above 95 kPa.
Turn on a night indicator when illuminance is less than 200 lux, and turn it off when illuminance is 200 lux or higher.
Sound an alarm when CO2 concentration exceeds 1200 ppm. Silence the alarm automatically when CO2 returns to 1200 ppm or lower.
Trigger an air quality warning LED when PM2.5 is above 35 µg/m³. Turn the LED off when PM2.5 is 35 µg/m³ or below.
If TVOC rises above 300 ppb, activate a warning buzzer; deactivate it when TVOC is 300 ppb or less.
Set a single alarm output whenever temperature is outside the safe range of 10 degC to 30 degC (inclusive).
Illuminate a humidity alert LED when RH is below 30 % or above 60 %. Keep the LED off when RH is within 30–60 %.
Activate a pressure alarm if barometric pressure is outside the band 98–102 kPa. Otherwise keep the alarm off.
Turn on a glare warning when illuminance exceeds 8000 lux. Turn it off when illuminance is 8000 lux or lower.
If ozone concentration is above 70 ppb, raise an air quality alarm; clear the alarm when ozone is 70 ppb or below.
Activate an alarm if formaldehyde (HCHO) exceeds 80 ppb. Deactivate when HCHO is 80 ppb or below.
Detect a rapid cooling event: raise an alarm if temperature falls faster than 5 degC per minute.
If AQI exceeds 150 (unitless), turn on a siren. Turn it off when AQI is 150 or lower.

Implement two-level temperature alarms with hysteresis: Warning at 38 degC (amber LED) and Critical at 42 degC (red LED + buzzer). Require 3 s above each threshold to activate and 3 s below (with 1 degC hysteresis) to clear. Sample at 5 Hz.
For humidity, show NORMAL (green), DRY (blue) if RH < 30 %, and HUMID (yellow) if RH > 70 %. Use 2 % hysteresis on transitions to avoid chatter.
Compute a 1-minute moving average of pressure in hPa. If it drops by more than 5 hPa over 10 minutes, turn on a storm alert LED; auto-clear when the 10-minute drop is less than 3 hPa.
Control a night-light output using lux: turn on when illuminance stays below 150 lux for 10 s and turn off when illuminance stays above 300 lux for 10 s. Include anti-flicker timing.
Implement 3-level CO2 status: NORMAL < 800 ppm (green), ELEVATED 800–1200 ppm (amber), HIGH > 1200 ppm (red + buzzer). Add 50 ppm hysteresis between bands.
For PM2.5, raise a warning if > 55 µg/m³ for at least 5 minutes, and raise a critical alarm immediately if > 150 µg/m³. Clear warning when below 45 µg/m³ for 2 minutes.
Track a 24-hour rolling baseline of TVOC [ppb]; if current TVOC exceeds baseline by more than 200 ppb for 60 s, assert a spike alert. Do not reduce the baseline faster than 50 ppb/hour.
Calculate the heat index from temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%]. Indicate CAUTION when HI > 32 degC and DANGER when HI > 40 degC, with 1 degC hysteresis.
Compute dew point from temperature [degC] and humidity [%]. If (temperature − dew point) < 2 degC for more than 30 s, enable a condensation warning; clear when the spread is ≥ 3 degC for 30 s.
Read two temperature sensors; if they differ by more than 2 degC for over 10 s, flag a sensor fault alarm. Otherwise, display the average temperature.
Design a simple state machine for AQI monitoring: NORMAL and ALERT. Enter ALERT when AQI > 100 for 5 s; latch until AQI ≤ 80 for 30 s. Sample at 1 Hz and drive a buzzer only in ALERT.
Detect rapid buildup of CO2: if the slope exceeds +200 ppm/min for 30 s, light a 'ventilate' indicator even if absolute CO2 is below 1200 ppm. Clear when slope is below +50 ppm/min.

Provide a light calibration mode: on a digital input command, capture current illuminance [lux] as baseline. In run mode, alarm if lux deviates by more than ±50 % from baseline for 15 s. Include a timeout to exit calibration after 60 s.
Implement day/night light thresholds using a real-time clock: at night, turn on an indicator if lux < 100; during day, only if lux < 300. Add 20 lux hysteresis.
Validate inputs and raise a sensor fault alarm if humidity is < 0 % or > 100 %, temperature is < −40 degC or > 85 degC, or if any reading is NaN. Keep environmental alarms separate from sensor fault.
Evaluate comfort zone: NORMAL when 20–24 degC and 40–60 % RH; WARNING otherwise; ALARM if deviation exceeds ±5 degC or ±20 % RH. Drive LEDs accordingly with 1 degC and 3 % hysteresis.
For PM2.5 [µg/m³], compute both 1-minute and 15-minute averages. Raise an alert only when both exceed 35 µg/m³; clear when both are below 30 µg/m³.
Map TVOC [ppb] to buzzer patterns: 200–400 ppb = 1 short beep every 10 s; 400–800 ppb = 2 short beeps every 10 s; > 800 ppb = continuous tone. Below 200 ppb = silent.
Classify pressure trend each minute using slope in hPa/hour: RISING if > +1, FALLING if < −1, otherwise STEADY. Indicate state with distinct LEDs.
Add an acknowledgeable over-temperature alarm: at > 45 degC, sound a buzzer and light an LED. Acknowledge input silences the buzzer but keeps the LED latched until temperature < 42 degC.

Implement a PID loop to maintain air temperature at 22 degC using heater/fan outputs. Safety: emergency shutoff and latched alarm if temperature exceeds 50 degC or sensor fails. Run at 10 Hz with WCET ≤ 1 ms.
Control humidity to 50 % using a PID (humidifier/dehumidifier). Enforce safety thresholds so RH never exceeds 70 % or goes below 25 %. Detect sensor faults and fail safe (outputs off).
Fuse CO2 [ppm], TVOC [ppb], and PM2.5 [µg/m³] into a composite air quality score. Define thresholds for WARNING and CRITICAL alarms, with per-signal caps and hysteresis to ensure safety.

Use three temperature sensors with 2-out-of-3 voting. If any sensor deviates by > 3 degC from the median for > 10 s, isolate it, raise a sensor fault, and continue with the remaining two. Over-temperature alarm at 45 degC is latched.

Apply a Kalman filter to smooth barometric pressure [hPa] while compensating for temperature effects. Compute sea-level pressure and alarm if drop rate exceeds 2 hPa per 10 minutes. Run at 5 Hz with WCET ≤ 2 ms.

Predict condensation risk: forecast dew point 5 minutes ahead using exponential smoothing of temperature [degC] and RH [%]. Alarm if predicted (T − Td) < 1 degC. Include a minimum 0.5 degC safety margin.
Detect thermal runaway by monitoring temperature slope and curvature: if dT/dt > 3 degC/min and d²T/dt² > 1 degC/min² for 10 s, trigger an immediate alarm and latch until manual reset.
Implement automatic baseline correction for a CO2 sensor: update baseline only when CO2 < 600 ppm for ≥ 30 minutes; limit baseline change to ≤ 50 ppm/day. Alarm on sustained +400 ppm above baseline.

Perform temperature-compensated RH linearization using calibration coefficients to output RH [%]. Reject values outside 0–100 %. Sample at 100 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.5 ms, and raise a sensor fault on computation errors.

Fuse two photodiode channels (wideband + IR) to estimate illuminance [lux] with temperature compensation. Detect saturation and enter degraded mode using only the valid channel. Alarm if < 50 lux (too dark) or > 20,000 lux (too bright).

Create a supervisory controller with modes ENERGY-SAVE and HIGH-PRECISION. In both modes monitor temperature [degC] and humidity [%] with PID setpoints (22 degC, 50 %) but different sampling rates (5 Hz vs 20 Hz) and tighter alarms in HIGH-PRECISION. Include emergency cutouts at 50 degC and 80 % RH, plus WCET ≤ 1 ms. Provide comprehensive tests for mode switching, safety thresholds, and PID stability.

Implement a redundant air quality subsystem: 3 CO2 sensors [ppm] and 2 PM2.5 sensors [µg/m³] with sensor fusion (2oo3 voting for CO2, averaging for PM2.5 with outlier rejection). Flag and isolate faulty sensors, and raise multi-level alarms with hysteresis. Include a DIAGNOSTICS mode and verify determinism and WCET under worst-case input spikes.

Develop a lab hazard monitor: compute AQI from PM2.5 and O3 [ppb]; also watch CO [ppm] and H2S [ppm]. Escalate alarms through WARNING, ALARM, and EVACUATE with explicit thresholds, audible/visual patterns, and an EVACUATE latch requiring manual reset. Include startup calibration, periodic self-test, watchdog, 10 Hz sampling, and WCET ≤ 1 ms. Provide a verification plan covering thresholds, latching, and timing.

Build an environmental safety system for cold storage with modes NORMAL, ALARM, and DEFROST. Monitor temperature [degC], humidity [%], and door status; alarm if temperature > −15 degC or RH > 85 %, with hysteresis and latching rules. During DEFROST, relax temperature limits by +5 degC. Specify sampling at 2 Hz, WCET ≤ 1 ms, and a comprehensive test suite for mode transitions, alarms, and door-open edge cases.
Monitor ambient temperature in [degC] and assert a HighTemp alarm when it exceeds 50 [degC], with 2 [degC] hysteresis to clear at 48 [degC]. Drive a single alarm output accordingly.
Watch relative humidity and turn on a LowHumidity warning whenever RH drops below 30 [%]. Clear the warning as soon as RH returns to 32 [%] or higher.
Check barometric pressure and raise a HighPressure alarm when pressure exceeds 120 [kPa]. The alarm shall deassert once pressure falls below 118 [kPa].
Use a light sensor to detect darkness: if illuminance is below 100 [lux], set a Night flag; otherwise clear it. Update at 2 Hz.
Trigger a CO2 alert when concentration exceeds 1000 [ppm]. Provide a visual alarm output while active and automatically clear when CO2 falls under 900 [ppm].
Issue a PM2.5 warning if the particulate level is above 35 [µg/m³]. Include a 10 s persistence so momentary spikes do not cause false alarms.
Raise a VOC alert when the VOC index exceeds 200, and keep it latched until it drops below 180. Expose a single boolean status.
Indicate SafeStorage only when temperature is between 2 [degC] and 8 [degC] inclusive; otherwise enable an OutOfRange alarm.
Announce a StormWarning if pressure falls below 95 [kPa]. Clear the warning when it goes back above 96 [kPa].
Report a CondensationWarning when relative humidity exceeds 85 [%]. Remove the warning once RH is back under 80 [%].
Assert a Glare alert if light exceeds 10000 [lux], and clear it when it falls below 9000 [lux].
Detect a temperature sensor fault if any reading is outside the valid range of -40 [degC] to 125 [degC], and raise a SensorFault flag until readings return to within range for 5 consecutive samples.
Sample temperature at 2 Hz and output a moving average over the last 4 samples in [degC]. Provide both raw and averaged values.
Set an UnhealthyAir indicator when the derived AQI exceeds 150. Clear the indicator once AQI <= 120 for 60 s.
Raise an Ozone alarm if ozone concentration is greater than 70 [ppb] for more than 15 s. Clear when it stays at or below 60 [ppb] for 30 s.

Compute heat index from temperature ([degC]) and relative humidity ([%]). If the heat index exceeds 32 [degC], assert HeatStress with 1 [degC] hysteresis. Only evaluate when both sensors pass basic range checks.

Create a CO2 severity state machine with states Normal (<800 [ppm]), Elevated (800–1200 [ppm]), High (1200–2000 [ppm]), and Critical (>2000 [ppm]). Drive a 2-bit status output and apply 100 [ppm] hysteresis on each boundary.
Determine Day versus Night from lux using thresholds 200 [lux] (enter Night) and 300 [lux] (exit Night) plus a 3 s debounce. At Night, reduce other sensor sampling rates by half.
Track pressure tendency by computing the change over 30 minutes. If pressure drops by more than 4 [hPa] in 30 minutes, assert a RapidDrop warning until the drop falls below 2 [hPa].
Calculate dew point from temperature ([degC]) and humidity ([%]). If temperature minus dew point is less than 2 [degC], raise CondensationRisk; clear when the margin is >= 3 [degC].
Sample temperature and humidity at 1 Hz, maintain a 10-sample rolling average and variance, and set a StableEnv flag after variance stays below thresholds for 60 s.

Combine PM2.5 ([µg/m³]) and VOC index to classify air as Good, Moderate, or Poor using rules: Poor if PM2.5 > 55 or VOC > 300; Moderate if PM2.5 > 35 or VOC > 200; otherwise Good. Output the class as an enum.
Latch VentilateNow when CO2 exceeds 1500 [ppm] continuously for 30 s, and clear only after CO2 remains below 1200 [ppm] for 2 minutes. Provide both instantaneous and latched statuses.
Detect RapidHeating if the temperature rate-of-rise exceeds 1.5 [degC]/min over a 60 s window; clear when it drops below 0.5 [degC]/min.
Enforce a safety threshold on pressure: if it goes outside 90–110 [kPa], assert ImmediateStop within 100 ms of detection. Include a timer to verify the response time.
Check data freshness: if temperature, humidity, or pressure is not updated for more than 5 s, set DataStale and suppress environmental alarms while stale.
Implement auto-brightness: map lux to a 0–100 [%] dimming command with a piecewise-linear curve and a 2 [%] deadband to prevent flicker. Update at 10 Hz.
If a CO2 alarm has been active continuously for longer than 15 minutes, escalate to an Evacuate state that persists until CO2 drops below 800 [ppm] for 10 minutes.
Apply an exponential moving average to PM2.5 with a 10 s time constant at 1 Hz. Choose the smoothing factor accordingly and ensure the latency of step response is under 2 s.
Maintain a comfort band: set AdjustHumidity when RH is outside 40–60 [%], but suppress the high humidity alarm if temperature is below 10 [degC]. Include 2 [%] hysteresis.
Run a startup self-test: during the first 5 s, take light readings; if the value does not vary by at least 1 [lux] across samples, flag LightSensorFault; otherwise proceed to Normal.
Prioritize concurrent alarms: present only the highest according to Critical CO2 > Pressure Fault > High Temp > High Humidity > Glare. Provide a single encoded alarm output.
Design a sampling schedule with WCET limits: temperature at 5 Hz (max 5 ms), humidity at 2 Hz (max 8 ms), PM2.5 at 1 Hz (max 20 ms). Ensure cumulative CPU utilization remains under 50%.
Count pressure over-limit events where pressure exceeds 115 [kPa] for at least 1 s. Maintain a daily counter that resets at midnight and expose the count.
For VOC alerts, implement hysteresis and a minimum quiet time: after clearing, do not re-alert for at least 60 s unless VOC index exceeds 400.

Fuse three temperature sensors ([degC]) using a median-of-three approach with plausibility checks. If any sensor deviates by more than 3 [degC] from the fused value for over 10 s, mark it faulty and exclude it.

Use a Kalman filter to smooth barometric pressure and estimate sea-level pressure and its trend. Trigger a GaleWarning if trend is below -6 [hPa] over 3 hours while absolute pressure is under 98 [kPa].
Implement a PID controller to regulate temperature to 22.0 [degC]. Run at 10 Hz, enforce output limits 0–100 [%], apply integral anti-windup, and raise Overheat if temperature ever exceeds 30 [degC].

Create a humidity control supervisor: maintain 50 [%] RH by adjusting a dehumidifier command via a PID. When VOC index exceeds 250, temporarily lower the RH target linearly down to 45 [%]. Enforce bounds 40–55 [%].
Fuse PM2.5 and PM10 into a single AirQuality score using weighted averaging with saturation. If the score exceeds 100 for 5 minutes, assert PoorAir and keep it latched until below 80 for 10 minutes.
Build redundant CO2 monitoring with two sensors and 2-out-of-2 voting for alarm. If the difference between sensors exceeds 200 [ppm], set CO2Disagree and alarm using the worst-case (higher) value.

Estimate dew point with uncertainty by propagating temperature and humidity variances. If predicted dew point is within 1 [degC] of any provided surface temperature, enter SafetyShutdown. WCET must be under 100 ms.

Combine two light sensors to extend dynamic range: cross-check for saturation, apply temperature compensation, and output a fused lux value valid from 0 to 100000 [lux]. Alarm when either sensor saturates.
Adapt PM2.5 sampling between 0.1 Hz and 1 Hz based on observed variance, while guaranteeing CPU load below 40% and a minimum idle time of 50 ms between acquisitions.

Control ventilation with a PI controller to maintain CO2 near 900 [ppm]. Limit command slew to 10 [%] per second, cap output at 100 [%], and declare Overshoot if CO2 exceeds 1100 [ppm] for more than 60 s.

Specify a multi-mode environmental monitor with modes Boot, Calibration, Normal, Alert, and Fault. Calibrate a light baseline during the first 10 s. In Normal, monitor temperature ([degC]), humidity ([%]), pressure ([kPa]), lux ([lux]), CO2 ([ppm]), and PM2.5 ([µg/m³]) against defined thresholds. Enter Alert when any limit is exceeded and Fault when self-tests fail. Include latching behavior, a software-only reset path, and per-task WCETs.

Design a four-zone environmental monitoring system that aggregates zone statuses. Trigger a building-wide alarm when at least 2 zones are in Critical due to CO2 (>2000 [ppm]) or PM2.5 (>150 [µg/m³]). Ensure alarm propagation across zones within 500 ms and include a detailed test plan with edge cases.

Define a comprehensive state machine for heat stress that uses temperature ([degC]), humidity ([%]), and illuminance ([lux]) to output Rest, Caution, Warning, or Danger. Include hysteresis, minimum dwell times per state, and validation tests for boundary conditions.

Produce a safety-focused environmental supervisor that enforces these ranges: temperature 18–26 [degC], humidity 40–60 [%], pressure 98–102 [kPa], CO2 < 1000 [ppm], PM2.5 < 35 [µg/m³], and lux < 10000 [lux] in glare-sensitive areas. Use sensor fusion where appropriate, include startup and periodic self-tests, define scheduling with WCETs, and provide a set of unit tests.

Write a certification-ready specification for CO2-based ventilation control using PID. Requirements: setpoint 900 [ppm], settling time < 5 minutes, overshoot < 10%, output limited to 0–100 [%] with rate limit 10 [%]/s, fallback to open-loop upon sensor fault, worst-case timing constraints, and fault-injection tests with traceability to requirements.
Turn on a red warning LED whenever the measured temperature exceeds 45 degC; turn it off when temperature falls back below 45 degC.
Sound a buzzer if relative humidity drops below 25% to indicate overly dry air; silence the buzzer when humidity returns to 30% or higher.
Switch a cooling fan on when ambient temperature is above 30 degC and switch it off when temperature is below 28 degC (simple hysteresis).
Activate a low-pressure alarm when absolute pressure falls under 95 kPa; clear the alarm when pressure is at or above 96 kPa.
If ambient light falls below 50 lux, turn on a night indicator; otherwise keep it off.
Trigger an air quality alarm when PM2.5 exceeds 35 µg/m³; clear it when PM2.5 is below 25 µg/m³.
Raise a rapid heating alert if the temperature rise rate exceeds 2 degC per minute.
Drive a 0–100% bar indicator based on measured relative humidity %, and blink a warning LED when humidity exceeds 85%.
Turn a heater relay on when temperature is below 18 degC and turn it off when temperature rises to 19 degC or higher.
Set an alert flag when CO2 concentration surpasses 1000 ppm; clear when it drops below 800 ppm.
Issue an overexposure warning if light level exceeds 80,000 lux for more than 5 seconds.
Generate a pressure instability warning if absolute pressure changes by more than 3 kPa within 10 seconds.
Enable a frost alert when temperature is below 0 degC; disable it at 2 degC or higher.
Set a condensation risk alarm when relative humidity is above 95%.
If the VOC index rises above 5 (unitless), activate an indoor air quality alarm indicator.
Create a two-level temperature alarm: Warning at 35 degC and Critical at 45 degC. Light yellow for Warning, red and sound buzzer for Critical. Latch Critical until an acknowledge input is pressed.
Control both a humidifier and a dehumidifier to keep relative humidity within 40% to 60%. Ensure only one device can be active at a time and include 2% hysteresis on each threshold.
Sample pressure at 10 Hz and maintain a moving average of the last 5 samples. Raise a low-pressure alarm if the averaged value stays below 90 kPa for more than 3 seconds.
Implement a day/night state machine using ambient light: enter Day when lux > 300 for 30 s, Night when lux < 100 for 30 s. In Night, lower the temperature alarm threshold by 2 degC.
Classify PM2.5 into Good (<12 µg/m³), Moderate (12–35 µg/m³), or Unhealthy (>35 µg/m³). Drive a tri-color LED accordingly and start a buzzer if Unhealthy persists for 60 seconds.
Detect sensor faults: if the temperature reading is invalid, or changes less than 0.1 degC over 5 minutes, enter a Fault state, turn off all actuators, blink a red LED, and require manual reset.
Ignore all humidity alarms for the first 10 seconds after startup (warm-up), then monitor and alarm if humidity > 85% for longer than 5 seconds.
Provide a silence button that mutes the buzzer for 5 minutes, but immediately reactivates it if any Critical air quality threshold is exceeded (CO2 > 2000 ppm or PM2.5 > 150 µg/m³).
Use a configurable temperature setpoint input (in degC) for a high-temperature alarm. Constrain it between 20 degC and 60 degC, and latch the alarm until acknowledged.

Based on both temperature and humidity, decide which actuator to run: if temperature > 30 degC and humidity > 70%, enable ventilation; if temperature > 30 degC and humidity ≤ 70%, enable cooling; if humidity > 70% and temperature ≤ 30 degC, enable dehumidification.
Track daily min and max for temperature (degC) and relative humidity (%). On a midnight signal, publish the values and reset the trackers.
Monitor the pressure rate of change and warn if it falls faster than 0.5 kPa per minute; escalate to Critical if faster than 1.5 kPa per minute.
Detect light flicker anomalies by flagging an alarm if lux fluctuates by more than 20% at around 50 Hz. Sample at 200 Hz and report an anomaly within 2 seconds.
Use two temperature sensors and select the one to trust: if their difference is ≤ 2 degC, use their average; otherwise raise a sensor disagreement fault and hold the last trusted value.
Define a humidity comfort band: green when 40–60%, yellow when 30–40% or 60–70%, red outside that range. Escalate to a buzzer if red persists for more than 2 minutes.
After air quality improves (PM2.5 < 12 µg/m³ and CO2 < 800 ppm), keep the buzzer muted for a 10-minute grace period before returning to normal alarm behavior.
Provide thermal runaway protection: if temperature is above 50 degC and increases by more than 5 degC within 30 seconds, cut power output and latch a high-priority alarm.
When any monitored variable crosses a safety threshold, assert an Event output for exactly 500 ms and block retriggering for 5 s. Run the logic at 100 Hz.
Establish an adaptive lux baseline over the first 5 seconds after startup, then raise an alarm if current light deviates by ±60% for at least 1 minute to avoid false alarms.
Compute an air quality status from CO2 (ppm) and VOC index: Good, Caution, Poor. Activate ventilation in Caution and start an audible alarm in Poor. Re-evaluate every 2 seconds.

Implement a PID controller to maintain ambient temperature at 22 degC within ±0.5 degC. Include anti-windup, clamp output on sensor faults, and hard safety cutoff at 50 degC. Run at 10 Hz with a WCET ≤ 1 ms.
Use PID control to regulate relative humidity to 45% with limited actuator duty cycle to prevent overshoot. If humidity exceeds 80%, trigger an emergency dehumidify mode and an alarm.
Fuse readings from three temperature sensors using a median filter, reject any sensor deviating by more than 2 degC from the median, and compute a fused temperature for alarm decisions (> 40 degC).

Estimate altitude from pressure (kPa) and temperature (degC) to detect rapid weather changes; raise a storm warning when the derived pressure trend indicates a drop of > 3 kPa in 30 minutes. Handle missing sensor data gracefully and sample at 5 Hz.

Combine PM2.5 (µg/m³) and CO2 (ppm) into a composite indoor air quality score using weighted fusion. Set multi-level alarms (Advisory, Warning, Critical) and default to Critical if either sensor is stale for > 3 seconds.

Calculate dew point from temperature (degC) and relative humidity (%). Trigger a condensation alarm when dew point is within 1 degC of ambient temperature for at least 15 seconds, using plausibility checks for sensor limits.

Design a safety manager that forces a safe state (ventilation on, heater off, dehumidifier on) if any sensor becomes stale (> 3 seconds since last update), reports NaN, or exceeds safe operating ranges. Latch a safety fault until reviewed.

Guarantee timing: complete monitoring of temperature, humidity, pressure, light, and air quality every 100 ms. Enforce per-cycle WCET budgets; if an overrun occurs, raise a timing fault and execute a minimal critical-alarm path.

Create an adaptive temperature PID that reduces integral gain when the measured temperature variance increases (indicating airflow disturbances). Enforce output rate limiting and a hard cap at 60 degC.

Smooth CO2 readings with an exponential moving average using a time constant that shortens when variance rises. Provide three alarm levels at 800 ppm, 1200 ppm, and 2000 ppm, each with minimum on-times of 30 s.

Build a multi-mode environmental monitor with modes: Startup Self-Test, Normal, Alert, Critical, and Fault. Monitor temperature (degC), humidity (%), pressure (kPa), light (lux), CO2 (ppm), and PM2.5 (µg/m³). Specify transitions with thresholds and persistence times, latch Critical until operator acknowledgment, and define outputs per mode. Cycle period 50 ms with WCET ≤ 5 ms.

Design a building air quality supervisor with modes: Occupied, Unoccupied, Night Purge, and Smoke Event. Use CO2 (ppm), PM2.5 (µg/m³), temperature (degC), and humidity (%) to drive ventilation commands and alarms. Safety: never exceed 35 degC or 85% RH; in Smoke Event (PM2.5 > 150 µg/m³) force maximum exhaust and lockout until acknowledged. Include a temperature PID in Occupied mode.

Create a redundant sensing architecture using two temperature sensors and two humidity sensors. Perform majority voting where possible, detect mismatches > 2 degC or > 5% RH, enter Degraded mode on disagreement, and require periodic self-test. Prove alarm latency stays under 200 ms and enforce a 20 Hz loop with WCET ≤ 2 ms.

Define a multi-sensor fusion engine to compute an Indoor Air Quality index from CO2 (ppm), VOC index, PM2.5 (µg/m³), and humidity (%). Modes: Good, Moderate, Unhealthy, Hazardous. Enforce formal invariants: never clear Hazardous without operator acknowledgment, and always assert Hazardous within 2 s of threshold crossing. Include drift calibration mode and test vectors for boundary cases.

Specify an environmental chamber controller with dual PID loops for temperature (degC) and humidity (%), with modes: Control, Monitor-Only, Emergency Shutdown. Safety cutoffs at 60 degC and 95% RH. Control loop at 20 Hz with WCET ≤ 2 ms, and include comprehensive tests: step responses, sensor fault injection, overrun handling, and accuracy tolerances.
Read a single temperature sensor and turn on an alarm output if the value exceeds 60 [degC]; include a configurable threshold and a latched alarm that requires manual reset.
Sample relative humidity and illuminate a warning indicator when the reading drops below 25 [%]; clear the warning once humidity rises above 30 [%].
Switch to night mode when it's dark: monitor ambient light and set a flag below a chosen threshold; add a simple 1-second debounce to prevent flicker.
Monitor barometric pressure and raise an alert if pressure falls more than 500 Pa within 10 minutes; run the check once per second.
If the air gets dirty, make some noise - watch AQI and buzz when it goes above the limit; keep buzzing at least 5 seconds.
Read temperature in [degC] and display a three-color status: green below 40 [degC], yellow 40 to 60 [degC], red above 60 [degC].
Sample humidity [%] every second and set an alarm if the reading exceeds 85 [%]; include 5 [%] hysteresis to prevent chatter.
Detect rapid temperature rise: if the slope exceeds 2 [degC]/min, set a pre-alarm flag.
Monitor CO2 concentration and assert a ventilation request when above 1000 ppm; clear when below 800 ppm.
Measure ambient light and open a relay if illumination exceeds a configurable threshold; include hysteresis to prevent chatter.
Blink a heartbeat indicator once per second while also watching temperature in [degC]; enter overheat alarm above 70 [degC].
Monitor barometric pressure and raise an alarm if it is below 95 kPa or above 105 kPa; log the current status.
Read temperature [degC] and send a one-shot alarm if it crosses 50 [degC] upward; ignore further alarms for 60 seconds.
Keep it simple: check humidity [%] and show 'dry' when below 30 [%], 'normal' otherwise.
Monitor light and turn on a backlight when illumination stays below a threshold for more than 3 seconds; turn it off when back above the threshold for 3 seconds.

Combine temperature [degC] and humidity [%] to estimate dew point; drive a three-state indicator: NORMAL, WARNING (within 2 [degC] of dew point), ALARM (below dew point); include 0.5 [degC] hysteresis between states.
Implement a sampling loop at 10 Hz reading temperature and pressure; compute altitude change and raise a 'rapid ascent' warning if pressure drop corresponds to more than 2 meters in 5 seconds.
Create a state machine for air quality with states GOOD, MODERATE, and UNHEALTHY based on PM2.5 and CO2; require 10 consecutive samples meeting criteria before committing a state change.
Use both light and temperature: if light is high and temperature exceeds 32 [degC], request shading and cooling; cancel the request when either drops below thresholds for 20 seconds.
Monitor temperature [degC] with two thresholds: WARN above 55 [degC], CRITICAL above 65 [degC]; latch CRITICAL until manually reset and temperature falls below 50 [degC].
Sample humidity [%] at 2 Hz, compute a 30 second moving average, and trigger a humidifier request when the average is below 35 [%]; enforce a minimum off-time of 120 seconds to prevent cycling.
Monitor differential pressure between two points; alarm if the absolute value exceeds 300 Pa or if the sign flips more than 3 times in one minute.
Implement a two-sensor temperature voting scheme: compare two sensors in [degC]; if their difference exceeds 2 [degC], flag a sensor disagreement alarm; otherwise use their average for reporting.
Build a day or night classifier based on light with hysteresis and a minimum dwell time of 5 minutes per state; expose the current state and time-in-state.
Compute heat index (feels-like temperature) from temperature [degC] and humidity [%]; raise a CAUTION above 32 [degC] heat index and DANGER above 40 [degC].

Monitor VOC index and CO2 together; if either exceeds its warning threshold, set ventilation demand level 1; if both exceed critical thresholds, set level 2 and sound an alarm; include auto-clear hysteresis.
Read temperature [degC] at 5 Hz and publish an averaged value with an exponential filter (time constant 10 seconds); raise an alert if the raw reading spikes above 80 [degC].
Implement an alarm inhibit window after startup: for the first 60 seconds, collect baseline humidity [%] and temperature [degC] and suppress alarms; after that, enable normal alarm logic.

Create a finite state machine for condensation control with states DRY, RISK, and WET; transitions depend on dew point proximity and must persist for at least 30 seconds per state to avoid oscillation.
Monitor pressure trend using a 5 minute linear regression; if projected pressure reaches a low threshold within the next 15 minutes, raise a forecast warning.
Sample light at 50 Hz and compute a flicker percentage; set a flicker alarm if modulation index exceeds 10 [%] for more than 2 seconds.
Combine two humidity sensors [%] and reject outliers using a median of three consecutive samples; alarm on sustained high humidity above 90 [%] for 60 seconds.
Track cumulative time above 70 [degC] and raise a maintenance alert after 100 hours accumulated; clear only via manual reset.
Add a manual acknowledge input that silences audible alarms but keeps visual alarms active until temperature [degC] and humidity [%] return to safe ranges.

Monitor temperature and compute rate-of-change; issue staged alarms: Stage 1 if greater than 1 [degC]/min, Stage 2 if greater than 3 [degC]/min, with separate clear thresholds and latching for Stage 2.

Design a PID loop to regulate ambient temperature to 25 [degC] using a heater output; sample at 10 Hz with WCET <= 3 ms; include safety: hard cutoff above 60 [degC], sensor failure detection (stuck or invalid), and an audible alarm on any safety trip.

Fuse readings from three temperature sensors in [degC] using majority voting with outlier rejection; produce a fused temperature and an uncertainty estimate; alarm if any sensor deviates by more than 3 [degC] for over 10 seconds.

Implement a humidity [%] PID controller targeting 50 [%] using a humidifier/dehumidifier demand output; enforce actuator rate limiting and anti-windup; sample at 5 Hz with WCET <= 5 ms; trigger alarms if humidity exceeds 80 [%] or drops below 20 [%].

Build a sensor fusion module that combines barometric pressure and temperature to compute compensated altitude; detect and flag sensor drift using a sliding statistical test; raise a safety alarm if drift persists for 2 minutes.

Estimate dew point using two independent formulas and cross-check results; if the discrepancy exceeds 1 [degC], declare a computation fault and inhibit condensation alarms until resolved; execute at 2 Hz with WCET <= 2 ms.

Create a predictive air quality alarm that uses a weighted moving average of VOC and CO2 plus a short-term derivative; alarm early if the trend indicates crossing critical levels within 5 minutes; ensure false alarm suppression through confirmation logic.

Implement a light exposure integrator that accumulates dose in lux-hours; compute daily dose and trigger an overexposure alarm when dose exceeds a configurable limit; sample at 20 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Develop a robust temperature monitoring system with dual redundant sensors, median fusion, and automatic switchover; include periodic self-test against a reference; on any discrepancy greater than 2 [degC], enter degraded mode and raise a safety warning.

Detect condensation risk via sensor fusion: combine air temperature [degC], humidity [%], and surface temperature; compute margin to dew point and drive a proportional heater demand while enforcing overtemperature safeties and alarming if margin is below 0 [degC] for more than 30 seconds.

Implement a pressure monitoring task running at 50 Hz with WCET <= 2 ms that performs band-pass analysis to detect oscillations; if oscillation amplitude exceeds 200 Pa peak-to-peak for 5 seconds, raise an equipment protection alarm.

Create a multi-mode environmental monitor with modes STARTUP, NORMAL, ALARM, and MAINTENANCE. Monitor temperature [degC], humidity [%], and CO2. Define mode entry and exit rules, latched alarms for overtemperature (> 65 [degC]) and high humidity (> 90 [%]), manual acknowledge behavior, and safe fallbacks on sensor faults. Provide detailed acceptance criteria and test cases for each mode transition, including hysteresis and timing.

Design a dual-channel temperature safety supervisor with two independent sensing paths. Implement voting, discrepancy detection (> 2 [degC] for > 5 s), and a safe state that de-energizes outputs on any fault. Include timing constraints: loop rate 100 Hz with WCET <= 2 ms, plus brownout handling and startup self-test. Deliver a verification plan with fault injection (stuck-at, out-of-range, frozen) and objective pass/fail criteria.

Specify a comprehensive air quality controller with operating modes AUTO, MANUAL, CALIBRATION, and SAFE. Fuse CO2, VOC, and PM2.5 to compute an air quality score; drive two-stage ventilation demand with alarms at warning and critical thresholds. Define timing (loop rate 10 Hz, WCET <= 3 ms), safety behaviors on sensor timeout, and a full set of unit and integration tests, including boundary, hysteresis, and persistence checks.

Develop a light and temperature management system with modes DAY, NIGHT, and PROTECT. Use light level, temperature [degC], and humidity [%] to control shading and heating requests, with condensation protection based on dew point margin. Include safety thresholds (overtemp > 70 [degC], high humidity > 95 [%]) with latched alarms, manual reset policy, deterministic timing (20 Hz, WCET <= 2 ms), and a validation plan covering worst-case timing and fault scenarios.

Engineer an environmental monitoring framework with sensor fusion, diagnostics, and traceability. Inputs: temperature [degC], humidity [%], pressure, light, and CO2. Outputs: alarm relays and staged warnings. Requirements: multi-rate scheduling (fast path 50 Hz WCET <= 1 ms; slow path 1 Hz WCET <= 2 ms), end-to-end range checks, stuck sensor detection, calibration mode, and a comprehensive test suite detailing coverage goals, reproducible test vectors, and acceptance thresholds.
When the ambient temperature exceeds 40 degC, assert an alarm output and latch it until temperature falls below 38 degC.
Turn on a warning LED if relative humidity rises above 85% and turn it off below 80% (include hysteresis).
Switch on a fan relay whenever temperature is over 30 degC; switch it off when under 29 degC.
If light level is below 50 lx, turn on a lamp; if above 80 lx, turn it off.
Raise an air quality bad flag when VOC index exceeds a threshold of 200, clear it when below 180.
Report an alarm if humidity is below 20% (too dry).
Pulse an indicator once per second while temperature is between 0 degC and 5 degC to indicate frost risk.
Trigger a critical alarm if temperature exceeds 70 degC for more than 5 seconds.
Log a warning event when light level changes by more than 100 lx within 1 second.
Enable dehumidifier output when humidity is above 60%, disable below 55%.
Turn on a filter LED when particulate matter PM2.5 measurement goes above 35 ug/m3; turn it off below 25 ug/m3.
Set an alarm if temperature reading is invalid or out of range (-40 degC to 125 degC).
If pressure falls below 980 hPa, set a storm watch flag; clear above 985 hPa.
Flash the alarm LED at 2 Hz when humidity exceeds 95%.
Assert a maintenance reminder when total run time with humidity over 80% reaches 100 hours.

Create a two-state controller (Normal, Overheat) that monitors temperature in degC and humidity %. In Overheat, drive a fan and trigger an audible alarm; return to Normal only after temperature is below 45 degC for 30 seconds.
Combine temperature and humidity to compute a simple heat index; if the heat index exceeds a comfort threshold, switch the HVAC output and illuminate a warning indicator.
Implement hysteresis and debounce for a light sensor: if averaged lux is below 40 lx for 3 consecutive readings at 10 Hz, turn on lights; turn off after above 70 lx for 3 readings.

Manage a dehumidifier with three states: Idle, Drying, Cooldown. Enter Drying when humidity is greater than 65%, run for at least 5 minutes, then Cooldown for 1 minute before returning to Idle. Include safety to prevent oscillation.
Generate an alarm if temperature rises faster than 2 degC per minute while humidity is above 80%.
Control a ventilation fan based on both CO2 ppm and VOC index; choose the higher priority pollutant to decide speed levels Low and High and raise a warning when either exceeds its threshold.
Implement a sunrise and sunset simulator using light sensor feedback: ramp an LED output slowly unless ambient light exceeds 200 lx, then hold.
Monitor pressure and temperature; if pressure drops below 990 hPa and temperature is below 5 degC, activate a frost-free mode indicator.
State machine with three modes: Normal, Warning, Critical for PM2.5 and PM10 readings. In Critical, sound continuous alarm; in Warning, beep at 1 Hz.
Add a watchdog for the humidity sensor: if no new sample arrives within 2 seconds, raise a sensor fault and put outputs into a safe default.
Compute dew point from temperature (degC) and humidity (%). Turn on anti-condensation heaters when dew point is within 2 degC of measured surface temperature.

Use two light sensors, indoor and outdoor, to decide whether to open shades: open when outdoor is greater than 30000 lx and indoor is less than 300 lx; close otherwise, with 60 s minimum dwell time between changes.
Implement an averaging filter for pressure at 5 Hz and raise a barometric trend indicator with states Rising, Steady, Falling based on 10 minute history.
Drive a tri-color LED to show air quality category based on AQI value: green below 50, yellow 50 to 100, red above 100; blink when values are stale more than 30 s old.
Only enable the heater if temperature is below 10 degC and humidity is below 90% to reduce condensation risk.
Implement a spillover alarm: if humidity exceeds 90% and light level simultaneously drops below 20 lx, emit a distinct alarm pattern indicating possible water ingress.
Run a periodic task at 10 Hz to read sensors and a 1 Hz task to update status LEDs; ensure both tasks coordinate so alarms reflect the latest temperature and humidity values.
Control a fan with two thresholds: low speed when CO2 exceeds 800 ppm, high speed when CO2 exceeds 1200 ppm; include a 2 minute minimum on-time.
Implement a calibration mode entered by holding a button for 3 seconds; in this mode, capture baseline light level and store it; in normal mode, alarm if measured light deviates by 50 percent.
Detect sensor outliers: if any single temperature sample deviates by more than 5 degC from the running median, ignore it and flag a transient anomaly.
Use PID control to maintain ambient temperature at 22 degC using a heater output. Limit the actuator duty cycle to 0 to 80 percent and include anti-windup. Raise an overheat alarm above 50 degC.

Fuse two redundant temperature sensors in degC and one humidity sensor in percent to produce a robust dew point estimate; reject a sensor if it disagrees by more than 3 degC from the fused estimate for 10 seconds and raise a fault.

Implement a barometric altitude estimator using pressure in hPa with a complementary filter combining short term rate and long term average; trigger a rapid change alarm if altitude rate exceeds 5 m per s equivalent.

Design a closed loop humidity controller using PID to keep relative humidity at 55 percent with a dehumidifier output; enforce a minimum compressor rest time of 3 minutes and add high humidity alarm at 80 percent.
Perform sensor fusion between a photoresistor and a digital lux sensor to improve low light accuracy; weight sensors based on noise estimates and indicate confidence level on an LED bar.

Implement a safety manager that supervises temperature, humidity, and VOC index. If any reading goes beyond critical limits 70 degC, 95 percent, VOC greater than 400, enter Emergency state, disable actuators, and latch alarms until manual reset.
Execute all sensing and control at 50 Hz with a worst case execution time budget of 2 ms per cycle; if the time budget is exceeded, fall back to a safe open loop mode and raise a timing fault.
Apply a moving horizon outlier rejection for pressure and temperature streams; if more than 3 consecutive outliers occur, mark the sensor as degraded and switch to a backup channel.
Implement a thermal ramp controller that limits the temperature increase to 1 degC per minute while approaching a setpoint of 30 degC; alarm if the slope limit is violated.

Estimate indoor air quality using a simple model combining CO2 ppm and humidity percent. If both are high, CO2 greater than 1000 ppm and RH greater than 70 percent, declare stuffy and boost ventilation to maximum; otherwise use proportional control.

Create a multi mode environmental monitor with modes Startup Self-Test, Normal, Energy-Saving, and Fault. During Startup Self-Test of 10 s, verify temperature, humidity, pressure, and light sensors provide plausible readings; in Fault, force outputs to safe states and latch alarms until acknowledged.

Specify a complete state machine for an indoor climate controller with modes Heating, Cooling, Dehumidifying, Idle, and Emergency. Include interlocks to prevent simultaneous heating and dehumidifying when humidity exceeds 90 percent, and define transition guards using degC and percent thresholds.

Develop a safety critical monitoring system that samples temperature, humidity, pressure, and PM2.5 at 10 Hz with worst case execution time not exceeding 3 ms. Include redundancy checks, sensor timeout handling, and an alarm hierarchy with levels Info, Warning, and Critical with clear escalation and de escalation rules.

Provide a comprehensive test plan within the specification: define unit tests for threshold crossings such as 25 degC, 60 percent, and 1000 hPa, hysteresis behavior, timing constraints, and fault scenarios including sensor stuck, noisy, and missing. Include acceptance criteria for alarm latency less than 200 ms.

Design a multi zone sensor fusion supervisor that manages three rooms, each with temperature in degC and humidity in percent sensors. Fuse readings per room, detect cross room inconsistencies, and coordinate shared ventilation. Include diagnostics, periodic self calibration, and detailed logging requirements.

Turn on a buzzer when ambient temperature exceeds 40 [degC], and turn it off when it falls below 38 [degC] (2 [degC] hysteresis). Sample at 2 [Hz]. If the temperature reading is invalid, keep the buzzer off.
Drive a status LED ON when relative humidity rises above 70 [%], and OFF when it drops below 65 [%]. Use a simple 5-sample moving average to reduce noise.
Monitor barometric pressure and assert a warning output if pressure is below 980 [hPa]. Check once per second and clear the warning only after pressure returns above 990 [hPa].
Sound an alarm if illuminance stays under 30 [lux] continuously for more than 5 [s]. Otherwise remain silent. Sampling rate: 10 [Hz].
Control a ventilation relay: energize it when CO2 concentration > 1000 [ppm], de-energize when < 800 [ppm]. If no new CO2 sample arrives within 3 [s], fail-safe to relay OFF.
Activate a heating-needed indicator whenever ambient temperature is below 15 [degC], and deactivate it once temperature rises above 18 [degC].
Raise a latched air-quality alarm when VOC index exceeds 150. Require a manual reset request to clear the alarm after VOC returns below 120 for at least 60 [s].
Switch a dehumidifier output ON when relative humidity exceeds 85 [%]; switch it OFF when humidity is below 80 [%]. Limit output toggling to at most once every 10 [s] to avoid chattering.
Signal brightness state with one indicator: blink at 1 [Hz] when ambient light > 2000 [lux], steady ON for 500–2000 [lux], and OFF below 500 [lux].
Assert a heatwave alert if temperature rate-of-rise exceeds 2 [degC]/min while the current temperature is above 30 [degC]. Reset the alert when both conditions are no longer met.
Set a 'comfort' output HIGH when temperature is between 20 and 24 [degC]; otherwise set it LOW. Update at 1 [Hz].
Declare a storm-warning output if barometric pressure falls by more than 5 [hPa] within 10 [min]. Clear only after the 10-minute pressure change is less than 1 [hPa].
Drive a fan output in 3 discrete levels based on CO2: OFF below 800 [ppm], LOW between 800–1200 [ppm], MEDIUM between 1200–1500 [ppm], and HIGH above 1500 [ppm].
Enable a nightlight when ambient light is below 100 [lux]; disable it when ambient light exceeds 150 [lux] to provide hysteresis.
Turn on a freeze alert when temperature ≤ 0 [degC]. After temperature rises above 1 [degC], wait 60 [s] before turning the alert off.

Build a small state machine for indoor comfort with states NORMAL, ALERT_HOT, ALERT_HUMID, and ALERT_BOTH. Use temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%] with thresholds: hot > 27 [degC], humid > 70 [%]. Provide hysteresis of 1 [degC] and 5 [%]. Drive an alarm output in ALERT_BOTH only.

Estimate condensation risk: from temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%], compute dew point (approximate is fine) and assert a CONDENSATION alert when ambient temperature is within 2 [degC] of the dew point. Clear when separated by > 3 [degC]. Sample at 2 [Hz].

Use two independent temperature sensors to protect against faults. If their readings differ by more than 1.5 [degC], raise a SENSOR_FAULT and suppress heating output; otherwise, allow heating when temperature < 18 [degC] and disable it above 21 [degC].

Classify air quality with two inputs: CO2 [ppm] and VOC index. Set status to GOOD, MODERATE, or POOR using thresholds (GOOD if CO2 < 800 and VOC < 100; POOR if CO2 ≥ 1500 or VOC ≥ 200; otherwise MODERATE). Latch an alarm when POOR persists for 2 [min].

Create a ventilation controller with states IDLE, VENTILATE, and BOOST driven by CO2 [ppm]. Enter VENTILATE above 1000 [ppm], BOOST above 1500 [ppm], and return toward IDLE with 100 [ppm] hysteresis per boundary. Include a 30 [s] minimum dwell time in each state.
Filter barometric pressure using an exponential moving average (time constant ~10 [s]) and trigger a RAPID_DROP warning if the raw pressure decreases faster than 2 [hPa]/min for at least 3 [min].
Only enable display backlight when light < 120 [lux] AND temperature > 0 [degC] (to protect hardware). Add hysteresis: disable when light > 160 [lux] or temperature ≤ -2 [degC].
Manage a dehumidifier with minimum ON/OFF times: turn ON when humidity ≥ 75 [%], OFF when ≤ 65 [%]; enforce at least 2 [min] ON time and 2 [min] OFF time.

Support a runtime calibration offset for temperature in [degC] (configurable between -2.0 and +2.0 [degC]). Apply it to measurements before evaluating thresholds, and persist the offset across resets.

Implement a high-temperature alarm with a 'mute' input: when temperature > 35 [degC], sound an alarm. If mute is requested, silence the alarm for 10 [min] but keep monitoring and re-latch if temperature exceeds 38 [degC] (safety override).
Trigger a humidity alert only if humidity remains above 80 [%] continuously for 2 [min]; cancel the alert after humidity is below 75 [%] for 2 [min]. Sample at 1 [Hz].
Adapt light-based control with asymmetric filtering: respond immediately (≤ 200 [ms]) to drops below 50 [lux] to turn a lamp ON, but require 5 [s] of readings above 80 [lux] to turn it OFF.

Detect altitude gain using barometric pressure: assert ALTITUDE_REACHED when pressure corresponds to at least 100 [m] ascent from startup baseline (use a standard atmosphere approximation). Provide a manual reset to capture a new baseline.

Design a CO2 alert with multi-threshold behavior: PREALARM above 1200 [ppm], ALARM above 2000 [ppm]. PREALARM can be silenced for 10 [min], but ALARM must remain active until CO2 < 1500 [ppm] for 5 [min] (safety rule).

Perform plausibility checks on temperature [degC] and humidity [%]: flag OUT_OF_RANGE if temperature < -40 or > 85 [degC], or humidity < 0 [%] or > 100 [%]. Suppress control outputs when OUT_OF_RANGE is active.

Use two humidity sensors and take the higher value for safety when deciding to start a dehumidifier (threshold 75 [%]). If the sensor readings differ by more than 10 [%], raise a SENSOR_MISMATCH warning.

Map ambient light [lux] to a target brightness percentage 0–100 [%] with a configurable curve: define three breakpoints (e.g., 50, 500, 5000 [lux]) and linearly interpolate between them. Rate-limit changes to 20 [%]/s.
Capture a barometric baseline at startup and provide drift monitoring: if current pressure deviates by more than ±15 [hPa] from baseline for over 10 [min], raise a DRIFT alert.

Sample humidity at 1 [Hz] and temperature at 5 [Hz]; recompute comfort classification each second using the latest available values. Ensure consistent hysteresis so the classification does not oscillate.

Provide both visual and audible alerts for high temperature: turn on a red LED above 35 [degC] and a buzzer above 38 [degC]. Both alarms clear only after temperature drops below 34 [degC]. Include a 500 [ms] blink pattern for the LED in alarm.

Maintain room temperature at 22.0 [degC] using a PID controller driving a heater output. Sample temperature at 10 [Hz]. Include anti-windup, output clamping, and a safety cutoff that latches an alarm if temperature exceeds 28 [degC]. Budget WCET ≤ 2 [ms] per control cycle.

Fuse two humidity sensors into a single estimate in [%] using a weighted average that de-weights a sensor if it deviates by > 8 [%] from the other. Drive a dehumidifier to 70 [%] setpoint with simple proportional control. Enter FAILSAFE (dehumidifier OFF, alarm ON) if both sensors are invalid. Cycle rate 5 [Hz].

Apply temperature compensation to barometric pressure: compute compensated pressure = raw_pressure − k*(temperature − 25 [degC]) with configurable k [hPa/degC]. Detect rapid weather changes by combining compensated pressure trend (> 3 [hPa]/hr) and absolute threshold (< 985 [hPa]) to raise an EARLY_STORM alarm. WCET ≤ 1 [ms].

Compute an air quality score from CO2 [ppm], VOC index, and PM2.5 [µg/m3] using normalized weighting. Trigger staged responses: NOTICE, WARNING, DANGEROUS at 60/80/95 [%] of worst-case score. Latch DANGEROUS until all inputs return below 70 [%] for 10 [min]. Include sensor timeout and plausibility checks.

Regulate workspace illuminance to 500 [lux] with a PID loop that adjusts a dimming output based on a light sensor. Sample at 50 [Hz], limit output slew to 30 [%]/s, and detect sensor saturation. If illuminance exceeds 800 [lux], raise an over-brightness alarm. Ensure control WCET ≤ 0.5 [ms].

Use three temperature sensors for fault tolerance: compute the median temperature [degC] as the control value; if any sensor deviates by > 1.5 [degC] from the median, flag it as suspect. If two or more are suspect, enter SAFE_SHUTDOWN and latch an overtemp alarm if temperature > 30 [degC].

Prevent condensation on a surface by keeping its temperature at least 3 [degC] above the ambient dew point. Estimate dew point from ambient temperature [degC] and humidity [%], then use a PID loop to regulate a heater on the surface. Safety: hard limit surface temperature to 45 [degC] and latch an alarm if exceeded.

Analyze barometric pressure trends using a windowed linear regression over 15 [min] to forecast storms. Raise ALERT if the slope is ≤ −2 [hPa]/hr and absolute pressure is < 995 [hPa]; escalate to WARNING if ≤ −5 [hPa]/hr. Include hysteresis and a requirement that data gaps > 1 [min] invalidate the window.

Implement proactive ventilation: if the CO2 rise rate exceeds 200 [ppm]/min and absolute CO2 is already above 900 [ppm], preemptively move to BOOST ventilation for 5 [min]. If CO2 surpasses 1800 [ppm], trigger a hard ALARM that cannot be muted until below 1400 [ppm] for 3 [min].

Design a robust acquisition layer for temperature [degC], humidity [%], pressure [hPa], and light [lux]: include timeouts, stale-data detection (> 2× sampling period), outlier rejection (median-of-5), and unit-consistent scaling. Provide aggregate health status and ensure total processing WCET ≤ 1.5 [ms] per cycle.

Create a life-safety air quality supervisor with phases INIT, WARMUP, MONITOR, PURGE, and SAFE_SHUTDOWN. Monitor CO2 [ppm], VOC, and PM2.5 [µg/m3]; compute a health index; and command PURGE when index ≥ 90 [%] for 60 [s]. In SAFE_SHUTDOWN, all actuators OFF and alarm ON. Provide a full test specification: state transition tests, threshold hysteresis tests, sensor-fault injection (stuck-at, timeout), and timing tests with WCET ≤ 2 [ms].

Design a safety-critical cold storage monitor for vaccines with redundant temperature sensors. Modes: NORMAL, WARNING, CRITICAL, and SENSOR_FAULT. Thresholds: WARNING if temperature > −20 [degC], CRITICAL if > −10 [degC]. Require majority voting on three sensors, latched CRITICAL, and an audit log of threshold crossings. Provide verification steps: boundary tests at −20/−10 [degC], fault-masking tests, and deterministic 1 [Hz] update with WCET ≤ 1 [ms].

Define an environmental logging and alarm system that tracks temperature [degC], humidity [%], and pressure [hPa] with user-configurable alarm thresholds and hysteresis per channel. Modes: CONFIG, RUN, SILENCED, and EMERGENCY. Include persistence of settings, rollover-safe counters, time-based alarm persistence (e.g., must persist 30 [s]), and a detailed test plan covering configuration validation, alarm latching/clearing, counter overflow, and WCET profiling.
Create a simple alarm that turns on a red LED whenever the measured temperature exceeds 60 [degC] and turns it off below 60 [degC]. Sample once per second and ensure the alarm logic is deterministic.
Control a humidifier relay from a single humidity sensor: turn ON when humidity drops below 30 [%] and turn OFF when humidity rises above 55 [%]. Include 5 [%] hysteresis to prevent chatter.
Sound a buzzer if indoor CO2 exceeds 1200 ppm. Silence the buzzer when CO2 returns below 1000 ppm. No other behavior.
Monitor barometric pressure in hPa. If pressure falls below 950 hPa, flash a warning LED at 2 Hz; otherwise keep a green LED solid ON. Keep the logic simple and responsive.
Use an illuminance reading to control a nightlight: turn it ON below 20 lux and OFF above 50 lux. Add a minimal 2 s persistence so it doesn't flicker.
Log temperature in [degC] once per second and raise an alarm output if it exceeds 45 [degC]. Clear the alarm once temperature falls back below 43 [degC].
Display the current temperature in [degC] and beep a buzzer continuously if temperature is at or above 80 [degC]; otherwise do not beep.
Trigger a dehumidification alert when humidity exceeds 90 [%]. Keep the alert active until humidity drops below 85 [%].
Turn a ventilation output ON if PM2.5 exceeds 35 µg/m3 and OFF when it drops below 25 µg/m3. Keep the behavior minimal and reliable.
If VOC concentration stays above 400 ppb for 5 s, turn on a warning LED; turn it off when VOC falls below 300 ppb.
Drive a UV alarm LED when the UV index is 7 or higher; keep it off below 7. No other actions.
Control a heater enable signal from temperature: enable when below 5 [degC], disable when at or above 8 [degC]. Hysteresis is required to avoid rapid toggling.
Monitor humidity [%] for plausibility. If the reading is outside 0..100 [%], assert a Fault LED; otherwise keep the Fault LED off.
Drive a status lamp: green when temperature is below 40 [degC], red when temperature is 40 [degC] or higher. Keep the update rate at 1 Hz.
If illuminance remains below 5 lux continuously for 10 s, turn on a pathway indicator. Turn it off only after illuminance has been above 15 lux for 10 s.

Implement a temperature supervision state machine with states: Normal (<35 [degC]), Warning (35..50 [degC]), and Critical (>50 [degC]). Add hysteresis of 2 [degC] between boundaries and drive a buzzer pattern that is faster in Critical. Provide a clear state transition diagram in behavior.

Compute the heat index from temperature [degC] and humidity [%]. Show the computed value and raise an alarm if the heat index exceeds 40 [degC]. Clear the alarm when the heat index falls below 38 [degC].

Sample humidity at 2 Hz, apply a 5-sample median filter, and control a humidifier: ON below 35 [%], OFF above 45 [%]. If the filtered value does not change by at least 1 [%] for 10 minutes, raise a sensor-stuck warning.
Every 10 s, record temperature [degC], humidity [%], and pressure (hPa), updating min/max for each since startup. Assert an alarm if pressure is outside 980..1030 hPa.

Create a Day/Night state machine based on illuminance with thresholds: Night below 20 lux, Day above 100 lux, with hysteresis. Update every 200 ms. Turn on a nightlight in Night and open shades in Day.

If CO2 remains above 1500 ppm for more than 2 minutes, latch a high CO2 alarm that stays active until a user acknowledge input is received and CO2 is below 1200 ppm. Include a visual indicator while latched.

Implement a safety handler: if any sensor (temperature [degC], humidity [%], pressure hPa) reports an implausible value, enter a Safe state that de-energizes outputs and asserts a Fault LED. Remain in Safe until inputs have been valid for 5 s.
Create multi-level humidity alerts: Warning at 70..85 [%] and Critical above 85 [%] with 5 [%] hysteresis between levels. Drive a slow buzzer in Warning and a fast buzzer in Critical.

Read two temperature sensors. If they differ by more than 3 [degC], assert a SensorFault. Otherwise display their average temperature. If one sensor fails, hold last valid average for 10 s while raising a degraded warning.
Detect a storm warning when pressure drops by more than 3 hPa within 30 minutes. Implement a Normal/StormWarning state machine and blink a warning LED at 1 Hz in StormWarning.
Run a periodic task at 10 Hz with Worst-Case Execution Time (WCET) <= 2 ms. Maintain a 5 s rolling average of illuminance; if the average stays below 30 lux for 15 s, assert an energy_save output.

Compute dew point from temperature [degC] and humidity [%]. If dew point is within 2 [degC] of a provided surface temperature, raise a CondensationAlert and latch it until acknowledged and the condition clears.
Implement light detection robust to mains flicker: ignore 50/60 Hz flicker by using hysteresis and require a minimum 500 ms persistence before toggling Day/Night outputs.
Combine PM2.5 and PM10 to classify air quality as Good, Moderate, or Unhealthy based on standard thresholds. Drive a tri-color LED for each level and sound a buzzer if Unhealthy persists for 60 s.
Derive a room comfort status from temperature [degC] and humidity [%]: Comfort, TooHot, TooCold, TooHumid, TooDry. Display the status and beep once when leaving Comfort.

Monitor humidity in two rooms (RoomA and RoomB). Turn on a shared dehumidifier if either room exceeds 65 [%]. Display the higher of the two humidity values and illuminate a per-room warning LED when that room is above threshold.
Estimate altitude from pressure using a provided sea-level pressure. Update at 1 Hz with a 5-sample moving average. Raise an alarm if altitude exceeds 2500 m and clear when it drops below 2400 m.

Combine light and temperature: assert a ShadeCommand when illuminance exceeds 60000 lux and temperature exceeds 30 [degC]; clear when illuminance falls below 40000 lux or temperature falls below 28 [degC].

Implement temperature rate-of-rise monitoring: if the rise exceeds 2 [degC]/min for more than 30 s, assert a PreAlarm. If absolute temperature exceeds 70 [degC], assert an Alarm. Use hysteresis to clear both conditions.

Track moisture exposure: if humidity is above 60 [%] continuously for more than 30 minutes, assert a MoldRisk alarm. Clear only after humidity stays below 55 [%] for 15 minutes. Log exposure durations.

Use PID control to regulate temperature to 25 [degC]. Sample at 10 Hz with anti-windup on actuator saturation. Enforce a hard safety limit: if temperature exceeds 30 [degC], cut output and raise an over-temperature alarm.

Fuse three barometric sensors using 2-out-of-3 voting with outlier rejection to produce a trusted pressure (hPa). Raise a fault if two sensors fail or disagree persistently. Issue a storm alarm if trusted pressure stays below 970 hPa for 10 minutes.

Apply a Kalman-style filter to temperature [degC] and humidity [%] to estimate true values and rate of change. Alarm if temperature rate exceeds 5 [degC]/min or if predicted dew point will cross the surface temperature within 10 minutes.

Compute an overall air quality index (AQI) from PM2.5 (µg/m3), PM10 (µg/m3), O3 (ppb), NO2 (ppb), and CO (ppm). Identify the dominant pollutant and raise a Warning at AQI ≥ 100 and Critical at AQI ≥ 150 with distinct alarm patterns.

Implement 2oo3 voting for three humidity sensors to produce a trusted humidity [%]. If any two readings differ by more than 5 [%], flag a disagreement fault; degrade to 1oo2 fallback when one sensor is failed and assert a safety alarm.

Perform sensor diagnostics for temperature [degC]: detect stuck-at behavior (no change > 1 [degC] over 1 hour), compare against a periodic reference check to estimate drift, and apply a bounded offset trim (±1 [degC]). Raise a Fault if limits are exceeded.

Adapt humidity alarm thresholds based on temperature by controlling absolute humidity. Alarm for mold risk when absolute humidity exceeds 12 g/m3, computed from temperature [degC] and humidity [%]. Clear when it drops below 11 g/m3.

Control a ventilation fan with PID to keep CO2 below 1000 ppm. Limit actuator slew to 10%/s and saturate 0..100%. On CO2 sensor fault, go to fail-safe (fan high) and raise an alarm. Run at 5 Hz with WCET ≤ 3 ms.

Accumulate UV exposure dose (J/m2) from UV index over time and raise an alarm when a daily limit is exceeded. Reset the dose at midnight. If temperature exceeds 35 [degC], escalate the alarm priority.

Compute sea-level pressure from measured pressure (hPa), temperature [degC], and a provided altitude. Warn when corrected pressure is below 980 hPa. Validate unit consistency and handle missing or implausible inputs safely.

Design a multi-mode lab environmental monitor with modes Normal, Calibration, Maintenance, and Fault. Monitor temperature [degC], humidity [%], pressure (hPa), light (lux), and CO2 (ppm). Run a deterministic 20 Hz loop with WCET ≤ 2 ms. Implement latched alarms with manual acknowledge, a startup sensor self-test, and periodic built-in tests. Include a concise test plan covering threshold crossings, hysteresis, fault injection, and timing behavior.

Implement cleanroom monitoring enforcing 21 ± 1 [degC], 45 ± 5 [%] humidity, and +15 Pa differential pressure. Build a Normal/Alert/Critical/Fault state machine with escalating audible/visual alarms and an alarm inhibit window (max 5 min, auto-timeout). Guarantee WCET ≤ 2 ms. Specify at least 10 acceptance test scenarios.

Create a greenhouse multi-zone monitor with 4 temperatures [degC] and 2 humidity [%]. Modes: Day, Night, Heatwave. Compute zone averages and extremes, derive a global comfort index, and drive dehumidifier and shade commands. Include latched multi-level alarms with manual reset, a simulation stub for sensor inputs, and comprehensive unit tests.

Build a networked environmental hub aggregating up to 5 nodes reporting temperature [degC], humidity [%], pressure (hPa), and PM2.5 (µg/m3). Time-synchronize within 100 ms, apply majority voting on conflicting data, and declare Degraded mode if any data age exceeds 30 s. Implement severity levels Info/Warning/Critical with clear rules, enforce WCET ≤ 4 ms, and include a verification checklist.

Develop a safety-certified environmental monitor with modes Normal, Warning, Critical, Sensor_Fault, and Degraded. Compute AQI from PM2.5/PM10/O3/NO2/CO and monitor temperature [degC] for overheat protection. Perform a startup lamp-and-buzzer self-test, service a watchdog each cycle, and ensure alarms fail safe on power loss. Run at 10 Hz with WCET ≤ 1 ms. Provide a detailed test matrix and explicit safety thresholds.

Implement simple control that turns on a cooling fan when ambient temperature [degC] > 30, turns it off when temperature < 28, and triggers a high temperature alarm if temperature > 50 degC at any time. Include hysteresis between 30 and 28 degC to prevent chatter.
Monitor relative humidity [%] and switch on a dehumidifier when humidity >= 70%. Sound an alarm if humidity >= 90% for longer than 10 s. Clear the dehumidifier at 65%.

Watch barometric pressure [hPa]. Turn on a low pressure warning indicator when pressure < 950 hPa and clear it when pressure > 960 hPa. If pressure < 930 hPa at any point, latch a critical alarm until manually reset.

Use a light sensor to turn on a lamp when illuminance [lux] is below 100 and turn it off when above 150. Add a minimum on time of 5 s to avoid flicker and raise an alarm if lux stays below 20 for more than 60 s.

Display a comfort status based on temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%]. Show Comfort when 20 to 24 degC and 40 to 60%. Raise a warning if outside 16 to 28 degC or 30 to 70%, and a critical alarm if temperature < 5 degC or > 45 degC.
Control ventilation using CO2 concentration [ppm]. Turn ventilation on above 1000 ppm and off below 800 ppm. Trigger a high CO2 alarm when reading exceeds 2000 ppm, with a distinct alarm output.
Monitor PM2.5 concentration [ug/m3]. Indicate Poor Air when PM2.5 >= 35 ug/m3, and trigger a health hazard alarm when PM2.5 >= 150 ug/m3. Clear the Poor Air indicator when PM2.5 < 25 ug/m3.
When relative humidity [%] drops below 20%, turn on a humidifier. Turn it off when humidity rises above 30%. Raise a low humidity alarm if humidity goes below 10% at any time.

Add sensor fault detection for temperature [degC]. If the reading is out of plausible range (< -40 or > 85 degC) or remains unchanged for 60 s, set a fault indicator and force outputs to a safe state.
Implement light based night detection using illuminance [lux]. Declare NIGHT when lux < 50 for at least 1 s and DAY when lux > 200 for at least 1 s. Trigger a low light alarm when lux < 10 for 5 s.
Turn on a High Pressure indicator when barometric pressure [hPa] > 1020, and turn it off when below 1015. Provide a single shot notification when pressure crosses 1000 hPa upward.
Monitor TVOC [ppb] and raise an air quality alert when TVOC > 500 ppb. Clear the alert once TVOC < 300 ppb for at least 15 s. Include a safety note that above 1200 ppb triggers a critical alarm.
Implement freeze protection: if temperature [degC] < 2, turn on a heater; turn it off once temperature > 5. If temperature > 60 degC, raise an overheat alarm and inhibit heating.

Use a light sensor to control an indicator with two thresholds: dim mode when illuminance [lux] between 50 and 150, bright mode when below 50, and off when above 150. Add safety that if sensor fails, default to off.
Raise a high humidity alarm if relative humidity [%] > 85% continuously for 5 s, and auto clear when it falls below 80% for 5 s. Keep the logic simple and robust.

Create a temperature alarm state machine with states Normal, Warning, and Critical based on temperature [degC] thresholds 35 and 45, with 2 degC hysteresis between states. Sample at 10 Hz and ensure deterministic transitions.

Compute a heat index warning using temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%]. Indicate Caution, Extreme Caution, and Danger levels with distinct outputs. Add a safety alarm if heat index equivalent exceeds 45 degC.

Read two independent light sensors and control lighting based on their average illuminance [lux]. If their readings differ by more than 20% for 10 s, flag a sensor discrepancy fault and fall back to the lower reading for safety.

Detect storm onset by monitoring barometric pressure [hPa]. At 1 Hz, maintain a 10 minute sliding history and raise a storm warning if pressure drops more than 5 hPa over that window. Include a critical alarm for a drop > 10 hPa.

Control ventilation using both CO2 [ppm] and TVOC [ppb]. Turn ventilation on if either CO2 > 1000 ppm or TVOC > 500 ppb; escalate to high speed if both are above thresholds. Clear only when both fall below 80% of their thresholds.
