Create ozone alerts with hysteresis and levels: warn at >80 [ppb], alarm at >120 [ppb]. Clear both only after falling below 70 [ppb].
Rate-limit notifications so that each alarm type emits at most one message per 60 s, without affecting the actual alarm output pins or flags.

Implement PID control to maintain temperature at 37 [degC] with 10 Hz sampling. Enforce safety: cut the actuator and raise an alarm if temperature exceeds 39 [degC] or on sensor fault. Guarantee WCET <= 2 ms.

Control humidity to 55 [%] using a PID with anti-windup, driving humidifier/dehumidifier outputs. Disable humidification if temperature < 10 [degC] to prevent condensation and raise a safety alert if RH > 85 [%].

Fuse two temperature sensors at 5 Hz using outlier rejection (discard readings deviating by >3 [degC]). Publish the fused temperature, and raise an inconsistency alarm if disagreement persists >15 s. Ensure WCET <= 1 ms.

Filter barometric pressure at 20 Hz (e.g., Kalman/complementary) to estimate altitude and vertical velocity [m/s]. Raise rapid_descent if velocity < -3 [m/s] for >2 s, with plausibility checks and fault flags.

Combine two RH sensors and one temperature sensor to compute dew point and drive a condensation_prevent alarm with 1 [%] hysteresis. Handle single-sensor fallback and raise faults on any sensor failure.

Maintain 500 [lux] at a light sensor using a PID controller on a dimmer output. Constrain output between 0 [%] and 100 [%], rate-limit changes to avoid flicker, and raise alarms if target cannot be achieved.
Integrate PM2.5 [ug/m3] over time to estimate exposure dose in [ug·h/m3]. Raise a daily_dose alarm above 500 [ug·h/m3] and reset the accumulator at local midnight with safe rollover handling.

Derive a 3-level indoor air quality state from CO2 [ppm], TVOC [ppb], and PM2.5 [ug/m3] via rule-based fusion. Escalate to 'Severe' if any two exceed their high thresholds, with persistence timers and latching until manual reset.

Use three redundant temperature sensors with 2-out-of-3 voting. Publish the voted value, identify and isolate the outlier, and enter fail-safe if fewer than two sensors remain healthy. Provide a test input to simulate a stuck sensor.
Detect thermal runaway: if temperature slope exceeds 5 [degC/min] while temperature is above 60 [degC], trigger an emergency_shutdown, sound an alarm, and latch the condition until power cycle.

Design a multi-mode environmental monitor (Normal, Alert, Emergency, Calibration) using a state machine driven by CO2 [ppm], PM2.5 [ug/m3], and O3 [ppb]. Include hysteresis, 5 Hz sampling, hard WCET <= 2 ms, per-mode alarms and sampling rates, and a built-in self-test at startup and on demand.

Develop a two-zone air quality supervisor. Fuse temperature [degC], humidity [%], and PM2.5 [ug/m3] per zone; detect cross-zone leaks via correlated spikes; add a fail-safe mode if time synchronization is lost. Provide comprehensive test cases and acceptance criteria.

Specify an environmental safety controller for a storage room: maintain 2..8 [degC] and 35..55 [%] with priority to temperature. Use coordinated PID loops with interaction limits, define safety thresholds and degraded operation, and verify deterministic timing with WCET <= 3 ms at 10 Hz.

Create a certification-grade smoke/air-quality detector that fuses temperature [degC], light [lux], and PM10/PM2.5 [ug/m3]. Use a multi-stage state machine to distinguish steam/dust/smoke, include plausibility checks, stuck-sensor detection, a calibration window, traceable event logs, and a full test plan with boundary and fault injection cases.

Build an environmental monitoring framework with modes Off, Standby, Run, and Maintenance. Schedule sampling at 1 Hz nominal and 10 Hz during alarms, enforce WCET <= 1 ms with a watchdog heartbeat, manage redundant sensors per variable, implement comprehensive latching alarm logic with manual acknowledgment, and define a verification checklist covering unit tests, timing analysis, and safety thresholds in [degC], [%], lux, [kPa], and [ppm].

Turn on an alarm indicator when ambient temperature exceeds 30 [degC], and turn it off when it falls below 29 [degC] (1 [degC] hysteresis). Sample once per second and ignore any readings outside [-40, 85] [degC] as invalid.
Sound a buzzer if relative humidity rises above 80 [%] for longer than 10 seconds; silence it immediately when humidity drops below 75 [%].
Record barometric pressure in [hPa] once every second and raise a warning if pressure drops by more than 5 [hPa] within 60 seconds.
Switch on a night-light output when illuminance falls below 50 [lux]; switch it off when illuminance is above 60 [lux]. Provide a 2-second debounce to avoid flicker.
Trigger an air quality alert if CO2 exceeds 1000 [ppm] for at least 60 seconds; clear the alert when CO2 is below 800 [ppm] for 30 seconds.
Issue a freeze warning when temperature is below 5 [degC] and a heat warning when above 35 [degC]. Use independent 1 [degC] hysteresis for each threshold.
Map humidity [%] to LED blink rate: 0–30 [%] slow (1 Hz), 30–60 [%] medium (2 Hz), above 60 [%] fast (4 Hz). Ensure rates change only at bracket boundaries.
Turn on a ventilation fan when PM2.5 exceeds 35 [µg/m3]; turn it off when PM2.5 falls below 20 [µg/m3]. Raise a critical alarm if PM2.5 stays above 100 [µg/m3] for 5 minutes.
Sample temperature at 2 Hz, clip values to [-40, 85] [degC], and ignore any spike that differs by more than 10 [degC] from the previous sample. Blink an error indicator upon spike rejection.
Classify ambient light as DAY when above 300 [lux] and NIGHT when below 150 [lux], with hysteresis in between to prevent chatter.
Raise a sensor fault alarm if no new pressure reading (in [hPa]) arrives within 5 seconds, and clear the fault after two consecutive valid updates.
Compute the rolling average of the last five temperature samples in [degC]. If the average changes by more than 2 [degC] between consecutive seconds, assert a stability alarm.
Saturate humidity readings to the valid range 0–100 [%]. If any raw reading is outside this range, flag a data validity alarm for 5 seconds.
At startup, capture ambient light baseline over 3 seconds, then set a threshold at 20 [%] below that baseline to detect sudden darkness; trigger an alert when crossed.
Generate a high-pressure alarm when pressure exceeds 1030 [hPa] and a low-pressure alarm when below 980 [hPa], each with 2 [hPa] hysteresis and distinct indicator patterns.

Implement a three-state temperature monitor: NORMAL (<= 30 [degC]), WARNING (30–35 [degC]), and CRITICAL (> 35 [degC]). In CRITICAL, latch an alarm until a manual acknowledge, even if temperature drops. Use 0.5 [degC] hysteresis between states.

Control a humidifier relay to keep humidity within 45–55 [%]. If humidity remains above 70 [%] for more than 10 minutes, assert a high-humidity alarm and disable the relay. Sampling rate: 1 Hz; WCET per cycle <= 2 ms.
Analyze pressure trend at 1 Hz and classify as RISING, FALLING, or STABLE based on a linear fit over the last 5 minutes. Trigger a storm warning if the drop rate exceeds 1 [hPa/min].

Drive an indicator whose brightness is proportional to ambient light [lux], with minimum and maximum clamps to avoid glare. Raise a sensor saturation alarm if the light sensor reads at its limit for more than 2 seconds.
Compute running medians for PM2.5 [µg/m3] and VOC index. Use two alarm levels: CAUTION and DANGER with 10-second entry delay and 30-second minimum-on time. Indicate levels with distinct blink codes.

Estimate dew point [degC] from temperature [degC] and humidity [%] to detect condensation risk. If dew point is within 2 [degC] of ambient, trigger a condensation warning and start a dehumidifier output.
Use two temperature probes for redundancy. If their difference exceeds 2 [degC], flag a mismatch alarm and prefer the lower of the two for safety until agreement is restored.
Buffer temperature [degC], humidity [%], and pressure [hPa] at 1 Hz into a circular log of the last 10 minutes. Ensure logging never causes the control loop WCET to exceed 5 ms.
Determine DAY and NIGHT via light [lux] with hysteresis and a 30-second debounce. Publish transitions and ensure no more than one transition occurs within any 30-second window.
Ventilation logic: open vent when CO2 > 1200 [ppm], close when < 800 [ppm]. If CO2 remains > 1500 [ppm] for 5 minutes, assert a high-CO2 alarm and keep vent open. Sample at 0.5 Hz.
Calculate heat index in [degC] from temperature [degC] and humidity [%], categorize as SAFE, CAUTION, DANGER, and trigger corresponding alarms with 15-second debounce and 60-second minimum-on time.
Run a humidity calibration workflow with states: IDLE, CALIBRATE (stabilize at 50 [%] reference), SAVE, and ERROR. Time out any step after 120 seconds and raise an error alarm.

Watchdog for sensors: if any reading is NaN or outside its physical range (temperature [-40, 85] [degC], humidity [0, 100] [%], pressure [300, 1100] [hPa], light [0, 120000] [lux]), enter FAILSAFE and latch an alarm until reset.
Monitor temperature rate of change in [degC/min] at 5 Hz. If the rate exceeds 10 [degC/min], assert a rapid-change alarm; clear only after the rate stays below 5 [degC/min] for 30 seconds.
Compute AQI from PM2.5 [µg/m3] using standard breakpoints; output GOOD, MODERATE, UNHEALTHY categories with matching indicator colors and an audible alert for UNHEALTHY.
Display humidity bands with three outputs: DRY (< 30 [%]), COMFORT (30–60 [%]), and HUMID (> 60 [%]). Provide 2 [%] hysteresis around each boundary and update at 2 Hz.
Use two humidity sensors and compute their average for display. If either deviates by more than 5 [%] from the average, mark it suspect, exclude it from the average, and raise a maintenance alarm.

If illuminance stays below 100 [lux] continuously for 30 seconds, set a LOW_LIGHT alarm; clear it after illuminance remains above 150 [lux] for 10 seconds. Implement as a small state machine with timers.

Detect a leak by monitoring pressure [hPa] for a cumulative drop greater than 10 [hPa] within 5 minutes. Escalate to CRITICAL if the drop exceeds 20 [hPa], and keep CRITICAL latched for at least 10 minutes.
Classify thermal comfort using temperature [degC] and humidity [%] into COLD/DRY, COMFORT, and HOT/HUMID zones. Drive three indicators and ensure transitions use 1 [degC] and 3 [%] hysteresis.

Maintain 22.0 [degC] with a PID loop driving a heater output at 10 Hz. Include anti-windup, output saturation, and a hard safety cutoff at 28 [degC] with a latched overtemperature alarm. WCET per tick <= 2 ms.

Regulate humidity to 50 [%] using PID on a humidifier, with temperature-compensated setpoint (reduce target by 1 [%] per 2 [degC] above 24 [degC]). Predict condensation using dew point and suspend humidification if dew point lies within 1 [degC] of ambient. Include alarm logic.

Fuse two pressure sensors with weighted averaging based on recent noise estimates. Reject outliers beyond 3 [hPa] from the fused estimate. Compute sea-level pressure using temperature [degC]. Raise a sensor fault if fusion degrades (weights collapse).

Combine PM2.5 [µg/m3], VOC index, and CO2 [ppm] into a composite air quality score (0–100). Drive three alarm tiers (NOTICE, WARNING, DANGER) with entry/exit timers and a manual acknowledge that silences audio but keeps visual alerts latched.

Use three temperature probes and select the median value for control. If any probe deviates by more than 3 [degC] from the median, mark it faulty and ignore it. If fewer than two probes remain healthy, enter FAILSAFE and raise an alarm.

Compute heat index [degC] and map to occupational risk categories. Enforce a 15-minute maximum exposure timer in DANGER, then require a cooldown period before clearing alarms. Sample at 2 Hz; WCET <= 3 ms.

Perform adaptive illuminance filtering using a moving average and standard deviation to detect and suppress spikes. Calculate flicker amplitude; if flicker exceeds a threshold for 5 seconds, trigger a FLICKER alarm.
Estimate altitude [m] from pressure [hPa] via the barometric formula, corrected by temperature [degC]. Raise an alarm if altitude changes by more than 50 [m] in 10 seconds. Run at 5 Hz; WCET <= 3 ms.

Calibrate a gas sensor: warm-up for 180 seconds, measure baseline VOC in clean air, and compensate for drift over hours. Compute an IAQ score (0–500) and alert if the score worsens continuously for 15 minutes.

Predict mold risk using temperature [degC], humidity [%], and a wall surface temperature probe [degC]. If surface temperature is within 3 [degC] of dew point for more than 30 minutes, assert a MOLD_RISK alarm and prioritize dehumidification over heating.

Design a multi-mode environmental sentinel with modes NORMAL, ENERGY_SAVE, ALERT, and MAINTENANCE. Monitor temperature [degC], humidity [%], pressure [hPa], light [lux], and CO2 [ppm]. Define entry/exit conditions with hysteresis, latching alarms, quiet hours for audio, and degraded operation if any sensor fails. Sample at 2 Hz with WCET <= 4 ms.

Create a two-zone monitor for ROOM_A and ROOM_B that reports temperature [degC], humidity [%], and dew point [degC] per zone. Prioritize alarms when either zone exceeds safety thresholds, support manual acknowledge with auto-rearm, and guarantee a 10 Hz sampling deadline with watchdog supervision.

Specify an early fire indicator using temperature rate-of-rise [degC/min], rapid CO2 increase [ppm/min], and abrupt light drop [lux]. Implement PREALARM and EVACUATE stages with false-positive suppression, per-stage timers, and a WCET budget <= 2 ms.

Develop an environmental control with dual PID loops for temperature [degC] and humidity [%], plus feed-forward from outside air readings. Provide modes NORMAL, RAPID_RECOVERY, and SAFE_SHUTDOWN, with hard safety thresholds (overtemp at 28 [degC], overhumidity at 80 [%]) and a comprehensive test plan covering saturation, sensor faults, and step responses.

Define acceptance tests and behavior for an air quality guardian monitoring PM2.5 [µg/m3], VOC index, and CO2 [ppm]. Include threshold maps, hysteresis, latching alarms, sensor-fault handling, startup calibration, manual reset behavior, and WCET compliance at 1 Hz.

Create a simple over-temperature alarm: read temperature in degC at 1 Hz and raise an alarm when it exceeds 60 degC. Add 2 degC hysteresis so the alarm clears only when temperature drops to 58 degC or below. Ensure the check runs within a 2 ms WCET.
Monitor relative humidity and trigger a 'high humidity' alarm when RH exceeds 85%. Use percent units [%] and clear the alarm only when RH falls to 80% or less.
Watch ambient pressure and assert an alarm if it is outside 980–1030 hPa. Report the current pressure value alongside the alarm state once per second.
Detect low light conditions: if illuminance falls below 50 lux for at least 500 ms, set a night_mode flag; clear it after illuminance stays above 70 lux for 1 s. Sampling rate 10 Hz.
Raise a ventilation_needed flag when CO2 concentration exceeds 1000 ppm, and clear it when CO2 is at or below 900 ppm. Include an on-delay of 3 s to avoid false positives.
Issue an air quality alert if PM2.5 exceeds 35 µg/m3 for more than 60 s. Provide a counter for seconds above threshold.
Generate a freeze_warning when temperature drops below 0 degC. Include a minimum 5 s on-delay to prevent chattering near the threshold.
Signal a dry_air warning when relative humidity falls below 30 [%]. Publish the RH reading every 2 s.
Compute the heat index from ambient temperature (degC) and relative humidity (%), and raise a heat_stress alarm if the heat index exceeds 40 degC for at least 10 s. Run the calculation at 2 Hz.
Sample temperature in degC at 1 Hz and publish the latest reading plus a 'within_comfort_range' boolean that is true between 20–24 degC.
Report relative humidity [%] once per second and assert a humidifier_needed flag when RH is below 35% (clear at 40%).
Set a bright_light flag when illuminance exceeds 20000 lux. Add hysteresis so it clears only after falling to 15000 lux.
Assert a poor_tvoc flag when a total VOC index exceeds 5 (unitless scale), and clear it when it falls to 3 or below.
Expose a comfortable_environment flag that is true only when temperature is between 21–23 degC and RH is between 40–60 [%]. Update once per second.
If both temperature exceeds 35 degC and RH exceeds 70 [%], raise a heat_alert. Clear the alert when either metric returns below those thresholds.
Trigger a warning_beep signal whenever ambient light drops below 10 lux and PM2.5 rises above 25 µg/m3 simultaneously. Evaluate at 5 Hz.

Build a three-state alarm for temperature: Normal below 50 degC, Warning between 50–60 degC sustained 5 s, and Critical above 60 degC sustained 2 s; include hysteresis of 2 degC on transitions. Update at 5 Hz.

Calculate dew point (degC) from temperature (degC) and RH (%) and assert a condensation_risk alarm when dew point is within 2 degC of measured temperature for longer than 30 s. Ensure decisions within 5 ms WCET.
Monitor barometric pressure trend: compute a 15-minute linear trend (hPa/hour) and raise a storm_warning if the drop exceeds 6 hPa/hour. Use 1 Hz sampling and a sliding window.
Implement a day/night state machine based on illuminance with thresholds 70 lux (enter night) and 120 lux (enter day), each with a minimum dwell time of 60 s to avoid rapid toggling.
Create escalating CO2 alarms with three levels: Advisory at ≥800 ppm, Caution at ≥1200 ppm, and Danger at ≥2000 ppm. Include 60 s persistence to escalate and 30 s persistence to de-escalate.
Perform plausibility checking on a humidity sensor: flag sensor_fault if the reading is stuck within ±0.1% for more than 20 s or jumps by more than 15% in one sample. Suppress alarms while faulted.
Apply a moving average (window 10 samples) to PM2.5 readings while also exposing the raw value. Trigger alerts based on the filtered value crossing 25 µg/m3 for 30 s.
Schedule sensor polls so temperature, humidity, pressure, and light are sampled at 10 Hz, but computed summaries (min/max/average) are updated at 1 Hz. Guarantee per-cycle WCET under 3 ms.
Compute a rolling 5-minute average PM2.5 and raise a long_term_exposure alert if it exceeds 15 µg/m3. Also report the current 1-minute average.
Detect rapid temperature rise: alarm if temperature increases faster than 0.5 degC per minute, sustained for at least 2 minutes.
Cross-check two temperature sensors: if their difference exceeds 2 degC for more than 10 s, assert a discrepancy flag; otherwise publish the average temperature (degC).

Implement a comfort_index (0–100) derived from temperature (degC) and RH (%), and categorize states as Comfortable (≥80), Moderate (50–79), or Uncomfortable (<50). Provide a corresponding status output.
Create an air_quality state machine using CO2 (ppm) and PM2.5 (µg/m3): states Good, Fair, Poor, and Hazardous with configurable thresholds and 10 s debounce on transitions.
Add alarm on-delay/off-delay behavior: for a high humidity alert (>80%), require 15 s above threshold to turn on, and 30 s below 75% to turn off. Run checks at 2 Hz.
Implement stale_data detection: if any sensor input (temperature, RH, pressure, light) is not updated within 2 s, set a stale flag and inhibit downstream alerts.
Compute sea-level pressure (hPa) from measured pressure and temperature, using a fixed altitude parameter. Raise an alarm if sea-level pressure is outside 980–1030 hPa.
Track the daily maximum temperature and time of occurrence. Reset the daily maximum on a daily_reset trigger, and assert a high_temp_today alert if the max exceeds 35 degC.

Detect long-term sensor drift: maintain a 24-hour exponential moving average of temperature and compare to the last 10-minute average; if the deviation exceeds 3 degC without corresponding RH change (>5%), raise a drift_suspected flag.

Validate sensor ranges: temperature must be -40 to 85 degC, RH 0–100 %, pressure 300–1100 hPa, light 0–120000 lux. If any reading is out-of-range, raise sensor_range_error and ignore it in calculations.
Combine RH and temperature to compute absolute humidity (g/m3) and assert an alert if it exceeds 20 g/m3 for longer than 1 minute.

Fuse two redundant temperature sensors and one humidity sensor to estimate operative temperature: reject outliers >3 degC from median, then compute a weighted average and produce a fused temp (degC) plus a sensor_fault flag. Use 5 Hz updates and cap WCET at 4 ms.

Design a PID controller that outputs a recommended fan_speed (0–100%) to keep CO2 near 800 ppm. Use anti-windup clamping and limit rate-of-change to 10%/s. Declare immediate safety override to 100% if CO2 exceeds 3000 ppm.

Apply a Kalman filter to barometric pressure (hPa) to estimate both pressure and its derivative (hPa/s). Trigger a fast_drop alarm if derivative < -0.01 hPa/s for 60 s. Ensure the filter step executes within 3 ms WCET at 10 Hz.

Fuse illuminance from two light sensors placed at different angles: perform outlier rejection, then compute a weighted lux value and a glare_risk index. Raise glare_alert when glare_risk > 0.7 for 5 s.

Compute altitude (m) from pressure with temperature compensation and a configurable reference pressure. Raise a sudden_altitude_change alert if altitude changes >5 m within 1 s. Sample at 20 Hz with WCET ≤ 2 ms.
Perform temperature-compensated RH: correct the humidity reading to a 25 degC reference using saturation vapor pressure curves, output corrected_RH [%], and alarm if corrected_RH > 70%.

Fuse CO2 (ppm) and VOC index to compute an indoor air quality score (0–100). Define score bands and drive a four-level alarm with latching behavior on the worst band. Provide de-latch only after 2 minutes in a better band.

Implement dual-sensor voting for temperature (three sensors): use 2-out-of-3 majority voting to produce the reported temperature (degC) and isolate the faulty sensor if it deviates >2 degC from the voted value for 30 s.

Estimate dew point using a numerically stable method and feed it into a PID that outputs a dehumidify_command (0–100%) to target a dew point of 10 degC. Limit integral windup and saturate output. Safety: if RH exceeds 90%, force output to ≥50%.

Design a multi-mode environmental monitor with modes Normal, PowerSave, Calibration, and Emergency. Monitor temperature (degC), relative humidity [%], pressure (hPa), light (lux), CO2 (ppm), and PM2.5 (µg/m3). Define mode-specific sampling rates (e.g., Normal 10 Hz, PowerSave 1 Hz), alarm behaviors, and transitions (e.g., enter Emergency on CO2 ≥ 3000 ppm or temperature ≥ 70 degC). Enforce a per-cycle WCET ≤ 5 ms and deterministic state transitions. Provide clear mode status outputs.

Create a fault-tolerant monitoring system with dual temperature sensors and dual humidity sensors. Implement automatic failover, sensor voting, and a degraded_mode when redundancy is lost. Include startup self-tests (range checks in degC, %, hPa, lux, ppm) and periodic built-in tests every 10 minutes. Specify comprehensive tests for thresholds, hysteresis, and persistence timers.

Implement an adaptive threshold manager with Day and Night modes (based on light in lux) and Seasonal profiles (Heatwave vs ColdSnap selected via configuration). Adjust limits for temperature (degC), RH (%), and CO2 (ppm) per mode, with a top-level state machine coordinating mode transitions. Provide verification requirements: boundary tests for each threshold, mode transition coverage, and timing checks (decision latency < 50 ms).

Build an alarm orchestrator that consolidates multiple environmental alerts (CO2, PM2.5, temperature, humidity) into unified Normal/Advisory/Caution/Danger system states. Include latching of Danger until acknowledged and safe auto-clear rules, prioritization when multiple sources compete, and a heartbeat output. Mandate WCET ≤ 3 ms and provide a test plan with fault injection (stuck readings, noise bursts).

Specify a greenhouse safety monitor with modes Normal, Ventilate, and Evacuate. Use temperature (degC), RH (%), CO2 (ppm), and light (lux) to drive transitions, with Evacuate entered immediately on CO2 ≥ 5000 ppm or temperature ≥ 80 degC. Include a sensor_fault handling strategy (enter FailSafe if any reading is out-of-range), rate limiting on mode changes (≥30 s dwell), and exhaustive acceptance tests (boundary values, timing, and fault scenarios).
Monitor a temperature sensor in [degC]; if it exceeds 50 [degC], turn on an alarm and latch it until the reading falls below 45 [degC]. Sample once per second.
Please read humidity in [%]; when below 30 [%], illuminate a warning LED; when above 70 [%], sound a buzzer. Keep alarms mutually exclusive.
Keep it simple: measure ambient light in lux and switch a status LED on when it falls below 100 lux, off above 150 lux. Include a 2 second delay before changing state to avoid flicker.
Measure barometric pressure in hPa; raise a warning if it drops more than 5 hPa within 10 minutes. Ignore changes smaller than 0.5 hPa.
Continuously display temperature in [degC] and humidity in [%] at 2 Hz; if either sensor fails to update for 5 seconds, flash an alarm indicator.
If temperature rises above 80 [degC], cut power to a heater relay and assert an overheat alarm; automatically clear when back below 70 [degC].
Read air quality (TVOC) in ppb; if above 600 ppb for more than 10 seconds, trigger ventilation alarm and log the event timestamp.
When humidity exceeds 85 [%], show 'condensation risk' on an indicator; clear when below 80 [%]. Check every 500 ms.
Compute heat index from temperature [degC] and humidity [%]; if heat index > 35 [degC], activate a warning LED.
Sample pressure at 1 Hz; if absolute pressure < 950 hPa, beep twice per minute until it returns to >= 950 hPa.
Monitor temperature [degC]; if it changes faster than 2 [degC]/min, blink an alert to indicate rapid thermal shift.
At very bright light levels > 50,000 lux, assert a 'bright light' warning; otherwise keep off. Update at 10 Hz.
Trigger an alarm if humidity [%] sensor reads invalid or out of range (<0 [%] or >100 [%]); otherwise do nothing.
Read CO2 in ppm; if above 1200 ppm, turn on a ventilation request output; clear when below 1000 ppm. Limit evaluation to once per second.
Display dew point computed from temperature [degC] and humidity [%]; if dew point is within 2 [degC] of ambient, flag a condensation warning.

Create a two-state monitor for temperature [degC]: NORMAL and OVERHEAT. Transition to OVERHEAT when >= 75 [degC] for 3 consecutive samples at 2 Hz; transition back to NORMAL when <= 70 [degC]. Drive separate LEDs for each state.
Implement humidity [%] hysteresis control with a fan output: turn fan on above 65 [%], off below 55 [%]. Add a safety alarm if temperature exceeds 60 [degC] at any time.

Combine temperature [degC] and humidity [%] to compute a comfort index; set three indicator levels: COMFORT, WARM, HUMID. Update at 5 Hz with debouncing so that state changes require stability for 2 seconds.
Monitor pressure trend using a rolling window over 10 minutes sampled at 0.5 Hz. If pressure drops steadily and temperature [degC] is below 5 [degC], raise a storm alert.
Make the alarm buzzer pattern different for high temperature (> 80 [degC]) and high humidity (> 90 [%]); ensure only the highest severity pattern plays when both occur.
Track minimum and maximum temperature [degC] and humidity [%] over the last 24 hours; reset the extrema at midnight, and raise an alarm if the daily max temperature exceeds 70 [degC].

Design a state machine with states: INIT, MONITORING, SENSOR_FAULT, ALARM_SILENCED. On startup (INIT), check sensor presence; enter MONITORING if OK. If sensor gives out-of-range values, go to SENSOR_FAULT. If alarm is active and a user silences it, stay in ALARM_SILENCED for 5 minutes before returning to MONITORING.
Sample light level at 20 Hz and compute a moving average over 1 second. Use averaged value to control an indicator with thresholds at 50 lux and 200 lux, with 10% hysteresis.
Implement rate limiting: publish temperature [degC] and humidity [%] readings no faster than 1 Hz, but compute alarms internally at 10 Hz.
If temperature [degC] surpasses a configurable threshold T_high and humidity [%] exceeds H_high simultaneously, raise a combined 'heat stress' alarm; include a 30-second hold-on after clearing.
Detect sensor stall: if the pressure reading remains unchanged to within 0.1 hPa for 2 minutes while temperature [degC] varies by more than 1 [degC], flag a pressure sensor fault.
Schedule periodic self-checks: every hour, take 5 rapid samples at 50 Hz of temperature [degC] to assess noise; if standard deviation exceeds 0.5 [degC], mark sensor degraded and light a warning.
Implement sunrise detection using light readings: when lux crosses from below 50 to above 300 lux within 10 minutes and humidity [%] is below 95 [%], assert 'daytime' state.
Add a manual alarm acknowledge input that silences active alarms for 15 minutes, but only if temperature is under 60 [degC]; otherwise ignore the acknowledge.
Compute absolute humidity from temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%], and trigger a 'dry air' alert if absolute humidity falls below 5 g/m^3 for more than 2 minutes.
Monitor air quality index derived from PM2.5 and TVOC; select one of four LEDs: GOOD, FAIR, POOR, HAZARDOUS. If any sensor fails, blink the HAZARDOUS LED until recovery.
Implement a watchdog on sensor update timing: if any of temperature [degC], humidity [%], or pressure fails to update within 1 second of its expected rate, raise a 'data timeout' alarm.
Add hysteresis and debounce to a condensation risk alarm: compute dew point and compare to ambient temperature [degC]; alarm when T - Td < 1.5 [degC] for 3 seconds, clear when T - Td > 2.5 [degC].

Design an averaging filter for CO2 ppm readings sampled at 2 Hz, rejecting spikes greater than 15% from the previous average. Raise an alarm if the filtered value exceeds 1500 ppm for more than 60 seconds.

Detect rapid light transitions indicating flicker: if lux varies by more than 20% peak-to-peak within 100 ms for 5 consecutive windows, set a 'flicker detected' flag; ensure CPU utilization stays under 10%.

Maintain a target temperature of 25 [degC] using a fan with PID control on error; enforce output saturation limits and raise an overrun alarm if the control loop misses its 50 ms deadline (WCET 10 ms).

Fuse two redundant temperature sensors (A and B) in [degC] using a median or outlier-rejecting average; if |A-B| > 2 [degC] for more than 5 seconds, declare a disagreement fault and prefer the lower reading for safety.
Estimate room humidity [%] using a complementary filter combining a slow accurate sensor and a fast noisy sensor. Use the estimate for alarms and report both raw and fused values at 1 Hz.
Implement a barometric pressure trend estimator with a Kalman filter at 5 Hz; issue an early storm warning when the filtered drop rate exceeds 1 hPa/hour while temperature [degC] < 10 [degC].

Control a dehumidifier with PID on humidity [%] to maintain 55 [%], with integral windup protection and a failsafe that shuts down if temperature exceeds 50 [degC]. Log any time the actuator saturates for more than 30 seconds.

Perform sensor fusion for light using two photodiodes with different ranges; combine to produce a continuous lux estimate and detect saturation. If both saturate and temperature [degC] > 70 [degC], trigger thermal caution.

Implement a robust dew point calculation using fused temperature [degC] and humidity [%]; if dew point approaches ambient within 1 [degC] while pressure drops > 2 hPa in 30 minutes, escalate to a high-risk condensation alarm.

Design a multi-variable air quality index combining CO2, TVOC, and PM2.5; apply exponential smoothing with a 30-second time constant. If index crosses a severe threshold for 2 minutes, assert ALARM and rate-limit alarm toggling to once every 60 seconds.

Execute a periodic self-calibration mode every 24 hours: compare two temperature [degC] sensors, adjust an offset if drift < 0.5 [degC]. Abort calibration and raise a fault if temperature changes faster than 1 [degC]/min during the process.

Implement a 100 Hz monitoring loop with WCET 5 ms that computes heat index and triggers fan boost when heat index > 32 [degC]. If WCET is exceeded, set a performance fault and degrade the loop to 50 Hz.

Build a multi-mode environmental monitor with modes: NORMAL, ALERT, EMERGENCY, CALIBRATION, and MAINTENANCE. Inputs: temperature [degC], humidity [%], pressure, light, CO2. Define transitions based on thresholds (e.g., EMERGENCY if temperature > 85 [degC] or CO2 > 2000 ppm), allow manual entry into CALIBRATION and MAINTENANCE, and ensure alarms behave differently per mode.

Specify a comprehensive test plan for a humidity [%] and temperature [degC] alarm system: include boundary tests at thresholds, hysteresis behavior, sensor dropout, stuck-at faults, timing jitter up to 20 ms, and verification that alarm latching and manual acknowledge work correctly.

Create a resilient monitoring system with dual redundant sensors for temperature [degC] and humidity [%] plus a single pressure sensor. Use majority voting, detect and isolate a faulty channel, and continue operation in a degraded mode with clear annunciation. Include timing constraints: 10 Hz sample rate, WCET 6 ms.

Design a greenhouse monitor with modes DAY and NIGHT affecting alarm thresholds for temperature [degC] and humidity [%]. Incorporate PID humidity control in DAY only, and require deterministic behavior: worst-case alarm evaluation must complete within 8 ms at 20 Hz. Provide an operator test sequence to validate all modes.

Specify a full-featured air quality monitor that fuses CO2, TVOC, PM2.5, and temperature [degC] into a health score. Include NORMAL/WARNING/CRITICAL modes, watchdogs for data freshness, self-test on startup, hysteresis and debounce, detailed alarm logic, and a requirement to log and time-stamp every mode transition.
Read the ambient temperature in [degC] once per second and turn on a red alarm indicator if it exceeds 45 degC; turn it off otherwise.
Monitor relative humidity in [%] and activate a warning buzzer whenever humidity falls below 30%.
Sample barometric pressure in hPa; if pressure drops below 980 hPa, switch on a yellow alert LED.
If PM2.5 concentration exceeds 35 ug/m3, raise an air quality alarm; otherwise keep the alarm silent.
Drive a heater output ON when temperature is below 18 [degC], and OFF when temperature is at or above 18 [degC].
Switch a dehumidifier ON when humidity is above 65 [%]; turn it OFF when humidity is 65% or less.
Trigger a freeze warning if temperature drops below 0 [degC]; clear the warning when temperature rises to or above 0 [degC].
Control a status LED to blink slowly when air quality is good (CO2 <= 800 ppm) and glow solid when CO2 > 800 ppm.
Raise a glare alert if ambient light exceeds 20000 lux; no alert otherwise.
Every 500 ms, read humidity [%]; if it is between 40% and 60%, set a comfort flag, else clear it.
Turn on an alarm relay when temperature exceeds 60 [degC]; this is a safety cutoff.
Set a visual indicator to green if pressure is between 990 and 1020 hPa, otherwise set it to red.
If relative humidity reaches 90 [%] or more, emit a beeping alarm; stop beeping when it falls below 90 [%].
Publish a simple status message: SAFE when temperature is <= 35 [degC] and humidity <= 70 [%], otherwise UNSAFE.
Sound an air quality alarm if TVOC index is above 5; silence it otherwise.

Implement humidity control with hysteresis: turn dehumidifier ON when humidity > 65 [%], OFF when humidity < 55 [%]; also raise a high humidity alarm if humidity stays > 80 [%] for more than 2 minutes.
Read two independent temperature sensors in [degC]; if their difference exceeds 2 [degC], latch a sensor fault alarm; otherwise use the lower of the two for safety decisions.
Compute dew point [degC] from ambient temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%]; assert a condensation warning when dew point is within 2 [degC] of a provided surface temperature input.

Design a simple state machine with states Idle, Monitoring, and Alarm. Begin in Idle for 5 s warm-up, then Monitoring. Transition to Alarm if temperature > 55 [degC] or humidity > 90 [%]. Provide a manual acknowledge input to silence the buzzer but keep Alarm state latched until conditions return to safe levels.
Track barometric pressure and generate a storm alert if pressure falls by more than 5 hPa within 30 minutes; clear the alert when the trend stabilizes.
Generate graded ventilation signals based on CO2: Level 0 if <= 800 ppm, Level 1 if 801-1200 ppm, Level 2 if 1201-2000 ppm, and an alarm if > 2000 ppm; include hysteresis of 50 ppm between bands.

Control a fan with three speeds using the higher demand from temperature and humidity: speed 1 when temp > 28 [degC] or RH > 65 [%], speed 2 when temp > 32 [degC] or RH > 75 [%], speed 3 and alarm when temp > 38 [degC] or RH > 85 [%].
Calculate heat index from temperature [degC] and humidity [%] and trigger a heat-stress alarm if heat index > 40 [degC]; include a 30 s delay before clearing.

Ignore the first 10 s of sensor readings after power-up, then start monitoring temperature [degC] and humidity [%] with thresholds; any reading outside 0-100 [%] or -40 to 85 [degC] must be treated as invalid and raise a sensor fault alarm.
Apply a moving average over the last 8 samples of ambient light; turn on a darkness indicator when the average < 100 lux for at least 5 consecutive samples; turn off when the average > 150 lux.
Sample humidity at 10 Hz and assert a high-humidity alarm when at least 7 of the last 10 samples exceed 80 [%]; clear when at least 7 of the last 10 are below 75 [%].
Monitor a safe operating envelope: temperature between 10 and 40 [degC] and pressure between 980 and 1030 hPa; if outside, latch an environmental alarm and record which boundary was violated.

Detect sensor stuck-at faults: if temperature reading does not change by at least 0.1 [degC] over 5 minutes while humidity varies, raise a stuck temperature sensor alarm and drive outputs to a safe state.
Raise a rapid humidity rise alert if RH increases faster than 10 [%]/min; clear after 10 minutes of stable readings.
Use ambient light to select mode: Day if > 1000 lux, Night otherwise; in Night mode, tighten the high-humidity alarm threshold to 70 [%] instead of 80 [%].
Implement latching alarm logic for temperature > 60 [degC]; once tripped, the alarm stays on until a manual reset is pressed and temperature has fallen below 55 [degC].
Maintain relative humidity within 45-55 [%] by toggling a fan: when RH > 55 [%], run the fan for 2 minutes; when RH < 45 [%], keep the fan off; otherwise pulse 10 s on and 50 s off.
Sample temperature and humidity at 5 Hz with a processing WCET of 2 ms per cycle; if the cycle ever overruns, raise a timing alarm and disable nonessential indicators to stay within budget.
Only assert a poor air alarm when both CO2 > 1200 ppm and PM2.5 > 25 ug/m3 for at least 60 s; clear when either drops below its threshold for 60 s.

Implement a PID controller to maintain ambient temperature at 25 [degC] with anti-windup and actuator saturation. Run at 20 Hz with a WCET <= 1 ms. If temperature exceeds 80 [degC], cut power and latch a safety alarm requiring manual reset.
Read three RH sensors; use the median value [%] for control; raise a sensor fault alarm if any sensor deviates by more than 8 [%] from the median for longer than 30 s.
Fuse two humidity sensors (RH1 and RH2) in [%] using outlier rejection: if their difference is <= 5 [%], use their average; otherwise trust the lower value and raise a sensor discrepancy alarm.

Apply a Kalman filter to barometric pressure (hPa) with temperature [degC] as a known input affecting process noise; estimate smoothed pressure and raise a rapid drop alarm when the filtered pressure slope is below -0.3 hPa/min for 10 minutes.

Compute a composite air quality score from CO2 (ppm), PM2.5 (ug/m3), and humidity [%], mapping to levels Good, Moderate, and Unhealthy. Latch Unhealthy when CO2 > 1500 or PM2.5 > 55 or RH < 25 [%] or RH > 85 [%]; require manual reset and a 10-minute safe window before clearing.

Develop a fault-tolerant monitoring loop running at 10 Hz with a 3 ms WCET. If any sensor misses two consecutive updates, enter a Safe state that disables actuators and asserts an alarm until recovery is verified for 30 s.
Use PID control on fan speed to keep CO2 below 800 ppm while also limiting RH to <= 65 [%]. Prioritize CO2; if RH exceeds 80 [%], override to maximum fan and raise a high-humidity alarm.
Monitor temperature slew rate and alarm on dangerous ramps: assert if dT/dt exceeds +5 [degC]/min or -5 [degC]/min for at least 10 s; include rate limiting on alarm toggling to avoid chatter.
Compensate RH readings for sensor self-heating using temperature [degC] with a configurable bias curve. Alarm if compensated RH goes outside 0-100 [%] or if the compensation exceeds 5 [%].

Implement adaptive sampling: when |dT/dt| < 0.2 [degC]/min and |dRH/dt| < 1 [%]/min, sample at 1 Hz; when thresholds are exceeded, sample at 10 Hz. Guarantee processing WCET under 2 ms at 10 Hz; if violated, fall back to 5 Hz and raise a timing warning.

Fuse three temperature sensors with a variance-weighted average. Update weights every minute; if any sensor deviates by more than 3 [degC] from the fused estimate for over 30 s, flag it as faulty and exclude it until it stays within 1 [degC] for 5 minutes.

Design a multi-mode environmental monitor with modes Normal, Energy-Saving, and Emergency. Use temperature [degC], humidity [%], and CO2 (ppm) to drive transitions with clear thresholds and hysteresis. Specify sampling rates per mode (for example, 2 Hz Normal, 1 Hz Energy-Saving, 10 Hz Emergency), WCET budgets, fail-safe actions, and a test plan covering all transitions, latching alarms, and boundary conditions.

Implement a two-zone monitoring system for Zone A and Zone B, each with temperature [degC] and humidity [%]. Provide modes Independent and Linked; in Linked mode, a safety alarm is raised if either zone exceeds limits (T > 60 [degC], RH > 90 [%]). Define timing constraints at 10 Hz, WCET <= 2 ms, sensor fault handling, and comprehensive tests for cross-zone discrepancies and recovery.

Create a wildfire smoke response state machine using PM2.5 and CO2 with states Clear, Caution, Hazard, and Shelter. Define thresholds (for example, PM2.5 >= 150 ug/m3 triggers Hazard), persistence timers, manual override behavior, and latching logic. Include verification criteria such as invariants that Shelter cannot exit until PM2.5 < 50 for 60 minutes and CO2 < 1000 ppm, plus timing budget checks.

Develop a heatwave protection controller with modes Precool, Sustain, and Emergency Shutoff driven by temperature [degC] and humidity [%]. Include a PID temperature loop with output limits, safety thresholds (cut off at 80 [degC]), dehumidifier duty cycling, WCET <= 2 ms at 20 Hz, and a validation suite with simulated ramps, sensor faults, and timing overruns.

Specify a comprehensive environmental safety supervisor coordinating temperature [degC], humidity [%], pressure (hPa), light (lux), and air quality metrics. Define modes Startup Self-Test, Monitoring, Degraded, and Alarmed Shutdown with watchdog timers, redundancy management, periodic built-in tests, and acceptance criteria covering boundary values, hysteresis correctness, alarm latching, and worst-case execution timing.
Turn on the cooling fan whenever ambient temperature exceeds 30 degC and turn it off otherwise. If temperature reaches 40 degC, raise a high-temperature alarm.
Trigger a buzzer alarm if relative humidity falls below 30% or rises above 80%. Indicate normal with a green LED when humidity is between 40% to 60%.
If barometric pressure is outside the safe range 980 hPa to 1040 hPa, light a yellow warning LED; otherwise keep green. Sample once per second.
Switch on the night light when ambient illuminance drops below 100 lux, and switch it off when it is 150 lux or higher. Add a critical alarm if the light sensor reports invalid data.
If CO2 concentration exceeds 1000 ppm continuously for 60 s, sound an alarm and set a red indicator; clear it when the level stays below 800 ppm for 60 s.
Turn on a red LED whenever PM2.5 exceeds 35 µg/m3; green when below. Also blink the red LED at 2 Hz if PM2.5 exceeds 100 µg/m3.
Create a latching over-temperature alarm that activates when temperature exceeds 50 degC and remains active until a manual reset input is received, even if temperature drops.
Control a dehumidifier: turn it on when humidity is greater than 60% and turn it off when humidity falls below 55%. Raise a safety alarm if humidity exceeds 90%.
Detect temperature sensor faults: if the reading is below -40 degC or above 125 degC, flag a sensor error and enter a safe state with an alarm.
If ambient light exceeds 8000 lux, issue a glare warning beep for 2 s; otherwise remain silent.
Sample relative humidity at 1 Hz and trigger an alarm whenever it exceeds 90%. Clear the alarm once it returns below 85%.
Indicate fresh air quality with a blue LED when CO2 is below 400 ppm. Turn the LED off otherwise.
Alert if air pressure drops below 980 hPa for more than 30 s. Keep a green LED on when above 990 hPa.
Show a comfort indicator: light green when temperature is between 18 degC and 26 degC and humidity between 40% and 60%; otherwise light amber.
If the volatile organic compounds (TVOC) reading exceeds 500 ppb, activate an alarm; clear it when it falls below 300 ppb.

Implement a three-state monitor for ambient temperature: NORMAL (<30 degC), WARNING (30 to 39.9 degC), CRITICAL (>=40 degC). Drive green/yellow/red LEDs accordingly and sound the buzzer only in CRITICAL. Include 1 degC hysteresis on state transitions.

Use hysteresis to control a cooling fan from temperature with two thresholds: turn on at 28 degC and off at 26 degC. Add a separate safety cutoff that disables the system and raises an alarm if temperature exceeds 60 degC.
Compute the heat index from temperature [degC] and humidity [%] and classify as SAFE, CAUTION, or DANGER. Trigger an audible alarm in DANGER and a visual warning in CAUTION.

Create a PM2.5 state machine with NORMAL (<35 µg/m3), ALERT (35 to 99 µg/m3), and HAZARD (>=100 µg/m3). Blink yellow in ALERT, blink red faster in HAZARD. Require a manual reset to clear from HAZARD after PM2.5 stays below 35 µg/m3 for 5 min.
Poll temperature, humidity, and pressure at 10 Hz, 2 Hz, and 1 Hz respectively within a 50 ms major cycle; ensure WCET of the loop is <= 10 ms. Raise an alarm if any sampling deadline is missed.
Use a 5 s moving average of illuminance (lux) to decide day/night status. Require the condition to hold for 10 s before switching states to avoid flicker. Alarm if the lux sensor saturates.
Detect rapid pressure drops exceeding 5 hPa within 2 minutes and raise a storm warning alarm; decay the warning after 10 minutes with no further drops.
Provide a calibration mode entered by holding a button for 3 s: capture current ambient light as baseline and store an offset. Include a safety confirmation blink pattern before committing.
Monitor data freshness: if temperature, humidity, or pressure readings are older than 5 s, raise a sensor-stale alarm and set outputs to a safe default.
Read two temperature sensors and cross-check: if their difference exceeds 2 degC, flag a discrepancy alarm; otherwise use their average for display and threshold checks.
Calculate dew point [degC] from temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%]. If dew point exceeds 18 degC, assert a condensation risk alarm until dew point drops below 16 degC.

Ventilation staging based on CO2: Stage 0 (<800 ppm), Stage 1 (800 to 1200 ppm), Stage 2 (>=1200 ppm). Enforce a minimum on-time of 2 minutes when a stage is entered. Sound an alarm if CO2 >= 1500 ppm.
Create day/night profiles: when ambient light < 50 lux (night), use a humidity upper limit of 70%; when >= 50 lux (day), use 60%. Alarm if exceeded with the appropriate profile.
Combine PM2.5 and PM10 for air quality: trigger a warning if PM2.5 > 25 µg/m3 or PM10 > 50 µg/m3; trigger a hazard alarm if both exceed their limits simultaneously.

Implement an alarm acknowledgment function: when any environmental alarm occurs, latch it and require a user acknowledgment input to silence the buzzer; keep the indicator red until the parameter returns to safe levels.
Filter humidity [%] using a median of the last 5 samples to reduce spikes before comparing against thresholds of 30% and 80%. Indicate out-of-range with a yellow LED.
Count and expose the total number of times each alarm (temperature, humidity, pressure, light) has been triggered since power-up; cap the counters at 65535.
Only escalate CO2 to an audible alarm when ambient light is above 200 lux (likely occupied); otherwise show a silent visual warning. Use CO2 thresholds of 1000 ppm and 1500 ppm.
Log temperature [degC], humidity [%], and pressure [hPa] every 5 s and maintain rolling min/max over the last 1 hour. Raise an alarm if min temperature < 0 degC or max > 35 degC.

Implement a gas sensor warm-up: for the first 120 s after power-on, suppress TVOC alarms and show amber. After warm-up, use thresholds 500 ppb (warning) and 1500 ppb (critical) with corresponding alarms.

Use PID control to maintain ambient temperature at 22 degC using a heater output (0 to 100%). Limit the output if humidity exceeds 70% and trigger a safety shutdown with alarm if temperature rises above 45 degC. Sampling period 200 ms.

Fuse readings from three temperature sensors using a median voter; if any sensor deviates more than 3 degC from the median, exclude it and raise a fault alarm. Continue operation with the remaining sensors.
Apply a complementary filter to combine a slow-responding humidity sensor with a fast-responding one to estimate true humidity [%]. Use the fused value for alarms at <30% and >80%.
Implement an estimator to smooth barometric pressure [hPa] and detect sudden steps; raise an alarm if an innovation spike suggests a sensor fault. Ensure loop WCET <= 5 ms at 50 Hz.
Adaptive PM2.5 thresholding: compute a 30-minute moving baseline and alarm when PM2.5 exceeds max(35 µg/m3, baseline + 25 µg/m3); escalate to critical at baseline + 75 µg/m3.
PID-controlled ventilation to keep CO2 below 900 ppm by modulating a fan (0 to 100% PWM). Add hard safety limits at 1500 ppm (critical alarm, max fan) and 2000 ppm (evacuate alarm). Sample at 1 Hz.

Compute absolute humidity [g/m3] from temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%], then constrain a humidifier output using a PI controller to reach 10 g/m3. Stop and alarm if condensation risk occurs (dew point >= 18 degC).

Implement fault-tolerant humidity monitoring with two sensors: if they differ by >10%, vote the lower value for safety and raise a discrepancy alarm; if either sensor reports out-of-range or stale data, enter a safe mode.
Sensor fusion for light: combine two illuminance sensors with different ranges by selecting the unsaturated one and smoothly transitioning between them. Alarm if both saturate (>100000 lux).

Compute a composite indoor air quality score from normalized CO2 (ppm), TVOC (ppb), and PM2.5 (µg/m3). Map the score to GOOD, FAIR, POOR, or HAZARDOUS states and drive indicator colors and alarms accordingly.

Design a multi-mode environmental monitor with modes NORMAL, ALERT, and EVACUATE. Monitor temperature [degC], humidity [%], CO2 [ppm], PM2.5 [µg/m3], and pressure [hPa]. Define thresholds for each mode, latch EVACUATE until manual reset, and guarantee a deterministic 100 ms main loop with WCET <= 20 ms. Include a power-on self-test of all sensors with fail-safe behavior on any fault.

Create a cleanroom monitor that maintains a positive pressure differential: monitor indoor and outdoor pressure [Pa], compute the difference, and control a fan via PID to keep +20 Pa. Enforce safety alarms if differential drops below +5 Pa for >10 s or if particles (PM2.5) exceed 15 µg/m3. Provide a comprehensive test plan with boundary and fault-injection cases.

Build a greenhouse environmental system with modes GROWTH, NIGHT, and SAFE. Use PID to regulate temperature at 24 degC (day) and 18 degC (night), and maintain humidity between 50% and 70%. Implement sensor fusion for redundant temperature sensors, alarm on dew point > 20 degC, and define acceptance tests for all mode transitions and alarm latches.

Specify an indoor air safety supervisor that integrates CO2, TVOC, and PM2.5 with a three-tier alarm scheme (Advisory, Warning, Critical). Require full traceability of thresholds, latching behavior, audible alarm muting with timeout, and deterministic timing at 10 Hz with measured WCET reported. Include self-diagnostics for stale or out-of-range data.

Develop a multi-zone monitoring state machine for two rooms, each with temperature [degC], humidity [%], CO2 [ppm], and light [lux] sensors. Implement per-zone alarms and a global EVACUATE mode if any critical limit is exceeded (e.g., CO2 > 2000 ppm or temperature > 50 degC). Require comprehensive unit tests, including hysteresis edges, sensor disagreements, and missed sampling deadlines.

Monitor ambient temperature and trigger an audible alarm when it exceeds 38 [degC]. Include a 2 [degC] hysteresis to prevent chatter and sample at 2 Hz. The alarm should auto-clear only when temperature falls below 36 [degC].

Turn on a dehumidifier output when relative humidity rises above 85 [%] and turn it off when it drops below 75 [%]. Indicate active dehumidification with a status LED and ensure safe default (off) on sensor fault.

Control a light indicator based on illuminance: turn it on when light is below 50 lux and off when above 200 lux, with 5 s debounce to avoid flicker. Provide a simple alarm if the sensor reading is out of range.
Raise a barometric low-pressure alarm when absolute pressure falls below 980 [hPa]. Add a clear condition at 985 [hPa] and make the alarm latched until clear condition holds for 10 s.
If indoor CO2 exceeds 1000 [ppm], turn on a ventilation output and raise a warning indicator. Clear the warning only when CO2 drops back below 800 [ppm].

Activate an air quality alarm when PM2.5 surpasses 35 ug/m3. Include a visual indicator that flashes at 1 Hz while the condition persists and becomes steady once PM2.5 returns below 25 ug/m3 for 60 s.
Monitor VOC index and issue a warning when the index exceeds 3.0. If VOC index stays above 5.0 for more than 2 minutes, escalate to an alarm state and require manual acknowledgment to clear.
Provide a freeze warning if temperature dips below 2 [degC]. Include a pre-warning at 4 [degC] and clear the warning only when temperature rises above 5 [degC].
Indicate dry conditions when humidity falls below 30 [%]. Drive a small humidifier relay while the condition persists, and stop when humidity recovers to 40 [%].
Detect glare and turn down a dimmable output when illuminance exceeds 10000 lux. Add hysteresis and a minimum on-time of 10 s for the reduced setting before returning to normal.
Compute a rolling average of temperature over the last 5 samples at 1 Hz. If the average exceeds 30 [degC], assert an overheat alarm; clear it when the average drops below 28 [degC].
Issue a storm alert when pressure is below 950 [hPa]. Include a distinct pre-alert at 960 [hPa], and ensure the alert resets only after 965 [hPa] is maintained for 30 s.
Monitor PM10 and trigger a ventilation output when PM10 exceeds 50 ug/m3. Turn the output off when PM10 is below 35 ug/m3 for at least 2 minutes.
Use a multicolor indicator to show thermal status: blue if temperature < 5 [degC], green if between 18 and 26 [degC], yellow if 26–35 [degC], and red if > 35 [degC].
If relative humidity remains above 95 [%] for longer than 10 s, assert a leak suspicion alarm. Clear only when humidity drops below 90 [%] for 60 s.
Design a state machine for thermal comfort using temperature [degC] and humidity [%] with states COOL, COMFORT, and HOT. Include hysteresis on transitions and drive separate indicators per state.

Create a day/night controller using illuminance with hysteresis (day > 300 lux, night < 100 lux). Add a 30 s delay when entering night to avoid false triggers and control two outputs for day and night modes.

Calculate dew point from ambient temperature [degC] and humidity [%]. Raise a condensation risk alarm if dew point is within 2 [degC] of a configurable surface temperature. Provide 1 [degC] hysteresis for clearing.
Implement 3-tier ventilation based on CO2: OFF < 800 [ppm], LOW 800–1200 [ppm], HIGH > 1200 [ppm]. Latch HIGH until CO2 falls below 1000 [ppm] for 60 s and include a visual level indicator.
Track barometric trend: if pressure drops by more than 4 [hPa] within 30 minutes, raise a weather alert. Sample at 60 s intervals using a moving average to reduce noise.

Detect sensor stagnation: if any environmental reading (temperature, humidity, pressure, light, CO2) stays unchanged for > 120 s, set a sensor_fault and force outputs to safe defaults. Provide a manual reset input to clear.
Use two temperature sensors to monitor a space. If their difference exceeds 2 [degC], assert a sensor_mismatch alarm; otherwise, use the average value to drive an over/under temperature indicator.
Control a bathroom fan: when humidity > 70 [%] for at least 15 s, turn the fan on for a minimum of 2 minutes. Stop when humidity < 60 [%] or after a 10-minute maximum run, whichever comes first.
Implement stepped dimming based on illuminance: 0% above 1000 lux, 50% between 200–1000 lux, and 100% below 200 lux. Include 10% hysteresis bands to prevent rapid switching.

Create an air quality traffic light using CO2 [ppm] and VOC index. Show green when both are good, yellow when either is moderate, and red when either is poor. Add latching behavior on red until both return to good levels for 2 minutes.
Estimate altitude from pressure [hPa] and raise a notice if climb rate exceeds 2 m/min over a 1-minute window. Include noise reduction to avoid false positives.
Detect rapid temperature changes by computing dT/dt. If the rate exceeds 5 [degC]/min for 10 s, issue a pre-alarm and clear when the rate falls below 2 [degC]/min.

Run environmental monitoring at 2 Hz with a WCET of 2 ms per cycle. If any cycle exceeds WCET, set a timing_fault alarm and record a counter; if two faults occur within 60 s, enter a safe state with outputs off.
Implement data freshness checks: if CO2 sample age exceeds 5 s, mark data stale and inhibit any change to ventilation level until fresh data arrives. Provide a stale_data indicator.
Add a warm-up state for the gas sensor: ignore readings for 30 s after power-up, then transition to NORMAL. If the sensor reports a fault, move to FAULT state and hold outputs safe.
Create a combined alarm that triggers if (temperature > 30 [degC] and humidity > 80 [%]) or CO2 > 1500 [ppm]. Latch the alarm and only clear after all values remain within safe bands for 60 s.
Reduce sampling to save power: when light is < 10 lux for 5 minutes, sample air quality every 10 s; otherwise sample every 2 s. Ensure smooth transition without missing stale data timeouts.

Check consistency between pressure-derived altitude changes and temperature trends. If the implied lapse-rate-equivalent change exceeds 10 [degC] without corresponding temperature variation, flag inconsistent_data.

Implement a nighttime comfort state machine that lowers the high-temperature alarm threshold by 2 [degC] after sustained darkness (illuminance < 20 lux for 15 minutes). Restore daytime thresholds when light returns.
Allow configuring a calibration offset for the light sensor. Apply the offset within ±20% limits; if the requested offset exceeds limits, reject it and assert a calibration_error alarm.

Implement a PID controller to maintain 22 [degC] using a heater output. Clamp output to safe limits, include anti-windup, sample at 10 Hz, and cut the heater if temperature exceeds 30 [degC]. Guarantee WCET ≤ 1 ms.
Control humidity to 50 [%] using a humidifier with PID. Enforce a hard ceiling at 60 [%], disable humidification if temperature < 10 [degC], and enter safe-off on sensor fault.

Fuse two temperature sensors into a single output using outlier rejection and weighted averaging. If disagreement exceeds 3 [degC], isolate the outlier, raise degraded_mode, and continue with the trusted sensor.

Create a fused indoor air quality score from CO2 [ppm] and VOC index. Drive ventilation in three levels based on the score with rising and falling thresholds. Enforce a maximum rate of change for level transitions.

Compute dew point and prevent condensation by controlling a dehumidifier to keep dew point at least 3 [degC] below a configurable surface temperature. Limit total dehumidifier runtime to 30 minutes per hour.

Implement adaptive glare detection: update a baseline from the 5-minute average illuminance and alarm if current illuminance exceeds baseline by 5000 lux. Rate-limit baseline updates to avoid chasing transients.
Provide fault-tolerant pressure monitoring with two sensors: estimate and compensate bias, cross-check plausibility, and isolate a failing sensor seamlessly while raising a degraded_mode alarm.

Design a multi-variable comfort controller that prioritizes 24 [degC] temperature and 50 [%] humidity. If both targets cannot be met, maintain temperature first. Limit humidification when CO2 > 1200 [ppm].

Add predictive alerting by estimating CO2 trend via linear regression over the last 2 minutes. If projection exceeds 1500 [ppm] within 10 minutes, assert early_warning; cancel if the projection drops below the threshold.
Run the monitoring and control loop at 20 Hz with a WCET of 2 ms. If WCET is exceeded twice within 60 s, enter a safe mode with all actuators off and a latched timing_alarm.

Specify a multi-mode environmental monitor with modes SELF_TEST, NORMAL, POWER_SAVE, and ALARM. Use thresholds in temperature [degC], humidity [%], pressure [hPa], light [lux], and CO2 [ppm] to govern transitions. Include latching alarms, degraded operation on sensor faults, and a WCET budget per mode.

Implement redundant temperature sensing with three probes and 2-out-of-3 voting. Isolate a faulty probe, then maintain 23 [degC] using a PID heater. Provide comprehensive tests with fault injection (stuck-at, drift, noise) and clear acceptance criteria.

Create a comprehensive air quality supervisor monitoring CO2 [ppm], VOC index, PM2.5 (ug/m3), and PM10 (ug/m3). Implement INFO, WARNING, and ALARM stages with thresholds, latching rules, auto-clear logic, and a SAFE_SHUTDOWN if ALARM persists > 15 minutes. Include a 10 Hz loop with WCET 1 ms.

Define a dual-mode environmental chamber controller: STABILITY holds 25 [degC] and 40 [%] with coordinated PID loops; RAMP follows a scheduled profile. Enforce safety ceilings (30 [degC], 70 [%]), fuse redundant temperature probes, and supply a verification plan with measurable pass/fail criteria.

Specify a safety-focused supervisor overseeing temperature [degC], humidity [%], pressure [hPa], light [lux], and CO2 [ppm]. Include startup self-test, continuous plausibility checks, watchdog response, alarm prioritization, fail-safe outputs, explicit mode transitions, timing guarantees (50 Hz loop, WCET 1 ms), and a structured test matrix.

Create a simple monitor that reads ambient temperature and turns on an alarm output whenever the value exceeds 60 [degC]. Include a separate output that indicates when the temperature returns to a safe range (< 55 [degC]).
Read relative humidity [%] and illuminate a status LED when the value drops below 30 [%] (too dry). The LED must be off otherwise. Add a 2-second minimum ON duration once triggered to avoid flicker.
Monitor barometric pressure in [kPa] and activate a buzzer if the pressure falls below 95 [kPa]. The buzzer should silence automatically when pressure rises above 96 [kPa].
Read illuminance [lux] and switch on a light output when it drops below 100 [lux]. Switch the output off when it rises above 150 [lux] to provide basic hysteresis.
Monitor PM2.5 concentration in [µg/m3]. If PM2.5 exceeds 35 [µg/m3], blink an alarm indicator at 1 Hz; otherwise keep it steady off.
Read CO2 [ppm] and assert a warning output when CO2 > 1000 [ppm]. Deassert when CO2 < 900 [ppm]. Keep the behavior as a simple threshold alarm with hysteresis.
Create a monitor that turns on a cooling fan output when temperature exceeds 28 [degC] and turns it off when temperature drops below 26 [degC].
Read relative humidity [%] and drive a single LED that indicates 'SAFE' (on) when 40–60 [%], and off otherwise.
Watch ambient light [lux] and sound a soft alert beep once when light transitions from > 500 [lux] to < 200 [lux]. Ignore further changes for 10 seconds to prevent spamming.
Simple alarm: if temperature is below 5 [degC], turn on a frost warning output. Turn it off when temperature is >= 7 [degC].
Read volatile organic compounds (VOC) index [arb] and light an LED when VOC index > 3.0. Extinguish the LED when VOC index < 2.5.
Monitor differential pressure [Pa]; if it exceeds 250 [Pa], assert an overpressure alarm. Clear when below 200 [Pa].

Check ambient temperature [degC] and humidity [%]. If humidity > 85 [%] while temperature < 10 [degC], assert a 'condensation risk' indicator. Otherwise keep off. Keep logic simple with two inputs and one output.
Read PM10 [µg/m3] and toggle a warning LED at 2 Hz if PM10 > 50 [µg/m3]; keep it off otherwise. Use a duty cycle of 50% for the blink.
Create a basic monitor that turns on a 'bright' indicator when illuminance > 1000 [lux] and off otherwise. No hysteresis needed.
Implement a two-level alarm for temperature [degC] with hysteresis: Warning at > 30 [degC] (clear < 28 [degC]) and Critical at > 40 [degC] (clear < 38 [degC]). Drive two separate outputs.
Design a humidity comfort indicator using three LEDs: 'Low' when < 30 [%], 'OK' when 30–60 [%], and 'High' when > 60 [%]. Ensure only one LED is on at a time.

Build a small state machine for air quality [CO2 in ppm]: Normal (< 800 [ppm]), Elevated (800–1200 [ppm]), and High (> 1200 [ppm]). Indicate the current state via three outputs and transition with 50 [ppm] hysteresis between bands.
Combine temperature [degC] and humidity [%] to estimate heat index and activate a warning output when the heat index exceeds 32 [degC]. Update at 2 Hz.
Monitor pressure [kPa] and temperature [degC]. If pressure drops more than 2 [kPa] within 10 [min], assert a 'rapid change' alarm. Include a timer so the rate-of-change check runs every 5 [s].

Create a light-based dimmer controller: read illuminance [lux] and drive a PWM output to keep indoor light at a target 300 [lux] by increasing output when measured < 300 [lux] and decreasing when > 350 [lux]. Include a 5% deadband to avoid oscillation.

Implement a dew point warning: fuse temperature [degC] and humidity [%] to compute dew point. If ambient temperature is within 2 [degC] of dew point, assert 'condensation risk.' Add 1 [degC] hysteresis for clearing.
Add alarm escalation for PM2.5 [µg/m3]: Warning at > 25, Critical at > 75. In Warning, blink at 1 Hz; in Critical, blink at 4 Hz. Ensure transitions include 5 [µg/m3] hysteresis.
Create a sampling loop that reads CO2 [ppm] at 5 Hz and logs the maximum value over the last 1 [min]. If this rolling max exceeds 1500 [ppm], assert an alarm output for ventilation.

Design a state machine for temperature safety with three states: SAFE (< 35 [degC]), HOT (35–45 [degC]), and SHUTDOWN (> 45 [degC]). In SHUTDOWN, assert a latch that requires manual reset when temperature returns below 40 [degC].

Monitor humidity [%] and control a dehumidifier output with hysteresis and minimum on/off times: turn on above 65 [%], off below 55 [%], minimum on-time 120 [s], minimum off-time 60 [s] to protect equipment.

Compute air quality status from CO2 [ppm] and VOC index. If CO2 > 1200 [ppm] or VOC index > 4.0, set status BAD; else if CO2 > 800 [ppm] or VOC index > 2.5, set status FAIR; otherwise set GOOD. Indicate status via three outputs.

Implement a light-based day/night detector: sample illuminance [lux] at 2 Hz, apply a moving average over 10 samples, and switch a 'night' output on when the filtered value < 50 [lux] (off when > 80 [lux]).
Create an overpressure protection logic: if differential pressure [Pa] exceeds 500 [Pa] for more than 3 [s], assert a trip output. Auto-reset only after pressure remains below 300 [Pa] for 10 [s].
At 10 Hz, compute the rate of temperature change [degC/min]. If heating rate exceeds 5 [degC/min], trigger a runaway alarm. Include a requirement that the calculation task WCET must be < 2 [ms].

Design a humidity comfort controller using a simple two-state machine: NORMAL (40–60 [%]) and ADJUST (outside that range). In ADJUST, assert outputs to either humidify or dehumidify based on direction. Include 5 [%] hysteresis.

Monitor PM2.5 [µg/m3] and PM10 [µg/m3]. If either exceeds its threshold (35 and 50 respectively), assert an alarm; if both exceed thresholds, escalate to critical with a faster blink pattern. Apply 10-second hold-off before clearing.

Create a pressure and temperature compensation block that outputs a corrected pressure [kPa] using a linear temperature coefficient. Then alarm if corrected pressure < 95 [kPa]. Sample at 20 Hz with WCET < 1 [ms].
Implement a 'clean air' timer: when CO2 < 800 [ppm] and PM2.5 < 15 [µg/m3] for 15 consecutive minutes, pulse a green indicator for 5 seconds. Reset the timer if either metric goes out of bounds.

Create a humidity-based mold risk state machine using temperature [degC] and humidity [%]. States: LOW, MEDIUM, HIGH risk based on a simple index. Transition with hysteresis and assert an alarm only in HIGH.

Fuse two temperature sensors [degC] with a median filter over 3 recent samples per sensor. If the absolute difference between sensors exceeds 3 [degC], flag a sensor disagreement alarm; else output the average temperature.

Implement a PID controller to maintain chamber temperature at a configurable setpoint in [degC]. Limit the actuator output, add integral windup protection, and enforce a safety cutoff at 80 [degC] that disables control and raises an alarm.

Create a sensor fusion algorithm that combines CO2 [ppm] and VOC index into a composite 'air quality score' from 0 to 100. Apply an exponential moving average with a 30-second time constant. Alarm if score < 40, with 5-point hysteresis. Ensure update at 2 Hz and WCET < 3 [ms].

Design a fault-tolerant temperature monitor using three sensors [degC]: perform median voter fusion; if any sensor deviates > 5 [degC] from the median for over 10 seconds, mark it faulty and exclude it. Alarm if fused temperature > 70 [degC].

Implement a pressure altitude estimator using barometric pressure [kPa] and temperature [degC]. Low-pass filter the altitude with a 2-second time constant and alarm if descent rate exceeds 300 [m/min]. Sample at 10 Hz with WCET < 2 [ms].

Create a humidity [%] control loop using PI control to maintain 50 [%] with output saturation and a deadband of ±3 [%]. Include safety: if measured humidity sensor reports NaN or out-of-range (< 0 or > 100 [%]), force output to safe off and raise a fault.

Develop a light regulation controller with PID that targets 500 [lux]. Clamp output rate-of-change to prevent flicker and alarm if measured lux stays < 300 [lux] for 60 seconds despite > 80% output (indicating failure).

Implement sensor fusion of two humidity sensors [%] using a weighted average that favors the sensor with lower noise (weight ratio 0.7/0.3). Detect and isolate a sensor if it reads outside 0–100 [%] or differs from the fused value by > 10 [%] for 15 seconds.

Create a comprehensive air quality alarm that considers CO2 [ppm], PM2.5 [µg/m3], and VOC index. Use the worst-case of three normalized scores to decide status: GREEN, YELLOW, RED. Provide hysteresis and a 30-second minimum dwell in RED before clearing.

Implement a thermal runaway protection with two independent temperature channels [degC]. If either > 85 [degC], assert SHUTDOWN immediately. If both > 80 [degC] for > 5 seconds, also assert SHUTDOWN. Require manual reset after temperatures fall below 70 [degC].

Build a multi-mode environmental monitor with modes: NORMAL, WARNING, CRITICAL, and FAULT. Inputs: temperature [degC], humidity [%], CO2 [ppm], PM2.5 [µg/m3]. Mode transitions depend on thresholds with hysteresis; FAULT is entered on any sensor timeout or out-of-range. Indicate mode via distinct output patterns.

Specify a system that samples all sensors (temperature [degC], humidity [%], pressure [kPa], light [lux]) at 20 Hz, with a budgeted WCET per cycle of 3 [ms]. Raise alarms if any parameter crosses configured safety thresholds and ensure each alarm clears only after the parameter is back within limits for 5 seconds.

Design a dual-setpoint temperature controller (ENERGY_SAVE and COMFORT modes) with PID for [degC] control and automatic mode switching based on light [lux] (day/night). Include safety cutoff at 80 [degC], integral anti-windup, and a FAULT mode for sensor failures.

Create an expert-level environmental supervisor with modes: NORMAL, VENTILATE, PURGE, and FAULT. Inputs: CO2 [ppm], VOC index, PM2.5 [µg/m3], humidity [%]. Outputs select ventilation levels. Include hysteresis, escalation timers, and a safe default in FAULT. Provide test cases covering threshold crossings, hysteresis behavior, and sensor stuck-at faults.

Develop a comprehensive monitoring and control spec that: (1) Maintains temperature at 25 [degC] via PID with output limits and overtemperature trip at 70 [degC]; (2) Tracks humidity [%] and dehumidifies above 65 [%] with min on/off times; (3) Assesses air quality from CO2 [ppm] and PM2.5 [µg/m3] with multi-level alarms; (4) Runs all tasks at 10 Hz with WCET < 4 [ms]; and (5) Includes a verification plan with unit tests for thresholds, hysteresis, and fail-safe transitions on sensor faults.
Turn on an alarm output whenever ambient temperature exceeds 50 [degC]; turn it off when temperature drops below 48 [degC].
If relative humidity falls below 20 [%] for longer than 5 s, activate buzzer and set an alarm flag; clear both when humidity rises above 25 [%].
Switch a status LED on when ambient light is under 30 [lux] and off when at or above 32 [lux] to provide small hysteresis.
Drive a relay to OFF if CO2 exceeds 2000 [ppm] to force ventilation; restore to ON only when CO2 is below 1500 [ppm].
Blink a warning LED at 2 Hz while barometric pressure is below 950 [hPa]; keep it off otherwise.
Sample temperature at 1 Hz and append to a circular log only if the change since the last logged value exceeds 0.5 [degC].
Turn the fan ON when PM2.5 is at or above 35 [ug/m3] and turn it OFF when PM2.5 drops below 20 [ug/m3] to avoid chatter.
Show air quality as green when VOC is at or below 500 [ppb] and red when VOC is above 500 [ppb].
Compute a 5-sample moving average of ambient light [lux] and turn on a lamp when the average is below 100 [lux]; turn it off when it rises to 110 [lux].
Raise a sensor fault flag if temperature reads below -40 [degC] or above 125 [degC]; otherwise keep the flag clear.
Map measured humidity [%] linearly to a 0..100 [%] output level, saturating below 0 [%] and above 100 [%].
Implement a two-level temperature alarm: warn when temperature exceeds 45 [degC] and set a critical alarm at 60 [degC], driving separate indicators.
For carbon monoxide, keep the indicator off below 10 [ppm], blink at 1 Hz between 10 and 30 [ppm], and steady on above 30 [ppm].
Control a simple heater using bang-bang logic with hysteresis: enable heat below 18 [degC] and disable heat above 22 [degC].
Sample barometric pressure at 5 Hz and raise a stale-data alarm if the time between consecutive samples exceeds 250 ms.

Build a small state machine for temperature monitoring: Warmup for 2 s ignoring readings, then Monitor enforcing safe range 0 to 50 [degC]; if above 50 [degC], enter Alarm and drive an output until temperature falls below 48 [degC].
Calculate a heat index from temperature [degC] and humidity [%], and run a fan when heat index exceeds 30 [degC]; stop the fan when heat index falls below 28 [degC].

Combine CO2 [ppm] and PM2.5 [ug/m3] to drive a tri-color LED: green when CO2 < 800 and PM2.5 < 12, yellow when either is moderate (CO2 800..1200 or PM2.5 12..35), and red when any is high (CO2 > 1200 or PM2.5 > 35).
Enable a dehumidifier when humidity is above 60 [%] and ambient light is below 50 [lux] to prefer night operation; disable it otherwise.
Use hysteresis and persistence on light-based alarms: turn on a low-light warning when light stays below 100 [lux] for 300 ms, and clear it only after light exceeds 120 [lux] for 300 ms.
Monitor barometric pressure [hPa] and trigger a storm alert if it drops by more than 5 [hPa] within 10 minutes; clear the alert if the 10 minute trend is within 2 [hPa].
Read two temperature sensors, flag a fault if they differ by more than 2 [degC], and otherwise use their average to update a display and alarm thresholds.
Schedule temperature sampling at 10 Hz and humidity at 2 Hz within a 100 ms control cycle, and ensure the worst-case execution time per cycle stays under 2 ms.
Create a latching CO2 alarm: if CO2 exceeds 2500 [ppm] for over 60 s, assert an alarm that remains active until a reset input is pressed and CO2 is below 1500 [ppm] for 5 minutes.
Add a calibration mode triggered by a 3 s long-press on a service input to capture a light baseline [lux]; thereafter treat values relative to this baseline to determine low-light alarms.
Estimate altitude from barometric pressure [hPa] using a standard atmosphere approximation and beep when estimated altitude exceeds 1500 [m]; stop beeping when it falls below 1450 [m].
Filter VOC readings using a 30 s rolling mean and raise an air quality warning when the mean exceeds 150; clear after it remains below 120 for 30 s.
Detect rapid heating by computing temperature rate of change in [degC/min] and trigger an alarm when the rate exceeds 2 [degC/min] for at least 10 s.
Suppress all environmental alarms during the first 5 s after startup, then enforce normal thresholds, and raise a fault if no new temperature sample arrives within 1 s.
Drive a fan in steps based on CO2 [ppm]: 0 [%] below 800, 30 [%] between 800 and 1200, 60 [%] between 1200 and 2000, and 100 [%] above 2000, with 50 [ppm] hysteresis at each boundary.
Compute dew point from temperature [degC] and humidity [%] and engage a dehumidifier to keep dew point below 16 [degC], using a 1 [degC] hysteresis band.
Estimate absolute humidity in [g/m3] from temperature [degC] and relative humidity [%], and trigger a condensation risk alarm if RH exceeds 70 [%] or absolute humidity exceeds 12 [g/m3].
Perform pressure sensor health checks: on startup run a self-test, continuously flag out-of-range readings below 300 [hPa] or above 1100 [hPa], and degrade outputs to a safe default on fault.
Manage greenhouse shading: extend shade when light exceeds 50000 [lux] and temperature is above 30 [degC]; retract shade when light falls below 30000 [lux] or temperature drops below 28 [degC].
Validate timestamps on humidity data and ignore samples older than 2 s; raise a stale-data warning if no fresh humidity sample arrives within 3 s.
Implement a PID temperature controller to maintain 22 [degC] with a tolerance of +/- 0.5 [degC], sampling at 10 Hz; include output saturation, anti-windup, and guarantee a WCET under 1 ms per cycle.

Control a dehumidifier with a PID loop to hold relative humidity at 50 [%], adjusting a 0..100 [%] speed output; add integral windup protection and slightly reduce the setpoint when dew point exceeds 18 [degC].
