Design a state machine for a motorized gate with states Idle, Opening, Closing, and Fault. Use open and close limit switches; if travel exceeds 10 s or a limit fails to change, enter Fault and stop. Command a fixed speed of 2.5 [rad] per second during motion.

Compute left and right wheel targets from a desired forward velocity [mps] and yaw rate [rad] per second. Saturate each wheel to ±2.0 [mps] at the rim and publish the final wheel commands at 100 Hz with WCET < 1 ms.
Implement a pan sweep between −1.2 and +1.2 [rad] with a 1 s dwell at each end while a tilt servo holds 0.3 [rad]. Pause motion when a person sensor is true and resume when false.

Control a conveyor that defaults to 0.6 [mps] but slows to 0.2 [mps] while an object sensor is active. Limit acceleration to 0.4 [mps^2], and enforce an emergency stop that forces 0 [mps]. Target WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Use PID to hold a rotary joint at a commanded angle [rad] from an encoder. Enforce output saturation and clamp the integral term when saturated. Run at 500 Hz and raise a fault if following error exceeds 0.2 [rad] for >100 ms.
Given a wheel radius, convert a requested linear speed [mps] into target motor speed [rad] per second. Use proportional feedback on encoder velocity to track the target and saturate the output.
Coordinate two servos to move simultaneously to +θ and −θ [rad] and arrive together. If either channel reports a fault, stop both and enter a safe state.
When an obstruction sensor triggers during closing, reverse a motor at 1.0 [rad] per second for 0.3 s, then stop and set a blockage flag. Normal operation continues only after manual clear.

Create a velocity ramp generator for a stepper: when a new target speed [rad] per second is set, change speed no faster than 10.0 [rad] per second squared, and provide direction and step timing accordingly.
After a rotating disk passes an index sensor once, set absolute zero and proceed to 2.0 [rad]. If the index is not seen within 5 s of spinning at 5.0 [rad] per second, stop and fault.
Generate a trapezoidal motion profile between current and target angles [rad], honoring vmax and amax. Update the setpoint at 1 kHz and ensure WCET < 1 ms.

Use min/max limit switches to define the travel range of a linear actuator. Clamp commanded positions to this range and scale speed to 4.0 [rad] per second nominal near the middle, reducing speed to 1.0 [rad] per second within 0.05 [rad] of the ends.

Provide two modes for a joint: Park (hold 0.0 [rad] stiffly) and Run (accept velocity commands [rad] per second with soft limits). Implement safe transitions that only switch modes when velocity is near zero.
Maintain a wheel speed using an incremental encoder: estimate velocity over a 20 ms window and use PI control to track a [mps] setpoint. Sample at 200 Hz with WCET <= 0.8 ms.
Create a wiper motion for a servo with adjustable sweep amplitude [rad] from a knob. Include 0.5 s dwell at each end and a safe stop that freezes the current position on fault.
Run a spindle at a target speed with overspeed protection: if measured speed exceeds 120.0 [rad] per second for >100 ms, command 0 and latch an overspeed fault. Otherwise, track the requested speed.
Implement soft zones near travel limits: when within 0.1 [rad] of either end, cap speed at 1.0 [rad] per second; otherwise allow 5.0 [rad] per second. Reject commands outside the physical range.
On an align command, rotate a wheel to the nearest multiple of 0.7854 [rad]. Use a proportional controller on encoder angle, and declare success when error is within 0.01 [rad] for 200 ms.

Monitor loop timing and input sanity: if the control loop timing jitter exceeds target WCET by more than 0.2 ms three times in a row, transition the motor to a safe hold (0 [rad] per second) and set a diagnostic flag.

Implement a high-precision joint position controller using PID on encoder angle [rad] with derivative filtering. Include position limits 0..2.5 [rad], velocity limit 3.0 [rad] per second, and acceleration limit 6.0 [rad] per second squared. Run at 1 kHz with WCET < 0.8 ms.

Build a velocity PID loop for a wheel with encoder feedback to track a [mps] setpoint. Use integral anti-windup and schedule gains so low speeds use higher integral action than high speeds. Enforce output saturation and a jerk limit.

Fuse encoder-derived belt speed with an accelerometer to estimate smoother linear velocity [mps] via a complementary filter. Use the fused estimate in a PI speed controller with max acceleration 0.5 [mps^2] and an emergency stop path that overrides immediately. Target 500 Hz, WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Create a closed-loop stepper system with an encoder: compare commanded angle [rad] to measured angle and detect missed steps >0.05 [rad]. When errors grow, automatically reduce speed and re-home before resuming. Provide a PID position loop around the step generation.

Plan and execute synchronized motion for two rotary axes so they start and finish together using trapezoidal profiles. Each axis has its own vmax [rad] per second and amax [rad] per second squared, but both must meet a common move time. Abort safely on any fault.

Implement position PID with anti-windup and a current-limit input: when current limit is active, freeze the integrator and cap output while still tracking position safely. If limit persists >2 s, transition to a hold mode at 0 [rad] per second.

Stabilize a camera gimbal axis: fuse gyro rate [rad] per second and encoder angle [rad] to estimate orientation, then drive a servo with PID to hold a commanded angle despite base motion. Saturate output and limit angle to ±1.2 [rad]. Run at 500 Hz, WCET < 1 ms.

Detect wheel slip by comparing commanded and measured velocities on a differential drive. If left−right speed difference exceeds 0.3 [mps] for >100 ms, reduce both speed commands by 30% and raise a slip warning while maintaining stability.

Generate a jerk-limited (S-curve) position trajectory for a joint from current to target [rad], honoring limits on velocity, acceleration, and jerk. Provide the instantaneous setpoint to a downstream controller at 1 kHz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Implement thermal derating for a motor: as temperature rises from 60 to 80 °C, linearly reduce the allowed speed limit from 10.0 to 4.0 [rad] per second. Above 85 °C, command 0 and latch an overtemperature fault. Ensure transitions are smooth.

Specify a multi-mode two-axis motion controller for joint angles in [rad] with states Boot, SelfTest, Home, Ready, Run, Degraded, and Fault. Include homing routines, PID position control, emergency stop handling, travel limit enforcement, and watchdog timing. Define task rates (1 kHz control, 100 Hz supervision) with WCET budgets per task and a detailed test plan covering limit switch failure, encoder dropout, and missed deadlines.

Design a high-integrity joint controller with redundant angle sensing (two encoders). Cross-check readings; when they agree within 0.02 [rad], fuse them (e.g., weighted average) and use PID to track the command. If disagreement exceeds 0.05 [rad], transition to SafeHold (0 [rad] per second), log the fault, and require manual reset. Guarantee 1 kHz loop with WCET < 0.8 ms.

Create a dual-motor drive for a differential platform with Manual and Auto modes. In Manual, map operator commands to wheel speeds [mps] with rate limiting; in Auto, track a commanded forward speed and yaw rate using wheel-level PID velocity loops. Fuse wheel encoders with yaw-rate gyro for better heading regulation. Enforce e-stop, overspeed limits, and provide a comprehensive test suite including fault injection and timing verification (WCET per loop <= 1 ms).

Develop a closed-loop XY table using steppers and encoders: modes include Calibration, Homing, Jog, Programmed Move, and Fault. Use synchronized trajectories so X and Y reach targets together; detect missed steps and re-home if error >0.1 [rad]. Provide sensor fusion between step counts and encoder angles, strict travel limits, e-stop, and a verification plan with deterministic timing and WCET budgets.

Specify a safety-critical rotary axis controller with trajectory generation, PID position control, and feedforward. Enforce a safety envelope: absolute position within 0..2.8 [rad], speed limit 6.0 [rad] per second, and jerk limit 20.0 [rad] per second cubed. Include mode management (Init, Home, Operate, Fault), watchdog and heartbeat supervision, and property-based tests plus fault injection to prove that WCET constraints are met at 1 kHz.

Please drive a linear actuator motor at 0.25 [mps] while a digital start input is true; otherwise command 0 [mps]. Rate-limit the ramp to avoid sudden changes, and sample at 50 Hz with WCET under 1 ms.
On a button press, set a servo to 0.8 [rad]; on release, return to 0.0 [rad]. Constrain the commanded angle to the safe range 0.0–1.0 [rad].
Map a knob input (0–100%) to a wheel velocity between 0.0 and 0.7 [mps], saturating at the limits. Include a deadman enable input that forces 0 [mps] when not held.
Jog a stepper shaft by +0.10 [rad] each time a momentary button is tapped, and by -0.10 [rad] when another button is tapped. Ignore repeat triggers within 150 ms.
Implement a soft-start: ramp a conveyor from 0 to 0.3 [mps] over 2 s when a start command arrives, and ramp back to 0 [mps] over 1 s when stop is requested.
If an endstop switch is active, immediately command 0 [mps] to the motor; otherwise allow motion. This is a simple interlock.
Toggle motor direction each time a mode button is pressed, but cap magnitude at 0.4 [mps]. Provide a simple 100 Hz loop with WCET below 0.5 ms.
Make the servo sweep between -0.5 [rad] and +0.5 [rad] with a 3 s dwell at each end, continuously.
Set a fixed wheel velocity of 0.2 [mps] while a run input is held; if an emergency stop input is asserted, immediately command 0 [mps] and latch until reset.
Use a simple rate limiter so that a target angle command cannot change by more than 0.05 [rad] per control cycle.
When a trigger pulse is received, rotate the joint by +0.5 [rad] relative to its current position, then hold.
Switch between two speeds with a selector input: low 0.1 [mps] and high 0.3 [mps]. Ensure no overshoot by ramping over 200 ms.
Read a temperature sensor; if temperature exceeds 70 C, reduce the maximum allowed velocity to 0.25 [mps]; otherwise allow up to 0.5 [mps].
Drive a servo to match a reference angle input, clamped within [-1.0, 1.0] [rad], and stop motion if a fault flag is set.
Generate a square velocity profile alternating between 0.15 and 0.35 [mps] every 2 s for a test conveyor, with WCET under 0.8 ms.

Create a homing state machine for a rotary axis: move negative until the home switch closes, set the current angle to 0 [rad], then move to a commanded setpoint within [0.0, 3.14] [rad]. Run at 200 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.
Implement a trapezoidal move: upon start, accelerate to 0.9 [mps], hold for 2 s, then decelerate to 0 [mps]. Abort immediately to 0 [mps] if a safety input asserts.

Control two drive wheels so they start together and aim for the same velocity setpoint. If their measured velocities differ by more than 0.05 [mps] for 100 ms, enter a fault state and command 0 [mps].
Translate a joystick input into a signed velocity command with a 10% deadband and an exponential response, capped at 0.8 [mps]. Include an enable switch and WCET budget of 0.7 ms at 100 Hz.

Design a door actuator with Open, Hold, and Close states. Open to 1.2 [rad] on command, hold position, and close back to 0 [rad] when requested. Stop and report fault if an obstruction sensor triggers.
Create a position controller that follows a reference angle but enforces software endstops at -1.5 and +1.5 [rad]. Apply slew limiting of 0.1 [rad] per 10 ms tick.
Build a three-speed selector using two digital inputs to choose among 0.2, 0.4, or 0.6 [mps], with direction from a third input. Smooth transitions with a 300 ms ramp.
Implement a scan routine that moves a joint back and forth between 0.3 [rad] and 2.2 [rad], dwelling 1 s at each end. If an E-stop is asserted, stop and remain in a latched Fault state.
Make a stepper jog mode: left and right buttons command continuous rotation with an adjustable target up to 1.2 [rad] per second, and apply a rate limit of 0.02 [rad] per 10 ms tick.
Synchronize two servos so Joint B follows Joint A with an offset of +0.30 [rad]. If the difference deviates from the offset by more than 0.08 [rad] for 50 ms, stop both.
Implement a simple velocity hold using feedback: measure wheel speed and adjust output so the conveyor stays at 0.5 [mps]. Saturate the command and add a watchdog that forces 0 [mps] on timeout.
Build an Idle/Run/Fault controller. In Run, command 0.4 [mps]. Transition to Fault on overtravel input, and require operator reset to leave Fault.
Create a mode where a knob sets angle between 0 and 2.6 [rad]. Apply a smoothing filter and limit rate to 0.05 [rad] per cycle, WCET under 0.6 ms at 200 Hz.
Implement a dwell-and-step: rotate the shaft by 0.2 [rad], hold for 500 ms, repeat N times upon start. Abort immediately on stop.
Add temperature derating: scale the maximum allowed velocity linearly from 0.6 [mps] at 40 C down to 0.2 [mps] at 80 C; never exceed the scaled limit.
Develop a homing-and-limit enforcement routine for a joint: after homing, clamp commanded positions to [0.0, 4.5] [rad] and slow down when within 0.2 [rad] of either end.
Design a simple catch-up controller: when an external encoder indicates the joint is lagging setpoint by >0.15 [rad], temporarily increase the velocity command until the error is <0.05 [rad].
Implement a periodic test pattern for a wheel: 1 s at 0.2 [mps], 1 s at 0.4 [mps], 1 s at 0.0 [mps], then repeat. Assert WCET <= 0.9 ms.
Create a two-button interface: one commands +0.3 [rad] increments, the other -0.3 [rad], with software endstops and debouncing.
Control two axes that must not move simultaneously: if Axis A is moving toward its target in [rad], block Axis B until A reaches its target or times out, then allow B.

Implement a PID position controller for a rotary joint with encoder feedback. Accept a target in [rad], enforce software limits [-2.0, 2.0] [rad], apply anti-windup, and saturate output. Run at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Create a PID velocity loop that tracks a setpoint in [mps] for a conveyor using measured speed. Include integrator clamping, slew-rate limiting on setpoint changes, and an enable that zeros the integrator when disabled.
Build a cascaded controller: outer-loop PID on position in [rad] commanding an inner-loop PID on velocity. Limit the commanded velocity to prevent overshoot and ensure stability.

Fuse encoder-derived angular rate with a gyro using a complementary filter to estimate angular velocity, and use that estimate in a velocity controller to follow a [rad] per second target. Provide a fault if the sensors disagree persistently.
Implement closed-loop stepper control: compare encoder position in [rad] to commanded steps, correct for missed steps with a PID position loop, and halt if error exceeds 0.2 [rad] for 100 ms.

Generate jerk-limited motion between two angles in [rad] with bounded velocity changes per tick. Feed the trajectory to a PID position loop and enforce a maximum linear speed equivalent of 0.7 [mps] when mapped through the mechanism.
Design a dual-motor synchronizer with a PID that minimizes the position difference in [rad] while also tracking a common velocity in [mps]. Enter Fault if the difference exceeds 0.12 [rad].
Create a velocity controller that maintains 0.9 [mps] under varying load, with an observer that estimates disturbance and compensates via integral action. Ensure WCET under 0.7 ms.

Implement anti-rollback on an incline: hold position with a PID when setpoint velocity is 0 [mps], switch to velocity control smoothly when a nonzero [mps] command appears, and never exceed defined limits.

Develop a sensor-fusion-based estimator that blends wheel encoder [mps] with an external optical flow measurement to obtain a robust velocity, then control to a commanded [mps] profile with safety saturation.

Engineer a multi-mode motion controller for a joint with modes: Disabled, Homing, PositionHold, VelocityTrack, and Fault. Use PID where appropriate, accept commands in [rad] or [mps] per mode, enforce endstops and ramps, and guarantee a 1 kHz loop with WCET <= 0.9 ms. Provide a self-test that validates each mode transition.

Design a dual-axis gantry controller with modes: Startup, Align, Track, and Fault. Cross-couple the axes to keep them parallel using position difference in [rad], limit maximum carriage speed in [mps], and include a comprehensive test plan that simulates sensor dropouts, overtravel, and recovery.

Build a mobile base drive with two wheel motors supporting Manual, Safe, and Autonomous modes. In Safe, cap speed at 0.4 [mps]; in Manual, follow joystick with ramps; in Autonomous, follow a time-stamped [mps] profile. Include PID velocity loops, watchdogs, WCET analysis, and tests for E-stop behavior.

Create a redundant sensing scheme for a rotary actuator that fuses encoder and gyro to estimate angle and rate in [rad], detects sensor faults, falls back to a single-sensor mode with derated limits, and verifies behavior with scenario-based tests. Maintain a strict 1 kHz schedule and WCET margin.

Specify a mode-switchable joint controller that toggles between Compliance (low-gain) and Rigid (high-gain) PID position control. Define acceptance tests for step responses (overshoot, settling time) at targets in [rad], ensure velocity limits expressed in [mps] are never violated, and demonstrate WCET budget adherence.
Drive a position servo to 0.75 [rad] when a start switch is true; otherwise hold its current angle. Enforce soft limits within [0.0, 1.57] [rad]. Run the control at 50 Hz with WCET < 1 ms.

Spin a wheel to a constant surface speed of 0.5 [mps]. Use an open-loop ramp with a change limit of 0.1 [mps] every 100 ms to avoid jerks. On stop command, decelerate linearly to 0 within 1.0 s. WCET must be <= 2 ms at 100 Hz.
On reset, command the joint to 0.0 [rad]; otherwise pass through a joystick angle command, clamped to ±1.2 [rad]. Indicate when clamping occurs. Update at 100 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.
Move a stepper actuator forward by 0.20 [rad] each time a pulse input is detected; no motion otherwise. Prevent motion beyond +3.0 [rad] via a hard limit. Run at 100 Hz with WCET <= 0.5 ms.
Implement an on/off brake: if measured wheel speed exceeds 1.0 [mps], engage brake; release when speed drops below 0.8 [mps] (hysteresis). Update at 50 Hz with WCET < 1 ms.
Track a setpoint in [rad] with a first-order filtered input (time constant 0.3 s) to smooth servo motion. Clamp output within [0.0, 1.57] [rad]. Control loop at 100 Hz, WCET <= 1 ms.

Provide a jog feature: while jog_plus is held, increase target angle at 0.05 [rad/s]; while jog_minus is held, decrease at 0.05 [rad/s]; otherwise hold position. Limit position to [-1.5, 1.5] [rad]. Run at 100 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.
Command a conveyor to either 0.0 or 0.3 [mps], selected by a mode input. Limit acceleration to 0.2 [mps^2] to avoid shocks. Update at 50 Hz with WCET < 1 ms.
If an obstacle flag is true, immediately command the wheel to 0.0 [mps]; otherwise pass through the requested speed, clamped to ±0.6 [mps]. Update 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Perform simple homing: move negative at 0.1 [rad/s] until the home sensor triggers, then set position to 0 [rad] and stop. If homing exceeds 5 s, assert a fault and stop. Run at 100 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Enable the motor driver only when emergency_stop is false and the command is nonzero. On emergency_stop true, disable the driver immediately and zero the command. Execute at 200 Hz with WCET < 0.2 ms.
Hold a gimbal yaw axis at 0.0 [rad] unless a valid command is active. Limit the commanded rate to 0.5 [rad/s] to avoid overshoot. Update at 100 Hz, WCET <= 1 ms.

Convert a linear speed command in [mps] to wheel angular velocity [rad/s] using a configurable wheel radius. Saturate to ±8.0 [rad/s] and report when saturation occurs. 200 Hz update with WCET <= 0.5 ms.
Apply a deadband to a joystick angle: if |input| < 0.05 [rad], command 0; otherwise subtract the deadband and scale to ±1.0 [rad] output range. Update at 100 Hz with WCET < 0.5 ms.
For thermal protection, if motor temperature exceeds 70 Celsius, immediately command 0.0 [mps] and assert an overheat flag; clear when below 60 Celsius. Update at 20 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Create a two-state controller for a rotary joint: IDLE and MOVE. In MOVE, follow a trapezoidal profile from current angle to target [rad] with max velocity 1.0 [rad/s] and acceleration 2.0 [rad/s^2]; return to IDLE when within 0.01 [rad]. Abort motion if the limit switch is active. Run at 200 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Implement a drive enable sequence with states DISABLED -> PRECHARGE -> ENABLED -> FAULT. Only accept torque/velocity commands in ENABLED. Transition to FAULT on emergency_stop or driver_fault. PRECHARGE should last 200 ms before enabling. Execute at 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Given a desired travel distance in meters, convert to a wheel angle [rad] using the wheel radius, and drive a servo to that angle with a rate-limited command. Stop if encoder feedback deviates by more than 0.2 [rad]. Run at 100 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Create a stepper indexer with states START, RUN, and HOLD. START: home negative at 1.0 [rad/s] until the home switch, zero angle; RUN: move to target [rad] at 3.0 [rad/s] with jerk-limited acceleration; HOLD: pause motion on a pause input. Resume on resume input. Update at 1 kHz, WCET < 0.5 ms.

Provide dual limit protection: clamp commanded position to soft limits [-1.57, 1.57] [rad] and flag soft_limit when clamped. If either hard limit switch is active, command motion away from the switch at 0.2 [rad/s] until cleared. 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Estimate angular velocity from encoder by discrete differentiation and low-pass filter it with a 0.1 s time constant. Raise a slip alarm if |cmd_vel - meas_vel| > 0.5 [rad/s] for more than 0.3 s. Update at 500 Hz, WCET <= 0.4 ms.

Implement differential drive mixing: accept chassis linear speed [mps] and yaw rate [rad/s], compute left and right wheel angular velocities [rad/s] given track width and wheel radius, saturate to motor limits, and report saturation percentage. Update at 200 Hz with WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Homing with soft land: approach the home switch at 0.4 [rad/s], when triggered back off 0.05 [rad], then creep forward at 0.05 [rad/s] until a second trigger; set zero. Fault if not complete within 8 s. 200 Hz loop, WCET <= 1 ms.

Hold a joint at its current angle; if an external disturbance causes deflection > 0.1 [rad], allow following at a limited rate of 0.3 [rad/s] until released (deflection < 0.02 [rad]), then return to the original angle. Update 100 Hz with WCET <= 0.7 ms.

Control a conveyor with three discrete speeds based on zone sensors: 0.6, 0.3, or 0.0 [mps]. Rate limit acceleration to 0.4 [mps^2] and deceleration to 0.6 [mps^2]. On e-stop, force 0 [mps] immediately. Run at 50 Hz, WCET <= 0.6 ms.

Create a rate/accel limited setpoint generator for a joint: joystick input [-1..1] maps to angle [-2.0..2.0] [rad] with max rate 1.5 [rad/s], accel 3.0 [rad/s^2], and deadband 0.05. Update at 250 Hz with WCET <= 0.5 ms.
Guard against large command steps: if the angle setpoint changes by more than 0.5 [rad] between cycles, interpolate over 0.5 s to smooth motion. Log each smoothing event. 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.4 ms.

Add a mode switch between position control (track angle [rad]) and velocity control (track [rad/s]). Only transition modes when the commanded velocity magnitude is below 0.05 [rad/s]. Indicate the active mode on outputs. Update at 100 Hz with WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Implement an S-curve soft-start: ramp from 0 to target speed [mps] with jerk limited to 2.0 [mps^3]. If an overload flag is set, pause the ramp and hold current speed; resume when clear. 100 Hz loop, WCET <= 1 ms.
Create a motion watchdog: if the control period exceeds 12 ms or WCET exceeds 2 ms, assert motion_inhibit and command zero [rad/s] until manual reset. Monitor at 100 Hz.

Add a saturation monitor with integrator reset: if the actuator command saturates for longer than 0.2 s, set a flag, zero any integrator state, and hold until the command demand reduces. Update at 200 Hz with WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Implement anti-windup for a position controller: freeze the integral term when the output is at limits or when the error sign flips rapidly. Publish a boolean anti_windup_active. Update at 500 Hz with WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Allow runtime updates to motion limits: max velocity [rad/s] and acceleration [rad/s^2]. Validate that new values are within safe bounds and reject invalid inputs while keeping prior values. Rate: 50 Hz, WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Control a pan-tilt pair: yaw and pitch servos each clamped to ±1.2 [rad]. If either axis faults, stop both and assert a common fault. Provide a park command that moves both to 0.0 [rad]. Update 100 Hz with WCET <= 1.2 ms.

Emergency retract: when e-stop is asserted, drive the linear actuator negative at 0.15 [mps] until the retract limit switch closes. If the switch is not reached within 3.0 s, stop and latch a fault. 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.7 ms.

Implement a PID position controller for a rotary joint with setpoint in [rad] and encoder feedback. Include velocity feedforward [rad/s], output saturation, and integral anti-windup. Update at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.8 ms. Safety: if |error| > 1.0 [rad] for > 0.2 s, cut output and enter FAULT.

Create a velocity PID for a wheel with target linear speed [mps]. Convert to angular feedback [rad/s] using wheel radius. Add a notch filter at 40 [rad/s] to suppress resonance. Limit acceleration to 1.0 [mps^2] and jerk to 5.0 [mps^3]. Run at 500 Hz, WCET <= 0.7 ms, and force 0 [mps] if a deadline is missed.

Design a two-loop controller: outer position PI in [rad] generates a velocity setpoint [rad/s]; inner velocity PID commands the actuator. Provide separate gains and limits, plus bumpless manual/auto transfer. 1 kHz update, WCET <= 0.9 ms. Safety: saturate within limits and log limit events.

Fuse encoder angle increments [rad] with IMU linear acceleration [mps^2] via a complementary filter to estimate linear velocity [mps]; use the fused estimate in a PID speed controller. Expose a confidence metric. Run at 200 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Use a 1D Kalman filter to fuse a rate gyro [rad/s] and a coarse absolute encoder [rad] for joint angle estimation [rad] and gyro bias. Drive a PID position loop from the estimate. If innovation > 0.5 [rad] for 3 cycles, reject the measurement and raise a warning. 1 kHz, WCET <= 0.9 ms.

Implement traction control: compare commanded speed [mps] to fused vehicle velocity [mps] (from encoders and optical flow); if slip > 0.3 [mps], reduce the command using a PI slip controller, restoring when recovered. Run at 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.8 ms. Safety: never exceed deceleration 1.5 [mps^2].

Cascaded PID for a gimbal axis with torque limiting: accept a current_limit input that reduces position loop gains and clamps velocity commands when high. Verify stability for 0.5 [rad] step inputs. Update at 2 kHz with WCET <= 0.6 ms. Safety: enter SAFE mode if current_limit persists > 1 s.

Add model-based feedforward to a PID motion controller: given desired angle [rad], velocity [rad/s], and acceleration [rad/s^2], compute a feedforward term and combine with feedback. Allow runtime enable/disable of feedforward. Ensure actuator command remains within configured limits. 1 kHz, WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Closed-loop stepper control with encoder: run a PID on microstep position [rad] to correct missed steps. Detect stall if error > 0.2 [rad] for > 50 ms and automatically reduce speed by 50%. Update at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.7 ms.

Synchronize two motors: maintain equal shaft angles [rad] by controlling the difference with a cross-coupled PID. Stop both if either encoder is invalid or if angle difference exceeds 0.3 [rad]. Run at 500 Hz with WCET <= 0.9 ms.

Design a multi-mode motion controller with modes BOOT, HOMING, IDLE, POSITION_TRACK, VELOCITY_HOLD, MANUAL_JOG, and FAULT. Use PID for POSITION_TRACK (angle [rad]) and PI for VELOCITY_HOLD ([rad/s]). Enforce soft limits ±2.0 [rad], max velocity 1.5 [rad/s], accel 3.0 [rad/s^2]. Execute at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.9 ms and overrun handling that enters FAULT. Include a latched e-stop requiring a power-cycle clear.

Implement a four-wheel allocator: from chassis linear [mps] and yaw rate [rad/s], compute each wheel target [rad/s] and run per-wheel PID with saturation and anti-windup. Add modes ECO, NORMAL, SPORT with different limits and gains. Provide startup self-test, deadline monitoring, and an interface to inject sensor faults. 500 Hz, hard WCET 1.2 ms; on exceed, degrade to ECO and clamp outputs.

Build a dual-redundant actuator controller with primary and secondary encoders for angle [rad]. Vote and switch to secondary if discrepancy > 0.1 [rad], entering DEGRADED mode. Provide multi-level faults, safe-stop behavior, and recovery. Closed-loop PID at 1 kHz, WCET <= 0.8 ms. Include requirements-based tests, state coverage, and logs of mode transitions.

Create a trajectory executor for a joint that accepts time-tagged waypoints with position [rad], velocity [rad/s], and acceleration [rad/s^2]. Perform jerk-limited interpolation and enforce constraints. Support pause/resume, cancel, and safety stop. States: IDLE, EXECUTING, PAUSED, ABORTED, FAULT. Include unit tests for boundary cases, verify WCET <= 1.0 ms, and ensure deterministic timing.

Develop a two-axis motion framework supporting auto-calibration, homing, coordinated moves, and fault containment. Use sensor fusion for velocity [mps] from encoders and accelerometers, plus cascaded PID loops per axis. Implement a supervisory state machine with recovery and limp-home. Specify and verify WCET bounds for planner, controller, and safety tasks, and include a simulated testbench with fault injection and acceptance criteria.
When the enable flag is true, drive a motor to a constant linear speed of 0.25 [mps]; otherwise command 0 [mps]. Limit speed to 0.30 [mps]. Run the control loop at 100 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.
Set a rotary servo to 1.57 [rad] when a command input is true; otherwise hold 0.00 [rad]. Enforce soft limits between 0.00 and 2.00 [rad]. Sample at 50 Hz; WCET must not exceed 0.5 ms.
On a rising-edge trigger, jog a servo by +0.05 [rad]. If a 'reverse' trigger occurs, jog by -0.05 [rad]. Keep absolute position within 0.00 to 1.20 [rad].
Map an analog demand (0.0 to 1.0) to a servo angle between 0.00 and 1.50 [rad]. Saturate outside the range and update at 100 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.
While a 'run' input is true, maintain conveyor speed at 0.10 [mps]; when false, command 0 [mps]. Never exceed 0.15 [mps].
Engage a brake output when measured shaft speed is below 0.01 [mps]; disengage the brake above 0.01 [mps]. Poll at 100 Hz and ensure WCET <= 0.5 ms.
Provide two discrete speeds: if a selector is OFF run at 0.05 [mps]; if ON run at 0.10 [mps]. Cap speed at 0.12 [mps] and stop immediately on an emergency input.
If an alarm input is active, immediately command 0 [mps]; otherwise pass through an operator speed demand (0.00 to 0.40 [mps]) with saturation and simple smoothing.
Drive a joint to an angle proportional to a joystick input, within -0.50 to +0.50 [rad]. Limit rate of change to prevent jumps. Update at 100 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.
Accept a numeric target in [rad] and move a servo smoothly from its current angle to that target. Reject targets outside 0.00 to 1.80 [rad].
Pulse a stepper to achieve a belt speed of 0.03 [mps], and stop all motion immediately when a stop button is pressed.
Hold a joint at 0.00 [rad] unless a 'park' command is received; on 'park', move to and hold 1.00 [rad]. Declare a fault if position exceeds 1.20 [rad].
Limit motor command changes to no more than 0.02 [mps] per 10 ms update to reduce jerk. Enforce WCET <= 0.5 ms.
If a temperature warning is active, cap maximum speed to 0.05 [mps]; otherwise allow up to 0.20 [mps]. Maintain the requested speed within these limits.
Command a sinusoidal position: amplitude 0.20 [rad] at 0.5 Hz around 0.00 [rad]. Ensure absolute position remains within ±0.30 [rad].

Build a homing state machine for a rotary axis: Idle -> SeekHome -> BackOff -> SetZero -> Ready. Rotate negative until the home switch closes, back off, set 0.00 [rad], then wait for position commands. Control loop 200 Hz, WCET <= 2 ms.
Regulate a conveyor between two photo sensors: slow to 0.10 [mps] when the downstream sensor is blocked, otherwise run at 0.30 [mps]. Stop on jam detection input. Enforce maximum 0.35 [mps].
Command two servos to mirror each other with a 0.10 [rad] offset. Both must obey soft limits (0.00..1.80 [rad]) and stop if either exceeds 1.90 [rad]. Update at 100 Hz.
Index a stepper-driven wheel using an index sensor: SeekIndex at slow speed until sensed, then align to 0.00 [rad] and advance to a commanded angle. Include states: Idle, Seek, Align, Move, Fault.
Maintain operator-set speed (0.00..0.80 [mps]) using a PI controller with anti-windup. Loop at 250 Hz; WCET <= 2 ms. Saturate output at 0.90 [mps].
Implement soft start/stop: ramp speed from 0 to the requested value in [mps] over 2 s, and ramp down on stop. Honor an emergency input that forces an immediate 0 [mps] command.
Use forward and reverse limit switches to enforce travel bounds while moving to target positions in [rad]. If a command would exceed a limit, refuse it and set a diagnostic.
Door actuator state machine with states Closed, Opening, Open, Closing, Fault. Drive at 0.05 [mps] opening, 0.05 [mps] closing; stop on end switches. Timeout after 8 s to Fault.
Convert a rotating cam shaft angle [rad] into a follower position setpoint and drive a servo to track it. Limit follower motion to prevent exceeding 1.50 [rad].
Provide two modes: Jog (increment/decrement 0.02 [rad] per press) and Position (go to numeric target in [rad]). Toggle modes with a switch and preserve last setpoint across mode changes.
Create an indexing carousel: N evenly spaced detents across 2π [rad]. On each trigger, move to the next detent with acceleration-limited motion. Wrap around after 2π.
Maintain filament feed speed at 0.30 [mps] using feedback from a tachometer. If error persists >0.05 [mps] for 2 s, reduce target to 0.20 [mps] and raise a warning.
Generate a trapezoidal motion profile from current angle to a target in [rad] with max velocity 0.50 [rad/s] and max acceleration 1.0 [rad/s^2]. Update the setpoint at 200 Hz, WCET <= 1 ms.
If a guard interlock opens, immediately move the actuator to a safe position at 0.00 [rad], disable drive, and latch a fault. Only clear the fault after an operator reset.
Coordinate two linear actuators so they arrive at their targets in [mps] at the same time by scaling their speeds. Halt both if position mismatch exceeds 0.01 [rad] equivalent.
Add backlash compensation: when direction reverses, apply a one-time 0.02 [rad] compensation before resuming normal tracking. Expose a status flag while compensating.
Detect 'in-position' by checking absolute error < 0.01 [rad] continuously for 200 ms. Provide an output that goes true only when stable.
Accept a remote command for target speed in [mps]; validate units and range (0.00..0.60 [mps]). Reject invalid inputs and keep the last safe target.
On power-up, wait for sensors to stabilize, then perform a slow homing sequence to the negative limit, set 0.00 [rad], and move to a standby angle of 0.10 [rad].
If oscillations are detected (sign changes in error >5 times within 2 s), reduce commanded velocity by 50% and enable a small ±0.01 [rad] dither to overcome stiction.

Implement a PID position controller for a rotary joint tracking targets in [rad]. Enforce soft limits (−1.0..+1.0 [rad]) and a hard fault at ±1.2 [rad]. Run at 1 kHz; WCET must be <= 0.8 ms. Include integral anti-windup and output saturation.

Fuse encoder angle with a gyro rate using a complementary filter to estimate angle and velocity; use the fused velocity to drive a PID speed loop to 0.40 [mps]. Provide fallbacks if either sensor is missing.
Drive three independent wheels to operator-requested speeds in [mps] with per-wheel limits and a total power cap that scales all commands proportionally. Loop at 500 Hz; WCET <= 1.5 ms.

Use cascaded control for a linear actuator: outer PID on position [rad-equivalent] produces a velocity target [mps]; inner PID regulates actual speed to that target. Enforce limit switches and soft stops.
Detect following error: if |position error| > 0.20 [rad] for more than 100 ms, enter a controlled stop that ramps velocity to 0 [mps] within 300 ms and latches a fault.
Track a time-parameterized trajectory in [rad] with jerk-limited profiles. Respect max velocity 1.0 [rad/s] and max acceleration 2.0 [rad/s^2]. Run the planner at 200 Hz; WCET <= 2 ms.

Combine two encoders on a joint (coarse absolute and fine incremental) to get a robust angle estimate in [rad]. Detect disagreement >0.02 [rad] and switch to the healthy sensor while flagging a fault.
Schedule PID gains based on current speed in [mps]: lower gains at higher speeds to maintain stability. Verify that closed-loop command never exceeds 0.80 [mps].
Derate maximum speed in [mps] as temperature rises: linearly reduce the cap from 0.60 [mps] at 40 C to 0.30 [mps] at 80 C. Integrate this cap into the velocity PID with anti-windup.

Estimate velocity from encoder positions using a filtered differentiator and use it in a PID speed loop. If the estimator saturates or becomes noisy, fall back to a conservative open-loop speed with a 0.20 [mps] cap.

Design a multi-mode actuator controller with states: Boot, Homing, Manual (velocity in [mps]), Auto (position in [rad]), and Fault. Define transitions, safety limits, and use PID in Auto and Manual. Control loop 1 kHz with per-task WCET budgets (e.g., 0.6 ms control, 0.2 ms safety). Include a basic self-test at Boot.

Implement redundant sensing for a rotary joint with dual encoders and a gyro. Use voting/fault-detection logic, fuse healthy sensors for angle [rad], and degrade to a safe mode if redundancy is lost. Provide test scenarios and acceptance criteria for each fault case.

Create a mobile base wheel controller with modes Standby, Teleop, Cruise, and E-stop. Track requested wheel speeds in [mps] with jerk-limited commands, watchdog supervision, and hard limits. Specify loop rates (500 Hz control, 100 Hz supervision) and WCET constraints and include a test plan.

Develop a joint controller that supports Calibration, Idle, Tracking, SafeStop, and Fault modes. Perform calibration to an index, then run a cascaded PID (position [rad] to velocity [mps]). Bound acceleration and position, and define comprehensive unit tests and timing checks (WCET assertions).

Build a packaging axis controller with multi-segment trajectories, on-the-fly replan, and safe stop on guard trips. Enforce soft/hard limits in [rad] or [mps], monitor worst-case execution time each cycle, and supply comprehensive test sequences covering nominal, overload, and worst-case burst commands.
When a pushbutton is pressed, command a servo to move to 1.2 [rad]; when released, move to 0.0 [rad]. Update at 50 Hz. Include a safety angle limit of 0.0 to 1.5 [rad].
Map a potentiometer input to conveyor motor speed: scale 0.0–1.0 to 0.0–0.8 [mps], clamp the output to that range, and stop at 0.0 [mps] if the dial reads below 0.05.
Each time a momentary button is tapped, advance a stepper by one step of 0.0157 [rad]. Debounce the input and ignore repeated taps within 100 ms.
Move a servo smoothly from its current angle to 0.5 [rad] over 2.0 s and then hold position. Limit the motion rate to 0.4 [rad]/s and do not exceed the range 0.0–1.2 [rad].
Start the motor when a start command is true, ramp linear speed to 0.3 [mps] over 1 s, and stop when a stop command is true. Enforce a maximum of 0.35 [mps].
Turn on an indicator whenever shaft angle exceeds 2.5 [rad]; otherwise command a constant travel speed of 0.2 [mps].
Implement an emergency stop: if the E‑Stop input is active, immediately set motor speed to 0.0 [mps] and hold until reset.
Drive a servo to follow a sine wave between 0.2 and 1.0 [rad] at 0.5 Hz, ensuring the commanded angle stays within 0.0–1.2 [rad].
Maintain a fixed linear velocity of 0.25 [mps]; if a fault flag becomes true, reduce to 0.0 [mps]. Run this at 100 Hz.
Use a two‑position selector: position A commands 0.0 [mps], position B commands 0.6 [mps].
On power‑up, home a rotary servo to 0.0 [rad] and hold there.
If an overtemperature alarm is signaled, immediately command 0.0 [mps] and inhibit further motion until cleared.
Apply a reverse toggle: normal mode sets 0.3 [mps]; when reverse is active, command −0.3 [mps]. Saturate to within ±0.4 [mps].
Implement a deadband for a speed command: ignore inputs within ±0.05 [mps], pass through outside that region, and clamp to 0.8 [mps] magnitude.
Generate a trapezoidal motion from 0.0 [rad] to 3.14 [rad] with max velocity 1.0 [rad]/s and acceleration 2.0 [rad]/s^2, then hold at the target.

Create a two‑state controller with IDLE and RUN. In RUN, regulate belt speed to a joystick‑demanded target in [mps]; in IDLE, hold 0.0 [mps]. Transition to IDLE on E‑Stop or fault, and to RUN on a start command. Update at 100 Hz.
Implement a position latch: when an optical trigger occurs, capture the current shaft angle in [rad] and command the motor to stop within 50 ms; otherwise track a nominal 0.6 [mps] command.

Build a homing sequence for a rotary axis: move slowly negative until a limit switch closes, set the position to 0.0 [rad], then move to 1.0 [rad]. Run the logic at 200 Hz and meet a WCET of 400 microseconds.
Accept a target angle in [rad] and drive a stepper accordingly, respecting a max speed of 1.5 [rad]/s and acceleration of 3.0 [rad]/s^2. Abort motion immediately if a limit switch is triggered.
Read a joystick and a load sensor: if load is above a threshold, cap the speed at 0.3 [mps]; otherwise allow up to 0.8 [mps]. Apply a rate limit of 0.5 [mps^2] to ensure smooth changes.
Use PID to hold a servo at 2.0 [rad]. Include integral anti‑windup, and limit the commanded rate to ±1.5 [rad]/s.
Add an in‑position flag: when absolute angle error is ≤0.02 [rad], assert in_position and light an indicator; otherwise keep moving with a speed cap of 0.7 [rad]/s.
Implement a jog mode: while JOG_PLUS is held, advance the axis at 0.2 [rad]/s; while JOG_MINUS is held, retreat at 0.2 [rad]/s. Enforce soft limits of 0.0 to 5.0 [rad].
Execute a waypoint sequence: move to 0.5 [rad], then 1.0 [rad], then 0.0 [rad], each with a velocity limit of 1.0 [rad]/s. Stop immediately on any fault.
Synchronize two wheels to the same linear speed in [mps]. If their difference exceeds 0.2 [mps], raise an alarm and reduce both to 0.1 [mps] until they resynchronize.
Implement a command watchdog: if no new velocity command arrives within 200 ms, force 0.0 [mps]. Under normal operation, map an input 0..1 to 0..1.2 [mps].
Generate a jerk‑limited ramp toward a target angle in [rad] with max velocity 0.8 [rad]/s, acceleration 2.0 [rad]/s^2, and jerk 10.0 [rad]/s^3. Abort if a force limit is exceeded.
Provide a mode where the input selects either position or speed: in position mode, move to 1.57 [rad]; in speed mode, hold 0.4 [mps]. Require the axis to be at 0.0 [mps] before switching modes.
Maintain 0.5 [mps] using PID velocity control with saturation at ±0.6 [mps] and anti‑windup. Execute at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 800 microseconds.
Soft‑start after enable: wait 300 ms, then ramp from 0.0 to 0.7 [mps] over 3.0 s. If a door_open input becomes true, immediately ramp down to 0.0 [mps].
Create an oscillating actuator: move between 0.2 [rad] and 1.0 [rad] with 1.0 s dwell at each end using a simple state machine. Limit velocity to 0.9 [rad]/s.
Track a time‑varying speed command in [mps] from a host. Apply a 5 Hz low‑pass filter and a rate limit of 0.5 [mps^2]. If the sequence number jumps, drop to 0.0 [mps].
Detect stall during position hold: when the command velocity is 0.0 [mps] but angle error remains >0.3 [rad] for more than 200 ms, declare a stall and disable the drive.
Add hysteresis to start/stop: start motion at 0.6 [mps] when an analog input exceeds 0.6, and stop when it falls below 0.4. Run at 50 Hz and clamp output within 0.0–0.8 [mps].
Create a calibration routine: from idle, move to the left limit (0.0 [rad]) and set zero, then move to 2.4 [rad] and store it as the maximum, then return to 1.2 [rad]. Abort on E‑Stop.

Design a cascaded controller: an outer PID regulates linear speed in [mps], while an inner loop runs at 1 kHz to regulate actuator effort. Enforce output saturation with anti‑windup, and meet WCET budgets of 200 microseconds for the inner loop and 500 microseconds for the outer loop.

Fuse an encoder angle in [rad] with a gyro rate using a complementary filter to estimate a smooth angle. Use PID to track a commanded angle, enforce a safe range of 0.0–2.5 [rad], and if sensor disagreement exceeds 0.2 [rad], stop motion.

Create a motion profile generator that feeds a velocity PID to move from 0.0 [rad] to 6.28 [rad] with max velocity 2.0 [rad]/s, acceleration 4.0 [rad]/s^2, and limited jerk. Guarantee a WCET under 600 microseconds.

Control a differential drive: accept left and right targets in [mps], run a PID per wheel at 200 Hz, and if either wheel deviates by more than 0.2 [mps] from its target, enter a slow‑down mode and cap both at 0.2 [mps]. WCET ≤ 400 microseconds.

Implement a pick‑and‑place rotary axis with states HOME, MOVE_TO_PICK, MOVE_TO_PLACE, and ERROR. Use PID position control in [rad], limit speed to 1.0 [rad]/s, check interlocks, and stop on any limit switch.

Reduce payload swing by adjusting trolley speed in [mps] using sensor fusion of encoder angle [rad] and IMU angle [rad]. Apply a PID with a notch filter, cap speed at 1.2 [mps], run at 200 Hz, and meet a 1 ms WCET.
Add adaptive feed‑forward to a PID tracking a sinusoidal angle command in [rad] to compensate friction. Keep the motion within ±2.5 [rad] and fall back to safe defaults if the learned term diverges.

Implement guarded motion near limits: maintain 0.4 [mps], reduce to 0.1 [mps] within 0.5 [rad] of a soft limit, and hold position with PID inside 0.1 [rad]. Ensure deterministic execution with WCET under 700 microseconds.

Drive a stepper with encoder feedback to keep following error below 0.01 [rad]. Generate microstep pulses, decelerate if error grows, raise an alarm on loss of steps, run at 2 kHz, and keep WCET under 300 microseconds.

Ramp to 1.0 [mps] with a velocity PID while supervising acceleration and jerk; if measured jerk exceeds 5.0 [mps^3], limit output and initiate a safe stop category 0. Run at 1 kHz with WCET ≤ 250 microseconds.

Create a multi‑mode axis controller with OFF, MANUAL, AUTO, and FAULT modes. MANUAL jogs at ±0.3 [mps]; AUTO executes a waypoint list in [rad]. Mode transitions require zero speed and no active faults. Include watchdog, E‑Stop, soft limits, PID loops, event logging, verification of WCET ≤ 500 microseconds, and a clear set of test scenarios with acceptance criteria.

Design coordinated motion for two rotary axes executing synchronized trapezoids in [rad]. Support pause/resume, enforce per‑axis soft limits, run at 1 kHz, and ensure the scheduler meets a system WCET of 800 microseconds. Provide simulation hooks and structured tests for tracking error and limit enforcement.

Develop a servo drive with redundant sensing: fuse two encoders for angle in [rad] with a fault‑tolerant estimator. If discrepancy exceeds 0.05 [rad], degrade to a safe slow mode of 0.1 [mps] and request maintenance. Include a mode manager, PID control, sanity checks, a comprehensive fault injection test plan, and WCET no more than 600 microseconds.

Build a velocity manager for a mobile base with modes NORMAL, LIMITED, and SAFE_STOP. Accept a vector speed command in [mps], limit magnitude and rate, fuse wheel encoders to estimate actual [mps], and govern transitions using obstacle and E‑Stop flags. Provide thorough unit tests and timing analysis to guarantee WCET of 400 microseconds at 1 kHz.

Create a high‑precision indexing system rotating to N evenly spaced angles across 2*pi [rad], with calibration, backlash compensation, and emergency handling. Use a formal state machine, PID position control, soft and hard limit handling, watchdogs, a WCET budget of 700 microseconds, and a detailed verification checklist including worst‑case trajectory and fault‑injection tests.
While the run switch is held, drive the conveyor to a commanded speed with a hard limit of 0.8 [mps]; when released, stop immediately. Ignore any command outside −0.8..0.8 [mps].
Read a target angle and set a servo to that angle in [rad], but clamp it between 0.0 and 2.0 [rad] and apply a gentle approach so it never exceeds 1.0 [rad]/s.
Implement jog controls for a stepper: each press of Button A advances +1 step, Button B retreats −1 step; de-bounce inputs and ignore presses occurring within 20 ms of the previous event.
When enabled, hold a wheel at 0.6 [mps] using feedback; if actual speed deviates more than 10% for longer than 200 ms, raise a warning; when disabled, command zero velocity.
An emergency-stop input shall force all actuators to zero effort within one control cycle; motion may resume only after an explicit reset request has been received.
Implement a velocity ramp on the motor command: the commanded speed approaches the setpoint but changes no faster than 0.2 [mps] per second.
On startup, move a joint promptly to 1.0 [rad] and hold it there; enforce soft limits 0.2..2.2 [rad] and reject any request outside this range.
Toggle direction on each tap of a control input: alternate between +0.4 [mps] and −0.4 [mps]; use edge detection and ignore presses shorter than 30 ms.
Detect a stall: if commanded velocity exceeds 0.3 [mps] but the encoder reports nearly zero motion for 2.0 s, cut power and flag a fault requiring manual clear.
Home a rotary stepper axis by moving slowly in the negative direction until the home switch closes; then set position to 0.0 [rad] and stop.
Add a deadband of ±0.05 [rad] around neutral for a servo so tiny command changes are ignored; outside the band, follow the command normally.
Run a motor update task at 200 Hz with WCET ≤ 400 µs; if the task overruns, immediately command a safe idle and raise a timing fault.
Ramp the wheel from 0.0 to 1.0 [mps] over 5 s with a linear acceleration; on any fault input, bypass the ramp and command a stop in the next cycle.
Execute a trapezoidal angular move from 0.0 to 1.5 [rad] with max velocity 0.5 [rad]/s and max acceleration 0.5 [rad]/s^2; hold final position.
Accept a velocity command but clamp it to the safe range −0.3..0.3 [mps]; if a request is out of range, ignore it and leave the current command unchanged.
Create a small state machine for a conveyor: Idle, RunFwd, RunRev. Transitions are commanded by inputs; any safety interlock opening forces Idle. Limit speed to ±0.7 [mps].
Cycle a servo through three preset angles [rad] (0.5, 1.2, 2.0) each time a mode button is pressed; enforce a maximum slew of 0.8 [rad]/s. Run at 250 Hz with WCET ≤ 300 µs.
Implement stepper homing with upper and lower limit switches: home near the lower limit, establish soft limits, and provide jog controls that respect both soft and hard limits.
Close the loop on wheel speed with a basic PID at 200 Hz to track a target in [mps]; clamp output to a safe range and apply integral anti-windup.
For a differential drive, map desired linear velocity [mps] and yaw rate [rad]/s into left and right wheel targets; enforce per-wheel limits and stop both on any fault.
Build a joint controller with states Idle → Move → Hold; moves are to an absolute angle in [rad] with soft limits; any limit hit aborts to Hold with an alarm.
Make two servos mirror each other with a fixed offset of 0.2 [rad]; both outputs must honor the shared limits 0.1..2.3 [rad].
Create a timed sequence: open gripper to 1.2 [rad], wait 0.5 s, move wrist to 0.8 [rad], then close gripper to 0.4 [rad]. If any step exceeds its timeout, abort and stop all motion.
Add a command watchdog: if no fresh command arrives within 300 ms, set all actuators to zero. Control updates run at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 200 µs.
Implement throttle ramp-up and coast-to-stop logic: accelerate gently toward the target [mps]; when the disable input is pressed, remove drive and let the system coast, then hold at 0.
Low-pass filter the measured wheel speed before control to reduce noise; track the target [mps] while ensuring the commanded speed stays within ±1.2 [mps].
Command a joint to follow a sine wave with amplitude 0.5 [rad] and frequency 0.2 Hz for 10 s; ensure the instantaneous velocity never exceeds 0.8 [rad]/s.
Use top and bottom limit switches on a linear axis; if either is hit, immediately stop and retract 0.02 [rad] equivalent away from the switch before resuming normal control.
If a collision sensor triggers, reverse the motor at −0.2 [mps] for 1.0 s, then stop and wait for an operator ack; de-bounce the collision input.
Provide inching mode: while a button is held, nudge the stepper by 0.01 [rad] every 100 ms; releasing the button stops any further motion.
Calibrate the zero position: drive toward the negative end until a limit is reached, then set the current angle to 0.0 [rad] and store an offset for future moves.
Move a joint at a constant angular speed to a target angle in [rad]; once there, hold with proportional control and report any steady-state error exceeding 0.03 [rad].
Limit jerk for smoother motion: constrain the rate of change of acceleration to a maximum of 2.0 [rad]/s^3 during any commanded move.
Add thermal derating: when measured actuator temperature exceeds 70 °C, reduce the allowed max velocity by 50% (both [mps] and [rad]/s modes).
Provide two modes—velocity control in [mps] and position control in [rad]—selectable via a command; retain common safety limits and ensure clean handover between modes.
Track a wheel speed setpoint with a PID at 1 kHz; enforce a hard speed limit of 1.5 [mps], clamp the command, and implement integral anti-windup. WCET must be ≤ 300 µs; on overrun, drop to safe idle.
Control a rotary joint with a position PID in [rad], including velocity feedforward; obey soft limits and an e-stop input; log whenever saturation persists more than 100 ms.

Fuse encoder speed and IMU-derived acceleration to estimate linear velocity in [mps] (complementary logic); drive a motor to follow a target, and if either sensor is flagged invalid, degrade gracefully to the other.
Cross-check dual encoders on a joint: if their angles disagree by more than 0.05 [rad], command a controlled stop and enter a fault state; control loop at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 250 µs.
Schedule PID gains as a function of angular velocity [rad]/s for a joint (low gains at high speeds, higher gains near zero) to improve stability; transition gains smoothly.
For a two-wheel platform, run a separate velocity PID per wheel in [mps] with saturation and anti-windup; compute wheel targets from vehicle commands and enforce per-wheel safety limits.
Detect oscillation in speed control: if measured velocity ripples exceed 0.2 [mps] peak-to-peak for 1 s, temporarily reduce integral gain and flag a tuning alert.
Implement soft endstops for a cable-driven joint between 0.0 and 2.2 [rad]. Approach limits with a decaying velocity profile; if a physical limit switch is hit, back off 0.05 [rad] and hold.
Improve linear actuator velocity control in [mps] by blending encoder-derived speed with IMU acceleration; handle sensor dropout, maintain WCET, and ensure safe saturation behavior.
Monitor control task timing; if WCET overruns or missed deadlines are detected, initiate a controlled ramp-down to zero over 0.5 s for all axes (both [rad] and [mps]) and enter a latched fault.

Design a multi-mode joint controller with states: SafeIdle, Homing, PositionHold, VelocityTrack, and Diagnostics. Define transitions, safety interlocks, PID usage, and timing (1 kHz control, WCET ≤ 300 µs).
Specify a high-integrity drive for a single shaft using dual redundant motors and dual encoders with voting; tolerate a single fault, perform self-tests at startup, and meet strict timing guarantees.

Implement a motion planner with an S-curve (jerk-limited) trajectory queue for a rotary axis in [rad]. Allow online re-planning on new commands, enforce safety limits, and bound worst-case compute time.

Define an end-to-end test plan for a velocity-controlled conveyor: 1 kHz control, WCET ≤ 250 µs, e-stop and guard interlocks, step responses in [mps], and acceptance criteria for overshoot, settling time, and safety.

Coordinate two rotary joints in [rad] with synchronized start/stop and blended corners; support mode switching between position and velocity control; provide deterministic scheduling, WCET evidence, and a safety fallback state.
Set a servo to 0.5 [rad] when a toggle input is active, otherwise to 0.0 [rad]. Enforce hard limits from 0.0 to 1.0 [rad].
Spin a wheel motor at constant 0.4 [mps] forward while an enable input is true; stop when false. Include a maximum velocity clamp of 0.5 [mps].
On startup, move a rotary actuator to 0.0 [rad], then hold. If a nudge command arrives, step +0.1 [rad] once. Do not allow movement beyond 1.2 [rad].
Advance a stepper by 0.01 [rad] every 50 ms while a run flag is set. Stop immediately if a stop flag is set.
Read an analog dial (0..1) and map it to a servo angle 0..2.0 [rad]. Saturate at the ends.
Toggle a small motor on for 2 seconds when a trigger event occurs, then off. Ignore new triggers during the on-time.
Ramp a conveyor to 0.6 [mps] over 1 s after enable, and ramp down to 0 [mps] over 1 s after disable.
Hold a position actuator at 0.8 [rad] using simple proportional control; limit output to avoid overshoot.
When a foot pedal is pressed, increment a joint by 0.05 [rad], otherwise do nothing. Prevent cumulative position from exceeding 0.9 [rad].
Please make the servo track a square wave between -0.5 [rad] and +0.5 [rad] at 0.2 Hz.
If a temperature sensor exceeds threshold, stop the motor; otherwise maintain 0.3 [mps].
Drive at 0.05 [mps] until a limit switch closes, then stop and hold position.
Implement deadband: ignore small changes below 0.02 [rad] in the angle setpoint before commanding the servo.
Reverse a motor direction every 3 seconds at 0.2 [mps]. Ensure no acceleration spikes beyond comfort.
On power-up, wait 200 ms, then set the servo to 0.25 [rad].
Create a two-state controller for a linear actuator: IDLE and MOVE. In MOVE, drive to the target position in [rad]; transition to IDLE when within 0.01 [rad]. Ignore new targets in MOVE.

Home a rotary stage using a limit switch: move at 0.05 [mps] until the switch closes, back off 0.02 [rad], approach slowly at 0.01 [mps] to re-engage, then set zero. Enforce soft limits from 0 to 1.5 [rad].
Coordinate two wheel motors to run at the same velocity in [mps] using simple speed matching; adjust one motor to minimize velocity error.
Implement a state machine for a gripper servo: OPEN at 0.0 [rad], CLOSE at 1.0 [rad], and HOLD states. Transitions by command; include a timeout to return to OPEN if no command for 10 s.
Drive a joint with a velocity setpoint in [mps] based on joystick input; apply a low-pass filter and clamp acceleration.
Monitor motor current and stop motion if current stays above threshold for more than 200 ms; otherwise allow position commands up to 1.2 [rad].
Run a control loop at 200 Hz (WCET 2 ms): read encoder, compute position error in [rad], apply proportional-derivative control, and saturate output.
Alternate between two positions: 0.0 [rad] and 1.0 [rad], dwelling 1 s at each. Abort and hold if an emergency stop input is asserted.
Implement velocity tracking with feed-forward gain for a conveyor in [mps]; limit max jerk to keep motion smooth.
Synchronize a rotary axis ([rad]) to a linear conveyor ([mps]) by maintaining a ratio; pause sync if slip detection triggers.
Add a watchdog: if no new setpoint arrives within 500 ms, stop the motor at 0 [mps] and set a fault flag; clear fault on command.
Create a simple anti-windup saturating integrator for position control to 0.5 [rad]; ensure output limits prevent overshoot.
Use the rising edge of a sensor to trigger a 0.2 [rad] step move; ignore any retriggers for 100 ms (debounce).
Make a three-state motion profile—ACCEL, CRUISE, DECEL—to reach a target at up to 0.7 [mps]; transition on position and velocity thresholds.
Implement a soft stop: when stop is requested, ramp down velocity from current [mps] to 0 [mps] over 0.5 s; hard stop if emergency.
Control two servos mirroring each other: when servo A goes to +theta [rad], servo B goes to -theta [rad]; clamp |theta| <= 0.9 [rad].
Perform periodic calibration every 60 s: move to 0.0 [rad], wait until position change is less than 0.001 [rad] over 100 ms, then resume the last command.
At 100 Hz, compute velocity from encoder increments and hold it at 0.3 [mps] with a proportional controller; if noise spikes occur, ignore outliers greater than 0.1 [mps].
Implement a move-cancel behavior: if a new target arrives while moving, decelerate to 0 [mps] then start toward the new target.
Command two joints to follow sine position profiles in [rad] with a fixed phase difference of 1.5708 [rad]; allow amplitude adjustment.

Design a PID position controller for a rotary joint with setpoint in [rad], including anti-windup and output saturation. Enforce soft limits from 0.0 to 2.0 [rad] and an emergency safe stop on a limit switch. Run at 500 Hz with WCET 1 ms.

Implement a cascaded velocity PID (outer position in [rad], inner velocity in [mps]) for a linear actuator. Include acceleration limiting and a watchdog that drops to 0 [mps] on communications timeout.

Fuse encoder-based velocity with an IMU-derived estimate to produce a robust [mps] velocity signal, then regulate to a target using PID. Reject outliers and handle sensor dropout by fading to the available source.

Perform homing with current limit and PID position hold: move toward home until a switch closes, back off, re-approach slowly, then lock at 0.0 [rad]. Stop and fault if motion exceeds 1.6 [rad] without finding home.

Create a motion planner that generates trapezoidal profiles to track a time-varying setpoint in [rad] with maximum velocity expressed in [mps] for a linear axis. Ensure tracking error never exceeds 0.02 [rad]; if it does, cut drive and flag a fault.
Implement dual-motor synchronization with a PID loop on the difference in [mps], plus individual soft limits in [rad] for each axis. If mismatch exceeds 0.3 [mps] for 200 ms, enter a safe state.
Build a position servo that uses PID with dynamic gain scheduling based on position error magnitude (in [rad]). Guarantee WCET under 750 microseconds and deterministic 1 kHz updates.
Use sensor fusion to estimate absolute position: combine incremental encoder counts ([rad]) with a periodic reference marker to correct drift. Drive to commanded angles with PID and log corrections.
Add jerk-limited motion with a velocity PID in [mps] and a safety monitor that clamps output if estimated deceleration capacity is low. Ensure no command exceeds the soft limit of 1.8 [rad].
Implement a safety interlock: if temperature or supply voltage is out of range while moving above 0.1 [mps], decelerate to 0 [mps] within 0.3 s and hold at the last safe position in [rad].

Create a multi-mode drive system with modes: OFF, MANUAL, AUTO, and FAULT. In MANUAL, map joystick input to velocity in [mps] with limits; in AUTO, execute position trajectories in [rad] with PID. Switch to FAULT on any safety trigger and command 0 [mps]. Specify task rates and WCET budgets for each mode.

Design a redundant velocity control with two sensors (encoder-derived [mps] and model-based observer). Vote between them, detect disagreement greater than 0.2 [mps], and degrade to a safe-limited mode. Provide unit tests for transitions and timing, including worst-case loop jitter.

Implement a robot arm joint controller with HOMING, CALIBRATION, and OPERATION modes. Use PID position control in [rad], enforce soft/hard stops, and provide a test harness that simulates setpoint steps, ramps, and faults to verify settling time and overshoot.

Build a coordinated two-axis controller with modes: IDLE, HOMING, TRACKING, and EMERGENCY. Generate synchronized trajectories ([rad] and [mps] as appropriate), maintain alignment, and include end-to-end safety checks, with WCET not to exceed 1 ms at 1 kHz.

Develop a motion subsystem with automatic recovery: on sensor dropout, switch to observer-based estimation; on overload, enter SAFE-LIMIT mode capped at 0.2 [mps]; restore normal PID control when conditions clear. Include exhaustive scenario tests and acceptance criteria.

Command a servo to move to 1.2 [rad] when an enable input is true; otherwise hold the current position. Include a simple position hold with proportional control, enforce a maximum slew rate of 0.5 [rad/s], and run the loop at 200 Hz with WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Drive a motor to a fixed wheel speed of 0.8 [mps] when start is active; ramp to 0 [mps] when inactive. Limit speed between 0 and 1.0 [mps] and use a linear ramp of 0.2 [mps/s]. Run at 100 Hz with WCET <= 0.3 ms.
Toggle a stepper motor between forward and reverse at 0.5 [rad/s] on each button press. Debounce the button and stop immediately on an emergency stop signal.
Map an analog input (0–1) to a servo target from -0.6 [rad] to +0.6 [rad]. Clamp output to this range and apply a 0.1 [rad] deadband around zero.
Implement an on/off brake: engage when wheel speed is below 0.05 [mps], release when above 0.06 [mps] (hysteresis). Update at 50 Hz with WCET <= 0.2 ms.
Control a linear actuator to extend at 0.02 [mps] unless a limit switch is active, in which case stop and hold position. Add a 250 ms hold-off after stopping to prevent chatter.
Command two servos to mirror each other so that servo B angle equals the negative of servo A angle, bounded within ±0.8 [rad]. Limit rate to 1.0 [rad/s] for both.
Start a conveyor motor at 0.3 [mps] and turn on a status LED while moving. If a jam sensor is active, immediately set speed to 0 [mps] and turn the LED off.

Implement a jog function: while a jog-left button is held, decrement joint position at 0.2 [rad/s]; jog-right increments at the same rate; release stops motion. Enforce software limits [-1.5, +1.5] [rad].
Generate a square wave position command for a servo between 0.0 [rad] and 1.0 [rad] with a 4 s period. Use a trapezoidal velocity profile with a 2.0 [rad/s] cap for transitions.
Pulse a stepper at 0.2 [rad/s] for exactly 3 s when triggered, then stop and wait for the next trigger. Ignore retriggers while active.
Implement a soft start: ramp wheel speed from 0 to 0.6 [mps] over 2 s and then hold. Provide a cancel input to abort the ramp and stop immediately.
Clamp a commanded joint position to soft limits. Inputs: target [rad], min [rad], max [rad]. Output the clamped target.
Convert a desired linear speed [mps] to an angular velocity [rad/s] using a given wheel radius [m] and output the [rad/s] setpoint.
Blink a fault indicator if the velocity command exceeds 1.5 [mps], and prevent motor enable until the command returns within limits.
Create a homing state machine for a rotary axis: IDLE -> SEEK_LIMIT (-0.5 [rad/s]) -> BACKOFF (0.05 [rad]) -> ZEROED -> HOLD. Abort to SAFE_STOP on emergency input. Run at 500 Hz with WCET <= 0.4 ms.
Implement a PI velocity controller to track a speed command [mps], with integral anti-windup at saturation. Limit speed to ±1.2 [mps], update at 1 kHz, WCET <= 0.3 ms.
Drive a pan/tilt pair to target angles [rad] received from a message, with per-axis rate limits and motion inhibited when supply voltage is low. Indicate stale targets (>200 ms) via status outputs.
Generate a trapezoidal profile to move from the current angle to a target [rad] with v_max 1.5 [rad/s] and a_max 3.0 [rad/s^2]. Output a position setpoint at 1 kHz.
Synchronize two wheel motors so their linear speeds [mps] remain matched within 0.02 [mps]. If the difference exceeds 0.05 [mps], reduce both commands to protect mechanics. Update at 200 Hz.

Map a joystick and deadman switch to differential drive: forward input maps to linear speed [mps], turn input to yaw rate [rad/s]. Limit linear speed to 0.7 [mps] when yaw rate exceeds 0.8 [rad/s]. Stop if the deadman is released.
Implement a position hold using PID on encoder angle [rad] with a gravity compensation feedforward term. Saturate output safely and freeze the integrator when beyond ±0.9 [rad] soft limits.

Create a gripper state machine: OPEN, CLOSE, HOLD, and EMERGENCY. CLOSE drives a servo until load threshold or 0.8 [rad] reached, then HOLD maintains. OPEN moves to 0.1 [rad]. EMERGENCY releases to 0 [rad]. Run at 250 Hz, WCET <= 0.2 ms.

Implement a timed move: upon a command with target [rad] and duration [s], generate a smooth velocity profile to reach the target exactly in the specified time with v <= 2.0 [rad/s]. Reject durations < 0.1 s as unsafe.
Add safety limits to a stepper: reject any command exceeding 3.0 [rad/s] or beyond [-2.0, +2.0] [rad], set a latched fault, and require a reset before accepting new moves.
Use two limit switches to enforce travel ends on a linear actuator. Hitting the positive limit blocks further positive motion but allows reverse up to 0.05 [mps]. Debounce switches by 50 ms.
Implement a command watchdog: if no velocity command is received for 500 ms, ramp down to 0 [mps] over 1 s and enter IDLE. Resume only on a new valid command.
Drive a motor with a velocity PID loop tracking a target [mps]. Provide configurable gains, saturations, and a slew limit of 0.3 [mps/s]. Run at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.25 ms.
Reduce hold torque: when within ±0.01 [rad] of target and speed < 0.02 [rad/s], scale controller output down by 40% to save power; restore full output if error grows.
Implement a soft stop based on an obstacle sensor: if distance < 0.3 m, limit linear speed to 0.1 [mps]; if < 0.2 m, stop. Update at 100 Hz and avoid overshooting the limit.
Track a sine wave position: amplitude 0.2 [rad], frequency 0.5 Hz, with velocity capped at 1.0 [rad/s]. Provide start/stop control and report the current phase.
Add a manual trim to commanded angle: apply a bias up to ±0.1 [rad] with a slew limit of 0.05 [rad/s], and clamp total command within [-1.0, +1.0] [rad].
Compensate servo dead zone: if errors persist within ±0.02 [rad], apply a static offset up to 0.03 [rad] to overcome stiction; remove it once velocity exceeds 0.1 [rad/s].
Create a two-button jog with acceleration: while held, increase speed linearly up to 1.2 [rad/s]; on release, decelerate to zero smoothly. Respect software stops at ±1.8 [rad].
Follow an external line speed estimate [mps] for a conveyor while limiting acceleration to 0.5 [mps^2] and deceleration to 0.8 [mps^2]. If the estimate is stale (>100 ms), hold current speed.

Design a cascaded position-velocity PID for a rotary joint: the outer loop tracks target angle [rad], the inner loop tracks target velocity [rad/s]. Include integrator anti-windup, output saturation, and run at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.35 ms.

Fuse encoder angle [rad] and gyro rate [rad/s] using a complementary filter to estimate joint velocity, then use that in a velocity PID to track a target [rad/s]. Provide a tunable fusion coefficient and handle gyro bias.

Implement a jerk-limited S-curve trajectory for a rotary axis to move to a target [rad] with limits v_max 2.5 [rad/s], a_max 6.0 [rad/s^2], and j_max 50.0 [rad/s^3]. Ensure continuity and safe saturation.

Build a fault-tolerant velocity controller that detects sensor disagreement: compare encoder-derived speed [rad/s] with an observer estimate; if discrepancy > 0.3 [rad/s] for >100 ms, enter DEGRADED mode and cap linear speed to 0.4 [mps] until reset.

Control two opposing belt drives to maintain a target linear speed [mps] while keeping their speed difference under 0.02 [mps] using cross-coupled PI. Include an emergency stop path, 500 Hz update, WCET <= 0.4 ms.

Create a gain-scheduled position PID: reduce proportional gain as velocity [rad/s] rises to avoid excitation. Ensure actuator command saturates within safe bounds and implement integrator back-calculation.

Implement online PID gain updates via parameter inputs while maintaining stability: reject invalid updates (e.g., negative gains) or those implying loop bandwidth > 20 Hz. Run at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Add model-based feedforward for velocity: compute a feedforward command for desired acceleration [mps^2] and sum with PID feedback to follow a trajectory in [mps]. Enforce bounds on acceleration and overall output.

Implement a disturbance observer for a joint: estimate load effects from deviations between commanded and measured velocity [rad/s] and compensate within safety limits. Disable compensation within 0.05 [rad] of end stops.

Create an auto-homing sequence with overspeed protection: during SEEK, if speed exceeds 1.0 [rad/s], cut power, back off 0.1 [rad], wait 1 s, and retry up to 3 times before faulting. Log retries and final status.

Design a multi-mode motion controller with modes DISABLED, MANUAL, AUTO_TRAJECTORY, and EMERGENCY_STOP. Each mode has its own limits for linear speed [mps] and yaw rate [rad/s]. Schedule sensor fusion at 500 Hz, trajectory generation at 200 Hz, and velocity PID at 1 kHz with WCET budgets 0.2 ms, 0.3 ms, and 0.35 ms respectively; drop to DISABLED on any overrun.

Create a dual-redundant encoder fusion for a joint: two encoders provide angle [rad]. Perform consistency checks, select the best source, fail over seamlessly, and drive a position PID with the fused angle. Add a SAFE_HOLD that maintains within ±0.02 [rad] if both sensors disagree beyond 0.05 [rad]. Include fault injection test hooks.

Implement a coordinated 4-wheel velocity allocator that maps desired body linear speed [mps] and yaw rate [rad/s] to individual wheel speed commands. Handle saturation with priority to yaw stability. Provide a self-test covering step responses, limit handling, and watchdog behavior at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Specify and implement a comprehensive homing and calibration procedure: switch debounce, approach speed 0.4 [rad/s], backoff 0.03 [rad], max attempts 5, timeout 10 s, and a guaranteed safe halt if exceeded. Include unit-tested state transitions and timing assertions.

Develop a multi-axis gantry controller to maintain squareness: the primary axis follows a position trajectory [rad], the secondary axis uses cross-coupled control to keep differential angle at 0 [rad]. Modes: IDLE, SYNC, RUN, FAULT. Include end-stop handling, a 1 kHz control loop, WCET budget 0.6 ms, and verification steps for mode coverage.
When a boolean go signal is true, drive a wheel motor at 0.5 [mps]; otherwise command 0 [mps]. Enforce a hard max speed of 0.6 [mps].
On a rising edge of an open command, move a servo to 1.20 [rad]; otherwise hold at 0.00 [rad]. Clamp all position commands to the safe range [0.00, 1.50] [rad].
Map a single analog input in [0..1] to wheel velocity in [-0.8, 0.8] [mps] with a 0.05 deadband around zero. Output the resulting [mps] to one motor.
Toggle a stepper target between 0.00 [rad] and 6.28 [rad] when a toggle input changes state. Never allow the commanded position to exceed 8.00 [rad].
Drive a single motor toward a target speed in [mps] with a simple slew limit of 0.2 [mps/s]. Saturate the output to ±1.0 [mps].
Set a servo’s commanded angle directly from a target [rad], clipped to [0.0, 2.5] [rad], and ignore small changes below 0.01 [rad] to prevent chatter.
If enable is true, hold wheel speed at 0.3 [mps]; if false, command 0 [mps]. Do not allow reversal; negative commands are clamped to 0 [mps].
Implement a simple safety: when emergency stop is active, immediately force motor velocity to 0 [mps]. Otherwise pass through the requested speed, bounded to ±0.4 [mps].
When test mode is true, step a servo between 0.50 [rad] and 1.00 [rad] with a 2 s dwell at each end; otherwise hold last position.
Convert a joystick forward command in [-1, 1] to wheel velocity with scale 1.2 [mps], then limit the output to ±1.0 [mps].
When a center signal is pressed, command a linear actuator servo to 0.50 [rad]; otherwise retain the previous command. Clip all angles to [0.20, 0.80] [rad].
If motor temperature exceeds a threshold, linearly derate maximum allowable speed down to 0 [mps] at 90 C; otherwise allow up to 1.0 [mps].
Implement jog controls for a stepper: each jog+ pulse adds +0.10 [rad], each jog- pulse subtracts 0.10 [rad]. Enforce hard stops at 0.00 [rad] and 3.14 [rad].
When battery voltage is below 11.0 V, cap wheel velocity commands to 0.3 [mps]; otherwise permit up to 0.8 [mps].
Latch a fault if measured motor current exceeds a threshold for more than 100 ms and force speed to 0 [mps] until reset; otherwise pass through the requested [mps] within safe limits.
For a two-wheel drive, convert forward velocity [mps] and yaw rate [rad/s] into left/right wheel velocities [mps]. Apply saturation and a per-loop slew limit. Run at 100 Hz with WCET ≤ 1 ms.
Create a small state machine: IDLE → ARMED → MOVING for a servo. On ARMED and a start pulse, move to a target [rad]; on complete, return to IDLE. Any E-STOP sends to FAULT and commands 0 motion.

Implement stepper homing: on startup, move toward home until a switch triggers, set zero, then accept absolute position commands in [rad] within soft limits. Include a homing timeout and fail-safe stop.
Generate a simple trapezoidal velocity profile from current to target speed in [mps] using specified accel/decel limits. Cancel if a stop signal occurs. Run at 200 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.8 ms.
Mirror two servos so that servo2_angle = π − servo1_angle, both constrained to [0.2, 2.8] [rad]. If either channel faults, freeze both at their last safe positions.
If measured motor current rises above a configurable threshold, gradually derate the speed command [mps]; restore normal limits once current falls and hysteresis clears. Expose a derate_active flag.
Control a two-axis gimbal with commanded pan/tilt angles in [rad]. Enforce per-axis rate limits of 0.5 [rad/s] and absolute angle limits. E-STOP must reset both axes to neutral safely.
Accept a stepper target given in revolutions, convert to [rad], and command the move only when enabled. Enforce an absolute bound of 50 [rad] and ignore inputs while moving.
Implement soft limits for a servo: warn when commanded outside the preferred window [0.1, 2.4] [rad] and clip to that range. Count and expose the number of soft-limit clips.
Maintain a rotary arm at a set angle [rad] using on/off control with a ±0.02 [rad] deadband. If overshoot occurs, coast until re-entering the deadband.
Design a safety state machine for motor velocity [mps]: RUN → STOP → CLEAR. Loss of enable or E-STOP transitions to STOP (0 [mps]); only a clear signal returns to RUN.
Synchronize two motors: track individual velocities [mps] and adjust commands to minimize their difference. If |v1−v2| > 0.1 [mps], limit both speeds until matched.
Create a servo sweep test: move from 0.00 to 3.14 [rad] over 10 s and back, repeating while test_enable is true. Provide a ready flag after each full cycle.
For a stepper, ignore any new target angle within 0.20 [rad] of the current position to prevent micro-moves; execute larger moves immediately.
Implement a safe-start for throttle-to-speed mapping: require throttle near zero for 2 s before enabling motor output. Then ramp to the target [mps] with a per-cycle limit. Limit sudden jumps.
