Add a drive mode selector: NORMAL caps at 1.0 [mps], TURTLE caps at 0.3 [mps]. Track the active mode and latch a fault that prevents exiting TURTLE until reset.
Filter the speed setpoint [mps] with a first-order filter to smooth operator inputs. Specify a time constant and ensure control loop runs at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Implement a deadman: require periodic keepalive pulses; if none are received for 150 ms, force motor command to 0 [mps] and set a timeout fault.
Create a thermal derate state machine: NORMAL, WARM, HOT based on motor temperature (C). Reduce max speed [mps] per state and apply hysteresis to avoid rapid toggling.
For a pan/tilt head, limit tilt range based on pan angle: when |pan| > 1.4 [rad], constrain tilt to ±0.6 [rad]; otherwise allow ±0.8 [rad]. Reject commands violating the coupled limits.

Implement a PID velocity controller to track a target wheel speed in [mps]. Include anti-windup, derivative on measurement, and output saturation at ±1.2 [mps]. Run at 200 Hz, WCET ≤ 0.7 ms, and raise tracking_ok when error < 0.05 [mps] for 100 ms.

Build a PID position control loop for a rotary joint to hold a commanded angle in [rad]. Enforce slew rate ≤ 1.0 [rad/s], angle bounds [0.0, 2.8] [rad], and anti-windup. Declare a fault if not within ±0.02 [rad] in 2 s.

Create a cascaded controller: outer position PID (target in [rad]) produces a velocity command [rad/s], inner velocity PID drives the actuator. Enforce hard angle and speed limits, run at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 1.2 ms, and freeze integrators during saturation.

Fuse encoder angle [rad] with gyro rate [rad/s] using a complementary filter to estimate angle/velocity. Use the fused signals in a PID position loop to follow a target [rad]. Fault if fusion residual exceeds 0.2 [rad] for >100 ms.

Estimate wheel velocity [mps] by fusing encoder-derived speed with accelerometer integration. Drive a PID speed loop using the fused estimate, and derate max speed by 50% if the two sources disagree by >0.3 [mps].
Track a time-stamped velocity profile in [mps] with jerk-limited transitions. Feed setpoints into a PID speed controller. Require steady-state error < 0.05 [mps] and run at 250 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.8 ms.

Detect stalls: if position error stays > 0.10 [rad] while commanded velocity exceeds 0.4 [rad/s] for 500 ms, declare a stall, cut outputs to zero, latch a fault, and require explicit reset to recover.

Augment a PID speed controller [mps] with friction compensation (static and Coulomb feedforward). Provide a calibration routine to estimate parameters, and ensure the summed command remains within ±1.0 [mps].
Apply gain scheduling to a PID velocity loop in [mps] based on motor temperature to maintain stability across conditions. Define gain ranges, ensure no oscillations, and clamp outputs to ±0.9 [mps].

Control a stepper in closed loop using encoder feedback: track a target angle [rad] with a PID that corrects missed steps. If error spikes > 0.3 [rad], enter a hold-safe mode. Run at 1 kHz, WCET ≤ 0.6 ms.

Design a multi-mode joint controller with CALIBRATE (home to switch, set zero), POSITION_HOLD (PID on [rad]), VELOCITY_TRACK (PID on [rad/s]), and FAULT. Define transitions, E-STOP priority, absolute limits, and rate limits. Schedule at 1 kHz with WCET ≤ 0.7 ms, and list test cases (start/stop, E-STOP during motion, homing timeout).

Create a dual-wheel system with modes: MANUAL (joystick to [mps]), CRUISE (PID holds [mps]), and SAFE_STOP. Fuse encoder and IMU signals for velocity estimation, detect slip by comparing command vs estimate, derate on low battery/overtemp, and provide acceptance tests for each mode.

Implement a robotic slider that executes sequences of target positions [rad] with jerk-limited profiles, using cascaded PID loops. Include a dynamic no-go zone that shrinks the allowed range. Require deterministic timing at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.9 ms and a startup self-test.

Coordinate four servos to reach a 4D joint target vector [rad] synchronously with a shared timeline. Provide modes IDLE, EXECUTE, PAUSE, ABORT, and FAULT; watchdog and deadman safety; tests for limit violations, mid-move pause/resume, and WCET compliance.

Develop a high-integrity stepper controller with modes: OPEN_LOOP microstepping, CLOSED_LOOP correction via encoder, CAL for steps-per-rad calibration, and SAFE on anomalies. Enforce motion envelopes, detect stalls, and specify WCET ≤ 1.0 ms at 1 kHz plus verification procedures per mode.
When a boolean input 'open' is true, set a servo to 1.0 [rad]; otherwise hold 0.0 [rad]. Reject any command outside [-1.5, 1.5] [rad] and default to 0.0 [rad] on fault.
On each rising edge of a button, jog a rotary actuator by +0.05 [rad]; on a long-press (>1 s), jog -0.05 [rad]. Rate-limit jogs to at most one action per 200 ms.
Map an analog slider (0–100%) to a servo angle from 0.0 to 2.0 [rad]. Clamp the output to [0.0, 2.0] [rad] and apply a small deadband to reduce jitter.
Drive a motor to 0.25 [mps] whenever 'enable' is true; when false, stop. Use a smooth 0.5 s ramp on start/stop, but if 'estop' is true, command 0 [mps] immediately.
At power-up, command a joint to 0.75 [rad] and hold. If a new target arrives, go to that [rad] value but constrain the allowed range to [-1.2, 1.2] [rad].
Use a boolean 'reverse' to choose direction: if true, command -0.15 [mps], else +0.15 [mps]. Maintain constant magnitude and stop when 'reverse' is undefined.
If a limit switch is active, set the target position to 0.0 [rad] and hold; otherwise, leave the current target unchanged.
Accept a numeric input in [rad] and command a servo to that angle. Clamp to [-2.0, 2.0] [rad] and ignore NaN or invalid values.
Run a conveyor at 0.35 [mps] while 'run' is true; when false, decelerate linearly to 0 [mps] over 0.3 s.
On a double-tap of a button within 400 ms, move to 1.57 [rad]; a single tap moves to 0.0 [rad]. Ignore further taps while motion is active.
When enabled, generate a soft-start ramp from 0 to 0.20 [mps] over 2 s. Hold the final speed until disabled, then ramp down over 1 s.
Accept a scalar velocity setpoint and drive the motor accordingly. If the setpoint is negative, reverse direction. Saturate the magnitude at 0.40 [mps].
Every second, toggle an actuator between -0.5 [rad] and +0.5 [rad], with a 0.5 s dwell at each end. Keep the pattern while enabled.
If a fault signal is true, immediately command 0 [mps]. Otherwise, pass the requested speed through a limiter capped at 0.60 [mps].
Convert a dial reading (0–1) to a joint angle from 0.0 to 2.0 [rad], with a ±0.02 [rad] deadband near 0.0 to suppress jitter.

Implement a two-state machine: IDLE holds 0.0 [rad]; TRACK moves to 1.2 [rad] with a trapezoidal profile (max 0.5 [rad] per second). On 'start' enter TRACK; on 'cancel' or limit trip return to IDLE. Run at 100 Hz.

Create a homing routine for a rotary axis: move negative until the home switch closes, set position to 0.0 [rad], then back off to +0.05 [rad]. Refuse motion if the far limit switch is already active.
Synchronize two wheels to the same linear speed target up to 0.8 [mps]. If either wheel’s feedback differs by more than 0.1 [mps], slow both to 0.0 [mps] and raise a warning.
Alternate among three position setpoints: 0.0 [rad], 0.8 [rad], and 1.6 [rad], each with a 2 s dwell. Use a timer-driven state machine at 50 Hz and ensure WCET under 0.5 ms.

Accept position commands in [rad] over a message channel. Validate they are within [-1.5, 1.5] [rad] and that step-to-step change does not exceed 0.2 [rad]. Reject invalid commands and hold last safe value.
Implement a jog mode with two buttons: one jogs +0.02 [rad] per press, the other -0.02 [rad]. Lock out jogs while moving and auto-disable power after 5 s of inactivity.
Drive a feeder belt to a target speed in [mps] with an overrun sensor. If the sensor toggles rapidly (>10 Hz), debounce and stop the belt until manually cleared.
Provide a soft limit zone: when within 0.1 [rad] of either end stop, reduce max speed to 0.1 [rad] per second; otherwise allow 0.5 [rad] per second.
Implement a watchdog: if no new speed command is received for 300 ms, ramp to 0 [mps] over 0.2 s and latch a timeout flag until reset.
Switch between POSITION and VELOCITY control modes via a selector. In POSITION, track a target in [rad]. In VELOCITY, hold a target in [mps]. Transition smoothly between modes without output jumps.
Add a slew-rate limiter so the commanded angle changes no faster than 0.4 [rad] per second. Guarantee WCET of the limiting path is < 0.2 ms at 200 Hz.
Implement start/stop/estop for a motor. Start ramps to 0.30 [mps], stop ramps down over 0.5 s, estop forces 0 [mps] immediately and blocks restart until cleared.
Create a shuttle motion between two adjustable positions A and B in [rad], with limits on acceleration and speed and a maximum cycle time of 4 s. Pause if a presence sensor is blocked.
Combine a foot pedal and dial: the pedal enables motion, the dial sets speed up to 0.6 [mps]. On pedal release, decelerate to 0 [mps] in 150 ms.

For a stepper axis, perform smooth microstep motion to a commanded angle in [rad], respecting a maximum angle change rate of 1.0 [rad] per second. Use the home switch to prevent over-travel and back off by 0.01 [rad] if tripped.
Implement a dwell-and-rotate routine: rotate to 0.9 [rad], hold 1 s, rotate back to 0.0 [rad], hold 1 s, and repeat while enabled. Ensure the control task runs at 100 Hz with WCET < 0.4 ms.
Add anti-jam behavior: if measured speed stays below 0.05 [mps] while commanded > 0.20 [mps] for more than 300 ms, reverse at 0.10 [mps] for 200 ms, then retry forward.
Control a pan axis with a joystick; map joystick deflection to velocity in [mps] with a deadzone and exponential scaling. Enforce position limits at [-1.0, 1.0] [rad].
Hold a vertical actuator at 0.0 [rad] unless a load sensor exceeds a threshold, then move to 0.2 [rad] to relieve force and return when cleared. Honor a speed limit of 0.15 [rad] per second.
Create a periodic calibration reminder that, every 10 minutes, requests a move to 0.0 [rad] when safe. If motion is in progress, defer the request to the next idle window.
Design a PID position controller for a rotary joint with a setpoint in [rad]. Include anti-windup, output saturation, and a max slew of 0.6 [rad] per second. Run at 200 Hz with WCET under 0.3 ms.

Implement a cascaded controller: an outer-loop PID regulates position in [rad], and an inner-loop PID regulates linear velocity in [mps]. Ensure bumpless transfer between manual and automatic and enforce soft limits at ±1.5 [rad].
Fuse two velocity measurements to estimate linear speed in [mps], then regulate to the commanded speed with PID. Reject outliers and fall back to a single sensor if disagreement exceeds 0.2 [mps].

Generate a trapezoidal motion profile from the current position to a target in [rad] with configurable max speed and acceleration. Feed the profile to a PID actuator loop and ensure peak following error stays below 0.03 [rad].
Implement feedforward plus PID control for a conveyor to reach 0.50 [mps] quickly with less than 10% overshoot. Limit acceleration to prevent slip and command 0 [mps] if an emergency input triggers.
Create a dual-motor synchronization scheme where a slave tracks a master’s position in [rad] via PID. If error exceeds 0.1 [rad] for 200 ms, enter a fault state and decouple the axes.

Perform online friction compensation: estimate static friction by observing when velocity in [mps] first moves from zero, then bias the PID output to reduce stiction while respecting speed and position limits.
Implement a velocity PID that switches gains by speed bands: low (0–0.1 [mps]), mid (0.1–0.4 [mps]), high (0.4–0.8 [mps]). Ensure stable transitions and WCET <= 0.4 ms at 250 Hz.

Combine an incremental encoder with a coarse absolute sensor to estimate actuator position in [rad]. If the difference exceeds 0.2 [rad], trust the absolute reading and re-zero the encoder during a controlled stop.

Add a safety supervisor around the motion controller: monitor position [rad], speed [mps], and command age. Immediately command 0 [mps] if any exceeds limits, and require an operator reset before enabling again. Log timestamps and fault reasons.

Build a multi-mode actuator controller with states OFF, MANUAL, AUTO, and SAFE. MANUAL maps a dial to velocity in [mps]; AUTO tracks a position sequence in [rad] using PID; SAFE commands 0 [mps] and ignores inputs. Define interlocks, transitions, 200 Hz update, and a WCET budget of 0.5 ms.

Develop a redundant speed control system using two independent sensors reporting [mps]. Fuse them with median or weighted logic, detect disagreement, degrade gracefully to limited performance, and produce a comprehensive test plan including sensor failure injection, rate jitter analysis, and WCET margin checks.

Create a coordinated dual-axis motion plan for a pick-and-place: both joints move to targets in [rad] so the end effector maintains a constant transport speed of 0.30 [mps]. Include mode transitions, soft-limit enforcement, and acceptance tests for maximum tracking error.

Specify a complete homing-and-run sequence with modes POWERUP, HOMING, READY, RUN, and FAULT. Use PID position control in RUN for targets in [rad]. Define recovery from mid-cycle faults, watchdog behavior, safety limits, 100 Hz update rate, and WCET < 0.6 ms, with verification steps.

Design an end-to-end verification-oriented controller for a belt drive: requirement-based tests for step responses to 0.20, 0.50, and 0.80 [mps]; limit testing for over-speed and stale command handling; state machine coverage; and logging of cycle time to prove WCET compliance.
Drive a single rotary actuator to 0.00 [rad] while an input button is released, and to 1.00 [rad] while the button is pressed. Update at 100 Hz.
While an enable flag is true, command a linear actuator to a constant speed of 0.20 [mps]; otherwise command 0 [mps].
On each rising edge of a jog input, increase the target joint angle by +0.10 [rad]; on each falling edge, decrease by -0.10 [rad]. Constrain the angle between 0.00 [rad] and 2.50 [rad].
At startup, ramp a rotary joint from 0.00 [rad] to 1.50 [rad] over 3 s and hold there.
Implement a dead-man function: if a hold-to-run input is maintained, command 0.30 [mps]; if released, immediately command 0 [mps]. Guarantee WCET <= 1 ms.
Each time a toggle button is pressed, switch the motor direction while maintaining a constant magnitude of 0.10 [mps].
On power-up, move the actuator to 0.785 [rad] and hold; if a reset input is asserted, drive to 0.000 [rad] and hold.
If a stop command arrives, decelerate smoothly to 0 [mps] within 1.0 s; if run is true, maintain 0.25 [mps].
Accept a numeric setpoint in [rad] and command the joint to that absolute angle, clamped to the range [0.00, 3.14] [rad].
Track a requested linear speed input in [mps], but cap the magnitude to 0.40 [mps] before sending to the motor.
Drive forward at 0.15 [mps] unless a limit switch is active, in which case command 0 [mps] immediately.
Five seconds after startup, move a rotary actuator from 0.00 [rad] to 2.00 [rad]; otherwise hold at 0.00 [rad].
Hold a joint at 1.20 [rad] unless an overtravel signal is present; then command 0.00 [rad] and inhibit motion.
Map an analog input in the range 0.0 to 1.0 to an actuator angle from 0.0 to 3.14 [rad], updating at 50 Hz.
Map an analog slider -1.0 to +1.0 to linear speed -0.50 to +0.50 [mps], with a small deadband around zero.

Create a homing state machine for a linear axis: on startup, move toward home at 0.05 [mps] until the home switch closes, stop, zero the position, then wait for a go command to allow normal operation.
Given commands for forward speed in [mps] and turn rate in [rad] per second, compute left and right wheel speeds and drive them, saturating each wheel to +/-0.60 [mps].
Maintain a desired joint angle in [rad] with a simple error threshold: if |error| < 0.01 [rad], command zero motion; otherwise drive toward the setpoint.

Provide two modes for a rotary joint: Manual jog with two buttons that step +/-0.05 [rad] per press, and Auto where the joint moves to a numeric setpoint [rad]. Include a latch to switch modes safely.
If measured speed exceeds 0.60 [mps], immediately cut motor command to zero and latch a fault until a reset input clears it.
Enforce soft limits on a joint: keep the commanded angle within [0.00, 2.50] [rad], and taper the allowed speed to zero as the setpoint approaches either limit.
Slew-limit a requested linear velocity so it cannot change faster than 0.20 [mps] per second before applying it to the actuator. Ensure update rate 200 Hz.
When a current-limit input is asserted, reduce the target linear speed to 0.15 [mps]; otherwise allow up to 0.30 [mps]. Provide a 200 ms delay before restoring full speed.

Implement a three-state controller for a joint: Idle, Moving, and Settled. On start, go to Moving toward a target [rad]; when within 0.02 [rad] for 100 ms, go to Settled; on new command, return to Moving; on timeout, enter Fault.
Detect a stall: if the system commands >0.10 [mps] for more than 2 s but measured motion remains <0.01 [mps], stop the motor and raise a fault.
Toggle between two absolute angles (0.00 [rad] and 1.57 [rad]) every 3 s while enabled; otherwise hold current position. Update loop 100 Hz; enforce WCET <= 0.5 ms.
While an enable is true, generate a sinusoidal position target with amplitude 0.20 [rad] at 1 Hz and drive the joint to follow it; when disabled, hold at 0.00 [rad].
On overcurrent, ramp the commanded linear speed to 0 over 0.5 s; on clear, ramp back toward the request, limited to 0.40 [mps].
Manual/auto selection: in manual, map joystick input -1 to +1 to -0.50 to +0.50 [mps]; in auto, follow a preloaded speed schedule. Switch modes only when actual speed is within +/-0.05 [mps] of zero.
Track a piecewise-linear angle profile defined as time/angle pairs in [rad], advancing at real time and holding at the final point.
Implement an emergency stop: on e-stop input, command 0 [mps] immediately, disable further commands, and require a 2 s stable condition plus reset input before re-enabling.
Low-pass filter a noisy velocity command (cutoff 5 Hz) before applying it to the actuator, maintaining units in [mps]. Run at 200 Hz and guarantee WCET < 1 ms.
Constrain a servo to operate only within [-1.0, +1.0] [rad]. If a command attempts to exceed the window, saturate to the boundary and report a limit-hit status.
On an index pulse, capture the current joint position [rad], stop motion, and report the captured angle for downstream use.
If measured temperature exceeds a threshold, reduce maximum speed from 0.30 to 0.10 [mps]; restore to 0.30 [mps] only after cooling below the lower threshold to add hysteresis.

Design a closed-loop PID position controller for a rotary joint: input is desired angle in [rad] and measured angle in [rad]. Limit the output so that the implied angular speed cannot exceed a safe value, and ensure the control loop runs at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.5 ms. Include integrator anti-windup.

Implement a PID speed controller for a linear axis to track a commanded velocity in [mps]. Add a feedforward term, limit acceleration by slewing the setpoint, and declare a fault if actual speed stays below 0.02 [mps] for 1 s while the command exceeds 0.10 [mps].

Build a cascaded controller: outer loop holds position [rad] with PID and outputs a velocity request; inner loop regulates that velocity with PID before sending to the motor. Run at 500 Hz, with clear saturation limits and anti-windup.

Fuse an encoder angle [rad] with a gyroscope rate to estimate angle and rate using a complementary filter, then hold a commanded angle in [rad] with PID. If the encoder signal is lost, fall back to gyro integration with reduced bandwidth and limit speeds for safety.

Detect and mitigate wheel slip by comparing kinematic forward speed from wheel rotation to an IMU-derived estimate of [mps]; if the discrepancy exceeds 0.20 [mps] for >100 ms, reduce the commanded speed by 50% until agreement returns.

Generate a jerk-limited S-curve motion from current to target angle in [rad], bounding peak speed such that the linear tip speed does not exceed 0.60 [mps] given a provided radius. Guarantee timing determinism with WCET <= 1 ms.

Implement thermal derating: read motor temperature and linearly reduce the allowed speed limit from 0.50 to 0.10 [mps] between 60 C and 85 C. Integrate this limit with a PID velocity controller and enforce a watchdog on the update rate.

Use two redundant encoders reporting [rad] to drive a joint; continuously compare them and if the difference exceeds 0.03 [rad] for more than 50 ms, enter a degraded mode that caps speed to 0.10 [mps] and flags a fault.
Apply a notch filter centered at 20 Hz to the commanded angle [rad] to suppress resonance, then control the joint with PID. Run at 1 kHz and cap the output to safe motion rates.

Follow a time-stamped trajectory of angles in [rad] with a PID position loop such that tracking error stays below 0.02 [rad]; if error exceeds this for 200 ms, perform an emergency stop to 0 [mps] and hold.

Create a multi-mode joint controller with modes Safe, Homing, PositionHold, and TrajectoryFollow. Define transitions (e.g., Safe on any fault, Homing at startup, PositionHold when holding a [rad] setpoint), enforce speed limits in [mps] during each mode, and specify loop rate 1 kHz with per-mode WCET budgets. Provide a brief built-in self-test on entry to Safe and Homing.

Design a dual-channel actuation supervisor for a critical axis: two independent command sources propose angles in [rad]. Cross-check them, vote or reject on disagreement beyond 0.05 [rad], and ensure a fail-operational degraded mode that caps motion to 0.10 [mps]. Include periodic self-tests and define precise timing (update 500 Hz, WCET <= 0.8 ms).

Implement a multi-mode drive for a differential base: Manual teleoperation accepts forward speed in [mps] and turn rate in [rad] per second; Autonomous follows a path of [mps] vs time; Fault mode forces 0 [mps]. Define transitions, watchdogs, soft limits, and a test plan covering mode switches, limit enforcement, and loss of command.

Specify an end-of-line calibration and verification sequence for a servo joint: sweep from -1.0 to +1.0 [rad] at a gentle 0.05 [mps], detect hard stops, compute center offset, store it, and verify by commanding 0.0 [rad] twice. Include safety stops, timing limits (WCET <= 1 ms), and acceptance criteria.

Develop a comprehensive motion safety controller for a conveyor-like axis: manage max speed limits in [mps], protective stops, restart interlocks, and periodic proof tests of sensors. Define deterministic timing (200 Hz, WCET <= 0.5 ms), diagnostic coverage targets, and clear pass/fail criteria for automated testing.
Set a rotary servo to 1.0 [rad] when the 'go' input is true; otherwise hold at 0.0 [rad]. Add a simple software limit to prevent commands outside [-1.2, 1.2] [rad].
Take a single numeric speed command in [mps] and send it to a linear actuator, clamping the value to the safe range [-0.4, 0.4] [mps].
On each rising edge of a trigger input, advance a stepper by +0.05 [rad]; when position exceeds 1.2 [rad], wrap to 0.0 [rad].
Track a target speed input in [mps] with a slew rate limit of 0.1 [mps] per second; send the limited speed to the motor.
Map a single angle input in [rad] directly to a servo command, but enforce soft limits [-1.0, 1.0] [rad].
Command a joint to the requested angle [rad] from a single setpoint input while limiting the maximum slew to 0.5 [rad/s].
Monitor measured belt speed [mps]; if it exceeds 0.8 [mps], command the drive to 0 [mps] immediately and latch an overspeed flag.
When an enable input is true, jog a stepper forward by 0.03 [rad] every 100 ms; when false, hold the current angle.
Read a scalar input (0..1) and scale it linearly to a motor speed of 0..0.6 [mps], with output saturation at 0.6 [mps].
Each time a 'next' pulse arrives, move a servo to the next preset angle from [0.0, 0.5, 1.0] [rad], wrapping back to 0.0 [rad] after the last.
Drive a conveyor at a constant 0.2 [mps] unless an emergency input is asserted, in which case command 0 [mps] immediately.
Mirror a measured angle input [rad] to a servo output so the actuator follows the input exactly, with clamping to [-1.2, 1.2] [rad].
Low-pass filter a speed command input (time constant 0.3 s) before sending it to the motor in [mps], to smooth abrupt changes.
Apply a deadband of ±0.02 [mps] to a single speed command input; only pass values outside the deadband to the actuator.
Run a 50 Hz loop (WCET 5 ms) that reads a target angle [rad] and updates the servo to that angle with saturation at ±1.0 [rad].
Drive a rotary joint to a commanded angle [rad] while observing two endstop inputs; stop and latch a fault if an endstop is hit before the target. Control at 200 Hz with WCET 0.8 ms.
Given forward speed [mps] and turn rate [rad], compute left and right wheel velocities and command both motors, enforcing ±0.6 [mps] limits and honoring an emergency stop input.

Build a small state machine: Idle → Homing → Ready → Fault. On start, rotate negative until a home switch closes, then move to 0.0 [rad]. In Ready, accept angle setpoints [rad]. Any e-stop sends the system to Fault and disables motion.
Provide jog controls with two buttons: one increments +0.02 [rad] per press, the other decrements by 0.02 [rad]; if a 'hold' input is held, move continuously at 0.1 [rad/s] within [-1.2, 1.2] [rad].
Track a target conveyor speed [mps] but if the target step change exceeds 0.2 [mps], ramp over 1.0 s; otherwise follow immediately. Clamp to [-0.5, 0.5] [mps].
Generate a trapezoidal motion to a target angle [rad] using provided max velocity [rad/s] and acceleration [rad/s^2]; never command outside ±1.5 [rad].
Synchronize two joints: mirror joint A’s angle [rad] to joint B; if |A−B| exceeds 0.1 [rad] for more than 200 ms, stop both and report a tracking error.
Only apply high torque when the joint is within ±0.05 [rad] of the target; otherwise move toward the target at a limited rate of 0.05 [rad/s].
Creep forward at 0.02 [mps] until a force sensor input indicates contact, then hold position; stop with a fault if no contact after 5 s.
Implement a deadman function: as long as a safety-hold input is true, relay a joystick speed [mps] with a slew limit of 0.4 [mps^2]; when released, decelerate to 0 [mps] smoothly.
Enforce software motion limits: clamp any target angle [rad] to [-1.1, 1.1] [rad], flag when clamped, and run the control loop at 100 Hz with WCET 1 ms.

Manual/Auto selector: in Manual, pass a joystick speed [mps] through a rate limiter; in Auto, step through a stored list of angles [rad] with 0.5 s dwell at each. Ensure safe transitions between modes.
Blend a feedforward term with feedback: accept a desired angle [rad] and a nominal torque feedforward; sum with a bounded correction so the final command stays inside a safe envelope.
Execute: move to target angle [rad], dwell for a time input, then signal done; if a new target arrives mid-dwell, preempt and go to the new target.
Reject encoder spikes: if measured angle changes by more than 0.3 [rad] in one tick, ignore the update, keep the last good value, and increment a transient fault counter.
Schedule a velocity controller at 250 Hz with WCET 0.6 ms; if a deadline is missed, force speed to 0 [mps] and enter a degraded state until manually cleared.
Run a two-stage profile: accelerate to 0.4 [mps], hold for 2 s, then decelerate to 0 [mps]; start on a trigger input and ignore retriggers until the sequence completes.
Drive joint B to the negative of joint A's angle [rad] with a maximum allowed difference of 0.05 [rad]; if violated for 200 ms, stop both and raise an error.
Latch-and-execute: when a 'new target' strobe arrives, capture the angle [rad] and move there; ignore further strobes until the motion completes or a stop input occurs.
Apply temperature-based derating: limit max conveyor speed from 0.6 [mps] at 40 C down to 0.2 [mps] at 70 C, and stop motion entirely above 75 C.
Implement PID position control to track a setpoint [rad] with anti-windup, output saturation, and a 0.6 [rad/s] slew limit. Flag a fault if error >0.05 [rad] persists for >1 s.
Hold a conveyor at 0.35 [mps] with a velocity PID using encoder feedback; include integral clamping and overspeed shutdown. Run at 500 Hz with WCET 0.9 ms.
Use cascaded control: an outer position loop in [rad] generates a velocity command; an inner velocity loop tracks it. Both loops have saturation and anti-windup.
Fuse an encoder with an accelerometer to estimate carriage velocity [mps]; use the fused estimate to follow a target speed while rejecting spikes and handling dropouts.
Coordinate two joints on a Lissajous path: A = 0.8·sin(t) [rad], B = 0.8·cos(t) [rad]; ensure each stays within ±1.2 [rad] and enter a fault if tracking error exceeds 0.1 [rad].
Provide a runtime-tunable position PID: when a 'tune' flag is set, apply a 0.1 [rad] step, measure rise time and overshoot, and revert gains if overshoot exceeds 10%.
Detect stalls during speed control: if commanded >0.2 [mps] but measured <0.01 [mps] for 500 ms, cut power, latch a stall fault, and require an explicit reset to clear.
Implement a speed envelope dependent on angle: vmax = 0.5 [mps] for |θ|<0.5 [rad], linearly tapering to 0.2 [mps] at |θ|=1.2 [rad]; prevent any motion beyond ±1.2 [rad].
Track a time-stamped angle trajectory in [rad] with feedforward (velocity and acceleration) plus PID feedback; guarantee a 1 kHz control rate and WCET ≤ 0.7 ms.
Compare two redundant angle sensors [rad]; if they disagree by >0.03 [rad], freeze motion and raise sensor_fault; otherwise average them for the position PID loop.

Design a multi-mode motion controller with states: Boot, SelfTest, Homing, Manual, Auto, Fault. Manual uses joystick speed [mps] with a slew limiter; Auto follows queued waypoints in [rad]. Enforce 1 kHz rate, WCET 0.8 ms, and run self-tests (encoder range, actuator response) before enabling motion.

Create a coordinated dual-drive controller: maintain equal wheel speeds [mps] while tracking a commanded heading [rad]; include a supervisor for sensor disagreement, e-stop, and a degraded single-drive limp mode. If any cycle exceeds WCET 1.0 ms, transition to SafeHold.

Build a motion supervisor for a three-phase routine: Home to 0.0 [rad], visit five waypoints [rad] with dwells, then park and hold. Include comprehensive faults (home failure, timeout, overspeed) and a recovery step that backs off 0.1 [rad] and retries once. Loop at 500 Hz, WCET 1.2 ms, and record timing slack.

Implement a high-integrity conveyor controller using dual velocity estimates [mps] (encoder and fused IMU), a safety-rated PID with limiters, watchdog, and deadline proofs. Acceptance tests: step within 300 ms, steady-state error <0.01 [mps], and zero deadline misses over 10 minutes.

Develop a synchronized two-joint trajectory executor with jerk-limited profiles in [rad] and online replanning on new waypoints. Provide assertions for bounds, invariants on time stamps, WCET 0.9 ms, and a test harness that simulates limit switch and e-stop events.
Please move a servo to a target angle in [rad] from an input; clamp 0 to 1.5 [rad]; if the target is out of range, ignore it and hold position.
When a rising edge on Start occurs, advance a stepper exactly 200 steps then stop; enforce a maximum step rate of 100 steps per second and ignore further starts until done.
While Enable is true, command a linear actuator to a constant forward velocity of 0.25 [mps]; when Enable is false, command zero velocity.
Mirror two rotary servos: when one receives a target angle in [rad], command the other to the negative of that angle, both limited to ±1.0 [rad].
Gate a speed command by an emergency stop: if E‑Stop is active, force velocity output to 0 [mps]; otherwise pass the requested velocity but saturate at ±0.8 [mps].
Control a solenoid actuator with a minimum off time of 1.0 s between activations; ignore trigger requests arriving during the lockout.
Provide jog control for a joint: on Up, increase position setpoint by 0.05 [rad]; on Down, decrease by 0.05 [rad]; constrain setpoint to 0.0–1.2 [rad].
When Start is true, move a servo to 0.70 [rad]; when Start is false, hold current position.
Run a motor forward until an endstop switch becomes active, then stop immediately and latch a 'reached endstop' status.
Apply a deadband to a linear velocity command: treat magnitudes below 0.02 [mps] as zero; otherwise pass through unchanged.
If a temperature warning is present, cap the commanded linear velocity to 0.10 [mps]; clear the cap only after the warning has been absent for 5 s.
Generate a square-wave position pattern for a servo alternating between 0.20 [rad] and 1.00 [rad] with a 4 s period; provide a Stop input to freeze at the current angle.
On reset, drive a servo to a neutral angle of 0.50 [rad] and report when within ±0.02 [rad].
Delay motion start by 2.0 s after a Go request, then command a constant 0.20 [mps] until a Stop request arrives.
Rate-limit a position setpoint so it changes no faster than 0.5 [rad] per second; apply symmetric limits for increasing and decreasing commands.

Implement a homing sequence for a rotary axis: move negative at 0.4 [rad] per second until the home switch is active, back off by 0.05 [rad], re-approach slowly at 0.1 [rad] per second to re-trip, then set position to 0 [rad] and enter Idle.

For a two-wheel drive, accept commands of linear velocity in [mps] and turn rate in [rad] per second; compute left and right wheel target velocities, saturate to ±1.0 [mps], and ramp changes at 0.5 [mps] per second; run at 100 Hz.

Build a state machine with states Idle, Arm, MoveToTarget, and Hold. Transition to MoveToTarget on a valid position command in [rad], to Hold when within ±0.01 [rad], and back to Idle on Cancel or fault.

Control a stepper in absolute mode: convert a target angle in [rad] to steps using a configurable steps-per-[rad] parameter, respect both min and max limit switches, and require an Acknowledge to clear limit faults.
Create a scan routine that visits waypoints 0.20, 1.00, and 0.50 [rad]; dwell 1.0 s at each; allow Pause and Resume; abort immediately on Stop.
Generate a motion profile for a linear actuator: accelerate at 0.3 [mps] per second up to 0.6 [mps], cruise for 2.0 s, then decelerate to zero; allow a Stop input to interrupt and decelerate safely.
Synchronize two rotary axes to the same commanded position in [rad]; if their measured positions differ by more than 0.05 [rad], pause motion and raise an error.
Scale and offset a joystick angle input to a servo command in [rad]; apply a deadband of 0.02 [rad] and clamp the final command to 0.1–1.2 [rad].
Provide two modes: ManualJog and GoTo. Toggle modes with a switch. In ManualJog, use incremental inputs to step by 0.02 [rad]. In GoTo, move to a target angle in [rad] and hold.
Enforce soft limits for a joint: between 0.0 and 1.4 [rad], with a smoothing zone of 0.1 [rad] near each limit where velocity is reduced to protect mechanics.
Implement a watchdog for command freshness: if no new velocity command has been received for 500 ms, set output to 0 [mps]. The control loop runs at 200 Hz with WCET not exceeding 0.8 ms.
Coordinate a motor brake with motion: before commanding torque, release the brake and wait 50 ms; when target velocity drops to 0 [mps], engage the brake after a 100 ms hold.
Index a stepper by 0.785 [rad] each time a part sensor triggers; ignore triggers closer than 200 ms apart; time out and flag an error if the index is not completed within 1.5 s.
Implement a deadman switch: while Deadman is true, follow a velocity command in [mps]; if it goes false, force velocity to 0 [mps] within 50 ms. Update at 1 kHz with WCET ≤ 0.3 ms.
Teach and repeat up to five positions in [rad] when Record is pressed; on Play, move through them at 0.2 [rad] per second with 0.5 s dwell at each; allow Stop to cancel.

Design a gripper rotation controller with states Open, Closing, Closed, and Opening. Use position thresholds in [rad], include a timeout to detect stalls, and emit a fault when the timeout is exceeded.
Detect wheel slip: if commanded velocity exceeds 0.3 [mps] but measured encoder velocity stays below 0.05 [mps] for 0.5 s, raise a fault and command 0 [mps].
Limit both acceleration and jerk for a linear velocity setpoint: at most 0.5 [mps] per second acceleration and 1.0 [mps] per second squared jerk.
Track a sinusoidal position target of amplitude 0.40 [rad] at 0.5 Hz; run the loop at 200 Hz and keep WCET below 1.0 ms; provide a Stop input.
Require safety interlocks: motion is allowed only when both GuardClosed and Enable are true; otherwise drive zero velocity [mps] and publish an inhibited status.

Implement a closed-loop position PID for a rotary joint using encoder feedback in [rad]. Include anti-windup, output saturation, and a configurable sample rate of 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.7 ms. Stop motion if a limit switch is hit or temperature alarm is active.

Create a velocity PID for a linear actuator with a target in [mps]; use encoder-derived velocity, include a feedforward term for the commanded [mps], and apply a low-pass filter to the derivative. Constrain output slew and enforce WCET under 0.6 ms at 1 kHz.

Build cascaded control loops for a rotary axis: an outer position PID on angle [rad] and an inner velocity PID on angular rate in [rad] per second. Run the inner loop at 1 kHz and the outer at 200 Hz; ensure deterministic scheduling and WCET budgets.

Fuse an encoder angle in [rad] with a gyro angular rate using a complementary filter to estimate angle and rate; use the fused angle for a position PID and the fused rate for damping. Specify filter time constant and ensure stable behavior during sensor dropout.
Coordinate two motors to maintain a constant phase offset of 0.785 [rad] using a PID on phase error; saturate outputs and halt if the phase error exceeds 1.0 [rad] for more than 200 ms.

Implement a motion planner that generates trapezoidal profiles to move from current to target position in [rad], respecting max velocity and acceleration limits. Feed the plan to a position PID; update at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.8 ms.
Compensate mechanical backlash: detect direction reversals and apply a configurable offset to the position command in [rad]. If the compensation exceeds 0.10 [rad], stop and flag a maintenance fault.

Fuse left and right wheel encoders to estimate linear velocity in [mps]; handle loss of one encoder by degrading to single-sensor mode with increased filtering. Use the fused [mps] in a velocity PID and limit acceleration.

Apply gain scheduling for a position PID: use higher gains near zero velocity and lower gains at higher planned speeds. Transition gains smoothly as a function of position error in [rad] and expected speed in [mps].

Implement thermal derating: as the motor temperature crosses thresholds, scale down the maximum allowed velocity in [mps] and clamp the PID integrator to prevent windup; include hysteresis to avoid chatter.

Design a multi-mode joint controller with modes Off, Calibrate, PositionHold, TrajectoryFollow, and ManualJog. Include an emergency stop, command watchdog, and logging of angle in [rad] and velocity in [mps]. Use an inner loop at 1 kHz (WCET ≤ 0.5 ms) and an outer planner at 200 Hz (WCET ≤ 1.0 ms). Provide clear state transitions and fault handling.

Specify a mobile base drive controller with modes SafeStop, Teleop, and Cruise. Accept Teleop commands as linear [mps] and turn rate in [rad] per second, enforce speed limit zones, and manage faults such as encoder mismatch and overcurrent by entering SafeStop. Include unit and integration test requirements.

Develop a redundant position sensing scheme using two encoders on the same joint. Cross-check angles in [rad]; if the difference exceeds 0.02 [rad], enter a Degraded mode with a reduced velocity limit of 0.15 [mps] and require operator reset. Define WCET budgeting and monitoring.

Create a dual-axis gimbal controller with modes Park, Stabilize, and Track. Use sensor fusion of encoder angle [rad] and gyro rate for stabilization, PID loops for each axis, saturation and rate limits, and comprehensive tests including step, ramp, and sinusoidal commands. State timing of 1 kHz inner loops and WCET limits.

Orchestrate multiple steppers for a conveyor system with modes Indexing, Continuous at a commanded belt speed in [mps], and JamClear reverse. Implement safety interlocks, trajectory generation, and a test plan validating WCET under 0.7 ms per axis and position error within 0.02 [rad] equivalent.
When a momentary button is pressed, move a servo to 1.57 [rad]; when released, return to 0.00 [rad]. Limit the move so it never overshoots more than ±0.02 [rad].
Toggle switch ON should run a motor at a constant 0.25 [mps]; switch OFF stops it. Include a simple acceleration ramp and immediately stop if an overcurrent flag is true.
Provide two jog buttons to step a rotary stage clockwise or counterclockwise to ±0.785 [rad] from zero; ignore commands if an endstop is active.
On enable, hold a shaft at 0.00 [rad] using tight deadband control (±0.02 [rad]); on disable, command zero torque.
At power-up, home a rotary axis by moving slowly until a reference switch closes, set that as 0.00 [rad], then move to 0.50 [rad] and stop.
Map a potentiometer (0-100%) to a servo target between 0.00 and 3.14 [rad], updating at 50 Hz. Clip to limits and ignore jitter near endpoints.
While a safety interlock input is true, command wheel speed to 0.40 [mps] at 100 Hz; otherwise command 0. Set a WCET budget of 100 us for the control update.
Implement a deadman drive: while the hold switch is pressed, drive forward at 0.20 [mps]; releasing the switch immediately commands 0 [mps].
Accept an external speed request and clamp it within ±0.60 [mps]; if clamped, keep the saturated value until the request re-enters the allowed range.
Select among three preset angles using a 2-bit input: 0.00, 0.79, or 1.57 [rad]. Move to the chosen angle and hold position.
If the absolute position error exceeds 0.20 [rad] for more than 100 ms, stop the actuator and latch a fault until a reset input is toggled.
Smooth a position command by applying a rate limiter so successive targets differ by no more than 0.05 [rad] per update.
Continuously sweep a servo between 0.00 and 1.00 [rad] with a 2 s dwell at each end; run the scheduler at 20 Hz.
Two buttons control forward/reverse motion at 0.30 [mps]; if both buttons are pressed at once, command 0 [mps] as a safety measure.
When stop is commanded, ensure the mechanism decelerates to below 0.10 [mps] within 500 ms; if not, apply an emergency stop output.
Create a small state machine (Idle, ToA, ToB) that moves a joint between 0.00 [rad] and 1.20 [rad] on alternating triggers. Respect two limit switches and time out if motion exceeds 3 s.
Run a conveyor section: accelerate to 0.50 [mps], slow to 0.10 [mps] when a part sensor activates, then stop at the next fiducial. Guarantee control updates at 200 Hz with WCET <= 200 us.
Drive a pan joint to the angle requested by a user dial (0.00-2.50 [rad]) but ignore spurious requests that change faster than 0.20 [rad] per 100 ms. Provide a gentle deceleration into the target.
Given left and right wheel encoders, compute average ground speed and hold 0.30 [mps] while a run command is true; apply a deadband to ignore tiny joystick inputs.
Index a stepper through 12 equally spaced positions (0.5236 [rad] apart). Home on a reference, then advance one index per trigger. Detect stall if no motion is sensed for 50 ms and halt safely.
Implement a door controller with states Opening, Closing, and Hold. Targets are 0.00 [rad] (closed) and 1.20 [rad] (open). If a pinch sensor triggers while Closing, immediately reverse to Opening.
Follow a list of waypoints in angle [rad] with max step of 0.10 [rad] between updates, dwelling 1 s at each waypoint. Abort and stop if any waypoint lies outside ±1.50 [rad].
Control wheel speed to a constant 0.45 [mps] using simple proportional feedback. Update at 500 Hz and cap the computation WCET at 60 us.
Record a sequence of joint angles for 5 s at 50 Hz when in Teach mode, then play back the trajectory once in Repeat mode. Enforce joint limits ±1.00 [rad].
On command, move smoothly from the current angle to a target within ±1.57 [rad] using a trapezoidal motion profile. Respect a max change of 0.05 [rad] per update, and stop on any limit hit.
Implement soft travel limits between -1.00 and +1.00 [rad]. If an external setpoint exceeds bounds, clamp and raise a 'limit reached' output until it returns within range.
Synchronize two joints moving to targets; slow the faster joint so that the position skew never exceeds 0.05 [rad]. If skew persists >500 ms, stop both and flag a fault.
Hold conveyor speed at 0.60 [mps] with proportional control and output saturation. Ensure updates at 1 kHz with WCET <= 80 us.
Drive a stepper to 1.20 [rad] and back to 0.00 [rad] repeatedly with controlled acceleration. If an endstop trips unexpectedly mid-travel, stop and rehome.
Convert a rotary setpoint in [rad] to a linear belt speed in [mps] using a known pulley radius, then command that belt speed at 100 Hz.
Coordinate a pan-tilt unit: pan to the target first, then tilt, only starting the second move after the first is within ±0.03 [rad]. Abort both on emergency stop.
Execute a cycle: go to 0.00 [rad], wait 3 s, move to -0.50 [rad], wait 1 s, then return to 0.00 [rad]. Repeat N times as requested.
Monitor measured speed; if it exceeds 1.20 [mps], immediately command 0 [mps] and latch a speed fault until an operator reset is received.
Provide two selectable cruise profiles: Eco at 0.20 [mps] and Fast at 0.50 [mps]. On mode change, decelerate smoothly before accelerating to the new speed.
At startup, sweep between two endstops to determine travel span in [rad], then scale a 0-100% command to that range. Reject commands that would exceed the learned endpoints.
Position PID for a single joint: track a target angle in [rad] at 1 kHz with anti-windup and slew limiting. Enforce soft limits ±1.80 [rad], emergency stop handling, and WCET <= 80 us.

Velocity PID to hold 0.40 [mps] using sensor fusion: combine wheel encoder and accelerometer to estimate speed, with fallback to encoder-only if the accelerometer is flagged faulty. Include saturation and over-speed protection.

Regulate a differential drive: maintain forward speed 0.50 [mps] while holding heading by balancing left/right wheel speeds with cross-coupled PID. Detect slip if commanded and measured speeds diverge and reduce gains accordingly.
Implement a cascaded controller: outer position PID in [rad], inner velocity loop in [mps]. Impose torque limits, jerk limitation on setpoints, and a watchdog timeout that forces a safe stop.
Track a jerk-limited S-curve trajectory in [rad] using position PID. If tracking error exceeds 0.15 [rad] for >100 ms, enter a fault state that requires operator reset.
Fuse incremental encoder angle with a periodic index pulse to correct drift, outputting a robust angle in [rad]. Use that estimate to drive a position PID and handle missed-index events gracefully.
Use gain scheduling: switch between low-velocity and high-velocity PID gains based on measured speed in [mps], ensuring bumpless transfer. Run at 500 Hz with WCET under 70 us.
Limit acceleration based on motor current estimate: integrate a velocity PID in [mps] but cap the rate of change when current is high. If current remains high for >50 ms, perform a controlled stop.
Coordinate two steppers on a gantry with cross-coupled control so parallelism error stays below 0.02 [rad]. If error spikes, pause, rehome the offending side, then resume.
Follow a sinusoidal position command up to 2 Hz with PID plus velocity/acceleration feedforward. Ensure control jitter stays within 50 us and overall WCET < 90 us.

Design a multi-mode joint controller with modes Idle, ManualJog, AutoPath, and Fault. Specify all state transitions, safety interlocks, limits ±2.00 [rad], caps on linear speed commands in [mps], a 1 kHz control rate with WCET <= 80 us, and the safe state on any fault. Include a concise test plan for mode transitions and limit enforcement.

Create a fault-tolerant velocity controller with redundant sensors: two wheel encoders and one IMU. Implement majority voting and fusion for speed in [mps], graceful degradation rules, PID control, and emergency stop behavior. Define timing (1 kHz loop, WCET 75 us) and a test plan with sensor fault injection and pass/fail criteria.

Specify an autonomous conveyor controller with modes StartUp, Homing, Run, EStop, and Recovery. Manage target speeds in [mps], monitor interlocks, and ensure any EStop forces a ramp to 0 within 300 ms. Provide per-task WCET budgets, deadlines, and acceptance tests covering every mode and transition.

Coordinate three rotary joints executing a time-synchronized trajectory. Include synchronization constraints, recovery to a limp mode on any single-axis fault, hard/soft limits in [rad], speed caps in [mps] for linear axes if present, a deterministic schedule (1 kHz) with WCET margins, and a verification plan with worst-case scenarios.

Engineer a high-integrity servo drive: dual-loop PID (position in [rad], velocity in [mps]), an independent safety monitor that enforces rate and position bounds, watchdog supervision, and a deterministic scheduler. Define the safety-governed ramp-to-zero behavior, WCET budgets, and a comprehensive set of validation tests.

Make a simple controller that drives a DC motor at a fixed linear speed when an enable input is true, and stops otherwise. The command speed should be specified in [mps] and clamped to a safe maximum. Include a configurable soft-start ramp so it reaches the target in 2 seconds.

Set a hobby servo to a requested angle given as [rad]. Clamp the angle between 0.0 [rad] and 2.6 [rad], and ignore any command outside this range. If no command is received for 3 seconds, move to a safe park angle of 0.5 [rad].
Jog a stepper motor forward while a 'jog' button is held, and stop when released. Limit the step rate to a safe maximum corresponding to 10 [rad/s] at the shaft.
On each press of a toggle button, reverse a motor's direction at a constant speed of 0.4 [mps]. If an emergency stop input is active, immediately command 0 [mps].
Ramp a conveyor motor from 0 to a target velocity in [mps] using a linear ramp over 3 seconds. Do not exceed 0.5 [mps] or an acceleration limit of 0.2 m/s^2.
Read a rotary knob (0–100%) and map it to a servo angle from 0.1 [rad] to 2.4 [rad]. Apply a simple rate limit so the angle changes no faster than 0.5 rad/s.
Switch a small actuator between two positions: 0.0 [rad] and 1.2 [rad], every 2 seconds. Ensure the transition rate is limited to 1.0 rad/s.
Hold a motor at zero velocity using a deadband: if measured speed is within ±0.05 [mps], command 0; otherwise command a small corrective speed toward zero.
Move a stepper exactly 200 steps forward when a start signal arrives, then stop. Ignore further start signals until motion completes.
Engage a motor brake when measured speed drops below 0.05 [mps]; release it when speed rises above 0.1 [mps]. Provide a 100 ms debounce on the brake command.
Filter a joystick input and send the smoothed value to a servo position target in [rad]. Use a first-order filter with a time constant of 0.3 s.
Drive a motor forward at 0.3 [mps] unless an obstacle sensor is active, in which case command -0.1 [mps] reverse for 1 second and then stop.
Mirror two wheel motors: given a single forward speed command in [mps], set the left motor to +speed and the right motor to -speed for in-place rotation. Cap absolute speed at 0.6 [mps].

On startup, move a servo slowly toward its minimum limit until a home switch is closed, then set current position as 0.0 [rad] and move to a parked angle of 0.3 [rad]. Use a slow seek rate of 0.2 rad/s.
When a 'boost' button is pressed, temporarily increase a motor's velocity by +0.1 [mps] for 2 seconds, then return to the base speed. Never exceed 0.8 [mps].

Implement a differential drive mapper: accept linear velocity [mps] and yaw rate [rad/s] and compute left and right wheel velocities [mps]. Saturate outputs to ±1.0 [mps] and preserve commanded curvature when saturating.

Build a homing and positioning state machine for a stepper axis: Home -> Backoff -> Zero -> Track Setpoint. After homing, accept a position setpoint in [rad], limit speed and acceleration, and stop at end-of-travel switches.

Create a servo controller with three modes (IDLE, MANUAL, PARK). In MANUAL, follow a joystick angle command in [rad] with a max slew of 1.0 rad/s. Switch to PARK after 5 s of inactivity and move to 0.4 [rad].

Design a conveyor drive that detects jams via a load sensor. If jammed, reverse at -0.2 [mps] for 2 seconds, then retry forward up to three times before latching a FAULT state that requires an operator reset.

Implement a simple velocity PI loop for a motor running at 100 Hz. The target is given in [mps]. Include anti-windup via output clamping and report a fault if error exceeds 0.3 [mps] for more than 1 s.

Make a servo sweep generator: follow a sinusoidal position command with configurable amplitude [rad] and frequency (Hz), limited to ±2.0 [rad] and rate-limited to 2.5 rad/s. Pause the motion when a pause input is active.
Build a motion window monitor: given a target angle [rad] and a tolerance of ±0.05 [rad], assert 'in_position' when inside the window for 100 ms; if outside for more than 2 s, raise an alarm.
Control a motor with dual end switches: allow jogging toward a switch with buttons, but inhibit commands that would drive past a triggered switch. Provide 50 ms switch debounce.

Create a soft-start/soft-stop controller for a pump motor: ramp velocity [mps] up over 4 s on start and down over 3 s on stop. If an overtemperature input is active, immediately stop and lock out restart for 60 s.
Implement a gimbal axis controller that accepts an angle command in [rad], enforces a maximum angular rate of 1.5 rad/s, and switches between STANDBY and TRACKING based on an enable input.

Generate step pulses for a stepper based on a velocity command in [rad/s], with trapezoidal acceleration limiting and a maximum speed corresponding to 12 [rad/s]. Provide a 'busy' output while motion is ongoing.
Add following error protection: when the absolute difference between commanded and measured position exceeds 0.2 [rad] for more than 200 ms, cut motor drive and assert a fault.
Implement an inactivity watchdog: if no new velocity command in [mps] arrives for 500 ms, ramp the motor to 0 [mps] over 1 s and set a timeout flag.
Coordinate two axes to move to their respective target angles [rad] and only assert 'all_in_position' when both are within ±0.03 [rad]. Enforce independent rate limits per axis.
Make a position latch: when a trigger occurs, capture the current motor angle [rad] and hold it for reporting while motion continues unaffected. Debounce the trigger.

Implement a duty-to-velocity mapper with linearization: convert a normalized command to a velocity in [mps] using a calibration table, clamp to safe limits, and add a small deadband to overcome stiction.
Create a velocity controller running at 200 Hz with a maximum WCET of 0.5 ms. The loop maintains a target [mps] using proportional control and output clamping.
Build a simple cruise control: maintain conveyor speed at the nearest multiple of 0.05 [mps] to the requested speed, with smooth transitions and a cap at 0.9 [mps].
Develop a start/stop finite state machine for a feeder motor with states: STOPPED, STARTING, RUNNING, STOPPING, FAULT. Enforce acceleration limits, handle estop, and require a reset to exit FAULT.

Implement a rate scheduler: run the motion control loop at 1 kHz with a WCET budget of 200 us, and a diagnostics task at 10 Hz. If the control loop overruns, drop to a safe 0 [mps] command and flag an error.

Design a closed-loop PID position controller for a rotary axis using encoder feedback in [rad]. Include velocity feedforward, integral anti-windup, and hard limits of ±2.8 [rad] and ±3.0 rad/s rate. Control loop: 1 kHz, WCET <= 150 us.

Implement a fused angular velocity estimate by combining encoder differentiation and a gyro sensor using a complementary filter. Use this estimate for a motor speed PID loop targeting [rad/s], with overspeed protection and a safe stop on sensor disagreement.

Create a trajectory follower that tracks a trapezoidal position profile in [rad] with jerk-limited transitions, ensuring velocity does not exceed 2.0 rad/s. Abort to a controlled stop if the following error exceeds 0.25 [rad].

Develop a closed-loop velocity PID for a linear actuator with targets in [mps]. Include automatic gain scheduling based on estimated load, enforce acceleration and jerk limits, and guarantee WCET under 100 us at 1 kHz.

Build a stepper axis with encoder verification: generate steps to follow a position setpoint [rad], compare actual encoder position to commanded, and if slip > 0.1 [rad], reduce speed, retry once, then enter FAULT with motor off.

Implement a spindle controller holding a set speed in [rad/s] using PID with notch filtering at a known resonance. Provide overspeed cutout at 1.2x setpoint and thermal derating when temperature rises.

Create a safe torque off interlock around a position PID loop: if emergency stop is active or limits exceeded, disable drive outputs within 10 ms and hold last safe position [rad] for status reporting.

Develop a dual-redundant position sensing scheme: read two independent encoders in [rad], compare them continuously, and if their difference exceeds 0.05 [rad] for >100 ms, transition to a safe halt state and require manual reset.

Implement coordinated two-axis motion with synchronized start and completion. Each axis follows its own [rad] profile with shared velocity and acceleration limits; either axis entering FAULT must command both to a controlled stop.
Design a high-precision positioner: use PID with feedforward and friction compensation to hold within ±0.01 [rad]. Run at 2 kHz with WCET <= 120 us and log any cycle exceeding 80% of the budget.

Specify a drivetrain controller with modes MANUAL, VELOCITY_HOLD, POSITION_HOLD, and FAULT. Accept commands in [mps] and yaw rate [rad/s], map to wheel speeds, and switch modes based on operator input and watchdogs. Include comprehensive unit tests for mode transitions, saturation behavior, and WCET conformance at 1 kHz.

Define a joint controller for a robotic arm with modes: HOMING, POSITIONING, COMPLIANCE, SAFE_STOP, FAULT. Use encoder feedback in [rad] and current sensing to limit torque. Require formalized safety limits, PID tuning parameters, and test cases covering limit switch failures and missed deadlines (WCET 150 us).

Create a multi-motor conveyor coordinator with synchronized sections. Each section maintains a set [mps] speed, shares ramp profiles, and supports degraded operation if one section faults. Provide a test plan with simulations of jams, estop, and recovery sequences, and verify all control tasks meet WCET budgets.

Develop a three-axis gimbal controller with modes CALIBRATE, TRACK, STABILIZE, PARK, and FAULT. Fuse gyro and encoder data for each axis, enforce angle limits in [rad], and guarantee graceful degradation on sensor loss. Specify acceptance tests for tracking accuracy, startup timing, and worst-case execution at 2 kHz.

Design a pick-and-place motion subsystem using steppers with a queued trajectory planner. Support modes IDLE, RUN, PAUSE, RESUME, and ESTOP, and homing per axis. Include verification procedures, latency measurements for step generation, and WCET guarantees for the 1 kHz planner and 10 kHz pulse engine.
Hold a single rotary actuator at 1.00 rad using a simple PID position loop; clamp the command output and stop motion if |error| exceeds 2.0 rad. Run at 50 Hz with WCET ≤ 1.0 ms.
Regulate a linear drive to 0.50 m/s using a PI velocity controller; saturate the output and limit acceleration to 0.5 m/s^2. Control loop at 200 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.4 ms.
When a boolean 'go' flag is true, command constant speed 1.0 m/s; otherwise command 0 m/s. Apply a slew rate limit of 0.5 m/s^2. Update at 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Accept a target angle (rad) from an input variable and move a servo to that angle with proportional control. Enforce soft limits [−1.5, 1.5] rad. Run at 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Spin a stepper motor at 2.0 rad/s equivalent and stop if estimated speed exceeds 2.5 rad/s. Use a simple acceleration limit of 1.0 rad/s^2. Update at 200 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.3 ms.
Hold a joint at its current angle; if the absolute error remains below 0.05 rad for 2 s, gently disable the drive, and re-enable if error rises. Control at 50 Hz; WCET ≤ 1.0 ms.
Move a servo toward 1.2 rad using a PID controller and restrict motion to [0.0, 2.0] rad. Halt and flag a soft-limit fault on overshoot. 100 Hz loop; WCET ≤ 0.6 ms.
Maintain wheel speed at 0.80 m/s using PI control with a ±0.05 m/s deadband to reduce chatter. Update at 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.4 ms.
Generate a trapezoidal point-to-point move from 0.0 rad to 3.14 rad with vmax 1.0 rad/s and amax 0.5 rad/s^2; track the profile with a position PID. Run at 200 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.4 ms.
Perform simple homing: move at −0.30 rad/s until a home switch becomes active, set position to 0.0 rad, and stop. Execute at 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Limit actuator speed based on temperature: if temp > 70 C, cap to 0.20 m/s; else allow 0.60 m/s. Apply a smooth transition. Loop at 50 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.6 ms.
On start, jog the actuator by +0.10 rad and hold the new position within ±0.02 rad. Update at 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Convert a linear speed target of 0.25 m/s to angular speed using wheel radius 0.05 m and command that angular speed (rad/s) with a PI loop. Saturate at 10.0 rad/s. 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Filter measured velocity with a first-order low-pass (time constant 0.10 s) and regulate to 1.50 m/s using PI. Run at 200 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.4 ms.
Implement an emergency stop: when an e-stop flag is true, immediately command zero output and hold position; otherwise maintain a 0.50 rad setpoint. 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.3 ms.

Control a differential drive: regulate left and right wheel speeds to requested m/s values with independent PI loops, limit acceleration to 1.0 m/s^2 per wheel, and cap speed at 1.2 m/s. 200 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.6 ms.

Create a joint state machine with states Idle, Homing, Tracking, and Fault. Home at 0.20 rad/s until switch, then track position commands (rad) with PID. Enter Fault if |error| > 0.50 rad for >0.20 s. 250 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Follow a time-varying trajectory given as angle (rad) and rate (rad/s) using position control with velocity feedforward and output saturation. Run at 500 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.3 ms.
Ramp a speed command from 0.0 to 5.0 rad/s with jerk limited to 10.0 rad/s^3 and scale the max speed using a thermal derate factor input. 200 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.6 ms.
Index a stepper by exactly 1.00 rad equivalent using a profile with amax 1.0 rad/s^2 and vmax 2.0 rad/s; report busy/complete status and abort safely on stop request. Time base 1 kHz; WCET ≤ 0.2 ms.
Stabilize a gimbal axis at 0.0 rad with PID plus rate damping from gyro input; increase damping if measured rate exceeds 3.0 rad/s. Limit angle to ±0.8 rad. 400 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.4 ms.
Implement PI speed control to 0.70 m/s with integrator anti-windup by clamping the integral when saturated and resetting on direction changes. 200 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.4 ms.
Drive to 2.20 rad and assert an 'in position' flag when |error| < 0.02 rad for 100 ms; otherwise show 'moving'. Update at 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Coordinate two joints so moves to A=1.0 rad and B=0.5 rad finish simultaneously while respecting per-joint limits of 1.5 rad/s and 2.0 rad/s^2. 200 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.7 ms.
Implement a soft approach to a limit at 3.0 rad by scaling velocity linearly from full at 2.8 rad to zero at 3.0 rad. 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.3 ms.
Hold 1.0 m/s and detect stall: if actual speed stays below 0.20 m/s for 0.50 s, cut output and raise a fault. 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Map a linear position sensor to meters and regulate height to 0.15 m with PI, limiting speed to 0.05 m/s. 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.6 ms.
While streaming position targets at 100 Hz, pause setpoint updates if following error exceeds 0.10 rad until recovered to <0.05 rad. WCET ≤ 0.4 ms.
Provide a jog mode: 'jog_plus' increments the setpoint by +0.05 rad and 'jog_minus' decrements by −0.05 rad; hold with PID and enforce limits [−1.0, 1.0] rad. 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Blend a manual velocity input (m/s) with an automatic cap; if the requested speed exceeds the cap, scale it smoothly without discontinuities. 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Account for gear ratio 5:1 so that a motor angle translates to joint angle; command the joint to 0.60 rad and report both angles. 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Track an external angle target with a slew-limited setpoint generator enforcing 0.8 rad/s and 1.5 rad/s^2 limits before feeding a PID loop. 200 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.3 ms.
Prioritize holding when supply droops: if supply estimate is low, reduce max translational speed to 0.30 m/s and maintain position rather than accelerate. 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.6 ms.
After enable, perform a soft-start from 0 to 0.50 rad/s over 2.0 s; if a fault flag asserts, stop immediately and wait for reset. 50 Hz; WCET ≤ 1.0 ms.
Mitigate oscillation at a 0 rad hold by adding derivative damping limited to 2.0 rad/s and a small deadband ±0.01 rad. 400 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.3 ms.

Use cascaded control: an outer position loop (rad) generates a velocity target; an inner PI velocity loop (rad/s) drives the actuator. Include anti-windup, velocity saturation at 2.0 rad/s, and acceleration limit 3.0 rad/s^2. Run at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.35 ms, and raise a fault if the command saturates for >0.30 s.

Fuse encoder-derived velocity and gyro rate using a complementary filter (alpha = 0.7) to estimate joint rate; use the fused rate for PD position control to 1.20 rad. Operate at 1 kHz with WCET ≤ 0.25 ms and trigger a fail-safe if sensors disagree by >2.0 rad/s.

Implement an emergency stop state that zeros the control output within 10 ms and requires a guarded reset to exit. In normal mode, regulate to 0.75 m/s. Run the loop at 250 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.4 ms and include a watchdog.

Execute a jerk-limited S-curve move from 0.0 to 2.50 rad with vmax 3.0 rad/s, amax 6.0 rad/s^2, and jmax 20.0 rad/s^3. Track with PID plus velocity/acceleration feedforward. Operate at 1 kHz with WCET ≤ 0.3 ms and abort if following error > 0.15 rad.
Synchronize two linear actuators to move at matched speeds of 0.40 m/s using cross-coupled control; if speed difference exceeds 0.05 m/s for 0.20 s, slow both safely. Loop at 200 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.6 ms.
Apply thermal-aware speed limiting: predict temperature rise and, if forecast exceeds 80 C within 60 s, cap velocity to a safe value while maintaining position hold. Control at 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.8 ms.
Compensate for 0.02 rad backlash in a geared joint by applying a direction-dependent position offset; ensure no overshoot beyond a 1.8 rad hard limit. Update at 400 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.4 ms.
Add gravity compensation torque proportional to sin(angle) for a vertical joint, then close a PID position loop. Respect soft limits [0.0, 1.6] rad and fault on stall. 500 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.35 ms.

Estimate angular velocity (rad/s) from noisy position samples using a discrete observer and regulate to 4.0 rad/s with a PI speed loop. Guarantee observer and control updates within WCET ≤ 0.3 ms at 1 kHz.

Perform safe homing: if not homed, confine motion to ±0.30 rad and max 0.40 rad/s; approach the home switch at 0.10 rad/s, back off 0.05 rad, and re-approach slowly. Timeout after 5 s. 200 Hz loop; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.

Design a multi-mode motion controller with modes: Boot, Safe-Stop, Homing, Standby, Positioning, Velocity, and Fault. Define transitions, interlocks, and latched faults. Use cascaded PID with feedforward in Positioning and PI in Velocity. Enforce soft limits [−2.0, 2.0] rad, max speed 3.0 rad/s, and accel 5.0 rad/s^2. Control loop at 1 kHz with WCET per cycle ≤ 0.35 ms. Provide a test plan with simulated disturbances, step responses, and fault injection (e-stop, sensor dropout).

Implement a 3-axis coordinated motion system for a planar robot: follow synchronized trajectories in meters and m/s with coupled jerk limits. Support Jog, Teach, Auto, and Fault modes via a clear state machine. Include cross-coupled error correction, per-axis PID, and a safety supervisor that enforces workspace bounds and emergency deceleration to 0 m/s within 100 ms. Run at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.6 ms. Provide acceptance criteria and timing tests.

Build a wheel module controller with two operating modes: angle control (rad) and drive speed control (m/s). Include sensor fusion between encoder and IMU yaw rate, calibratable zero offsets, and online friction estimation that adapts PI gains. Enforce safety by limiting velocity and slew rates only, and define a comprehensive self-test at startup verifying limits, estimator stability, and WCET < 0.4 ms at 1 kHz.

Create a redundant dual-encoder joint controller with voting and plausibility checks. Fuse two position sensors (rad) to estimate angle and rate; degrade gracefully to single-sensor mode if one fails. Provide Homing, Normal, and Degraded modes with a full state machine, hard and soft limits, runaway detection, and emergency stop. Use cascaded PID with anti-windup. Control at 1 kHz and guarantee WCET ≤ 0.35 ms. Include validation procedures and diagnostic logging requirements.

Specify a high-integrity motion profile executor that loads time-tagged setpoints for multiple axes, interpolates to 1 kHz, and guarantees bounded following error under disturbances. Include safety constraints (max 4.0 rad/s, 8.0 rad/s^2, jerk 50.0 rad/s^3), watchdog supervision, deterministic scheduling with WCET budgets per task, and a verification plan covering conformance tests, stress tests, and worst-case timing analysis.
When an enable signal is true, drive the linear actuator at a constant speed of 0.6 [mps]; when false, command 0 [mps] immediately. Run the control loop at 100 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.
On receiving a 'set angle' trigger, move the servo to 1.20 [rad] and hold position; ignore additional triggers until the target is reached within ±0.01 [rad].
Toggle motor direction on each button press, switching between +0.40 [mps] and -0.40 [mps]; include 50 ms debounce on the button input.
If a limit switch is active, stop motion and hold position. Otherwise, move toward the target at 0.2 [mps].
Command a rotary joint to advance exactly 0.785 [rad] from its current angle, then stop and hold. Ignore new move requests until the motion completes.
Implement soft-start and soft-stop: ramp from 0 to 0.8 [mps] over 3 s on start, and ramp down to 0 [mps] over 1 s on stop.
Continuously sweep a servo between 0.10 [rad] and 2.60 [rad] at 0.3 [rad] per second, pausing 1 s at each end.
Hold the joint at 0.00 [rad] until a 'go' signal arrives, then move to 1.00 [rad] and hold there until a 'reset' returns it to 0.00 [rad].
Saturate any incoming speed command to the range [-0.5, +0.5] [mps] and publish the clipped value.
If measured velocity exceeds 1.5 [mps], immediately cut drive output to zero and log an overspeed event with a timestamp.
Map a 0-100% potentiometer to a servo angle range of 0.20 [rad] to 2.40 [rad]; update at 50 Hz with simple smoothing (time constant ~0.2 s).
Run a conveyor at 0.30 [mps]. Stop when the object sensor goes high; resume 2 s after the sensor clears.
Implement a dead-man control: move at 0.70 [mps] only while the hold switch is continuously true; otherwise command 0 [mps].
Provide jog controls: 'jog+' drives +0.25 [mps], 'jog-' drives -0.25 [mps], and 'stop' commands 0 [mps].
After power-up, wait 1 s, then move to the home angle 0.00 [rad] and hold position.

Implement a homing state machine: move at -0.2 [mps] until the home switch triggers, advance 0.05 [rad] to clear the switch, set position to 0.00 [rad], then enter Ready. Limit speed to 0.3 [mps]. Run at 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Create a 3-state controller (Idle, MoveToAngle, Hold). On start, go to MoveToAngle and reach 1.57 [rad] using a trapezoidal profile (max rate 0.8 [rad] per second), then Hold. E-stop forces Idle immediately.
Synchronize two servos so Joint B maintains a fixed offset of +0.30 [rad] relative to Joint A. If either limit switch is hit, stop both and enter a Fault state.
Apply directional speed limits: forward max 0.90 [mps], reverse max 0.60 [mps]. Reject commands outside these limits and emit a status flag when clamped.
Use a PID controller to hold 1.00 [mps] against load variation. Expose P/I/D gains as tunable parameters and constrain output within safe limits.
Map a -100%..+100% joystick to -1.2..+1.2 [mps] with a 5% deadzone and a slew-rate limit of 0.3 [mps] per second.
Implement two speed modes: Normal at 0.50 [mps] and Fast at 1.00 [mps]. Mode toggles via a digital input. Limit acceleration to 0.2 [mps] per second on transitions.
Create a periodic scheduler: run motion control at 250 Hz with WCET <= 0.8 ms, and a diagnostics task at 10 Hz. Diagnostics must not block control.
Implement a one-shot move: on rising edge of a 'pulse' input, rotate +0.35 [rad], then return to the starting angle. Ignore further pulses until the cycle completes.
Track a triangle-wave position command between 0.50 [rad] and 2.00 [rad] at 0.4 [rad] per second; clamp targets to joint limits and report saturation events.
Automatically reverse direction when an endstop is reached, maintaining a travel speed of 0.30 [mps]. Keep a counter of reversals and reset on command.
Latch faults: an overcurrent input or overspeed (>1.8 [mps]) drives the system to a Fault state. Only a reset clears it. In Fault, command zero output.
Combine feedforward and proportional feedback to track a velocity command up to 1.5 [mps]; expose kF and kP for tuning; run the loop at 500 Hz.
Compute differential wheel speeds from a linear command in [mps] and a turn rate command in [rad] per second; enforce wheel speed limits of ±1.2 [mps].
Implement a stop-at-index feature: using an index pulse, stop at the next index with final position accuracy within ±0.01 [rad]. Limit approach rate to 0.7 [rad] per second.
Design a PI position hold near 0.00 [rad] with anti-windup: integrate only when |error| < 0.20 [rad], and clamp the integrator to ±10% output.
Implement a jog mode with thermal awareness: while the jog button is held, move at 0.20 [mps]; after 5 s of continuous jogging, reduce to 0.10 [mps] to limit heating.
Generate a velocity profile: accelerate at 0.4 [mps] per second to 1.0 [mps], cruise for a set distance, then decelerate symmetrically to 0 [mps].
Manual/Auto selector: Manual maps a knob to 0.0..2.2 [rad]; Auto follows a streamed position setpoint. Ramping must ensure smooth transitions when switching modes.
Add a watchdog: if no new velocity command arrives within 200 ms, ramp to 0 [mps] over 0.5 s and assert a 'timeout' flag.
Implement cascaded control: outer PID for position (setpoint in [rad]), inner PID for velocity (linear stage in [mps]). Sample at 1 kHz, WCET <= 0.6 ms, with anti-windup and output rate limiting.

Fuse encoder-derived velocity with gyro rate using a complementary filter; use the fused rate to drive a PID that tracks 1.2 [rad] per second. If the two sensors disagree by >0.3 [rad] per second for >50 ms, perform a safe stop.

Create a jerk-limited S-curve trajectory for a rotary move from 0.00 [rad] to 2.80 [rad]; respect max velocity 1.0 [rad] per second and max acceleration 2.0 [rad] per second^2; keep error <0.02 [rad]; E-stop must halt motion safely.
Implement redundant limits: two hardware limit inputs plus a soft limit at 2.50 [rad]. Any trip must stop motion and require a homing sequence to recover; log which limit tripped and when.
Thermal derating: if motor temperature exceeds 70 Celsius, reduce the max speed from 1.0 to 0.5 [mps]; above 80 Celsius, ramp to 0 [mps] and latch an overtemp fault.
Perform a torque-limited position move to 1.57 [rad] using PID. If estimated torque exceeds a threshold for 300 ms, abort and back off by 0.10 [rad]. Verify WCET <= 0.75 ms.
Estimate velocity by filtering the derivative of position (in [rad]) and drive a PI speed controller to hold 0.90 [mps] on a linear actuator; include saturation with anti-windup.

Backlash calibration routine: move +0.20 [rad] then -0.20 [rad] repeatedly to estimate backlash from encoder data; store a compensation value; keep motion rate under 0.5 [rad] per second during the test.
Vertical axis interlocks: while descending faster than 0.30 [mps], monitor a catch sensor. If the sensor fails or speed exceeds 0.60 [mps], apply dynamic braking and enter Fault.
Design a closed-loop velocity controller with gain scheduling: below 0.20 [mps], use higher integral gain; above that, lower it. Add hysteresis to avoid chatter. Run at 500 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Build a multi-mode motion controller for a joint with modes: Idle, Homing, Positioning, VelocityHold, Fault. Define all transitions including E-stop to Fault; enforce 0.00..2.70 [rad] limits; run at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.5 ms; provide a test plan for normal and invalid transitions and fault recovery.

Coordinate pan and tilt servos to reach their target angles (both in [rad]) simultaneously using synchronized trapezoidal profiles. Include an integration test verifying end-time alignment within 10 ms and final error <0.01 [rad] on both axes; define safe-stop behavior.

Create a drive system with three modes: Manual (joystick to ±1.0 [mps]), Auto (follows velocity setpoints in [mps]), and Diagnostic (sweeps 0.00..2.50 [rad] on a test joint). Specify mode arbitration, safety limits per mode, WCET budgets per task, and acceptance tests for switching under load.

Implement redundant velocity command paths: primary over network, secondary local. Add validity checks and failover logic, saturate to ±1.5 [mps], and require a verification procedure that simulates packet loss, stale commands, and recovery without overshoot >0.2 [mps].

Develop a comprehensive motion subsystem for a pick-and-place axis: include Homing, SoftLimit enforcement, PID position control (targets in [rad]), emergency braking, and a degraded mode when the encoder fails (open-loop at 0.10 [mps] capped). Provide WCET allocations, logging requirements, and a structured test plan with timing measurements.
When a momentary run switch is pressed, spin a motor to a constant linear velocity of 0.25 [mps]; stop immediately when released. Include a 100 ms debounce on the switch.
Set a rotary servo to 1.57 [rad] when a trigger input goes high, otherwise hold 0.00 [rad]. Include a movement timeout of 2 s and raise a fault if the target is not reached.

Provide jog controls for a stepper: each press of UP advances +0.10 [rad], each press of DOWN retreats −0.10 [rad]. Enforce soft limits from 0.00 to 6.28 [rad] and ignore commands that would exceed them.
Run a conveyor motor at 0.20 [mps] until the forward limit switch is activated, then stop and latch an indicator until a reset input is pressed.
Implement a deadman function: drive at 0.30 [mps] only while a hold switch is continuously active; ramp to 0 [mps] within 100 ms when released.
If an emergency stop input is asserted, immediately disable all motor outputs and engage a brake actuator; only re-enable after a manual reset action.
On start, ramp speed from 0 to 0.40 [mps] over 2 s; on stop, ramp back to 0 [mps] over 1 s. Reject new start commands while a ramp is in progress.
