Continuously sweep a servo between 0.00 [rad] and 2.60 [rad] with a 1 s dwell at each end. Abort the sweep if an interlock input is active.
Monitor measured velocity and, if it exceeds 0.60 [mps] for more than 50 ms, shut down the drive and latch a fault that requires a reset input to clear.
Toggle travel direction each time a pushbutton is pressed while maintaining a constant 0.20 [mps]. Debounce and ignore double-clicks closer than 200 ms.
Hold a shaft at 0.00 [rad] using simple proportional control with a ±0.05 [rad] deadband; within the deadband, disable output to reduce chatter.
Soft-start a motor by limiting the change in command to no more than 0.05 [mps] every 20 ms; if an overcurrent flag appears, ramp down to 0 [mps] immediately.
Drive a servo within a safe mechanical range: clamp commanded angles to 0.20–2.40 [rad] and flag any request outside that window.
When a hold button is pressed, position the joint at 1.00 [rad]; when released, move to 0.50 [rad]. Filter the input to reject glitches shorter than 10 ms.
Advance a stepper by exactly 1.00 [rad] at a steady pace when a start input is asserted, then stop and wait for the next start.

Design a homing routine: move negative until the home switch activates, back off 0.05 [rad], then set position to 0.00 [rad]. After homing, accept target angles in [rad] and move to them with a slew limit of 0.10 [rad] per 20 ms. Run the control loop at 200 Hz with WCET ≤ 1 ms.
Map a joystick input to a velocity command in ±0.80 [mps] with a 5% dead zone and symmetric slew rate limiting. If an emergency stop is active, force 0 [mps] and latch an interlock until cleared.
Coordinate two servos so that servo B maintains an offset of +1.57 [rad] relative to servo A. Enforce safe ranges for both (0.00–3.14 [rad]) and freeze motion if either exceeds its limit.
Create a state machine for a linear actuator with states: Idle, Extend, Retract, Fault. Use two end switches to govern transitions, include a 5 s timeout per move, and require a reset to leave Fault.
For a pair of drive motors, maintain equal commanded velocity and monitor encoder feedback; if the difference exceeds 0.10 [mps] for 200 ms, stop both and signal a fault.
Every 10 s, rotate a shaft by +0.50 [rad]; on the next cycle, rotate −0.50 [rad], repeating indefinitely. Blink a status indicator while motion is in progress and stop on interlock.
Implement three preset positions selectable by a 3-position switch: 0.00 [rad], 1.00 [rad], and 2.00 [rad]. Apply a small motion smoothing so the actuator does not jerk, and never exceed 2.20 [rad].
Tie motor speed to temperature: above 70 °C, limit to 0.20 [mps]; above 80 °C, stop and latch Fault; below 65 °C, allow normal operation at up to 0.60 [mps].
Watch for position drift: if the encoder differs from the commanded angle by more than 0.10 [rad] for 100 ms, raise an alarm and increase output until the error is back within ±0.05 [rad].
Provide bumpless transfer between manual and automatic velocity commands in [mps] using a ramp limiter; avoid steps larger than 0.05 [mps] per 20 ms when switching.
Accept angle commands over a communication channel in [rad]; validate range 0.00–3.00 [rad], reject malformed messages, and report acknowledgments. Time out if no command arrives within 2 s.
Drive a stepper to a target angle with a trapezoidal move profile constrained by endstops. Execute the control updates at 1 kHz with WCET ≤ 0.5 ms and abort cleanly on any limit hit.
If supply voltage drops below a threshold, immediately command a controlled retract at 0.10 [mps] until a safe position is reached; otherwise allow normal operation up to 0.50 [mps].
Switch between two speeds based on a proximity sensor: 0.10 [mps] when near, 0.30 [mps] when far. On sensor fault, default to 0 [mps] and require operator confirmation to resume.
Hold a conveyor at 0.25 [mps] and detect jams by monitoring motor current and speed feedback; if speed falls below 50% of the command for 300 ms, stop and alert.
Move a joint to a commanded angle in [rad] using a trapezoidal profile; dwell for 2 s at the target, then return to the start. Abort if either limit switch engages during the move.
Implement a communication watchdog: if no valid velocity command in [mps] is received for 500 ms, ramp down to 0 [mps] within 300 ms and hold.
Use separate forward and reverse inputs to select direction while maintaining a magnitude command in [mps]. Reject conflicting inputs and enforce a minimum 200 ms hold time between direction changes.
Compensate gearbox backlash by adding a 0.02 [rad] pre-load whenever direction reverses. Do not apply the compensation if it would exceed a 0.00–3.14 [rad] range.
Seek an index pulse on a rotating shaft: spin slowly until the index is detected, then set position to 0.00 [rad] and stop. Ignore spurious index pulses shorter than 1 ms.
Implement closed-loop PID control of linear velocity in [mps] with feedforward and anti-windup. Allow configuration of limits, and on any fault ramp to 0 [mps]. Run at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.8 ms.

Build a cascaded controller: an outer position loop in [rad] generates a velocity command, which an inner loop tracks. Enforce jerk-limited transitions and ensure bumpless mode switching. Loop rate 1 kHz, WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.

Fuse encoder angle and gyro rate to estimate joint angle accurately; control the joint to a setpoint in [rad] using PID. On loss of either sensor, degrade gracefully to the remaining source and restrict motion.
Synchronize two conveyors using coupled PID controllers so their speeds match within ±0.02 [mps]. If the speed difference exceeds 0.20 [mps] for 100 ms, stop both and report a synchronization fault.

Generate an S-curve trajectory from the current angle to a target in [rad], respecting maximum speed and acceleration limits. Track the trajectory with a PID position loop and enforce thermal and current safety limits.
Detect slip by comparing commanded and measured velocity in [mps]; when slip persists beyond 150 ms, reduce the command by 30% and attempt recovery, otherwise stop on continued degradation.
Schedule PID gains as a function of speed: higher gains at low [mps], lower gains at high [mps]. Log gain changes and ensure stability by limiting adjustments to once every 50 ms.
Blend position control in [rad] with a torque limit proxy from motor current to create a compliant mode. If a sudden position error > 0.20 [rad] occurs, enter a protective stop and hold.

Estimate linear velocity in [mps] using a Kalman filter that combines encoder increments and accelerometer readings. Close a PID loop on the filtered velocity; if estimation uncertainty rises above a threshold, switch to a safe degraded mode.

Mitigate stepper resonance: detect oscillation using encoder phase error and notch it via command shaping while maintaining accurate position tracking in [rad]. Provide a safe fallback to low-speed operation if instability is detected.

Define a multi-mode motion controller with modes Idle, Manual, Auto, and SafeStop. Manual maps a joystick to ±0.60 [mps]; Auto executes queued moves in [rad]. Specify all transitions, include hysteresis on interlocks, run at 250 Hz with WCET ≤ 1 ms, and produce diagnostic events.

Create a drive system with modes PositionHold, VelocityTrack, and Homing. Position is in [rad], velocity in [mps]. Include health monitoring, redundancy fallback on sensor loss, a watchdog timer, and acceptance tests covering faults, recovery, and WCET measurement.

Coordinate a two-axis gantry: keep axes aligned while following velocity setpoints in [mps], with modes Homing, Jog, and Auto Path. Limit cross-axis skew, handle limit and estop conditions, and supply a comprehensive test plan including edge cases and stress timing.

Develop a joint controller for a robotic arm with modes Calibration, Operate, and ProtectiveStop. Use PID to hold commanded angle in [rad], enforce soft stops, and limit end effector speed reported in [mps]. Specify control rate 1 kHz, WCET ≤ 0.6 ms, and verification criteria for worst-case trajectories.

Specify a complete motion stack: command parser, trajectory planner (S-curves), control loops (velocity in [mps], position in [rad]), and a fault manager. Require deterministic scheduling with WCET margins, trace logging, and a hardware-in-the-loop test plan for regression.

Map an analog 'knob' value in the range 0.0..1.0 to a servo angle between 0.0 and 1.57 [rad]. Update at 50 Hz. Clamp the commanded angle within those limits and ignore inputs when an 'estop' boolean is true.
On button press, command belt motor to 0.20 [mps]; on release, 0 [mps]. Limit acceleration to 0.10 [mps^2] to avoid jerk.
When a rising edge on 'start_move' occurs, drive a stepper exactly +100 steps at a steady 0.2 [rad/s] equivalent shaft speed, then stop. Ignore new requests until the move completes.
At startup, set a yaw servo to 3.1416 [rad]. Do not exceed a software limit of 3.2 [rad]. If 'stop' is asserted, hold the current angle.
Generate a 0.5 Hz sinusoidal command between 0.0 and 0.5 [rad] for a test servo. Immediately output 0 [rad] whenever 'estop' is active.
Mirror a boolean 'enable_cmd' to a motor enable output. Default to disabled after power-up and whenever 'estop' is true.
When 'go' is true, ramp wheel speed from 0 to 1.0 [mps] over 5 s; when false, ramp down to 0 at the same rate.
Set motor direction reverse when 'reverse' is true, else forward, and cap the magnitude of velocity to 0.30 [mps].
On 'home_jog' command, jog the axis at 0.05 [mps] for 2.0 s and then stop.
Track a 'target_angle_rad' input with a servo at 100 Hz. Clamp to 0.0..2.0 [rad]. Ensure WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
If 'overheat' is asserted, force motor speed to 0 [mps]; otherwise keep the last requested speed.
Use a mode bit to snap a servo to either 0.0 [rad] or 1.2 [rad].
Drive along at 0.10 [mps] unless a 'limit' switch is closed, in which case reverse direction at the same speed.
If 'hold' is true, maintain the current joint angle; otherwise follow 'target' angle in [rad].
When a 'pulse' event arrives, run the motor at 0.40 [mps] for 3.0 s, then return to 0 [mps].

Implement a homing state machine for a linear axis: approach toward the home switch at 0.05 [mps] until the switch closes, back off 0.010 [m], re-approach slowly at 0.02 [mps], then set position to 0. Update at 200 Hz and honor an 'estop' at all times.
Control two drive wheels with commanded speeds 'left_cmd' and 'right_cmd' in [mps]. Saturate each to ±0.8 [mps], limit acceleration to 0.3 [mps^2], and stop both immediately when 'estop' is active.

Create an indexer for a rotary stepper: on each 'goto' request, move to an absolute target angle in [rad] using a trapezoidal speed profile with vmax 2.0 [rad/s] and accel 4.0 [rad/s^2]. Ignore new targets while busy.
For a servo joint with soft stops at ±2.5 [rad], follow 'target' with a ±0.02 [rad] deadband. If a 'fault' latch is set, hold position until 'reset_fault' is pulsed.
Shape a 'speed_cmd' in [mps] through a rate limiter of ±0.20 [mps^2]. If 'overvoltage' is true, force the output to 0 [mps]. Run at 100 Hz, WCET under 1 ms.
Provide a mode-selectable actuator: in position mode, move to 1.0 [rad]; in velocity mode, regulate at 0.30 [mps]. Switch modes on 'mode_select' edges without causing steps.
Gate all motion with an 'arm' boolean: when unarmed, force outputs to 0 [mps] and 0 [rad]; when armed, pass commands through after clamping to safe ranges.
Constrain a hoist motor so downward motion never exceeds 0.40 [mps] while upward speed is limited to 0.20 [mps]. Apply estop immediately when 'guard_open' is true.
Advance a rotary table through a sequence of angles [rad] using a 'next' button. Only accept the next press after the current move has reached within 0.01 [rad] of target.
Generate a trapezoidal move of 0.50 [m] with vmax 0.20 [mps] and accel 0.10 [mps^2] for a linear actuator, then stop and signal 'done'.
Use forward and reverse limit switches to enforce end stops. Prevent any command that would drive further into a tripped limit. Report 'limit_fault' if violation is attempted.
Close the loop on wheel velocity to track 'v_set' in [mps] with a proportional controller on encoder feedback. Saturate the commanded velocity to ±0.6 [mps] and freeze updates while 'estop' is true.
Implement a jog-versus-go-to state machine: while a 'jog' button is held, move at 0.05 [mps]; when released, resume moving to 'setpoint' [rad] with a rate limit so transitions are smooth.
Create an IDLE → RUN → FAULT state machine for a motor. Enter FAULT on estop or overcurrent; require 'ack' to leave FAULT; in RUN, enforce velocity limit 0.5 [mps] and acceleration 0.2 [mps^2].
Map a joystick value in [-1, 1] to wheel speed in [-0.6, 0.6] [mps] with a 0.05 deadzone and a cubic response curve. Run at 200 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.75 ms.
Ensure only one of two linear actuators moves at a time. If both receive a command, service the higher-priority one first and queue the other, respecting a max speed of 0.15 [mps].
Monitor position error |target - actual| in [rad]. If it exceeds 0.05 [rad] for more than 2.0 s, assert a 'stalled' flag and inhibit further motion.
Command a pulley axis to a target angle with braking: when speed falls below 0.02 [mps] within 0.05 [rad] of target, apply a 'brake' output to hold position.
Perform homing with backlash compensation: approach the switch at 0.04 [mps], back off 0.008 [m], re-approach at 0.02 [mps], then set zero and apply an offset of +0.002 [m].
Run a burn-in test that alternates velocity between +0.30 [mps] and -0.30 [mps] every 5 s for 10 minutes. Stop immediately on estop and log the number of reversals.

Design a cascaded controller for a rotary joint: outer PID on position [rad], inner PID on velocity [rad/s]. Update loops at 1 kHz with WCET ≤ 0.2 ms. Include output saturation, anti-windup, and soft stops at ±2.8 [rad].

Implement a closed-loop velocity PID to maintain 0.50 [mps] on a belt using encoder feedback. Enforce accel limit 0.25 [mps^2], saturate output, and trigger a watchdog fault if any cycle exceeds its WCET of 0.3 ms.

Fuse encoder-derived velocity with an accelerometer via a complementary filter to estimate actuator speed in [mps]. Use that estimate in a PID velocity loop. Handle sensor dropout by reverting to the remaining sensor and reducing vmax.

Drive a stepper with an encoder for slip detection. If position error exceeds 0.05 [rad], pause motion, re-home, and resume. Use a jerk-limited profile with vmax 3.0 [rad/s] and max jerk 20.0 [rad/s^3].

Close the loop on a rotary axis position with PID in [rad], but derate the allowed velocity [mps] when temperature exceeds 60.0 °C. Publish a 'derated' status and restore limits only after cooling below 55.0 °C.
Synchronize two shafts so their phase difference stays near 0 [rad]. Control one motor with a PID on phase error (wrap-aware), sampling at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.4 ms. Limit speed to 2.0 [rad/s].
Add feedforward to a PID velocity controller to improve tracking of a time-varying speed profile in [mps]. Include friction compensation, output clamping, and a safety interlock on estop.

Estimate wheel speed [mps] using a Kalman filter that blends encoder counts and accelerometer readings at 400 Hz. Use the estimate in a velocity PID, and enter FAULT if the estimated covariance exceeds a threshold.
Implement a 'soft landing' position controller that increases damping as the error falls below 0.1 [rad] to reduce overshoot. Obey hard limits at ±3.0 [rad] and guarantee WCET under 0.25 ms at 1 kHz.

Create a safety monitor that supervises a PID-controlled actuator: watch for overcurrent, overtemperature, limit switch violations, and missed deadlines. On any violation, cut velocity to 0 [mps] and latch a fault requiring operator reset.

Build a multi-mode joint controller with modes: HOMING, MANUAL_VELOCITY, AUTO_POSITION, and FAULT. Use PID in AUTO_POSITION (units [rad]) and rate limiting in MANUAL_VELOCITY (units [mps]). Specify update rates for each mode (e.g., 1 kHz control) and WCET budgets, and define clear transition rules and latching faults.

Create a fault-tolerant velocity control for a motor with two independent encoders. Fuse the sensors with plausibility checks; if they disagree by >0.1 [mps], drop to a degraded mode with reduced limits and alert. Include a PID, watchdog timing (WCET ≤ 0.3 ms), and a test plan covering sensor failure cases.

Coordinate three stepper axes to execute synchronized moves that keep the resultant vector speed at 0.25 [mps]. Support pause/resume, estop, and queue management. Define timing constraints for planning vs. stepping and prove WCET margins.

Develop a pan–tilt motion system with modes CALIBRATE, TRACK, HOLD, and FAULT. Use PID position control in [rad], enforce soft stops and velocity limits, and include a startup self-test. Provide comprehensive tests for mode transitions, setpoint steps, and safety interlock behavior.

Specify a multi-rate control architecture: 1 kHz inner velocity PID [rad/s], 200 Hz outer position planner [rad], and 50 Hz safety monitor. Define WCET for each task, a watchdog, and a verification plan including stress tests (command saturation, missed cycles, estop) and acceptance criteria.
Drive a hobby servo to 1.2 [rad] when a button is pressed and to 0 [rad] when released. Clamp commanded angle to the safe range [0..1.5] [rad]. Run control at 50 Hz and keep WCET under 0.5 ms.
On a foot-pedal boolean input, run a motor at a constant linear velocity of 0.30 [mps]; otherwise command 0 [mps]. Include a 200 ms ramp up/down and enforce a maximum of 0.40 [mps]. WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Read an analog knob as a position command and drive a servo to follow 0.0–2.5 [rad], saturating outside the range. Update at 100 Hz. If the reading is invalid, hold last valid angle.
Implement an emergency stop for a motor: when E‑STOP is active, immediately command zero output and engage a brake signal; when cleared, require a manual reset to re-enable motion.
Limit changes in a linear velocity command to 0.10 [mps] per second (slew rate) before sending it to the motor. Run at 200 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.2 ms.
For a rotary actuator, limit the angular rate by capping the per-cycle change in angle so it corresponds to at most 0.5 [rad] per second at 100 Hz. Reject setpoints outside 0–2.0 [rad].
Combine a start/stop boolean and a user speed command to produce a motor setpoint in [mps]. When stopped, force 0 [mps]. Clamp the commanded speed to ±0.25 [mps].
Control a linear actuator with two commands: extend and retract. Move until the respective end switch is hit, then stop. Default to stop on any fault or conflicting commands.
Create a timed motion: when a trigger arrives, move a servo to 0.80 [rad] for 2.0 s, then return to 0.0 [rad]. Ignore additional triggers during the active interval.
If temperature exceeds a safety limit, stop the conveyor motor; otherwise run at a constant 0.20 [mps]. Include hysteresis to avoid chatter.
Apply a deadband of ±0.02 [mps] around zero to a velocity command so the motor remains stopped for tiny inputs. Clip the final command to ±0.3 [mps].
Translate a target linear speed in [mps] into a step rate for a stepper motor using a provided wheel circumference parameter. Update at 1 kHz with WCET ≤ 0.1 ms.
Engage a brake output whenever the measured speed falls below 0.02 [mps]; release the brake when speed rises above 0.05 [mps]. Fail-safe to engaged on sensor fault.
When a 'latch' button is pressed, memorize the current joint angle [rad] and command the servo to hold that angle. If the button is pressed again, release and hold the current angle instead.
Enable a drive only when both an interlock and a run command are true; otherwise force the motor command to 0 [mps] and disable power. Require rising-edge detection to enable.

Implement a homing routine for a rotary axis: move slowly negative until the home switch closes, set position to 0.0 [rad], then stop. Abort and signal FAULT if not found within 5.0 [rad] of travel. Run at 200 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.3 ms.
Build a two-state controller (IDLE, RUN). In RUN, follow a trapezoidal position profile to a target angle [rad] with configurable max speed and acceleration. On cancel, transition to IDLE and stop.
For a conveyor, run forward at a commanded speed [mps]. If a jam sensor trips, reverse at 0.10 [mps] for 1.0 s, then stop and wait for operator reset. Enforce a speed limit of 0.5 [mps].
Control a door servo with states CLOSED, OPENING, OPEN, CLOSING. Use target angles 0.0 [rad] and 1.2 [rad], with dwell time of 3 s in OPEN. Stop immediately on obstruction signal.
Maintain constant linear speed [mps] unless a current-limit input indicates overload, in which case scale the command down linearly to protect the drive. Restore when overload clears.

Add a mode selector for a gimbal yaw joint: MANUAL passes through angle commands (clamped to ±1.2 [rad]); HOLD maintains the current angle against disturbances; FAULT drives to a safe 0.0 [rad]. Transition on a three-position switch.

Execute stepper moves to reach a requested angle [rad] with a maximum speed, braking as you approach the target. Respect both MIN and MAX endstops, and stop with FAULT on unexpected switch activation.
Combine a debounced START button and an E‑STOP. START initiates motion at a set speed [mps]; E‑STOP at any time forces 0 [mps] and disables power. Require manual reset after E‑STOP.
Drive a clutch‑coupled actuator: track position to a command [rad], but when measured speed exceeds 0.3 [mps] equivalent due to external motion, disengage control and hold until speed is safe again.
Synchronize two conveyor motors: adjust the secondary motor so its measured speed matches the primary within ±0.02 [mps]. Signal FAULT if the error persists for more than 2 s.
Implement an indexing table: each cycle, rotate by 0.785 [rad], settle, and assert an 'indexed' output. Enforce a travel limit of 0–6.283 [rad] and stop on timeout.
Impose both slew‑rate and jerk limits on angle commands for a joint so motion remains smooth within 0–1.8 [rad]. Reject any setpoint step that would violate the limits.
Provide a COAST‑TO‑STOP mode: when selected, remove drive and let the axis slow naturally; when not selected, actively command 0 [mps]. Switch modes without causing reversals.
Compute linear speed from encoder counts over a window and clamp the motor command to keep speed within ±0.25 [mps]. If no counts are observed for 200 ms, declare a sensor fault and stop.
Implement a warm‑up sequence: ramp from 0 to 0.40 [mps] over 10 s, hold 5 s, then return to 0 [mps]. Abort at any time on E‑STOP. Control loop at 100 Hz; WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.

Use a lookup table to drive a cam profile for a rotary actuator, producing angle [rad] vs. time. Loop the profile continuously and allow a phase offset input. Ensure angle stays within [0.0, 1.6] [rad].
After 5 s of inactivity (no motion commands), disable the drive enable output. On a new command, re‑enable and resume with a soft start limited to 0.1 [mps]/s.
Implement bidirectional jogging: two buttons jog negative/positive at 0.15 [mps] while held. Releasing both buttons commands 0 [mps]. Prevent both directions being active simultaneously.
Create a simple keep‑alive watchdog for motion: if the control task misses two consecutive 100 Hz cycles, force outputs to a safe 0 [mps] and raise a FAULT flag.
Track a triangle wave command for a servo angle between 0.2 and 1.4 [rad] at 0.2 Hz. Ensure motion never exceeds the mechanical limits and pause on limit switch activation.
Implement a PID position controller for a joint with encoder feedback in [rad]. Include output saturation, anti‑windup, and a velocity limit to protect mechanics. Run at 500 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.2 ms.

Build a cascaded controller: outer loop PID for position [rad], inner loop PID for velocity derived from encoder. Include feed‑forward for desired velocity. Enforce a maximum linear speed of 0.6 [mps].

Fuse wheel encoder speed and accelerometer readings to estimate linear velocity [mps]; use this estimate to hold a commanded speed with a PID. If the sensors disagree by >0.2 [mps] for 0.5 s, fall back to open‑loop at a safe 0.1 [mps] and alert FAULT.

Implement redundant angle sensing for a servo with two encoders. Compute position [rad] from each; if they differ by more than 0.05 [rad], cut drive, engage brake, and enter FAULT. Otherwise run a PID to the setpoint.

Add adaptive thermal derating: as temperature rises above a threshold, linearly reduce the allowed speed limit from 0.5 down to 0.2 [mps]. Ensure the PID controller respects the changing limit without windup.
Design a velocity PID for a conveyor where the plant gain varies with load. Include an integral clamp and derivative filtering. Maintain ±0.02 [mps] steady‑state error at 100 Hz. WCET ≤ 0.3 ms.
Control a joint with nonlinear friction compensation: add static and viscous friction feedforward terms to a position PID (angle in [rad]). Ensure stability when crossing zero speed.
Create a safe motion envelope: bound angle within [0.1, 1.7] [rad] and speed within ±0.4 [mps]. The controller must ensure both constraints during trajectory tracking and halt on violation.
Implement a profiler that generates S‑curve trajectories to reach a target angle [rad] with jerk limits, feeding a velocity PID. Guarantee no more than 0.02 [rad] tracking error.
Add slip detection using difference between commanded and measured velocity [mps]. If slip exceeds 0.15 [mps] for 300 ms, reduce the speed command by 50% and log the event.

Create a multi‑mode joint controller with states OFF, HOMING, POSITION, VELOCITY, and FAULT. Use PID control in POSITION (angle in [rad]) and VELOCITY ([mps]). Include homing via a switch, soft limits, and an emergency stop. Specify a 1 kHz loop with WCET ≤ 0.15 ms and define all state transitions explicitly.

Design a dual‑channel safety supervisor for a conveyor: two independent speed sensors in [mps] must agree within 0.05 [mps]; otherwise force a safe stop and require manual reset. Provide self‑tests at startup and periodic cross‑checks.

Implement coordinated motion for two rotary axes that must reach their respective targets [rad] at the same time. Generate synchronized S‑curve profiles, enforce per‑axis limits, and pause both if either enters FAULT. Include acceptance tests for timing and accuracy.

Provide an automated PID validation routine: apply step and sine test inputs for position [rad] and velocity [mps], record responses, and assert that overshoot < 10%, settling time < 1.0 s, and steady‑state error < 0.02 [rad]/0.02 [mps]. Fail safely on any violation.

Develop a fault‑tolerant drive with degraded modes: primary mode uses encoder‑based PID for position [rad]; if the encoder fails, switch to a velocity‑hold mode using an estimator and limit speed to 0.2 [mps]. Include thorough unit tests, watchdogs, and WCET measurement reports.
When a pushbutton is pressed, command a small DC motor to run forward at a fixed surface speed of 0.25 [mps]; stop the motor immediately when the button is released.
Read a knob and set a servo's absolute position between 0.0 and 1.57 [rad] accordingly. Apply a simple slew rate limit so the servo moves no faster than 0.8 [rad]/s.
Each time a trigger input pulses, advance the stepper motor by one step; ignore input bouncing by enforcing a 20 ms deadtime between steps.
On each press of a button, alternate a servo between 0.0 [rad] and 1.2 [rad]. Debounce the button and ensure movement completes before accepting another press.
On a start command, rotate the motor shaft exactly 6.28 [rad] and then stop. Ignore additional start commands until the move has finished.
Hold a servo at a neutral angle unless a limit switch is active; when the switch is pressed, move to a safe retract angle of 0.30 [rad].
Implement jog control: press-and-hold Button A to jog forward at 0.10 [mps], press-and-hold Button B to jog backward at 0.10 [mps], and stop when neither is pressed.
Use an analog slider to set a wheel's target speed between -0.40 and +0.40 [mps]. Update the command at 50 Hz.
Drive a small fan motor at constant speed, but shut it down if a temperature reading exceeds 70 °C; automatically restart when it falls below 65 °C.
Sweep a servo smoothly between 0.20 [rad] and 1.00 [rad] with a 1 s dwell at each end of travel.
Advance a stepper by 200 steps when a start signal goes high. Ignore any further starts until the 200-step move completes.
When a 'go' signal is true, move a joint to 1.57 [rad]; otherwise hold it at 0.00 [rad].
Run a motor until a stop button is pressed, then apply active braking for 200 ms before releasing to a coast state.
Keep the drive disabled until a safety interlock is engaged; once engaged, allow manual speed commands limited to 0.00–0.60 [mps].
On startup, backdrive the joint slowly until the home switch closes, then set the position to 0.00 [rad] and stop.

Create a simple state machine with states: Idle, Homing, and Run. In Homing, move the axis slowly negative until the home switch closes, zero the position, then transition to Run where the axis tracks a target position command in [rad]. Include a maximum velocity of 1.0 [rad]/s and acceleration of 2.0 [rad]/s^2.
Combine two joystick inputs to command left and right wheel velocities with arcade mixing. Apply a deadband of 0.05 and limit wheel speeds to ±1.2 [mps] with a slew rate limit of 0.6 [mps^2].

Implement a stepper move-to-angle function: on a new target in [rad], generate a trapezoidal velocity profile with max speed 3.0 [rad]/s and max acceleration 10.0 [rad]/s^2, then execute steps until the target is reached.
If a current sensor indicates stall (>3.0 A) while motion is commanded, stop the motor and latch a fault until a manual reset input is received.
Add soft position limits between -1.0 [rad] and +2.2 [rad]; clamp commands beyond these limits and raise a warning when clamped.
Drive a valve servo to commanded angle in [rad] and, if no new command is received for 2 s, park it at 0.0 [rad]. Apply a small dither of ±0.01 [rad] at 2 Hz to prevent stiction.
Estimate wheel velocity from encoder counts at 100 Hz and regulate to a commanded speed in [mps] using a simple proportional controller. Limit the command between -0.8 and +0.8 [mps].
Run a velocity control loop at 200 Hz with WCET of 1.5 ms; if a cycle overruns, set a diagnostic flag and drop the next noncritical logging task.
Add a motion command shaper that ramps velocity commands toward the target with limits on jerk, acceleration, and speed (jerk 20.0 [rad]/s^3, acceleration 8.0 [rad]/s^2, speed 4.0 [rad]/s).

Control a linear actuator with two end-stop switches. Move toward Open or Close on command, stop immediately when the corresponding limit switch is hit, and prevent reversing for 100 ms to avoid bounce-induced re-trigger.

Implement a brake/drive interlock: require the motor to be commanded to 0 [mps] for at least 300 ms before enabling the mechanical brake, and require the brake to be released for 100 ms before allowing nonzero velocity commands.
Hold a joint at a commanded position in [rad] with a stiffness-like proportional control, but cap the motor current command at a level corresponding to 1.5 N·m to avoid over-torque.
Scan a mirror servo between -0.30 [rad] and +0.30 [rad] at a constant sweep rate of 1.0 [rad]/s with a 50 ms dwell at each end.
When the axis reaches within 0.01 [rad] of the target, declare 'in position' and stop issuing motion updates to avoid chattering, but resume if the error grows beyond 0.02 [rad].
Enforce a reduced speed limit of 0.20 [mps] when a guard input is open; restore the full speed limit of 1.00 [mps] when the guard is closed.
Watch an emergency stop input and immediately disable all actuators when asserted. Require a manual reset sequence to clear, ensuring the reset cannot occur while any motion command is nonzero.
Command a conveyor motor to maintain 0.60 [mps] but stop if a downstream photoeye is blocked for more than 250 ms. Restart automatically once the path is clear for 1 s.
If the commanded speed is zero for more than 5 s, engage a holding torque mode on the stepper; release it when a nonzero move command arrives.
Track following error between commanded and measured position in [rad]; if error exceeds 0.15 [rad] for more than 100 ms, declare a fault and disable the drive.

Synchronize two axes so they move together: when axis A receives a new target in [rad], mirror the same target to axis B and maintain their position difference within ±0.02 [rad] by adjusting B's command slightly.

Implement a PID velocity controller for a DC motor running at 250 Hz. The setpoint is in [mps], include integral anti-windup via clamping, and limit the output so actual acceleration does not exceed 3.0 [mps^2].
Create a cascaded control system: an outer PID position loop in [rad] at 100 Hz and an inner PID velocity loop in [rad]/s at 500 Hz. Include feedforward terms and enforce a WCET of 0.8 ms per loop.
Fuse an encoder angle [rad] with a gyroscope [rad]/s using a complementary filter to estimate joint angle and rate. Use the estimate in a position controller and report estimator bias drift.
Estimate wheel speed in [mps] by fusing encoder and accelerometer using a simple Kalman filter; use the estimate to drive a PID speed loop with anti-windup and a 1.0 [mps] maximum speed limit.

Generate and execute an S-curve trajectory in [rad] for a move from current to target with constraints: vmax 5.0 [rad]/s, amax 20.0 [rad]/s^2, jmax 200.0 [rad]/s^3. Provide an 'in motion' flag and stop cleanly if a new target arrives mid-move.

Implement thermal derating for a motor: compute a simple thermal model and reduce the allowed velocity limit linearly as estimated temperature approaches a threshold. Never exceed a current-limited torque estimate while regulating speed in [mps].

Perform a robust homing routine: try the home switch first; if not detected within 2.0 [rad], switch to a slow torque-based search that stops on stall detection, then set home. Report which method succeeded.

Detect jams by monitoring the derivative of position error in [rad]/s; if it stays near zero while a nonzero command is applied for 500 ms, trigger a controlled stop with a deceleration limit and raise an alarm.

Budget control tasks so that position control (WCET 1.0 ms) and trajectory generation (WCET 0.5 ms) both run within a 2.0 ms frame at 500 Hz. If budget is exceeded, shed lower-priority diagnostics while maintaining stable control.

Add cross-coupling between two parallel drives: compute average position [rad], regulate both axes with PID, and add a differential term to minimize skew within ±0.01 [rad] while respecting individual soft limits.

Design a multi-mode motion controller with modes: Safe, Manual, Auto, and Test. Define transitions, including that any fault forces Safe. In Manual, allow direct velocity commands in [mps] with reduced limits; in Auto, execute queued position moves in [rad] with S-curve profiles. Specify control loop rates (position 200 Hz, velocity 500 Hz) and enforce WCETs (1.0 ms and 0.6 ms).

Specify comprehensive requirements and test scenarios for a joint actuator: include unit tests for PID control, property-based tests for saturation and anti-windup, timing tests to prove deadlines are met, and simulations for limit switch handling and emergency stops.

Implement coordinated 3-axis motion where each joint accepts [rad] setpoints and follows time-synchronized trajectories with path blending between segments. Include a supervisory safety layer that enforces joint soft limits, per-axis WCET watchdogs, and a global e-stop that arrests all axes with bounded deceleration.

Build a controller that fuses encoder and IMU to estimate position [rad] and velocity [rad]/s, but can degrade gracefully to encoder-only or IMU-only modes when faults are detected. Define mode transitions, acceptable estimation error bounds, and how control gains change per mode.

Create a real-time safety monitor that watches following error [rad], speed [mps], temperature, and deadline misses. On any violation, transition the motion controller into a Safe Halt sequence with defined deceleration limits, assert a fault latch, and require a structured recovery procedure before resuming.

Make a simple servo positioner: when the enable input is true, hold the arm at 1.20 [rad]; when false, move to 0.00 [rad]. Enforce hard limits 0.00..1.57 [rad], and ramp angle changes to avoid sudden jumps. Run at 100 Hz with WCET <= 0.3 ms.

On each rising edge of a pushbutton, jog a stepper by +0.05 [rad]; on a long press (>1 s), jog -0.05 [rad]. Keep cumulative position within 0.00..2.00 [rad]. Include debounce, and ignore presses while motion is in progress. Control loop 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.2 ms.

Map an analog knob to a conveyor belt speed command in 0.00..0.80 [mps]. Clamp actual speed to 0.90 [mps] maximum. If an emergency stop input is active, command 0.00 [mps] immediately. Target update at 100 Hz with WCET <= 0.3 ms.

On startup, softly home a rotary actuator to 0.00 [rad] and hold. Ignore any target requests above 0.50 [rad]. Limit slew rate to prevent step changes, and stop motion if a fault flag input becomes active. Run at 50 Hz, WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Implement two preset conveyor speeds: 0.30 [mps] and 0.60 [mps], selected by a digital input. Smoothly ramp between presets and never exceed 0.70 [mps]. If the preset input changes rapidly, rate-limit commands. 100 Hz loop, WCET <= 0.25 ms.

Hold a servo at 0.00 [rad] using simple proportional control. Limit the drive output to prevent chatter. If a separate fault input asserts, disable the drive and keep last measured angle. Operate at 250 Hz, WCET <= 0.2 ms.

Create a heartbeat-supervised actuator: track a periodic command timestamp; if no update arrives within 100 ms, move the servo to a safe angle of 0.10 [rad]. Normal commands set any angle within 0.00..1.00 [rad]. WCET <= 0.3 ms at 100 Hz.

While a digital enable input is high, command a motor to produce 0.50 [mps] linear speed; when low, apply brake and hold stopped. Cap speed at 0.60 [mps] and ignore enable if an overspeed flag is active. Run at 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.2 ms.

Generate a gentle oscillation for a pan axis: sweep between -0.50 [rad] and +0.50 [rad] with a period of 5 s. Limit jerk so motion is smooth. If an interrupt input is asserted, stop at the nearest midpoint (0.00 [rad]). 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.3 ms.

After a 2 s startup delay, move a rotary actuator to 0.25 [rad] and hold. Never go beyond 0.40 [rad]. If a cancel input toggles, return to 0.00 [rad] with a fixed slew rate. 50 Hz control loop, WCET <= 0.4 ms.
Read an encoder and compute current angular position in [rad]. Light a status output whenever the angle is within 0.90..1.10 [rad]. Sample at 200 Hz and guarantee WCET <= 0.1 ms.

A single pushbutton should jog a stepper: short press adds +0.05 [rad], double-press adds +0.10 [rad], and long press subtracts 0.05 [rad]. Constrain total travel within -0.50..1.50 [rad]. Include press rate limiting. 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.35 ms.

Command a fixed belt speed of 0.60 [mps] for a motorized roller. If a low-supply analog input falls below a threshold, immediately command 0.00 [mps] and latch an alarm until reset. Run at 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.2 ms.

Enable a servo only when the temperature input indicates below 60 C. While enabled, hold 0.30 [rad] with angle limits 0.00..0.50 [rad]. If temperature rises above 70 C, disable and move to 0.00 [rad]. 50 Hz, WCET <= 0.4 ms.

When an enable input goes high, ramp a linear axis from 0.00 to 1.00 [mps] over 3 s; when it goes low, ramp down over 1 s to 0.00 [mps]. Any emergency input forces immediate stop at 0.00 [mps]. Control at 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.25 ms.

Build a state machine with states Idle, Homing, and Running. Homing drives toward a reference switch until triggered, then sets angle to 0.00 [rad]. Running accepts target angles in 0.00..2.00 [rad] and obeys soft limits. Execute at 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Control a 2-axis gimbal: accept two angle setpoints in [rad], apply per-axis slew rate limits, and stop motion if an overcurrent flag asserts. If a fault clears, re-enter hold mode at the last valid angles. 250 Hz loop, WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Implement velocity control with a trapezoidal profile to change between current speed and a new target in [mps]. Do not allow the carriage to cross position boundaries defined by 0.00..1.50 [rad] of rotation equivalent. 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.4 ms.

On startup, use an encoder index pulse to re-zero angle to 0.00 [rad]. If the index is not found within 1.00 [rad] of motion, stop and declare a fault. In normal operation, command angles with soft limits and hold. 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Create a position loop with PID for a servo to track a target angle in [rad]. Provide gain inputs for tuning. Clamp integral windup and limit the output to safe bounds. Accept commands at 100 Hz; control loop at 500 Hz; WCET <= 0.2 ms.

Drive a stepper with a controlled step rate profile: accelerate, cruise, decelerate to reach a target angle in [rad]. Watch a stall-detected input; on stall, abort and hold. Cap peak speed to the equivalent of 0.50 [mps]. 200 Hz planner, WCET <= 0.35 ms.

Run a conveyor at a commanded 0.40 [mps]. Monitor motor current via an analog input; if current exceeds a threshold for >200 ms, declare a jam, stop to 0.00 [mps], and latch until reset. Refresh at 100 Hz with WCET <= 0.25 ms.

Implement differential drive control: accept forward speed [mps] and turn rate in [rad] per second, compute left/right wheel velocities, and saturate within allowable limits. If one encoder signal is missing, stop both wheels. Run at 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Control a gripper servo to close until a force switch indicates contact, then hold at that angle. Constrain angles within 0.00..1.20 [rad] and time out after 1 s if no contact is found. Use a small PID to hold position. 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Every minute, if idle, return the rotary axis to 0.00 [rad] to recalibrate against a reference marker. Skip calibration if the busy input is true. Motion must respect a 0.80 [mps] equivalent speed limit. 250 Hz, WCET <= 0.2 ms.

Maintain a roller at 0.50 [mps] with simple feedforward plus feedback correction. Enforce slow-start and slow-stop behavior. If an emergency stop asserts, command 0.00 [mps] immediately. Control at 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.25 ms.

Use two end switches to enforce a safe zone for a rotary stage. Prevent motion that would drive beyond 0.00..2.50 [rad]. If both switches read active simultaneously, stop and latch a fault until reset. 100 Hz loop, WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Coordinate a pan-tilt move so both axes arrive at their targets in [rad] at the same time. Compute synchronized profiles that honor per-axis max speed and acceleration limits. 200 Hz planning, WCET <= 0.35 ms.

Map a joystick to a servo angle in [rad] with a central deadband. Apply slew rate limits and saturations. If no joystick message is received within 100 ms, move to a neutral angle of 0.00 [rad]. 250 Hz loop, WCET <= 0.2 ms.

Rotate to the nearest detent among 0.00, 1.57, 3.14, and 4.71 [rad], choosing the direction with the least travel. After reaching, hold position with a small proportional controller. 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.25 ms.
Implement velocity hold using a PI controller for a linear axis in [mps]. Limit acceleration and jerk, and include anti-windup. Sample at 500 Hz and guarantee WCET <= 0.15 ms.

Create an S-curve speed ramp from 0.00 to a target speed in [mps], with an abort input that returns speed to 0.00 [mps] safely. Enforce a maximum allowed speed at all times. 200 Hz update, WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Hold a screw-driven actuator at a commanded angle in [rad] corresponding to a specific extension. Include soft limits and a hold mode that minimizes oscillation. If a limit is hit, back off to a safe 0.05 [rad]. 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.25 ms.

Add an overspeed guard: if the measured change in angle exceeds 15 [rad] per second, immediately disable the drive and engage a brake output. Require a manual reset to re-enable. Run detection at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.1 ms.

Implement a 3-state control logic: Disabled, Armed, Active. Only in Active may the motor move toward targets in [rad] or [mps]. Include a watchdog timer and explicit transitions with timeouts. 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Design a closed-loop PID position controller with feedforward velocity and acceleration terms for precise angle tracking in [rad]. Include angle limits, integrator clamping, and a low-pass filter on the derivative term. Run the loop at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.10 ms.

Fuse an encoder angle (in [rad]) with a gyro rate to estimate joint velocity, then use that estimate for a PID velocity control of a linear stage in [mps]. Handle sensor dropout by falling back to the remaining sensor and reduce bandwidth. 500 Hz loop, WCET <= 0.15 ms.

Implement dual-loop control: an outer position loop in [rad] and an inner velocity loop in [mps]. Manage saturation to avoid windup and respect a torque-limit input. Include an emergency stop path. Controller at 1 kHz, WCET <= 0.12 ms.

Add friction compensation to a PID position loop: provide static friction offset near zero velocity and viscous compensation proportional to speed. Maintain safety limits on angle in [rad] and speed in [mps]. 1 kHz, WCET <= 0.1 ms.

Use two redundant angle sensors to measure the same joint in [rad]. If their difference exceeds 0.02 [rad], stop the actuator and latch a fault. Otherwise, use the average for a PID position loop. 500 Hz, WCET <= 0.15 ms.

Track a time-stamped sequence of waypoints in [rad] with specified arrival times, ensuring jerk-limited profiles. Abort the sequence if a waypoint is late or infeasible. Guarantee control loop WCET <= 0.08 ms at 1 kHz.

Create a homing routine that combines a reference switch and a current spike signal to detect hard stops. Home at a safe approach speed in [mps], then back off and latch zero at a repeatable point. Include failure handling if either signal misbehaves. 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.2 ms.

Implement a disturbance observer to estimate external load torque and compensate within a position controller in [rad]. Limit the compensation to safe bounds and verify stability by capping observer bandwidth. 1 kHz loop, WCET <= 0.1 ms.

Add thermal derating to a velocity-controlled axis in [mps]: above 70 C, linearly reduce the allowed max speed; above 85 C, command 0.00 [mps] and latch a fault. Log each transition event and maintain WCET <= 0.12 ms at 500 Hz.

Integrate dual emergency-stop channels that must both be healthy to enable motion. If channels disagree, enter a fail-safe state and require a power-cycle reset. Maintain normal motion control in [rad] and [mps] at 500 Hz, WCET <= 0.10 ms.

Specify a multi-mode actuator controller with modes Manual, Auto, SafeStop, and Diagnostics. Define behavior per mode for position in [rad] and velocity in [mps], transitions, timeouts, and interlocks. Guarantee loop rate 500 Hz with WCET <= 0.12 ms, and include self-tests for sensors and watchdog on entry to each mode.

Develop a coordinated move planner for three rotary joints to execute synchronized trajectories under per-joint limits on speed ([rad] per second), acceleration, and jerk. Include a global stop that halts all axes safely. Provide acceptance tests for timing jitter and WCET <= 0.12 ms at 1 kHz under worst-case command load.

Create a high-integrity PID control configuration with unit consistency checks for [rad] and [mps], bounded integral action, and online gain scheduling across speed ranges. Require built-in step-response tests and safety limit assertions before enabling drive output. 1 kHz loop, WCET <= 0.10 ms.

Define a comprehensive homing and commissioning state machine for a stepper axis, including search, backoff, latch, and soft-limit computation in [rad]. Add error recovery branches for switch failure and missed steps. Provide test cases and verify WCET margins at a 1 kHz scheduler.

Specify a drive-by-wire wheel module with modes Park, Steer, and Align. Blend position control for steering in [rad] with wheel velocity in [mps]. Fuse dual encoders with a gyro for heading, enforce strict interlocks and degraded operation, and include a test plan for comms loss, sensor disagreement, and emergency stop latency. 500 Hz loop, WCET <= 0.12 ms.

When a start signal is true, spin a motor forward at a fixed speed of 0.5 [mps]; stop when the signal is false. Enforce a maximum runtime of 120 s per command and immediately cut power if an emergency stop is asserted.
Set a servo to 1.57 [rad] when a toggle is pressed; otherwise hold 0.0 [rad]. Limit motion speed to 0.5 rad/s and respect a soft range between -0.2 [rad] and 1.8 [rad].
Drive a stepper one step every 10 ms while an enable input is high; stop instantly if a limit switch triggers. Ensure the control task runs at 100 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.
Implement a deadman switch: keep motor velocity at 0.0 [mps] unless a keep-alive flag toggles at least once per second; otherwise coast down safely.
Reverse motor direction every 2 s to create a gentle oscillation between +0.2 [mps] and -0.2 [mps], and clamp any command to those limits.
Read an analog knob and map it linearly to a servo angle from -1.0 [rad] to +1.0 [rad], with a rate limit of 0.2 rad/s to avoid abrupt motion.
On button press, move a joint by +0.3 [rad] relative; when the button is released, return to the previous position. Enforce min and max position bounds at all times.
Start a conveyor at 0.3 [mps] when a part sensor detects presence; stop 3 s later or immediately if a jam sensor triggers.
Blink a status indicator faster when measured motor velocity exceeds 1.0 [mps]; slower otherwise. Keep the velocity measurement updated at 50 Hz.
Issue a trapezoidal ramp from 0 to 0.8 [mps] over 2 s, then hold steady; cancel and decelerate to 0 if the stop input goes high.
Keep a servo centered at 0 [rad]; if a nudge input is held, offset by +0.1 [rad]. Bound the absolute angle to ±1.2 [rad].
Drive until encoder counts correspond to +1.0 [rad] of rotation, then stop. If a limit switch is active at start, do nothing and signal a fault.
Soft-start a motor: increase velocity by 0.05 [mps] every 50 ms until reaching 0.4 [mps]; on disable, soft-stop with a symmetric ramp.
Generate a square-wave position command for a servo, alternating between -0.5 [rad] and +0.5 [rad] every second. Include an enable input that freezes at the current angle when false.
Command a stepper to jog at -0.5 rad/s while a jog-negative input is active; halt immediately if the home sensor is hit.

Create a two-state controller (Idle, Run) that, when started, follows a velocity schedule: 0.0 [mps] -> 0.6 [mps] -> 0.0 [mps], each segment lasting 3 s. Abort to Idle on fault input. Task period 50 ms; WCET <= 2 ms.
Implement homing for a rotary axis: move slowly at -0.2 rad/s until home is detected, back off by 0.1 [rad], then approach at -0.05 rad/s and latch zero. Enforce a 10 s timeout.
Blend two velocity setpoints (operator dial and supervisory limit) so the commanded speed never exceeds the lower of the two, expressed in [mps]. Emergency stop must override at all times.
Maintain a position-hold mode for a servo with simple proportional control; when a jog button is tapped, shift the target by 0.05 [rad]. Limit torque command and saturate outputs to safe bounds.
Coordinate two wheels to track a commanded linear speed in [mps] and a yaw rate in rad/s; compute left/right wheel velocities and enforce saturation to protect actuators.
Create a motion profile executor for position moves given a target in [rad], with jerk-limited acceleration. Provide pause, resume, and cancel controls.
Detect a stall condition: if commanded velocity exceeds 0.3 [mps] but encoder velocity remains below 0.05 [mps] for more than 500 ms, trip a fault and cut drive.
Switch between three velocity presets (0.2, 0.5, 0.8 [mps]) based on a selector input; ramp between presets with an acceleration limit of 0.4 m/s^2.
Drive a pan axis to scan from -1.2 [rad] to +1.2 [rad] at 0.4 rad/s, pause 0.5 s at each end, and repeat until stop. Provide a busy output.
Implement a stepper indexer that executes a sequence of relative moves in [rad]: [+0.4, +0.4, -0.8], with 100 ms dwell between moves and immediate abort on any limit fault.
Add a watchdog: if the control loop misses two consecutive 10 ms cycles (WCET violation), force outputs to a safe state and raise an alarm.
Combine a bump sensor and a motor current estimate to decide when to stop closing a gripper; if either indicates contact, stop motion and hold position.

Implement a finite state machine for a lift: AwaitCommand, Moving, Settling, Done. Move to the commanded position using velocity control in [mps] with an acceleration limit and soft end stops at the travel limits.
Monitor motor temperature and derate maximum velocity from 1.0 [mps] down to 0.3 [mps] when over threshold; restore when cooled, with hysteresis.
Implement a jog mode with repeat rate: every 200 ms while the jog button is held, nudge the target by +0.02 [rad]. Prevent exceeding -1.5 [rad] to +1.5 [rad].
Generate a sinusoidal test motion for a joint: position(t) = 0.6·sin(1.0·t) [rad]. Ensure the command rate is 200 Hz and WCET <= 300 µs.
Add soft-start and soft-stop with S-curve acceleration for motions up to 0.9 [mps]; on an external stop command, decelerate to zero within 500 ms.
Create an overspeed latch: once velocity >1.2 [mps] is detected, inhibit motion until a reset input is received.
Cross-couple two actuators so they move symmetrically: when one is commanded +θ [rad], mirror the other to -θ [rad], respecting each axis’s soft limits.
Accept position targets in [rad] via messages and apply them only when the axis is within ±0.05 [rad] of the current setpoint; otherwise keep a single pending target that gets replaced on new input.
Implement a velocity PID controller using encoder feedback in [mps] with anti-windup, output saturation, and a 1 kHz loop. Specify WCET <= 80 µs and log any saturation events.
Create a cascaded control structure: outer position PID in [rad], inner velocity PID in rad/s for a joint actuator. Include configurable limits on position, velocity, and acceleration.
Fuse encoder and gyroscope data to estimate joint velocity in rad/s via a complementary filter; drive a velocity PID to track a setpoint with units of rad/s while rejecting noise.
Execute time-parameterized trajectory waypoints in [rad] with feedforward velocity and acceleration, while enforcing a safety envelope that limits torque and speed near end stops.
Add dynamic friction compensation (static and viscous) within a velocity PID loop in [mps], and automatically disable compensation if oscillations exceed a threshold.
Implement stall detection by estimating back-EMF and comparing it to the encoder rate; on suspected stall, switch to a hold-position mode and raise an alert.
Perform online auto-tuning of PID gains during a controlled step test to achieve ≤5% overshoot and <300 ms settling for a velocity target of 0.7 [mps]. Cap actuator output during the test for safety.
Design a jerk-limited trajectory generator feeding a position PID in [rad]; include a safe decelerate-to-stop on any fault within 200 ms.
Control two synchronized axes with master–slave gearing: the slave tracks k×master position in [rad] using PID and maintains phase alignment; handle loss of sync gracefully.
Integrate thermal derating into the controller: as estimated winding temperature rises, scale the PID output limit to keep power within a safe curve, with hysteresis to prevent chatter.

Build a multi-mode joint controller with modes: Boot, Homing, Idle, PositionHold, Trajectory, Fault. Include state transitions, interlocks, and a safety case: hard stops at ±2.0 [rad], velocity limit 1.2 rad/s, WCET monitoring at 1 kHz with a 100 µs budget. Provide test procedures for each mode.

Implement a mobile base drive with modes Manual, Auto, and EStop. Manual maps joystick to linear speed [mps] and yaw rate rad/s; Auto follows a velocity profile; EStop forces 0 within 50 ms. Include a watchdog, heartbeat, and acceptance tests for timing and limit violations.

Create a dual-loop controller for a telescoping axis that switches between force-limited insertion and precise position PID (position in meters, velocity in [mps]). Specify comprehensive fault handling and unit tests for edge cases.

Design a coordinated 4-motor system with trajectory modes (standby, index, continuous) and synchronization tolerance of 0.01 [rad]. Include deterministic scheduling at 500 Hz, a WCET budget per motor of 150 µs, and verification steps.

Develop a safety-critical motion supervisor that enforces a global envelope on position [rad] and velocity [mps] across multiple axes, supports degraded mode on sensor loss, and includes a complete test harness with fault injection.

Move a rotary servo to 1.57 [rad] when a boolean 'enable' is true; otherwise hold at 0.00 [rad]. Limit the move rate so the transition takes about 0.5 s and prevent any command outside [0.00, 2.50] [rad].
Implement a jog function for a stepper: each rising edge on a 'jog' input advances the axis by +0.10 [rad]. Ignore long presses, and enforce travel bounds of ±3.14 [rad] around zero.
When 'start' is asserted, ramp a conveyor to 0.50 [mps] over 2 s; when 'stop' is asserted, ramp back to 0.00 [mps] over 2 s. Apply an output saturation to keep the actuator within safe limits.

Hold a joint at a setpoint provided by an analog input mapped to 0.00–3.14 [rad] using proportional-only control. Clip commands at the soft limits and report if the requested setpoint exceeds the allowable [rad] range.
Toggle a servo between 0.30 [rad] and 0.80 [rad] every 5 s. If a 'fault' input is true, pause motion at the current angle and resume the periodic toggling only when the fault clears.
On power-up, home a rotary axis by moving slowly until a home sensor is detected, then set the position to 0.00 [rad] and stop. Ignore any move commands until homing completes.
Drive a linear actuator while a momentary 'extend' switch is held; stop when released. Limit extension speed to 0.20 [mps] and lock out reverse motion if an end-of-travel limit is active.
Implement a simple thermal derate: run a belt at 0.40 [mps] when temperature is nominal; if temperature crosses a threshold, reduce to 0.10 [mps] until temperature recovers.
Create a deadman function: the motor shall run only while 'enable' is true; otherwise immediately command 0.00 [mps]. Treat any invalid input as not enabled.
Implement a command watchdog: if no new setpoint arrives for 500 ms, force the actuator velocity to 0.00 [mps] and latch a timeout indicator until a manual reset.
Accept an angle setpoint in [rad] and drive a servo to it, saturating requests to the safe range [0.00, 2.00] [rad]. Reject NaN or out-of-range inputs gracefully.
Make a gripper finger move smoothly: limit the change in commanded angle to 0.20 [rad] per control update toward the requested [rad] setpoint to avoid sudden jumps.
When 'go' is asserted, command a single wheel to 0.60 [mps]. When 'go' is false, command 0.00 [mps]. Clamp the command to a maximum of 0.80 [mps] for safety.
Generate a simple trapezoidal move from 0.00 to 2.00 [rad] completing in 4 s, then hold position. Abort and hold immediately if an 'estop' input is asserted.
Implement a soft-stop: if the measured angle exceeds 3.00 [rad], immediately override any command to hold position and flag a limit violation until cleared.

For a differential drive, accept commands for linear speed in [mps] and a heading increment in [rad] per control period. Compute left/right wheel targets in [mps], apply saturation and a simple ramp to avoid abrupt changes.

Create a state machine for a rotary axis with states: Idle, Homing, Ready, Fault. On Homing, move until the home switch triggers, set 0.00 [rad], then transition to Ready. Any error transitions to Fault and disables motion.
Build a stepper indexer that moves through a list of target positions in [rad] with configurable dwell times at each point. Allow an 'abort' input to decelerate to a stop and exit the sequence.
Maintain a joint within ±0.05 [rad] of a setpoint using simple closed-loop control. If the error stays outside that band for more than 1 s, assert a fault and disable the actuator.
Match the speed of a follower roller to a leader roller by measuring both and commanding the follower in [mps]. Include a low-pass filter on the measured speeds and limit the allowable slip.

Enforce soft position limits: clamp any commanded angle to [0.20, 2.60] [rad]. If a physical limit switch asserts, back off 0.10 [rad] away from the limit and enter a Safe state that ignores further move requests.
Implement a variable-speed jog controlled by a knob mapped to -0.50 to +0.50 [mps]. Use a deadband around zero, limit acceleration, and stop at 0.00 [mps] when a 'stop' button is pressed.
Sequence a pick-and-place joint through three angles in [rad] with specified dwell times at each. Provide 'pause' and 'resume' inputs and ensure motion halts safely on pause.
Hold a conveyor near 0.40 [mps] using bang-bang control with a ±0.05 [mps] hysteresis band. Saturate output and log an overspeed condition if the measured speed exceeds 0.60 [mps].
Provide a non-blocking motion queue: accept up to five position setpoints in [rad] and execute them FIFO. Support a 'cancel' to clear the queue and stop at the current position.
Only allow reversing direction when the measured speed is below 0.05 [mps]. If a reverse command arrives while faster than that, decelerate to below 0.05 [mps] before switching.
Detect wheel slip by comparing target and measured speeds in [mps]. If the absolute error exceeds 0.20 [mps] for more than 300 ms, reduce the command by 50% and raise a warning indicator.
Stabilize a gimbal axis toward a [rad] setpoint using proportional control with a maximum rate limit. If a gyro validity flag is false, freeze the command and hold the last good angle.
Run a servo sweep from 0.00 to 2.50 [rad] and back continuously at a constant rate. Monitor the control loop and assert an error if the task WCET exceeds 1 ms at any point.
Implement dual-mode control: when a 'speed_mode' flag is true, regulate velocity in [mps]; when false, hold the last position in [rad]. Add hysteresis on the mode switch to avoid chatter.
On a stop command, ramp the actuator from its current speed to 0.00 [mps] linearly over 2 s, then hold position. Ignore new start commands until the ramp-down completes.

Handle hard endstops: when the left limit is triggered, set the position to 0.00 [rad]; when the right limit is triggered, set it to 3.14 [rad]. Prevent commands that would drive further into a limit.
Define emergency stop behavior: immediately command 0.00 [mps] and disable outputs on 'estop'. Require a manual reset sequence to re-enable motion.
Derate maximum speed based on temperature: from 0.80 [mps] at 60 C down to 0.30 [mps] at 80 C, with a complete stop above 80 C. Restore limits as temperature decreases.
Publish a status message at 50 Hz with current setpoint [rad], measured position [rad], and controller state. Ensure the control loop WCET stays below 2 ms.

Implement PID position control for a rotary joint with a setpoint in [rad]. Include output saturation, anti-windup, and a slew rate limiter. Run at 500 Hz with WCET < 1 ms and fail-safe to hold if the sensor becomes invalid.
Create a velocity PID for a wheel with target speed in [mps], adding a simple acceleration feedforward. Use integral anti-windup during saturation. Execute the loop at 250 Hz with WCET < 1.5 ms.

Fuse an encoder angle with a gyro to estimate a joint angle for control. Drive the actuator to a [rad] setpoint using the fused estimate, and degrade gracefully to encoder-only if the gyro fails self-check.

Build a cascaded controller: an outer position loop in [rad] at 200 Hz commanding an inner velocity loop in [mps] at 1 kHz. Enforce WCET < 2 ms for the outer and < 0.5 ms for the inner loop, and ensure stable transitions to a manual mode.
Synchronize two belt drives so their speeds match in [mps] using a master–follower PID. Detect stalls and trigger a safe shutdown if the follower cannot track within 0.05 [mps] for 500 ms.
Follow a jerk-limited trajectory defined by time-tagged waypoints in [rad], using PID tracking. Enforce soft limits and abort if the tracking error exceeds 0.10 [rad] for more than 100 ms.
Apply gain scheduling to a speed controller: adjust PID gains as a function of operating speed in [mps] to maintain stability. Define safe gain ranges and inhibit changes when a fault is active.

Estimate linear stage velocity by fusing encoder-derived speed with an accelerometer, then close a PID loop on [mps]. Detect and mitigate bias drift; if fusion confidence drops, revert to encoder-only. Keep WCET < 1.5 ms.

Add anti-cogging compensation to a position PID: learn a periodic offset table over one mechanical revolution in [rad] and apply it as feedforward. Provide a reset procedure and enforce safe command limits.

Implement stall detection using an observer that considers current draw and speed error. On stall, cut drive, back off by 0.05 [rad], and retry up to three times before latching a fault with a cooldown timer.

Design a multi-mode joint controller with modes: Idle, Position, Velocity, Teach, Fault. Accept setpoints in [rad] or [mps] per mode, enforce safe interlocks and a watchdog, and ensure an e-stop overrides all. Specify loop rates and WCET for each mode, plus built-in self-tests.

Implement control for a two-wheel mobile base with modes Standby, Teleop, Trajectory, Dock, Fault. Use cascaded PID for wheel speeds in [mps] and heading in [rad]; fuse encoders with IMU yaw. Guarantee WCET < 2 ms for control and < 5 ms for localization, and define acceptance tests for overspeed, slip, and comms loss.

Create a redundant position controller using dual encoders. Compare and vote on angle in [rad], detect drift beyond a threshold, and continue in fail-operational mode where possible. Track setpoints with PID, define safety limits and WCET budget, and outline a comprehensive fault-injection test plan.

Develop a motion supervisor for a 4-axis manipulator that coordinates axis trajectories in [rad], enforces soft-limit envelopes to avoid collisions, and replans if conflicts occur. Use multi-rate loops with WCET per axis and provide detailed verification criteria.

Specify a certified-grade speed governor for a conveyor that caps speed at 1.20 [mps]. Include PID control, a formal safe-state machine, WCET analysis for the control task, diagnostic coverage with periodic proof tests, and acceptance tests across load and temperature variations.

Drive a motor at a fixed linear velocity of 0.25 [mps] while a momentary switch is pressed; when released, stop immediately. Include a simple ramp so the speed changes no faster than 0.1 [mps] per 0.1 s.
Upon receiving a target angle from a knob input, move a servo to that angle in [rad], clamping the command between 0.0 [rad] and 2.6 [rad]. If the input is out of range, hold the last valid angle.
On a rising edge of a button, rotate the shaft by exactly 1.57 [rad] and then hold position; ignore further presses until the motion completes.
Toggle between two wheel speeds, 0.2 [mps] and 0.5 [mps], using a switch. Indicate the current mode via an LED (slow blink for slow, fast blink for fast).
Implement a deadman function: command 0.4 [mps] only while a safety enable is held; otherwise command 0 [mps]. Ensure outputs go to zero within 50 ms after release.
Ramp the joint position smoothly from its current angle to a target in [rad] using a maximum rate of change of 0.5 [rad] per second. If a cancel button is pressed, abort and hold.
Stop motion immediately if a normally-closed limit switch opens; otherwise allow manual jog at 0.1 [mps] forward or reverse using two buttons.
Generate a periodic sweep: move the servo between -0.5 [rad] and +0.5 [rad] at 0.25 Hz with smooth turnaround pauses of 0.2 s at the ends.
Command a conveyor to 0.3 [mps], but if an optical sensor sees an object, reduce to 0.05 [mps] until it clears, then resume.
When a target angle setpoint in [rad] is provided, snap to it if the difference is less than 0.05 [rad]; otherwise step toward it in increments of 0.02 [rad] every 20 ms.
Drive a stepper to rotate 0.785 [rad] clockwise on each button press, with a minimum 300 ms debounce and no motion if an interlock input is inactive.
Hold a constant angle of 1.0 [rad] and engage a brake output when the error is below 0.01 [rad]; release the brake if error exceeds 0.05 [rad].
Map an analog speed command to 0.0-0.6 [mps] with linear scaling and saturate at both ends. Provide a low-pass filter with a 200 ms time constant.
Reverse direction every 3 seconds while maintaining 0.15 [mps]. Ensure direction changes include a 100 ms coast at 0 [mps] before reversing.
Implement a simple safety stop: if the estimated velocity exceeds 0.8 [mps], cut the command to 0 [mps] and latch a fault until reset.

Create a small state machine for a rotary joint with states: Idle, Move, Hold, Fault. Accept a target angle in [rad], move until within 0.02 [rad], then Hold. Enter Fault if a limit switch opens unexpectedly. Run at 200 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Implement homing: from Idle, move slowly negative until the home sensor triggers, back off 0.1 [rad], then re-approach at 0.05 [mps] to refine. After homed, accept absolute angle commands in [rad] within soft limits.

For a two-wheel drive base, accept a desired forward speed in [mps] and a turn command in [rad] of arc to execute over 2 seconds. Split into left/right track speeds, clamp each within ±0.6 [mps], and stop if a bumper triggers.

Use an encoder to estimate angular position in [rad] and implement a hold function that increases motor output proportionally to angle error with a deadband of +/-0.01 [rad]. Limit output rate of change to prevent jerks.

Build a jog-and-teach routine: two buttons jog the axis at 0.1 [mps] and 0.3 [mps]; a third button records the current angle in [rad] into a 10-point list. A separate input plays back the list sequentially with 0.02 [rad] tolerance.
Add soft travel limits: prevent commanding beyond 0.0 [rad] and 3.0 [rad]. If a command would exceed a limit, clamp and emit a warning signal for 200 ms. Control loop at 250 Hz; ensure WCET < 0.8 ms.

Coordinate two servos so they mirror around 1.57 [rad]: when one is commanded to theta [rad], the other goes to (3.14 [rad] - theta). Enforce each within 0.0-3.14 [rad] and halt both if either faults.

Implement a velocity scheduler: follow a time-stamped list of target speeds in [mps], interpolating linearly between points. If the list ends, hold the last speed. Abort if an emergency stop goes active.
Do a soft-start: when a start command arrives, ramp from 0 to 0.4 [mps] over 1.5 s; on stop, ramp down over 0.5 s. If a temperature warning is high, cap speed at 0.2 [mps].
Add a watchdog to the command stream: if no new angle setpoint in [rad] arrives within 200 ms, hold last and flag a timeout; if no setpoint for 1 s, move to a safe angle of 0.0 [rad].
Create a discrete-time slew limiter: limit change of target angle to 0.03 [rad] per 10 ms tick. Run at 100 Hz and guarantee WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Build a simple trapezoidal move generator to go from current angle to a target in [rad] with max speed 0.5 [mps] and acceleration limited to 0.1 [mps] per 100 ms. Expose a 'busy' output while in motion.
Implement a motion interlock: do not move unless both 'guard closed' and 'enable' inputs are true. If either goes false during motion, decelerate to 0 [mps] within 150 ms and latch a fault.
Make a homing-and-go sequence: on power-up, home to index, then move to 1.2 [rad]. If homing fails within 5 s, enter Fault. Control loop runs at 500 Hz with WCET <= 0.4 ms.
Implement position window logic: assert an 'in-position' output when |error| < 0.02 [rad] for at least 100 ms, and deassert immediately if error exceeds 0.05 [rad].
Create a cyclic task that samples an encoder and updates motor command at 400 Hz. Document and enforce WCET <= 0.6 ms, and drop to a safe 0 [mps] output if WCET is exceeded twice in a row.
Accept a stream of relative move commands in [rad]; queue up to 5 moves and execute them FIFO. Allow a 'cancel next' input that drops the head of the queue safely.
Implement a simple stall detector: if the error remains larger than 0.2 [rad] while commanded speed stays above 0.3 [mps] for 1 s, declare stall and stop.
Create a position nudge feature: while holding a trim button, adjust the target by +/-0.005 [rad] every 50 ms. Bound the overall target within 0.0-2.5 [rad].
Add a mode switch with three fixed velocities: 0.1 [mps], 0.3 [mps], 0.6 [mps]. Indicate the active mode on three LEDs and apply a 0.2 s ramp when changing modes.

Implement a PID position controller for a rotary joint with target in [rad]. Include output saturation, integral anti-windup, and a configurable deadband of 0.01 [rad]. Run at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Design a PID velocity loop in [mps] for a conveyor driven by a motor. Add a feedforward term based on the speed setpoint, rate limit the command changes, and declare overspeed if measured > setpoint + 0.2 [mps] for 100 ms.

Fuse an encoder and a gyroscope to estimate angle in [rad] with a complementary filter; use the fused angle for a PID hold controller. Specify update rate 500 Hz and WCET <= 0.5 ms. If the sensors disagree by >0.3 [rad], enter Fault.

Create a cascaded control: outer PID regulates position in [rad], inner PID regulates linear actuator velocity in [mps]. Limit the inner loop output and propagate saturation to the outer loop for anti-windup.

Generate and track a trapezoidal profile for a move from current to target angle in [rad], with max cruise speed 0.7 [mps] and jerk-limited corners achieved by smoothing over 50 ms. Abort safely on interlock open.

Add temperature-based derating: if the temperature exceeds a warning threshold, linearly reduce the allowed max speed from 0.6 [mps] down to 0.2 [mps] as it approaches a high limit, and stop at the limit. Maintain control loop at 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Implement a dual-sensor velocity estimate in [mps] by fusing wheel encoder and optical flow; use the fused value for a PID speed controller. Detect sensor dropout and gracefully degrade to single-sensor mode.

Build a compliance mode: hold position in [rad] with a low PID gain until a force input exceeds a threshold, then allow up to 0.3 [rad] of deflection while capping velocity at 0.2 [mps]. Return to stiff hold when force subsides.

Add a torque-limited move: while moving to a target in [rad], limit the rate so that the estimated torque proxy stays within bounds. If the torque proxy indicates a jam for >300 ms, stop and signal a fault.

Implement an autotune routine for the velocity PID in [mps]: apply small perturbations, estimate response, and update gains. Ensure the routine runs only in a maintenance mode and respects all safety limits.

Develop a multi-mode motion controller with modes: Manual Jog, Auto Profile, Homing, and Fault. Manual accepts jog speeds in [mps]; Auto tracks queued positions in [rad] with PID; Homing executes a safe sequence; Fault latches until reset. Include WCET monitoring and a 1 kHz scheduler.

Specify a state machine for a dual-axis system with coordinated moves: both joints track angles in [rad] while keeping their difference within 0.02 [rad]. Include modes Idle, Sync Move, Desync Recovery, and Safe Stop. Provide unit tests for all transitions and timing at 500 Hz, WCET <= 0.6 ms.

Create a motion subsystem that supports Normal, Reduced-Speed, and Emergency Stop modes. In Normal, follow speed commands up to 0.8 [mps]; in Reduced-Speed, cap at 0.3 [mps]; Emergency Stop ramps to 0 [mps] within 120 ms. Include comprehensive fault injection tests and timing assertions.

Design a full-featured joint controller: cascaded PID (position in [rad], velocity in [mps]), profile generator, soft/hard limits, stall detection, and sensor fusion of encoder and gyro. Provide a test plan covering WCET bounds, step responses, limit violations, and recovery sequences.

Define a comprehensive actuator control module with Auto, Teach, Service, and Fault modes. Support queued moves in [rad], live velocity overrides in [mps], safety interlocks, watchdogs, and WCET enforcement. Include requirements for simulation-based tests of corner cases and determinism.

Create a simple servo controller that sets the output angle to a commanded target in [rad], clamps it between 0.0 [rad] and 2.6 [rad], and slews toward the target with a maximum rate of 0.5 [rad]/s. Run the loop at 50 Hz with WCET <= 0.2 ms, and force the servo to 0.0 [rad] if an emergency stop input is true.

When enabled, drive a motor to a constant linear velocity of 0.25 [mps] with a soft-start ramp of 0.1 [mps]/s; when disabled, ramp down to 0 [mps]. Enforce a speed safety limit of 0.3 [mps]. Execute at 100 Hz with WCET not exceeding 0.3 ms.

On each rising edge of a trigger input, reverse the motor direction while maintaining a fixed magnitude of 0.15 [mps]. Apply a 200 ms debounce and ensure the absolute speed never exceeds 0.2 [mps]. Control loop at 100 Hz; WCET <= 0.25 ms.

Map a user knob (0–100%) to a servo angle from 0.2 [rad] to 2.4 [rad], with a 0.02 [rad] deadband around the current angle to prevent jitter. Update at 50 Hz with WCET <= 0.2 ms, and clamp the final command to the safe range.

Generate a simple motion: drive a conveyor motor at 0.1 [mps] for 2.0 s, then stop and hold for 3.0 s, repeating indefinitely. Include a safety input to immediately stop to 0 [mps]. Task rate 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Hold a pan servo at a fixed 1.0 [rad] setpoint and re-center to 1.0 [rad] if disturbed, using proportional control only. Limit the output to the 0.0–2.0 [rad] safe range. Run at 50 Hz; WCET must be <= 0.2 ms.

Implement a speed limiter: if measured belt speed exceeds 0.35 [mps], force the command to 0 [mps] and latch a fault until reset. Normal operation commands 0.3 [mps]. Cycle time 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.25 ms.

Create a simple jog function: when a jog-left button is held, command −0.12 [mps]; when jog-right is held, command +0.12 [mps]; otherwise 0 [mps]. Apply a rate limit of 0.3 [mps]/s for smoothness. 100 Hz loop, WCET <= 0.3 ms.
Linearly interpolate a servo from its current angle to a new target angle in [rad] over exactly 1.5 s, then hold. Limit the allowed target to [0.1, 2.5] [rad]. Run at 50 Hz and ensure WCET <= 0.2 ms.

Implement a deadman switch: command 0.2 [mps] only while a safety hold input is true; otherwise immediately stop to 0 [mps]. Add a 0.1 [mps]/s deceleration limit to reduce jerk. 100 Hz update; WCET <= 0.25 ms.

For a stepper, on a start command, move exactly 0.157 [rad] forward at a constant rate, then stop; on a reverse command, move −0.157 [rad]. Ignore new commands while moving. Enforce a soft limit of ±3.0 [rad]. Loop at 200 Hz; WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Implement a position window: drive a servo to a target [rad] and report in-position only when the absolute error is < 0.015 [rad] for 100 ms. Clamp command between 0.0 and 2.7 [rad]. 100 Hz loop, WCET <= 0.25 ms.

Make a periodic sweep: oscillate a servo between 0.5 [rad] and 2.1 [rad] with a smooth triangle profile of 0.6 [rad]/s peak slew. Abort to the nearest bound on safety stop. Run at 50 Hz; WCET <= 0.2 ms.

Given a simple speed command in [mps], apply a deadband of ±0.02 [mps] around zero to prevent dithering, and rate-limit changes to 0.2 [mps]/s. Ensure |speed| never exceeds 0.4 [mps]. 100 Hz; WCET <= 0.25 ms.
