Follow a trapezoidal position profile from 0 to 6.28 [rad] with max velocity 1.0 [rad/s] and acceleration 0.5 [rad/s^2]. Abort to stop if an obstruction sensor triggers. Loop at 200 Hz with WCET <= 0.8 ms.
Implement PID speed control to hold 0.50 [mps]. If the speed sensor data is stale for >100 ms, auto-disable output and raise a fault. Control at 250 Hz with WCET <= 0.6 ms.
Provide jog controls: jog+ and jog- move at ±0.20 [mps]; when neither is active, hold current angle [rad] using PID. Enforce soft limits [0.0, 3.0] [rad]. Run at 200 Hz with WCET <= 0.7 ms.

Drive a differential pair: track commanded forward velocity in [mps] and yaw rate in [rad/s], compute left/right wheel targets, and limit each to ±1.2 [mps]. Include current limiting. Loop at 200 Hz, WCET <= 1 ms.

Home a rotary stage: seek negative until the home switch, back off to 0.10 [rad], set zero, then accept absolute targets 0..5.5 [rad] with PID tracking. Timeout homing at 5 s. Rate 100 Hz; WCET <= 0.8 ms.
Add a watchdog that sets motor command to 0 if no new velocity setpoint arrives within 200 ms. Otherwise follow the setpoint with a first-order filter. Units in [mps]. Loop 100 Hz; WCET <= 0.3 ms.
Only allow position changes when a safety interlock is true; otherwise hold using PID. Targets are in [rad]. Enforce a rate limit of 0.60 [rad/s]. Rate 250 Hz with WCET <= 0.7 ms.
Create a cyclic sweep between 0.20 [rad] and 1.80 [rad] with 2 s dwell at the endpoints. Use S-curve acceleration, pause on a 'pause' input, and resume smoothly. Run at 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.9 ms.

Implement a stepper indexer that accepts a step count and feedrate in [mps], generates acceleration-limited steps, stops on a limit hit, and asserts 'in-position' when within ±0.01 [rad] equivalent. WCET <= 0.6 ms at 1 kHz update.
Build a wheel speed governor: cap speed by an operator knob (0.20..1.00 [mps]), show an overspeed warning output if measured > limit, and use PID with anti-windup. Loop at 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Implement reversible conveyor control with soft direction changes: when direction toggles, ramp to 0 [mps], wait 500 ms, then ramp to 0.40 [mps] in the opposite direction. E-stop cuts immediately. 100 Hz; WCET <= 0.5 ms.
Hold a gimbal yaw angle at a commanded [rad] using PID. Add a ±0.01 [rad] deadband to prevent hunting and limit slew to 0.70 [rad/s]. Run at 500 Hz with WCET <= 0.6 ms.
Provide a 'ready' output when |position error| < 0.02 [rad] for 200 ms. Reject and flag any move commands outside soft limits. Update at 200 Hz, WCET <= 0.4 ms.

Add a motor brake interlock: release the brake only when commanded speed > 0.02 [mps] and drive is enabled; reapply when command returns to 0. Enforce a 100 ms brake engagement delay. 100 Hz, WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Blend control modes: while moving, use velocity control; when the speed target drops below 0.05 [mps], capture the current angle [rad] and switch to position hold. Include hysteresis. 200 Hz; WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Coordinate two axes so that axis A reaches 2.0 [rad] while axis B maintains 0.60 [mps]. Start both together, and signal complete only when both are done. Abort both on any fault. 200 Hz; WCET <= 0.9 ms.
Temperature derating: linearly reduce max speed from 1.00 to 0.30 [mps] as motor temp rises from 60 to 90 C, and command 0 at 95 C. Provide a 'derated' flag. Control at 100 Hz with WCET <= 0.4 ms.

Limit the change in velocity command to 0.05 [mps] per tick to reduce jerk. Ensure measured speed stays within ±0.05 [mps] of command; otherwise raise a 'tracking error' alarm. 200 Hz; WCET <= 0.3 ms.

Control a rotary valve with 4 preset positions {0.00, 0.79, 1.57, 2.36} [rad]. Use a state machine to move, settle for 300 ms, then assert 'position_ok'. Enforce soft limits 0..2.4 [rad]. 100 Hz; WCET <= 0.6 ms.

Implement a cascaded controller: outer position PID in [rad] feeding an inner velocity PID in [mps]. Track a piecewise linear trajectory with max 0.80 [mps]. Include anti-windup and integrator freeze at output limits. 500 Hz; WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Fuse encoder-based speed with accelerometer-derived velocity using a complementary filter to estimate [mps]. Use this estimate for PID speed control. If the two sources disagree by >15% for 100 ms, fail over to encoder-only and flag a fault. 400 Hz; WCET <= 0.9 ms.

Provide dual-encoder redundancy for a joint angle [rad]. Continuously compare primary vs secondary; if |difference| > 0.05 [rad] for >50 ms, enter a fault state and engage the brake. Otherwise use the primary sensor for control. 200 Hz; WCET <= 0.6 ms.
Track a reference angle [rad] with velocity feedforward plus PID error correction. Limit jerk to 1.0 [rad/s^3], and detect any missed deadlines. Control at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.7 ms.
Move to 4.0 [rad] while enforcing a current/torque limit. If torque saturation persists for >200 ms, abort, back off by 0.10 [rad], and log a fault count. 250 Hz; WCET <= 0.6 ms.

Apply gain scheduling for PID speed control based on commanded speed: interpolate gains from higher at 0.20 [mps] to lower at 0.80 [mps]. Ensure smooth transitions and bound gains to maintain stability. 300 Hz; WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Detect wheel slip by comparing commanded vs estimated speed [mps]. If slip > 0.30 [mps], reduce commanded acceleration by 50% until slip < 0.10 [mps]. Use PID speed control with anti-windup. 200 Hz; WCET <= 0.5 ms.
Perform homing with a soft landing: approach home at 0.20 [mps] until the switch, back off, then re-approach slowly to set zero at 0.00 [rad]. Timeout at 8 s. 100 Hz; WCET <= 0.6 ms.

Use an observer to fuse encoder angle and gyro rate for a cleaner [rad] estimate (alpha-beta style). Drive the position PID with the fused estimate, tunable time constants, 500 Hz loop, WCET <= 0.9 ms.

Implement a speed envelope v_max(theta) that varies with angle: v_max = 0.50 + 0.30*cos(theta) [mps]. Never exceed this limit; if violation persists >20 ms, latch a fault requiring manual reset. 250 Hz; WCET <= 0.5 ms.

Design a multi-mode actuator controller with modes: Off, Manual Jog (±0.30 [mps]), Auto Position (targets in [rad]), and Fault. Use a formal state machine with guarded transitions, timeouts, and entry/exit actions. In Auto, use PID with jerk limiting and soft limits. An emergency stop forces Fault. Control at 500 Hz; WCET <= 0.8 ms.

Create a dual-axis system with synchronized start/stop and selectable profiles: trapezoidal, S-curve, or constant velocity. Each axis has targets in [rad] and speed limits in [mps]. Include coordinated completion and a safety supervisor that halts both if either axis has >0.05 [rad] error for 100 ms. 400 Hz; WCET <= 1.2 ms.

Specify a drive-by-wire style throttle: two redundant pedal inputs and two independent speed sensors. Fuse inputs with plausibility checks; drive a motorized plate to a commanded angle [rad] using PID. On disagreement, enter limp-home limiting output to 0.40 [mps] equivalent until power cycle. Include startup self-tests and periodic diagnostics. 1 kHz; WCET <= 0.9 ms.

Develop a motion controller with phases: Boot, Self-Test, Home, Calibrate, Operate, SafeStop. Each phase has time budgets and success criteria. Operate supports queued position setpoints [rad] with speed limits [mps] and PID tracking. Include watchdogs, deadline monitoring with WCET accounting, fault logging, and deterministic recovery to SafeStop on any exception. 500 Hz; WCET <= 0.7 ms.

Produce a comprehensive servo spec: multi-rate loops (position 250 Hz, velocity 1 kHz), cascaded PID with feedforward, soft/hard limits in [rad], speed caps in [mps], e-stop behavior, and requirements for unit tests (gain bounds, saturation, timing), integration tests (homing, tracking, faults), and runtime monitors (deadline misses, sensor staleness). WCETs: 0.6 ms at 1 kHz and 0.8 ms at 250 Hz.
When a digital 'enable' signal is high, drive a DC motor at a constant velocity of 0.5 [mps]; otherwise stop. Include a configurable max velocity limit of 1.0 [mps].
Map a rotary knob input to a servo target between -1.0 [rad] and +1.0 [rad], with a simple linear scaling and a 0.1 [rad] deadband to avoid jitter.
On rising edge of a 'start' button, move a stepper exactly 200 steps forward, then hold position; on 'reverse' button, move 200 steps backward. Ignore repeats while motion is in progress.
Implement a soft-start ramp so the motor accelerates from 0 to a commanded 0.8 [mps] over 2.0 s; decelerate to stop on a 'stop' input.
Toggle direction of a conveyor motor each time a 'toggle' button is pressed, holding speed at 0.3 [mps] and enforcing a maximum current-limit flag to stop if triggered.
Move a servo to 0.0 [rad] at startup, then to +0.5 [rad] when a proximity sensor is true, and back to -0.5 [rad] when false.
When a limit switch is pressed, immediately stop the motor; otherwise run at 0.2 [mps].
On each pulse input, increment a target position by +0.25 [rad] for a servo, capped within [-1.5, +1.5] [rad].
Hold a constant velocity of 0.6 [mps] and allow a 'slow' input to reduce to 0.2 [mps]; ensure a hard cap at 0.8 [mps].
Generate a 5 s sweep for a servo from -0.8 [rad] to +0.8 [rad] and back, looping continuously.
Implement a deadman switch: only permit motor motion at 0.4 [mps] while the 'hold' signal is true; otherwise brake to zero.
Scale an analog speed command 0-100% to a motor speed range 0.0-1.2 [mps], applying a simple clamp.
Hold a rotary actuator at a fixed angle of +0.25 [rad] with minimal motion when undisturbed.
Run a 50 Hz control loop that updates a servo setpoint from a pot, ensuring WCET <= 0.5 ms per cycle.
Spin the motor forward at 0.1 [mps] for 3 s, stop for 2 s, and repeat endlessly.

Create a simple state machine with states: Idle, Homing, Running. On power-up, Homing drives a stepper negative until the home switch triggers, backs off 0.02 [rad], then transitions to Running. In Running, accept position commands in [-1.5, +1.5] [rad]; any E-stop forces Idle.
Read two limit switches at each end of travel and enforce soft limits: block motion beyond [-2.0, +2.0] [rad], and stop if a limit switch is hit while moving outward; allow retreat direction only.

Implement a velocity profile for a conveyor: accelerate at 0.3 [mps^2] to 0.7 [mps], cruise for a commanded distance, then decelerate symmetrically. Provide a 'pause' input that holds velocity at 0 [mps] and resumes from the same point.

Drive two servos in mirrored motion: when one is commanded to +angle [rad], the other goes to -angle [rad], where angle comes from a slider in range 0 to 1.2 [rad]. Ensure both respect individual min/max limits.
Implement a periodic 100 Hz loop that reads an analog speed command and applies a rate limiter of 0.4 [mps] per second before sending to the motor; WCET must be <= 1.0 ms.
Create a jog function: while 'jog_plus' is held, increase position by 0.01 [rad] every 20 ms; while 'jog_minus' is held, decrease by the same; obey hard stops at +/-2.5 [rad].
Add a simple PI velocity hold for a motor to track a setpoint in [mps], with integral clamped to prevent windup; expose Kp and Ki as parameters safe to tune within bounds.
Sequence three positions for a rotary actuator: 0.0 [rad], +0.6 [rad], -0.6 [rad], dwelling 1.0 s at each, repeat. Provide a 'skip' button to advance immediately to the next position.
For a differential drive, limit each wheel command to +/-1.0 [mps] and reduce both equally if the combined magnitude exceeds 1.8 [mps] to stay within a power budget.
Add a watchdog that stops all motion if no new command has been received for 500 ms, and a 'resume' input to clear the fault.
Implement a clutch interlock: only allow servo movement beyond 0.1 [rad] when 'clutch_engaged' is true; otherwise hold at 0.0 [rad].
When an index pulse occurs, latch the current axle angle [rad] to a diagnostic variable and retain it until 'reset_latch' is pressed.
Create a homing routine using both a home switch and an encoder index: move at 0.1 [mps] until the switch closes, then creep until the index, set position to 0 [rad].
Implement a soft-brake function that, when 'stop' is requested, ramps velocity down at 0.5 [mps^2] rather than cutting immediately, unless E-stop which drops to 0 [mps] instantly.
Drive a stepper a specified travel distance in [rad] at 0.5 [mps], but if the motion exceeds 5 s, abort and signal a timeout.
Add thermal derating: if temperature exceeds 70 C, limit max velocity to 0.3 [mps]; if above 80 C, stop motion and require manual reset.
Implement a 200 Hz scheduler that interleaves reading sensors and updating a servo command; ensure the control update path WCET <= 0.8 ms and overall loop jitter < 0.2 ms.
Provide a 'teach' mode: press and hold 'record' while moving the joint manually; when released, store the angle [rad]. Later, pressing 'play' moves the actuator to the stored angle.
Coordinate two axes so both finish together by stretching the faster axis's profile; limit angular velocity to 1.0 [rad]/s and angular acceleration to 0.8 [rad]/s^2 per axis.
Implement backlash compensation: when reversing direction, add an extra 0.02 [rad] before engaging closed-loop hold.
Implement a PID position controller for a rotary joint with target in [rad], running at 500 Hz, with anti-windup, output saturation, and jerk-limited setpoint generation; WCET <= 0.6 ms.
Fuse a wheel encoder and a gyro to estimate linear velocity in [mps], then use that estimate in a PID velocity loop to track a setpoint; fall back to encoder-only if the gyro is invalid.

Design a cascaded controller: outer position loop in [rad] outputs an angular velocity target [rad]/s, inner velocity PID drives the motor; enforce position +/-2.5 [rad] and velocity +/-3.0 [rad]/s limits.

Plan trapezoidal velocity profiles for a linear actuator with vmax 0.9 [mps] and amax 0.7 [mps^2], synchronized to a 1 kHz control loop; stop safely if calculated stop distance exceeds remaining travel.
Create a torque limit safety layer that reduces PID output when a torque estimate indicates overload, using current and velocity to estimate, and never exceeding a safe velocity of 0.5 [mps].
Fuse motor-side and joint-side encoders to detect slippage; if mismatch exceeds 0.05 [rad] for more than 50 ms, cut drive and engage a brake, then require an operator reset.
Implement adaptive PID gains that switch between two tuned sets based on velocity magnitude: below 0.1 [mps], use higher gains; above, use lower gains, with bumpless transfer.

Add a calibration procedure: sweep a servo from -1.0 to +1.0 [rad] while recording endstop contacts; compute soft limits with 0.05 [rad] margin and store persistently; refuse motion until calibration completes.
Implement feedforward plus PID velocity control for a conveyor to reject load disturbances, with a 250 Hz loop and WCET <= 0.8 ms; include integral hold when at velocity limit.
Control two wheels to maintain a commanded straight-line speed in [mps] while keeping heading via differential correction from a gyro; degrade to speed-only if the gyro saturates.

Build a multi-mode joint controller with modes: Boot, Manual, Auto, Fault. Manual maps a joystick to velocity [rad]/s with limit 2.0 [rad]/s; Auto executes queued position targets in [rad] using a planner. Any limit switch or E-stop forces Fault. Define exact state transitions, latching behavior, and ensure a 1 kHz loop with control path WCET <= 0.7 ms.

Specify a comprehensive acceptance test for a velocity-controlled conveyor: verify clamps at +/-1.2 [mps], acceleration limit 0.6 [mps^2], timeout behavior on jam detection, and recovery procedure. Require deterministic behavior under worst-case command bursts and document WCET and measured jitter.

Design a dual-redundant sensor fusion scheme for a rotary actuator using two encoders and a gyro, with voting and plausibility checks. Define how discrepancies >0.03 [rad] are handled, how the system degrades gracefully, and how motion limits and PID control are maintained across failover.

Create a hierarchical state machine for a mobile platform drive: top-level modes Parked, Teleop, Autonomous, Emergency; within Autonomous, implement trajectory tracking at 0.5-1.2 [mps]. Include watchdogs, a deadman input, formal safety limits, logging of faults, and a test plan covering mode transitions and WCET adherence.

Develop a motion control framework for a 3-axis system that supports commissioning, calibration, and normal operation. Include synchronized profiles, per-axis limits (position in [rad] where applicable, linear in [mps]), an emergency stop strategy, parameter validation, and automated self-tests with pass/fail criteria and WCET budgets for each task.
Drive a servo to 0.75 [rad] when the 'activate' input is true; otherwise hold at 0.0 [rad]. Apply a soft limit that clamps commands within ±1.0 [rad].
Command a linear actuator to extend at 0.12 [mps] while a digital 'extend' input is high; command 0.00 [mps] when it is low.
Map a single analog knob (0..1) to a servo angle 0.0..1.5 [rad], update at 50 Hz, and clamp the target within that range.
Command a stepper-driven linear stage to move at 0.05 [mps] while 'jog' is true; command 0 [mps] when false.
Set motor velocity to a requested value (in [mps]) from a single input, limit it to ±0.3 [mps], and apply a 0.2 s ramp to avoid abrupt changes.
On rising edge of 'pulse', rotate a servo by +0.1 [rad]; on falling edge, rotate by -0.1 [rad]. Keep the cumulative angle within ±0.5 [rad].
Control a gripper servo: open to 1.2 [rad] if 'open' is true, else close to 0.2 [rad]. Update at 20 Hz.
Command a wheel to 0.0 [mps] when a proximity measurement exceeds a threshold; otherwise maintain 0.4 [mps].
Provide a deadman input: if it is not held for 200 ms, force velocity to 0 [mps]; otherwise pass through the requested [mps] velocity.
Hold a servo at 0.0 [rad] baseline, with an optional trim input in [rad] limited to ±0.05 [rad].
When 'reverse' is true, command -0.1 [mps]; when false, command +0.1 [mps].
After power-up, wait 1 s, then set a servo to 0.5 [rad]; until then hold 0.0 [rad].
Generate a triangle sweep for a servo between 0.2 [rad] and 1.0 [rad] with a period of 4 s.
Clamp an incoming position setpoint (in [rad]) to within 0.0..1.57 [rad] and forward it to the actuator.
For a conveyor, convert a 0..10 V analog input to a speed command of 0.0..0.6 [mps], saturating outside the range.
Create a two-state controller (Idle, Move) for a rotary joint. In Move, track a target position in [rad] using encoder feedback; transition to Idle when within 0.01 [rad] or after a 3 s timeout.

Implement jog controls for a linear axis: 'jog_plus' and 'jog_minus' set velocity to +0.08 [mps] or -0.08 [mps]; zero if both or neither. Enforce soft travel limits via position and stop at boundaries.
Perform homing for a stepper linear stage: move at -0.03 [mps] until a home switch triggers, then back off 0.005 [m] and set position zero. After homing, wait for a new [mps] command.
Add an emergency stop input that immediately commands 0 [mps] and disables motion; only resume when a reset is pressed and the requested velocity is 0 [mps].
Build a rate limiter that bounds acceleration to 0.5 [mps]/s and jerk to 2.0 [mps]/s^2 for any incoming velocity command in [mps].

Create a three-state servo controller (Standby, Tracking, Fault). Tracking holds a requested angle in [rad]. Enter Fault if encoder feedback is lost; in Fault, command 0.0 [rad] and latch until reset.
Implement soft start/stop for a conveyor: ramp from 0 to target [mps] in 2 s, and decelerate to 0 in 1 s when 'stop' is requested. Respect a max speed of 0.7 [mps].
Drive a pan axis that obeys virtual endstops: prevent commands outside -1.2..+1.2 [rad], and emit a warning when saturation occurs.
Use integral anti-windup for a velocity controller: when the command saturates at ±0.4 [mps], freeze the integrator. Update the control loop at 200 Hz.
Implement a deadband around zero speed: commands within ±0.01 [mps] map to 0 [mps]; exit deadband only when exceeding ±0.02 [mps].
Control a servo that moves between three presets: 0.15 [rad], 0.8 [rad], and 1.2 [rad], selected by a 2-bit input. Provide 0.3 s settle time before accepting a new selection.
Create a velocity sequencer that outputs: 0.0 [mps] for 1 s, 0.2 [mps] for 3 s, -0.1 [mps] for 2 s, then repeats.
Add a command watchdog: if no new target is received within 250 ms, force the actuator to 0 [mps] and raise a fault indication.
Implement a soft torque limit using current feedback: if overcurrent is detected, limit the speed command to 0.05 [mps] and hold that limit until cleared.
Create a state machine for a rotary valve with states Closed (0.0 [rad]), Opening, Open (1.57 [rad]), and Closing. Use a rate of 0.2 [rad]/s and stop if a limit switch is hit unexpectedly.
Blend between two velocity inputs in [mps] using a weighting input (0..1), with slew-limited transitions to avoid steps.
Provide a motion-complete signal: assert true when position error magnitude is <0.01 [rad] for at least 100 ms; deassert otherwise.
Add a teach function: when 'teach' is pressed, capture current position [rad] as the target; on 'go', move to that target. Keep angles within ±1.5 [rad].
Implement an anti-backlash routine: overshoot the target by 0.02 [rad] and settle back to the target from the same direction, completing within 0.3 s.
Schedule periodic status updates at 50 Hz while the control loop runs at 500 Hz, and ensure the control loop WCET is <= 150 microseconds.

Implement a PID velocity controller for a linear axis with setpoint in [mps] and encoder-derived velocity feedback. Run at 1 kHz with anti-windup, output saturation at ±0.6 [mps], and WCET <= 100 microseconds.

Create a PID position controller for a rotary joint with setpoint in [rad], encoder feedback in [rad], and velocity feedforward. Limit slew to 0.5 [rad]/s, clamp position within ±2.0 [rad], update at 2 kHz, and keep WCET <= 80 microseconds.
Fuse wheel encoder and IMU gyro to estimate angular velocity, then use it for a PID loop controlling a wheel to a target in [rad]/s. Enforce a limit of ±8.0 [rad]/s and cut to 0 on gyro fault.

Design a dual-loop controller for a linear slider: the outer position loop in [m] generates a velocity target; the inner PID velocity loop tracks it in [mps]. Enforce an acceleration limit of 1.0 [mps]/s and stop on e-stop.
Implement a PID with bumpless transfer between Manual and Auto modes for conveyor speed in [mps]. Manual mode directly sets the output; Auto tracks a setpoint. Freeze integral during Manual.

Perform homing with closed-loop current limiting: approach the home switch at low [mps], set zero when triggered, then transition smoothly to PID position control in [rad]. Guarantee control WCET <= 120 microseconds.
Add adaptive gain scheduling for a position PID in [rad] based on measured velocity magnitude, with three gain regions and hysteresis to prevent chattering.

Execute a trapezoidal motion profile generator that outputs velocity in [mps] given start/goal positions in [m]. Feed this to a PID velocity loop and enforce jerk limits. Run the control loop at 1 kHz with WCET <= 90 microseconds.

Integrate a safety limiter that monitors stopping distance: if the distance required to stop from the current |velocity [mps]| exceeds the remaining distance to a soft limit, automatically decelerate to 0 while maintaining stability.

Use a Kalman filter to estimate cart velocity in [mps] from encoder and accelerometer data, and drive a PID to hold a commanded [mps]. Enter Fault if innovation exceeds a threshold for more than 200 ms.

Build a multi-mode motion controller for a 2-axis system: modes Idle, Jog, Profile, Fault. Coordinate axes to follow independent position targets in [rad] with synchronized start and shared e-stop. Require loop at 1 kHz, WCET per axis <= 70 microseconds, and deterministic behavior on mode transitions.

Develop a safety-rated servo system with modes Manual, Auto, and Safe-Stop. In Auto, run a cascaded position/velocity controller using [rad] and [mps]; in Safe-Stop, achieve 0 [mps] within 300 ms while respecting jerk limits. Include comprehensive interlocks, latched faults, and recovery procedures.

Create a drive manager for four wheels that distributes velocity commands in [mps], enforces per-wheel limits, monitors feedback, and isolates a faulty wheel while maintaining the average vehicle speed. Provide built-in tests and timing checks that prove WCET < 200 microseconds total.

Specify a complete motion control state machine for a pick-and-place arm with joints in [rad]: PowerOnSelfTest, Home, Ready, ExecutePath, Pause, Recover, and Fault. Require trajectory tracking with PID, watchdogs, limit handling, and formal safety limits on speed and position. Include acceptance criteria and traceable test cases.

Design a mission-ready controller for a telescoping mast with linear [mps] velocity control and angular stabilization in [rad]. Support redundancy with dual sensors for cross-check, graceful degradation, and a verification plan including worst-case timing analysis, WCET proofs, and fault injection tests.
Set a single servo to a commanded angle in [rad], clamping between 0.0 [rad] and 1.2 [rad]. Update at 100 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms, and hold position when no command is received.
When a momentary enable switch is pressed, drive a conveyor motor at 0.30 [mps]; stop immediately when released. Apply a gentle ramp of 0.05 [mps] every 100 ms to avoid jolts.
Jog a linear actuator using two buttons: 'extend' moves at +0.02 [mps], 'retract' at -0.02 [mps]. Stop if either end-stop is active. Run logic at 50 Hz; WCET 0.5 ms.
On rising edge of a trigger input, move a rotary actuator to 0.50 [rad] and report 'in position' when within ±0.02 [rad]. If the trigger drops, hold the current angle.
Map a dial (0–100%) to a target velocity from 0.00 to 0.60 [mps]; slew limit changes to 0.10 [mps] per second and cap the maximum at 0.60 [mps].
At startup, drive a servo to a neutral angle of 0.00 [rad] and keep it there until a new target in [rad] arrives. Enforce a rate limit of 0.20 [rad/s].
Toggle a motor between stopped and 0.15 [mps] with a latching pushbutton. Debounce the input and ensure direction remains forward only.
If an overtravel input is active, force motor velocity to 0.00 [mps]; otherwise run at a constant 0.08 [mps]. Ensure updates at 20 Hz; WCET 0.5 ms.
Drive a hobby-style servo to one of two preset angles (0.0 [rad] or 1.0 [rad]) based on a selector input, switching cleanly with a 0.1 s transition.
Implement a simple watchdog: if no velocity command is received for 200 ms, set motor velocity to 0.00 [mps]. Normal operation runs at 100 Hz; WCET <= 0.8 ms.
Hold a joint at the last commanded angle in [rad] with a deadband of ±0.01 [rad] to prevent chatter. Update at 200 Hz.
Provide a soft stop: when a stop button is pressed, decelerate the actuator to 0.00 [mps] over 1.0 s, then hold.
Limit incoming angle commands to the safe range [−0.5, +0.5] [rad] and ignore any rate of change exceeding 0.5 [rad/s].
Implement a two-state sequence: IDLE and MOVE. In MOVE, go to 0.75 [rad]; return to IDLE after reaching ±0.02 [rad]. Cycle at 100 Hz; WCET 1 ms.
Drive a stepper axis at 0.01 [mps] when a 'maintenance' mode is active; otherwise keep it stopped. Ensure immediate stop on emergency input.

Create a state machine for homing a rotary axis: rotate at -0.20 [rad/s] until the home sensor trips, zero the angle [rad], then move to a commanded position in [rad]. Enforce soft limits [−1.0, +1.0] [rad].
Accept linear velocity in [mps] and direction input; drive a motor accordingly with acceleration limited to 0.3 [mps/s]. Stop on emergency input and latch the fault until reset.
Drive a servo along a repeating pattern: 0.2 [rad] hold 1 s, 0.6 [rad] hold 1 s, then back to 0.2 [rad]. Ensure smooth transitions with a max rate of 0.4 [rad/s].
Implement a two-axis coordination: keep the difference between Joint A and Joint B within ±0.05 [rad] by adjusting Joint B's target; pause both if the error exceeds 0.10 [rad].
Filter target velocity commands in [mps] with a first-order slew limiter so consecutive steps are no larger than 0.05 [mps] every 50 ms. Run at 100 Hz; WCET 1 ms.
Stepwise move a rotary joint through a sequence of angles [rad] provided as a list, waiting for 'in position' at ±0.02 [rad] before advancing. Abort on stop input.
Implement overspeed protection: if measured velocity exceeds 0.8 [mps], force a stop and raise a latched alarm requiring operator reset.
Create a 'park'/'operate' mode selector for a joint: park goes to 0.0 [rad], operate allows any command within [−0.7, +0.7] [rad]. Transition only when angular speed is below 0.01 [rad/s].
Drive a conveyor with two photocell inputs: run forward at 0.25 [mps] when clear, slow to 0.10 [mps] when the downstream sensor is blocked, stop if either emergency input is active.
Implement a phase-locked rotation: rotate Joint B to track Joint A plus an offset of 0.15 [rad]; limit the tracking rate to 0.5 [rad/s] and stop if the offset exceeds ±0.30 [rad].
Add a watchdog to a velocity-controlled motor: require fresh [mps] commands at least every 100 ms; otherwise ramp down to 0.00 [mps] over 0.5 s.
Create a timed move: move from current angle to 0.9 [rad] over exactly 3.0 s, capping the peak rate at 0.6 [rad/s]. Signal done on completion.
Implement direction control: run at +0.12 [mps] when a selector is forward, -0.12 [mps] when reverse, but ignore reverse if a safety interlock is active.
Add debounced start/stop controls to a stepper-driven axis moving at 0.02 [mps], with status outputs for RUN and STOPPED. Enforce immediate stop if limit switch is hit.
Create a finite state machine for 'HOMING', 'READY', 'MOVING', 'FAULT'. In MOVING, go to target angle in [rad] respecting soft limits. Any sensor fault triggers FAULT and stops motion.
Track a setpoint velocity in [mps] using feedforward plus simple proportional error correction; cap the output to enforce a maximum of 0.6 [mps]. Run at 250 Hz; WCET 0.8 ms.
Implement dwell-on-position: after reaching the target within ±0.01 [rad], hold for 2.0 s before accepting the next target. Timeout after 5.0 s if not reached.
Generate step-free angle commands by applying a trapezoidal rate limiter to incoming targets in [rad] with max rate 0.3 [rad/s] and acceleration 1.0 [rad/s^2].
Coordinate two conveyor segments: Segment 1 runs at 0.20 [mps]; Segment 2 mirrors Segment 1 unless its sensor is blocked, in which case Segment 2 drops to 0.05 [mps].
Build a motion interlock: forbid moves beyond +0.9 [rad] unless a guard input is active; if the guard drops, smoothly return to 0.5 [rad] at 0.2 [rad/s].
Design a PID position controller for a rotary joint with commands in [rad]. Include anti-windup, output saturation, and a maximum rate limit of 0.8 [rad/s]. Run at 1 kHz with WCET <= 0.9 ms.
Implement a PID velocity controller for a conveyor with setpoint in [mps] and encoder feedback. Add integrator clamping, a 0.5 s ramp to setpoint, and a hard stop on overspeed.
Fuse encoder angle [rad] and gyroscope rate [rad/s] with a complementary filter to estimate angle; use it in a PID position loop holding within ±0.01 [rad]. Control at 500 Hz; WCET 1 ms.
Create a synchronized dual-motor controller that keeps two shafts aligned within ±0.03 [rad] using a PID on phase error. If error exceeds 0.2 [rad] for 100 ms, stop both and raise fault.
Plan and execute a trapezoidal velocity profile to move from current to target angle in [rad] under max velocity 0.7 [rad/s] and acceleration 1.5 [rad/s^2], feeding a PID position loop.
Implement a speed governor that limits any commanded velocity to 0.50 [mps] while preserving smoothness via a PID velocity loop. Include a safety timeout to zero after 300 ms without commands.

Design an inner velocity loop in [rad/s] and an outer position loop in [rad] for a joint (cascade control). Specify loop rates (inner 2 kHz, outer 500 Hz), WCET budgets (0.6 ms total), and anti-windup.
Add fault-tolerant sensing: if the primary encoder angle in [rad] disagrees with a secondary sensor by >0.05 [rad], switch to degraded mode, reduce max angular rate to 0.2 [rad/s], and notify.
Implement position control with gravity compensation: add a feedforward term based on target angle [rad] while a PID loop handles error. Enforce output saturation and WCET <= 0.8 ms at 1 kHz.
Develop a jerk-limited S-curve motion generator for joint moves in [rad], providing targets to a PID position loop. Respect soft limits and stop cleanly if an interlock opens.

Specify a multi-mode motion controller (MANUAL, AUTO, SAFE-STOP) for a mobile drive: MANUAL tracks operator velocity in [mps]; AUTO follows a scripted profile; any fault enters SAFE-STOP with controlled decel to 0.00 [mps]. Define deadlines (control 200 Hz, WCET 1 ms) and mode transition rules.

Create a comprehensive homing-and-operation system for a rotary axis with modes: POWER-UP, HOMING, CALIBRATED, RUN, FAULT. Include WCET monitoring, soft/hard limits in [rad], and acceptance tests for each mode.

Design a dual-axis coordinated controller that can execute waypoints for two joints in [rad] with synchronous timing, pause/resume, and per-axis PID. Include safety monitors for overspeed, limit violations, and missed deadlines.

Implement redundant sensing with sensor fusion (Kalman or complementary) combining two encoders to estimate angle in [rad]; require consistency checks, degraded-mode operation, and test cases verifying bounds under simulated dropouts.

Define a deterministic schedule for cascaded position/velocity control (inner 2 kHz, outer 500 Hz) across three actuators, with per-task WCET budgets, deadline overrun handling, and a formal test plan for worst-case transitions and safe shutdown.

When a momentary switch is pressed, drive a single motor at a constant linear rim speed of 0.25 [mps]; when released, command zero. Clamp the speed so it never exceeds 0.30 [mps]. Run the control loop at 100 Hz and ensure WCET ≤ 0.5 ms.
Map a 0–100% knob to a servo angle from 0.00 [rad] to 2.00 [rad]. Saturate at the limits and update at 50 Hz. WCET ≤ 0.3 ms.
Each time a button is pressed (with 50 ms debounce), toggle a servo between 0.00 [rad] and 1.57 [rad]. Never command outside [0.00, 2.40] [rad].
Command a stepper-driven axis to advance at a steady feed of 0.01 [mps] while a Run input is true; command zero when false. Enforce a max of 0.02 [mps].
Provide a simple velocity ramp: accelerate from 0 to 0.50 [mps] in 2.0 s when Start goes high; decelerate to 0 in 1.0 s when it goes low. Limit to ≤ 0.60 [mps].
If an emergency stop input is active, immediately set actuator output to zero and latch it until a Reset input is received.
Pass through position commands to a servo but clamp them to [0.00, 2.40] [rad] and raise a flag whenever clamping occurs.
Hold a wheel at an angular position of 0.00 [rad] by default; when Jog+ or Jog− buttons are held, move in ±0.10 [rad] steps at most 5 steps per second.
Implement a simple overspeed brake: if measured linear speed exceeds 1.00 [mps], assert brake; if it falls below 0.80 [mps], release. Add hysteresis to avoid chatter.
Generate a 10 Hz heartbeat and run the motor control at 100 Hz. Guarantee the control loop WCET is ≤ 0.4 ms.
On each rising edge of a command pulse, toggle motor direction while holding magnitude at 0.20 [mps]. Stop automatically after 60 s of continuous operation.
Translate a foot pedal input to conveyor velocity from 0.00 to 1.00 [mps], with a 5% deadband. Slew-limit the change to 0.20 [mps] per second.
Hold a servo at a configurable target angle in [rad]; allow updates at runtime but reject any single-step change larger than 0.50 [rad].
When the forward limit switch is closed, block positive motion commands; when the reverse limit switch is closed, block negative motion commands. Otherwise pass commands through unchanged.
When a Start button is pressed, run a motor at 0.30 [mps] for 5.0 s; ignore further presses during the run. Stop early if an overcurrent flag is raised.

Implement a two-state controller (Idle, Run) for a conveyor. In Run, track a velocity setpoint in [mps]; in Idle, command zero. Transition to Idle if a guard door opens or an E-stop is active. Update at 200 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.8 ms.

Perform a homing routine for a rotary axis using a home switch: search negative below 0.20 [mps], detect the switch, back off 0.05 [rad], re-approach slowly, then set position to 0.00 [rad]. After homing, accept absolute moves.
Create a trapezoidal profile generator for an angular move of N [rad], enforcing max angular speed 1.0 [rad/s] and accel 2.0 [rad/s^2]. Output per-cycle position commands.

Use an incremental encoder to measure wheel motion and compute linear speed in [mps] from a configured wheel radius. Apply a short moving average to reduce noise. Stop the motor if measured speed exceeds 1.2× the command.

Provide a jog mode with two buttons (left/right). Hold-to-move with speed ramp up/down, and enforce soft limits at 0.00 [rad] and 5.00 [rad]. Fault if the position exceeds a limit by more than 0.01 [rad].

Design a small state machine: Idle, Arming, Moving, Holding, Fault. On command, move a servo to a target in [rad]; verify arrival within ±0.02 [rad] and hold. Timeout to Fault if not reached in 3.0 s.
Implement runtime-configurable acceleration and velocity limits for a motor tracking a velocity setpoint in [mps]. Reject setpoints that would violate limits and log the rejection.
Add a watchdog for streaming velocity commands: if no update arrives within 150 ms, ramp down to 0.00 [mps] over 0.5 s and enter Safe state until reset.
Drive a pair of motors as a synchronized axis: maintain equal positions; if one lags by more than 0.05 [rad], slow the other until re-aligned. Enforce a maximum speed of 0.40 [mps].
Apply over-temperature derating: if motor temperature exceeds 70 C, limit commanded speed to 0.20 [mps]; above 85 C, stop and latch a Fault until cooled below 60 C.
Provide a calibration mode that sweeps a servo from 0.00 [rad] to 2.40 [rad] in 0.10 [rad] steps, pausing 200 ms at each step. Abort immediately if a fault input becomes active.
Implement direction-sensitive soft limits: allow a small overshoot up to 0.01 [rad] when moving out of a limit, but none when moving into a limit. Reject commands that would violate this rule.
Create a manual/auto selector. In Manual, map a dial to velocity in [mps]. In Auto, follow a scheduled profile of setpoints. Switching between modes must blend over 500 ms to avoid jerk.
Measure incoming command latency and publish it. If latency exceeds 100 ms, reduce the speed limit to 50% until latency recovers below 50 ms.
Implement a reversing conveyor: after accumulating 10.00 [rad] of roller rotation, reverse to the start at the same speed in [mps]. Repeat until a Stop request.
Add an interlock so the motor only runs when both a safety gate is closed and a Run request is active; otherwise command zero and assert an interlock status.
Publish periodic status at 20 Hz reporting current angle [rad], speed [mps], and controller state. Run the control loop at 200 Hz with WCET ≤ 0.7 ms.
Provide bump-less transfer from open-loop to closed-loop hold: when switching to hold mode, capture the current angle [rad] as the target to avoid any position step.
Accept a queue of target angles in [rad] with individual dwell times; execute them in order. Support pause, resume, and abort commands.
Coordinate a clutch/brake output with motor motion: disengage brake before ramp-up begins; engage when speed falls below 0.05 [mps] and desired motion is zero.

Implement closed-loop PID velocity control for a wheel to track a setpoint in [mps], with saturation, anti-windup, and output slew limiting. Handle step changes without overshoot beyond 10%. Run at 1 kHz with WCET ≤ 0.6 ms.
Use cascaded control: an outer PID holds position in [rad] while an inner PID tracks angular rate. Ensure inner-loop saturation propagates to prevent integral windup and respect travel limits.

Fuse encoder and gyroscope data to estimate angular rate for control. Use the fused estimate to regulate rate to a setpoint with a PID. If encoder and gyro disagree by more than a threshold for 200 ms, enter Fault and stop motion.
Plan and execute a jerk-limited S-curve angular move of 1.20 [rad], respecting max speed and acceleration constraints, and feed a velocity controller. Guarantee the planner’s WCET ≤ 0.8 ms.
Add redundant endstop verification using two switches and the encoder. If an endstop is reported but the encoder differs by >0.02 [rad], perform a safe stop and latch a diagnostic code.
Implement thermal protection with model-based derating: estimate winding temperature from power and ambient, limit maximum velocity [mps] as temperature approaches 90 C, and hard stop at 100 C.
Detect mechanical slip by comparing integrated motor angle [rad] and measured carriage speed in [mps]. If slip exceeds an equivalent 0.03 [rad] over 500 ms, halt and report the condition.
Add adaptive feedforward friction compensation to a PID velocity loop. Identify static and Coulomb friction online and cap the compensation to 20% of full-scale output.
Coordinate two joints so that their moves complete simultaneously despite different limits. Compute per-axis profiles and synchronize start/finish; abort both if either axis faults.
Provide a compliant hold mode: regulate to a target angle in [rad] with low stiffness so the actuator can be back-driven slightly. Bound allowable deviation and rate-limit torque-producing commands.

Design a multi-mode motion controller with modes: Boot, Self-Test, Manual, Auto, and Fault. Define the state machine, safety interlocks, latching faults, and recovery paths. Specify loop rates (1 kHz control, 50 Hz supervision) and WCET budgets (control ≤ 0.6 ms, supervision ≤ 1.0 ms). Include acceptance criteria for each mode.

Implement dual-redundant velocity control for a critical actuator: two independent PID channels vote on the command. If their estimates differ by >10%, enter Degraded mode with reduced speed [mps]; if >20%, transition to Safe Stop. Define monitoring, diagnostics, and test procedures.

Create a comprehensive joint controller with modes Position [rad], Velocity [mps], and Teach-and-Repeat. Include homing, soft/hard limits, E-stop, manual override, and watchdogs. Provide formal safety requirements, timing constraints, and traceable test cases.

Develop an end-to-end trajectory executor handling queued waypoints in [rad], onboard S-curve planning, per-axis PID control, and a supervisor that enforces power, temperature, and speed limits. Include detailed fault handling, recovery steps, and WCET guarantees for the planner and control loops.

Specify a verification plan and built-in self-test for the motion stack: startup sensor/actuator checks, encoder plausibility, limit-switch tests, and loopback of command paths. Define measurable pass/fail criteria, maximum test duration, and how to fail-safe if any step exceeds WCET or violates safety limits.
On a rising edge of an enable input, drive a single DC motor at a constant linear velocity of 0.30 [mps]; when the input is low, command zero velocity. Do not exceed 0.40 [mps] under any condition.
Move a rotary servo to 1.00 [rad] when a command flag is true and to 0.00 [rad] when false. Clamp motion within 0.00..1.20 [rad] to avoid mechanical overtravel.
Rotate a stepper actuator to exactly 1.57 [rad] from zero on start, then hold position. If a stop button is pressed, return to 0.00 [rad] and hold.
Homing routine: creep in the negative direction until a limit switch is active, set the current position to 0.00 [rad], then stop.
Please ramp the conveyor from 0.00 to 0.50 [mps] over 2.0 s when started, and ramp back to 0.00 [mps] over 2.0 s when stopped.
Simple task: sweep a servo continuously between 0.30 [rad] and 1.20 [rad], dwelling 0.5 s at each end.
When a start signal is received, move the joint forward by 0.25 [rad] relative to the current position, then stop.
Enforce a maximum speed limit: never allow commanded velocity to exceed 0.60 [mps]; if an emergency stop input is active, immediately command 0.00 [mps].
Apply a small deadband around zero so that commanded velocities within ±0.02 [mps] result in 0.00 [mps] to prevent jitter.
Each time a pushbutton is pressed, toggle the motor direction and run at 0.20 [mps] until the next press.
Use a single incremental encoder to move to and hold 2.00 [rad] from home; stop the motor when within ±0.01 [rad] of the target.
Run at 0.40 [mps] for 3.0 s after a start pulse, then command 0.00 [mps] and stay idle.
Select between two preset angles using a 2-bit command: position A at 0.50 [rad] and position B at 1.00 [rad]; ignore other codes.
Map a normalized input 0.0..1.0 to a motor speed of 0.00..0.80 [mps] with linear scaling.
Only allow motion when a guard_closed signal is true; otherwise hold current position and reject any new move commands.

Position control with PID: track a target angle in [rad] with configurable gains, limit output rate to ensure smooth motion, and enforce soft limits at 0.00 and 2.50 [rad]. Run the loop at 200 Hz and keep WCET under 2 ms.

Implement a state machine with states Idle, Homing, Running, and Fault for a linear actuator. Use two limit switches for homing, cap velocity at 0.60 [mps], and transition to Fault if a limit is hit unexpectedly.
Synchronize two wheel motors so their linear velocities match within ±0.05 [mps]. If the mismatch persists for more than 0.5 s, reduce both speeds to 0.10 [mps] and signal a warning.
Execute a repeating step sequence on a rotary stage: move +0.50 [rad], then -0.25 [rad], hold for 1.0 s, and repeat. Respect a maximum change of 1.00 [rad] per second.

Create a three-state servo controller: Open at 0.00 [rad], Close at 1.00 [rad], and Hold current angle. Drive transitions from discrete commands and enter Fault if position error exceeds 0.10 [rad] for more than 0.5 s.
Track a time-stamped velocity profile sampled at 50 Hz with targets in [mps]. Limit acceleration to 0.30 [mps] per second and reject profiles that exceed 0.80 [mps].
Calibrate zero by moving slowly until a home switch is detected, set position to 0.00 [rad], then move to 0.40 [rad] and hold within ±0.02 [rad].
Add an integral clamp to the velocity PID controller to avoid windup when the actuator saturates at 0.70 [mps].
When commanded velocity changes sign, decelerate at no more than 0.20 [mps] per second to zero before accelerating in the opposite direction.
Deadman timer: if no heartbeat message is received for 200 ms, ramp the motor down to 0.00 [mps] within 0.5 s.
Hold an axis within a position window of ±0.02 [rad] around the target; if drift exceeds the window, correct with a proportional kick then resume normal holding.
Filter measured linear velocity with a median filter over the last 5 samples before applying PID, to reduce impulsive noise.
Reduce conveyor speed from 0.40 [mps] to 0.10 [mps] while a part_present sensor is active, then smoothly return to 0.40 [mps] once it clears.
Perform on-the-fly setpoint updates by interpolating from the current setpoint to the new target over 0.30 s to prevent abrupt jumps.
Limit the effective angular movement rate so that commanded angle does not change by more than 3.14 [rad] per second, regardless of incoming setpoint steps.
Compare two independent encoder readings of the same joint; if their inferred positions differ by more than 0.05 [rad] for longer than 100 ms, stop motion and raise a fault.
Add simple friction compensation: when moving at low speed (<0.05 [mps]), apply a small feedforward offset to overcome stiction, but never exceed 0.60 [mps].
Implement a retract-then-advance routine upon a jam signal: back off by 0.10 [rad], wait 0.2 s, then advance again at half speed 0.20 [mps].
Record and report the execution time of each 100 Hz control cycle; assert it remains below a WCET of 3 ms and transition to Safe Idle if exceeded.
Add a smooth start feature: when enabling motion, apply a cosine ramp to reach 0.50 [mps] in 1.0 s; when disabling, mirror the ramp down to 0.00 [mps].

Implement a cascaded controller: outer loop holds position in [rad], inner loop regulates linear velocity in [mps]. Include PID in both loops with anti-windup, output saturation, and rate limiting. Run at 500 Hz with WCET under 1.5 ms.

Fuse an encoder with a gyro to estimate angular position in [rad] for a gimbal axis using a complementary filter. Use the fused estimate for control, and enter a degraded mode if encoder and gyro disagree by >0.10 [rad] for >0.3 s.
Generate and follow a jerk-limited S-curve profile for a 1.20 [rad] move. Cap the change rate at 2.0 [rad] per second and ensure zero overshoot at the target.
Detect stalls: if measured linear velocity stays below 0.05 [mps] for more than 0.30 s while the target exceeds 0.20 [mps], enter a fault state, ramp down safely, and require manual reset.

Coordinate two rotary joints to arrive at their targets simultaneously. Compute synchronized profiles so both complete their respective moves (e.g., 0.80 [rad] and 1.20 [rad]) at the same time while respecting per-joint limits.
Implement online PID gain scheduling for a velocity controller in [mps] based on current speed bands (low/medium/high). Ensure transitions are bumpless and keep WCET below 2 ms at 250 Hz.
Use a state observer to estimate linear velocity in [mps] from quantized position updates; feed the estimate into a velocity PID and bound the estimation error to avoid control chatter.
Apply soft and hard limits: soft stop within 0.05 [rad] of the limit using a deceleration ramp; if the hard limit is ever reached, cut command immediately and latch a fault requiring restart.
Implement dynamic braking on stop requests by commanding an opposite velocity limited to 0.30 [mps] until measured speed drops below 0.02 [mps], then hold.
Schedule the control task and logging so that the 1 kHz velocity loop stays under a WCET of 0.8 ms even under worst-case branching; drop nonessential work if the budget is at risk.

Design a multi-mode motion system with Manual, Automatic, and Safe Idle modes for a joint controlled in [rad] and a conveyor in [mps]. Define mode-specific limits, transitions, and interlocks, with a top-level state machine and run-time WCET checks.

Create a coordinated two-axis actuator controller with Cross-Coupled Control to keep differential error below 0.03 [rad] while following time-synchronized trajectories. Include a comprehensive test plan with step, ramp, and disturbance cases.

Provide a full commissioning workflow: Homing, PID Tuning (for both position in [rad] and velocity in [mps]), and Production. Include live parameter update capability, bounds checking, and acceptance criteria such as settling within 0.05 [rad] and 0.05 [mps].

Implement a fault-tolerant motion supervisor with redundant feedback sources for a single joint. Use voting to select the best position estimate in [rad], degrade gracefully on sensor loss, and include built-in tests and WCET assertions at 500 Hz.

Specify an end-to-end requirement-driven controller: plan jerk-limited moves, run cascaded PID loops, enforce safety limits, and provide traceable metrics (overshoot < 0.02 [rad], steady-state velocity error < 0.03 [mps], loop WCET < 1.0 ms). Include a checklist of runtime self-tests.

Create a porch light controller that turns the relay on when the wall switch is pressed and automatically turns it off after 15 minutes. Use a simple two-state machine (OFF/ON) with an enum for states, and include a watchdog that forces the relay OFF if the timer ever overruns or the task stalls.
Make a momentary button trigger a relay for exactly 30 seconds, ignoring any retriggers while timing. Model it as a small state machine with IDLE and TIMING states and provide a 50 ms debounce.
Schedule a single relay to turn ON every day at 06:30 and OFF at 22:15. Ensure the schedule handles midnight boundaries and that the relay defaults to OFF if the clock becomes invalid.
Turn on a hallway light when motion is detected and keep it on for 90 seconds after the last motion. If new motion occurs, extend the timer. Keep the logic simple and reliable.
Control outdoor lights using a light sensor: turn ON when ambient drops below 50 lux and turn OFF when it rises above 150 lux. Include hysteresis and a 2-second stability check to avoid chattering.

Add a latching overtemperature cutoff: if the temperature exceeds 65 °C, open the relay and require a manual reset button to restore power. Safety requirement: default to OFF on startup and any fault.
Implement a simple humidity controller for a dehumidifier: turn the relay ON when humidity > 60% RH and OFF when humidity < 50% RH. Use an enum for ON/OFF states and blink an LED while ON.
Run an exhaust fan for 15 minutes at the top of every hour, then turn it off. Provide a schedule that repeats daily and ensure the fan is OFF on power-up until the next window.
Create a doorbell control where a button press energizes a chime relay for exactly 1.0 second. Debounce the button by 50 ms and ignore additional presses while the chime is active.
Make a staircase timer: toggling a wall switch turns the light ON, and it automatically turns OFF after 2 minutes if not toggled again. Keep the logic simple and robust.
On power-up, delay 5 seconds before energizing a relay, unless a cancel button is held. After the relay turns on, it stays latched until power is removed or the button is pressed to turn it off.
Add a system watchdog that must be serviced at least every 200 ms. If the watchdog expires, force all controlled relays to their safe state (OFF) and indicate a fault with a steady LED.
Control a garage light so that a pushbutton toggles the light, but if no motion is detected for 10 minutes, the light turns off automatically. Motion should only reset the timer when the light is ON.
When a water leak sensor trips, immediately close the shutoff valve via a relay and latch this state until a manual reset. Safety: default to valve CLOSED on any error or watchdog timeout.
Make a bedside lamp controller where a short touch toggles the light and a long touch (>1.5 s) always turns it OFF. Provide a slow 1 Hz LED heartbeat when the lamp is ON.

Build a multi-mode fan controller with enum modes OFF, MANUAL, and AUTO. In AUTO, turn the fan ON above 27 °C and OFF below 25 °C. In MANUAL, a button toggles the fan. Use a state machine for mode transitions and a 200 ms watchdog.

Create a smart outlet scheduler that supports up to four daily ON/OFF windows with priority if they overlap. Use a state machine to evaluate the schedule and ensure the outlet turns OFF if the real-time clock is invalid.

Combine motion and ambient light: only turn room lights ON when motion is detected and ambient < 100 lux. Keep lights ON for 5 minutes after last motion. Add a QUIET mode (21:00–07:00) where clicks are minimized; model modes with an enum.
Control a heater with minimum ON (60 s) and minimum OFF (180 s) times to prevent short cycling. Use temperature with 0.5 °C hysteresis and a state machine to enforce timing constraints.

Design an alarm relay driven by window/door sensors: allow a 30 s exit delay after arming, then trigger ALARM if any sensor opens. Enum states: DISARMED, EXIT_DELAY, ARMED, ALARM. Run at 50 Hz with WCET 3 ms and reset to DISARMED on watchdog expiry.

Control a hot-water recirculation pump: run on demand via a button or during schedules (06:00–08:00, 17:00–21:00). Stop early if return temperature reaches 45 °C. Enforce a minimum 5-minute rest between runs using a state machine.
Create an irrigation zone timer where a selector chooses durations of 10, 20, or 30 minutes (enum). Cancel if a rain sensor is wet or soil moisture > 35% VWC. Default valve OFF on watchdog timeout.

If a washing machine vibration sensor indicates activity for > 2 minutes, turn ON a dehumidifier outlet for 30 minutes. Provide a manual override switch and use a state machine to prevent rapid toggling.

Ventilate a garage based on CO concentration: turn ON low-speed relay when CO > 30 ppm, high-speed when > 70 ppm, and OFF when < 20 ppm. Alarm if > 150 ppm. Include a watchdog and interlock the relays so both cannot be ON.

Bathroom fan logic: when the light turns OFF, keep the fan running for 7 minutes. If humidity remains > 60% RH after that, extend up to a 20-minute maximum. Use a state machine to manage post-run and limits.

Implement a child-safe outlet that requires a double-tap within 1 second to enable power for 15 minutes. A single tap disables immediately. LED blinks faster as time expires. Fail-safe to OFF on watchdog.

Control window blinds with two interlocked relays (UP/DOWN). Button taps should trigger OPEN/STOP/CLOSE behavior, stopping at limit switches. Add a 120 s watchdog fallback that forces both relays OFF if any state sticks.

Schedule a pool pump: weekdays 09:00–11:00 and 15:00–17:00; weekends 10:00–14:00. Skip runs if ambient temperature < 5 °C. Provide a manual override that auto-expires after 1 hour. Resolve overlapping windows deterministically.

Use two PIR sensors for more reliable hallway lighting: require both to trigger within 3 seconds before turning lights ON for 2 minutes. If only one triggers, ignore. Include a watchdog to force OFF on fault.

Create a brownout-safe smart relay: if supply voltage falls below 10.5 V, turn the relay OFF and enter RECOVERING. Only return to NORMAL after 60 seconds above 11.0 V. Enum states: SAFE, RECOVERING, NORMAL. Blink LED codes per state.

Control a pet feeder motor via a relay: dispense for 3 seconds at scheduled times and prevent re-dispensing within 10 minutes. If a lid-open sensor is active, cancel dispensing. If three jams are detected, disable until manual reset.
Greenhouse misting: turn valve ON when temperature > 30 °C and humidity < 40% RH. Never allow ON longer than 2 minutes without a 1-minute rest. Use a state machine and a watchdog to enforce safety.
Holiday lights scheduler with weekday and weekend patterns. Inhibit operation after 23:30 if ambient noise exceeds 50 dBA. Add enum modes HOME and AWAY, where AWAY disables all lights.
Towel warmer control: manual ON with a button and auto-OFF after 45 minutes. Prevent restart until the bar temperature falls below 40 °C. Default OFF on faults and watchdog expiration.
Gate lighting: when the gate opens after sunset (ambient < 80 lux), turn lights ON and keep them ON for 5 minutes after closing. Re-triggers can extend the timer but cap total ON time at 10 minutes.

Implement a thermostat using relay time-proportioning with a PID loop (20 s window) to maintain 22.0 °C. Enforce minimum relay ON/OFF of 5 s, safety cutoff at 70 °C with latch, and enum states OFF, HEAT, FAULT. Run at 5 Hz with WCET 1 ms and a 200 ms watchdog.

Control hot-water recirculation using two temperature sensors (supply and return): when delta > 5 °C and the schedule is active, run the pump; stop at delta < 1 °C or return reaching 45 °C. Fail-safe OFF if any sensor is missing. Watchdog recovers to SAFE within 300 ms.

Ventilation control with CO2 PID: maintain 800 ppm using low/high fan relays via duty cycling. If CO2 > 3000 ppm, force HIGH and raise ALARM. Enum modes MANUAL, AUTO, ALARM. Sample at 2 Hz with WCET 2 ms and include a watchdog.

Smart irrigation with sensor fusion: use soil moisture (%VWC), rain gauge pulses (mm), and a forecast inhibit input to decide watering. Track daily flow (L) via a pulse meter and cap at 10 L/day. State machine states SAFE, IDLE, WATERING, FAULT. Kill valve if no flow pulses for 10 s while ON.

Freezer defrost controller: use air and evaporator coil sensors to maintain -10 °C coil temperature with PID time windows for a defrost heater relay. Cut power if air > -5 °C for 10 minutes. Loop at 1 Hz, WCET 3 ms, with a 250 ms watchdog.

Multi-zone floor heating: control three zone relays with per-zone schedules and PID time-proportioning based on room temperature. Limit to at most two relays ON simultaneously. Enum modes NIGHT, DAY, VACATION. Safety: floor sensor must stay < 45 °C. Run at 2 Hz, WCET 4 ms, with watchdog.

Sump pump controller with sensor fusion: use a float switch, ultrasonic level (cm), and current sensing. Start when level > 30 cm or float closed; stop at 10 cm or on dry-run current < 0.2 A. Wait 5 s for backflow before rechecking. Alarm on run > 5 minutes. Include a watchdog.

Air purifier control: PID to maintain PM2.5 at 12 µg/m³ using two relays (LOW/HIGH) via duty cycling. Enum modes AUTO, SLEEP, BOOST; in SLEEP limit switches to ≤ 6 per hour. WCET 2 ms at 2 Hz. Watchdog forces LOW->OFF safely on timeout.

Radiant antifrost: if outdoor temp < 2 °C, maintain loop at 10 °C using a PID windowed boiler relay (60 s window). Safety trip at 60 °C. State machine NORMAL, ANTIFROST, FAULT with heartbeat watchdog and safe OFF on fault.

Legionella prevention: weekly at 02:00, raise tank to 65 °C for 30 minutes using PID time-proportioning. Lock out space heating relay during the cycle. Use dual-sensor voting and abort if sensors disagree by > 2 °C. Run at 1 Hz, WCET 5 ms, with watchdog.

Design a whole-home mode manager with enum modes HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, VACATION that orchestrates lights, outlets, and fans via schedules and presence inputs. Use a hierarchical state machine, manual overrides that auto-expire after 1 hour, a global safe state on watchdog expiry, a 10 Hz loop with WCET 2 ms, and provide a test plan for transitions, override conflicts, and recovery.

Build a smart switch framework with plug-in automation rules. Define enum rule types (TIMER, SCHEDULE, SENSOR_GUARD, LATCH) and run a state machine per channel. Include a system watchdog, rule-level timeouts, and persistence of last safe state. Require tests for ±100 ms timing accuracy over 24 h, arbitration under simultaneous triggers, and safe shutdown on clock skew.

Implement a safety-critical garage controller with modes IDLE, ENTER, EXIT, LOCKDOWN. Coordinate relays for motor (open/close), light, and vent. Enforce interlocks and edge sensors, monitor CO, and handle faults. Include a 250 ms watchdog, 20 Hz control loop with WCET 3 ms, and a comprehensive fault test matrix.

Create a multi-room lighting scheduler managing 8 circuits with priority rules, quiet hours, and occupancy prediction from PIR + door + lux sensors. Use enum scenes RELAX, WORK, NIGHT, CLEAN and a HOME/AWAY mode manager. Include a watchdog, deterministic state machine updates at 10 Hz (WCET 1.5 ms), and simulation tests for conflict resolution.

Specify a hot-water circulation and bathroom anti-fog system with modes OFF, AUTO, SHOWER, BOOST. Fuse humidity (%RH), mirror temperature (°C), and door state to drive pump and fan relays. Include schedule windows, post-run timers, anti-short-cycle limits, a default OFF on watchdog timeout, and a verification plan with timing, hysteresis, and sensor-fault injection tests.

Create a simple on/off light controller: a single button toggles a relay. Debounce the button (50 ms). Default the relay to OFF on power-up. Add a watchdog timer that forces the relay OFF if the control loop does not tick within 1 second.
Turn a lamp relay ON while a button is held and OFF when released. Include 50 ms debounce and mirror the relay state on a status LED. Fail-safe to OFF if any error is detected.

Implement a staircase timer: pressing a button turns a light relay ON for 120 seconds, then automatically OFF. Retriggering extends the timer. Include a heartbeat watchdog that reverts to OFF if the timer logic stalls.
Toggle a smart outlet relay only when the button is held at least 300 ms. Short taps are ignored. A 3-second long-press forces the outlet OFF regardless of current state.

Schedule a porch light to turn ON at 18:00 and OFF at 23:30 daily. Allow a manual override button that holds the current state until the next scheduled event. Add a watchdog that requires the scheduler to signal alive at least once per minute.
Create a bang-bang thermostat for a heater relay: turn ON below 20.0 C and turn OFF above 22.0 C with hysteresis. Indicate heating status via LED. On temperature sensor fault, force the relay OFF.
Control a bathroom fan by humidity: turn ON above 60% RH, turn OFF below 55% RH. Enforce a minimum ON time of 120 seconds to avoid short cycling. All durations in seconds.
Implement a nightlight rule: if ambient light stays below a threshold for 10 seconds, turn the relay ON; if above for 10 seconds, turn it OFF. Include hysteresis to prevent chatter.
Provide two-way control for a single relay with two inputs acting as toggles. Ensure rapid toggling does not miss state changes. A status LED shows the current relay state.
Create a doorbell: when the pushbutton is pressed, energize the chime relay for exactly 700 ms, then enforce a 2-second lockout before the next ring. Watchdog should clear any stuck lockout on fault.
On button press, run a booster pump relay for 30 seconds. Prevent a re-run for 120 seconds (lockout). Provide a stop button that cancels immediately.

Vacation lighting: between 19:00 and 22:00, randomly alternate a lamp relay ON for 5–15 minutes and OFF for 5–15 minutes. A switch enables/disables this behavior. Ensure relay is OFF outside the time window.
Smart plug auto-off: whenever the outlet is turned ON manually, automatically turn it OFF after 45 minutes unless the button is pressed again to extend by another 45 minutes.
Simple occupancy light: motion triggers light ON; if no motion for 90 seconds, turn OFF. Retriggering extends the timer. Default to OFF on power-up.
Hold-to-reset behavior: holding the button for 5 seconds resets the automation state and forces all relays OFF. During the hold, blink an LED as a countdown indicator.

Create a state machine with enum modes OFF, AUTO, MANUAL for a heater relay. In AUTO, follow a schedule (06:00–22:00) with setpoints 20 C/18 C. In MANUAL, keep the last user-selected relay state. A watchdog forces OFF if no control tick within 500 ms.

Implement a fan controller with enum modes QUIET, NORMAL, BOOST selectable via a button cycle. When motion is detected, run for 2, 10, or 20 minutes depending on mode. Use a state machine for timing and transitions.

Design a blind controller using two relays (UP and DOWN) with strict mutual exclusion. State machine states: Idle, MovingUp, MovingDown, Stalled. Auto-stop after 20 seconds. If conflicting commands are received, honor the most recent. A watchdog drops both relays on fault.

Interlock two loads on one circuit: Heater and Kettle relays must never be ON simultaneously. Implement a state machine that gives Heater priority and enforces a 3-minute minimum OFF time before restarting Heater.

Create weekday/weekend schedules to control a dehumidifier relay. In AUTO, run if RH > 65% and inside the active window; otherwise OFF. Manual override provides a 30-minute temporary ON. Add a watchdog that requires the scheduler to pulse a heartbeat every minute.

Hallway light with dual sensors: only turn ON when motion is detected and ambient lux < 200. Turn OFF 2 minutes after no motion, or if lux > 250 for 10 seconds. Use a state machine and enum ACTIVE/IDLE to manage behavior.

Pump controller with fill/drain cycle: on start, run Fill (relay A) until a high float triggers or 60 seconds elapse, then run Drain (relay B) until a low float triggers or 60 seconds elapse. Use timeouts and a state machine to avoid overlap.

Two-speed fan using two relays (LOW, HIGH) with interlock. Provide enum modes OFF, LOW, HIGH. If switching to HIGH, ensure LOW is OFF and wait 300 ms before energizing HIGH. Watchdog forces both OFF on fault.

Rule engine for a lamp: three sources (button, schedule, remote flag) can request ON. Lamp is ON if any source requests, OFF when none do. Each source request expires after 30 minutes unless renewed. Use a state machine for arbitration.

Child-safe smart outlet: a double-press within 400 ms toggles the outlet; a single press is ignored. A 5-second long press locks the outlet OFF until a triple press unlocks it. Model LOCKED and UNLOCKED as enum modes.

Garage light automation: turn ON if the door is open or motion is detected, and turn OFF 3 minutes after both are inactive. Include a safety input that forces immediate OFF (blackout). Use a state machine for transitions.

Sprinkler controller for two zones with non-overlapping operation. Daily schedules and manual start per zone. Enforce a 10-second pause between zones. A watchdog resets the system to all valves OFF if a hang is detected.

Water heater control with time-of-use schedule: disable heating during 17:00–21:00; otherwise maintain 50–55 C with hysteresis. Enforce a minimum 5-minute interval between relay state changes to prevent short cycling.

Sunset-like routine using a configurable fixed time: lights ON at StartTime and OFF at 23:00. In AWAY mode (enum), add a random jitter of ±10 minutes to both events. Include manual override that lasts until the next event.

Gate latch control: on Open command, energize the latch relay for 800 ms unless a limit switch indicates already open. If jammed (no limit within 5 s), retry once after 2 s, then enter ALARM state. Watchdog ensures the relay never stays energized longer than 2 s.

Bathroom fan controller that detects humidity rise: if RH climbs 5% above baseline for 60 s, turn ON; turn OFF when within 2% of baseline. Update baseline at 03:00 daily when the fan is OFF. States: Idle, Tracking, Boost.

Laundry activity indicator: if current > threshold for more than 10 seconds, turn an indicator relay ON. Turn it OFF when current stays below threshold for 2 minutes. Include a watchdog to fail-safe OFF on error.

Porch lighting with two relays: NightLamp ON between 20:00–06:00. When motion is detected at night, turn BrightLamp ON for 30 seconds, then OFF, keeping NightLamp ON. Enforce that both relays can be ON together only during motion.

CO2-based fresh air control: OPEN a damper relay when CO2 > 1000 ppm, CLOSE when CO2 < 800 ppm. In SLEEP mode (enum), ignore openings from 00:00–06:00 unless CO2 > 1500 ppm. Enforce a minimum OPEN time of 120 seconds.

Kettle safety timer: when the outlet turns ON, auto-OFF after 7 minutes unless a boil sensor indicates completion earlier. If a dry-run condition is detected, switch OFF immediately and latch a fault until cleared by a long press.

Implement a thermostat with time-proportional control: use a PID to compute duty within a 10-minute window for a heater relay to hold 21.0 C. Run at 1 Hz with WCET 5 ms. Include anti-windup, sensor fault detection, and fail-safe OFF.

Sensor fusion for occupancy: combine motion events, door transitions, and a sound level threshold into a 0–100 confidence score. Turn the light relay ON when score > 60, and OFF when score < 30 continuously for 120 seconds. Include a watchdog and a heartbeat LED.

Load shedding for three high-power relays with priorities 1–3: keep total estimated power under 3000 W by shedding lowest priority first. Enforce a 30-second minimum OFF time before re-enabling any shed load. Use a state machine and watchdog.

Sump pump with redundancy: primary and backup floats plus run-dry sensor. Prefer primary; if backup triggers, raise alarm and run pump. Add a 5-second self-test every 24 hours. Watchdog ensures the pump cannot run more than 5 minutes continuously without float activity. All faults latch until cleared.

Greenhouse cooling with staged fan relays: use a PI controller targeting 25 C to decide how many of three fans to enable. Require a minimum 2-minute dwell per stage and detect failure if temperature continues rising while all stages are ON.

Water valve actuator with feedback: states Idle, OpenCmd, OpenVerify, CloseCmd, CloseVerify, Fault. Energize the relay during OpenCmd/CloseCmd with 8-second maximums. Verify with a position sensor; on mismatch, enter Fault and latch. Watchdog de-energizes on timeout.

Heater and ventilation interlock: if temperature > 28 C, force heater OFF and ventilation ON for at least 10 minutes. Use enum modes NORMAL and EMERGENCY. Control loop at 10 Hz with WCET 2 ms; missed ticks trigger the watchdog to enter EMERGENCY safe behavior.

Schedule-aware EV trickle charger outlet: allow ON only from 22:00–06:00 and cap daily energy by limiting ON-time equivalent to 6 kWh at 1.2 kW. On exceeding budget, lock out until next day. Provide a 30-minute manual override.

Leak mitigation: if a leak sensor trips, close the main valve relay, cut power to selected outlets, and flash an alarm LED. Latch the condition until manual reset with double confirmation. Exercise the valve for 10 seconds every 7 days.

Freezer protection: manage compressor relay with anti-short-cycle (minimum OFF 5 minutes). If temperature rises above -10 C for 15 minutes, enter ALARM, sound a buzzer relay, and force compressor ON if interlocks allow. Include watchdog and sensor plausibility checks.

Whole-home mode manager with enum modes HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, VACATION. A central state machine applies different rules to lights, outlets, and fans per mode. Include scheduled mode transitions, manual overrides, and a global watchdog that forces SAFE mode (all relays OFF except critical) on missed heartbeats. Provide clear test signals for validation.

Multi-zone irrigation scheduler for 8 zones (by ID): run non-overlapping programs on specific days/times, support a rain-delay input to pause schedules, and allow manual start/skip per zone. Pre-charge a pump relay for 3 seconds before any valve and keep it ON for 5 seconds after. Include test hooks and a watchdog.

Energy-aware home controller orchestrating six relays across enum modes ECO, COMFORT, and CRITICAL. Implement priority-based shedding, daily schedules, occupancy rules, and a fire-alarm override that cuts power except emergency lighting. Specify control loop rate 20 Hz, WCET 1 ms, and require deterministic transitions in a formal state machine.

Automation supervisor coordinating sub-controllers (lighting, climate, security) using enumerated sub-states and a master state machine. Incorporate a system watchdog, heartbeat aggregation, and degraded SAFE operation if any sub-controller stops reporting. Define acceptance tests covering mode changes, schedule edges, and fault injections.

Comprehensive garage system with modes IDLE, OPENING, OPEN, CLOSING, FAULT. Control door motor via up/down relays, manage a light relay with timers, integrate a safety beam input and obstruction detection. Include schedules (auto-close after 10 minutes open), a battery-backup degraded mode, watchdog-protected timeouts, and a suite of edge-case test scenarios.

Turn a single relay ON while a pushbutton is held and OFF when released. Include 50 ms debounce, default to OFF at startup, and a watchdog that forces a safe reset if the control loop stalls longer than 200 ms.

On a momentary button tap, latch a relay ON for exactly 5 minutes, then switch it OFF automatically. A second tap during the countdown should cancel and turn it OFF immediately. Add 40 ms debounce and a 1 s watchdog timeout.

Drive a porch light relay from an ambient light sensor: turn ON when below 50 lux and turn OFF when above 100 lux using hysteresis. Sample every 200 ms, default to OFF on startup, and integrate a 500 ms watchdog.

Activate a lamp via motion sensor: when motion triggers, turn the relay ON for 30 seconds and extend the timer with each new motion event; otherwise keep it OFF. Ignore all else and include a 1 s watchdog.

Control a sump pump relay with a float switch: run while the float is closed and stop when open. Add a maximum continuous run time of 10 minutes; exceeding it forces OFF and requires the float to open to reset. Include a 500 ms watchdog.
Implement a heater relay with temperature thresholds: turn ON below 18 C and OFF above 20 C using hysteresis. Sample every 1 s, ensure default OFF at boot, and provide a 2 s watchdog.
Drive a siren relay when a door contact opens: sound for 60 seconds then auto-clear. Re-opening during the active period should not extend the time. Default OFF and include a 1 s watchdog.
Follow a remote boolean command to set a power relay ON/OFF. If no valid command is received for 100 ms, force the relay to OFF (failsafe). Add a watchdog with 200 ms timeout.
Create a countdown outlet: on button press, energize a relay for 15 minutes; pressing again cancels and turns OFF immediately. Include 50 ms debounce and a 500 ms watchdog.
Run a cyclic light timer: keep a relay ON for 10 seconds, then OFF for 50 seconds, repeating indefinitely. Limit time drift to under 100 ms per hour and include a 1 s watchdog.
Stairway light with press-and-hold: a short press toggles the relay; a long press (>2 s) forces OFF. Use 30 ms debounce and a 1 s watchdog.
Control a greenhouse misting relay: if humidity is below 40% RH, run for 20 seconds, then enforce a 2-minute lockout before the next run. Default OFF and add a 1 s watchdog.
Garage frost protection: heater relay turns ON when temperature < 5 C and OFF when > 8 C. Enforce minimum OFF time of 2 minutes to avoid short cycling. Include a 1 s watchdog.
Daily schedule for holiday lights: switch a relay ON at 18:00 and OFF at 23:00. On startup, catch up missed events appropriately. Provide a 1 s watchdog.
Implement a safety arming sequence: keep the relay de-energized at boot and require a button to be held for 2 seconds to arm and enable it. Add 50 ms debounce and a 500 ms watchdog.

Build a state machine for a smart fan with enum modes OFF, AUTO, MANUAL. In AUTO, turn the fan relay ON above 26 C and OFF below 24 C. In MANUAL, a toggle button directly controls the relay. Indicate mode with LEDs, debounce inputs (50 ms), and integrate a 1 s watchdog.

Hallway light using motion and ambient light: if motion occurs and lux < 100, turn the relay ON for 90 seconds, extending with further motion. Implement a state machine with Idle, Active, and Holdoff states to prevent rapid retriggering. Include a 500 ms watchdog.

Two-relay bathroom controller: Relay1 is exhaust fan, Relay2 is heater. Enum modes ECO and BOOST. Motion starts ECO (fan for 5 minutes). Long button press enters BOOST (fan + heater for 10 minutes). Limit combined operation to 15 minutes per hour. Use a state machine and a 1 s watchdog.

Laundry room light with door sensor and manual override: door opening turns light ON; closing starts a 2-minute grace then OFF unless an override switch is active. Override keeps light ON until the next door open event. Implement enum Mode: AUTO, OVERRIDE with a state machine and a 1 s watchdog.

Garden irrigation: only allow a manual start within a 06:00–08:00 window. Abort immediately if a rain sensor indicates wet. Cap any run at 15 minutes. Implement a state machine with safe default OFF and a 500 ms watchdog.

Compressor anti-short-cycle: thermostat input requests cooling; enforce minimum OFF time of 3 minutes and minimum ON time of 2 minutes for the compressor relay. Provide a state machine and a 1 s watchdog with enum Status: OFF, WAIT, RUN.

Dual control switches for one light: two momentary switches at top and bottom of stairs toggle a single relay. Debounce 50 ms and use a state machine to prevent double toggling from simultaneous presses. Add a 1 s watchdog.

Night mode scheduler: define enum Mode DAY, EVENING, NIGHT. At 18:00 enter EVENING; at 23:00 enter NIGHT; at sunrise return to DAY. In NIGHT, ignore motion-triggered lighting. Implement as a state machine with a 1 s watchdog.

Seasonal reminder: twice per year at 09:00, pulse a reminder lamp via a relay for 1 second, but only if ambient light > 200 lux. Ensure at most one pulse per day and persist across power cycles. Include a 1 s watchdog.
