Pantry light with door-ajar alarm: door open turns light ON. If the door remains open longer than 5 minutes, blink the light by toggling the relay at 1 Hz until the door closes. Use a state machine, 30 ms debounce, and a 1 s watchdog.

Smart socket with energy budget: if total household power exceeds 1.5 kW, force the controlled relay OFF until usage is below 1.2 kW for 30 seconds. Provide a manual override button that keeps it ON for at most 10 minutes. Implement with a state machine and a 500 ms watchdog.
Chandelier warm-up: on ON command, engage a preheat relay for 2 seconds, then switch to the main relay without overlap. Use states OFF, PREHEAT, ON and a 1 s watchdog.

Window fan interlock: only allow the fan relay when a window contact is open and indoor temperature > 25 C. If the window closes while running, stop within 500 ms. Implement a state machine, default OFF, and a 500 ms watchdog.

Pet feeder light with vacation mode: enum Mode NORMAL and VACATION. NORMAL turns ON 07:00–07:30 and 18:00–18:30. VACATION uses 10-minute windows at the same times. Mode toggles via long-press. Implement a state machine with 40 ms debounce and a 1 s watchdog.

HVAC fan circulation: run the fan relay for 10 minutes every hour at the top of the hour, unless cooling is currently active (input). Recover missed runtime after power loss without exceeding 10 minutes per hour. Provide a state machine and a 1 s watchdog.

Driveway lights with vehicle sensor and curfew: vehicle arrival turns lights ON for 5 minutes, but after 00:00 only for 1 minute. Force OFF at sunrise. Implement as a state machine with a 500 ms watchdog.

Kitchen hood interlock: when stovetop is ON, enable hood fan relay and block the make-up air damper relay from closing. When stovetop turns OFF, delay fan OFF by 90 seconds, then allow damper closing. Enforce mutual exclusion with a state machine and include a 1 s watchdog.

Outlet child lock: the outlet relay can only be turned ON by entering a code using four sequential button presses (short/long pattern). Any incorrect press resets the sequence. Auto-OFF after 30 minutes. Use a state machine with 30 ms debounce and a 1 s watchdog.

Workshop heater with occupancy: allow the heater relay only if occupancy is detected and temperature < 17 C. After last occupancy, keep ON for a 15-minute overrun, then OFF. Implement as a state machine and include a 1 s watchdog.

Rainwater pump alternation: control two pumps via Relay A and Relay B, alternating each new cycle to balance wear. Start when a run request occurs, stop after the low-water clears or after 10 minutes maximum. Abort starting if low-water is active. Use a state machine and a 1 s watchdog.

Thermostat with time-proportioned control: maintain 21 C using a PID running at 2 Hz to compute a duty cycle over a 5-minute window. Drive a single heater relay with ON/OFF pulses for that fraction. Safety: max continuous ON 20 minutes, sensor fault forces OFF, default OFF on boot. Watchdog 500 ms and WCET per cycle < 5 ms.

Dehumidifier controller with PID: target 50% RH using a 1-minute PWM window based on a PID updated at 1 Hz. If temperature < 10 C, disable and lock out for 30 minutes to prevent icing. State machine with states OFF, PID_RUN, LOCKOUT, FAULT, and a 1 s watchdog.

Smart lighting via sensor fusion: combine motion detection with a low-pass filtered ambient light signal (2 Hz filter) to estimate occupancy probability. Turn the relay ON only if probability > 0.7 and lux < 80. Include a post-off grace period to avoid immediate retrigger. Run at 10 Hz, WCET 3 ms, watchdog 500 ms.

Boiler pump safety with dual temperature sensors: if sensors disagree by more than 2 C for 10 seconds, enter FAULT and disable the relay. Otherwise, enable the pump when supply > 45 C and disable when < 40 C. Add lockout after 6 rapid cycles in 10 minutes. Implement as a state machine with enum modes and a 1 s watchdog.

Sump control with redundant floats: start pump relay when the high float closes; stop when the low float opens. If the high float remains closed after 3 minutes of pumping, declare failure, alarm via a second relay, and lock out until a manual reset button is pressed. Include a 500 ms watchdog and WCET < 2 ms.

Greenhouse ventilation by fusion: compute a discomfort index from temperature (C) and humidity (%RH) and run a fan relay only when the index exceeds a threshold for at least 60 seconds. If wind speed > 8 m/s, inhibit the vent-opening relay. Provide FAULT on sensor timeout, a state machine, and a 1 s watchdog.

Freezer defrost control: every 12 hours, run a defrost heater relay, using the coil temperature slope to end early, capped at 7 minutes. Ensure the compressor relay is OFF during defrost and remains OFF for a 3-minute recovery. Abort if temperature exceeds 15 C. Watchdog 500 ms, main loop 5 Hz, WCET 2 ms.

Water heater element control with safety: use dual thermostats and a thermal fuse input. Time-proportion the relay around a 55 C setpoint using a PID, but permanently lock out if the thermal fuse triggers. Implement states IDLE, HEATING, HOLD, FAULT and include a 500 ms watchdog.

Air quality ventilation: combine CO2 ppm and VOC index with a moving average over 30 seconds. Run the fan relay if either exceeds thresholds, and extend runtime by 10 minutes after values return to normal when both were high. Provide modes NORMAL and BOOST, a state machine, a 1 s watchdog, and a maximum daily runtime of 6 hours.

Smart hot water recirculation: learn recent usage times (track last 20 events) and preheat by running the pump relay for 10 minutes before predicted demand. Allow a manual BOOST button for 15 minutes. Enforce quiet hours 23:00–05:00 (OFF). Implement as a state machine with a 1 s watchdog and timing jitter < 100 ms.

Design a multi-mode energy shedder with enum modes HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, PARTY. Coordinate three relays (water heater, dryer, pool pump) so total load stays under 3 kW, honoring priorities and mutual exclusions. Provide manual overrides with timeouts, shed immediately on brownout input, and implement a clear state machine with a 500 ms watchdog. Include a test plan covering mode transitions, conflicts, and brownout recovery.

Create a whole-house lighting scene controller with modes DAY, EVENING, NIGHT, ALARM. Drive multiple lighting relays using different delays and durations per mode; ALARM flashes all at 2 Hz until cleared. Mode changes occur via schedule and sensors (e.g., motion at night). Specify maximum ISR latency 1 ms, include a 500 ms watchdog, and provide tests for simultaneous triggers and power-up during ALARM.

Implement a secure garage controller: manage door opener relay, light relay, and a lockout relay. States include DISARMED, ARMED, OPENING, OPEN, CLOSING, OBSTRUCTED, FAULT. Inputs: door position sensor, obstruction sensor, keypad code, and an auto-close after 10 minutes. Use enum modes and a 200 ms watchdog. Provide at least 10 acceptance tests, covering obstruction during closing, code-entry timeout, and watchdog-induced reset recovery.

Develop a domestic water leak mitigation controller: on leak detection in kitchen or bath, close a main valve relay and cut power relays to nonessential outlets. Modes NORMAL, MITIGATE, RESET_REQUIRED. Require manual reset and perform a startup self-test that actuates the valve briefly. Include a 500 ms watchdog, WCET 3 ms, and a test matrix for typical and fault conditions.

Build a vacation scheduler with nested automation rules: modes NORMAL and VACATION. In VACATION, randomly vary light relay ON times within ±10 minutes around an evening schedule, inhibit irrigation if a rain-forecast input is TRUE for the next 24 hours, and ensure no two exterior relays are ON simultaneously. Provide a 1 s watchdog, deterministic loop at 10 Hz (WCET 2 ms), and simulation tests over seven days to verify randomness bounds, rule conflicts, and power-loss recovery.

Implement a simple switch-to-relay control: when the toggle switch is ON, energize the relay; when OFF, de-energize. Add 50 ms input debounce, and include a watchdog timer that forces the relay OFF if the control loop stalls for more than 500 ms.
Create a doorbell automation that pulses a relay for 300 ms on each valid button press and ignores repeats for 2 seconds. Ensure a fail-safe watchdog that forces the relay OFF on timeout or fault.

Build a timer-controlled outlet that turns ON at 07:00 and OFF at 22:00 daily, with a manual override button that forces ON for 60 minutes before reverting to schedule. Default to OFF on reboot, and use a watchdog to force OFF if the main loop misses its timing.

While a momentary button is held, keep a relay energized; release returns it to OFF. Debounce the button at 20 ms, run the control at 100 Hz with WCET under 2 ms, and use a watchdog that sets outputs to a safe OFF state if missed deadlines occur.

Implement a staircase light timer: a push button turns the light relay ON for 2 minutes; additional presses while active extend the timer by 2 minutes up to a maximum of 10 minutes. Include a watchdog that defaults to OFF on fault.

Create a thermal cutoff for a heater relay: if temperature exceeds 60 C, switch OFF immediately and latch a fault until a reset button is pressed. Use hysteresis of 2 C and a watchdog that guarantees the relay is OFF when timing fails.
Control a bathroom fan relay using humidity: turn ON when RH > 65% and turn OFF when RH < 55% (10% hysteresis). Add a watchdog to fail-safe the relay OFF if the loop stalls.
Design a night-light relay that turns ON when ambient light falls below 100 lux and turns OFF above 150 lux. Sample the sensor every 500 ms and include a watchdog that enforces OFF on timeout.
On power-up, energize a relay for 1 second and then switch it OFF. Ensure the watchdog keeps the relay OFF if timing constraints are not met.
Implement edge-triggered toggling: each distinct button press toggles the relay state; ignore long holds. Debounce at 10 ms and use a watchdog to force OFF on a missed cycle.
Drive a pilot indicator output: blink at 1 Hz when the main relay is ON, otherwise keep the indicator OFF. Add a watchdog that turns both outputs OFF on fault.
Using a motion input, keep a light relay ON for 3 minutes after the last detected movement. Ignore subsequent motion for 2 seconds after turn-on to avoid chatter. Include a watchdog fail-safe to OFF.

Combine a float switch and a manual enable to control a pump relay: the pump runs only when the enable is TRUE and the float is safe. If the float indicates low level at any time, force the relay OFF and latch until manual reset. Watchdog must default to OFF.
Create a simple weekly schedule where a relay is ON on Saturdays from 08:00 to 12:00 and OFF otherwise. Ensure correct behavior across midnight and include a watchdog that sets OFF on failure.

Build a vacation lighting randomizer: between 18:00 and 22:00, toggle a relay with random ON durations between 5 and 15 minutes and OFF durations between 5 and 15 minutes, ensuring duty cycle stays under 50% per hour. Use a watchdog to force OFF on fault.

Design a finite state machine for a hallway light with enum states Idle, Active, Grace, and LockedOut. Inputs: motion and ambient light; manual button toggles override. Below 100 lux, motion sets Active for 90 s; a double press enters LockedOut for 10 minutes. Include a watchdog that fails OFF.

Implement interlocked blind control using two relays (Up and Down) and a state machine handling commands Up, Down, and Stop. Enforce mutual exclusion and a 30 s movement timeout; missed ticks > 200 ms should de-energize both relays via a watchdog.

Create a smart water heater contactor controller with weekday (05:30–08:30, 17:00–22:00) and weekend (06:30–23:00) schedules. A manual boost button grants 60 minutes ON. If temperature exceeds 70 C, force OFF and assert an alarm output. Use enum modes and a watchdog.

Build a ceiling fan controller with enum states Off, Low, Medium, High mapped to three relays. Prevent changing speeds more than once every 5 seconds and ensure only one speed relay can be ON at a time. Watchdog must revert to Off.

Implement an outdoor light schedule that turns ON 30 minutes before sunset and OFF at 23:30. A button provides a 15-minute temporary override. Use a state machine for Scheduled, Override, and Fault, and a watchdog to default OFF.

Create a garage heater controller with states Heating, Standby, and Fault. Heat when temperature < 15 C and presence is TRUE; stop when temperature > 18 C or no presence for 10 minutes. Include a 5-minute minimum OFF time to prevent short cycling and a watchdog that fails OFF.

Control two irrigation valves on alternating 10-minute cycles with a weekly schedule; skip watering if a rain sensor is active or soil moisture exceeds 30% v/v. Implement a state machine per zone and ensure both relays are never ON simultaneously. Watchdog forces both OFF on failure.

Develop a smart outlet that turns OFF if power draw exceeds 1500 W for more than 3 seconds and latches until a reset input is received. Limit operation to 08:00–22:00 daily. Use enum modes Normal, Latched, and OffSchedule, with a watchdog forcing OFF.

Create an entryway light with short-press toggle and long-press (>1.5 s) Night mode. In Night mode, motion extends auto-off to 5 minutes; in normal mode, motion extends only 1 minute. Implement enum modes and a watchdog that ensures OFF on error.

Implement a fan and service indicator: track cumulative fan ON time; after 200 hours, assert a service output until a reset input clears it. The fan relay continues normal operation. Include a watchdog that leaves both outputs safe if timing fails.

Design a bathroom fan controller that runs when humidity exceeds a threshold with hysteresis and also supports a 20-minute manual override. Cap total runtime to 4 hours per day. Use a state machine and a watchdog defaulting to OFF.

Build a scene controller with three buttons selecting enum modes Reading, Movie, and Off, which drive two relays L1 and L2 in different combinations. Include input debounce, prevent illegal combinations, and use a watchdog to revert to Off on error.

Implement software two-way switching: two wall switches control a single light relay, toggling on each rising edge from either input. Debounce each input at 15 ms and ensure the watchdog sets the relay OFF on failure.

Control a pool pump relay to run 4 hours starting at 09:00 and 4 hours at 18:00; if water temperature is below 10 C, skip the schedule. Provide freeze protection: run continuously if temperature is below 2 C. Use a state machine and a watchdog fail-safe.

Automate greenhouse venting: when temperature > 28 C, pulse an actuator relay ON for 10 seconds every minute; inhibit if rain is detected. Enforce a maximum 25% duty cycle over any 10-minute window and fail OFF via watchdog.

Create a two-stage heater controller using relays Stage1 and Stage2. Maintain a 20 C setpoint: Stage1 turns ON when temperature < 19.5 C; Stage2 turns ON only if error exceeds 3 C. Include minimum ON/OFF times of 3 minutes and a watchdog that fails OFF.

Implement a door lock scheduler: lock at 22:00 and unlock at 07:00. Manual toggle is allowed but auto-relocks after 60 seconds. A tamper input triggers an alarm output for 2 minutes. Use enum states and a watchdog that sets all relays to safe positions on fault.

Create a holiday lights sequencer that cycles three relays through patterns every 5 seconds; a Next button advances to the next pattern. Operate only between 17:00 and 22:30. Employ a state machine and a watchdog that shuts all relays OFF on error.

Manage an aquarium with a light relay ON from 10:00 to 20:00 and a feeder relay that pulses for 1 second at 12:00 daily. In Vacation mode, skip feeding and keep the light schedule. Use enum modes and ensure a watchdog forces both OFF on failure.

Control a sump pump with primary and backup relays using two float switches. Run the backup if the primary runs continuously for more than 30 seconds or if a high-level float triggers. If overcurrent is detected, lock out both until manual reset. Watchdog must default both OFF.

Implement a thermostat using PID to time-proportion a heater relay within a 10-minute window to hold a setpoint in Celsius. Enforce minimum ON/OFF of 2 minutes, cap duty at 80%, add anti-windup, and run control at 1 Hz with WCET under 2 ms; watchdog fails OFF.

Create a hot water recirculation pump controller using sensor fusion: combine motion events, flow detections, and time-of-day to decide when to run the pump for 2 minutes. Limit to 30 minutes per hour, sample at 10 Hz, and use a watchdog to ensure the relay defaults OFF.

Design a dehumidifier controller that uses PI control of RH to target 50% using a relay with cycle period modulation. Enforce a 5-minute compressor short-cycle protection, limit daily runtime to 8 hours, and include a watchdog that fails OFF.

Build occupancy-based lighting with sensor fusion of motion, ambient sound level, and door contact to estimate occupancy confidence (Low/Medium/High) and drive a relay. Include hysteresis and timeouts, define an enum for confidence states, and fail OFF via watchdog.

Implement a load-shedding controller: monitor total current in amperes and drop a 'shed' relay when the 1-minute average exceeds 40 A; restore when below 30 A. Use a sliding window filter, apply a 5-minute minimum shed duration, and use a watchdog to ensure safe OFF.

Control greenhouse climate using PID to time-proportion a heater relay to maintain 22 C and activate a vent relay if overshoot > 1 C persists for > 2 minutes. Limit vent cycles to once per 5 minutes. Tick at 1 Hz, WCET 3 ms, and fail OFF via watchdog.

Create a smart irrigation controller that fuses soil moisture percentage with a rain sensor and a base schedule to decide watering. Skip if moisture is above a configurable threshold, cap watering to 30 minutes per day, and use a watchdog to default relays OFF.

Manage a water tank fill relay by estimating level from two float switches and pump runtime accumulation. Prevent dry-run by lockout if low-level is active more than 5 seconds after start, and require manual reset after faults. Include a watchdog to force OFF.

Implement an adaptive evening lighting schedule that learns the typical first-occupancy time using an EWMA and sets ON time within bounds (18:00–22:00). Provide manual override that resets the model when used. Enforce a watchdog that turns lights OFF on failure.

Develop a dual-mode thermostat with separate PID loops for heating and cooling, controlling two relays to hold 21 C ±0.5 C. Enforce a 1 C deadband and mutual exclusion, sample at 60 s, and include a watchdog that fails both relays OFF.
Simple lamp control: when a momentary switch is pressed, energize a relay; when released, de-energize it. Add 50 ms debounce and ensure the watchdog forces the relay OFF if it ever times out.

Bathroom fan timer: a single press on a pushbutton runs the fan relay for 10 minutes, then turns it off automatically. A press while timing restarts the 10-minute timer. Include a watchdog that defaults to OFF on expiry.
Daily schedule for a porch light: switch a relay ON at 20:00 and OFF at 23:00 local time. If the real-time clock is invalid, keep the relay OFF. Implement a watchdog that forces OFF if not serviced.
Staircase light: trigger a 2-minute ON timer when a pushbutton is tapped; tapping again during the interval restarts the 2 minutes. Ensure a watchdog drives the output OFF if it expires.
Motion-activated light: on motion input rising edge, turn the relay ON for 30 seconds; retrigger to extend. Ignore input chatter shorter than 100 ms. Watchdog timeout must force the relay OFF.
Pulse output: on touch sensor activation, energize a relay for a fixed 1 second pulse regardless of how long the sensor is held. Debounce 30 ms and fail safe to OFF on watchdog expiry.
Water heater boost button: a long press (>2 s) enables a 15-minute boost via relay; short presses are ignored. The watchdog must revert the relay to OFF if it ever fires.
Weekend-only lighting schedule: turn a relay ON at 08:00 and OFF at 10:00 on Saturdays and Sundays, otherwise keep OFF. Ensure a watchdog that drops the relay to OFF if triggered.
Fan toggle with protection: a pushbutton toggles a fan relay state, but enforce a minimum OFF time of 60 s before allowing a new ON to protect the relay. Watchdog forces OFF on timeout.
Safe startup lamp: keep the relay OFF for 3 seconds after power-up, then mirror a switch input (with 20 ms debounce). Include a watchdog that forces OFF if not regularly fed.
Capacitive touch lamp: toggle a relay on each distinct touch with 50 ms debounce; if the input stays high for more than 1 s, ignore until it returns low. Watchdog must force OFF on timeout.
Inverted switch: relay is ON when the switch input is LOW and OFF when HIGH. Debounce 20 ms, and ensure watchdog expiry sets the relay to OFF.
Manual override timer: while a hold-to-run switch is held, keep the relay ON; after release, keep it ON for an additional 10 minutes, then turn OFF. Watchdog enforces OFF on fault.
Doorbell-style pulse: pressing a button energizes the relay for exactly 500 ms; ignore any further presses during that 500 ms window. Add a watchdog that returns the relay to OFF if it expires.

Vacation randomizer: between 19:00 and 22:00, randomly switch a light relay ON and OFF with intervals between 5 and 15 minutes. Outside that window the relay remains OFF. Watchdog should force OFF if triggered.

Porch light automation using a simple state machine: if motion is detected and ambient light < 50 lx, turn ON for 2 minutes; retrigger to extend; otherwise stay OFF. Watchdog timeout places the system in OFF state.

Two-way stair lighting: two debounced switches control a single relay via edge-triggered toggling. Ignore toggles that occur within 200 ms of the previous change to prevent chatter. Include a watchdog that forces OFF on expiry.

Relay interlock: two relays represent HEAT and COOL modes selected by a mode switch. Implement an enum for OFF, HEAT, COOL, and guarantee never both relays ON. Enforce a 5 s separation when switching modes. Watchdog must disable both on timeout.
Irrigation starter: start a 15-minute run from a button or a daily 06:00 schedule, but inhibit if the rain sensor is wet. A second button press stops immediately. Include a watchdog that forces OFF.

Vacancy logic with a state machine: use a door contact and a motion sensor to maintain an OCCUPIED/UNOCCUPIED state. Turn lights ON when entering, OFF 30 s after door closes and no motion. Watchdog fails to OFF.

Laundry room light: motion turns lights ON, off after 3 minutes of no motion unless a sound activity input indicates presence. Disable automation between 23:00 and 06:00. Implement an enum sensitivity mode and a watchdog to force OFF.
Ceiling fan speed selection: read a selector and drive one of three relays (LOW, MED, HIGH). Implement an enum OFF, LOW, MED, HIGH and ensure only one speed relay is ever ON. Watchdog forces OFF.

Delayed-off fan controller: when the light switch turns OFF, keep the fan relay ON for 5 minutes, otherwise mirror the light. Use explicit states LightOn, Overrun, Idle. Include a watchdog that sets fan OFF on timeout.

Child-safe outlet: require a double-press within 2 seconds to toggle the outlet relay; single presses do nothing. Provide feedback via a status indicator output and include a watchdog that forces OFF.

Weekly lighting schedule with holiday override: follow programmed on/off times unless a holiday input is active, in which case stay OFF. On power-up, apply the correct state even if an event was missed. Watchdog must force OFF on timeout.

Blind control with up/down relays: a single rocker switch short-press toggles movement; long-press fully opens or closes. Enforce interlock so both relays are never ON and add overrun cutoff at 90 s. Use a simple state machine and a watchdog.

Garage heater: if temperature < 10 C and the window contact is closed, turn heater relay ON; otherwise OFF. Enforce a minimum 2-minute OFF time between ON cycles. Watchdog sets relay OFF if it triggers.

Sump pump assist: when a float switch closes, run pump relay for at least 5 s to ride out chatter; stop when the float opens and the 5 s min has elapsed. If a single run exceeds 10 minutes, energize an alarm output. Watchdog forces both OFF on expiry.

Dual motion hallway lights: OR two motion sensors, gate by ambient light threshold, and use a state machine with Idle, Active, Hold to manage a 2-minute timeout. Watchdog must drop to Idle with lights OFF.

Scene controller: three buttons select enum scenes RELAX, BRIGHT, OFF that map to two relays. Holding any button for 3 s enters a LOCKED scene that ignores inputs until power cycle. Include a watchdog that reverts to OFF if it expires.
Pet feeder outlet: energize for 20 s at 07:00 and 19:00 unless a safety door contact is open. Never allow more than 3 activations per hour. Watchdog ensures the outlet is OFF on timeout.
Hot water recirculation: a pushbutton or motion input triggers a 90 s pump run, inhibited if water temperature > 45 C. Implement a small state machine and ensure watchdog timeout turns the pump OFF.

Energy saver strip: when a master switch turns OFF, sequentially turn OFF four outlet relays with 100 ms spacing to limit inrush. When master turns ON, do the reverse. Watchdog sets all relays OFF on fault.
Ventilation controller: if CO2 > 1000 ppm or motion is detected, turn the fan relay ON; turn OFF only after both are normal for 10 minutes. Add hysteresis of 50 ppm and a watchdog that forces OFF.

Door-triggered light with day/night behavior: on door open, turn light ON. On close, keep ON for 30 s; extend to 2 minutes when lux < 20 lx. Use explicit enum Day/Night, a small state machine, and a watchdog to force OFF on expiry.

PID thermostat for a resistive heater using time-proportioning: target 22 C with a 0.5 C deadband, period 60 s, and limit to 6 relay actuations per hour. Sensor fault forces relay OFF. Include a watchdog and report a fault state.

Boiler circulation pump using two temperature sensors: run when supply > 50 C and (supply - return) >= 5 C; stop when delta < 2 C. Enforce anti-short cycle of 2 minutes. Include a watchdog and ensure WCET < 2 ms per cycle.

Water heater legionella cycle: every Sunday at 02:00, heat to 60 C for 30 minutes using a time-proportioning controller to avoid overshoot. Overtemperature cutoff at 65 C and manual abort input. Use a state machine (Idle, Heat, Hold, Abort) and a watchdog to fail safe OFF.

Automated blinds with enum modes AUTO and MANUAL: in AUTO, open at 07:00 if ambient > 200 lx and close at sunset. Detect jams via a current sensor threshold > X for >300 ms, then stop and latched fault. Watchdog causes a safe stop on timeout.

Greenhouse fan controller: regulate humidity to 60% RH with a PI time-proportioning relay (period 120 s, duty limited to 5–80%). Independently force ON if temperature > 30 C. Lock out if door open. Add watchdog and a fault state.

Demand-response outlet: combine a utility event input and a local schedule. In CRITICAL, force OFF unless a 5 s long-press override is active; otherwise follow schedule. Implement a state machine with enum modes and a watchdog; run at 20 Hz with WCET < 3 ms.

Pressure-controlled pump: maintain a target pressure (kPa) using PID to decide relay on/off with anti-windup. Dry-run detection: if relay ON and current below threshold for >5 s, enter a 10-minute lockout. Watchdog forces OFF on expiry.

Air purifier controller with sensor fusion (PM2.5, VOC, CO2): choose enum OFF, LOW, HIGH and drive relays accordingly, with quiet hours 22:00–06:00 limiting to LOW. Add hysteresis and minimum 30 s between changes. Watchdog returns to OFF on fault.

Pool pump automation: run 09:00–17:00 daily; extend runtime if sanitizer (ORP) is low; reduce by 50% if water temperature < 10 C. Inhibit if low water switch is active. Implement a state machine with a watchdog and handle missed events on power-up.

HVAC changeover valve: decide heating/cooling request from room temperature via a PID trend, and drive a single changeover relay with minimum 5-minute dwell between direction changes. Include watchdog and guarantee WCET < 1 ms at 50 Hz loop rate.

Vacation lighting simulator with enum modes HOME, AWAY, VACATION: manage 6 relays. VACATION uses randomized but repeatable schedules (fixed seed); AWAY uses a fixed schedule; HOME mirrors manual switches. Use a mode transition state machine, limit to one relay switch per 100 ms to curb inrush, and include a watchdog that forces all OFF. Specify loop 50 Hz, WCET < 2 ms. Provide a test plan for each mode, power loss at event edges, and watchdog expiry.

Water leak response system with modes NORMAL, ALARM, BYPASS: inputs from three leak sensors and a bypass key; outputs are a shutoff valve relay and a siren. Latch ALARM on any leak, optionally confirm with a second sensor within 30 s, and require manual reset. Watchdog failure goes to BYPASS with valve open. Enforce WCET < 1.5 ms. Provide acceptance tests for stuck sensors, chatter, and mid-alarm power restoration.

Energy manager for two high-power loads using enum NORMAL, PEAK_SHAVING, CRITICAL: shed lower-priority load first during PEAK_SHAVING and force both OFF in CRITICAL. Maintain minimum ON time of 10 minutes per load. Use a daily timetable to predict shed windows. Add a watchdog that drops to a conservative state. Provide tests for mode transitions, schedule edge races, and minimum ON enforcement under rapid signal changes.
Create a simple rule: when the wall switch is pressed, energize a relay to turn on a lamp; when released, turn it off. Debounce the switch with 30 ms and ensure no relay chatter.
Build a timer that toggles a fan relay on for 15 minutes and off for 15 minutes whenever an enable input is active. If disabled, immediately turn the relay off.
Implement a countdown switch: a single button starts a 5-minute on-time for a relay, and pressing again cancels the countdown. Blink an LED at 2 Hz while the relay is on.
Night light controller: if ambient light is below 50 lux, turn on a lamp relay; if above 60 lux, turn it off. Use 10 lux hysteresis to prevent rapid switching.
Convert a momentary pushbutton into a latching on-off control for a relay. First press turns on, second press turns off. Debounce 20 ms and enforce a 200 ms toggling deadtime.
Daily schedule: turn on a relay at 07:00 for 10 minutes, then off. If the device boots after 07:10, do not run the missed event; wait for the next day.
Occupancy-triggered light: when motion is detected, turn on the light for 2 minutes and retrigger on new motion. After 30 minutes of no motion, ensure the light is off.
Water pump safety: if a low-level float switch is active, immediately de-energize the pump relay. Manual override inputs must be ignored while low level is present.
Garage light logic: a button toggles the light relay. Additionally, if the door opens, turn the light on for 5 minutes. Do not force off when the door closes; let the timer expire.
Vacation presence simulation: randomly turn a lamp relay on and off between 18:00 and 23:00 with on times 10 to 30 minutes and off times 5 to 15 minutes. Ensure randomness persists across reboots.
Fan boost button: if the button is held more than 2 seconds, start a 20-minute fan run; a short tap does nothing. A second long press during a run cancels it.
Temperature-triggered exhaust: if measured air temperature exceeds 40 C, turn on the exhaust fan relay; turn it off when the temperature drops below 35 C. Sample every 1 s.
Humidity-controlled dehumidifier: turn on above 60 percent RH and off below 55 percent RH. Enforce a minimum 3-minute off-time between starts to protect the compressor.
Stairway light timer: pressing either of two buttons starts a 90-second on-time; pressing either button again cancels the timer and turns the light off.
Safety interlock for two loads: never allow both Relay A and Relay B to be on simultaneously. If simultaneous requests occur, prioritize Relay A and keep Relay B off.

Bathroom fan controller with a state machine and enum modes Off, Auto, Manual: Auto turns on above a humidity threshold and runs 10 minutes after falling below; Manual runs 15 minutes per button press; Off disables all. Use a watchdog that must be kicked each control cycle.
Heater scheduling: implement weekday and weekend profiles (Weekday 06:30-08:00 and 18:00-22:00; Weekend 08:00-23:00). Provide enum modes Normal, Away (all off), Party (on until 01:00).
Porch light state machine with modes Day, Dusk, Night. Transition on ambient light thresholds and time windows. Add a watchdog that, when it expires, forces the system back to Day with the relay off.

Sump pump controller using two float switches for low and high. State machine manages Fill, Hold, Fault. If switch readings conflict for more than 2 s, enter Fault and latch off until a long button press reset.
Programmable timer outlet with buttons for up, down, and start. Allow setting 1 to 120 minutes in 1-minute steps. Relay runs for the selected duration. Store the last setting and include a watchdog.

Entry light logic: combine door sensor and motion. At night, turn on Bright when door opens; after both door closed and no motion for 2 minutes, turn Off. Use enum states Off, Dim, Bright and manage a relay plus a dimmer enable.

Simple rule engine: support up to 8 automation rules like IF Input1 AND after sunset THEN turn on Relay1 for 30 minutes. Maintain a schedule table and a heartbeat watchdog that forces all outputs off if no heartbeat within 200 ms.

Ceiling fan seasonal controller with enum modes Off, Auto, Manual. Auto logic: if temperature > 26 C and occupancy true, run fan; in winter, run 10 minutes each hour to destratify. Include a watchdog.

Irrigation with rain delay: schedule zones with start times and durations but skip watering if a rain sensor is wet or soil moisture > 35 percent. Enforce a 1-minute gap between zones. Use a state machine Idle, RunZone, Pause, Abort.

Roller blind controller for Up and Down relays with limit switches. Implement a state machine to reach Open, Closed, and a timed step mode for partial openings. Prevent simultaneous activation, add a 90-second motion timeout, and include a watchdog.

Dual-tank selector: alternate the active tank each day at midnight. Coordinate two valve relays with a 5-second deadband during switching to avoid pressure shocks. Watchdog must default both relays to off on error.

Entryway scenes with enum modes Home, Away, Sleep. Home: motion at night turns light on for 5 minutes. Away: keep lights off. Sleep: trigger a 30-second dim courtesy light on motion. Night is ambient < 60 lux or time 22:00-06:00.
Create a cyclic control loop that runs at 50 Hz. Ensure all logic completes within 10 ms WCET per cycle. Use a watchdog that turns all outputs off if WCET is exceeded.

Greenhouse shade control: if temperature > 28 C and light > 20 klux, open shade; close when temp < 24 C. Provide enum modes Auto, ForceOpen, ForceClose with manual priority. Debounce sensors and include a watchdog.

Holiday schedule manager: allow up to 5 special dates overriding the weekly schedule. On boot, validate schedule data; if invalid, enter Error with all relays off. State machine for Validate, Run, Error.
Stairwell light safety: two switches operate a light with cross-toggle behavior. If no motion is detected, auto-off after 2 seconds. Add a watchdog that reverts to Off on missed heartbeat.

Heated towel rail: morning timer at 06:30 for 45 minutes and evening timer at 19:00 for 30 minutes. Manual boost runs 15 minutes. Prevent runs within 30 minutes of the last cycle to limit overheating.

Smart outlet overcurrent protection: if measured power exceeds 1500 W for more than 3 seconds, open the relay and enter Fault. Require manual reset. Include a watchdog and enforce a 10-second minimum off-time.

Pool pump scheduler: run 09:00-11:00 and 14:00-16:00 daily, but if water temperature < 10 C, reduce to 14:00-15:00. Enum modes Auto, Off, Clean (continuous 2 hours). Watchdog enforces safe off on expiry.

Laundry room light: motion starts a 5-minute timer; if the door closes, pause the countdown; when the door opens, resume. Provide enum Normal and ChildLock (ignore button). Include a watchdog and an LED heartbeat.

Thermostat using PID to maintain 21 C with adjustable setpoint 16-24 C. Sample at 2 Hz. Enforce minimum 1-minute on and off times for the relay. Include a watchdog and a fail-safe Off if sensor reads outside -40 to 125 C.

Sensor fusion occupancy: combine motion, door events, and sound level to estimate occupancy. Use a state machine with Confidence enum Low, Medium, High to control a lighting relay. If no sensor updates in 500 ms, trip watchdog and default to Vacant.
Hot water recirculation pump: PID control to maintain return line at 45 C; at night 23:00-05:00, target 35 C. Limit continuous on-time to 20 minutes and require 10-minute cooldown. Watchdog required.

Adaptive ventilation: fuse CO2 ppm and humidity percent to control a fan with a PI controller and integral clamping. Target CO2 900 ppm and RH 50 percent. State machine Idle, Vent, Boost, Fault. Include a watchdog and enforce WCET of 5 ms per cycle.

Smart irrigation with evapotranspiration: combine soil moisture, air temperature in C, and recent run time to compute a daily water budget. Run at dawn, skip if wind gusts exceed 10 m/s. Safety: never exceed 30 minutes per zone per day. Watchdog fallback turns all relays off.

Curtain controller with sun tracking: use sunrise and sunset offsets plus ambient light to choose Open, Half, Closed. Apply a proportional timed movement with calibration on limits. On watchdog timeout, stop motion and de-energize relays.

Floor heating dual-zone PID: maintain separate setpoints in C for two zones with shared safety limiting total duty cycle to 80 percent over a rolling 15 minutes. Detect sensor faults and enforce a watchdog that forces all off on failure.

Freezer defrost control: monitor compressor state and coil temperature. Schedule defrost every 12 hours or when coil below -20 C for 90 minutes. PID the defrost heater to reach 5 C then stop. Safety cap heater on-time at 10 minutes and include a watchdog.

Demand response lighting: respond to a utility event input by shifting schedules and reducing runtimes by 30 percent. Fuse time-of-day, ambient light, and event priority into a control state. Include a watchdog and store the last 10 events in nonvolatile memory.

Water softener regeneration scheduling: track usage pulses and elapsed time. Decide between Nightly, Skipped, or Immediate Regen when usage exceeds a threshold. Do not run between 06:00 and 22:00. Watchdog fallback cancels regen and leaves relays off.

Whole-home mode controller with enum modes Home, Away, Night, Vacation, Alarm controlling up to 8 relays. Define a state machine with explicit transitions and priorities, a 100 Hz control loop with WCET under 8 ms, and a watchdog that forces all outputs safe on overrun. Provide test scenarios for each transition and verify debouncing and timing tolerances.

Smart switch cluster for six rooms with per-room schedules, motion triggers, and manual overrides. Include a supervisory watchdog, a heartbeat LED, and a degraded mode where only manual toggles work if schedules are invalid. Define enum states per room and a global Maintenance mode. Supply a test plan covering clock drift, missed sensor updates, and power-loss recovery.

Energy scene manager coordinating relays for lighting, fan, and heater with modes Eco, Comfort, Cleaning, Emergency. Emergency must preempt others and shut down non-essential loads. Enforce WCET of 4 ms per 50 Hz cycle with a watchdog. Provide acceptance tests including sensor faults, rapid mode flapping, and schedule changes at midnight.

Irrigation controller with hierarchical state machine and modes Auto, RainDelay, ManualZone, Winterize, Fault. Schedule up to 6 zones with interlocks, pressure stabilization delays, and seasonal scaling. Control rate 20 Hz, WCET 3 ms, with a watchdog. Deliver a verification checklist for safety constraints like max daily runtime and mutually exclusive valves.

Multi-appliance scheduler for laundry, dishwasher, and water heater optimized for time-of-use tariffs. Modes include Normal, OffPeakBoost, GridEvent, Safe. Implement priority arbitration, preemption, and rollback on errors under watchdog supervision. Define sensor scan at 25 Hz and WCET under 5 ms. Include a comprehensive test matrix with daylight saving transitions and brownout recovery.

Create a simple controller where a wall switch input toggles a single relay with 50 ms debounce and a 1.0 s turn-on delay. Include a watchdog timer that forces the relay OFF if the main loop stalls. The control loop should run every 20 ms with WCET under 1 ms.

Build a dusk-activated light: read an ambient light sensor (lux) every 500 ms and turn a relay ON below 120 lux and OFF above 180 lux using hysteresis. Provide a manual override button that forces the light ON for 30 minutes.
Implement a timed outlet: when the button is pressed, energize the relay for 10 minutes then turn it off. A second press restarts the 10-minute timer. Ignore button bounce and long-presses.

Schedule a lamp to turn ON at 06:30 and OFF at 22:00 daily, with a temporary manual override switch that suspends the schedule for 2 hours. On controller reset, resume the schedule. Include a safety default of OFF if the clock is invalid.

Control a hallway light using a motion sensor: turn ON immediately on motion and turn OFF after 90 seconds of no motion. Add a 5-second cooldown after turning off to ignore retriggers. Sample the sensor at 100 ms.

Manage a small water pump with a float switch: start the pump when the float indicates LOW and stop when HIGH. Lock out the pump if it cycles more than 10 times in 5 minutes, with an indicator LED for lockout. Default to OFF on any error.

Turn a ventilation fan relay ON when temperature exceeds 30 C and OFF when it falls below 27 C. Read temperature once per second. If the temperature sensor is missing or invalid, force the fan OFF and latch a fault until reset.
Control a humidifier: switch ON below 45% RH and OFF above 55% RH. Enforce a minimum ON time of 120 s and a minimum OFF time of 60 s to protect the relay from rapid cycling.

Create a staircase timer: a pushbutton turns the light ON for a configurable duration (default 180 s). Provide two buttons to increase/decrease the duration in 30 s steps from 30–600 s, and store the last setting in nonvolatile memory.

Implement a doorbell relay that energizes for 800 ms when the bell button is pressed and ignores additional presses for 1.0 s. Include a watchdog timer that resets the control state if the relay stays ON longer than expected.
Control a two-outlet power strip: one switch input toggles both relays together. If any fault is detected, ensure both relays are forced OFF and require a manual reset.

Create a weekday-only alarm switch: at a configured time, turn a relay ON for 20 minutes on Monday–Friday, and do nothing on weekends. Allow a snooze button that defers the ON event by 10 minutes once.

Drive a curtain motor using two interlocked relays (OPEN and CLOSE). A single toggle input alternates open/close actions, each with a 20 s run time. Ensure both relays can never be ON simultaneously and stop early if an endstop signal triggers.

Switch a garage light ON when the door contact opens and OFF after 5 minutes. A manual button forces the light ON for 30 minutes regardless of door state, after which it returns to automatic behavior.
Implement a vacation presence simulator: between 19:00 and 22:00, randomly turn a lamp relay ON for 10–20 minutes, then OFF for 5–15 minutes. Reseed the randomizer once daily at 12:00.

Design a lighting controller with enum modes HOME, AWAY, and SLEEP. Use a state machine that combines motion and schedules to decide ON/OFF. The control loop runs at 100 ms with WCET under 2 ms and a watchdog timer that fails safe to OFF on timeout.

Coordinate two heating zone relays from two thermostat inputs. Enforce anti-short-cycling (min OFF 3 minutes) and max ON time 45 minutes. Provide a 15-minute BOOST button per zone and a safety cutoff above 80 C. Include a watchdog timer.

Manage a three-speed fan using three mutually exclusive relays. A 0–3 selector input sets speed. Implement a state machine that inserts a 500 ms all-OFF dead time before changing speeds. Use a watchdog timer to reset to OFF on hang.

Create a four-zone irrigation scheduler with per-zone start times and durations. Pause irrigation when a rain sensor is active. A pump relay must turn ON 2 s before any zone valve and stay ON 2 s after the last valve turns OFF. Include a watchdog timer that forces all valves OFF on timeout.

Control a rolling shutter: UP and DOWN relays are interlocked. Short-press moves in 25% position steps, long-press drives continuously until a limit or a stop command. Stop immediately on obstacle input. Run at 50 ms with WCET under 2 ms.

Drive a dryer booster fan based on humidity rise: turn ON when humidity is +5% above a rolling 10-minute baseline and OFF when it returns to baseline. Include a watchdog timer that defaults to OFF on failure.

Combine motion and light sensors to control a stairway light: only turn ON if motion is detected and ambient light < 100 lux. Implement a state machine with ENTRY_DELAY and HOLD states, and turn OFF after 2 minutes of inactivity. Guarantee WCET under 1 ms.

Regulate a water heater element using time-proportional control over a 20 s window to maintain 55 C. Detect temperature probe faults, enforce a thermal cutoff at 65 C, and require minimum OFF time 5 s. The relay is an SSR.

Automate greenhouse misting with schedule windows and a soil moisture inhibit above 35%. Add a weekly 60 s flush cycle and record the last run timestamp. A watchdog timer is required to ensure outputs revert to OFF on timeout.

Control a door lock strike: activate the relay on valid keypad input for 5 s. Lock out the system for 30 s after five failed attempts. A tamper input should energize an alarm relay for 2 minutes. Use a clear state machine for IDLE, ACCESS, and LOCKOUT.

Implement bathroom fan modes via an enum: OFF, MANUAL, AUTO. MANUAL toggled by a switch; AUTO uses humidity with hysteresis. An LED reflects the current mode. Run at 200 ms with WCET under 3 ms and add a watchdog timer.

Create a holiday lights scene controller for two relay circuits. Provide evening schedules, a button to cycle an enum of scenes, and a long-press that forces OFF until morning. Use a watchdog timer to recover to a known safe scene.

Manage a sump pump using dual floats: primary float runs the pump; a high-water float triggers an alarm relay and forces the pump until cleared. Enforce 10 s cooldown between cycles and track cycles per hour to detect excessive cycling.

Control a ceiling heater with occupancy: require motion and temperature below setpoint to turn ON; if no motion for 20 minutes, switch to ECO mode with a lower setpoint. Implement COMFORT and ECO states and turn OFF above 24 C.

Build a smart outlet with overcurrent protection: sample current at 10 ms and cut the relay if current > 10 A for more than 1 s. Latch the fault until manual reset. Guarantee WCET under 1 ms and include a watchdog timer.

Implement a gate opener with open/close relay interlocks and limit switch feedback. If travel exceeds 15 s without hitting a limit, stop and signal an alarm. Use a state machine with IDLE, OPENING, CLOSING, and FAULT states.

Create a nightlight schedule for children: active 19:00–06:00 in a dim mode simulated by 2 s ON / 8 s OFF cycling. If motion occurs, hold steady ON for 5 minutes, then return to dim mode. Ensure a watchdog timer is in place.

Design a bathroom fan purge: a button initiates a 20-minute purge. If humidity > 65%, extend by 10 minutes; if the door opens, shorten to 10 minutes. Sample humidity every 500 ms and debounce the door contact.

Control a boiler primary pump relay: turn ON when any of two thermostat calls are present, and delay OFF by 120 s after the last call. If boiler temperature > 90 C, force the pump ON. Add a watchdog timer and fail-safe behavior.

Implement an aquarium top-off system: a low float triggers the pump for up to 30 s. If the high float is not reached by then, alarm and lock out. Enforce a minimum 60 s wait between attempts and disable top-off nightly from 00:00 to 06:00.

Create a thermostat with time-proportional PID-like control: compute a duty cycle each 60 s window to maintain 21 C using a single heater relay. Enforce 10 s minimum ON/OFF, adjust integral to prevent rapid cycling, include a watchdog timer, and hard-limit at 28 C.

Develop a whole-house ventilation manager: fuse CO2 (ppm), humidity (%), and motion to control a fan relay. Use enum modes NORMAL, BOOST, and QUIET with a state machine. Limit average duty cycle to 50% per hour. Run at 100 ms with WCET under 3 ms.

Control a hot water recirculation pump with predictive scheduling for morning/evening use, plus triggers from a PIR sensor or button. Limit total pump runtime to 30 minutes per day and stop if the return line exceeds 45 C. Include a watchdog timer.

Manage a dual-speed pool pump using two interlocked relays. Select low or high based on time-of-use tariffs. Trip to FAULT on overcurrent and attempt recovery with exponential backoff. Maintain a 1 s dead time between any speed transitions.

Implement a smart breaker: monitor voltage and current, and open the relay if power > 2000 W for > 5 s or if voltage < 180 V. Log the last fault cause and require manual reset to re-enable. Run at 10 ms with WCET under 2 ms and a watchdog timer.

Build a garage heater safety controller: a state machine drives relays for blower and gas valve through IGNITE, RUN, and COOL states. Validate flame within 5 s or abort. Lock out after 3 failed attempts with a 60 s retry delay. Never allow temperature above 80 C.

Coordinate two HVAC dampers: open/close relays infer positions by timing. Fuse a pressure switch to detect a stuck damper and fall back to safe OPEN. Provide a watchdog timer and heartbeat monitoring to ensure timely actuation.

Create a battery-backed lighting controller with modes MAINS and BACKUP. On BACKUP, limit duty to 20% using 10 s ON / 40 s OFF. Restore normal mode when mains returns and debounce flicker. Enforce a safety cap of 300 W load on backup.

Implement leak detection and shutoff: require confirmation from two moisture sensors and a flow meter trend before declaring a leak. On leak, close a valve relay and cut an appliance relay. Exercise the valve weekly for 2 s. If a reset occurs during valve movement, fail safe with valve open.

Control greenhouse temperature with cascaded logic: a coarse heater relay and a fine vent relay maintain 22 C within ±1 C. Inhibit venting if wind > 8 m/s. Run at 50 ms with WCET under 5 ms and include a watchdog timer.

Design a multi-mode home energy manager with enum modes HOME, AWAY, NIGHT, and VACATION. Coordinate relays for lighting, water heater, and HVAC using schedules, occupancy, and tariffs. Provide manual overrides with timeouts. Clearly specify the watchdog timer behavior and heartbeat.

Create a smart panel for 8 relays using a hierarchical state machine that supports scenes, safety interlocks, and timed actions. Include a built-in self-test at startup that exercises each relay for 200 ms, test hooks for fault injection, and guarantee WCET < 4 ms at a 20 ms tick.

Specify a building entry controller with modes DAY, AUTO, and LOCKDOWN. Integrate keypad access, schedules, door contact, and request-to-exit. Include explicit safety requirements (fail-locked on power loss, anti-tailgate timing, alarm relay), a watchdog timer and recovery strategy, and acceptance tests.

Develop a hot water boiler and circulation system: use time-proportional PID for boiler firing relay while schedule and occupancy govern the circulation relay. Limit relay cycles per hour and include thermal safeties. Define control rate and WCET, and provide a verification plan with state coverage goals.

Produce a facility lighting controller with zones using enums MANUAL, SCHEDULE, SENSOR, and EVENT modes. Enforce interlocks (e.g., decorative and maintenance circuits never together). Include a watchdog timer, health monitoring, detailed timing constraints, and scenario-based test cases including edge conditions.
Create a simple smart switch: when the pushbutton is pressed, toggle a relay output. Debounce the input, and add a watchdog timer that turns the relay off if no loop heartbeat occurs within 250 ms.

Turn a relay on when a button is held, and turn it off when released. Also start a 10-minute auto-off timer once it turns on, whichever comes first. Use a tiny state machine and include a watchdog that forces OFF on timeout.
Schedule a porch light to turn on at 19:00 and off at 23:00 every day. Provide a manual override toggle that times out after 30 minutes back to schedule mode. Use enum modes OFF, ON, SCHEDULE.

Motion-activated light: when motion input goes high, energize a relay for 30 seconds and retrigger on repeated motion. Add simple hysteresis so the relay cannot chatter faster than once per second. Include a watchdog that defaults to OFF.
Implement a two-way toggle: two wall switches control a single relay. Any edge on either input toggles the relay. Debounce each input and ensure atomic updates.
Create a door-activated light: on door open, turn on a relay; on door close, wait 5 seconds then turn it off. Use a small state machine and a 1 kHz scheduler tick.

Timed fan: when a button is pressed, run the fan relay for 15 minutes, then stop. If pressed again while running, extend the timer by 5 minutes, up to 30 minutes max. Include a watchdog that fails safe to OFF.
Implement a simple mode button that cycles enum modes OFF, ON, AUTO on each short press. In AUTO, mirror a digital sensor input to the relay. Use LED indicator patterns per mode.
Nightlight control based on ambient brightness: if the light level falls below 100 lux, turn the relay on; above 200 lux, turn it off. Use hysteresis and a 50 ms update rate.
On boot, keep all relays OFF for 3 seconds, then enter NORMAL mode. If a periodic task fails to run within its WCET of 2 ms, trip a watchdog that forces FAULT mode and turns everything off.
Short-press versus long-press on a pushbutton: short press toggles a lamp relay; long press (>1.5 s) starts a 2-minute timer that then turns it off. Provide LED blink feedback and a watchdog.
E-stop input: if an emergency stop is asserted, immediately de-energize all relays and latch until a manual reset button is held for 2 seconds. Keep the logic simple and deterministic.
Three-position selector switch chooses scene for two relays: ALL_OFF, A_ON_ONLY, BOTH_ON. Debounce selecting and apply changes atomically.
Blink a status LED at 1 Hz in AUTO mode, solid in ON mode, and off in OFF mode, while controlling a single relay accordingly. Use an enum for modes and a periodic tick.
Create a countdown timer switch: pressing the button cycles 5, 10, 20, 30 minute durations; relay turns off when the countdown reaches zero. Show remaining time via brief LED flashes.

Design a smart wall switch as a state machine with enum modes OFF, ON, MOTION, SCHEDULE. Support a manual mode button, a motion sensor input, and daily on/off schedule times. The state machine should resolve conflicts deterministically with priority: E-STOP > MANUAL > MOTION > SCHEDULE.

Implement vacation lighting: turn a relay on and off at user-defined times, with a random offset of +/- 15 minutes applied each day. Provide AWAY and HOME enum modes, a watchdog that defaults to OFF if timing drifts, and a way to skip today.

Stair light control using motion and ambient light: only turn on if motion is detected and light is below 150 lux. Keep the light on for 45 seconds after last motion. Prevent reactivation within 3 seconds of turn-off.

Garage entry light using door sensor plus inactivity: on door open, turn light on; if no motion occurs for 10 minutes, turn off. If motion continues, cap continuous on-time at 30 minutes for energy savings. Include a soft-fail watchdog.

Bathroom fan controller: in AUTO mode, if humidity rises above 65% RH, run the fan; keep running until humidity drops below 55% RH and at least 8 minutes have elapsed. Manual ON overrides but enforces a minimum 5-minute runtime. Use an enum with OFF, ON, AUTO.

Irrigation zone controller for one valve relay with a daily schedule of start time and duration. Add a rain sensor input that immediately cancels irrigation and inhibits future starts for 24 hours. Include a watchdog that fails closed (valve off).

Implement a weekly schedule table for a lamp relay allowing multiple on/off windows per day. Add a manual override that times out after 1 hour or at the next schedule boundary, whichever comes first. Make this a well-defined state machine.

Child bedroom lamp safety: if the relay stays on continuously for more than 2 hours, force it off and require a long-press (2 s) to re-enable. Use states NORMAL and LOCKOUT and ensure a watchdog resets to LOCKOUT on missed heartbeats.

Two-relay alternating stair tread lights: when motion is detected, alternately flash the two relays at 4 Hz for 3 seconds, then hold both on for 20 seconds, and then off. Ensure transitions are precise with a 10 ms tick.

Room heater with simple thermostat: turn a relay on when temperature drops below 19 C and off above 21 C. Include a sensor fault check (out-of-range < -40 C or > 120 C), which should force the relay off and enter FAULT mode.

Doorbell chime debouncer: ignore repeated presses within 2 seconds, allow only one 500 ms activation of the chime relay per press, and block activation during QUIET_HOURS mode (22:00–07:00). Use a clean enum state machine.

Laundry room light automation: turn on when motion is detected or the door opens; turn off 5 minutes after the last activity. If the door is closed and motion continues, extend by 2 minutes. Add a maximum on-time of 30 minutes.

Implement modes NORMAL, VACATION, and AWAY for two lighting circuits with different schedules per mode. Selecting a new mode should apply immediately at the next safe boundary (not mid-transition). Include a supervisory watchdog.

Manual override with timeout: a physical toggle switch forces a relay on, but if left on for more than 1 hour, return to AUTO schedule. Use explicit states WAITING, FORCED_ON, and AUTO with clear timers.

Garden lights with dusk threshold and schedule window: only allow activation when ambient light is below 150 lux and current time is between 18:00 and 23:30. Provide a one-shot PARTY mode for 2 hours regardless of dusk.

Scene controller with two buttons controlling three relays: support single, double, and long-press patterns to select scenes RELAX, BRIGHT, and MOVIE. Debounce, prevent ambiguities, and ensure deterministic selection order.

Extractor fan follow-on: when the bathroom light turns off, keep the fan relay running for 3 minutes; if humidity > 60% RH, extend to 10 minutes, then stop. Manual fan switch should override and cancel follow-on.

Smart outlet thermal protection: if the outlet temperature (Celsius) exceeds 60 C, turn the relay off and latch FAULT until temperature drops below 50 C and a reset is pressed. Run a 20 ms periodic task with WCET < 3 ms.

Two-sensor occupancy: combine motion and door sensors to decide occupancy. If door closed and motion detected, hold lights for 10 minutes after last motion. If door open, shorten hold to 2 minutes. Default off if sensors disagree for >15 minutes.

Holiday lights scheduler: multiple on/off windows and a flashing pattern mode at 2 Hz using a single relay. Provide enum modes OFF, STEADY, FLASH, and SCHEDULE, with a watchdog that disables FLASH if the loop slips.

Implement a PID-based thermostat for a greenhouse heater using a relay and time-proportional control over a 120-second window to maintain 22 C. Include anti-windup, minimum on/off of 10 seconds, sensor plausibility checks, and a watchdog that drops to SAFE_OFF on fault.

Maintain target illuminance of 300 lux using a light sensor and a solid-state relay with time-proportional control at 1 Hz. Use a PI controller with output clamped to 0–100% duty, and ensure WCET <= 4 ms at a 50 ms update rate.

Sensor fusion for occupancy-controlled lighting: fuse PIR motion, door contact, and sound level (dB) to estimate occupancy confidence (0–1). If confidence exceeds 0.7, turn lights on; drop below 0.3 for 2 minutes to turn off. Fail safe to OFF on any sensor fault and include a watchdog.

Ventilation control using two relays (low and high speed) based on CO2 (ppm) and humidity (%RH). Apply hysteresis and interlock so both relays are never on simultaneously. Add an AWAY mode that raises thresholds and a watchdog that forces LOW speed on missed heartbeats.

Water heater schedule with weekly legionella prevention: heat to 60 C for 30 minutes every Sunday at 03:00, otherwise maintain 50 C setpoint via hysteresis. If temperature sensor is invalid, disable heating and enter FAULT. Include minimum off-time of 5 minutes between cycles.

Motorized blinds using two relays (UP and DOWN) with strict interlocks: implement a state machine with states IDLE, MOVING_UP, MOVING_DOWN, and FAULT. Use timed travel (e.g., 14 s full stroke) and stop early if a limit sensor triggers. Ensure both relays cannot energize together and add a watchdog.

Demand response load shedding: coordinate four lighting relays with priorities 1–4. In PEAK mode, shed lower-priority loads first to maintain total on-count <= 2. Restore in reverse order when leaving PEAK. Deterministically resolve ties and include a supervisory watchdog.

Leak detection and water shutoff: if a leak sensor triggers, immediately close the valve relay and latch ALARM state. Provide a weekly self-test that briefly cycles the valve for 2 seconds at 02:00, but only if no leak is present. Watchdog required.

Adaptive hallway lighting: learn average occupancy durations per hour of day and adjust the hold time between 30 and 180 seconds accordingly. Cap learning rate, keep deterministic bounds, and fail safe to a 60-second hold if memory is invalid.

Time-synchronized lighting scenes across three rooms: when a scene is selected, sequence relays with precise offsets (e.g., 0 ms, 250 ms, 500 ms) and guarantee jitter < 10 ms. Provide a heartbeat watchdog and explicit FAULT handling.

Whole-home lighting and outlets coordinator controlling eight relays with enum modes HOME, AWAY, NIGHT, and VACATION. Implement a hierarchical state machine that merges schedules, sensor triggers, and manual overrides with a clear priority scheme. Specify timing: main loop at 20 ms, WCET <= 5 ms, and a watchdog that forces NIGHT with essential loads only if missed.

Multi-zone irrigation controller for six valves with weekly schedules, rain and soil-moisture lockouts, and seasonal percentage adjustment (50–150%). Include concurrency rules so only one valve runs at a time, pump relay interlock, and comprehensive test cases covering overlapping schedules, sensor failures, and power loss recovery.

Energy shedding and restore orchestrator for a smart apartment: manage ten relay loads with modes NORMAL, ECO, and CRITICAL. Enforce constraints (max 3 simultaneous loads; never shed fridge or medical device relays), handle delayed restarts with randomized backoff, and include self-tests and a watchdog. Provide acceptance criteria and scenario tests.

Garage automation supervisor for lighting and door motor relays with strict safety: implement interlocks to prevent motor relays from energizing during obstruction, timed light follow-on, and a FAULT state for sensor inconsistencies. Define enum modes MANUAL, AUTO, and LOCKOUT, give WCET and watchdog settings, and list invariants to enforce.

Comprehensive smart-home scheduler with user profiles and quiet hours: coordinate relays for lights, fans, and valves across daily and weekly calendars, one-shot events, and overrides. Use a deterministic conflict resolver, a watchdog supervisor, and provide a test plan including edge cases at midnight, DST changes, and power restoration.

Toggle a lamp relay when a wall switch is pressed, with 30 ms debounce. Include a watchdog timer that forces the relay Off if the control loop stalls for more than 500 ms. Run the control loop at 100 Hz and keep worst-case execution time under 1 ms.

Make a momentary button hold the relay On while pressed and turn it Off on release, with a safety auto-off after 5 seconds of continuous On. Add a watchdog timer that resets the state machine if no input edges are seen for 2 seconds.

Schedule a daily run at 07:00 to turn on a coffee machine relay for 8 minutes. Ensure missed events are not replayed after power-up. On startup, default to Off and wait for the next scheduled time. Provide an enum Mode Auto and Off and a watchdog timer that drops to Off if the scheduler overruns.

Control two-way staircase lighting so either of two switches toggles the light relay, but enforce a 500 ms cooldown to reject chatter. Track On and Off with an enum and retain the last state across resets.

Implement a fan boost button that cycles through enum modes Off, Low, High on each press. Map Low to a 1 minute run and High to a 10 minute run; pressing again cancels. Build as a small state machine and add a watchdog timer that reverts to Off if any timer misbehaves.

Create nightlight automation: between 22:00 and 06:00, motion triggers the lamp relay for 2 minutes; outside that window ignore motion. Run at 10 Hz with WCET 1 ms. A watchdog timer should force Off if the scheduler does not tick within 300 ms.

Require a double press within 1 second to energize a garage gate relay for 500 ms. Single presses are ignored. Use a state machine and include a watchdog timer that reverts to idle if no presses arrive within 2 seconds.

Add a heater safety cutoff: if the temperature sensor reports above 80 Celsius, de-energize the relay and latch a fault until a manual reset. A heartbeat watchdog timer at 100 ms should force the relay Off if the sensor data is stale for 500 ms.

Define an aquarium light schedule that turns the relay on at a provided sunrise time and off at 21:30. Do not replay missed events after power loss. Include enum modes Auto and Off. Enforce safe Off on any scheduler fault via a watchdog timer.

Control a smart outlet from textual commands ON and OFF to drive the relay. Ignore invalid commands and default to Off on communications loss. Add a 1 second command watchdog timer to prevent stale commands from keeping the relay On.

Create a doorbell one-shot: when a dry contact closes, energize the chime relay for 800 ms and ignore retriggers while active. Include a watchdog timer that clears the output if the timing logic exceeds expected duration.

Implement basic window shade control: a single button short press toggles run or stop; a long press over 1.5 seconds starts opening. Use a small state machine with enum Direction None, Up, Down. Add a watchdog timer that stops motion if no button updates for 300 ms.

Build a pulse stretcher: when a brief tap is detected, keep the relay On for 3 seconds. If another tap occurs during the stretch, extend by 3 seconds. Include a watchdog timer to reset the state if the timer overflows.

Control a bathroom fan by humidity: turn On when humidity exceeds 60 percent RH and Off when it falls below 55 percent RH, with a maximum run time of 45 minutes. A watchdog timer must force Off if the sensor is missing.

Create a hallway lamp schedule with manual override: between 18:00 and 23:00 keep the light On, outside this window Off. Manual override via enum Mode Auto, On, Off. The watchdog timer should restore Auto after 30 minutes in override.

Design interlocked control for two relays from two switches where only one relay can be On at a time. Add 100 ms deadtime between switching. Build a state machine with enum Active None, A, B. The watchdog timer should force both Off on any fault.

Implement a security light that turns on for 3 minutes when motion is detected and ambient light is below 50 lux. Extend by 1 minute on additional motion. Ignore stale sensor values older than 5 seconds. Run at 20 Hz with WCET 1 ms. Include a watchdog timer that forces Off on scheduler failure.

Create a four-zone sprinkler controller: schedule each zone duration in minutes, ensure only one zone runs at a time, and pause if a rain sensor is wet, resuming the next day. Provide enum Mode Auto, Manual, Off. A heartbeat watchdog timer at 200 ms sets all relays Off on timeout.

Control a hot water recirculation pump: when any of three buttons is pressed, run the pump for 3 minutes, then lock out for 10 minutes. Allow manual Force Off. Implement as a timed state machine. Run at 100 Hz with WCET under 3 ms. Add a watchdog timer to drop to Off on deadlock.

Manage a sump pump with anti-chatter: start when the float is high, enforce minimum on time 2 seconds and minimum off time 5 seconds. Alarm if a single run exceeds 10 minutes. The watchdog timer must set pump Off if the float appears stuck high for over 1 hour.

Build a curtain controller: Up and Down relays are mutually exclusive. A short press jogs for 1 second, a long press runs until the corresponding limit input. Use enum Direction None, Up, Down and debounce buttons 20 ms. The watchdog timer stops motion on any anomaly.

Schedule a greenhouse vent fan: weekdays run 09:00 to 18:00, weekends 10:00 to 14:00. Provide manual modes Off, Auto, Force. Safe Off if the temperature sensor is missing. Control loop tick at 10 Hz with WCET 1 ms. Include a watchdog timer that resets to Off on missed ticks.

Create a pet feeder relay: at 07:00 and 18:00 activate for a configurable number of seconds. If a lid switch is open, skip and record a fault that requires acknowledgment. Add a watchdog timer that cancels a feed if run time exceeds its limit by 10 percent.

Implement a smart outlet with energy limit: if measured power exceeds 1500 watts for more than 2 seconds, cut the relay and latch a fault. Require manual reset after 30 seconds. Provide enum Mode Auto, On, Off. A watchdog timer turns Off if power data is stale.

Create an entry light timer: a switch or remote command turns the light On; door opening extends the timer to 5 minutes, otherwise use 2 minutes. Manual Off always wins. Merge triggers with a state machine. A watchdog timer forces Off on inactivity faults.

Implement a towel rail thermostat with bang-bang control: below 35 Celsius turn On, above 40 Celsius turn Off. Include manual modes Auto and Off. Poll sensors at 2 Hz with WCET 1 ms. Add a watchdog timer to default Off if the sensor times out.

Define laundry room light behavior: double press toggles a 30 minute timer, single press toggles immediate On and Off, long press enters Night mode with a shorter 5 minute timer. Represent modes as an enum. Implement as a state machine with a watchdog timer to exit Night after 2 hours.

Set a holiday window lights schedule: from December 20 to January 5, turn on 17:00 to 23:30; otherwise 18:30 to 22:00. Handle leap years and midnight crossings. Evaluate the next event within 1 second after power-up. Include a watchdog timer to recover to Off on schedule errors.

Add an HVAC fan circulate feature: run the fan 10 minutes each hour in Auto mode; if the heating relay is already On, skip the circulate cycle. Implement with a schedule wheel and a state machine. Guarantee WCET 2 ms at 50 Hz. A watchdog timer forces Off on missed scheduler ticks.

Control a garage courtesy light: when the door opens turn the light On; keep it on for 5 minutes after close; extend on ongoing motion up to a maximum of 30 minutes. Include a watchdog timer that clears the light if event processing stalls.

Implement aquarium top-off: enable a pump when level is Low and disable when High. Cap each run to 45 seconds and enforce a 5 minute lockout. After three consecutive timeouts, raise an alarm output. Use a state machine and include a watchdog timer.

Create a smart switch with presence awareness: if presence input indicates Home, a short press toggles the relay; if Away, require a press held for at least 2 seconds. Represent presence as an enum Home or Away. Use a watchdog timer that defaults to Away if presence updates stop for 10 seconds.

Manage blinds using sunrise and sunset offsets: open at sunrise plus 15 minutes and close at sunset minus 10 minutes. Update offsets daily. Ensure triggers are idempotent and do not replay after power loss. Include a watchdog timer to revert to Off on schedule failure.

Add garden watering boost: pressing the boost button starts a 5 minute run unless soil moisture is above 35 percent. Enum Mode Auto, Boost, Off. After timeout return to Auto. The watchdog timer drops to Off on sensor fault.

Provide nighttime path lighting for elderly care: between 00:00 and 05:00, if bed exit and motion are both detected, turn on path lights for 7 minutes. Ignore sensor readings older than 2 seconds. A state machine manages triggers. A watchdog timer forces Off if sensors stop reporting.

Implement room heating with PID: maintain temperature at a setpoint in Celsius by modulating a relay using time-proportional control with a 10 second window. Include anti-windup and output limits. Safe Off on sensor failure. Run at 4 Hz with WCET 2 ms. A watchdog timer trips if the loop misses two consecutive ticks.

Control a water tank fill valve using sensor fusion: combine a float switch and an ultrasonic level estimate with confidence logic to command the relay. Prefer the float for safety but ignore chatter with a 200 ms filter. Fail-safe closes the valve. Run at 20 Hz with WCET 1 ms. The watchdog timer forces the valve closed on stale data.

Compute ventilation demand by fusing CO2 in ppm and a VOC index. Implement enum modes Off, Auto, Boost. In Auto, drive a fan relay using proportional-on-time per minute. Enter emergency Boost if CO2 exceeds 1500 ppm for 3 minutes. Use a watchdog timer to ensure safe Off if any sensor is invalid.

Protect boiler return temperature: use a PID to maintain return water at 55 Celsius by cycling a pump relay. Enforce a hard cut and latched fault if outlet temperature exceeds 80 Celsius. Include a warmup state machine and a heartbeat watchdog timer at 100 ms.

Create irrigation with weather awareness: integrate rain sensor status, a forecast precipitation input in millimeters, and soil moisture to decide whether to run the morning schedule. Skip watering if recent rain exceeds 2 mm. Support enum RainDelay 24h and 48h. Include a watchdog timer that cancels runs on stale data.

Implement occupancy-based lighting via sensor fusion: combine motion in two rooms and door contact changes to infer presence. Suppress lighting if ambient light exceeds 120 lux. Use a state machine with enum states Vacant, Probable, Occupied. Guarantee WCET under 2 ms at 20 Hz. The watchdog timer returns to Vacant on missed updates.

Control greenhouse misting with PI: maintain 65 percent relative humidity using proportional-integral control translated into relay duty within a 60 second window. Inhibit misting if temperature is below 10 Celsius. Active only between 06:00 and 20:00. The watchdog timer switches to Off on any fault.

Schedule a water heater sanitation cycle: once weekly at 03:00 elevate setpoint to 65 Celsius for 30 minutes then return to normal. Add a safety interlock if the sensor reads above 75 Celsius. Use a state machine with enums Idle, Heat, Sanitize. Keep WCET under 5 ms per tick. A watchdog timer cancels the cycle on anomalies.

Detect sump pump failure by fusing mains presence, pump current draw, and water level. If anomaly persists for 10 seconds, assert a siren relay and send a notification output. Use a watchdog timer that polls every 100 ms and forces a periodic siren self-test every 24 hours.

Emulate soft-start for an incandescent load using a solid-state relay: increase on-time within a 1 second ramp to reduce inrush. Derate if a case temperature sensor reaches 70 Celsius. The watchdog timer trips to Off on thermal runaway. Ensure WCET 1 ms at 1 kHz scheduling.

Design a whole-home vacation mode controller: enum modes Normal, Away, Night, AwayNight. Orchestrate six lighting relays with randomized on windows between 18:00 and 23:30 when in Away modes. Manual wall switch inputs must override per circuit with a 15 minute local timer. Include a watchdog timer and provide a test plan covering daylight saving transitions, power loss during active periods, simultaneous overrides, and verification of safe default to Off.

Create a multi-zone hot water recirculation manager with three pumps, motion sensors near bathrooms, and schedule windows. Modes Auto, Eco, Party. Enforce priority so no more than one pump runs and limit total daily runtime to 2 hours per pump. WCET under 3 ms at 50 Hz, watchdog timeout 300 ms. Deliver a verification checklist for state transitions, lockouts, and timing.

Build comprehensive garage automation: coordinate door motor relay, courtesy light relay, safety beam input, and presence sensor. Modes Manual, Auto, Locked. The state machine must handle obstruction retries, motion timeouts, and power-up recovery. Define watchdog timer behavior. Provide a test matrix for debouncing, obstruction handling, lockout behavior, and fail-safe to Locked.

Implement a smart thermostat supervisor with dual-loop control: an outer scheduler sets temperature setpoints by time and day, while an inner PID modulates the heating relay duty. Modes Heat, Off, FrostProtect. Add a safety lockout if the sensor changes faster than 3 Celsius per second. WCET 2 ms at 4 Hz. Include a validation plan with worst-case timing and watchdog failover tests.

Create an energy management coordinator that orchestrates relays for a water heater, dryer, and an EV outlet under a 3 kilowatt total power cap. Modes Auto, Shed, Override. Use schedule windows and priority-based shedding. Fuse whole-home power readings with per-circuit currents. The watchdog timer drops to Shed on stale data. Require comprehensive unit tests, simulation of peak events, and a formal state machine review.

Create a simple timer light: when a momentary wall switch is pressed, energize a relay driving a hallway light for 10 minutes, then switch off automatically. Include debounce for the switch and default the relay to OFF on startup and if a watchdog timer ever expires.

Turn on a relay when a motion sensor goes active and keep it on for 30 seconds after the last motion; otherwise keep it off. Use a small state machine for idle/active and make sure any watchdog timeout forces the relay OFF.
When the front door contact opens, turn on the porch light relay for 2 minutes; do nothing when it closes. Ignore repeated openings during the timer window.

Implement a daily schedule: turn an outlet relay ON at 06:30 and OFF at 22:00 local time. If the system restarts, restore the correct state from the schedule immediately. Use a watchdog that reverts the relay to OFF if the main loop misses its heartbeat.
Make a pushbutton toggle a lamp relay: each short press toggles ON/OFF. A long press (>2 seconds) should force OFF. Debounce the input and ensure the relay is OFF if the watchdog trips.
