Hallway light with two virtual switches: two pushbuttons at opposite ends toggle the same relay. Debounce both and ensure atomic state changes. If both presses arrive within 200 ms, treat as a single toggle. Include a periodic watchdog pet.

Pet feeder relay: at 07:30 and 18:00 activate the motor relay for 7 seconds. If the lid sensor is not closed, skip activation. On jam detection via overcurrent > 1.5 A, cut power immediately and enter Fault until manually reset.

Aquarium lighting with two relays (blue and white): at 07:00 turn on blue, then white after 15 minutes. At 21:00 turn off white, then blue after 15 minutes. A Feed button pauses any changes for 10 minutes.

Security lighting: during 00:00–05:00, if motion triggers twice within 5 minutes, latch the floodlight On for the rest of the night. Otherwise, turn On for 2 minutes per trigger. Reset everything at sunrise.
Laundry reminder: monitor two vibration sensors from washer and dryer. When both are quiet for 5 minutes, pulse a notifier relay for 30 seconds. Suppress notifications between 22:00 and 07:00.

Attic fan control: turn On when attic temp > 35 °C, indoor temp > 24 °C, and outdoor temp < 30 °C, and humidity < 80% RH. Turn Off when any condition is not met for 3 minutes. Add a 10-second startup delay to avoid short cycling.

Dual sump pumps with lead/lag rotation: alternate the lead pump daily at 00:00. When demand is active, start the lead pump; if no flow confirmation in 5 s, start the lag pump and lock out the failed one. Provide a manual reset to clear lockouts.
Holiday lights program: weekdays 18:00–22:30, weekends 17:00–23:59. Use an enum Pattern {Solid, SlowBlink, FastBlink} controlled by a button. Keep pattern timing stable and free from drift.

Heat lamp safety controller: if the nearby temperature exceeds 70 °C, switch Off and enter a 10-minute cooldown. If the watchdog trips, force Off. Require a two-button confirmation to re-enable. Record shutdown cause in an enum.

Pool pump schedule: run 08:00–11:00 and 16:00–19:00 daily (two windows). If water temperature < 10 °C, reduce each window to 1 hour. Add a Manual Clean mode that runs 30 minutes regardless of schedule.

Thermostatic control for an electric heater: use PID to maintain 22.0 °C with ±0.5 °C tolerance. Sample temperature at 10 Hz and drive a time-proportional relay with a 60 s window capped at 60% average power over 10 minutes. On sensor fault or watchdog (500 ms) expiry, force Off.

Dehumidifier controller using PID: target 50% RH, control via a relay using 2-minute time-proportional windows. Enforce a minimum 3-minute compressor off-time to protect it. Control loop rate 5 Hz with WCET < 2 ms.

Occupancy-driven lighting using sensor fusion: combine motion, door, and sound inputs to estimate Occupied/Unoccupied. Turn lights On only when Occupied and lux < 80. Decay to Unoccupied after 5 minutes inactivity. Provide a Test mode that visualizes state via LED patterns and ensure watchdog forces Off on failure.

Smart water heater: PID regulate outlet temperature to 55 °C with anti-windup. Limit effective duty to keep below 2 kW. Overtemp trip at 65 °C requires manual reset. Run at 1 Hz, WCET < 5 ms, and open the relay on watchdog expiry.

Greenhouse irrigation with sensor fusion: combine two soil moisture sensors via a weighted average. If the absolute difference exceeds 15%, enter Fault and inhibit watering. Otherwise, water at 06:00 for 5 minutes. Use a state machine: Ready, Watering, Fault. Log faults.

HVAC damper actuator via two relays (Open/Close pulses): maintain indoor CO2 under 1000 ppm using PID to compute pulse durations. Prevent simultaneous relay activation and enforce end-stop timing. Run at 1 Hz with WCET < 3 ms. On watchdog, stop all outputs.

Sump pump controller with fusion: use a float switch OR rising water rate from a distance sensor to start. Stop when both indicate safe for 10 s. Alternate between two pumps daily. Detect dry-run if current < 0.2 A and stop. Safety: max continuous run 10 minutes with 5-minute rest.

Boiler circulation control: maintain 50 °C return temperature using time-proportional relay (30 s window) with PID. Apply outdoor reset to adjust the setpoint based on outdoor temperature. Modes: Eco, Normal, Boost (enum). Overtemp > 70 °C latches a fault requiring manual acknowledge.

Adaptive desk lighting using relay banks: target 300 lux with PID by switching three lamp banks. Enforce minimum dwell of 30 s per bank to avoid rapid toggling. Update at 2 Hz, watchdog 1 s, and ensure at least one bank can be Off to limit load.

Smart lock strike control: fuse keypad attempts with a wireless presence indicator to decide unlock. Pulse the strike relay for 800 ms on success. After 5 failed attempts, lock out for 2 minutes. Watchdog must ensure the default Locked state. Log events.

Design a whole-home vacation mode for six lighting circuits with randomized schedules between 18:00–23:00, ensuring no more than two circuits are On simultaneously. Provide per-circuit state machines and a supervisory mode manager (Normal, Vacation, AwayNightOnly). Add a 1 s watchdog, scheduler period 100 ms, WCET < 4 ms. Include a test plan for mode switching, max-on constraint, and randomness bounds.

Multi-zone heating for four rooms with enum modes Off, Eco, Comfort, Boost per zone and a global FrostProtect. Each zone drives a relay valve using 5-minute time-proportional windows. Use occupancy fusion (motion + schedule) to auto-switch modes. Implement fail-safes on sensor faults, a supervisory watchdog, and provide unit tests for state transitions, timing windows, and frost protection.

Comprehensive irrigation controller: 8 zones with calendar schedules, skip-day rules, and seasonal percent scaling. Include a master pump relay interlock and verify flow per zone; if no flow detected within 10 s, abort the zone and fail over safely. System modes: Maintenance, Auto, Manual, Fault. Run at 10 Hz with WCET < 5 ms and a watchdog. Define acceptance tests for dry-run, rain skip, flow fault, and manual override.

Garage automation: control door opener relay, lights, and ventilation fan. Modes: Home, Away, Night, Service. Safety interlocks: prohibit door motion if obstruction is active; lights follow door movement and remain On for 3 minutes after closing; fan runs if CO2 > 1200 ppm or after engine-start detection. Include a 500 ms watchdog and a priority event handler with WCET < 3 ms at 50 Hz. Provide a verification checklist for interlocks and fault recovery.
Make a simple toggle: when the wall switch is pressed, toggle a single relay. Debounce the input by 50 ms and ensure the relay defaults OFF on power-up.
Create a daily schedule that turns a porch light relay ON at 18:00 and OFF at 23:00 local time. On reboot, resume the correct state for the current time without replaying past events.
When a button is pressed, energize an outlet relay for exactly 10 minutes, then turn it off. A second press during the countdown cancels the timer.
Turn on a light relay when motion is detected and keep it on for 30 seconds after the last motion. Each new motion should extend the timer.

Control a small water pump relay from a tank level switch. Only energize the pump when the switch indicates low level, and enforce a minimum OFF time of 5 seconds between starts to avoid rapid cycling.
Implement a doorbell: on button press, energize the chime relay for 1 second and then ignore any further presses for 2 seconds.
Mirror a two-position wall switch to a fan relay: ON follows ON, OFF follows OFF. On any fault or startup, default to OFF.
Set up a simple daily schedule: turn a coffee maker relay ON at 07:30 and OFF at 08:00. Do not run missed events after power loss.
Use a single pushbutton to toggle a lamp relay. A long-press (>2 seconds) forces the relay OFF regardless of current state.
When a door contact opens, turn the hallway light relay ON; when it closes, turn it OFF. Debounce the contact by 30 ms.
Run a feeder motor relay for 20 seconds when the feed button is pressed. Ignore additional presses while active.
On pressing a momentary switch, pulse a relay for 500 ms to trigger a garage opener, then enforce a 5-second lockout.
Implement a staircase timer: a button press turns the light relay ON for 2 minutes; any press during that period restarts the timer.
Expose a remote boolean control variable; when it is true, energize the relay, and when false, de-energize it. Changes should take effect immediately.
Energize a relay only while a button is held down. Debounce the input by 20 ms so brief noise doesn't flicker the output.
Create two-way control of a single light with two switches. Either switch toggles the light, and the system remembers current state across reboots.
Define an enum Mode with OFF, ON, and SCHEDULED for a fan relay. In SCHEDULED, run 06:00–08:00 and 18:00–21:00 daily. Provide a manual override that returns to SCHEDULED after 30 minutes.
Turn a light relay on only when motion is detected and ambient light is below 100 lux. Keep it on for 60 seconds after the last motion.
Add a 'vacation' mode: between 18:00 and 23:00, randomly vary light relay ON times (1–15 minutes) with OFF gaps (2–20 minutes). Include a watchdog timer that forces the relay OFF if the logic stalls.
Interlock two relays that drive a motor forward and reverse so they are never ON at the same time. On direction change, enforce a 100 ms break-before-make.
Control a sump pump relay from a float switch, enforcing a minimum ON time of 15 seconds once started and a minimum OFF time of 10 seconds to reduce wear.
If a door remains open for more than 30 seconds, turn the heater relay OFF; otherwise allow it to run. Provide a manual override switch that forces ON for 10 minutes.
Implement weekday/weekend schedules for a heater relay: Mon–Fri ON 06:30–08:00 and 18:00–22:00; Sat–Sun ON 08:00–10:00 and 19:00–23:00. Include a button to skip the next ON event.
Build a selector with three buttons and three relays for lighting circuits such that pressing any button turns ON its relay and turns OFF the other two.

Drive a latching valve using a state machine: a command to OPEN produces a 200 ms pulse on the OPEN relay; a command to CLOSE produces a 200 ms pulse on the CLOSE relay. Ignore redundant commands and report current state.
Thermostat logic with hysteresis: maintain 22 C with a heater relay using ±0.5 C hysteresis. If the temperature sensor fails, force the relay OFF and raise an alarm flag.
Sunrise/sunset scheduler: turn the garden lights relay ON at sunset minus 15 minutes and OFF at 23:30. If time-of-day is unavailable, fall back to a fixed 18:00–22:00 schedule.

Bathroom control: when the light switch turns OFF, keep the exhaust fan relay running for an additional 5 minutes. Also, if humidity exceeds 70%, start the fan regardless of the light and stop it when humidity falls below 60%.
Differentiate button gestures: single-click toggles Relay A, double-click toggles Relay B, and long-press (>1.5 s) turns both OFF. Debounce and deglitch appropriately.
Pause a radiator relay when a window contact is OPEN. Only resume the relay if the window has been CLOSED continuously for at least 3 minutes, with 2 seconds of debounce on the contact.
Use a watchdog timer that expects a periodic 1-minute heartbeat from a cloud service. If missed for 15 minutes, fall back to a local evening schedule (17:00–22:00) for the lamp relay.
Irrigation scheduler running at 50 Hz control rate with WCET ≤ 1 ms: run Zone 1 for 5 minutes, then Zone 2 for 8 minutes. If an overrun is detected, immediately turn all valves OFF and flag a fault.
Garage area lighting: turn ON when either the door opens or motion is detected; turn OFF 3 minutes after both are inactive. Limit to at most 3 activations within any 10-minute window.
Door strike control: on valid access signal, energize the strike relay for up to 5 seconds. If the door opens sooner, release immediately. Enforce a 30-second cooldown between activations.
Time-proportional heater control using a PID to maintain 22.0 C. Use a 30-second window for relay duty cycling, apply anti-windup, and hard-cut OFF at 60 C as a safety limit.

Control a room light via sensor fusion: combine PIR motion and ambient sound level (dB) into a confidence score. Turn the light relay ON if confidence exceeds a threshold and no light is already present; turn it OFF after 2 minutes of silence and stillness. Add a watchdog that forces OFF on fault.

Automate a hot-water recirculation pump: run on a schedule (06:00–09:00, 17:00–22:00) and on-demand when a flow sensor detects hot water use. Enforce minimum OFF time of 2 minutes and cap total runtime to 20 minutes per hour.

Greenhouse ventilation: use a PID to regulate air temperature at 25 C by time-proportioning a fan relay (15-second window). If temperature exceeds 35 C, trigger an emergency vent relay and keep it ON until below 30 C. Observe a control-loop WCET of 2 ms.

Motorized blinds with two relays (UP/DOWN) and limit sensors: implement an interlocked state machine with enum modes AUTO, MANUAL, and SCHEDULED. Schedule open at sunrise and close at sunset, detect jams via current spike input, and stop immediately on jam.

Gas valve safety control: require both a physical enable switch and a secure remote command to energize the valve relay. If a gas leak sensor triggers, shut OFF and latch out until a manual reset. Include a watchdog timer that fails safe to OFF.

Ventilation damper: follow an enum Mode SEASONAL with SUMMER and WINTER schedules, but also open whenever CO2 exceeds 1000 ppm and close when it drops below 800 ppm. On sensor fault, move to a safe default and log the fault flag.

Load shedding: manage three appliance relays with priority 1–3 so total estimated power stays below 2.0 kW. Shed lowest priority first during peak tariff hours (17:00–21:00) and restore with hysteresis. Respect minimum ON/OFF durations of 5 minutes.
Smart fridge defrost: schedule a defrost heater relay for 10 minutes every 12 hours, but terminate early if evaporator temperature rises above 5 C. Prevent back-to-back defrosts after power recovery.

Garden irrigation with sensor fusion: schedule watering at 05:30, but skip if two soil moisture sensors both read above 30% or if a rain sensor is wet. Detect leaks via a flow sensor and shut all valves within 500 ms on leak detection. Add a watchdog that closes valves on fault.

Design a whole-home lighting controller with enum SystemMode: NORMAL, NIGHT, AWAY, and EMERGENCY. Use a state machine to apply different schedules per mode, transition to EMERGENCY on fire alarm, and guarantee all non-emergency relays default OFF at startup and on any fault. Include a watchdog, specify a 100 Hz control rate with WCET ≤ 1 ms, and outline self-test procedures and acceptance criteria for each mode transition.

Implement a multi-zone sprinkler with weather-aware scheduling and safety: up to 4 valves, never open more than 2 at once, enforce a 2-second gap between zone switches, and close all within 300 ms if the watchdog trips. Include a MAINTENANCE mode that allows manual jog of each valve. Provide a test plan covering dry-run schedules, sensor faults, and overrun handling.

Create a home energy manager for three relays (water heater, EV charger, HVAC) with enum modes COST_SAVING, COMFORT, and MANUAL. Use tariff schedules and solar surplus estimates to decide which loads to enable while ensuring aggregate current never exceeds 16 A. Specify invariants, hysteresis, blackout recovery behavior, watchdog handling, and a list of scenario-based tests.

Control a residential dumbwaiter with relays for UP, DOWN, BRAKE, and DOOR interlock switches. Build a safety-critical state machine with door-closed requirement, brake release timing, travel timeouts, and emergency stop. Define modes IDLE, MOVING_UP, MOVING_DOWN, and FAULT, include WCET and watchdog requirements, and provide a comprehensive verification checklist.

Coordinate a smart transfer switch panel with contactor relays for GRID, GENERATOR, and LOAD. Define enum modes GRID, GEN, and ISLAND, implement strict interlocks to prevent cross-connection, and manage scheduled load shedding during transitions. Include startup self-test, periodic watchdog kicking, 50 Hz control loop with WCET ≤ 1 ms, and exhaustive test cases for mode changes, faults, and recovery.

Make a simple on/off control for a lamp relay using one push button. Use a two-state enum (OFF, ON) and toggle on a short press; ignore presses shorter than 30 ms for debounce. Include a basic watchdog that must be kicked every 200 ms and forces the relay OFF if it ever expires.

Hold-to-run behavior: while the wall switch is held, keep the appliance relay energized; turn it off immediately when released. Add 100 ms input filtering and a fail-safe that forces the relay OFF if the watchdog timer is not serviced within 300 ms.

When the doorbell button is pressed, energize a chime relay for exactly 1.0 s, then reject any further presses for 3.0 s (lockout). Keep the behavior deterministic and include a simple watchdog heartbeat.

If a motion sensor goes active, turn on a hallway light relay immediately and keep it on for 30 s after motion stops. Debounce the motion input by 50 ms and ensure the relay turns OFF if a watchdog expires.

Create a nightlight controller that turns a relay ON when the ambient light level drops below a threshold and OFF when it rises back above it. Use a small hysteresis to prevent chatter and a two-state enum for ON/OFF.

Temperature switch: if the room temperature falls below 5.0 °C, energize the heater relay; if it goes above 7.0 °C, turn it off (hysteresis). Include a watchdog that resets the output to OFF on failure.
Implement a bathroom fan 'boost' timer: a single push button starts the fan relay for 10 minutes, then automatically turns it off. Reject presses shorter than 40 ms and incorporate a basic watchdog.
Daily schedule for a porch light relay: turn ON at 18:00 and OFF at 23:00. If power cycles, resume correct state based on the current time. Add a simple two-state enum and a watchdog kick.
When a 'test' switch is ON, blink a relay with a 2 s period (1 s ON, 1 s OFF). When the switch is OFF, keep the relay OFF. Include a watchdog that disables blinking on timeout.

Make a relay that only toggles on a double-click of the control button (two presses within 400 ms). Single presses do nothing. Use a tiny state machine to track click timing and a watchdog to fail-safe to OFF.
If a window sensor opens, sound a siren relay for 15 s, then silence it automatically. Ignore further openings while active. Keep logic simple with a two-state enum and a watchdog fallback to OFF.
Pet feeder trigger: when the feed button is pressed, energize the motor relay for 4 s then stop. Ignore additional presses until the 4 s run completes. Include debounce and a watchdog.
Irrigation single-zone timer: on a start button press, turn valve relay ON for 20 minutes, then OFF. Provide a cancel button that stops immediately. Add a watchdog that forces OFF on timeout.

Vacation mode light: when the 'away' switch is ON, randomly turn a lamp relay ON for 5–15 minutes once per hour within 18:00–23:00; when 'away' is OFF, keep the lamp OFF. Watchdog must force OFF on failure.

Implement a simple relay pattern generator that, when a mode switch is ON, outputs a repeating pattern: 300 ms ON, 300 ms OFF, 300 ms ON, then 1.5 s OFF. When the switch is OFF, keep the relay OFF. Include a basic watchdog.

Schedule a coffee maker relay to turn ON at 07:00 and OFF at 07:30 daily. Provide a manual override button that toggles the current state and suspends the schedule until the next day. Include a state machine and watchdog.

Create a two-way control for a single light using two wall switches. Either switch toggles the light, and the final relay state is consistent regardless of which switch was used last. Use a small state machine and ensure debouncing.

Garage light logic: opening the door sensor turns the light relay ON for 2 minutes; pressing a manual button while on extends to 10 minutes; closing the door early does not cancel the timer. Force OFF if a watchdog fails.

Control motorized blinds with two relays (UP/DOWN). Implement an interlocked state machine with enum states STOPPED, MOVING_UP, MOVING_DOWN, and FAULT. Use timeouts to stop movement after 20 s and enter FAULT if both relays would be on.

Two-zone irrigation controller: configurable start time and duration per zone, skip watering if a rain sensor is active, and enforce a 5 s delay between zones. Provide a clear state machine and watchdog supervision.

Staircase lighting: two motion sensors (top and bottom) can start a 60 s timer that keeps the light relay ON; additional motion retriggers the timer. Implement input debounce, a state machine, and a fail-safe watchdog.

Laundry reminder: detect when a vibration sensor goes quiet for 5 minutes, then flash an outlet relay at 1 Hz for 30 s. If vibration resumes during flashing, stop flashing. Include debounce and watchdog.

Bathroom fan with modes: enum OFF, AUTO, MANUAL. In AUTO, turn the fan relay ON above 70% RH and OFF below 60% RH (hysteresis). In MANUAL, a button toggles the fan. Always fail safe to OFF on watchdog timeout.

Weekly schedule for a water heater relay with weekday/weekend times. A 'holiday' input disables scheduled ON events but allows manual ON via button. Enforce a minimum OFF time of 10 minutes to prevent short cycling. Add a watchdog.
Smart outlet energy saver: if measured current stays below 0.1 A for 30 minutes, turn the outlet relay OFF. A button press turns it back ON immediately. Provide a state machine and watchdog timer.

Sump pump control: primary float switch starts the pump relay until the float drops; a high-level float triggers an alarm relay and forces the pump ON. Add a 3 s anti-chatter filter and watchdog-based fail-safe.

Door lock actuator with lock/unlock buttons and a state machine: LOCKING (2 s drive), LOCKED, UNLOCKING (2 s drive), UNLOCKED, and FAULT if timing overruns. Interlock outputs so both relays cannot energize at once. Include a watchdog.

Scene cycling with one button: each press advances an enum through SCENE1, SCENE2, SCENE3, and OFF, setting three relays accordingly. Long-press resets to OFF. Debounce inputs and add watchdog supervision.

Doorbell quiet hours: between 22:00 and 07:00, ignore button presses and flash a status relay briefly instead; outside these hours, activate the chime relay for 1 s. Include timekeeping, debouncing, and watchdog.

Circulation fan schedule: when enabled, run the fan relay 10 minutes every hour on the hour; a manual toggle forces immediate ON or OFF until the next hour boundary. Enforce a state machine and watchdog.

Pool pump routine: daily schedule ON from 09:00 to 17:00. A 'backwash' button triggers a separate 3-minute sequence on a valve relay followed by pump run, then return to normal schedule. Ensure sequences are mutually exclusive and watchdog-protected.

Heater anti-short-cycle control: with a thermostat input, enter HEATING when requested and leave when satisfied, but enforce minimum 5 min OFF and 2 min ON durations using a state machine. Include watchdog and fail-safe OFF.

Heated towel rail safety: if temperature exceeds 75 °C, de-energize the relay and require a manual reset button to resume. Add periodic sampling, input debouncing, and a watchdog that forces the output OFF on timeout.

Dehumidifier outlet: turn ON above 65% RH and OFF below 55% RH, but if a window sensor opens, force OFF and only resume 5 minutes after the window closes. Implement a clear state machine and watchdog.

Ventilation boost control: long-press (>2 s) starts a 20-minute fan boost; additional presses add 10 minutes up to 60. A short press cancels. Use an enum for IDLE, BOOST, and CANCELLED with watchdog supervision.

Thermostat with time-proportioned control: implement a PI controller that drives a heater relay using a 60 s window (duty cycle within the window), targeting a setpoint in °C. Enforce minimum ON/OFF times (2 min), sample at 1 Hz, watchdog at 200 ms, and guarantee WCET ≤ 2 ms per tick.

Use two temperature sensors for sensor fusion. Control a heater relay based on the median reading with 0.5 °C hysteresis. If the sensors differ by >2.0 °C for more than 10 s, enter FAULT and force OFF until manual reset. Sample at 2 Hz, WCET ≤ 2 ms, and include a watchdog.

Smart water heater: weekday schedule with a weekly 65 °C pasteurization cycle for 30 minutes. Cut OFF above 90 °C or if current exceeds 12 A. Enforce anti-short-cycling (5 min OFF), state machine for NORMAL/PASTEURIZE/FAULT, watchdog supervision, and clear recovery rules.

Pool filtration control with a pressure sensor in kPa: run a daily pump schedule; if filter pressure > 250 kPa for 60 s, execute an automated backwash state machine controlling valve and pump relays with timed interlocks. Include safety interlocks, watchdog, sample at 5 Hz, WCET ≤ 3 ms.

Oven preheat controller: enum IDLE, PREHEAT, HOLD, FAULT. Require door-closed sensor before energizing the heater relay; preheat to target °C, then maintain with hysteresis. Force FAULT if temperature rises above 300 °C or if door opens in PREHEAT. Add watchdog and timing limits.

Home modes engine: enum HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, VACATION. Each mode maps to a set of relay states and schedules (lights, outlets). Provide atomic mode transitions with WCET ≤ 10 ms at the top of each minute, a clear state machine, rules for conflicts, and a 200 ms watchdog.

Motorized shades with calibration: on first run, seek end positions using timeouts, then manage UP/DOWN with interlocked relays and a state machine. Detect stalls if movement exceeds 25 s and enter FAULT. Include a watchdog and recovery via manual reset.

Greenhouse climate: coordinate heater and exhaust fan relays. Use temperature (°C) and humidity (%RH) to decide actions. If either sensor is missing or invalid, enter a SAFE mode (all relays OFF). Sample at 1 Hz, enforce WCET ≤ 3 ms, and use a watchdog.

Freeze protection: fuse two outdoor temperature probes by averaging. If below 2.0 °C, run a pipe heater/pump relay at 25% duty within a 120 s time-proportioning window; stop above 4.0 °C. Ensure minimum run 30 s per cycle, sample at 1 Hz, and include watchdog.

Smart relay hub with a scheduling engine supporting recurring rules (daily, weekly) and exception dates. Resolve overlapping rules via priorities. Guarantee evaluation at minute boundaries with WCET ≤ 5 ms. Provide a state machine for rule evaluation and watchdog protection.

Design a whole-home schedule and scene engine with enum modes NORMAL, AWAY, GUEST, and ALARM. Each mode drives multiple relays with priorities and safety overrides (e.g., ALARM preempts others). Include watchdog supervision, WCET ≤ 5 ms per tick, and provide a set of acceptance test scenarios covering mode transitions, conflicting schedules, and fail-safe behavior.

Develop a safety-critical gas boiler controller: states PREHEAT, IGNITE, VERIFY, RUN, PURGE, and FAULT with strict timing windows and interlocks on relays. Require manual reset from FAULT. Specify watchdog handling, safety requirements (e.g., max ignition attempts, purge duration), and a comprehensive test plan exercising normal and fault paths.

Create a multi-zone irrigation system (up to 8 zones) with schedules, rain skip, and soil moisture fusion (median of three probes per zone). Include seasonal adjustment, do-not-water windows, watchdog supervision, and a diagnostic mode. Provide simulation test cases for overlapping schedules, sensor failures, and power recovery.

Implement a load-shedding controller for up to 6 circuits: keep total current under 30 A using a current sensor by shedding lower-priority relays first. Support enum modes NORMAL, ECONOMY, and EMERGENCY with different shedding policies. Include watchdog, WCET targets, and unit tests for priority resolution and recovery.

Build a cooker hood and stove interlock: if a stove surface sensor exceeds 80 °C or smoke is detected, set the fan relay to HIGH and turn the light ON; in MANUAL mode, user can override; in AUTO, follow sensors; in LOCKOUT, disable outputs after a fault. Enforce fail-safe OFF on watchdog timeout. Provide a full test plan and safety rationale.
Make a simple on-off controller for a lamp: a single pushbutton toggles a relay; debounce the button with 30 ms, start with the relay off after power-up.
When a motion sensor goes active, energize a relay for 120 s, retriggering if motion occurs again; when the timer expires, turn the relay off.
Use an ambient light sensor to control a relay: turn on when below 100 lux and off when above 110 lux to add 10 lux hysteresis.
Implement a basic thermostat: if room temperature is below 18 C, turn the heater relay on; turn it off above 21 C; include a minimum on and off time of 2 minutes to reduce cycling.
Switch a hallway light: when a door contact opens, turn the light relay on immediately; turn it off 5 s after the door closes.
Create a daily schedule that turns a relay on at 07:00 and off at 22:30 every day, with the relay remaining off at startup until the first event.
Design a countdown outlet: one button press energizes a relay for 10 minutes; another press cancels the countdown and turns the relay off.
Use a single pushbutton to control a relay with short and long press logic: short press toggles the relay, long press of 1 s forces it off; implement 40 ms debounce.
If a water leak sensor reports wet, immediately de-energize a valve relay to close it; when the sensor returns to dry, restore the previous state after 10 s.
Program weekday morning lighting: Monday to Friday, turn a relay on at 06:00 and off at 08:00; relay stays off on weekends.
Control a fan relay from a toggle switch with 200 ms debounce; the relay must default to off after power-up.
Use a presence touch sensor as a trigger: when touched, turn on a relay for 5 minutes, and retrigger to extend the time; turn off when the timer ends.
Implement a doorbell: on button press, close a relay for 500 ms; ignore additional presses within 1 s to avoid chatter.
Schedule a porch light to turn on at 20:00 and automatically turn off after 30 minutes.
Ventilation fan control using CO2: turn the fan relay on above 800 ppm and off below 700 ppm to provide hysteresis.
Create a two-way light control: two wall switches both toggle a single light relay; debounce each input 30 ms and toggle the relay on any rising edge.

Combine a daily schedule with manual override: a button toggles a relay and enters manual mode for 60 minutes, after which control reverts to the schedule; use a simple state machine with states Scheduled and Manual.

Implement an enum mode selector for a bathroom fan with modes OFF, AUTO, and ON; in AUTO, use humidity thresholds of 65 percent to turn on and 55 percent to turn off; enforce minimum on and off times of 2 minutes.
Design a staircase timer with two buttons (top and bottom): any press turns on the light for 120 s; detect double-click within 500 ms to extend to 300 s; long press cancels and turns off immediately.

Control a garage heater relay with safety: normal thermostat operation at 15 C on and 18 C off, but if air temperature exceeds 50 C, latch the relay off until a manual reset button is held for 2 s; ensure the relay defaults off at startup.

Integrate a watchdog timer: run the control loop at 20 Hz and kick the watchdog each cycle; on watchdog timeout, force all relays off and leave an alarm LED blinking at 2 Hz until manual acknowledgement.

Add a vacation mode scheduler for a living room lamp: when mode Vacation is active, randomize each evening on time between 18:30 and 20:00 and off time between 22:00 and 23:30 with up to ±10 minutes jitter per day; when mode Normal is active, follow fixed times.
Drive two interlocked relays for a motorized shade: Up and Down must never be on at the same time; when changing direction, insert a 250 ms dead time with both relays off.

Implement an energy saver: if there is no motion for 15 minutes between 09:00 and 17:00, turn an outlet relay off; a manual button press turns it on and holds it on for 30 minutes regardless of motion.
Build a simple scene controller using a single button: cycle an enum through OFF, RELAX, and BRIGHT; map each scene to two light relays, and update an indicator LED to show the current scene.

Control an exhaust fan using door and humidity: the fan turns on when the bathroom door opens and humidity is above 60 percent; when humidity falls below 55 percent, keep the fan running for a 3 minute after-run, then turn it off.

Schedule a 4-zone sprinkler: every day at 06:00, run zones 1 to 4 sequentially for 5 minutes each by energizing their relays; if a rain sensor is active, skip the entire run; provide a button to start or cancel the sequence manually.

Add child safety to a space heater outlet: require a double-press within 1 s to toggle the heater relay; a 3 s long press locks the control until power is cycled; use a small state machine to manage Locked and Unlocked states.

Meet timing constraints: execute all logic on a 50 ms tick with a worst-case execution time under 2 ms; blink a heartbeat LED at 1 Hz; if the heartbeat fails to toggle for 3 s, turn all relays off as a safety fallback.

Create a weekly schedule with weekday and weekend variations: weekdays on 07:00 off 22:00, weekends on 08:30 off 23:30; a dedicated button invokes a 2 hour manual override that can be canceled by a second button.

Implement master and local light control: a master switch turns three light relays on or off together, while each light also has a local toggle; if the master is turned off, all lights must be off regardless of local toggles.
Add a bathroom fan boost: button press starts a 10 minute boost that forces the fan on, then returns to automatic humidity control; ignore additional boost requests while boost is active.

Protect a power relay with brownout logic: if the measured supply voltage falls below 11.0 V, turn the relay off and latch it off for 30 s before allowing restart; normal toggle operation resumes when voltage is above 11.5 V.

Blend light and time conditions: turn a living room light on only when ambient light is below 120 lux and current time is between 18:00 and 23:00; a manual override button keeps the light on for 30 minutes regardless of light level.

Create a timed outlet with selectable durations: each button press advances an enum through 15, 30, and 60 minute timers, then OFF; start the countdown when a duration is selected, show the selection via LED blink patterns, and allow a cancel press.

Implement time-proportional PID temperature control for a small heater using a solid-state relay: maintain 22.0 C with a 10 s control window, update the PID at 1 Hz, and clamp duty between 0 and 80 percent; add a hard safety cutoff at 50 C that latches off until manual reset; feed a watchdog timer and set the relay off on watchdog faults.

Fuse occupancy signals from a PIR sensor, a simple sound level threshold, and a door contact to drive a light: require at least two of the three to be active within the last 30 s to consider the room occupied; implement a confidence state machine that decays to unoccupied after 2 minutes without evidence.

Control a hot water recirculation pump using schedule, temperature, and motion: during 06:00–09:00 and 17:00–21:00, if motion is detected and return line temperature is below 35 C, turn the pump on until 45 C or 3 minutes max; enforce a 5 minute anti short cycle between runs and default to off on any fault.

Use a PID to regulate room temperature via a relay using time slicing: compute a duty cycle at 0.5 Hz and apply it as on/off bursts within a 20 s window to a heater relay; include integral anti-windup, minimum pulse width of 1 s, and a watchdog that forces the relay off if the control task misses two updates.

Design a backup sump pump controller: if water level is high or main power is lost, energize a backup relay; perform a 1 s test pulse every Sunday at 12:00 if water is low; ensure fail-safe defaults with all relays off after reset and on watchdog timeout.

Ventilation control with sensor fusion: keep a fan on when motion has been detected in the last 5 minutes or CO2 is above 800 ppm; if either is true, maintain at least a 10 minute ventilation period each hour; implement a simple state machine to track the quota and enforce minimum on and off durations.

Implement load shedding for three heavy appliances using a power meter input: keep total power under 3.0 kW by turning off lower priority relays first; enforce minimum on time of 5 minutes and minimum off time of 3 minutes per load; on watchdog timeout, turn all loads off; guarantee a 50 ms cycle time and WCET under 3 ms.

Build a safe garage door controller: use a reed switch for open/closed position, a current sensor to detect obstruction, and a single motor relay with up and down relays interlocked; implement a state machine with Opening, Closing, Stopped, Fault; stop and reverse if obstruction is detected; include timeouts and a watchdog that forces a stop on fault.

Provide redundant temperature control for a heater with two independent sensors: if the sensors disagree by more than 3.0 C, enter a latched FAULT state; otherwise maintain 21.5 C using time-proportional control of a relay within a 15 s window; hard cutoff at 60 C; kick a watchdog each cycle and force the relay off on any watchdog or sensor fault.

Create a smart dryer outlet: monitor vibration and exhaust air temperature; turn off the outlet if temperature exceeds 70 C or if vibration stops for 5 minutes; require a 10 minute cooldown before allowing restart; include a schedule window during 07:00–22:00; keep WCET under 2 ms at a 50 ms rate.

Create an emergency shutdown system with modes NORMAL, ALARM, and SILENCE: when smoke or overtemperature is detected, immediately de-energize all controlled relays and flash an alarm indicator; require manual acknowledgement to enter SILENCE; latch events until cause clears; implement a deterministic state machine, periodic self-checks, and a watchdog; specify a comprehensive test plan including sensor fault injection, power cycle recovery, and timing edge cases.

Implement a smart water heater controller with modes ECO, COMFORT, and BOOST as an enum; use PID-based time-proportional relay control to track setpoints in Celsius, with BOOST expiring after 30 minutes; enforce safety limits including maximum tank temperature of 65 C and dry-fire prevention using temperature rate-of-change; run the control task at 1 Hz with WCET under 3 ms and use a watchdog to drop to a safe OFF mode on any fault; include test cases for mode transitions and safety trips.

Build a multi-zone irrigation scheduler for eight zones with modes AUTO, MANUAL, and OFF; support weekday and weekend programs, per-zone durations, and a rain sensor that suspends runs; include manual single-zone start and cancel; ensure deterministic timing, watchdog integration with fail-safe all-off on timeout, and provide a thorough test matrix for time boundaries, schedule exceptions, and day changeovers.

Develop a residential load management controller with modes NORMAL, PEAK_ALERT, and CRITICAL; use a digital peak alert input to shed up to six loads by priority while honoring each load's minimum on and off times and individual schedules; provide manual override per load that expires automatically; run the scheduler at 50 ms with WCET below 3 ms, kick a watchdog, and force a safe all-off state on fault; include formal test cases for mode transitions, shedding order, and timing guarantees.

Create a simple light control: when a momentary wall switch is pressed, toggle a lamp relay. Use 50 ms debounce and ignore presses while the relay is transitioning. On startup and on any watchdog timeout, force the relay OFF. Provide a 2 Hz heartbeat indicator output.

Implement a timer switch: a single pushbutton turns a relay ON for 5 minutes, then automatically OFF. A second press while active cancels the timer and turns it OFF immediately. Make sure the watchdog forces the relay OFF if the control loop stalls.
Make a motion-activated hallway light: when motion is detected, turn the light relay ON for 30 s. Retriggers extend the timer. Add a 2 s rearm window to avoid chatter. On power-up, default OFF.

Schedule a night light: ON at 18:00, OFF at 23:00. A manual override switch toggles the light and temporarily disables the schedule for 1 hour. Ensure a watchdog timer returns control to the schedule and sets OFF if the system becomes unresponsive.
Control a bathroom fan relay with humidity: turn ON above 65 %RH and OFF below 60 %RH (hysteresis). A manual toggle switch overrides for 15 minutes. Start with the relay OFF on reset.

Create a simple scene selector using enum modes: OFF, READING, MOVIE. A single button cycles modes; each mode drives two relays in a predefined pattern. Ensure the current mode persists across a warm restart and resets to OFF if the watchdog fires.
Implement an interlock for two relays controlling a load: never allow both relays ON at the same time. If both are requested, prioritize Relay A and deny Relay B. On any fault, de-energize both.
Design a stairwell light with tap actions: single tap turns ON for 2 minutes; double tap toggles persistent ON/OFF. Debounce 40 ms, double-tap window 400 ms. On watchdog timeout, revert to OFF.
Drive a chime relay for exactly 1.0 s when the doorbell button is pressed. Ignore additional input until the pulse completes. If the button is held, only one pulse per 5 s.

Control a window shade with UP and DOWN relays using a simple state machine. Hold-to-run behavior: run while the corresponding button is held, stop on release. Enforce mutual exclusion so only one direction relay can be active. Add a 15 s max run safety cutoff.
Automate a water pump schedule: turn ON daily at 06:00 for 10 minutes. If a tank-high float switch is active, skip the cycle. On power loss and recovery, do not retroactively run missed cycles.
Create a two-way staircase light timer using switches at top and bottom. Any edge turns the light ON for 3 minutes; subsequent edges extend the time by 30 s. Ensure the light starts OFF at boot.
Implement a relay pulser: each time an input transitions from low to high, pulse the relay ON for 100 ms. Rate-limit to at most 5 pulses per second.
Provide a power-cycle function: on command, turn a device relay OFF for 5 s, then back ON. Do not allow another cycle for at least 10 minutes. If the watchdog triggers mid-cycle, leave the relay OFF.
Blink a status indicator: steady 2 Hz when healthy; if the watchdog had to recover the system, switch to a 4-blink pattern repeated every 2 s until the next manual acknowledgment input.

Build a thermostat controller with enum modes OFF, HEAT, COOL, and AUTO. Include day/night schedules, adjustable setpoints in °C, compressor/furnace minimum off-time of 3 minutes, and a state machine managing transitions. On watchdog or sensor fault, force mode to OFF.

Create a four-zone irrigation scheduler that runs zones sequentially with per-zone durations. Skip all watering if a rain sensor is active. Provide MANUAL mode to run a selected zone for a fixed time. Ensure only one zone relay is ON at a time.

Combine motion and ambient light to control room lights. If lux is below a threshold and motion is detected, turn lights ON for 5 minutes; otherwise ignore motion. Add a HOME/AWAY enum that lengthens or shortens the timer. Watchdog should fall back to lights OFF.

Schedule exterior security lights based on astronomical dusk and dawn with configurable offsets. Use a simple state machine for DUSK, NIGHT, DAWN to avoid rapid toggling around twilight. If any fault occurs, default the relays to OFF.

Control an electric water heater relay using a time-of-use schedule. Enforce a maximum continuous ON time of 2 hours, then a minimum OFF time of 30 minutes. A manual override switch runs for 30 minutes and then returns to the schedule.

Develop a blinds controller with a state machine: IDLE, MOVING_UP, MOVING_DOWN, CALIBRATING. Use endstop switches to stop movement. Auto-stop after 15 s if an endstop isn’t reached. Watchdog must immediately cut power to the motor relays on timeout.

Run a booster fan when bathroom humidity rises above baseline by 10 %RH for more than 2 minutes. Turn OFF once it returns within 5 %RH of baseline. Sample sensors at 1 Hz and debounce readings over 5 samples.

Implement a door lock strike relay pulse: when authorized, energize for 800 ms. Provide enum modes ARMED, DISARMED, and LOCKOUT. In LOCKOUT, ignore requests for 5 minutes. On any watchdog event, enter LOCKOUT and de-energize.

Create a vacation lighting program: between 19:00 and 23:00, randomly toggle two lighting relays with on-intervals of 10–30 minutes and off-intervals of 5–20 minutes. Never have both relays ON at once. A manual switch cancels the program immediately.

Map a ceiling fan speed control using enum LOW, MED, HIGH to three relays. Enforce that only one speed relay can be ON at any time. Double-press the speed button to turn the fan OFF. Ensure power-up default is OFF.

Implement a bedtime routine: at 22:30, turn OFF a list of relays. If any monitored door sensor is open, postpone by 10 minutes and beep a notification output twice per minute until all are closed or the postpone limit (30 minutes) is reached.

Create a timed outlet with a child lock: enable the outlet for 30 minutes when a button is pressed, then lock it for 60 minutes. Use an enum to indicate states: IDLE, ACTIVE, LOCKED. Blink an indicator differently per state.

Control a garage light linked to the door: when the door relay activates, turn the light ON. Turn it OFF 5 minutes after the door closes. If the door stays open longer than 15 minutes, flash the light at 1 Hz as a reminder.

Alternate between two sump pumps: each demand cycle starts the next pump in sequence. Enforce a minimum OFF time of 3 minutes per pump and a maximum continuous run of 20 minutes. If both demand signals arrive simultaneously, start only one pump.

Detect an open window during heating: if the room temperature drops more than 0.5 °C in 2 minutes while HEAT is requested, pause the heater relay for 20 minutes. Resume automatically when a stable rise resumes or the pause expires.
Implement an energy saver: if no motion for 30 minutes, turn off all non-critical relays. Apply only on weekdays 08:00–18:00. Use a simple enum to represent WORKDAY vs WEEKEND behavior.

Design a multi-button scene panel controlling four relays. Short presses select scenes; a long-press enters CONFIG mode to store the current on/off pattern as the new scene. On watchdog recovery, revert to a SAFE scene with all relays OFF.

Make a night-sensitive staircase timer: if ambient light is below threshold, any button press turns the light ON for 90 s, retriggering extends by 30 s. During the day, manual presses are ignored. Add 100 ms input debounce.

When a water leak sensor activates, immediately close a shutoff valve relay and latch an alarm state that requires manual reset. Provide a watchdog that, on timeout, ensures the valve is commanded closed and alarms remain latched. Sample inputs at 20 Hz; aim for WCET under 2 ms.

Automate a pet feeder motor relay: feed at 07:00 and 18:00 by running for 4 s. If a current sensor indicates a jam (current above threshold for >500 ms), reverse for 2 s, retry once, then raise an alert and disable further runs until reset. Use a state machine.

Greenhouse misting schedule: between 10:00 and 16:00, cycle 10 s ON and 5 min OFF only if temperature > 25 °C. Limit total ON time to 30 minutes per day. Sample sensors at 1 Hz, and ensure watchdog fallback leaves the misting relay OFF.

Maintain a room at 22.0 °C using time-proportional control of a heater relay. Implement a PID with a 10 s control period, anti-windup, and output as a duty fraction over each period. On sensor fault, switch to safe bang-bang with wide hysteresis and enforce a 3-minute minimum OFF time. Watchdog must force heater OFF on fault.

Determine occupancy using sensor fusion of motion and a door contact. Use a state machine with VACANT, TRANSIENT, and OCCUPIED, each with timers. Only energize lights and selected outlets in OCCUPIED. If no events for 20 minutes, decay to VACANT. Watchdog fallback sets VACANT.

Control a hot-water recirculation pump: run when recent activity near bathrooms is detected or when water temperature at the return line drops below 35 °C. Limit runtime to 15 minutes per hour. Manual override forces 10 minutes ON. Default to OFF on any error.

Regulate air quality: control an exhaust fan relay based on CO₂ (ppm) and VOC index. Provide enum modes ECO, NORMAL, BOOST with different thresholds and run times. Sample at 2 Hz, enforce WCET < 3 ms, and ensure fan defaults OFF if sensors are stale or watchdog fires.

Implement load shedding: when total current exceeds a threshold, shed non-critical relays according to priority tiers, then restore once current falls below a lower threshold. Reaction time must be under 200 ms. Include a SAFE mode that keeps only critical loads energized.

Control a sump pump system with redundant high and low float switches. Cross-check sensors and raise an alarm on disagreement. Start pump on high float, stop on low float. If the pump runs longer than 10 minutes, pause 2 minutes and retry. Use a watchdog to ensure pump is OFF on controller faults.

Operate smart curtains with a state machine that considers ambient light level and time-of-day. Open in the morning when light exceeds a threshold after 07:00, close at dusk. Stop immediately if an obstruction sensor triggers. Ensure control loop completes in <5 ms and watchdog cuts power to relays on timeout.

Maintain cellar humidity at 60 %RH using a dehumidifier relay with PID control on a 60 s period. Include compressor protection: minimum 3-minute OFF time and maximum 30-minute continuous ON before a mandatory 5-minute rest. On sensor fault, turn the relay OFF and alarm.

Manage a pool pump with prime detection: on start, if pressure does not rise within 30 s, stop, wait 2 minutes, and retry up to 3 times. Normal run is 4 hours per day split into two 2-hour windows. If retries fail, latch a fault and require manual reset. Watchdog forces pump OFF.

Build a whole-home automation mode manager with enum modes HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, and VACATION. Each mode sets a schedule and on/off state for multiple relays. Define clear state machine transitions driven by time, occupancy, and manual input. Include safety rules that de-energize non-essential loads on faults and a watchdog that enforces SAFE mode within 100 ms.

Create an energy management controller that coordinates relays for an EV charger, water heater, and HVAC auxiliary heater to keep peak demand under a configurable kW limit. Prioritize loads, pre-schedule during off-peak hours, and guarantee decision latency under 100 ms. Provide a comprehensive test plan for conflict scenarios.

Design a central safety interlock: if a smoke or CO alarm input asserts, immediately de-energize specified relays (gas valve, heater, and fans) and inhibit restart until manual reset. Include a watchdog that verifies the interlock logic runs every 10 ms and logs any missed deadlines.

Implement a multi-zone sprinkler controller with enum modes NORMAL, RESTRICTION, and MANUAL. In RESTRICTION, halve all durations and disallow watering on designated days. Integrate moisture sensors to skip zones that are already wet. Include tests for schedule overlaps and sensor failures.

Build a watchdog supervisor that monitors heartbeat signals from separate lighting, climate, and security control tasks. If any heartbeat is missed for 2 consecutive intervals, transition the system to SAFE mode: turn OFF non-essential relays and keep only critical ones ON. Provide recovery procedures and timing constraints (heartbeat period 500 ms, WCET < 2 ms).
Make a simple hallway light: press a button toggles a relay. Debounce the button at 20 ms. Add an indicator LED that mirrors the relay state.
When a motion sensor goes high, turn on a lamp relay for 60 seconds; if motion retriggers, extend the timer. After timeout, turn it off.
Create a porch light timer: on button press, turn the relay on for 5 minutes; pressing the button again cancels the timer and turns it off. Blink a status LED twice when the timer starts.
Daily schedule: at 18:00 turn ON a relay, at 23:00 turn it OFF. Allow a manual override switch that forces OFF until the next scheduled ON.
If ambient light < 100 lux, turn on a nightlight relay, else turn it off. Sample the sensor at 1 Hz.
Leak detector: when a leak input is asserted, immediately close a water valve relay and latch the alarm until a reset button is held for 2 seconds.
Humidity fan control: if humidity > 70 %RH turn the fan relay ON; if it falls below 60 %RH turn it OFF. Include 30 s minimum ON time.
Doorbell: when the button is pressed, energize a chime relay for 1 second and ignore any new presses for 2 seconds.
Implement a watchdog that restarts the control logic if the main loop fails to tick within 500 ms. Normal function: a button toggles a relay.
Staircase light: single press turns the relay on for 3 minutes; in the last 10 seconds, blink an LED at 2 Hz; any press during ON extends by 1 minute.
Child lock: only a long press (>= 2 s) toggles a power relay; short presses are ignored.
Vacation timer: alternate a lamp relay ON for 45 minutes and OFF for 75 minutes between 19:00 and 23:59 each day; outside that window keep it OFF.
Heater safety: if temperature exceeds 50 C, turn off a heater relay and latch a fault until reset; otherwise a switch directly controls the relay.
Fan boost: a momentary button turns on the fan relay for 15 minutes; each additional press adds 5 minutes up to a 60-minute cap.
Power-on default: after startup, keep a relay OFF for 10 seconds, then allow normal toggle from a switch.

Build a state machine for a motorized blind using two relays (UP and DOWN) with interlocks. States: Idle, MovingUp, MovingDown. A toggle button cycles through Up for 12 s, Stop, Down for 12 s, Stop. Ensure both relays are never on together and enforce a 500 ms dead time between directions.

Create a weekly schedule for a water heater relay: weekdays ON 06:00–08:00 and 17:00–22:00, weekends ON 08:00–22:00. A manual OFF switch suppresses the relay for the remainder of the current scheduled block. Status LED solid when the relay is ON, slow blink when scheduled ON but manually suppressed.

Implement a pump controller using two float switches (LOW, HIGH) and one relay. Use hysteresis: turn ON at LOW, turn OFF at HIGH. Add a maximum run time of 20 minutes that trips a fault state until reset.

Scene controller with two buttons and two relays. Short press on Button A toggles Relay 1, long press (>1.5 s) turns both relays ON. Short press on Button B toggles Relay 2, double-click turns both relays OFF.
Lighting automation using ambient light and time window. Between 22:00 and 06:00, if light < 50 lux and motion is detected, turn relay ON for 3 minutes, else keep it OFF. Retrigger on motion.

Define enum modes NORMAL, AWAY, SLEEP. In NORMAL, follow a daily lamp schedule 18:00–23:00. In AWAY, randomize ON periods between 10 and 40 minutes each evening 19:00–23:00. In SLEEP, force OFF. Mode is changed by a rotary selector input.

Sequenced startup of three relays (A, B, C) with 500 ms gaps; shutdown in reverse with 500 ms gaps. A single ON/OFF command triggers the sequence. Add a 2 s watchdog to revert all relays OFF if the sequence logic stalls.

Bathroom fan automation: if humidity rises 10 %RH above the rolling 10-minute baseline, turn fan ON for at least 5 minutes; turn OFF when within 2 %RH of baseline. Include a button to force ON for 20 minutes.
Garage door light: when the door opens, turn light relay ON for 5 minutes; if it's nighttime, extend to 15 minutes. Manual switch always forces OFF.
Two-zone heater control with a single boiler relay. If either zone request is active, turn boiler ON; otherwise OFF. Add anti-short-cycle: minimum 2 minutes OFF time before the boiler can restart.
Implement a window contact + thermostat interlock. If any window is open, force heater relay OFF and blink an LED until all windows are closed for at least 60 s.
Power shedder: if total power exceeds 1500 W, turn OFF the lowest-priority outlet relay; restore it only after power drops below 1200 W for 2 minutes.
Door lock actuator: pulse a relay ON for 500 ms to unlock on command; auto-relock after 30 s if a door-closed sensor goes true; if it stays open, do not relock. Limit to one unlock pulse every 5 s.
Fan with three discrete speeds using two relays in a safe combination. Enum speeds OFF, LOW, MED, HIGH. A single button cycles through speeds. Enforce 300 ms dead time between speed changes.

Irrigation controller for two zones: Zone 1 runs 10 minutes, then Zone 2 runs 8 minutes, starting at 06:00 daily. If a rain sensor is active, skip that day's run. Add a manual start button that starts the next zone in the sequence.

Make a finite state machine for a smart outlet: Idle, Armed, OnTimer, LockedOut. A single button arms the outlet, a short press starts a 30-minute ON timer, and after timeout the outlet enters a 10-minute lockout where presses are ignored.

Watchdog-supervised lighting: if no motion or button activity is seen for 24 hours, toggle a beacon relay for 1 minute as a health indicator. Normal operation: motion or schedule controls the main light.
Heated towel rail: On at 06:30 for 45 minutes and at 18:30 for 45 minutes. If bathroom temperature exceeds 30 C, cut power and suspend the next cycle. Require a manual reset to resume.

Dual-pump alternator: alternate which pump relay handles each demand cycle to balance wear. If the active pump runs more than 10 minutes continuously, raise a fault and switch to the other pump if available.

Add a watchdog timer that must be kicked every 200 ms by the main task; on timeout, de-energize all relays and set a FAULT enum state. Normal behavior: a schedule toggles a heater relay morning and evening.

Implement a time-proportioned thermostat for 22 C using a single heater relay. Use a 10-minute control window with PID to compute ON time within each window, with ON/OFF times clamped to at least 60 s to protect the relay. Cut out if room temperature exceeds 28 C or sensor fails. Run the control loop at 1 Hz and ensure WCET under 20 ms. Include a hardware watchdog kick.

Closed-loop humidity control for a bathroom: target 55 %RH with a PID that modulates fan duty over a 5-minute window using relay ON/OFF slices. Enforce a minimum 2-minute OFF between windows to avoid nuisance. If %RH sensor is stale for >30 s, enter a SAFE_LOW state with periodic 1-minute ventilation every 10 minutes.

Occupancy lighting using sensor fusion: combine a PIR motion sensor and a door contact. Treat a door open event as high confidence occupancy for 3 minutes, and decay PIR confidence with a 30 s half-life. Keep the light ON while confidence > 0.3 or while the manual override is engaged. Include a watchdog that requires activity processing at 20 Hz with WCET <= 5 ms.

Air quality fan controller: fuse PM2.5 (µg/m3) and VOC index into an air quality score. Map score to enum speeds OFF/LOW/MED/HIGH with hysteresis. If either sensor stops updating for >60 s, degrade to LOW and raise a warning. Add a 3 s interlock delay between speed changes to protect relays.

Hot water recirculation pump control: maintain return temperature at 45 C using PID with a 15-minute windowed relay output. Suspend operation if supply temperature exceeds 55 C. Schedule active hours 05:30–08:30 and 17:00–22:00. Failsafe OFF if any temperature sensor reports an error; kick a watchdog every cycle.

Energy management: keep total current under 10 A by shedding up to three noncritical relays in priority order. Reconnect them after current stays below 8 A for 5 minutes, one at a time with 30 s spacing. Brownout handler: if voltage < 200 V for more than 500 ms, force all noncritical relays OFF and latch until voltage is stable for 2 minutes.

Smart defrost for a freezer outlet: once every 24 hours between 02:00 and 04:00, turn the outlet OFF for up to 10 minutes to defrost, but only if internal temperature is below -15 C. Abort defrost if temperature rises above -10 C. Include a state machine with states Idle, WaitingWindow, Defrosting, Aborted, Completed.

Battery backup load control: when battery voltage drops below 11.8 V, shed relays according to priority until voltage recovers above 12.2 V for 2 minutes. Implement rate limiting so that only one relay changes state every 10 s. Watchdog timeout puts system into MINIMAL_LOAD mode.

Greenhouse misting relay control: use sensor fusion of temperature (Celsius) and humidity (%RH) to maintain VPD between 0.8 and 1.2 kPa. Calculate VPD each second, and use a bang-bang controller with minimum ON 5 s and minimum OFF 20 s. Suspend if door is open. Ensure WCET < 10 ms per cycle.

Smart garage door operator with safety: state machine with states Closed, Opening, Open, Closing, Obstructed, Fault. Use relays for motor up/down with interlocks, limit switches for end stops, and a photo-beam for obstruction. Auto-reverse on obstruction, stop after 20 s if no end stop. Include watchdog and manual emergency stop.

Implement a comprehensive scheduler for four irrigation zones with seasonal adjustment. Modes: NORMAL, RAIN_DELAY, WINTERIZE. NORMAL follows per-zone durations and start times; RAIN_DELAY skips watering for 48 hours; WINTERIZE runs each zone for 30 s sequentially on command. Add safety: never run more than one zone at a time, insert 5 s pressure stabilization between zones, and fail-safe OFF on watchdog expiry. Provide a clearly defined state machine.

Develop a load-priority controller for a small off-grid cabin. Enum modes ECO, COMFORT, BOOST. Inputs: battery voltage (V), solar input power (W), and user boost button. Behavior: schedule fridge, water pump, and heater relays according to mode while keeping total current under 8 A; in BOOST, allow temporary overload for 2 minutes then decay to COMFORT. Include brownout protection, watchdog supervision, and an acceptance test plan describing at least five scenarios.

Create a building entry light system with two entrance zones and shared walkway lights. Modes DAY, EVENING, NIGHT, MAINTENANCE. Use motion sensors per zone, ambient light in lux, and schedules. Requirements: mutual exclusion where maintenance forces all other logic OFF; cross-fade behavior emulated with relay banks; watchdog must be kicked at 100 ms intervals; WCET per tick <= 5 ms. Specify the state machine and all timing constants.

Specify a whole-home safety interlock controller that supervises multiple relays (gas valve, water valve, heater, outlets). Define events: GAS_LEAK, WATER_LEAK, SMOKE_ALARM, MANUAL_RESET. Rules: GAS_LEAK shuts gas and outlets, SMOKE_ALARM cuts heater and outlets, WATER_LEAK closes water valve; simultaneous events follow the strongest action. Include latched FAULT states, watchdog reset behavior, and a regression test checklist covering at least eight edge cases.

Make a simple on/off: when the wall switch is pressed, energize a relay; when released, de-energize. Add 50 ms debounce and a watchdog that resets the controller if the input sampling loop stalls for more than 500 ms.
Implement a staircase timer: a pushbutton turns the light relay on for 90 seconds, then off automatically. If the button is pressed again during the countdown, restart the timer.
Schedule a lamp to turn ON at 18:00 and OFF at 22:30 every day. Manual toggle switch can override, but the schedule takes effect again at the next event.
Control a fan relay using temperature: turn ON when temperature exceeds 28 °C, and turn OFF when it drops below 26 °C. Include 100 ms debounce on the sensor ready signal and a simple watchdog.
Create a doorbell behavior: each press triggers the chime relay for 300 ms. Ignore repeated presses for 2 seconds after activation.
Require a long-press to toggle a power outlet: only if the button is held for at least 2 seconds should the relay change state; short taps do nothing. Include a 1 s watchdog timer.
Motion-activated porch light: if motion is detected between 20:00 and 06:00, turn on a light relay for 30 seconds. Each new motion extends the time.
Single-tap toggles a lamp relay with clear debouncing (20 ms). Illuminate a small indicator output when the relay is ON.
Water valve safety timer: when a manual switch turns the valve ON, automatically turn it OFF after 5 minutes to prevent flooding.
Weekday work schedule: energize a smart outlet from 09:00 to 17:00 Monday–Friday; keep it OFF on weekends. Allow a local override that lasts until the next scheduled change.
Heater safety: if the thermostat input keeps calling for heat continuously for more than 45 minutes, switch OFF the heater relay and require a manual reset input to re-enable.
Garage light automation: when the door contact opens, turn the light relay ON immediately and turn it OFF 5 minutes after the door closes.
Aquarium lighting with two daily periods: turn lights ON from 08:00–12:00 and 16:00–20:00, OFF otherwise. Provide a manual ON that times out after 30 minutes.

Blind control (simple): pressing the UP button energizes the UP relay for 10 seconds then stops; pressing the DOWN button energizes the DOWN relay for 10 seconds then stops; never allow both relays at once.
Implement a safety heartbeat: a watchdog timer should reset the system if the main loop does not iterate within 200 ms. Provide a simple toggled relay output every 5 seconds as a heartbeat indicator.
Two-switch stairwell controller: two debounced wall switches control a single light relay. Use a state machine that tracks ON/OFF and an auto-OFF after 2 minutes of inactivity.

Vacation lighting mode: create enum modes OFF, ON, and RANDOM. RANDOM should randomly toggle a lamp between 18:00 and 23:00 with on/off durations between 5 and 20 minutes. A button cycles the mode. Include a watchdog.

Fan controller with enum modes AUTO, ON, OFF. In AUTO, use temperature thresholds (ON above 27 °C, OFF below 25 °C). A single button cycles modes and an LED indicates the current mode. Add a 1 s watchdog.
Pump protection: when a level switch indicates LOW, run the pump relay until the level indicates HIGH. Enforce minimum ON time of 15 seconds and minimum OFF time of 30 seconds to protect the pump.

Sprinkler with rain inhibit: schedule zone 1 to run at 06:00 for 15 minutes unless the rain sensor is active. Include a manual override button that starts a 10-minute run. Ensure the control loop meets a 10 ms WCET.

Heater relay with anti-short-cycling: in AUTO mode, heat if below 18 °C and stop at 20 °C. Enforce at least 3 minutes OFF before turning back ON. Provide MANUAL ON and OFF modes via an enum and a mode button.
Laundry room exhaust fan: when the light switch turns OFF, keep the fan running for 3 minutes (post-run). If humidity > 70% RH, extend post-run to 10 minutes. Use a simple state machine.
Curtain control with interlock: UP and DOWN relays must be mutually exclusive. Use limit switches to stop movement. Add a watchdog and a 500 ms motor rest delay between direction changes.
Restore last relay state on power-up: persist the ON/OFF state to nonvolatile storage when it changes. On startup, default to OFF if data is invalid or corrupt. Include a watchdog supervisor.

Smart plug with weekly schedule and holiday exceptions: ON 07:00–09:00 and 18:00–22:00 on weekdays, 09:00–23:00 on weekends. Skip all events on listed holiday dates. Manual override reverts at the next scheduled boundary.
Pet feeder motor control: at scheduled times, run the motor relay for 8 seconds. If a jam sensor stays active during the run, abort and signal an alarm. Block repeated feedings for 5 minutes.

Lighting scenes with enum modes DAY, NIGHT, and AWAY. Each mode sets a different group of relays and timers. Transition between modes via a schedule and a mode button; include a watchdog and an indicator output.
Hourly chime scheduler: energize the chime relay at the top of each hour between 09:00 and 19:00. During QUIET mode (set by a switch), suppress chimes.
Child-safe heat lamp: require two separate buttons to be pressed within 5 seconds to turn ON. Auto-OFF after 10 minutes. Any door-open sensor event should immediately shut OFF the relay.
Greenhouse vent fan: turn ON above 30 °C and OFF below 27 °C. Enforce minimum ON time 60 seconds and minimum OFF time 120 seconds. Fail-safe to OFF on sensor fault; include watchdog.

Aquaponics pump cycle: run 15 minutes ON, then 45 minutes OFF, continuously. Manual override for 10 minutes ON that then returns to the repeating schedule. Ensure timing drift is less than 1 second per hour.
Deadman/treadle switch: keep a tool relay energized only if the user taps a confirm button at least once every 30 seconds. If the heartbeat is missed, drop the relay and require a fresh start.

Dual-room light controller: two motion sensors control two light relays with independent timers, but a master 'QUIET HOURS' schedule (22:00–06:00) halves the ON durations. Provide an enum to enable/disable QUIET HOURS.

Entryway light logic: when the door opens after sunset, turn light ON for 5 minutes. If a second motion is detected within that period, extend to 10 minutes. Watchdog resets on missed 500 ms heartbeat.

Ceiling fan controller with mode button: cycle OFF -> LOW -> HIGH modes (enum). LOW energizes relay A, HIGH energizes relay B, never both. Long-press returns to OFF. Include debouncing and a watchdog.

Water heater control using time-proportioned PID: maintain 55 °C setpoint with a relay by modulating ON time within a 20-second window. Day/night schedule sets 50 °C at night. Hard safety cutoff if temperature exceeds 75 °C. Control loop at 5 Hz, WCET <= 10 ms, with a watchdog.
Dehumidifier controller with PID: target 50% RH by time-proportioning a compressor relay. Enforce minimum 3 minutes OFF between compressor cycles. Enum modes: AUTO, ON, OFF. Watchdog required.

Occupancy sensor fusion for lighting: fuse PIR, door contact, and sound level to derive OCCUPIED/UNOCCUPIED states that drive a lighting relay with 5-minute timeout. Specify update rate 20 Hz and fail-safe to OFF on sensor fault. Include a watchdog.

Main water shutoff: state machine with NORMAL, ALARM, and LATCHED states. On leak sensor trigger, close the valve relay, alarm, and require manual reset to return to NORMAL. Rate-limit valve actuations to at most 3 per 10 minutes.

Gate controller: enum modes AUTO, MANUAL, and LOCKOUT. Inputs: open/close buttons and a photo-beam. Interlock open/close relays, add soft delays, reverse if beam is broken while closing. Include watchdog and a 2 ms WCET constraint.

Transfer switch controller for backup power: safely switch between MAINS and GENERATOR with mutually exclusive relays and required dead-time. State machine handles TRANSFER, VERIFY, and FAULT states. Weekly exercise runs the generator for 10 minutes. Watchdog must supervise the main loop.

Greenhouse climate with dual relays: PID regulate temperature to 24 °C using a heater relay; above 28 °C use a vent fan relay with hysteresis. Day/night setpoints via schedule. Fail to SAFE-OFF on sensor error; include watchdog.

Load shedding for smart home: maintain total power draw below 3.5 kW by switching off lower-priority relays when a current sensor indicates overload. Use a state machine with priorities and cooldowns. Watchdog and 50 Hz update rate.

Sauna controller: maintain 80 °C using time-proportioned PID of a heater relay. Session timer max 60 minutes. If door opens for more than 30 seconds, pause heating. Emergency stop input must cut power immediately. WCET 5 ms; watchdog required.

Sump pump with redundancy: monitor two float switches and a periodic self-test. Run pump relay on HIGH float, stop on LOW. If HIGH sticks for > 10 minutes, raise alarm. Require minimum 20 seconds ON and 30 seconds OFF. Include watchdog and a weekly test schedule.

Design a whole-home mode manager: enum modes HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, VACATION controlling sets of light and outlet relays and their schedules. Provide a formal state machine with timed transitions, watchdog supervision, and startup self-test. Define acceptance tests for all mode transitions and schedule overrides.

Smart irrigation across multiple zones: schedule per-zone runtimes with rain skip and soil moisture sensor fusion. Modes AUTO/MANUAL/LOCKOUT. Enforce that only one valve relay is ON at a time, with pressure stabilization delays. Specify WCET <= 10 ms, include a watchdog, and require a comprehensive test plan including fault injection for stuck relays and sensor failures.

Energy-aware appliance controller: manage washer and dryer outlet relays using a dynamic pricing schedule input. Modes ECONOMY, NORMAL, and OVERRIDE. Implement load deferral rules, user overrides that expire at midnight, and a watchdog. Provide a test matrix and timing requirements for 20 Hz control with WCET 3 ms.

Integrated access and ambiance controller: coordinate gate, porch lights, and pathway relays with multi-mode DAY, NIGHT, and PARTY behavior. Include a rigorous state machine, fail-safe defaults, watchdog monitoring, and a verification checklist covering edge cases and timing races.

Emergency lighting system with dual power sources: supervise mains and battery, test the battery monthly, and switch relays to maintain lighting during outages. Provide enum modes NORMAL, TEST, FAULT; require a detailed state machine, watchdog coverage, WCET 2 ms, and traceable unit tests for all safety behaviors.

Turn on a lamp relay while a wall switch is held, and turn it off when released. Debounce the switch for 30 ms, default to Off on startup, and prevent relay chatter by ignoring edges closer than 100 ms. Run the control loop every 10 ms.

Toggle a smart plug relay on each single button click; a double-click should start a 2-hour countdown after which the relay turns off; a long-press (>2 s) forces Off immediately. Include a watchdog that reverts to Off if not fed within 200 ms.
When a motion sensor triggers, turn a hallway light relay on for 90 seconds. Allow retriggering, but enforce a maximum on time of 10 minutes for safety. Default to Off on power restore.

Implement a fan timer: pressing a touch switch starts a 15-minute countdown that keeps the fan relay on; pressing again cancels the timer. Indicate remaining time via an LED in 25% steps. Use a 20 ms scan period.

Create a nightlight schedule: turn an outlet On at 18:00 and Off at 23:00 local time daily. A manual override switch toggles the outlet and holds that state until the next schedule boundary. Limit clock drift to ±1 minute per day.

Implement a two-way stair light controlled by two switches: toggle the relay state on each debounced edge, enforce a minimum 200 ms between state changes to avoid bouncing, and start in Off. Keep it simple and robust.
Doorbell chime control: when the button is pressed, energize the chime relay for exactly 800 ms (one-shot) and then ignore further presses for a 1 s lockout.
Control a fill pump via a float switch: start when the level reads Low, stop when High. Debounce the float for 100 ms and enforce a minimum 3 s off-time between stops and starts to protect the pump.
Heat lamp controller as a simple two-state machine: On while a toggle switch is On, otherwise Off. A long press (>1.5 s) of the switch should force Off and initiate a 30 s lockout.

Timer switch behavior: pressing a button cycles through 5, 10, and 30-minute on-times if presses occur within 1 second of each other. LED color shows selected duration. Keep the relay on for the chosen countdown.

Window shade with two relays for open/close: run Open for up to 12 s unless the open limit is reached; run Close similarly with its limit. Block simultaneous commands and add a 250 ms deadtime when reversing direction.
Garage light automation: turn the light on when a door-open input goes active. Turn it off 3 minutes after the door closes, unless a manual override switch is currently on.
Aquarium light schedule: on at 09:00, off at 21:00. If water temperature exceeds 30 C, skip turning on or immediately turn off. If the temperature sensor fails, drop the relay to Off for safety.
Energy-saving outlet: if measured power exceeds 1500 W, switch off an auxiliary relay; restore it only when power drops below 1200 W. Implement hysteresis and sample at 200 ms intervals.

Build a state machine with enum modes Off, Auto, Manual for a living room light. In Auto, keep the light on for 2 minutes after last motion only if ambient < 100 lux. Manual follows a pushbutton. Power-up -> Off. Kick a watchdog each cycle or force Off.

Weekly irrigation schedule for multiple valve relays with per-zone durations and a rain sensor to skip watering. Provide manual 'Run Now' and 'Rain Delay 24h' modes via an enum. Rate-limit valve toggling to once every 5 seconds.

Two-stage heater control using two relays: Stage 1 on at 18 C, Stage 2 on at 16 C with 0.5 C hysteresis. An Away mode disables Stage 2. Ensure minimum on/off times of 2 minutes for each stage to protect hardware.

Fan controller with sleep schedule: Auto mode turns the fan on when humidity > 60% RH or temperature > 28 C. A Sleep sub-mode enforces quiet hours 22:00–07:00 limiting duty to 25%. Use enum modes and a clear state machine.

Smart bathroom control: after motion, turn both light and fan relays on. If no motion for 5 minutes, turn the light off; keep the fan running for 10 minutes after last motion. Manual switch can toggle the light independently. Watchdog timeout forces both Off.

Scene controller with four relays and modes Normal, Dinner, Movie, Cleaning. Long-press cycles scenes; short-press toggles current scene on/off. Debounce inputs by 100 ms and persist the active scene across reset.

Curtain controller: implement states Opening, Closing, Stopped, Fault with end-stop sensors. Support commands Open, Close, Stop. Add 200 ms interlock between reversing directions and a 30 s watchdog that halts movement if not Stopped.

Hot water recirculation pump: operate during windows 06:00–09:00 and 17:00–21:00; additionally run for 5 minutes upon kitchen motion. Do not exceed 30 minutes total runtime per hour. Enter SafeOff if water temperature > 55 C.

Porch light Auto/On/Off controller: in Auto, turn on when lux stays below 50 lux for 30 s; turn off when above 120 lux for 60 s. An override switch can force On or Off modes. Watchdog action sets Off mode if it expires.

Dual smart outlet with priority: if total current exceeds 10 A, temporarily disable Outlet B to protect the circuit. Restore B after 10 s only if current is below 8 A. Brownout input immediately forces both Off.

Greenhouse vents with enum modes Closed, Venting, Open: use temperature band 22–26 C to decide transitions. Include minimum open/close times to prevent flapping, and stop immediately if wind speed > 12 m/s.

Entryway light states Off, On, Hold, Lockout: motion turns On. After 2 minutes On, go to Hold for 30 s awaiting new motion; otherwise Off. If more than 5 motion events occur in 10 s, enter Lockout for 60 s.

Chronothermostat: weekday/weekend time slots with Celsius setpoints. Control a heater relay with 0.3 C hysteresis. Provide an Away mode overriding the schedule. Feed a watchdog every 50 ms with WCET not exceeding 5 ms.
