Pool pump automation: daily schedule segments with a manual backwash cycle triggered by long-press to run 2 minutes. Do not start the pump if a low water level input is active. Enforce minimum 45 s off-time between starts.

Smart switch with ChildLock: enable ChildLock on double-tap; in that mode, ignore single taps but allow a 3 s long-press to exit. Provide Manual and Scheduled modes; scheduled Off at 22:30. Persist the active mode in nonvolatile storage.

Whole-house fan: if attic temperature > 35 C and indoor < 28 C, enable fan only when a window-open input is true. In AutoCooling mode, run up to 20 minutes then force a 10-minute cooldown Off period. Use a watchdog to shut down on timeout.

Illuminated switch backlight logic: select Off, Dim, or Bright levels based on ambient lux and relay state. Debounce the user input. Disable backlight PWM entirely if the relay has been Off for more than 1 hour to save energy.

Sump pump alternation: alternate starts between two pump relays when water level reaches High. If a pump fails to drop level to Low within 60 s, raise Fault and switch to the other pump. Enforce a 3 s rest between stop and next start.

Holiday lights schedule: turn on at sunset and off at 23:30 from Dec 1 through Jan 6 only. A Manual Off override suppresses the schedule. Use a 1 Hz timebase and align schedule transitions to minute boundaries.

Laundry notifier: when washer current exceeds 0.5 A for more than 3 s, turn an indicator relay on; turn it off when current stays below 0.2 A for 60 s. Provide a Mute mode that suppresses the indicator for 2 hours after a long-press.

Implement a time-proportioning PID to maintain room temperature at a scheduled setpoint (Celsius) using a heater relay. Use 10 s control windows with on-time from 0–100%, anti-windup, and minimum 30 s off-time to protect the relay. Enter SafeOff if temperature > 50 C. Kick a watchdog each cycle.

Design sensor fusion for occupancy to control a hallway light: combine PIR, door contact, and sound level (dB) into states Occupied, Maybe, Vacant via a state machine. Keep the light on in Occupied or Maybe with different hold times. Update at 20 Hz with WCET <= 3 ms.

Smart recirculation pump with predictive start: learn average warm-up time and start early to meet warm-water availability at 06:30 and 19:00. Safety caps: maximum 10 minutes continuous run and mandatory 5-minute cool-off. Add a Fault state on sensor timeout and integrate a watchdog.

Greenhouse shading screens: fuse lux (lux), temperature (C), and wind speed (m/s) to drive Open/Close relays. Use modes Auto, Manual, Storm in a hierarchical state machine. In Storm, force Open. Include a 500 ms brake when reversing and a 60 s watchdog abort for stuck motion.

Water tank level control with PI top-up: maintain near 70% using a valve relay with duty cycling derived from a PI controller and a filtered level sensor. Allow filling only between 02:00–04:00. Detect leaks: if level drops >5% in 10 minutes while valve is Off, raise Fault and lock out.

Advanced ventilation: regulate humidity to 55% RH using a PID with time-proportioned fan relay, while quiet hours 22:00–07:00 cap max duty at 30%. Enum modes Off, Auto, Boost (15 min full power). Watchdog expiry resets to Off.

Energy-aware outlet bank of three relays: keep total power under 1500 W using feedback from a power sensor. Implement a state machine that sheds/restores loads by priority based on user policy (Aggressive, Balanced, Conservative). Brownout input must force all Off within 50 ms.

Adaptive smart thermostat: use occupancy prediction from the last 7 days to preheat with a PI loop controlling a heater relay via 5-minute duty windows. Safety: limit to 6 relay cycles per hour, overtemperature cutoff at 45 C, and a watchdog that drops to Off on timeout.

Leak mitigation: on leak detection, close the main valve relay, disable nonessential outlets, and enter a latched Fault requiring manual reset. Add a heartbeat watchdog that defaults to valve closed if it expires. Target WCET <= 2 ms.

Directional stair lighting: fuse two PIRs and a light sensor to infer up vs down travel and drive two relays accordingly using a finite state machine. Include anti-flicker timers and enter a safety Off state if any sensor data is invalid.

Whole-home vacation lighting simulator for five relays with modes Off, Auto, Vacation, Panic. In Vacation, replay randomized on/off sequences between 18:00–23:30 learned from the past week with ±10 minute jitter. Provide manual override and Panic (all On). Integrate a watchdog, persistent storage, and define acceptance tests for schedule adherence and safe fallback to Off.

Multi-mode water heating controller: states Off, Eco, Comfort, Boost, Fault selected by a weekly schedule with temporary user overrides. Enforce thermal limit at 60 C, dry-tank protection via float input, and minimum 3-minute rest between heating cycles. Specify a test plan covering power loss during Boost, sensor failure handling, and clock changes.

Smart switch framework for an apartment: scenes Morning, Work, Evening, Night, Away across six relays with rule-based automation using motion, lux, and time. Enforce WCET under 4 ms at a 100 Hz loop, integrate a watchdog, and provide a formal state machine plus unit tests for every scene transition with debounced inputs.

Load-shedding controller with modes Normal, Peak, Emergency: monitor total current and shed loads by priority while ensuring fairness and maximum off-time per device. Include brownout detection, watchdog supervision, persistent event logs, and a comprehensive verification checklist with simulated test scripts.

Multi-zone irrigation system with modes Off, Auto, Manual, RainDelay, Fault. Features include seasonal adjust, soil moisture fusion with rain input, per-zone schedules, anti-water-hammer valve delays, and a watchdog that fails closed. Provide timing budgets with WCET 3 ms and define acceptance criteria and regression tests.

Create a simple debounced push-button lamp controller: each press toggles a single relay, an indicator LED mirrors the relay state, and the relay must default to OFF on boot. Include a basic software watchdog timer that forces the relay OFF if the main loop stalls for more than 200 ms.

Make a push-button light with short-press toggle and long-press (held >2 s) to start a 10-minute auto-off timer. Keep behavior deterministic and ensure the auto-off timer cancels if the relay is turned off manually.

Implement a thermostat-like relay: turn ON at 26 Celsius and turn OFF at 24 Celsius (2 C hysteresis). If the temperature sensor is missing or reads out of range (< -40 C or > 125 C), force the relay to OFF and raise a FAULT enum state. Add a watchdog timer that reverts to FAULT if no control update occurs within 100 ms.
Create a momentary doorbell relay: each valid button press produces a 500 ms relay pulse, with debouncing and a 300 ms lockout to prevent repeat pulses from bounce.
Schedule a single relay to turn ON every day at 07:00 and OFF at 22:00 local time. Provide a manual toggle input that temporarily overrides the schedule until the next scheduled boundary.
On power-up, hold a load relay OFF for 2 seconds for safety, then follow a maintained wall switch input. If the input is in an indeterminate state, keep the relay OFF.

Add a safety auto-off: if a relay remains ON continuously for more than 30 minutes, force it OFF and require a new user input to turn it back ON. Provide a simple status LED that blinks twice every 2 seconds when auto-off has triggered.

Use an ambient light sensor to control a porch light relay with hysteresis: ON below 50 lux, OFF above 200 lux. Expose an enum state BRIGHT/DARK to represent the light regime and ensure the relay follows it. Default to OFF if the sensor fails.

Implement a pump relay with a manual toggle button and an inactivity timeout: if no button activity occurs for 15 minutes while the pump is ON, turn it OFF and light a timeout indicator for 10 seconds.

Make a simple motion-activated indicator: when a PIR sensor detects motion, turn an LED ON for 10 seconds, then turn it OFF if no new motion arrives. Ignore any motion events during the first 500 ms after power-up.
Blink an LED at 2 Hz whenever a relay is ON, and keep the LED solid OFF when the relay is OFF. Include a note that the LED must not flicker during relay transitions longer than 10 ms.

Program a kitchen timer button: a single press starts a 5-minute countdown; when the countdown ends, energize a relay for 30 seconds and then turn it OFF. A second press during the countdown cancels it.
For a doorbell chime relay, on each button press generate a double-beep pattern: 200 ms ON, 200 ms OFF, 200 ms ON, then a 1 second lockout before the next valid press.
Create a latching light switch that always powers up with the relay OFF regardless of previous state. The next button press after power-up sets the intended state and resumes normal toggle behavior.

Build a basic lamp switch with a software watchdog: the logic runs at 50 ms intervals, and if two consecutive intervals are missed, force the relay to OFF and flash an error LED at 1 Hz until a user acknowledges with a long press.

Design a hallway light state machine with enum modes OFF, AUTO, and MANUAL. AUTO turns the light ON when motion is detected and ambient light is below 100 lux, then turns it OFF 2 minutes after the last motion. MANUAL follows a wall switch. Include a watchdog timer that trips to OFF if the control task exceeds a 50 ms deadline.

Implement a weekly schedule for a water heater relay with two daily ON windows (e.g., 06:00–08:00 and 17:00–21:00). Add a manual 1-hour BOOST function via button that temporarily turns the relay ON regardless of schedule, then reverts. Enforce a maximum continuous ON time of 2 hours.

Control a window blind using two interlocked relays (UP and DOWN). Build a state machine with states IDLE, MOVING_UP, MOVING_DOWN, and FAULT. Ensure the relays are never ON simultaneously, limit motion to 15 seconds per command, and fall back to FAULT on watchdog expiry.

Create a smart outlet that uses a power sensor input (watts). Turn the outlet OFF if power exceeds 1200 W for more than 2 seconds, and block re-enable for 60 seconds (LOCKOUT state). Provide enum modes NORMAL and LOCKOUT, and allow a manual clear.

Build a staircase light with two wall switches (top and bottom). Pressing either turns the light ON for 3 minutes; each subsequent press extends the timer by 1 minute up to a 10-minute cap. Guarantee worst-case execution time under 1 ms per control cycle.

Create an irrigation valve controller that waters at 06:00 if soil moisture is below 30% and a rain sensor is inactive. Use a state machine with IDLE, WATERING, SOAK, and LOCKOUT, limiting total open time to 10 minutes. Include a 100 ms watchdog that moves to LOCKOUT if missed.

Implement a two-speed ventilation fan with LOW and HIGH relays. Use temperature thresholds (turn LOW ON at 25 Celsius, HIGH at 30 Celsius, OFF below 23 Celsius) and a manual override button. Enforce interlocking so both relays cannot be ON at once.

Make a 4-button scene controller for four relays. Single press toggles the assigned relay; long-press turns all relays OFF; double-tap on button 1 toggles a predefined scene (relays 1 and 3 ON, others OFF). Debounce inputs and use a 250 ms double-tap window.

For a garage, turn the light ON when the door opens or motion is detected, and turn it OFF 5 minutes after the last trigger. If the door remains open, keep the light ON. Add a watchdog timer that forces OFF after 2 missed 100 ms cycles.

Build a day/night thermostat schedule with enum mode HEAT or OFF. Use setpoints of 21 Celsius during the day and 18 Celsius at night, with a 3-minute minimum OFF time to protect the relay from short cycling. Provide a MANUAL HOLD mode that suspends the schedule.

Add a vacation lighting feature: between 18:00 and 22:00, randomly toggle a lamp relay with ON durations between 5 and 20 minutes and OFF durations between 5 and 15 minutes. Provide a manual override switch to disable vacation mode immediately.

Create a bathroom fan controller: if humidity exceeds 60% RH, turn the fan ON; turn it OFF when humidity drops below 50% RH or after 20 minutes, whichever comes first. A manual button toggles the fan, and the state machine must handle MANUAL and AUTO modes. Target WCET < 1 ms.

Control a porch light using a lux sensor with stability: turn ON when below 50 lux and stay ON for at least 10 minutes, even if lux fluctuates. Turn OFF when above 200 lux for 60 seconds. Expose an enum of LIGHT_DARK/LIGHT_BRIGHT.

Implement curtain control with OPEN and CLOSE relays and two limit switches. Interlock the relays, stop motion when a limit is reached, and add a 30-second timeout as a safety stop. Include a watchdog that forces both relays OFF on timeout.

Add a child-lock feature: a dedicated button toggles CHILD_LOCK mode (hold for 3 seconds). When enabled, ignore other control inputs for 1 hour or until the lock is toggled off. Indicate mode via an LED blinking pattern.

Create a power-up sequencer: when a master switch is turned ON, energize three relays in order with 500 ms spacing; when turning OFF, de-energize them in reverse order with 500 ms spacing. Ensure any sequence completes even if the master switch bounces.

Make a smart outlet that turns OFF if no motion has been detected for 30 minutes, and turns back ON when motion resumes. Provide a MANUAL override that holds the outlet ON for 2 hours before returning to AUTO. Watchdog: force OFF on control loop stall.

Implement a door strike: a keypad trigger input energizes a relay for 7 seconds, then enforces a 10-second re-arm period where new triggers are ignored. Provide status via an LED that is solid during unlock and slow-blink while re-arming.
Program an aquarium light schedule: ON at 09:00 and OFF at 21:00. Add a FEED mode enum that, when pressed, turns the light OFF for 5 minutes and then resumes the schedule automatically.

Control a sprinkler zone with a daily 06:30 schedule, but if a rain sensor is active, delay watering for 24 hours (RAIN_DELAY mode). Cancel RAIN_DELAY early if a manual WATER NOW button is long-pressed for 2 seconds.

Implement a time-proportioning PID controller for a heating relay to maintain room temperature at a configurable setpoint in Celsius using a 10 s control window. Include anti-windup, clamp output to 0–100%, and hard-cut the relay OFF if a high-limit sensor exceeds 80 C. Provide enum modes OFF/HEAT/FAULT and a watchdog that drops to FAULT if two 100 ms ticks are missed.

Create a water heater schedule with a weekly anti-legionella boost: normal schedule plus a weekly cycle that raises the setpoint to 60 Celsius for 30 minutes. Add safety interlocks: absolute max 90 C, sensor plausibility checks, and fallback to OFF on sensor fault. Enforce WCET < 2 ms per cycle and trigger a watchdog after 100 ms without service.

Control a fresh-air ventilator using sensor fusion of CO2 (ppm) and humidity (%RH). If either is high (CO2 > 1000 ppm or humidity > 60% RH), turn the fan ON; if both are low (CO2 < 800 ppm and humidity < 50% RH), turn it OFF. Use PID on humidity to time-proportion the relay (0–100% duty over a 60 s window). Provide MANUAL and FAILSAFE enum modes, with FAILSAFE entered on sensor dropout.

Design a greenhouse irrigation controller that reads three soil moisture sensors and uses the median value to decide watering. Water at 06:00 if median moisture < 30%, skip if a rain sensor indicates wet, and cap total watering to 8 minutes. Add a watchdog that forces valves OFF on timeout.

Build a dual sump pump controller with alternation. State machine: TEST, RUN_A, RUN_B, and ALARM. Alternate pumps each cycle, never run both simultaneously, and stop if a backflow sensor indicates failure. Exercise each pump weekly for 10 seconds. Guarantee WCET < 1 ms and include a 100 ms watchdog.

Regulate a dryer booster fan using time-proportioning PID to maintain duct air at 35 Celsius. Use a 20 s window for duty, implement anti-windup, and cut out if temperature exceeds 60 C. Add a LOCKOUT state that requires manual reset after overtemperature.

Create security lighting logic that fuses inputs from a motion sensor, a door contact, and a light sensor. Turn lights ON when motion or door opens in low light (< 100 lux). If a tamper input is active, enter ALERT mode and flash the lights with a 1 Hz strobe for up to 10 minutes. Include rate limiting to avoid more than 6 on/off cycles per minute.

Implement a pool pump controller with scheduled runs (e.g., 08:00–12:00, 16:00–18:00), a priming sequence (relay ON for 30 seconds at start), and a BACKWASH mode that runs for a fixed 5 minutes when a button is long-pressed. Enter LOCKOUT if a dry sensor is active. Watchdog forces OFF on missed cycles.

Control a motorized main water valve based on multiple leak sensors. On any leak, close the valve and enter ALARM. Provide a weekly self-test that briefly exercises the valve (open/close for 2 seconds each) unless ALARM is active. Limit to no more than 2 exercise cycles per day and guarantee WCET under 1 ms.

Create a transfer controller for backup power with three enum modes: CHARGE, DISCHARGE, and SHED. Fuse inputs for mains presence and battery voltage to decide when to energize the load relay or shed noncritical loads. Guarantee that backfeeding cannot occur (interlocked relays) and use a watchdog to drop to SHED on control failure.

Design a home mode manager with enum modes HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, and VACATION that orchestrates multiple relays (lights, fans, outlets) by schedules and triggers. Provide manual overrides with time-limited holds, a clear state machine for transitions, a 50 ms watchdog, and a concise test plan covering all mode changes and schedule overlaps.

Implement an 8-zone sprinkler controller with per-zone schedules, rain delay, and a MANUAL JOG that runs a selected zone for 2 minutes. Resolve overlapping zone requests by queueing with a one-zone-at-a-time policy. Include a watchdog timer and verify WCET < 3 ms per scheduler tick. Provide test cases for conflict resolution and rain delay recovery.

After a power outage, stagger the recovery of 10 smart relays according to a PRIORITY enum (HIGH, MEDIUM, LOW), with 1-second spacing between activations and a maximum of 3 HIGH devices powered first. Persist and restore last-known states, and include a comprehensive fault-injection test scenario (missed ticks, partial restores) and a watchdog that reverts to SAFE OFF on failure.

Control four motorized shutters with enum modes AUTO, STORM, and MANUAL. Use a wind sensor input in m/s to enter STORM and retract all shutters if wind exceeds 12 m/s; leave STORM when sustained wind falls below 8 m/s for 10 minutes. Provide sunrise/sunset offset scheduling in AUTO, interlock UP/DOWN relays per shutter, a startup self-test, and WCET < 1 ms per shutter.

Build a multi-room occupancy-aware controller for three rooms that manages lights and switched outlets. Modes: HOME, AWAY, NIGHT, and CLEANING. Fuse motion sensors, door contacts, and ambient light levels to decide outputs; enforce schedules (quiet hours 22:00–06:00) and per-room timeouts. Include a watchdog timer and a thorough test plan with deterministic simulated events.

Create a simple pushbutton-controlled relay: press toggles the relay on/off. Debounce the button (30 ms). Use a minimal two-state machine (On, Off) and a watchdog timer that forces the relay Off if not serviced within 1 second.

When a user presses a button, run a bathroom fan relay for exactly 10 minutes, then turn off. A second press during the countdown should cancel and turn it off immediately. Include a watchdog timer that defaults the relay Off on timeout.
Schedule a lamp relay to turn on at 20:00 and off at 06:00 every day. Include a simple enum mode with Auto and Off, and ensure a watchdog timer returns the system to Off if timing tasks stall.

Implement a safety cutoff for a heater relay: if it has been On for more than 30 minutes continuously, force it Off and start a 5-minute cooldown timer during which it cannot be turned back on. Use a tiny state machine and a watchdog.

Make a doorbell chime relay that activates for 1.0 second per button press, with at least 2.0 seconds between activations. Debounce the input and include a watchdog timer to guarantee the relay is Off on fault.

Turn on a porch light relay when motion is detected and keep it on for 120 seconds after the last motion. Cap the maximum continuous On time to 30 minutes for safety. Use a simple state machine and a watchdog.

Allow a heat lamp relay to energize only when ambient temperature is below 25 Celsius. If the temperature sensor reports an error or out-of-range value, ensure the relay is Off. Include a watchdog timer that reverts to a safe Off state.
Blink a status LED at 1 Hz whenever a daily schedule is active, and keep it solid On when inactive. Ensure timing jitter is under 10 ms and include a watchdog timer.
Turn on a nightlight relay when ambient light is below 100 lux and turn it off when above 150 lux (use hysteresis). Include a watchdog that sets the relay Off on timeout.
Switch off a smart outlet relay at 23:00 every day, regardless of current state. Provide an enum mode for Enabled/Disabled, and use a watchdog timer to force Off on failure.
Pulse a relay for 15 seconds when a start button is pressed, ignoring additional presses until the pulse completes. Debounce the button and include a watchdog defaulting to Off.
Open window blinds at 07:00 and close at 22:00 using a simple schedule. Use an enum mode Auto/ManualOff and ensure a watchdog timer places outputs in a safe Off state on timeout.
Latch a siren relay On when a panic button is pressed, then automatically turn it Off after 60 seconds. Use a small state machine with Idle, Active, and Cooldown states and a watchdog.
Implement a system heartbeat: flash an LED twice per second to indicate the control loop is alive. Feed a watchdog timer; if the watchdog ever expires, ensure all controlled relays default to Off.
Generate a 100 ms On pulse on a relay each time a trigger input edge is detected, with a minimum 300 ms gap between pulses. Include a watchdog that fails safe to Off.

Design a porch light controller with enum modes Off, Auto, and ManualOn. In Auto, turn the light on when motion occurs between sunset and sunrise and off 2 minutes after last motion. Provide a clear state machine and a watchdog timer.

Create a water heater scheduler: in Auto mode, allow the heater relay only during 05:00–08:00 and 18:00–22:00, and only if water temperature is below 50 C. Enforce a maximum continuous On time of 45 minutes and include a watchdog.

Control a laundry room exhaust fan using humidity: if humidity exceeds 60%, turn the fan on and keep it running until it drops below 55%. Include a manual override that runs 20 minutes then returns to Auto. Use enum modes and a watchdog.

Build a holiday lights controller with enum patterns Off, Steady, and Blink. Activate automatically on weekends 17:00–23:00. Update at 50 Hz with WCET under 5 ms. Include a watchdog that disables outputs on timeout.

Implement a simple thermostat for a room heater and cooler relays with mutually exclusive control. Use hysteresis around a setpoint (e.g., 22 C) and an enum mode Off/Heat/Cool/Auto. Include a watchdog that drops both relays on fault.

Automate a single irrigation zone with a schedule (Mon/Wed/Fri at 06:00 for 12 minutes) and a rain sensor override. Skip watering if soil moisture is above 35%. Ensure a watchdog timer and a safe Off default.

Control a window opener with two relays (Open and Close) and two limit switches. Use a state machine to prevent both relays from energizing at the same time, stop at limits, and handle a 30-second motion timeout. Include a watchdog.

Ventilate a garage using a CO sensor: if CO exceeds 20 ppm, turn the fan on; turn it off when below 10 ppm. Allow operation only between 07:00 and 22:00. Include a sensor-fault safe Off and a watchdog timer.

Make a two-switch hallway light with a single light relay: either switch toggles the light. Debounce both inputs, implement a brief 200 ms change lockout to avoid flicker, and include a watchdog that defaults to Off.

Create a smart power strip with four controllable relays. Each outlet has its own schedule and an enum mode Auto/On/Off. On watchdog timeout, all outlets must go Off. Ensure outlets 1 and 2 cannot be On simultaneously.

Combine a motion sensor and ambient light sensor to control a living room lamp: in Auto mode, only turn on when motion is detected and lux < 150, and turn off 3 minutes after last motion or when lux > 300. Include a watchdog.

Control a door strike relay: allow a 5 second energize only if a keypad grants access and the current time is within business hours. Enforce a 10 second lockout between activations, debounce inputs, and include a watchdog.

Schedule a pet feeder motor relay to run for 8 seconds at 07:30 and 18:00 daily. Detect jams via current draw > 1.5 A and abort immediately, entering a 2-minute lockout state. Include a watchdog and safe Off default.

Bedroom heater controller with enum modes Off, Auto, and Eco. Auto maintains 21 C with 0.5 C hysteresis; Eco maintains 18 C. Allow schedule-based mode changes. Include a watchdog that disables the heater on fault.

Automate curtains using sunrise/sunset times and a local button override. Use a state machine to drive Open/Close relays, observe end-stop switches, and back off on stall timeout. Include a watchdog that de-energizes on error.

Bathroom fan program: Auto mode turns on when relative humidity rises by more than 10% within 5 minutes, and runs at least 15 minutes. Manual mode runs 20 minutes per press. Cap continuous runtime at 45 minutes. Watchdog required.

Design a scene controller with two buttons that map to scenes AllOff, Reading, and Movie, driving three relays. Differentiate short vs long press. Use an explicit state machine and a watchdog that reverts to AllOff on timeout.
Smart plug energy saver: turn the outlet off if measured power stays below 2 W for 30 minutes, except during 06:00–08:00 when it must remain on. Include an enum mode and watchdog safe Off behavior.
Aquarium lighting schedule: On at 09:00, Off at 21:00, with a Feeding pause that turns lights off for 15 minutes upon button press then resumes schedule. Implement modes and a watchdog.
Nightlight with brightness levels Low/Medium/High and Auto modes using a light sensor. Auto selects level based on lux bands. Provide a state machine and a watchdog that forces Off on fault.

Implement a time-proportioned PID thermostat: compute heater relay on-time within a 10 second window to hold 21 C, updating at 1 Hz with WCET < 2 ms. Include anti-windup, a maximum duty of 70%, sensor-fault detection, and a watchdog that fails safe to Off.

Control a ventilation fan using sensor fusion of CO2 (ppm), VOC index, and humidity. Derive an air-quality score and turn the fan relay on when the score exceeds a threshold. Enforce a maximum 80% duty per hour, schedule operation only 06:00–22:00, and include a watchdog.

Water heater safety controller with states Safe, Heating, and Alarm. Heat only when temp < 55 C during scheduled windows; if a leak sensor triggers or temp > 65 C, immediately cut power and enter Alarm until manually reset. Use enums, timeouts, and a watchdog.

Smart charging outlet: allow charging only 22:00–06:00. Stop when battery voltage exceeds 12.8 V or current falls below 0.2 A for 5 minutes. Detect overcurrent > 5 A and fault. Include a state machine, hysteresis, and a watchdog.

Pool pump automation with daily cycles and filter monitoring. If filter pressure is high and motor current is above normal, detect clog and stop, retry up to 3 times with 10 minute intervals, then fault out. Respect WCET < 2 ms at 10 Hz and include a watchdog.

Greenhouse misting control using PID on humidity to time-proportion a valve relay, active only 08:00–18:00. Enforce min off/on times (20 s/10 s), prevent oversaturation (>90% RH), and fail safe Off on sensor error. Include watchdog and anti-windup.

Multi-sensor HVAC damper control with enum modes Idle, Preheat, Vent, and Cool. Fuse temperature and air-quality inputs to choose mode. Ensure mutually exclusive actuator relays, 30 s interlocks, WCET < 1 ms at 20 Hz, and a watchdog.

Adaptive outdoor lighting with sensor fusion: combine ambient lux and motion density to decide relay schedules with dimmer states. Include modes Off, Eco, and Full, and guarantee fail-safe behavior under watchdog timeout.

Drive a motorized gate with Open/Close/Stop relays and safety edge sensors. Implement a robust state machine with timeouts, soft-start timing, obstruction detection, and manual override. Include a watchdog that halts movement on failure.

Sump pump supervisor using two float switches and a moisture sensor. Prevent short-cycling, detect stuck-on conditions, and raise an alarm. Run control at 10 Hz with WCET < 1 ms. Use enums, lockout timers, and a watchdog.

Create a whole-home mode orchestrator with enum modes Home, Away, Night, and Vacation that coordinates multiple relays (lights and outlets). In Vacation, emulate occupancy with randomized schedules (±10 minutes). Define a formal state machine, include a watchdog, and specify self-test behavior at startup.

Design a multi-zone HVAC coordinator that controls heating and cooling relays for three zones. Use PID per zone with anti-windup, and arbitration that prevents heat and cool at the same time. Guarantee a 10 Hz loop with WCET < 2 ms, watchdog supervision, and comprehensive fault handling for sensor or relay failures.

Implement a peak-load shedding controller for up to six appliance relays. Prioritize loads and shed during tariff windows signaled by a schedule. Provide enum modes Normal, Peak, and Override; enforce mutual exclusions and minimum on/off times; include a watchdog and specify unit tests for jitter tolerance and edge cases.

Develop a domestic water system controller with modes Fill, Distribute, and Protect. Coordinate pump and valve relays using a deterministic state machine at 100 Hz (WCET ≤ 0.5 ms). Detect leaks via flow/pressure discrepancies, fail safe on watchdog expiry, and outline a HIL test harness.

Build an advanced door automation system with modes Auto, Manual, Locked, and Party. Fuse motion, door contact, and lock status to control latch and light relays with interlocks and jam detection. Specify WCET < 1 ms at 50 Hz, watchdog behavior, and a comprehensive test plan including power-loss mid-actuation.
Toggle a relay when a debounced pushbutton is pressed. Use a 50 ms debounce, and include a watchdog that forces the relay OFF if no heartbeat is received for 10 s. Safe default: relay OFF at startup.
Turn on a light relay when a motion sensor triggers, then keep it on for 30 s after the last motion. Allow retriggering during that window. Include a watchdog that forces the light OFF on timeout.
When the user presses a button, energize a relay for exactly 5 minutes, then turn it off. A second press during the countdown cancels the timer and turns the relay off immediately.

Implement a dusk-to-dawn switch: turn a relay ON when ambient light falls below 80 lux, and OFF when it rises above 120 lux (hysteresis). Poll every 200 ms. Fail-safe OFF if the sensor value is invalid or the watchdog fires.
Create a daily schedule that turns a relay ON at 07:00 and OFF at 22:00. The schedule should hold across reboots using the real-time clock. On watchdog timeout, default to OFF.
Single-button control for a smart plug: short press toggles the relay, long press (>2 s) forces the relay OFF. LED indicates ON (solid) vs OFF (off). Ensure debounce and safe OFF on watchdog.

When a door sensor opens, pulse a chime relay for 200 ms. Ensure the worst-case execution time of the event handler is under 1 ms, and use a watchdog that guarantees the chime is OFF if the control loop stalls.
If a toggle switch is ON, blink a porch light at 2 Hz; otherwise keep it OFF. The blink must be stable even if the control loop jitters by ±5 ms.
Any time the relay is turned ON (by button or schedule), start an auto-off timer for 15 minutes. If the timer expires, turn the relay OFF. Default OFF on boot and on watchdog events.
Run a bathroom fan relay when humidity exceeds 60% RH and turn it off when it drops below 55% RH. Sample every 1 s. Watchdog must force the relay OFF on fault.
On door open, energize a courtesy light for 20 s, then turn it off. Ignore repeated opens during the active period.
If a water leak sensor goes active, de-energize a main water valve (relay) immediately and latch this safe state until a reset button is held for 3 s. Watchdog must also keep the valve closed.

Provide two user modes via an enum: ECO and NORMAL. In ECO, whenever the relay is switched ON, auto-turn it OFF after 5 minutes. In NORMAL, leave it latched. A button cycles modes and a status LED shows the current mode.
Turn on a nightlight relay when ambient light is below 100 lux and turn it off above 150 lux. Sample at 10 Hz. If the sample task misses two cycles, the watchdog should force the relay OFF.

Implement a simple kitchen timer switch: holding the button enters a setting mode where each 1 s of hold increases the duration by 1 minute (wrap at 10 minutes). Releasing starts the countdown and energizes a relay for that duration, then turns it OFF. Default OFF.

Hallway lighting controller: motion sensor turns lights ON only when ambient light < 80 lux; off-delay 90 s after last motion. Include a manual override toggle that locks lights ON until toggled again. Model this as a state machine with states OFF, AUTO_ON, MANUAL_ON, and include a watchdog that forces OFF if no heartbeat for 1 s.

Irrigation control for one zone: run at 06:30 on weekdays for 15 minutes, but skip if a rain sensor is active. Provide a manual RUN/CANCEL button. Use an enum for modes IDLE, SCHEDULED, MANUAL, and a watchdog that de-energizes the valve on fault.

Staircase two-way control: two wall switches control a single light. Debounce each input by 30 ms and toggle the light on any valid edge. Add a watchdog that turns the light OFF if the loop does not tick for 500 ms.

Space heater controller: keep room at 21.0 C with 0.5 C hysteresis. If a window sensor is OPEN, force heater OFF. Provide enum modes COMFORT (21 C), ECO (19 C), and AWAY (16 C). Implement as a state machine with a watchdog and safe default OFF.

Three-speed fan: control three relays for LOW/MED/HIGH with enum mode OFF/LOW/MED/HIGH. Enforce that at most one speed relay is energized at a time and insert a 300 ms neutral pause between speed changes. Watchdog forces OFF on fault.

Security light: turn on when either motion is detected or the door opens, but only between sunset and 23:00. Off-delay 2 minutes. Include a manual override to keep it OFF regardless (VACATION mode). Implement this with an explicit state machine and ensure WCET < 3 ms.

Smart plug with child lock: in LOCKED mode, ignore button presses; in UNLOCKED, short press toggles. Long press (>3 s) toggles the lock. LED shows LOCKED (slow blink) vs UNLOCKED (solid when ON). Watchdog sets relay OFF on fault.

Laundry room ventilator: turn fan ON when humidity > 65% OR when a 10-minute timer is running (started by button). If either condition clears, keep running until both are inactive, then stop. State machine with debounced inputs and watchdog.

Window blind controller: OPEN and CLOSE relays with two limit switches. Enum modes AUTO and MANUAL. In AUTO, follow a schedule (open at 08:00, close at sunset). Prevent both relays from energizing simultaneously and stop when a limit is reached. Watchdog must drop both relays if the task stalls.

Aquarium lighting schedule: two relays for day and moonlight. Turn day ON at 09:00 and OFF at 21:00; moonlight ON at 21:00 and OFF at 23:00. Manual override button toggles current phase with a 30-minute timeout. Include a state machine and a watchdog that ensures both relays OFF on fault.

Bathroom light and fan: motion turns light ON. When light goes OFF, keep the fan running for 10 minutes. If humidity > 70% RH, run the fan regardless of light. Manual switch forces both OFF. Use a state machine and a watchdog.

Holiday lights scheduler: turn ON at sunset and OFF at 23:00 with a random jitter of ±5 minutes each day. Safety rule: never keep the lights ON for more than 4 hours continuously. Manual override switch with 1-hour timeout. Watchdog forces OFF on fault.

Doorbell control: during 07:00–22:00, ring chime for 500 ms on button press; during 22:00–07:00, ring only 100 ms. Provide a DND mode that ignores presses entirely. Ensure debouncing and watchdog safety.

Garage heater interlock: heater ON only if CO level is SAFE and the garage door is CLOSED. If either becomes unsafe/open, shut heater OFF immediately. Enum status OK/INHIBITED/FAULT and a state machine for transitions. Watchdog defaults to OFF.

Pool pump: run 09:00–12:00 and 15:00–18:00 daily. If a dry-run sensor is active, stop immediately and inhibit for 10 minutes. After power restore, wait 10 s before starting. Implement as a state machine with a watchdog.

Greenhouse misting: if temperature > 25 C and humidity < 50% RH, spray for 30 s every 15 minutes. Manual button starts a one-shot spray for 60 s. Ensure schedules do not overlap and the valve relay defaults to OFF on watchdog.
Touch faucet: touch sensor toggles a water valve relay; auto-shutoff after 60 s. If a leak sensor triggers, force OFF and latch until a reset sequence (double-press). State machine with watchdog.

Pet feeder: at scheduled times (08:00 and 18:00), run a feeder motor relay for 5 s. Only run if the hatch-closed sensor is TRUE; otherwise signal a fault via an alarm relay and skip the feed. Provide a manual FEED button with debounce and a watchdog.

Away mode scenes: enum modes HOME, AWAY, VACATION. In AWAY and VACATION, randomly toggle selected lights between 18:00 and 22:00 to simulate occupancy. Manual interactions are ignored in VACATION. Include a hierarchical state machine and a watchdog that reverts to HOME on fault.

Hallway nightlight levels: use two relays to create LOW and HIGH brightness steps. When motion occurs at night (lux < 50), turn on LOW for 60 s; if a second motion occurs, step to HIGH, then back to LOW after 30 s of no motion, and OFF after another 60 s. Prevent relay chatter and include a watchdog.

Thermostat with time-proportional control: compute a PI control output each second to maintain 21.0 C, then drive a heater relay using a 10-minute windowed duty cycle based on that output. Include anti-windup, minimum ON/OFF time of 2 minutes, enum modes OFF/HEAT, a state machine, and a watchdog that forces OFF on fault.

Occupancy lighting with sensor fusion: sample two PIR sensors and a sound level input at 20 Hz to compute an occupancy confidence (0–100%). Turn lights ON when confidence > 60% and lux < 80, with a 2-minute decay timer. Implement the fusion and hysteresis in a state machine, require WCET < 2 ms per cycle, and include a watchdog.

Water heater controller: estimate heat demand from tank temperature error and its rate; use a PID to compute a duty fraction across a 5-minute control window for the heater contactor. Enforce max continuous ON of 30 minutes and a minimum OFF of 3 minutes. Provide MANUAL and AUTO modes and a watchdog.

Demand-response coordinator: keep total load under 3.0 kW by scheduling two appliance relays with priorities. During DR events, shed the lower-priority relay first; restore when budget allows. Include NORMAL/DR/EMERGENCY enum modes, a preemption state machine, and a watchdog with safe OFF policy.

Sequenced startup for multiple relays: when entering RUN mode, energize up to four relays in order with 500 ms spacing; on STOP, de-energize in reverse order. Enforce that no two relays change state in the same 50 ms tick. Provide a supervisor watchdog and report a fault if timing constraints are missed.

Dehumidifier with PI control and sensor fusion: combine two humidity sensors using a median filter to reject outliers. Maintain 50% RH target using time-proportional PI control with a 10-minute window. Enforce minimum ON/OFF 3 minutes, states IDLE/RUN/LOCKOUT, and a watchdog.

Smart irrigation with data fusion: decide watering based on soil moisture from two probes (take the lower reading) and a rain flag. Adjust the schedule so a 10-minute slot runs only if moisture < 30% and no rain. Cap total watering to 20 minutes per hour. Use a state machine and a watchdog.

Sump pump supervisor: fuse a float switch and an analog water level to decide when to run. Use a proportional duty strategy over a 2-minute window to maintain level below a threshold. If the float is stuck or the level rises during RUN, assert an alarm relay and enter FAULT. Include watchdog and recovery rules.

Adaptive lighting with staged relays: hold 200 lux by selecting among OFF/LOW/HIGH relays and adding a duty-cycled BOOST relay if needed. Use a PI algorithm for the BOOST duty across a 60 s window. Include mode enum DAY/NIGHT/AWAY, state machine transitions, and watchdog failsafe.

Dryer booster fan: detect dryer operation using sensor fusion of temperature rise and an airflow reed. Start the booster relay when both indicate ON, and keep running for 3 minutes after they go OFF. Enter FAULT if the fan current sensor indicates no draw when ON. Include a watchdog.

Home mode manager: coordinate LIGHTS, PLUGS, and SPRINKLERS using enum modes HOME/AWAY/SLEEP/VACATION. Each mode enables different schedules and overrides. Implement a top-level hierarchical state machine, heartbeat monitoring, and a watchdog that forces all relays to their safe states on fault. Specify control tick 50 ms and WCET < 5 ms; include a test plan for power loss, clock drift, and mid-transition resets.

Relay hub with rule engine: allow users to define automation rules (IF conditions with schedules and sensor states THEN set relays). Resolve conflicts with priorities and last-writer-wins policy. Provide simulation time, a watchdog supervisor that staggers shutdown to avoid inrush, and a verification plan with unit tests for rule ordering, debouncing races, and schedule overlaps.

Multi-room scenes: define scenes MORNING/DAY/EVENING/NIGHT/CINEMA that map to per-room relay sets. Scenes activate by schedule or occupancy, with manual overrides that timeout after 30 minutes. Use a hierarchical state machine, enforce a configurable limit on simultaneous relays to reduce load, include watchdog supervision, and deliver a test matrix covering all transitions and edge cases.

Resilient irrigation controller: multiple zones with per-zone schedules, rain skip, pressure switch interlock, and a shared pump relay with anti-hammer sequencing. Include MAINTENANCE and FAULT modes, watchdog supervision, timing constraints (tick 100 ms, per-zone evaluation WCET 2 ms), and acceptance tests with simulated sensor faults and power cycles.

Emergency load shedding system: monitor a power meter input and manage relays in modes NORMAL/ALERT/CRITICAL. Shed nonessential loads by priority to keep demand under a threshold, then restore in a rolling schedule when safe. Use a deterministic state machine, include brownout detection, a system watchdog, and a comprehensive test plan with fault injection (stuck relay, sensor timeout) and worst-case timing analysis.

Make a simple toggle: when the wall switch is pressed, toggle a light relay. Debounce the switch for 50 ms. If no events occur for 10 s because the main loop stalls, a watchdog should force the relay to OFF.
Use a momentary pushbutton to control a relay: short press toggles the relay state; holding for 2 s always turns it OFF. Ensure the relay starts OFF on boot.
When a stairwell button is pressed, turn a light relay ON for 90 s, extending the timer on further presses. Blink a status indicator for the last 10 s. On watchdog timeout, go OFF.
Implement two independent switches that both control a single light relay (three-way behavior). Any press toggles the relay. Maintain state across power loss.
Create a daily schedule to switch a relay ON at 07:00 and OFF at 22:30 local time. If the device restarts, catch up and apply the most recent scheduled state.
Control a bathroom fan relay from humidity: turn ON above 70 %RH and back OFF below 60 %RH (hysteresis). Enforce a minimum ON time of 2 min once started.
Turn a porch light relay ON at 20:00 and OFF at 23:30 every day. Provide a manual override switch that temporarily toggles the relay but does not change the schedule.
Require a double-tap (two presses within 400 ms) to turn a child’s nightlight relay ON; a single press turns it OFF. Ignore any additional taps for 1 s.
Build a repeating cycle timer: run a pump relay ON for 10 s, then OFF for 50 s, continuing until a stop button is pressed.
When a doorbell button is pressed, energize the chime relay for exactly 300 ms, regardless of press duration. Enforce a minimum 1 s lockout between rings.
Ensure all relays start OFF on power-up. If a heartbeat signal is not received within 5 s, a watchdog must force all relays to a safe OFF state.
Implement a virtual switch command handler: upon receiving an ON or OFF command, set the relay accordingly, but ignore rapid toggles closer than 1 s apart.
Provide a 'boost' button for a water heater outlet: a press turns the relay ON for 30 min, pressing again during that period cancels and turns it OFF.
Between 23:00 and 06:00 (quiet hours), ignore manual button presses for a specific relay. Outside quiet hours, the button toggles normally.
Create an enum mode selector with values OFF, ON, and TIMER. In TIMER mode, a press starts a 5 min ON period; in OFF and ON modes, the relay is forced accordingly.

Design a bathroom fan controller with a state machine and enum modes MANUAL, AUTO, and HUMIDISTAT. Motion starts AUTO mode timing (10 min), humidity over 70 %RH starts HUMIDISTAT mode (min 5 min). Manual switch forces MANUAL. On watchdog timeout, go to MANUAL OFF.

Implement blind control using two interlocked relays with a state machine: STOPPED, MOVING_UP, MOVING_DOWN. Long press moves continuously, short press stops. Limit any move to 15 s and schedule open at 07:30, close at 20:30. Ensure worst-case execution time under 2 ms per cycle.

Coordinate a water pump relay and a water heater relay so they never run simultaneously. Give priority to the heater if both are requested. Obey a schedule that allows pump operation only 06:00–08:00 and 18:00–20:00. If a watchdog expires, turn both OFF.

Create home mode automation with enum modes HOME, AWAY, and SLEEP. In AWAY, randomize a lamp relay between 18:00–22:00; in SLEEP, disable hallway auto-on. Provide a button and schedule to transition modes and a state machine to manage behaviors.

Control two ventilation relays that alternate hourly to balance wear. If temperature exceeds 30 C, force both ON. Enforce a minimum 5 min OFF time before restarting a fan. Include a watchdog that reverts to both OFF on fault.

Implement a sump pump controller with a state machine: IDLE, PUMPING, and LOCKOUT. A high float switch starts PUMPING and runs until the low switch clears; if more than 10 starts occur in 60 min, enter LOCKOUT for 10 min. Manual override available.
Create a three-relay scene controller with three buttons. When multiple relays are commanded ON, sequence them with 200 ms spacing to limit inrush. On watchdog timeout, turn all OFF.

Add an energy-saver schedule for a water heater: allowed ON only within configured time windows unless a manual boost is active. After 90 min continuous ON, force a 30 min cooldown. Manage with a state machine.
Control a door strike with schedule-based access. A valid request opens for 5 s (adjustable 2–10 s). If more than 5 opens occur in 60 s, enter a 2 min lockout. Watchdog forces locked state on fault.
Greenhouse heater relay: day setpoint 22 C and night setpoint 18 C based on a schedule. Use 0.5 C hysteresis and hard safety cutoff at 30 C with alarm. Manual override switch exists.

Run irrigation zones sequentially at 05:00: zone1 10 min, zone2 8 min, zone3 8 min, zone4 12 min. Skip any zone if a rain sensor is active. Provide manual start/pause and a watchdog that guarantees all valves closed on fault.

Manage two stairwell lights with sensors at top and bottom. If either sensor triggers, turn on the nearest light; if both trigger, turn both on. Keep active lights on for 90 s after last motion, but cap any continuous on period to 10 min.

Operate a pet feeder door with open/close interlocked relays using a state machine: CLOSED, OPENING, OPEN, CLOSING, OBSTRUCTED. Scheduled opens morning and evening; do not close if an obstruction switch is active. Watchdog returns to CLOSED on fault.

Laundry room light automation: in AUTO mode, motion turns on; a vibration sensor keeps it on while the dryer runs; in MANUAL mode, a button directly toggles and disables AUTO. Provide enum modes and clear state transitions.

Air purifier with enum speeds OFF, LOW, HIGH mapped to one or two relays. When changing speeds, wait 2 s with both relays OFF before activating the new combination. Schedule: HIGH from 09:00–21:00, LOW otherwise. Watchdog defaults to OFF.

Pool pump controller: schedule daily run 09:00–17:00; if water temperature drops below 5 C, run 15 min each hour for freeze protection. Manual override button toggles a temporary ON. Ensure worst-case execution time <= 5 ms.
Door-triggered lighting: when the entry door opens after 18:00, turn on porch and hallway relays. Turn hallway OFF after 2 min and porch OFF after 5 min. Reopening the door restarts both timers.
Smart outlet with overload input: if overload asserted, immediately turn the outlet relay OFF and block restarts for 10 min. Require manual reset via button. Watchdog keeps outlet OFF on any fault.

Bedroom lighting rules: short tap toggles main light; long press (>800 ms) toggles reading light on a second relay. In SLEEP mode between 23:00 and 06:00, long presses are ignored. Use an enum mode selector.

Water valve safety system: normally closed valve relay. If either of two leak sensors is wet, close the valve and latch an alarm relay until both sensors are dry for 5 min and a reset is requested. Watchdog enforces valve closed on timeout.

Implement a thermostat using time-proportional control: compute a PID on temperature (Celsius) and drive a heater relay using a 60 s output window (e.g., ON duty matches PID percentage). Enforce a safety limit of 28 C and fail OFF on sensor fault. Include a watchdog and a state machine OFF/HEAT.

Ventilation fan control with sensor fusion: combine two humidity sensors and a temperature sensor; reject any humidity sensor that deviates by >10 %RH from the other. Use the fused RH to start the fan above 65 %RH with a 5 min minimum ON. Quiet hours schedule limits operation. Watchdog to safe OFF.

Hot water recirculation pump: run on schedule in the morning and evening, but skip if return line temperature is already >= 45 C. Provide a manual 15 min boost. Enforce max continuous ON of 15 min and a 10 min cooldown. Watchdog turns OFF on fault.

Greenhouse ventilation staging: use two fans controlled by relays. Fuse two temperature sensors using median; compute a PID demand and map 0–49% to both OFF, 50–79% to Fan1 ON, 80–100% to both ON. Ensure anti-chatter delays (5 s) when changing stages and hard alarm >40 C.

Secure door controller with enum modes NORMAL, LOCKED_OUT, and EMERGENCY. Schedule unlock windows for NORMAL. On tamper input, enter LOCKED_OUT; on fire input, enter EMERGENCY unlocking relays. Include a weekly 03:00 self-test pulse (500 ms) and a watchdog.

Freezer control with safety interlocks: maintain -18 C using relay control with 1 C hysteresis and a minimum 3 min compressor OFF time. If temperature rises above -10 C, assert an alarm relay. Ensure worst-case execution time of 2 ms and watchdog to force compressor OFF on fault.

Daylight-linked lighting: maintain approximately 300 lx using a PID on a light sensor; actuate three lamp groups via relays by staging them to approximate the PID output (no more than one switch per group per minute). Quiet hours from 22:00 to 06:00 force low stage. Watchdog to default OFF.

Boiler enable control: fuse two indoor temperature sensors (discard outlier if difference >1.5 C) and consider an outdoor sensor for setback. Compute a PID heat demand; enable the boiler relay when demand exceeds 10%, and keep the circulation pump relay running for 2 min after boiler off. Include high temperature lockout at 75 C and a watchdog.

Drying rack automation: manage a heater relay and a fan relay. Use humidity to drive a simple PI control loop to decide fan duty over a 120 s window; heater allowed only when humidity >60 %RH and air temperature <30 C. Stop everything after 60 min continuous operation. Watchdog to safe OFF.

Water tank fill controller using two level sensors. State machine with states IDLE, FILLING, and FAULT. Start filling when low level is dry; stop when high level is wet or after a 10 min maximum fill time (then FAULT). Rate-limit relay cycles to no more than once per minute and include a watchdog.

Design a whole-home schedule engine for multiple relays (lights and outlets) with enum modes HOME, AWAY, VACATION, and ALARM. Use state machines per mode to apply rules like randomized evening lights in VACATION. Include watchdog supervisors for each rule executor. Provide test scenarios for mode transitions, power-loss recovery with missed-event catch-up, and rule conflict resolution. Specify timing so each cycle meets WCET of 3 ms.

Multi-room heating coordinator: per-room state machines with enum modes ECO, COMFORT, and BOOST; each room computes PID heat demand from temperature sensors and schedules to decide zone valve relays. Fuse duplicate sensors per room by discarding outliers. Add freeze protect mode that prevents all valves from being closed simultaneously when any room <5 C. Include a 100 ms deterministic tick, watchdogs, and comprehensive tests.

Implement a pantry dumbwaiter with two interlocked motor relays. State machine with IDLE, MOVING_UP, MOVING_DOWN, DOORS_OPEN, and FAULT. Door interlocks and overload input must be respected. Enforce max travel time per move of 8 s and require an exhaustive test suite for edge cases. Guarantee WCET of 1 ms and a watchdog that halts in FAULT.

Create a comprehensive irrigation controller for 8 zones. Enum modes AUTO, MANUAL, OFF, and SAFE. Schedules, rain delay, and manual runtime per zone. Allow at most 2 valves at any time with a state machine that handles sequencing and preemption. Include watchdog supervisors and property-based tests proving no overlap beyond the limit and that all valves close on faults.

Build a building entrance control system managing door strike, lobby lights, and signage relays. Modes NORMAL, AFTER_HOURS, LOCKDOWN, and EMERGENCY with scheduled transitions and manual overrides. Watchdog and heartbeat supervision from an external panel; define fail-safe states for link loss. Provide acceptance tests for power-loss recovery, missed schedule catch-up, and concurrent event handling, with per-cycle WCET under 2 ms.

Create a simple on/off controller: a single wall switch drives one lighting relay. Use an enum for states {OFF, ON}, apply 30 ms debounce, and implement a small state machine so each clean press toggles the relay. If the watchdog ever expires, force the relay to OFF. Run at 50 Hz with WCET under 1 ms.

I want a pushbutton that toggles a single relay. Short press toggles, long press (>2 s) forces OFF. Debounce the input, keep an enum {OFF, ON}, and fail safe to OFF on any watchdog timeout. Keep loop timing deterministic at 20 ms.

Build a 90-second countdown switch: pressing a momentary button turns a relay ON for exactly 90 s, then OFF. Retriggering during the countdown restarts the full 90 s. Include a simple two-state machine, 25 ms debounce, and watchdog handling that guarantees the relay is OFF if the controller stalls.

Schedule a relay to turn ON daily at 07:00 and OFF at 08:00. Use a minimal state machine and an enum {IDLE, ACTIVE}. If time is invalid at startup, keep the relay OFF until the next scheduled event. On watchdog timeout, force OFF. Timing jitter for event execution must be less than 100 ms.

Mirror a maintained switch to a relay output with robust 40 ms debounce. Represent the relay status as an enum and include a trivial state machine to handle transitions. Ensure that watchdog expiry puts the relay in a safe OFF state and that WCET stays under 0.5 ms.

Design a basic motion-activated light: when a motion input asserts, turn a relay ON for 2 minutes, then turn it OFF. While timing, additional motion extends the timer. Use a small state machine with {IDLE, TIMING} and a watchdog that forces OFF if triggered.

Make an auto-off fan control: a single switch turns the fan relay ON, but it must automatically turn OFF after 30 minutes of continuous operation. Each press restarts the 30-minute timer. Include debounce, a two-state machine, and a watchdog that reverts to OFF on fault.

Implement a press-to-light function: one button press turns a relay ON for 30 seconds and then OFF. Additional presses during that window extend by 30 seconds each. Create a simple state machine and include a watchdog that ensures the relay defaults to OFF.

Create a noon chime using a relay: every day at 12:00, pulse the relay ON for 1.0 s and then OFF. Add an enum {WAIT, PULSE} and ensure that watchdog timeouts immediately drive the relay OFF. Limit scheduling jitter to under 50 ms.

Provide a stairway toggle: rising edges on a momentary button toggle a relay. Debounce for 20 ms, model with enum {OFF, ON}, and add a watchdog that forces OFF when not serviced. Poll the input at 50 Hz with a WCET of 1 ms.

On each clean button press, output a 200 ms relay pulse, then return to OFF. Reject additional presses until the pulse completes. Use a small state machine, debounce for 30 ms, and a watchdog that guarantees the relay is OFF if the controller is unresponsive.

When a door contact opens, energize a relay for 500 ms and then turn it OFF, ignoring further openings for a 2 s refractory period. Implement a state machine with {IDLE, PULSE, LOCKOUT} and a watchdog that ensures OFF is the fallback.

Make a weekly schedule for a single relay: ON at 18:00, OFF at 23:00 on weekdays; OFF all day on weekends. Use enums for days and states, and ensure a watchdog timeout forces OFF. Time event handling jitter under 100 ms.

Simple toggle controller please: a button toggles a relay via a two-state machine with 25 ms debounce. Default to OFF at startup, and guarantee the watchdog puts it back to OFF if the loop hangs. Run deterministically at 10 ms cycle time.

Between 18:00 and 23:00 keep a lamp relay ON, otherwise OFF. Use a state machine and an enum {DAY, EVENING}. If the time source is missing, keep OFF. Any watchdog failure must force OFF. Event latency budget ≤ 100 ms.

Two-button hallway light: two momentary switches control one relay as a toggle from either location. Use a debounced edge-detect state machine, ignore presses closer than 150 ms apart, and ensure a watchdog fallback to OFF. Provide enum {OFF, ON}.

Control window blinds with two interlocked relays (UP/DOWN). A single rocker input starts movement; movement stops after 18 s or when a stop command arrives. Enforce mutual exclusion, include enum {STOPPED, MOVING_UP, MOVING_DOWN}, add a watchdog that stops motion on timeout, and require a 2 s rest between direction changes.

Create a bathroom fan with modes OFF, ON, AUTO. In AUTO, turn the fan relay ON when humidity > 70% RH and OFF when humidity < 60% RH (2% hysteresis). A single button cycles modes. Include a clear state machine, 10 Hz sampling, and a watchdog that forces OFF on failure.

Water heater scheduler with boost: ON daily 05:00–07:00 and 18:00–20:00. A button triggers a 30-minute BOOST outside those times. Use enum {OFF, SCHEDULE, BOOST}, a state machine to resolve conflicts, cap continuous ON to 2 hours, and fail safe to OFF on watchdog.

Vacation lighting: follow an evening schedule but randomize each ON/OFF by ±15 minutes. Provide manual override via a button that suspends randomness until midnight. Use enum {SCHEDULE, OVERRIDE}, a state machine, and watchdog-driven safe OFF.

Door strike logic: energize a relay for 750 ms only when both a PIN-valid signal and a door-closed sensor are true. Enforce a 5 s lockout between activations. Implement a state machine with {IDLE, PULSE, LOCKOUT}, and force OFF on watchdog expiry.

Heater with child lock: a button toggles a LOCK mode. When LOCKED, ignore power button presses. Include an enum {UNLOCKED, LOCKED} and a state machine managing heater ON/OFF. Scheduled ON at 20:00 should still work. Watchdog must force heater OFF.

Pump safety controller: run a pump relay only if a float switch indicates water present and measured current is between 0.5 A and 3.0 A. If dry-run or overcurrent is detected, latch an ERROR state until a long press (>3 s) resets it. Include enum {IDLE, RUN, ERROR}, watchdog OFF fallback, and sample current at 10 Hz.

Scene button cycles three lighting scenes over two relays. Each press advances enum {SCENE1, SCENE2, SCENE3}. Provide a state machine that maps scenes to relay patterns, debounce 30 ms, and ensure the watchdog forces both relays OFF on timeout.

Smart plug with daily limit: allow a relay to be ON for a maximum of 2 hours per day, resetting at midnight. A button toggles ON/OFF until the quota is used. Use enum {OFF, ON, QUOTA_EXCEEDED}, a state machine, and ensure watchdog expiration turns the relay OFF.

Motion-and-light rule: turn a light relay ON for 3 minutes when motion is detected and ambient light < 100 lux. Extend while motion continues. Use a state machine with hysteresis on the light threshold (±10 lux), debounce motion input, and watchdog to OFF.

Gate controller using a single button: first press opens (relay A pulsed 1 s), second press stops, third press closes (relay B pulsed 1 s). Use limit switch inputs to detect fully open/closed. Enforce that only one relay can pulse at a time, include a state machine, and fail safe to no output on watchdog.

Greenhouse fan with modes OFF/ON/SCHEDULE: SCHEDULE runs 10:00–16:00, but if temperature exceeds 30 °C it must force ON; turn back OFF below 28 °C. Use an enum for modes, a state machine to resolve priorities, and watchdog OFF fallback. Sample temperature at 1 Hz.

Laundry reminder: when vibration is detected, start a 60-minute timer; at expiry, pulse a buzzer relay for 5 s. Ignore new vibration while timing. Use a three-state machine {IDLE, TIMING, ALERT}, debounce vibration input, and ensure watchdog drives the relay OFF.

Multi-duration timer switch: a button cycles through 5, 10, and 15 minute presets (LED feedback assumed). A second press starts the selected countdown and energizes a relay until the timer elapses. Use enum for presets, a state machine for selection/run, and watchdog OFF fallback.

Hallway light with day/night behavior: determine enum {DAY, NIGHT} from a light sensor with threshold 200 lux (±20 lux hysteresis). On motion, turn the relay ON for 120 s in DAY and 30 s in NIGHT. State machine governs timers. Watchdog forces OFF.

Two-speed fan using two interlocked relays: button cycles enum {OFF, LOW, HIGH}. Enforce a 2 s all-OFF delay when moving between LOW and HIGH. Include a mode state machine, input debounce, and default to OFF on watchdog timeout.

Sprinkler zone control: schedule watering for 10 minutes at 06:00 on Mon/Wed/Fri. If a rain sensor is active, skip watering. Provide a MANUAL button to start 10 minutes immediately. Use a state machine with enum {IDLE, RUN}, and ensure watchdog enforces OFF.

Garage heater interlock: allow the heater relay ON only if the garage door sensor indicates closed. A button requests ON/OFF. If the door opens, immediately turn OFF and latch until door closes again. Use enum {OFF, REQUESTED, ON, LOCKOUT}, state machine, and watchdog OFF fallback.

Coffee maker timer: lid-closed sensor must be true to allow a 10-minute brew cycle when the start button is pressed. Include states {IDLE, RUN, DONE}, auto-off at 10 minutes, and a watchdog that forces OFF if anything stalls.

Implement a thermostat that uses PID to maintain room temperature at a configurable setpoint in °C by switching a heater relay. Sample at 1 Hz, compute PID with anti-windup, and add a relay chatter guard (minimum 30 s between changes). State machine with {HEAT, IDLE, FAULT}, watchdog OFF fallback, and WCET ≤ 2 ms.

Dehumidifier control: maintain 55% RH using PI control on a relay, but only allow operation between 22:00 and 06:00. Add 3% hysteresis and a humidity sensor plausibility check (valid 10–90% RH). State machine with {IDLE, RUN, FAULT}, watchdog OFF fallback, sampled at 2 Hz.

Boiler pump staging: use two temperature sensors on the return line and select the median to reject a faulty reading. Turn pump relay ON if return < 45 °C and OFF at 50 °C. If sensors disagree by >5 °C, enter FAULT and latch OFF. Include a state machine, watchdog, and event handling under 100 ms.

Occupancy-based fan: require both motion and sound level > 50 dB for at least 10 s to turn a fan relay ON; turn it OFF after 5 minutes with no occupancy. Fuse the two sensors, use enum {UNOCCUPIED, CONFIRMING, OCCUPIED}, add watchdog OFF fallback, and run at 10 Hz.

Battery-backed sump pump controller: if supply voltage < 10.8 V or current > 8.0 A, immediately shut the pump relay OFF and enter BROWNOUT/OVERCURRENT state. Normal operation uses a float switch. State machine with {IDLE, RUN, FAULT}, watchdog OFF fallback, WCET ≤ 1 ms.

Greenhouse climate: regulate temperature using PID on a heater relay; if temp > 28 °C, disable heat and run a vent fan relay with mutual exclusion. States {HEATING, VENTING, IDLE, FAULT}. Safety: if sensor fails or temperature exceeds 40 °C, cut all outputs. 2 Hz loop, watchdog enforced.

Adaptive lighting: combine ambient light sensor and time-of-day rules. In DARK hours (22:00–06:00) and low light < 120 lux, automatically turn a lamp relay ON; otherwise OFF, unless a manual override switch is active. Use enum {AUTO, OVERRIDE}, a state machine, and watchdog OFF fallback.

Hot water recirculation: start a 2-minute pump run when either a demand button is pressed or motion is detected near the tap. Stop early if return line temperature reaches 45 °C. Limit to 10 starts per hour. Modes ECO/BOOST/VACATION via enum. State machine with safety OFF on watchdog.

Sun-aware shades: use ambient light and time range (10:00–16:00) to drive UP/DOWN relays. Fuse a light threshold (e.g., 30,000 lux) with schedule; add current sensing to detect a jam and stop. Enforce interlock, state machine with {IDLE, MOVING, JAM}, watchdog stop, and WCET ≤ 1 ms.

Presence-driven automation: combine door-open events, motion detection, and an external presence heartbeat input to determine enum {AWAY, HOME}. Only execute the evening light schedule when HOME. Use a clear state machine, handle missing heartbeat as AWAY, and enforce watchdog OFF behavior.

Design a home mode controller with enum {HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, VACATION}. Each mode applies different relay schedules for lights and a water heater. Include manual overrides and mode timeouts. Provide a robust state machine, watchdog coverage (OFF-safe), WCET ≤ 2 ms, and a concise test plan covering mode transitions and schedule boundaries.

Safety-focused room heater controller with modes IGNITE, WARMUP, RUN, SHUTDOWN, FAULT. Use a flame-detected input, limit ignition to 3 retries, and require a 30 s purge after failure. Temperature limit: cut off above 35 °C. Service the watchdog every 100 ms; any miss forces OFF. Supply a set of test cases including fault injection for stuck inputs and missed watchdog.

Smart load shedding: control three appliance relays to keep total load under 2.0 kW. If a higher-priority device requests ON, shed lower priorities first. Include a night schedule that blocks one device 22:00–06:00. Provide enum {NORMAL, SHEDDING}, a deterministic state machine, watchdog fallback, WCET ≤ 2 ms, and tests for worst-case contention.

Multi-zone irrigation (4 zones): weekday and weekend schedules with non-overlapping runs, plus a rain sensor to skip. Enum modes MANUAL/AUTO/RAIN_DELAY and a state machine to sequence zones. Watchdog must force all relays OFF. Specify a simulation test plan for schedule edges, sensor changes, and power-up mid-schedule.

Emergency lighting controller with modes NORMAL, ALARM, and TEST. On ALARM input, flash relays at 1 Hz; in TEST, run a 60 s self-test weekly at 02:00. Any fault or watchdog expiry must force relays OFF. Provide a clear state machine, timing constraints (WCET ≤ 1 ms), and a set of verification steps for alarm timing and watchdog behavior.

Make a simple relay switch: when the wall button is pressed, toggle the relay state. Debounce the button for 50 ms. If the relay stays on for more than 1 hour continuously, turn it off automatically. On power-up, default the relay to off.

Create a bathroom fan timer: a single press starts a 10 minute countdown and energizes the relay; a long press (≥2 s) starts a 30 minute countdown. Show remaining time via a status LED that blinks once per second. If the button is pressed again, cancel the timer and turn the relay off.

Implement a hallway light with an auto-off: when the touch switch is tapped, turn the relay on for 3 minutes, then off. Double-tap should latch the relay on indefinitely until tapped again. Debounce 30 ms.

Design a smart outlet with a child lock: the relay only toggles on a double-press within 400 ms; single press is ignored. After 2 hours of being on, revert to off. Ensure a fail-safe off state on brownout or reset.

Build a porch light timer that turns on at button press and gradually fades a status LED over 15 minutes while the relay is energized; once the fade completes, turn the relay off. Ignore additional button presses during the active timer.
Provide a timed relay pulse: on button press, generate a 500 ms relay activation (pulse) and then ensure the relay is off. Debounce input for 20 ms and ignore re-triggers until the pulse completes.

Create a stairway light auto-off: when the rocker switch is turned on, energize the relay and start a 180 s timer. If the switch is turned off before the timer expires, cancel the timer. On timeout, force the relay off.
Make a garage relay that only closes for 2 seconds when the pushbutton is pressed, regardless of press duration. Block any further activations for 5 seconds after a pulse to prevent rapid cycling.
Implement a pantry light with hold-to-run: the relay remains on only while the button is held, with 100 ms debounce and a 10 s maximum hold time to avoid overheating.

Create a night lamp scheduler: every day at 21:00 local time, turn the relay on; at 23:30, turn it off. If the manual override button is pressed, toggle the current state and suspend the next scheduled action for that day.

Program a coffee maker safety switch: when turned on by a button, keep the relay on for 40 minutes maximum, then force off and require a new button press to re-enable. Flash a status LED at 2 Hz during the final 1 minute as a warning.

Set up a countdown outlet: a knob selects 5, 15, 30, or 60 minutes; pressing a start button energizes the relay for the selected duration. If the knob changes mid-countdown, update the remaining time to the nearest setting.
Design a doorbell light flasher: on button press, flash the relay on/off at 2 Hz for 10 seconds, ending in off. Ignore further presses while flashing.

Make a vacation lamp blinker: generate a pseudo-random on/off pattern between 18:00 and 23:00 daily, with on-periods between 5–20 minutes and off-periods between 5–15 minutes. Ensure the relay is off outside that window.

Create a cleaning mode switch: a long press (≥3 s) turns the relay on for exactly 25 minutes; a short press turns it off immediately. Debounce the button and ignore long-press detection if already on.

Implement a motion-activated light with a simple state machine: states are IDLE, ON_HOLD, and LOCKOUT. Motion triggers ON_HOLD for 90 s; additional motion extends the timer. After turning off, enter LOCKOUT for 10 s to avoid rapid toggling. Provide a watchdog timer that resets the controller if no main loop tick occurs within 200 ms.

Build a sprinkler relay schedule with weekday selection: allow a schedule at 06:00 on Mon/Wed/Fri for 20 minutes and at 19:00 on Tue/Thu for 15 minutes. Include a rain delay flag that, when set, skips the next scheduled run and auto-clears afterward.

Create a two-way stair switch logic: two momentary buttons at top and bottom toggle a single light relay. Implement edge detection so any press toggles the relay, with 40 ms debounce per input and collision handling if both are pressed within 100 ms (treat as a single toggle).

Design an energy saver mode with enum modes: OFF, ECO, and BOOST. In ECO, a button press turns the relay on for 10 minutes; in BOOST, for 30 minutes; in OFF, button presses are ignored. Provide a separate mode button to cycle modes in order.

Program a scene controller with three relays and an enum of scenes: RELAX, READING, and NIGHT. A single scene button cycles scenes every press; each scene maps to a distinct relay combination. Implement a watchdog that expects a heartbeat every 100 ms and forces all relays off on watchdog timeout.

Create a pool pump timer that enforces a minimum off-time of 5 minutes before re-energizing the relay to protect the motor. A daily schedule runs 08:00–10:00 and 16:00–18:00. Manual override toggles the relay but must respect the minimum off-time.

Implement a fan delay off: when a linked light input turns off, keep the fan relay on for 120 s, unless the light turns on again, which cancels the delay and keeps the fan running. Include input debounce and a failsafe that turns the fan off on system reset.

Develop a porch light that uses a twilight sensor and a schedule: if ambient light is below threshold after 17:00, enable the relay and keep it on until 22:30. If the manual switch is used, suspend sensor-driven control for 1 hour. Use a simple state machine to manage manual vs. automatic control.

Make a dual-outlet controller with interlock: of two relays, only one may be on at a time. A toggle button chooses which outlet is active. If the active outlet is selected again, turn both off. Enforce a 200 ms break-before-make interval when switching.

Create a morning routine: at 06:45 on weekdays, turn on relay A for 10 minutes and relay B for 3 minutes. If a holiday flag is set, skip the routine. Provide a status LED that blinks three times at 06:40 as a pre-alert.

Implement a delay-on-break for a dehumidifier: when humidity input indicates high (>60% RH), turn the relay on; when it drops below 55% RH, begin a 5 minute delay before turning off. Limit relay cycles to at most 6 per hour.

Program a secure entry light with PIN-based enable: a keypad input toggles an ENABLE flag when a correct PIN is entered; only when enabled can the wall switch control the relay. Auto-disable after 4 hours. Include a watchdog that resets the system to disabled if no heartbeat within 500 ms.

Design a sprinkler master valve with zone interlocking: whenever any zone relay (1–4) is on, ensure the master valve relay is also on. The master must turn on 2 seconds before a zone and turn off 2 seconds after the last zone turns off.

Create a weekend schedule override: default schedule is daily 20:00–22:00 on. On Sat/Sun, extend to 23:30. If the user presses the override button between 19:30 and 20:00, skip the first hour of runtime that night.

Build a pump alternator with two relays for even wear: alternate which relay energizes on each start command, but if one relay fails to turn on (simulate via a feedback input), fall back to the other. Enforce a minimum 10 s off-time between starts.

Implement a safety interlock for a heater relay: require two independent enable inputs to be true for 100 ms before energizing. If either input drops, de-energize within 50 ms. On any watchdog timeout event, force the relay off and log an error flag.

Create an occupancy-based stair lighting with an enum mode: AUTO, MANUAL, and OFF. In AUTO, motion turns the relay on for 120 s; in MANUAL, a button toggles the relay; in OFF, ignore inputs and keep off. Provide a state machine to resolve conflicting inputs.

Set up a watering schedule with seasonal adjustment: a base runtime of 12 minutes at 06:00 daily; apply a seasonal factor (0.5–1.5) to scale runtime. A rain inhibit flag pauses all runs for 48 hours when set.

Design a double-tap scene trigger: single tap toggles relay 1, double tap within 300 ms toggles relay 2, and long press (≥1.5 s) turns both off. Debounce inputs and ensure clear precedence if gestures overlap.
Implement a gate light follow-me timer: when a gate opens (input edge), turn the light relay on for 5 minutes. If the gate closes within the first minute, reduce remaining time to 2 minutes instead.

Create a vacation mode with schedule shift: when VACATION is enabled, shift all existing on-times by +30 minutes and off-times by +15 minutes to simulate presence, but never extend past 23:59. Provide an enum for NORMAL vs VACATION.

Build a sunrise/sunset-based porch light: turn on at sunset with an adjustable offset (−30 to +30 minutes) and turn off at 23:00. A manual button toggles the relay and suspends astronomic control for 2 hours.

Develop a humidity-triggered fan with hysteresis and lockout: turn the relay on when humidity exceeds 65% RH; turn off when it falls below 55% RH. After turning off, enforce a 5 minute lockout before it can turn on again.

Create a delayed start heater: when the enable switch turns on, wait 90 s before energizing the heater relay. If the enable switch turns off during the delay, cancel. Include a maximum daily runtime cap of 4 hours.

Implement a watchdog-supervised lighting controller: the main control loop runs at 20 Hz (every 50 ms) and must complete within 5 ms WCET. Feed a watchdog every cycle; if missed twice in a row, hard-fail by turning all relays off and entering a SAFE state until a manual reset input is pressed.

Design a smart thermostat relay using PID control with anti-windup: target temperature in °C, control a heating relay via time-proportioning over a 10 minute window (minimum on/off segment 30 s). Include a state machine with OFF, HEAT, and FAULT states; enter FAULT if the enclosure temperature exceeds 60 °C and force the relay off.

Create a sensor fusion occupancy light: fuse motion detections and door open/close events. Consider occupancy true if either motion fired within the last 90 s or the door opened without an exit event. Keep the relay on while occupied; after both signals quiet, wait 60 s before turning off. Include a watchdog that resets to off if no loop tick for 300 ms.

Build a boiler pump duty controller: maintain a target return temperature of 45 °C using a simple PI controller that modulates relay on-time over 5 minute windows, respecting a minimum 60 s on and 60 s off. Limit total daily on-time to 8 hours and fail safe-off above 70 °C.

Implement a greenhouse misting schedule with safety limits: run the misting relay for 2 minutes every hour between 08:00 and 18:00, but skip a cycle if humidity is above 80% RH. Enforce no more than 10 relay activations per day to protect the valve.
