Create a water heater anti-legionella cycle: once per week on Sunday at 03:00, run the heater relay continuously for 60 minutes unless the temperature exceeds 65 °C, then abort. Do not start if the relay has been on within the last 3 hours.

Design an advanced lighting controller with enum modes: HOME, AWAY, NIGHT, and VACATION. Each mode applies different schedules and button behaviors (e.g., in AWAY, manual presses are ignored; in NIGHT, auto-off after 5 minutes). Use a state machine to manage transitions and ensure a watchdog forces mode to AWAY and all relays off on timeout.

Program a load shedder: when total power exceeds a threshold (e.g., 2000 W), shed relays in priority order (3, then 2, then 1) with 1 second spacing; when power falls below 1500 W for 2 minutes, restore in reverse order. Include a maximum 6 toggles per relay per hour.

Build a multi-zone irrigation controller with state machine sequencing: run zones 1–4 for 8 min each at 05:30 with a 10 s valve overlap to reduce pressure spikes. Allow a rain skip input that aborts the entire run and prevents restart for 24 hours. Add a watchdog that forces all valves closed on fault.

Specify a comprehensive testable lighting scheduler: define daily schedules, manual override behavior, and edge cases (DST transitions, midnight crossing). Require a heartbeat at 10 Hz, WCET ≤2 ms, and on any missed heartbeats, log an error and force all relays off. Include an enum for SCHEDULED, MANUAL, and SAFE states.

Create a whole-home automation rules engine with modes (NORMAL, PARTY, SLEEP, AWAY) controlling multiple relays and schedules. Define explicit state machine transitions, per-mode schedules, manual override precedence rules, and a watchdog that reverts to AWAY with all relays off on any control loop fault. Include acceptance criteria for timing, debouncing (≤30 ms), and maximum relay cycles per hour (≤10).

Create a simple controller where a pushbutton toggles a single relay for a lamp. Debounce the button press, prevent double toggles within 200 ms, and ensure a watchdog timer forces the relay to OFF if the system stops responding.

When a wall button is pressed, turn on a porch light relay for exactly 5 minutes, then switch it off automatically. If the button is pressed again during the countdown, cancel and restart the 5-minute timer. Default to OFF on watchdog timeout.

Control a light relay based on ambient light: if illuminance drops below 50 lux, turn the light ON; turn it OFF when it rises above 70 lux. Add hysteresis and a safe OFF state if a watchdog timer triggers.

Implement a bathroom fan delay-off: when the user turns the switch OFF, keep the fan relay ON for 90 seconds, then turn OFF. Use a simple two-state machine (Idle and Delaying) and make the watchdog force Idle if anything goes wrong.
On motion detection, energize a stair light relay for 30 seconds. Retrigger the timer on subsequent motion. If the watchdog timer expires, ensure the light defaults to OFF.

Drive a doorbell relay from a momentary pushbutton such that a single press produces a 1 second relay pulse. Ignore additional presses until the pulse completes. Use a minimal state machine and return to a safe idle on watchdog timeout.

Schedule a garden light relay to turn ON at 18:00 and OFF at 22:00 daily. Include handling for power-up so that the relay reflects the correct scheduled state, and ensure a watchdog forces the relay to OFF if the schedule task stalls.
Combine a manual switch with a temperature safety cutoff for a heater relay: follow the switch unless the temperature exceeds 80 Celsius, in which case force OFF. On watchdog timeout, default to OFF.
Control a sump pump relay using a float switch: when the float indicates high water, turn ON; when low, turn OFF. Include 100 ms debounce on the float and force OFF if the watchdog trips.
Generate a diagnostic test pulse: energize a relay for 100 ms every 1 hour. Ensure that at all other times the relay is OFF and that a watchdog timer maintains a safe OFF state on failure.
Ventilation fan control: turn the relay ON when CO2 exceeds 1000 ppm, turn it OFF when CO2 falls below 800 ppm. Add hysteresis and make the watchdog enforce OFF as a fail-safe.
Create a simple smart outlet: a single button toggles the outlet relay with 50 ms debounce. On power-up and on watchdog timeout, the outlet must default to OFF for safety.
Drive a siren relay when a window sensor opens: sound for 10 seconds maximum per open event, then remain silent until the window closes again. Ensure the watchdog forces the siren OFF.
If an external day/night flag input indicates night, keep the porch light relay ON; otherwise keep it OFF. Enforce that the relay returns to OFF if the watchdog timer ever expires.
Control a gate lock relay so it is energized only while an access-granted input is true. Immediately de-energize when access is revoked. On watchdog timeout, ensure the lock is de-energized.

Implement two-way hallway lighting using two wall switches controlling one light relay. Use a state machine to resolve simultaneous toggles, enforce a minimum 200 ms between relay actuations, and default to OFF on watchdog failure.

Build a bathroom fan controller with enum modes Manual, Auto, and Boost. Auto turns the fan ON when humidity exceeds 60 percent and keeps it running until it falls below 55 percent for 10 minutes. Boost runs for 15 minutes. Use a clear state machine and revert to Manual Off if the watchdog fires.

Create a smart socket with child lock: short press toggles the relay; long press enters or exits Lock mode where the button is ignored. Indicate status via a status output. Use enum modes and ensure a watchdog forces the socket OFF if unresponsive.

Control a single irrigation zone with schedule windows and environmental overrides. Do not water if a rain sensor is active or soil moisture is above threshold. Enforce a minimum 15 minute off-time between runs to protect the pump. Use a state machine and safe OFF on watchdog.

Manage a water heater relay with modes Vacation, Eco, and Normal. Respect active hours (06:00–09:00 and 18:00–22:00), enforce a high-temperature cutoff at 65 Celsius, and prevent relay chatter with a minimum 10 second dwell. Watchdog must force OFF on fault.

Control motorized blinds with separate Up and Down relays. Interlock the relays so both cannot be active. Use a state machine to run for up to 20 seconds per movement or until a stop command, and ensure the watchdog disables all movement on error.

Schedule a refrigerator defrost cycle: run a defrost relay for 15 minutes every 8 hours unless a door-open input is active. Include a manual defrost button and a state machine with Clear, Defrosting, and Paused. Watchdog returns to Clear.

Automate a garage light: turn on when motion is detected or when the door opens, then turn off after 3 minutes without activity. Inhibit operation if ambient light exceeds 200 lux. Use a state machine and force OFF on watchdog timeout.

Drive an exhaust fan with CO monitoring. Enum states: Normal, Vent, and Alarm. Enter Vent when CO exceeds 35 ppm and Alarm when above 50 ppm for more than 5 minutes. Exit Alarm only after manual acknowledgment and safe levels. Watchdog fails safe to Normal Off.

Aquarium control: follow weekday/weekend light schedules. Provide a Feeding mode that suspends the filter pump relay for 10 minutes, then resumes. Use a state machine, and ensure watchdog restores normal operation with pumps ON and lights per schedule.

Thermostat-driven heater control with a window-open sensor. Use hysteresis and enforce a 3 minute anti-short-cycle. If the temperature sensor is faulty, enter a Fault state and force the relay OFF. Include enum modes and watchdog handling.

Three-channel smart power strip: a master enable controls all relays. If Channel A is ON, force Channel B OFF. Alternate Channel C ON/OFF every 30 minutes during a schedule window. Implement with a state machine and safe defaults on watchdog.

Entryway light automation: if the door opens between 18:00 and 06:00, turn the light ON for 2 minutes. Provide a manual override button that toggles a Hold state to keep the light ON until pressed again. On watchdog timeout, drop out of Hold and turn OFF.

Laundry booster fan control based on humidity rate of change. Turn ON when humidity rises faster than 5 percent RH per minute and keep ON until the rise slows below 1 percent RH per minute, with a minimum 2 minute run. Use a state machine and watchdog safety.

Pool pump scheduler with a Backwash mode. Run during configured hours, but inhibit operation if a low water level input is active. Enforce a minimum run time of 15 minutes per start. Enum modes and watchdog-driven safe OFF state required.

Dehumidifier controller targeting 50 percent RH with a Turbo mode that forces ON for 30 minutes. Protect the compressor with a 5 minute minimum off-time. Track cumulative run hours and raise a filter reminder at 200 hours. Include enum modes and a watchdog.

Holiday lights scheduler active between specified calendar dates. Turn ON at sunset plus a random offset of up to ±10 minutes, and OFF at 23:00. Provide a 1 minute test mode. Use a state machine and ensure a watchdog reverts to OFF on anomalies.

Implement a panic relay requiring two separate buttons to be pressed within 2 seconds to activate. Auto-cancel after 5 minutes. Enter a Lockout state if activated more than three times in 10 minutes. Use enums and make watchdog force deactivation.

Ceiling fan controller with three discrete speeds using mutually exclusive relays. Select speed from a three-position input. Use a state machine to handle transitions safely, with a brief OFF in between speeds, and force Idle on watchdog.

Freezer protection: if the temperature rises above minus 10 Celsius, energize a backup cooling relay. Require manual acknowledgment to clear an alarm and only after temperature returns below minus 15 Celsius. Use enum states and watchdog safety.

Implement PID-based temperature control for a zone valve using time-proportioning of a relay with a 10 minute cycle. Include anti-windup, overtemperature cutoff at 85 Celsius, and a watchdog heartbeat every 100 ms that forces the relay OFF on failure.

Control a boiler pump to maintain return water temperature via PID. Enforce minimum on/off times of 60 seconds. Use two temperature sensors and enter a Fault state if they differ by more than 3 Celsius. Watchdog must drop to safe OFF.

Occupancy-based lighting using sensor fusion: combine motion, door contact, and sound level in dBA to compute an occupancy confidence. If confident and within active schedule, energize the light relay; otherwise turn it off. Fail safe to OFF on watchdog.

Smart water recirculation pump with predictive scheduling. Learn typical usage per hour of day and preheat for 5 minutes beforehand. Also trigger a 5 minute run on a manual tap event. Limit continuous operation to 15 minutes with a 10 minute cooldown. Use a state machine and watchdog.

Battery-backed sump pump controller. Monitor mains presence and battery voltage in volts. Modes: Normal, Backup, and Fault. Prioritize essential loads and shut down safely if battery drops below 11.5 V. Include a watchdog timer and safe defaults.

Greenhouse ventilation via PID using temperature in Celsius with relay time-proportioning. Respect a window-open interlock and cap cycling to no more than 6 cycles per hour. Run the control loop at 50 Hz with a WCET of 2 ms, and use a watchdog.

Power shedding controller: if total current exceeds 15 A, shed relays in priority order, restoring loads when current falls below 12 A. Provide a schedule window where shedding is disabled (20:00–22:00). Use a clear state machine and a watchdog.

Whole-house dehumidifier control using dew point derived from temperature and humidity. Maintain indoor dew point at or below 15 Celsius. Include compressor short-cycle protection of 3 minutes and fail safe to OFF on watchdog timeout.

Hot water circulation controller based on presence and a night schedule. Once per week, run a sanitation cycle raising water to 60 Celsius for 30 minutes. Never run if a leak sensor is active. Use enum modes and a watchdog for safety.

Secure door strike control requiring authorization from keypad, badge reader, and an external approval signal. Provide an Offline mode if the external signal is missing. Alarm if the door remains open longer than 30 seconds. Include tamper input, a state machine, and a watchdog.

Design a multi-zone relay scheduler for 8 channels with weekly calendars, holiday overrides, and dependency rules. Provide enum modes Auto, Manual, Test, and Lockout. Include a watchdog, main loop at 100 Hz, WCET 1 ms per channel, and a startup self-test.

Create an energy-aware home mode manager with modes Home, Away, Sleep, and Vacation that modifies multiple relay and switch rules. Include simulation hooks, enforce that heating and cooling relays cannot be ON together, add a watchdog and fail-safe after brownout, and define acceptance tests for all transitions and schedules.

Develop a resilient irrigation controller using soil moisture and rain sensors with connectivity loss handling. Store schedules locally and use enum states CommsOk, Degraded, and Offline. Include watchdog timers, fault injection test scenarios, and guarantee at least two watering events per week under dry conditions.

Implement a two-stop dumbwaiter controller using relays for Up and Down with interlocks, door switches, and a weight sensor. Enum modes Idle, Moving, Brake, EStop, and Fault. Require emergency stop behavior, run at 200 Hz with WCET 1 ms, include movement timeouts, a watchdog, and tests for stuck switches and overtravel.

Build a safe boiler room controller for gas valve, igniter, and pump using modes Ignition, Run, Purge, and Fault. Enforce minimum dwell times, retry limits, and a 30 second purge. Include a watchdog and a comprehensive test plan covering flame loss, sensor failure, and power restoration behavior.

Create a basic on/off light control: when a momentary switch is pressed, toggle a single relay. Include 30 ms input debounce, ensure the relay defaults OFF on startup, and add a watchdog timer that forces the relay OFF if the control loop stalls for more than 1 s.

Schedule a porch light to turn ON at 18:00 and OFF at 23:00 daily. Provide an enum mode with AUTO and MANUAL, where MANUAL obeys a separate toggle button. If a watchdog timeout occurs, revert to AUTO and ensure the relay is OFF.

Implement a bathroom fan timer: a single press on the fan button starts a 10-minute run, then turns the relay OFF. Short presses during a run extend by 5 minutes up to 30 minutes max. Add debounce and a 1 s watchdog that fails safe (OFF).

Control a stairway light from a motion sensor: turn the light relay ON immediately when motion is detected, and turn it OFF 30 seconds after the last motion. If motion persists, keep it ON. Add a safety watchdog to force OFF after a 2 s control freeze.

Drive a water heater enable relay: when a thermostat demand input is TRUE, energize the relay; otherwise keep it OFF. On any sensor fault or watchdog expiry (500 ms), force the relay OFF and latch a FAULT flag requiring manual reset.

Garage light control: turn the light ON when the garage door open switch is active and keep it ON for 2 minutes after the door closes, then turn it OFF. Start with light OFF on power-up and enforce a 100 ms debounce on the door input.

Build a simple countdown timer outlet: UP and DOWN buttons set a duration from 1 to 60 minutes in 1-minute steps. START begins the countdown and energizes the relay; it turns OFF when the timer expires. Include input debounce and a watchdog that cancels the countdown and turns OFF if no heartbeat for 1 s.

Create a one-shot holiday schedule: on a specified date, turn a relay ON at 07:00 and OFF at 10:00, then disable the schedule until reprogrammed. Manual override switch must still toggle the relay. Default OFF on reset.

Implement a safety auto-off for a coffee maker smart plug: if the relay has been ON for 30 minutes continuously, turn it OFF and require a manual press to re-energize. Include a watchdog that fails safe (OFF) if the loop hangs.

Weekday-only schedule: turn a lamp relay ON at 06:30 and OFF at 07:30 Monday through Friday. On weekends, keep the relay OFF unless a manual button is pressed. Ensure the relay state is correct after power-up even if restarting mid-window.

Doorbell chime: when the doorbell input rises, pulse a relay for 1.0 s and then force a 2.0 s lockout to ignore repeats. Debounce the input by 50 ms and ensure the relay is OFF on any watchdog timeout.

Double-tap lamp toggle: detect a double-press of a button within 400 ms to toggle a relay. Single presses are ignored. Provide a small state machine for press timing and include a 1 s watchdog to default OFF if the control loop stops.

Evening security light: force a relay ON daily from 19:00 to 22:00. If power is restored during this window, ensure the relay turns ON immediately and continues until 22:00. Outside the window, keep the relay OFF.

Aquarium feeder: at 08:00 each day, energize a feeder relay for 8 seconds, then turn it OFF. Provide a manual feed button that runs the same 8-second pulse with debounce. Default OFF at startup and on watchdog fault.

Water leak response: if the leak detector input goes TRUE, immediately de-energize an outlet relay and keep it locked out until a RESET button is held for 2 seconds. Ensure fail-safe OFF on watchdog timeout and after power-up.

Implement a two-way stair light using two momentary switches controlling one relay. Use a small state machine to handle toggles from either end with 30 ms debounce and guarantee deterministic behavior even with near-simultaneous presses. Include a 1 s watchdog that forces the light OFF on fault.

Heater controller with enum modes OFF, AUTO, MANUAL. In AUTO, follow a thermostat input with minimum ON time of 3 minutes and minimum OFF time of 3 minutes to prevent short cycling. Provide a WARMUP substate for the first 2 minutes after turning ON. In MANUAL, a button toggles the relay. Watchdog timeout forces OFF.

Irrigation zone scheduler: allow up to three daily windows to run a valve relay. Add a rain sensor input that inhibits watering, a MANUAL START button, and a state machine with IDLE, RUNNING, and PAUSED states. Resume correctly after power loss during RUNNING.

Blind motor control with open and close relays: short press toggles direction; long press (>1 s) jogs until released. Respect end-stop limit switches. Prevent both relays from energizing simultaneously. Provide a watchdog that de-energizes all outputs if no heartbeat for 500 ms.

Three-speed ceiling fan: use an enum SPEED0, SPEED1, SPEED2, SPEED3 to select mutually exclusive relay combinations. Add an inactivity timer that turns the fan OFF after 2 hours. On startup or watchdog fault, force SPEED0.

Scene controller: four buttons map to scene presets that drive two lighting relays. Implement a button-handling state machine for press/hold/release. If an overcurrent alarm input is TRUE, force both relays OFF and block further changes until cleared. Include a watchdog that fails safe.

Presence-plus-ambient light logic: turn lights ON when motion is detected and ambient light is below 200 lx; turn OFF 5 minutes after last motion if ambient light exceeds 300 lx. Implement hysteresis and a watchdog that forces OFF on control failure.

Hot water recirculation: at every top of the hour, run the pump relay for 3 minutes unless return water temperature is already above 45 °C. A BOOST button runs 10 minutes immediately. Enforce default OFF at startup and on watchdog expiry.

Kitchen exhaust control: in AUTO, turn the fan relay ON if CO2 > 1200 ppm or humidity > 70% RH, and keep it ON until CO2 < 900 ppm and humidity < 60% RH. MANUAL mode toggles the relay via button. Provide an enum mode and a watchdog that fails safe (OFF).

Garage door light logic: turn the light ON while the door motor command is active or the safety beam is broken, then keep it ON for 2 minutes after both are inactive. Debounce all inputs and force the light OFF if a watchdog timeout occurs.

Window ventilation: if indoor temperature exceeds 26 °C and outdoor temperature is below 24 °C, open the window actuator (relay). Close it if indoor temperature drops below 24 °C or outdoor rises above 26 °C. Add 1-minute minimum open/close dwell times and watchdog-safe OFF.

Simple alarm panel: enum modes DISARMED, ARMED_HOME, ARMED_AWAY. When armed, a door sensor triggers ENTRY_DELAY (30 s) state; if not disarmed within 30 s, energize the siren relay for 5 minutes. Manual disarm cancels siren immediately. Watchdog forces siren OFF.

Weekly smart socket schedule with holiday bypass: store up to 4 on/off pairs per day. A HOLIDAY input disables the schedule but allows manual toggling. Remember the last relay state across power cycles and include a watchdog that reverts to OFF on fault.

Overload-protected smart plug: if measured power exceeds 1500 W for more than 5 minutes, turn the relay OFF and enter TRIPPED until a reset button is held for 2 seconds. Implement a state machine NORMAL/TRIPPED and apply a watchdog that forces OFF.

Bathroom humidity logic: when humidity rises by at least 10% RH above a rolling baseline, start the fan. Keep running until within 2% RH of baseline or a 20-minute cap is reached. Debounce the start and include a watchdog that turns the fan OFF if control hangs.

Dual-pump interlock: only one of two pump relays may be ON at a time. Alternate the selected pump on each demand event using an enum ACTIVE_PUMP_A/B. If the selected pump does not assert a flow feedback within 5 s, switch to the other pump. Watchdog forces both OFF on fault.

Outdoor outlet freeze protection: disable the outlet relay when ambient temperature < -10 °C and re-enable when it rises above -5 °C (hysteresis). The normal daily schedule still applies when enabled. Include a watchdog that fails safe OFF.

Bedside lamp control: double-tap within 300 ms to toggle the lamp. Long-press (>1 s) starts a 30-minute auto-off timer. Provide input debounce, clear state after power loss, and a watchdog that defaults the relay to OFF on timeout.

Child-safe outlet: require two separate buttons to be pressed within 1 s to turn ON the outlet relay. Release of either button turns it OFF. Debounce inputs by 100 ms and include a watchdog that forces OFF if the loop stalls.

Water softener backwash cycle: every 3 days at 02:00, execute a 12-minute sequence across two relays with three phases (FILL, SOAK, FLUSH). Model this as a timed state machine with explicit phase durations and safe abort on watchdog fault.

Time-proportional heater control: maintain room temperature at a setpoint (°C) using a PID that computes a duty within a 10 s window to drive a heater relay. Sample at 2 Hz, cap heater if temperature exceeds 80 °C, and ensure WCET ≤ 2 ms per cycle. Watchdog forces the relay OFF.

Sump/tank management using sensor fusion: combine a float switch (hard limit) and an ultrasonic level sensor (cm) to control a fill pump relay. Use the float as an absolute safety cutoff and the ultrasonic for normal control. Detect sensor disagreement and enter FAULT with the relay OFF. Include a watchdog and a clear fault-reset path.

Air quality fan controller: use a PID on PM2.5 (µg/m³) sampled at 1 Hz to select one of three fan speeds via relays (LOW/MED/HIGH). Map PID output to discrete speeds with hysteresis and promote to BOOST if PM2.5 > 150 µg/m³. Watchdog forces fan OFF on fault.

Irrigation with environmental adaptation: decide daily watering using soil moisture (%) and rain accumulation (mm). Enforce a daily water budget and skip if rain > 5 mm in the last 24 h. State machine RUN/SUSPEND/FAULT, with a pressure sensor (bar) interlock that closes valves and enters FAULT on low pressure. Target control cycle 10 Hz with WCET ≤ 3 ms.

Automated window actuator with weather fusion: close immediately on rain or wind speed > 8 m/s; open if CO2 > 1200 ppm and indoor temperature < 28 °C and no rain. Enforce 10 s motor run limit and obstruction detection via current increase. Use a state machine and a watchdog that de-energizes all relays on fault.

Hybrid water heater cycle with anti-legionella: NORMAL mode follows a schedule; once per week run a PASTEURISE cycle to 65 °C for 30 minutes. Overtemperature at 80 °C or sensor fault must force the heater relay OFF and enter FAULT. Include a watchdog and clear transitions among NORMAL, PASTEURISE, and FAULT.

Dual sump pump controller: use two float switches (LOW/HIGH) and a flow sensor (L/min) to operate two pumps with alternation. Start at HIGH, stop at LOW. Detect short-cycling or no-flow faults; on overcurrent or no-flow for 5 s, switch pumps and log FAULT. Watchdog must force both relays OFF.

Greenhouse climate control: apply a PID to maintain 25 °C using three staged fan relays (LOW/MED/HIGH). Humidity override: if RH > 80% for 2 minutes, force at least MED. Sample at 2 Hz, enforce WCET ≤ 3 ms, and fail safe (all relays OFF) on watchdog timeout or sensor failure.

Whole-home water shutoff: monitor up to four leak sensors; on any detection, close the main valve relay immediately and enter ALARM state. Allow a timed bypass (max 5 minutes) via button for testing. If valve end-stop feedback is not reached within 10 s, enter FAULT and retry once. Watchdog forces the valve to closed.

Load shedding controller: keep total power below 3.0 kW by shedding up to four loads in priority order via relays. Re-enable loads with 60 s minimum off-time and 30 s minimum on-time. Control loop at 5 Hz with WCET ≤ 2 ms. On sensor fault or watchdog timeout, shed all loads.

House lighting supervisor with modes HOME, AWAY, NIGHT, VACATION (enum). Implement automation rules and schedules per mode (e.g., NIGHT dimmed scenes, VACATION randomized patterns). Provide a clear state machine for mode transitions, ensure outputs fail safe on watchdog timeout, and specify test scenarios covering edge times and power-loss recovery.

Smart irrigation with multi-mode operation: NORMAL, WATER_SAVING, RAIN_DELAY. Fuse soil moisture (%) and rain (mm) to adjust or skip schedules. Enforce flow meter interlock (L/min) and minimum valve rest times. Provide timing budgets (control rate 10 Hz, WCET ≤ 2 ms), watchdog handling, and acceptance criteria for each mode.

HVAC supervisor for a small home: enum modes OFF, HEAT, COOL, AUTO. Coordinate heater and compressor relays with minimum ON/OFF times (3 minutes), anti-short-cycle, and a defrost substate in COOL as needed. Use a PID on temperature (°C) to decide calls. Include overtemperature/overpressure fault inputs, a watchdog, and a comprehensive state machine plus a test plan with fault injection.

Energy price–aware load controller: modes CHEAP, NORMAL, EXPENSIVE driven by a tariff schedule. Manage three relays (water heater, EV outlet, dryer) with priorities and deadlines (e.g., water heater at least 1 h/day). Enforce WCET ≤ 2 ms, run at 5 Hz, include a watchdog, and provide unit tests and simulated day traces for each price mode.

Multi-room hot water recirculation orchestrator: modes MANUAL, AUTO, VACATION (enum). Per-room call buttons request pump runs; AUTO caps total pump time to 20 minutes per hour for energy savings. Implement a state machine to arbitrate requests, timers per room, and safe handling of power resets. Specify timing constraints, watchdog behavior, and verification cases for race conditions and overlapping requests.

Turn on a relay while a momentary switch is pressed and turn it off when released. Debounce the switch with 50 ms filtering. Include a watchdog timer that forces the relay to OFF if the control task fails to kick it within 500 ms.

Toggle a power relay on each distinct button press using edge detection. Ignore long presses and bouncing. Drive an indicator LED to mirror the relay state. Ensure the relay defaults to OFF at startup and after any unexpected reset.

Create a 10-minute countdown timer that energizes a relay while counting. A button press cancels the timer and turns the relay OFF. Blink a status LED at 1 Hz during the countdown and steady ON when idle.

When a motion sensor is active, energize a light relay for 30 seconds. Retrigger the timer on new motion. If an override switch is set, inhibit the motion logic and keep the relay OFF regardless of motion.
On power-up, energize a relay for exactly 3 seconds and then turn it OFF. This one-shot action should occur only on actual power cycles and not on soft resets within the control logic.
Implement a simple timer switch: pressing a button starts a 15-minute ON period for a relay; pressing the button again at any time immediately turns the relay OFF and cancels the timer.

Use an ambient light sensor in lux to control a relay for a night-light. Turn ON when lux falls below a threshold, and require the value to exceed the threshold for at least 2 seconds before turning OFF to avoid flicker.

Create a latch with separate START and STOP buttons. START sets the relay ON, STOP sets it OFF. Apply 20 ms debounce to both buttons. Ensure the latched state is retained across brief power dips only if non-volatile storage is explicitly updated.

If a temperature sensor reads above 50 °C, turn a cooling relay ON. Turn it OFF when temperature drops below 45 °C (hysteresis). On sensor fault or out-of-range reading, keep the relay OFF and indicate an error via LED.
Drive a chime relay for exactly 1.0 seconds whenever a doorbell switch is pressed. Implement a 2-second lockout after each chime to prevent rapid retriggering.

Build a small state machine for a bathroom fan: motion triggers relay ON, and the fan stays ON for 5 minutes after the last motion event. Provide a manual OFF button that immediately turns the fan OFF and cancels the timer.
Implement a delayed-ON function: when a switch is turned ON, wait 5 seconds, then energize the relay. If the switch is turned OFF during the delay, cancel the pending ON.
Map a two-position slide switch to a relay: UP means relay ON, DOWN means relay OFF. Drive an LED to show the inverse of the relay state (LED ON only when relay is OFF).
Create a blinking outlet: toggle a relay ON for 2 seconds, then OFF for 2 seconds continuously. Provide a global enable switch that, when OFF, forces the relay OFF and pauses the blinking timer.
Add a system watchdog that is kicked at 10 Hz. If it expires (no kick within 250 ms), immediately turn all relays OFF and blink a fault LED at 5 Hz until the system returns to normal operation.

Design a state machine for a bathroom fan with states IDLE, RUNNING, BOOST. Motion starts RUNNING for 10 min; humidity above 70% RH triggers BOOST for 20 min; a manual OFF forces IDLE and cancels timers. Include a watchdog that defaults the relay to OFF on expiry.

Create dual-control lighting using two wall switches. Either switch toggles the light relay (software three-way). Preserve the last known state across restarts so the relay resumes correctly after power loss.

Implement a weekly scheduler with per-day ON and OFF times. A manual override button forces the relay ON but times out after 30 minutes to return to schedule. Provide a 'Holiday' flag that disables the schedule when set.

Interlock two relays that drive HEAT and COOL so they are never ON simultaneously. Add a minimum OFF time of 3 minutes between changes of mode. Use an enum Mode {HEAT, COOL, OFF} and ensure safe transitions.
Automate a garden pump: if soil moisture stays below a threshold for 10 minutes, run the pump for 120 seconds. Inhibit watering if a rain sensor is wet. Limit to at most 10 pump starts per hour.

Garage light automation: door open sensor turns the light relay ON; when the door closes, keep it ON for 60 seconds. A manual button toggles the light and grants a 5-minute manual priority window during which sensor events are ignored. Implement with a clear state machine.
Create an enum Mode {AUTO, ON, OFF}. In AUTO, motion triggers a 30-second light timeout; ON forces the relay ON; OFF forces it OFF. Change modes using long-press vs short-press on a single button.

Build a smart outlet that opens the relay if measured current exceeds 8.0 A for more than 2 seconds. Latch a fault until a reset button is pressed. Indicate a fault via a blinking LED with a distinct pattern.
Implement a scheduler that supports sunrise/sunset plus configurable offsets in minutes, with weekday masks. Add an option to randomize ON time by ±10 minutes for presence simulation.
Include a watchdog timer that must be serviced every 100 ms by the control task. On expiry, set all relays to their configured safe states and record a monotonic counter as a surrogate timestamp.

Stairwell lights: top and bottom motion sensors are ORed. Between 22:00 and 06:00 use a 2-minute timeout; otherwise use 5 minutes. A 'BabySleep' flag disables motion triggers entirely. Manual override always works.
Laundry ready alert: when a vibration sensor is quiet for 5 minutes and power draw is below 5 W, close a beeper relay for 10 seconds. Suppress repeat alerts for 30 minutes.

Control a window blind motor with two relays (UP and DOWN) using mutual exclusion. State machine: IDLE, RAISING, LOWERING. Enforce a maximum run time of 30 seconds and a 1-second dead-time between reversing directions.

Create a programmable timer with up to 8 schedule slots (start time and duration). Resolve overlaps by giving priority to the later slot. Provide Mode {SCHEDULE, HOLD_ON, HOLD_OFF} to govern behavior.
Define a simple rule engine with up to 10 boolean conditions and 10 actions to drive two relays. Support AND/OR logic and rate limiting so any relay may switch at most 6 times per hour.

Ceiling fan controller: a pull-chain input cycles an enum Speed {OFF, LOW, MED, HIGH}. Map speeds to three relays with proper exclusivity so only the correct combination is active. Ensure worst-case execution time per event is ≤ 1 ms.

Heater safety logic: if temperature exceeds 80 °C, open the relay and latch a fault until a manual reset. If ambient falls below 5 °C, enable anti-freeze mode that runs the heater for 10 minutes every hour.

Smart outlet with presence awareness: when a paired device has not been seen for 15 minutes, turn the outlet OFF. When the device returns, restore the previous state. Include a watchdog that reverts to OFF on communication timeout.
Irrigation schedule: run zone 1 at 06:00 for 20 minutes on Mon/Wed/Fri. Skip watering if soil moisture exceeds 35% or if wind speed is above 10 m/s. Implement a separate state machine per zone.

Bathroom heater with occupancy logic: motion starts a 15-minute ON period. If temperature is below 18 °C, extend to 25 minutes; if above 24 °C, cancel early. A manual OFF always overrides and cancels timers.

Thermostat control using PID with time-proportioning over a 10-second window to drive a heater relay. Setpoint in °C comes from a knob. Include anti-windup and minimum ON/OFF dwell times to protect the relay contacts.

Dehumidifier automation: detect humidity trends and, when above 60% RH and rising, run the dehumidifier using a PID to adjust duty within a fixed window. A condensate overflow sensor immediately opens the relay and latches a fault.

Use sensor fusion for occupancy: combine motion (binary), sound level (dB), and a door sensor to compute confidence. Only enable lights if confidence ≥ 0.7. Define states VACANT, PROBABLE, OCCUPIED, and include a watchdog that resets to VACANT on fault.

Implement load shedding: monitor total current in amperes. If draw exceeds 12 A for 5 seconds, shed low-priority relays in order. Restore loads when current stays below 10 A for 30 seconds. Enforce at most one toggle per relay per minute.

Water heater interlock: if temperature > 65 °C or a leak sensor is wet, open the heater relay immediately. Perform a periodic self-test that pulses an indicator relay for 100 ms every 10 minutes. Specify WCET ≤ 2 ms and default to safe OFF on any error.

Greenhouse controller with enum Mode {AUTO, HEAT, COOL, OFF}. In AUTO, decide based on temperature and humidity thresholds. Ensure vent motor and heater relays are never ON at the same time. Include a watchdog and define behavior after brown-out recovery.

Transfer switch logic: sense mains voltage (V) and frequency (Hz). After mains loss for 3 seconds, close the generator start relay. When generator frequency is stable between 49–51 Hz for 10 seconds, close the load relay. On mains return, reverse the sequence. Include timeouts and safe defaults.

Smart water pump with dry-run protection: use flow (L/min) and current (A). If current is high but flow < 0.2 L/min for 5 seconds, open the relay and latch an alarm. Attempt auto-restart after 10 minutes, up to 3 retries, then require manual reset.

Adaptive lighting schedule: learn the average arrival time over the last 7 days and pre-activate lights 10 minutes beforehand. If data is missing or inconsistent, fall back to a fixed schedule. Include a watchdog that forces OFF on control failure.

Compressor controller with anti-short-cycle: state machine with OFF, START, RUN, COOLDOWN. Enforce minimum OFF of 5 minutes and minimum RUN of 3 minutes. Trip to FAULT on overcurrent > 15 A and require manual reset to clear.

Design a multi-mode home automation supervisor with enum HouseMode {HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, VACATION} controlling relays for lights, outlets, and a fan. Each mode has schedules and rules with explicit priority resolution. Include a watchdog, safe defaults on reboot, and a test plan with scenario coverage and edge cases.

Create a comprehensive state machine for a whole-home water system with relays for pump, UV lamp, and shutoff valve. Modes: NORMAL, AWAY, LEAK_ALERT, SERVICE. Define transitions, timeouts, and safety actions (default valve closed). Provide unit test requirements, including sensor-fault injection and watchdog expiry handling.

Implement an energy-aware scheduler for six smart relays with modes ECO and COMFORT. Use dynamic tariffs (cents/kWh) to defer noncritical loads. Constraints: no more than 2 relays may switch per minute and total current must remain under 20 A. Provide WCET targets and verification steps.

Design a resilient scene controller for lighting with Scenes {DAY, EVENING, NIGHT, AWAY}. Allow scheduled transitions, manual overrides, and blackout recovery. Include a watchdog, persistent storage of the last scene, and acceptance tests covering race conditions and simultaneous inputs.

Build a failsafe dumbwaiter controller using relays for UP, DOWN, and DOOR LOCK. Floor positions are sensed by switches. Include emergency stop, overload input, and maintenance mode. Specify the state machine, mutual exclusions, timing guarantees, and a comprehensive validation plan (safety tests, timing tests, WCET < 2 ms).

Create a basic timer switch: a debounced pushbutton turns a light relay on, and it automatically turns off after 30 minutes. Keep it simple: single button input, single relay output. Feed a watchdog timer with a heartbeat every 200 ms, and if the watchdog ever expires, default the relay to OFF for safety.

Implement a doorbell-style monostable: when the button is pressed, energize the chime relay for 2 seconds, then de-energize. Ignore additional presses for 3 seconds (retrigger lockout). Include a watchdog timer that resets the controller if no heartbeat is sent within 1 second.

Control a porch light using a light sensor. If ambient light drops below 50 lux, turn the relay ON; if it rises above 80 lux, turn it OFF (hysteresis). Sample at 10 Hz. If the light sensor reading is invalid, default the relay to OFF and report a fault via a status flag. Use a watchdog timer.

Make a simple fan delay: when a wall switch is turned ON, wait 5 seconds, then energize the fan relay; when the switch turns OFF, immediately de-energize. If the relay has been ON continuously for more than 1 hour, force it OFF as a safety timeout. Include 50 ms debounce and a watchdog.

When a leak sensor detects water, close a shutoff valve relay immediately and keep it closed for 15 minutes minimum. Acknowledge with a button press to reopen after the minimum time. If the sensor is faulted or disconnected, keep the valve closed as fail-safe. Add a watchdog timer.

Create a daily schedule for a lamp relay: turn ON at 06:00 and OFF at 22:00 local time every day. If the clock is not synchronized, keep the relay OFF and flag a fault. No inputs other than time-of-day. Include a watchdog that is kicked once per minute.

Implement a press-and-hold toggle: if the user holds a button for at least 1.5 seconds, toggle the outlet relay; short taps do nothing. Debounce for 50 ms. If three invalid sensor reads occur in a row, do not toggle and set an error status. Include a watchdog timer.

Build a kitchen timer switch: each button press starts or extends a countdown for the range hood relay by 10 minutes, up to a maximum of 60 minutes. Display the remaining time via a simple status value. When the countdown reaches zero, turn the relay OFF. Include a watchdog.

Make a motion-activated hallway light: when motion is detected, turn the relay ON for 120 seconds; each new motion event extends the timer. If no motion for the full duration, turn it OFF. Provide a cooldown of 5 seconds to prevent rapid toggling. Include a watchdog timer.

Design a simple thermostat for a garage heater: maintain 15 °C with ±1 °C hysteresis using a temperature sensor and a heater relay. If the sensor reads above 30 °C, immediately turn the relay OFF and latch a fault. Update at 1 Hz. Include a watchdog.

Control a window blind motor using a single toggle button and one relay output: when toggled, run the motor for 20 seconds then stop to avoid burnout. Ignore further toggles while running. If the button input is bouncing, use a 50 ms debounce window. Include a watchdog timer.

Create a humidity-controlled bathroom fan: if relative humidity rises above 60% RH, turn the fan relay ON; if it falls below 55% RH, turn it OFF. Sample at 1 Hz. If the humidity sensor fails, keep the fan OFF and set a fault flag. Use a watchdog timer.

Protect a smart outlet using a current sensor: if load current exceeds 800 mA for more than 200 ms, open the relay and latch it OFF until a reset button is held for 2 seconds. Sample at 200 Hz and implement a watchdog that enforces a safe OFF state on timeout.

Program a chime schedule: every hour on the hour between 08:00 and 20:00, pulse a bell relay for 500 ms, then stop. If the real-time clock is missing, skip the chime and indicate a fault state. Include a watchdog heartbeat once per minute.

Create a heartbeat relay that clicks for 100 ms every 60 seconds to indicate system health. If any internal fault is detected, suspend the heartbeat and leave all other relays OFF. Ensure a watchdog timer is fed only when all checks pass.

Design a lamp controller with enum modes OFF, MANUAL, and SCHEDULE. In MANUAL, a button toggles the lamp relay. In SCHEDULE, follow daily ON/OFF times with a 10-minute randomization. Provide a state machine that manages transitions and a watchdog that resets to OFF on timeout.

Create an entry light rule using two sensors: if motion is detected and ambient light is below 100 lux, turn the relay ON for 3 minutes; otherwise keep it OFF. Add a cooldown to avoid rapid retriggering. Implement a small state machine and use a watchdog timer.

Implement a virtual two-way staircase light with two wall switches controlling one relay. Any switch change toggles the light. Add a stair timer that turns the light OFF after 5 minutes unless there was a switch change in the last 30 seconds. Include a watchdog.

Build a garage door controller as a state machine with states: IDLE, MOVING_UP, MOVING_DOWN, and FAULT. A pushbutton toggles movement via a motor relay. Use open/closed limit switches to stop. Timeout motor motion after 30 seconds to avoid damage. Include a watchdog and fault latching.

Create an irrigation valve scheduler with enum modes OFF, AUTO, and RAIN_DELAY. AUTO follows a weekly schedule; a rain sensor or manual command activates RAIN_DELAY for 24 hours. Manual override starts a 20-minute run. Enforce a 2-minute minimum OFF time between runs. Use a watchdog.

Develop a home heating relay controller with modes OFF, HEAT, and BOOST. Maintain a setpoint in °C with hysteresis in HEAT; BOOST forces ON for 30 minutes. Ensure anti-short-cycle: minimum 3 minutes OFF and 3 minutes ON. Provide a state machine, enum modes, and a watchdog timer.

Manage a water pump using two level switches (LOW and HIGH). Start when LOW is open (low water) and stop when HIGH closes (tank full). If neither changes within 5 minutes of starting, enter FAULT and stop the pump. Implement a clear state machine and watchdog.

Implement demand-based water heater control: if a power monitor indicates whole-home consumption above 2.5 kW, postpone energizing the heater relay; otherwise allow it during a schedule window. Add hysteresis so it only re-enables below 2.0 kW. Include a watchdog.

Create a bathroom fan controller with enum modes OFF, AUTO, and TIMER. AUTO turns ON above 60% RH and OFF below 55% RH. TIMER runs for a user-set duration up to 60 minutes. A single button cycles modes. Use a state machine for transitions and a watchdog.

Control a sump pump with float switches: start the pump when the high float closes and stop when the low float opens. If the pump runs more than 10 minutes without low float opening, fault and stop. Enforce 30 seconds minimum OFF between cycles. Provide a watchdog.

Coordinate three relays for lighting scenes with enum modes EVENING, NIGHT, and AWAY. Define which relays are ON in each mode, and allow a schedule to auto-select modes. Manual override returns to scheduled mode after 1 hour. Include a state machine and watchdog.

Create a smart outlet with child lock. A long press (2 seconds) toggles the relay; in child lock, short presses are ignored. After power loss, restore to OFF unless explicitly configured to last known state. Add a 12-hour auto-off safety timer and a watchdog.

Design a blind controller with sunrise/sunset schedule offsets: open at sunrise +15 minutes, close at sunset. Manual buttons for UP/DOWN should override and stop at any time. Limit run time to 25 seconds to protect the motor. Use a state machine and a watchdog.

Control greenhouse ventilation with two rules: turn the fan ON above 28 °C and OFF below 26 °C; if humidity exceeds 80% RH, extend the ON time by 5 minutes. Manual override button runs the fan for 10 minutes. Enforce minimum 1-minute OFF. Include a watchdog.

Create a laundry-room light rule: if the door opens or motion is detected, turn the light ON. When the door is closed and there has been no motion for 5 minutes, turn it OFF. Prioritize safety: if either sensor faults, default to turning the light ON. Include a watchdog.

Implement a water heater that follows a daily schedule but defers heating when a utility demand signal is active. Provide a manual override that runs for 45 minutes. Ensure anti-short-cycle and a watchdog that fails the relay to OFF on timeout.

Automatically turn on entryway lights when presence is detected during a time window (18:00–23:00) and ambient light is below 120 lux. Keep them on for 10 minutes after the last presence detection. Include a small state machine, hysteresis, and a watchdog.

Design a smart power strip with three relays: a master switch turns all ON/OFF; each outlet has an individual 1-hour auto-off timer. Prevent more than one relay from turning on per 200 ms to limit inrush. Provide a watchdog timer.

Control a two-speed fan with two interlocked relays. Ensure only one speed relay is ever ON at a time, and enforce a 500 ms all-OFF transition when changing speeds. Include enum modes OFF, LOW, HIGH and a state machine. Add a watchdog.

Create a weekly holiday lights scheduler with manual override. The control task should run at 10 Hz with a worst-case execution time not exceeding 1 ms per cycle. Include a watchdog that is fed only when the cycle completes within the WCET.

Implement a time-proportional PID thermostat for radiant heating: target 21 °C. Compute a duty cycle over a 10-minute window and drive a heater relay accordingly. Enforce minimum 2 minutes ON and 2 minutes OFF, add anti-windup, and cut power if temperature exceeds 30 °C. Run control at 1 Hz with WCET ≤ 1 ms. Use a watchdog.

Use sensor fusion for occupancy: combine PIR motion, door switch, and a sound level threshold to maintain an occupancy confidence that decays over time. If confidence exceeds a set threshold, turn lights and a comfort relay ON; otherwise OFF. Limit to 2 toggles per minute per relay. Include a state machine and watchdog.

Control a ventilation system based on air quality using fused CO2 (ppm) and PM2.5 (µg/m³). Define modes NORMAL, BOOST, and ALARM; escalate to BOOST or ALARM if either signal is critical. Provide de-escalation hysteresis, sample at 2 Hz, ensure WCET ≤ 2 ms, and include a watchdog.

Schedule weekly legionella protection for a water heater: at 02:00 on Sundays, heat to 65 °C for 30 minutes; otherwise maintain 50 °C. If the temperature sensor fails or reads implausibly, cut the heater relay and latch a fault. Include a watchdog and anti-short-cycle limits.

Implement energy-aware load shedding for three relays based on fused readings from multiple current sensors. If total power exceeds 3.5 kW, shed lower-priority loads first; restore when power falls below 3.0 kW. Provide per-load cooldown timers, a state machine, and a watchdog.

Control greenhouse climate using PID for temperature: coordinate a heater relay and a ventilation relay to maintain 24 °C. Prevent both from being ON simultaneously. If humidity exceeds 85% RH, force ventilation for 5 minutes. Run the loop at 1 Hz, WCET ≤ 2 ms, and use a watchdog.

Detect plumbing leaks with sensor fusion: analyze a pressure sensor and a flow switch. If pressure drop rate (dP/dt) is high while flow is detected unexpectedly, close a shutoff valve relay and latch FAULT. Compute at 100 Hz with WCET ≤ 1 ms. Include a watchdog and a manual reset.

Control a dehumidifier using time-proportional PID for a compressor relay with minimum 3-minute OFF and 2-minute ON protections. Maintain 45% RH. Ensure the fan relay runs whenever the compressor is ON and for 60 seconds after. Include anti-windup, a state machine, and a watchdog.

Stage a whole-home ventilation system with two relays (stage 1 and stage 2) based on CO2 (ppm) and indoor temperature (°C). Use a state machine to ensure orderly engagement (stage 1 before stage 2) and a minimum of 2 minutes between stage changes. Control loop at 2 Hz with WCET ≤ 1 ms and a watchdog.

Manage a pool heater choosing between solar and electric sources: fuse roof and pool temperatures to decide when to open solar valve vs. energize electric heater relay. Enforce anti-scald by limiting pool temperature to 35 °C and add minimum 5-minute run times. Include a state machine and a watchdog.

Architect a multi-mode home automation controller with enum modes HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, and VACATION that orchestrates lighting and outlet relays via schedules and rules. Provide a clear state machine, deterministic 20 Hz control cycle with WCET ≤ 2 ms, a robust watchdog, and a suite of test scenarios validating schedule adherence, manual overrides, and power-loss recovery.

Design a safety-focused boiler relay controller with modes STARTUP, IGNITE, RUN, and FAULT, including interlocks on temperature (°C) and flame presence (binary). Enforce maximum ignition retries, minimum ON/OFF times, and safe shutdown on sensor faults. Specify a test plan covering normal cycles, failed ignition, and sensor failures. Include watchdog and WCET ≤ 1 ms at 50 Hz.

Create a residential load management system with modes NORMAL, PEAK_SHAVE, and BACKUP. Prioritize and shed up to five relays based on a power threshold (kW) and a schedule. Provide a diagnostic state machine, fail-safe defaults to OFF, watchdog supervision, and comprehensive tests for brown-out, timer drift, and state persistence across resets.

Implement a corridor lighting controller for an apartment building with NORMAL and EMERGENCY modes. In NORMAL, follow presence and schedule rules; in EMERGENCY, force all lighting relays ON. Include a supervisory state machine, 10 Hz control loop with WCET ≤ 1 ms, watchdog, and a verification plan with simulated sensor faults and mode transitions.

Develop a whole-home water leak mitigation system coordinating multiple shutoff valves and a pump relay. Modes: MONITOR, ISOLATE, PURGE, and FAULT. Run weekly self-tests of valves (brief exercise) on a schedule, log faults, and default to safe positions if tests fail. Specify timing constraints (5 Hz control, WCET ≤ 1 ms), watchdog behavior, and a comprehensive test suite including leak scenarios and sensor failures.

Write a simple controller for a single relay: toggle the relay each time a pushbutton is pressed, with 30 ms debounce and a minimum off-time of 200 ms to protect the load. Keep the logic straightforward and run it as a tiny state machine.

When a motion sensor goes active, turn a light relay on immediately and keep it on until 30 seconds after the last motion. If motion continues, extend the timer. Include debouncing/noise filtering for brief spikes (<50 ms).
Create a daily schedule for a relay: ON at 06:30 and OFF at 22:00 local time. Ignore manual inputs. On boot, ensure the relay reflects the current schedule state within 1 second.
Implement a bathroom fan relay controller: turn on if humidity exceeds 70% RH, and turn off when it drops below 60% RH (hysteresis). Sample at 2 Hz. Keep behavior deterministic.
If ambient light level falls below 50 lux, energize a lamp relay; when it rises above 80 lux, de-energize. Add a 5-second hold-off after switching to prevent chatter.
Design a safety timer for a heater relay: never allow the relay to remain on longer than 2 hours continuously. If the limit is reached, switch off and require a manual button press to re-arm.
On a short button press, pulse a relay for 500 ms then release. Ignore additional presses during the pulse. If the button is held longer than 2 seconds, do nothing (no action on long press).
Implement a doorbell relay: when the button is pressed, close the relay for 1.0 second. Afterward, enforce a 3-second refractory period where additional presses are ignored.
Create a simple thermostat for a heater relay: turn ON if temperature is below 19.0 C and turn OFF above 21.0 C. Report the current state (HEAT or IDLE) via a small enum.
Control a water pump relay using a float switch: pump ON when the float indicates level is low, pump OFF when high. Add a 2-second ON delay to avoid reacting to slosh.

Make a countdown timer: a button starts a 10-minute countdown. When the timer expires, turn a relay ON for 30 seconds and then turn it OFF. If the button is pressed during the countdown, reset the timer.
On startup, hold a relay OFF for 5 seconds before allowing normal control by a toggle switch. This prevents accidental energization during boot.
Drive a relay while a button is held down and release it when the button is released. Apply 20 ms deglitching to both press and release to handle switch bounce.

Run a 50 Hz control loop that turns a relay ON when a switch is closed and OFF otherwise. Include a watchdog timer that will reset the system if no loop tick occurs for 200 ms. Target WCET per tick: 0.5 ms.

Add an enum Mode {Disabled, Enabled} toggled by a long-press (>1 s) on a button. When Disabled, force a controlled device relay OFF regardless of inputs. When Enabled, the relay follows the push-to-toggle behavior. Include a minimal state machine to manage mode and relay state.

Build a smart lighting controller using a state machine with enum modes AUTO, MANUAL, and OFF. Inputs: motion sensor, ambient light in lux, and a wall switch. In AUTO, turn the light relay ON when motion occurs and lux < 100, keep it on for 2 minutes after last motion; MANUAL directly follows the wall switch; OFF forces the relay off. Use a 100 Hz loop with a watchdog timer and ensure WCET <= 1 ms.

Control two relays for heating and cooling with mutual exclusion. Implement a state machine with states IDLE, HEAT, COOL. Use a thermostat setpoint in Celsius with 0.5 C deadband. Enforce a 30-second minimum off-time before switching modes. Include a watchdog timer.
Create a 3-way lighting logic: two wall switches both toggle the same light relay. Debounce each input (40 ms), and ensure no false toggles on simultaneous changes. Restore last relay state on boot.

Implement a staircase timer: pressing any of two buttons turns a light relay on for 120 seconds. Additional presses extend the timer. While the timer is active, blink an indicator output at 1 Hz. Use a state machine for clarity.

Irrigation zone controller: schedule watering at 06:00 for 20 minutes on Mon/Wed/Fri. Skip watering if a rain sensor is wet or soil moisture is above 30%. Provide a manual override button to start/stop immediately. Include a watchdog timer.

Coffee maker safety relay: enum states OFF, HEATING, FAULT. A short press starts HEATING; auto-off after 30 minutes; if temperature exceeds 95 C, enter FAULT, force OFF, and require a long-press (>2 s) to clear. Add a safety watchdog.

Door lock actuator: on button press, pulse the relay for 800 ms to toggle the lock. Ignore repeated commands for 5 seconds. Verify lock movement via a door/bolt sensor; if movement is not detected within 2 seconds, raise a FAULT state and inhibit further pulses until manual reset.

Roller shutter control with two relays (UP and DOWN) and strict interlock. Short press: move until end-stop switch closes or 30 s timeout; long press: jog in 200 ms steps. Prevent energizing both relays. Target WCET 1 ms at 100 Hz and include a watchdog timer.

Smart outlet relay with overcurrent protection: turn OFF and latch a FAULT if measured current exceeds 10 A for more than 5 seconds. Provide a manual reset sequence (double-tap within 1 second). Normal operation is a push-to-toggle with 25 ms debounce.

Pool pump scheduler: run daily from 09:00 to 17:00 except during quiet hours 13:00–14:00. Manual override switch toggles immediate ON/OFF but reverts back to schedule at the next boundary. Enforce 5 minutes minimum off-time between starts to protect the pump.

Ventilation boost controller: if CO2 > 1000 ppm, turn the fan relay ON for 15 minutes, then return to normal. A cancel button exits boost early. Provide enum modes ECO and BOOST, and a watchdog timer.

Water heater schedule: maintain 50 C normally, but every Sunday at 02:00 raise to 60 C for 30 minutes (anti-legionella). If temperature exceeds 70 C, enter FAULT and force the relay OFF until manual reset. Use a state machine and watchdog timer.

Entry light automation: when the door opens and ambient light < 100 lux, turn a light relay ON for 2 minutes. If the door stays open for more than 10 minutes, force the light OFF to save energy. Reset timers on door activity.

Two-zone lighting controller: two buttons control two separate relays. Single tap toggles its zone; double-tap either button toggles both zones; long-press on either turns both OFF. Use a clear state machine for tap detection.

Occupancy simulation: between 19:00 and 23:00, randomly toggle a light relay at intervals between 5 and 15 minutes. If an occupancy sensor indicates presence, suspend simulation until the window closes. Ensure randomness is reproducible from a seed provided at boot.

Scene controller with enum SCENE {Off, Relax, Bright} using three relays to select lighting circuits. A single button cycles scenes on each press; a long-press (>1.5 s) jumps to Off. Indicate the active scene via an LED output pattern.

Sump pump protection: when the float switch calls for pumping, run the relay until the float clears or 3 minutes elapse. Enforce 1 minute rest between cycles. If more than 3 cycles occur within 10 minutes, latch a FAULT and require manual reset.

Changeover valve controller for heating/cooling requests: inputs HEAT_REQ and COOL_REQ. States: IDLE, HEAT, COOL. Insert 10-second neutral (valve de-energized) between mode changes. If both requests arrive, prefer HEAT and log a conflict flag.

Gate opener logic: a single button cycles states OPENING → OPEN → CLOSING → CLOSED, with a relay pulse for OPEN/CLOSE commands. If the photo beam is broken during CLOSING, stop and reverse to OPENING. Add timeouts (e.g., 20 s) for incomplete travel and enter FAULT if exceeded.

Master/child lighting: a master arm switch enables automation; a child switch toggles a light relay only when armed. Auto-disarm after 60 minutes of inactivity. On disarm, force the relay OFF. Use enum modes DISARMED and ARMED with a small state machine.

Implement time-proportional PID control for a boiler relay: sample temperature at 10 Hz, compute a PID output mapped to a 10-second relay window (relay ON fractionally). Enforce anti-short-cycling (minimum 2 minutes between activations). Include a watchdog and WCET <= 1 ms per tick.

Smart thermostat with schedule and PID: maintain a setpoint profile by time-of-day, with frost protection at 5 C. Use PID with relay time-proportioning. Detect an open window if temperature drops >0.5 C within 2 minutes, then suspend heating for 15 minutes. Include a watchdog timer.

Sensor fusion for room occupancy to control a light relay: combine PIR, acoustic level, and door switch using a state machine with states VACANT, PROBABLE, OCCUPIED. Update at 20 Hz, apply hysteresis to avoid flicker, and enforce a 2-minute hold in OCCUPIED before turning off. Use a watchdog.

Hot water recirculation pump: start on-demand via a button or automatically if remote pipe temperature < 35 C; stop when return temperature > 45 C or after a 5-minute timeout. Enforce 2-minute minimum off-time. If a leak sensor triggers, cut power and latch FAULT until manual reset.

Solar thermal diverter: control a pump relay and a 3-way valve to move heat to a storage tank when collector temperature exceeds tank temperature by 8 C. Add PI control to modulate pump via time-proportioning. Safety: overheat protection at 90 C and freeze protection below 3 C. Include a watchdog.

Air quality ventilation controller: fuse CO2, VOC, and humidity to select enum modes ECO, NORMAL, BOOST, FAULT. Drive a fan relay accordingly (BOOST = continuous ON for 20 minutes). Degrade gracefully if any sensor fails. Run at 50 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms and a watchdog timer.

Whole-home leak protection: monitor multiple leak sensors; if any is wet, close the main water valve relay and latch FAULT. Provide a weekly scheduled exercise (close for 5 s then reopen) to keep the valve free. Require a manual reset sequence to clear FAULT.

Greenhouse ventilation and shading: maintain 24 C using PID-based time-proportioned control of a fan relay; if wind sensor indicates high wind, force shade relay OPEN. Add overtemperature safety at 35 C (force fan ON continuously) and a watchdog timer.

Adaptive lighting groups: target 150 lux using two lighting relays as coarse levels. Fuse ambient light and time-of-day; filter lux with an exponential moving average. Choose OFF, LEVEL1, or LEVEL2 to approach the target without rapid toggling. Quiet hours 23:00–06:00 force OFF.

Brownout-safe controller: monitor supply voltage; when voltage dips below threshold, enter SAFE mode and drop all noncritical relays. On recovery, wait 5 seconds before returning to NORMAL. Enum modes NORMAL, SAFE, RECOVERING. Include a watchdog and specify WCET <= 1 ms at 100 Hz.

Design a whole-house main water valve automation with enum modes NORMAL, AWAY, and VACATION. Rules: close the valve when in AWAY/VACATION, unless a scheduled weekly 10:00–10:05 exercise is running. On leak detection, force FAULT and keep closed until manual reset. Provide a formal state machine, a 50 Hz control loop with watchdog, WCET <= 1 ms, and a set of acceptance and fault-injection test cases covering mode transitions and sensor failures.

Create a load-shedding controller for multiple appliance relays using enum modes NORMAL, PEAK, EMERGENCY. Use a schedule to enter PEAK on weekdays 17:00–21:00. Shed lower-priority relays first when total power exceeds a threshold input; never drop critical loads. Provide a deterministic state machine, watchdog timer, WCET budget, invariants (e.g., never energize more than N relays), and a test plan with edge cases.

Implement a multi-room lighting scheduler: each room has a calendar of ON/OFF times, an occupancy sensor override, and enum modes AUTO, MANUAL, and SLEEP. In SLEEP, ignore occupancy and force OFF. Specify a clear state machine per room, define update rate (100 Hz), WCET per room task, watchdog, and unit tests for schedule boundaries and overlapping events.

Dual-source water system: manage relays for a well pump and a city water valve with modes CITY, WELL, FAULT, AWAY. Automatically fail over to CITY if WELL pressure is low; anti-short-cycle the pump (3 minutes minimum off-time). On leak detection, close both sources and enter FAULT. Provide a complete state machine, watchdog, timing constraints, and a safety test suite.

Comprehensive garage/driveway automation: control a gate relay and two lighting relays with modes HOME, AWAY, NIGHT, and FAULT. Rules include auto-closing the gate after 60 seconds, lighting on motion at night, and obstruction sensor safety (reverse on block). Provide a deterministic state machine, 100 Hz loop with WCET <= 1 ms, a watchdog timer, and a thorough set of acceptance tests and fault-injection scenarios.

Create a simple smart light controller: a single momentary switch toggles a light relay, but a long-press (≥2 s) starts a 5-minute auto-off timer. Debounce the input, ensure the relay defaults to OFF on boot, and add a watchdog timer that forces the relay OFF if the main loop stalls for more than 200 ms. Run the logic at 100 Hz with a WCET of 1 ms.

Implement a garage light with a small state machine (OFF, ON, TIMING): a button toggles ON, and if left ON it auto-switches OFF after 10 minutes. A second press during TIMING should return to OFF immediately. Restore correct state after a reboot based on the timer, and include a watchdog that reverts to OFF on fault.

Make a bathroom fan controller using a temperature sensor (Celsius) with hysteresis: turn the relay ON above 28 °C and OFF below 25 °C. Sample at 1 Hz with basic filtering. If the sensor fails (out-of-range or stale), force the relay OFF and flag a fault. Include a simple watchdog timer.

Design a push-to-water irrigation valve: one button press opens the valve for 15 minutes, a second press cancels early. Cap total daily ON time at 30 minutes. On any reset or watchdog expiry, the valve must be OFF. Provide a small state machine to manage RUN/CANCELLED/IDLE.

Schedule a porch light to turn ON at 18:00 and OFF at 23:30 daily. If the device restarts mid-window, restore the correct ON/OFF state and handle any missed transitions gracefully. The light must fail safe to OFF on faults. Keep it simple and deterministic.

Please implement a hallway light activated by motion: at night (22:00–06:00) motion triggers the relay for 90 s, and each new motion extends the timer. Use a state machine (IDLE, ACTIVE, LOCKOUT) to avoid chattering. Add a watchdog timer and ensure the relay defaults to OFF.

Create a doorbell controller: pressing the button energizes the chime relay for exactly 2 s. Enforce a 5 s refractory period to ignore rapid repeats, and debounce the input. Include a watchdog that ensures the relay is never stuck ON.

Build a dehumidifier switch: switch the relay ON above 60% RH and OFF below 55% RH, sampling humidity at 2 Hz with a simple moving average. On sensor fault, force OFF. Make it robust with a watchdog timer.

I want a safe water heater enable switch with a child lock: only a long-press of 3 s enables the relay; a short press disables it. An LED indicates the latched enable state. Relay must default to OFF after power loss. Add a watchdog (500 ms timeout) that drops the relay on fault.

Implement up/down blind control using two relays with strict interlock so both can never energize together. Any move command times out after 30 s if no limit switch confirms completion. Provide a small state machine and ensure watchdog fallback to both relays OFF.

Create a sump pump exercise routine: every day at 09:00, run the pump relay for 5 s unless the high water sensor is active, in which case skip the test. The relay must never run if the watchdog fires or after a reboot until the schedule resumes normally.

Design a timed outlet with START and STOP buttons: START cycles through preset durations (5, 15, 30 minutes), then runs a countdown; STOP cancels immediately. Ensure the relay is OFF on boot and on watchdog timeout. Keep the UI simple and deterministic.

Make a two-circuit ceiling light controller with a single rocker: a short press toggles Circuit A, a double press (within 400 ms) toggles Circuit B. Debounce, detect double-press reliably, and ensure both relays default to OFF on faults via watchdog.

Configure a bathroom exhaust fan with post-run: when the light switch turns OFF, keep the fan relay ON for 3 minutes, extending if the light is turned back ON during that interval. Provide a tiny state machine to manage RUN/POST-RUN/IDLE and a watchdog that forces the fan OFF on fault.

Create a pet feeder relay control: energize the motor relay for 4 s at 07:00 and 19:00. Prevent more than 8 s of total motor runtime per hour to protect the motor. The relay must default to OFF on reboot and on watchdog expiry.

Design a smart thermostat with enum modes OFF, HEAT, COOL using relay outputs. Allow weekday/weekend schedules with target temperatures in °C. Enforce an anti-short-cycle guard of 3 minutes between changes. Use a clear state machine and a watchdog; sample sensors at 1 Hz.

Implement a laundry dryer booster fan that starts when relative humidity rises faster than 0.5 %RH/min and the door contact is closed. Cap runtime at 60 minutes, then enforce a 10-minute cooldown. Use a state machine and a watchdog; sample at 2 Hz.

Combine two outdoor PIR sensors to reduce false triggers: turn on the light relay for 2 minutes only when both sensors detect motion within a 5 s window. If neither confirms, do nothing. Add a watchdog and ensure the relay is OFF by default.

Create a pool pump schedule: run 08:00–12:00 and 16:00–18:00 daily. A manual override button starts a 30-minute run outside the schedule but must respect a maximum of 6 hours total runtime per day. Return to scheduled mode after override ends. Add a watchdog and a simple state machine.

Control 4 irrigation zones sequentially for 10 minutes each at 05:30 daily. Skip all zones if a rain sensor is active. Provide pause/resume and ensure only one valve relay is energized at a time. On reboot, resume safely or skip to the next cycle boundary. Include a watchdog and WCET ≤ 1 ms.

Make a towel rail heater that runs during a morning window (06:00–08:00) only if bathroom motion occurred within the last 30 minutes. Use a temperature sensor and shut down if the surface exceeds 55 °C. Implement a small state machine and a watchdog for safety.

Design a window-open inhibitor for heating: if a window contact remains open for more than 30 s, disable the heating relay and only re-enable after the window has been closed for 10 minutes. Track and expose an enum reason for inhibition. Include a watchdog that forces the relay OFF on fault.

Implement a garage door controller using a robust state machine (IDLE, OPENING, CLOSING, FAULT). Use open/closed limit contacts and an obstruction input. The motor relay must time out after 20 s if no limit is reached, and any FAULT drops the output. Include a watchdog and a manual stop input.

Create a washing machine safety cutoff: any water leak sensor triggers a latching power-cut relay to OFF until a manual reset button is held for 3 s. Reaction time must be ≤50 ms with WCET ≤1 ms. Ensure the relay fails safe to OFF on any watchdog fault.

Build a lighting scene controller with enum modes DAY, EVE, NIGHT, AWAY that map to three relay groups. Transition by schedule and a scene button. Persist the last scene across power cycles. Include a watchdog and guarantee a safe OFF state in AWAY.

Implement load shedding: monitor whole-home power (watts) and, if >3000 W for 10 s, shed nonessential relays in priority order. Restore loads when power remains <2500 W for 60 s. Essential relays must never be shed. Sample at 5 Hz, use a watchdog, and document safe defaults.

Create a greenhouse controller with two relays (heater and fan) to maintain 20–26 °C. Interlock so both can’t run simultaneously. Sample at 1 Hz. On sensor fault, force both relays OFF and enter a FAULT state. Add a watchdog timer.

Make an anti-stagnation water circulation controller: run the pump relay for 5 minutes every 12 hours unless the water temperature exceeds 60 °C. A button triggers an extra 5-minute run. Limit runtime to 15 minutes per hour. Include a watchdog and safe startup behavior.

Design a staircase light controller with two motion sensors (top and bottom) and a light sensor. After dark (<200 lux), motion turns the light relay ON for 2 minutes. If opposite-end motion follows within 5 s, extend to 4 minutes. Include a watchdog and ensure OFF on faults.

Add a vacation mode that randomizes two lighting relays between 18:30 and 22:30: ON durations 5–20 minutes and OFF gaps 3–10 minutes. After 22:30, never allow both relays ON simultaneously. Use a deterministic PRNG seed parameter, a clear state machine, and a watchdog.

Implement an HVAC filter reminder: accumulate fan relay ON time, and after 200 hours activate an indicator relay. Reset with a 3 s button hold. Persist counters across reboots. Add a watchdog that prevents the indicator relay from latching on fault.

Create a CO2-based ventilation controller: if CO2 > 1000 ppm and the window contact is closed, turn on the fan relay; turn it off when CO2 < 800 ppm. Limit continuous ON to 2 hours, then enforce a 10-minute cooldown. Sample at 1 Hz and include a watchdog.

Control a dishwasher booster: when a current sensor indicates dishwasher load >1.0 A, enable the booster relay; turn it off 5 minutes after the current drops below that threshold. Hard cap total cycle time at 2 hours. Use a state machine and a watchdog.

Create a hot tub safety interlock: the heater relay energizes only if the cover switch is closed. A leak sensor permanently inhibits the heater until a manual reset. Provide a maintenance mode input that temporarily bypasses the cover interlock with a 10-minute timer. Include a watchdog.

Make gate path lights follow the gate motor state: when MOVING, turn the path lights relay ON; keep it ON for 3 minutes after the CLOSED contact is asserted. Detect a fault if OPEN and CLOSED contacts are true simultaneously, and in FAULT force all relays OFF. Add a watchdog.

Implement time-proportioning PID heat control for a room using a relay: target 22 °C with a 10 s control window and 5 Hz sampling. Limit to 6 relay cycles per minute and add anti-windup. Include a high-temperature safety cutoff at 70 °C, a watchdog, and WCET ≤1 ms.

Design a boiler controller with outdoor reset: combine indoor and outdoor temperatures to compute a target and drive the burner relay with minimum ON/OFF durations of 2 minutes. Provide frost protection at 5 °C and log recent cycle durations. Include a watchdog and a clear state machine.

Create an occupancy fusion lighting controller: combine PIR, sound level (dBA), and ambient lux to compute an occupancy score between 0 and 1. Turn lights ON if score >0.7 and OFF if <0.3 after a timeout, with a nighttime bias to be more sensitive. Run at 10 Hz with WCET ≤2 ms. Add a watchdog and an enum mode selector (AUTO/MANUAL/OFF).

Build a smart irrigation system that adjusts daily watering based on evapotranspiration estimated from temperature (°C), humidity (%), and light (lux). Cap total watering to 30 minutes/day, inhibit for 48 hours after a rain sensor event, and measure valve current to detect overcurrent >0.5 A, entering FAULT and disabling outputs. Include a watchdog and a state machine.

Implement a backup sump pump manager: prefer mains pump, but if water level is rising faster than a threshold or mains is unavailable, switch to the backup pump relay. Test the backup monthly for 10 s. Ensure only one pump can run at a time, include a battery-low alarm, and add watchdog supervision with safe fallback to both pumps OFF.

Create a demand response controller: accept a price tier input (LOW, MED, HIGH, CRITICAL) and manage heater and water-heater relays to stay within comfort bands while shifting usage. Preheat in LOW, shed in HIGH/CRITICAL with maximum OFF durations. Use a state machine, schedules, and a watchdog.

Develop a load balancer using PID to keep mains current under 40 A by time-proportioning three relays (water heater, EV contactor, dryer) in windows. Run the control loop at 10 Hz with WCET ≤2 ms. Enforce priority and never exceed 80% duty for the dryer. Include a watchdog and fail-safe behavior.

Control a solar hot water recirculation pump: run when roof panel temperature is at least 8 °C above tank temperature, and stop when the delta falls below 3 °C. Prevent night-time reverse heat loss. Add freeze protection (roof <2 °C and tank >5 °C) by running for 2 minutes. Optionally use a duty-window PID to minimize cycling. Include a watchdog.

Implement an air quality manager that fuses PM2.5 (µg/m³), CO2 (ppm), and VOC (index) to select between LOW and HIGH fan relays. Provide enum modes AUTO, MANUAL, and OFF; manual buttons set mode and speed, with auto-revert to AUTO after 12 hours. Enforce that LOW/HIGH are never on together. Sample at 2 Hz and add a watchdog.

Create a motorized roller shade controller: interlocked up/down relays, a calibration routine to learn travel time, and stall detection via a current sensor. States include IDLE, MOVING, CALIB, and FAULT. Limit cumulative runtime to 4 minutes per hour to avoid overheating. Include a watchdog that forces both relays OFF on fault.

Design a whole-home mode manager with enum modes HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, and ALARM. Each mode defines rules for lighting, HVAC relays, and controlled outlets. Transitions depend on schedule, occupancy sensors, and an alarm input. Provide a high-level state machine, watchdog supervision, priority conflict resolution, and a test harness that simulates 48 hours including missed schedules and sensor flapping.

Implement a fire emergency integration: on smoke alarm, within 100 ms cut power to nonessential relays, energize stair lights, and unlock the door strike. Latch ALARM mode until a manual reset. Add a heartbeat watchdog and redundancy checks on the alarm signal. Define a fail-safe output pattern on watchdog expiry and provide verification cases.

Create a multi-zone irrigation controller for 8 zones with schedule blocks, manual mode, rain and soil moisture sensors, and seasonal percent adjustment. Use a state machine with enum modes IDLE, RUN, PAUSE, and FAULT. Enforce one valve at a time electrically. Run a 50 Hz scheduler with WCET ≤3 ms. Specify tests for valve short, missed schedule, and brownout recovery.

Build an energy-aware home orchestrator with enum modes ECO, COMFORT, BOOST, and EMERGENCY. Integrate a power meter, occupancy fusion, and time-of-day schedules to shed or enable relays by priority, with guard timers and maximum interruption durations.
