Define watchdog strategy, fault containment states, and a verification plan with scenario-based tests and timing checks.

Develop a residential dumbwaiter controller: up/down relays, door interlocks on both levels, floor position sensors, and an emergency stop. Implement a robust state machine with modes IDLE, MOVING, DOOR_OPEN, and FAULT. Never energize both directions, add motion timeouts and jam detection, and include watchdog supervision. Set the control loop to 100 Hz with WCET ≤1 ms and provide a comprehensive safety and test plan.

Create a simple controller where a wall switch toggles a light relay with 50 ms debounce. On power-up, default the relay to OFF. Include a basic watchdog timer that must be kicked every 2 seconds; if it expires, force the relay OFF.

Make a timer outlet: a momentary pushbutton starts a 15 minute countdown that energizes a relay, and pressing again cancels and turns the relay OFF. Ensure the relay is OFF on boot and if the watchdog (1 s period) is not refreshed.

When a door contact opens, turn on a siren relay; when it closes, delay 0.5 s then turn the relay off to avoid chatter. Keep behavior deterministic and include a watchdog that fails safe to OFF on timeout.

Drive a porch light relay from a motion sensor: on detection, turn ON for 120 seconds and retrigger if motion occurs again. Add a 100 ms input debounce and a watchdog that disables the relay if not serviced within 2 seconds.

Implement a fan relay driven by a toggle switch. If turned OFF, enforce a minimum 60 s OFF time before the relay can be turned back ON to prevent short cycling. Default to OFF on boot and on watchdog expiration.
Schedule a coffee maker relay to turn ON daily at 07:00 for 10 minutes, then OFF. If the real-time clock signal is invalid or the watchdog is not kicked every 1 s, force the relay OFF.

Use an ambient light sensor to control a lamp relay: if measured light is below 80 lux for 5 seconds, turn ON; if above 120 lux for 5 seconds, turn OFF (hysteresis). Include a watchdog that defaults to OFF if it expires.
For a water leak detector, when the leak input is active, energize an alarm relay. When the input is inactive for 10 seconds, turn the relay OFF. Ensure a 1 s watchdog forces OFF on timeout.
Build a doorbell controller: each press triggers a 1 second pulse on a chime relay. Ignore additional presses for 2 seconds (cooldown). Watchdog timeout should leave the relay OFF.
When an IR beam is broken, activate a gate relay for 5 seconds then turn it OFF. Debounce the input 20 ms and include a watchdog that forces the output OFF on any fault.
Hold-to-run mode: the pump relay is ON only while a momentary button is held; release turns it OFF immediately. Debounce 30 ms and add a 1 s watchdog that defaults the relay to OFF.

Link a door open sensor to a porch light: when the door opens, turn the light relay ON for 30 seconds; if the door closes before that, keep the light ON until the 30 seconds elapse. Fail safe to OFF on watchdog timeout.
Create a laundry done notifier: when a binary done input activates, pulse a buzzer relay for 10 seconds and ignore further triggers for 60 seconds. Include a watchdog that forces OFF on expiration.

Implement a bathroom fan delay-off: when the wall switch is turned OFF, keep the fan relay ON for 2 minutes, then OFF. When the switch is ON, the relay follows immediately. Debounce 50 ms and add a watchdog to default OFF.
Control a heater relay by temperature with hysteresis: turn ON below 20 C and turn OFF above 22 C. If the sensor is invalid or the watchdog is not serviced, force the relay OFF for safety.

Implement a two-way lighting controller for one relay using two switches. Use a small state machine with enum states LightOff and LightOn. Any switch edge toggles state with 50 ms debounce. Include a 1 s watchdog that forces LightOff on timeout.

Add a vacation lighting schedule with ±15 minute randomization. Provide enum modes Normal, Vacation, and Override. A manual button enters Override mode to force ON for 60 minutes. Use a supervisory watchdog that, if it expires, reverts to Normal and turns the relay OFF.

Design a staircase timer with two pushbuttons at top and bottom. Each press turns the light relay ON for 90 seconds and retriggers if pressed again. Blink an indicator during the last 10 seconds. Use a state machine and a watchdog that disables outputs on failure.

Ventilation fan controller with humidity and manual override: if RH > 65% for 30 s, turn fan relay ON; if RH < 55% for 5 minutes, turn OFF. Manual switch forces ON. Enforce a minimum 5 minute runtime when started. Use enum modes Auto and Manual, with a watchdog that fails safe to OFF.

Create a porch light automation using motion and door sensors, but only when ambient light < 100 lux. Rules: door open turns light ON for 3 minutes; motion retriggers. Model behavior with a state machine and include a 2 s watchdog that turns the relay OFF on timeout.

Water tank pump with low and high level sensors. If level low, keep pump OFF; if high, turn pump OFF; between low and high, pump ON. Add dry-run protection using a 10 s prime window and lockout if no level change. Use a state machine and watchdog defaulting to OFF.

A scene button cycles enum modes Off, Low, Medium, High for two lighting relays (relay A and relay B). Map: Low = A ON, Medium = B ON, High = A and B ON. Long press enters Night mode (A ON for 10 minutes). Implement a state machine and a watchdog that returns to Off on timeout.

Motorized blinds with Up and Down relays (interlocked). A single toggle input starts movement to the next state in a cycle: Idle -> MovingUp -> Idle -> MovingDown. Enforce max 30 s drive time. Ensure both relays can never be ON together. Add a watchdog that stops movement on expiry.

Heated towel rail with weekly schedule and a temporary Boost mode. Enum modes Off, Schedule, Boost. Boost runs for 30 minutes then returns to Schedule. Enforce a safety cap of 2 hours continuous ON. Include a watchdog that forces Off on fault.

Smart plug with overcurrent protection: if measured current exceeds 10 A, open the relay and require a manual reset button to re-enable. Normal operation follows a daily on/off schedule. Provide a state machine with enum states Off, On, Tripped, and a watchdog to force Off on error.

Boiler pump anti-short-cycle controller. Input is a call-for-heat signal; output is a pump relay. Enforce min OFF 3 minutes and min ON 5 minutes. Limit operation to scheduled hours. Model with states Idle, Waiting, Running, Lockout, and include a watchdog that reverts to Idle on timeout.

Entry light automation with multiple triggers: doorbell press forces ON for 2 minutes; motion turns ON for 60 seconds only when ambient light < 100 lux. Prioritize doorbell over motion. Use a state machine, input debounce, and a watchdog that defaults to OFF.

Dual-relay climate control with enum modes Off, Heat, Cool, Auto. Maintain a setpoint in Celsius with a 1 C deadband. In Auto, select Heat or Cool based on measured temperature. Ensure relays are interlocked so Heat and Cool are never ON together. Include a watchdog that forces Off.

Gate controller with power source awareness: detect mains presence and switch to a BatterySave mode when mains is absent. Enum modes Mains and BatterySave alter relay activation durations (shorter on battery). Implement as a state machine with a watchdog that closes the relay on timeout.

Aquarium feeder schedule: at 08:00 and 18:00, run a feeder motor relay for 5 seconds. If the lid-open sensor is active, skip feeding and set an alert flag. Provide a manual test button. Use a state machine and a watchdog that halts output on any anomaly.

Child-safe outlet: require a two-button sequence (A then B within 3 seconds) to energize the outlet relay for 30 minutes, then auto-OFF. Any wrong press resets the sequence. Implement a clear state machine and a watchdog that forces OFF if not refreshed.

Window heater control: follow a schedule, but if the window sensor is open, force the heater relay OFF. If closed and temperature < 18 C, allow scheduled ON. Model as a state machine and use a watchdog that returns to safe OFF on failure.

Laundry room fan with RH and light switch inputs. If RH > 70% or the light is ON, run the fan. Keep the fan ON for at least 10 minutes after the conditions clear. A manual Off command is ignored until min runtime is met. Use enum modes Auto and Hold, and a watchdog.

Sump pump with dual float sensors: when high float closes, turn pump relay ON until low float opens. If high remains closed for more than 10 minutes, raise an alarm relay. Include a test mode activated by a button. Implement a state machine and a watchdog.

Holiday lights controller with enum modes Off, Evening, AllNight. Randomize start times by ±10 minutes. Provide a manual override that forces Off for 2 hours. Watchdog timeout must force Off and exit any temporary overrides.

SSR-based duct heater control using PID to maintain 22 C with a 1 s time-proportioning window. Safety: hard cutoff at 70 C. Run the control loop at 10 Hz with WCET not exceeding 5 ms per cycle. Include a watchdog that disables the relay if the loop misses two cycles.

Occupancy-driven lighting using sensor fusion of PIR, door contact, and sound level. Compute an occupancy state that controls a relay with timeouts of 5 minutes when quiet. Enum modes Home, Away, Sleep alter timeouts. Include a watchdog and clearly defined state machine transitions.

Power shedding for a smart strip: if total power draw exceeds 3000 W, shed noncritical relays in priority order and restore when below 2500 W. Prevent rapid toggling with 60 s minimum off time. Implement a state machine and a watchdog that forces all relays OFF on fault.

Irrigation zone control with soil moisture and rain sensors. Skip watering if soil > 30% or rain detected. Limit total water to 20 minutes per day. Add valve protection by waiting 2 seconds after closing before any other action. Specify WCET under 3 ms and include a watchdog.

Water heater relay management with anti-scald: only energize when tank temperature < 50 C and there is no flow detected. Trip and lock out if current > 12 A until manual reset. Use a state machine with states Off, Heating, Tripped, and a watchdog that forces Off on timeout.

Freezer defrost control: alternate between Run and Defrost based on compressor runtime. Activate defrost heater relay for a fixed interval unless a safety thermostat trips. Use enum modes Run, Defrost, Standby, enforce minimum separation times, and include a watchdog and deadline checks.

Heated floor SSR with PID: maintain 21 C during the day and 18 C at night per schedule. Limit floor sensor to 30 C maximum. Control loop at 2 Hz with WCET under 4 ms. Use a watchdog that drops to Off mode if control is late or sensors are invalid.

Air purifier relay control with sensor fusion of PM2.5 and VOC. Enum modes Quiet, Auto, Turbo. In Auto, compute a combined air quality index to select relay duty (on/off cycling) with minimum 10 minute on-time when activated. Include a watchdog and state machine.

Dual-source sump system with mains and backup pump relays. Detect mains failure and switch to backup, ensuring only one pump runs at a time. Weekly self-test runs each pump for 5 seconds. Implement a robust state machine and a watchdog that halts both relays on fault.

Greenhouse climate coordination: control a heater relay and a vent relay with priorities. Keep 20–24 C target, avoid conflicting actions with a 120 s deadband before switching. Update at 2 Hz with WCET under 3 ms. Use a watchdog and enum modes ColdProtect, Normal, Heatwave.

Whole-home mode manager: enum modes Home, Away, Night, Vacation coordinating multiple relays (lighting scenes, water heater, exterior outlets) via schedules and overrides. Clearly define state machine transitions, priority of manual inputs, and include a system watchdog and deadline monitoring. Provide requirements for mode transition tests and schedule edge-case tests.

Boiler room sequencing: control fan, ignition, and pump relays with strict startup and shutdown interlocks. Enum modes Off, Prepurge, Ignite, Run, Postpurge, Fault. Enforce WCET under 3 ms and a 1 Hz heartbeat watchdog. Specify a comprehensive test plan covering sensor failures, watchdog expiry, and interlock violations.

Elevator lobby lighting controller: multi-zone relays governed by schedules, occupancy sensors, and an emergency input. Enum modes Normal, Emergency, Maintenance. Emergency forces all safety lights ON regardless of schedule. Include a watchdog, define state transition diagrams in prose, and list tests for mode switching and sensor overrides.

Smart PDU for a small server closet: multiple outlet relays with load shedding rules based on temperature (Celsius) and total power (W). Modes Normal, PeakSaving, FireAlarm. Implement per-outlet watchdog pings at 1 Hz that cut power to noncritical outlets if missed. Specify WCET bounds and a verification checklist for all state transitions.

Hospital room automation: manage bedlight, reading lamp, and nurse-call relay with enum modes Patient, Procedure, Cleaning. Enforce strict safety rules: never cut power to the medical outlet relay in any mode. Include quiet hours schedules, brownout recovery to safe states, a system watchdog, and a comprehensive unit test suite covering all state machine branches and timing constraints.
Toggle a single relay with a debounced pushbutton. Short press toggles the light; an LED mirrors the relay state. Debounce approximately 20 ms. Keep it simple.
Make a momentary control: energize the relay only while the button is held down, with 50 ms debounce and a 30 s maximum hold for safety.
When a motion sensor is triggered, turn on a relay for 30 s; retriggers extend the timer. After timeout, switch off.
Implement a bathroom fan timer: pressing the switch turns the relay on and it automatically turns off after 10 minutes. A second press restarts the timer.
Doorbell-style control: on button press, activate the chime relay for exactly 1.0 s, then ignore further presses until the cycle completes.
Use a light sensor to control a lamp relay: sample every 200 ms and keep the relay on when ambient lux is below a threshold, otherwise off. Include simple hysteresis to avoid flicker.
Daily schedule: turn the outlet relay on at 19:00 and off at 23:00 local time. Manual button toggles should temporarily override until the next schedule edge.
A countertop light with auto-off: pressing the button turns the relay on and starts a 5 minute timer; any additional press resets the timer; the relay turns off when the timer expires.
Pet feeder motor relay: when the feed button is pressed, run the relay for 5 s and then enforce a 60 s lockout before it can run again.
Prime pump: when the prime button is pressed, run the pump relay for up to 20 s and stop sooner if the button is released.
Touch-activated lamp: a capacitive touch input toggles a relay; ignore touches shorter than 100 ms and longer than 2 s.
Remote command input toggles a relay and blinks a status LED twice whenever the state changes.
Night hallway light: between 22:00 and 06:00, motion turns the relay on for 45 s; outside these hours, ignore motion.
Garage light follow door: when the door-open switch closes, turn on the light relay; when it opens, keep the light on for 10 s and then turn off.
Soft-start outlet: on power-up, force the relay off for 3 s, then allow normal button toggling with 30 ms debounce.

Smart outlet with enum modes Manual, Schedule, and Away. Implement a state machine: Manual responds to button toggles; Schedule follows daily on/off times; Away randomly varies on-times within 10–20 min in the evening. Include a watchdog timer that forces the relay off if the control loop doesn't run for 500 ms.

Blind motor control with two interlocked relays (UP and DOWN). Use a state machine with states Idle, Raising, Lowering, and Fault. Honor limit switch inputs, enforce a 300 ms dead time between directions, and drop to Fault if both limit switches read active. Add a watchdog to de-energize both relays if any movement exceeds 60 s.

Humidity-controlled fan with enum modes Off, Auto, Manual. In Auto, turn the fan relay on when humidity exceeds 70% and off when it drops below 60%. Manual follows the button. Poll the sensor every 500 ms. Add a watchdog that sets the system to Off if no sensor update occurs within 2 s.

Water heater schedule with a 2-hour boost. Follow daily on/off times; a button press starts a 2 h Boost state overriding the schedule, after which control returns to Schedule. Implement with an enum mode and clear state transitions.

Motion- and light-aware porch light. Only turn on if motion is detected and ambient light is below a threshold; keep on for 2 min after last motion. A manual switch acts as an override that holds the light on until turned off. Model as a state machine.

Scene sequencer: pressing a Scene button turns on Relay A, then Relay B 200 ms later; turning off does the reverse with the same spacing. Include a watchdog that ensures the sequence completes within 1 s or aborts to all-off.

Simple thermostat for a garage: heater relay ON below 15 C and OFF above 18 C. Include an enum with Auto and Off, a manual override button to toggle modes, and a safety that limits continuous ON to 2 h. If the temperature sensor is invalid, turn the relay off and enter Fault.

Three-zone sprinkler scheduler: run Zones 1→2→3 for configurable durations each morning at 05:30, ensuring only one valve relay is energized at a time. Provide a Skip Next Cycle button. On power loss, resume at the correct zone and remaining time.

Roller shade control with two limit switches and UP/DOWN relays. Implement an enum mode (Idle, MovingUp, MovingDown, Fault) with interlocks so both relays can never be on together. Add a maximum run time of 45 s per move.

Stairway lights with two motion sensors (top and bottom). If either triggers in darkness, turn on for 90 s; if both trigger within 3 s, extend to 180 s. Provide a Manual On that keeps lights on until 30 min inactivity. Use a state machine.

Lighting with modes Off, On, Vacation. In Vacation, randomly toggle the relay in the 18:00–23:00 window with 5–15 min intervals. Provide a button to cycle modes. Indicate the current enum mode via LED blink patterns.

Delay-on/delay-off relay: when input goes ON, wait 500 ms before energizing the relay; when input goes OFF, keep the relay ON for 2 s and then release. Include a fail-safe that forces OFF if input chatter is detected more than 10 transitions in 1 s.

Two high-load outlets sharing a breaker: if A is on, block turning B on; if both are requested, queue B until A turns off or a 10 min timeout occurs. Provide status LEDs for each relay and a state machine to manage requests.
Two-speed fan using two relays with mutual exclusion. Implement states Off, Low, High, Transition. Enforce a 300 ms off time when switching between Low and High to protect the motor.

Heated entry mat control: Enable when outdoor temperature < 3 C and current time is 05:00–08:00 or 17:00–22:00. Offer a 30 min Boost via button. If temp sensor is missing, force Off and signal Fault. Include a watchdog with a 1 s timeout.

Child lock outlet: state machine where long press (>= 2 s) toggles the relay; short presses are ignored when locked. A long press of 5 s toggles Lock/Unlock mode. LED indicates lock status. Persist the lock state across reboots.

Siren driver: when an Alarm input goes active, pulse the relay at 1 Hz with 50% duty for 2 minutes, then enforce a 10 min cooldown. If Alarm clears early, finish the current pulse and then stop. Add a watchdog to ensure pulses are timed accurately.

Aquarium lighting schedule: Day relay ON 08:00–20:00, Night relay ON 20:00–08:00. Provide a Feed mode that turns both relays OFF for 15 min when a button is pressed. Recover to the scheduled state automatically.
Lamp group cycler: one button cycles states Off -> Lamp1 -> Lamp2 -> Both -> Off. Remember the last state across power cycles. Debounce presses and ignore repeats faster than 200 ms.

Implement a supervisor that polls inputs at 100 Hz with WCET <= 2 ms. If the internal watchdog is not petted within 300 ms, set all relays to a safe Off state and enter a Fault enum until a manual reset.

Thermostat with time-proportional control: maintain 21.0 C using a relay-driven heater by modulating power within a 10 s window based on a PID output. Enforce minimum ON/OFF times of 1 s, add a 0.5 C deadband around the setpoint to reduce chatter, and latch Fault if temperature exceeds 50 C. Use enum modes Heat, Idle, Fault; sample temperature at 10 Hz; WCET <= 1 ms; watchdog trips to Fault if samples stall.

Humidity controller for a dehumidifier with PID. Target 50% RH. Drive the compressor relay with anti-short-cycle protection (minimum OFF 5 min, minimum ON 2 min). Include QuietHours schedule (22:00–07:00) where the target is relaxed to 55%. Sensor failure enters Fault and forces OFF.

Sensor fusion lighting: combine a motion sensor and ambient lux readings to compute confidence; require two consecutive motion detections within 1 s and lux < 100 to turn on; decay confidence over 30 s to turn off. Provide Manual and Auto enum modes with a Fault state. Add a watchdog that ensures the fusion loop runs at 20 Hz.

Energy-aware water heater: follow a weekday/weekend schedule but suppress heating when a DemandResponse input is active. Provide a 1 h Manual Boost. Verify relay actuation using a feedback contact; if the commanded state doesn't match feedback within 200 ms, enter Fault and force Off. Include a watchdog and deterministic state machine.

Timed-position window shades: calibrate full-open and full-close times, then allow position commands (0–100%). Use relays for UP/DOWN with interlocks, stop after computed travel time, and enforce a maximum 70 s safety cutoff. Handle power loss mid-move by resynchronizing on next full travel. Include a watchdog.

Greenhouse climate relays: maintain temperature between 18 C and 25 C using a heater and an exhaust fan. Never energize both simultaneously. Night schedule lowers the band by 2 C. Provide a Manual Override that times out after 1 h. Fault on sensor loss. Watchdog runs at 10 Hz with WCET <= 1 ms.

Load shedding controller: monitor an Overload input; when active, shed relays in priority order 3 -> 2 -> 1 with 5 s spacing. Restore each relay only after Overload has been clear for 60 s. Use a state machine with enum Normal, Shedding, Restore, Fault. Ensure deterministic timing and include a watchdog.

Safety smart outlet: if a Ground Fault input is detected, de-energize the relay immediately and latch a Fault state that requires a 5 s long-press to reset. Blink an LED with a coded pattern in Fault. Feed a watchdog every 100 ms only when the system is healthy.

Multi-room scene controller for four relays with enum scenes OFF, EVENING, MOVIE, AWAY. Implement timed transitions (e.g., staggered turn-on with 250 ms gaps), a weekday schedule to auto-select EVENING at 18:00, and a midnight fail-safe to OFF. Provide a watchdog and a Fault state for conflicting commands.

Leak protection valve: on LeakDetected input, close the valve relay, latch in Fault, and require a two-step reset (acknowledge then manual re-open). Run a monthly self-test at 03:00 by pulsing the valve for 200 ms while verifying a closed-position input. Include a watchdog and prevent chatter.

Home mode manager with enum modes HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, VACATION controlling multiple relays (lights and outlets). Each mode maps to different schedules and overrides; transitions can be commanded by button or remote. Implement a deterministic state machine, a supervisor that feeds a watchdog at 10 Hz only if all periodic checks pass, WCET per tick <= 2 ms, and provide test hooks to simulate mode transitions and verify outputs.

Boiler and pump controller using two relays with strict safety. Enum states PREHEAT, RUN, PURGE, FAULT governed by a state machine. Run at 50 Hz; WCET <= 1 ms. Interlock so both relays cannot be on incorrectly; always perform a 10 s PURGE after RUN. Watchdog forces PURGE on any anomaly. Define acceptance tests for state transitions and timing.

Advanced scheduler with calendar rules: different on/off times for weekdays vs weekends, holiday exceptions, and automatic DST adjustments. Provide manual overrides that expire at the next schedule boundary. Include enum modes Auto, Manual, Vacation, Fault; a watchdog; and LED logging patterns for diagnostics.

Network gear power cycler for up to three relays. Support commands OFF, ON, and REBOOT with parameterized reboot durations (e.g., 5–60 s). Serialize concurrent requests, queue them fairly, and schedule a nightly reboot at 03:15. State machine with enum Idle, Executing, Fault; watchdog supervision; and defined tests for race conditions.

Emergency power-off controller: monitor multiple E-STOP inputs and de-energize all relays within 50 ms. Recovery requires a dual-ack sequence: two distinct acknowledge inputs within 5 s. Implement redundant watchdogs (internal plus an external feed signal) and periodic input-path self-checks. Specify WCET and show how safe timing margins are maintained.

Design a simple two-state controller for a lamp relay: OFF and ON. A single momentary button toggles the state on each distinct press with 50 ms debounce. If left ON, automatically switch OFF after 30 minutes. Include a basic watchdog that forces the controller back to a safe OFF state if the main loop fails to tick for more than 2 seconds.

Implement hold-to-run control for a fan relay: while the button is held, the relay is energized; when released, the relay de-energizes. Debounce input at 20 ms. On power-up, ensure the relay is OFF. Add a watchdog that resets internal timers if no heartbeat is observed for 1 second.

Make a one-shot timer plug: pressing the button turns the relay ON for exactly 10 minutes, then OFF; pressing during the interval cancels and returns to OFF. Model as a small state machine and include a 100 ms periodic tick. Require that worst-case execution time per tick is less than 1 ms.

Create a doorbell controller: as long as the button is held, energize the chime relay, but enforce a maximum continuous on-time of 5 seconds to protect the coil, then lock out for 10 seconds. Debounce 10 ms and add a watchdog that reverts to idle if no events occur for 30 seconds.

Build a toggle light control: each clean press of a button toggles a light relay; if the light has been ON for 1 hour, force it OFF. Use an enum for states and ensure no more than 2 toggles are accepted per second to reject bounce.

Implement a dusk-activated switch using a light sensor: when ambient falls below 150 lux, turn the relay ON; when it rises above 250 lux, turn OFF. Sample at 10 Hz with 2-sample hysteresis and guarantee that the control loop WCET remains under 1 ms.

Control a sump pump relay from a float switch: ON when the switch indicates high water, OFF when low, with 200 ms input filtering. Include a 3 second minimum ON time to avoid chatter and a watchdog to revert to OFF on any detected fault.

Write a heater enable relay with anti-short-cycle: a thermostat contact closes to request heat; energize relay, but enforce a minimum OFF time of 2 minutes and a minimum ON time of 2 minutes. State machine preferred; watchdog returns to OFF if timing logic overruns.
Program a motion-activated porch light: when motion is detected, turn the relay ON for 120 seconds; new detections extend the timer. Ignore detections within 300 ms of each other to filter noise.

Create a manual sprinkler test: a single button starts a 60 second ON cycle of the valve relay; a second press cancels and turns it OFF. Require that the controller maintains time accuracy within 1 percent over the minute.

Implement an over-temperature cutoff for a heat strip: if the temperature sensor reads 70 Celsius or above, force the relay OFF; allow it to turn back ON only below 65 Celsius. Sample at 10 Hz; on sensor fault, go to FAILSAFE OFF.
Design a bathroom fan timer: press once to run the fan for 15 minutes, then stop automatically. Additional presses during run are ignored. After power loss, resume in OFF state.
Build a de-fogger pad control: a single button toggles the relay, but cap any continuous ON period at 30 minutes. After auto shutoff, require a fresh press to re-enable.
Make a festive flasher: press the button to start a 1 Hz relay blink for 10 minutes, then stop; a press during blinking stops immediately. Ensure blink duty cycle near 50 percent.

Implement a two-way staircase light with two wall switches controlling one relay. Either switch toggles the light. Debounce each at 30 ms and use a clear state machine to avoid race conditions. Include a watchdog that forces OFF if contradictory inputs persist longer than 2 seconds.

Create a motion-and-ambient-light rule: only turn the hall light relay ON when motion is detected and measured light is below 100 lux; keep it ON for 3 minutes after last motion, then turn OFF. Provide enum modes for Normal and Test (Test reduces timer to 10 seconds).

Build a kids room lamp controller with three enum modes: Day, Evening, Night. Day follows the wall switch. Evening enforces auto-off after 45 minutes. Night ignores the switch and keeps the relay OFF. Include a state machine and a 100 ms periodic tick.

Program a bathroom fan with humidity override: turn ON when the button is pressed, or when humidity exceeds 65 percent, whichever occurs first; turn OFF when the timer expires (20 minutes) and humidity has fallen below 60 percent. Use hysteresis and ensure WCET under 2 ms per 100 ms cycle.

Create a vacation randomizer for a lamp: between 18:00 and 23:00 local time, randomly choose ON intervals of 10 to 30 minutes separated by OFF intervals of 5 to 15 minutes. A physical switch input cancels randomization and forces OFF. Provide a watchdog to recover to OFF on timing anomalies.

Implement a dual-speed fan with two interlocked relays: Low and High. Only one relay may be ON at a time; transitions must pass through both OFF for at least 500 ms. Control via a three-position selector input. Add a fault state if both requests are active.

Design a greenhouse vent controller using two limit switches and two relays for Open and Close. Drive Open until the open limit is reached, otherwise drive Close until the close limit is reached. Prevent simultaneous activation with interlock and include a 20 second movement timeout to enter FAULT.

Build a porch light with sunrise and sunset schedule: turn ON at sunset, OFF at 23:00, and ON again at 05:30 until sunrise. Provide a manual tap to temporarily turn OFF for 30 minutes, after which the schedule resumes. Use enum modes for Schedule, Temporary Off, and Manual.

Create an exhaust fan controller that enforces a duty cycle: allow manual start, but if ambient temperature is below 10 Celsius, limit total ON time to 15 minutes per hour rolling window. Use a state machine to track window and time credits.

Program a water heater enable relay with time-of-use: block heating between 16:00 and 20:00 on weekdays unless the emergency override switch is pressed. On override, allow one 30 minute ON slot then revert to blocked. Add a watchdog that fails OFF if the schedule service stalls.

Implement a garage light with door sensor and motion sensor: if door opens or motion is detected, turn light ON for 5 minutes; if both are active, extend to 10 minutes. If ambient light exceeds 300 lux, keep the light OFF. Use clear priority rules.

Develop a bed lamp with gesture button patterns: single tap toggles ON/OFF, double tap starts a 20 minute timer, long press over 2 seconds activates Night mode with 10 percent duty cycle blinking for 1 minute. Model as a state machine with explicit enum events.

Create a power tool outlet with safety interlock: only energize the outlet relay when the enable switch is ON and the e-stop input is NOT active. If e-stop activates, drop the relay immediately and require a power cycle to re-arm.

Design a pantry light that learns presence: if the door sensor opens, turn ON; if door closes and no motion for 2 minutes, turn OFF. If motion continues while door is closed, keep ON up to a hard cap of 20 minutes. Include a watchdog heartbeat at 10 Hz.

Make a plant grow light schedule with seasonal modes: enum Season = Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall. For each season, apply different daily ON durations starting at 07:00. Provide a button to cycle seasons and an LED indicator state machine.

Program a relay-based heater with frost-protect: below 3 Celsius, keep relay ON regardless of schedule; otherwise follow a weekday 06:00–09:00 and 17:00–22:00 ON schedule. Manual OFF overrides for 1 hour with a button press, then returns to schedule.

Implement a laundry room light that respects quiet hours: motion normally turns ON for 5 minutes, but between 23:00 and 05:00 only a button press will turn it ON. Debounce inputs and ensure no more than 10 transitions per hour during quiet hours.

Create a dual-outlet controller where Outlet A and Outlet B are mutually exclusive: A has priority from 08:00 to 12:00, B has priority from 12:00 to 16:00. Manual toggle buttons can preempt the schedule but must enforce interlock and a 1 second dead time between relays.

Design a curtain heater and fan interlock: if heater relay is ON, the fan relay must also be ON; when turning heater OFF, keep fan ON for 2 minutes to cool. Provide enum modes Auto and Manual. In Manual, only allow fan control; block heater commands.

Create a thermostat controller that drives a heating relay using time-proportional (windowed) PID control to maintain 21 Celsius. Use a 10 minute window with a minimum pulse width of 30 seconds to limit relay wear. Enforce no more than 6 relay activations per hour. Include watchdog supervision and fail safe to OFF on sensor fault.

Develop a water recirculation pump controller that maintains pipe temperature at 45 Celsius using a PI algorithm with a 5 minute actuation window. Combine readings from two temperature sensors with median filtering to reject outliers. Add a schedule that disables control between 23:00 and 05:00.

Implement an occupancy-driven lighting system that fuses motion, sound level, and ambient light to decide occupancy state with a three-state machine: Vacant, Uncertain, Occupied. Only energize the light relay in Occupied when below 120 lux, and decay back to Vacant after adaptive timeouts. Specify a 50 ms control tick with WCET under 2 ms.

Design a battery backup transfer controller with two relays for Source A and Source B. Guarantee break-before-make with a 200 ms neutral interval, supervise with a watchdog, and enter a latched FAULT if both feedback inputs disagree with commanded states. Include a safe startup that defaults to Source A only after verifying feedback.

Create a greenhouse heat and shade coordinator: heating relay uses time-proportional control to maintain 24 Celsius, while a shade relay drops when temperature exceeds 28 Celsius. Prevent oscillation by enforcing a 10 minute minimum shade hold. Include high temperature safety that cuts both relays at 40 Celsius and requires manual reset.

Build a bathroom ventilation controller that uses a PID on humidity to hit 55 percent relative humidity. The exhaust fan relay is time-proportioned in a 5 minute window. Integrate a manual boost button that sets 15 minutes at full duty, then returns to PID. Limit total relay cycles to 12 per day.

Program a smart outlet with load monitoring: read a current sensor and if current remains zero for 10 minutes while the schedule says ON, cut power and flag a FAULT state. Add a watchdog and require deterministic execution with WCET under 1 ms at 100 Hz sampling.

Implement a pool pump with multi-period schedule and priming: at start of any ON period, run for 2 minutes, then follow a duty cycle pattern based on water temperature (more ON when warmer). Include dry-run protection using a pressure switch; on fault, lock out until 30 minutes pass.

Design a stairwell lighting system using sensor fusion: combine two PIR sensors from opposite ends to determine direction. When entering, keep lights ON for 3 minutes; when passing through quickly, 1 minute suffices. If both sensors fire simultaneously repeatedly, enter Degraded mode and default to 3 minutes. Include a watchdog.

Create a server room cooling failover: manage two fan relays in lead-lag configuration. Lead handles normal cooling; if temperature exceeds 30 Celsius for 2 minutes, start lag as well. Rotate lead every 24 hours. Detect stuck relays via current sense and enter FAULT if commanded ON but no current within 5 seconds.

Specify a whole-home lighting scheduler with enum modes Home, Away, Sleep, Vacation. Each mode defines different behaviors for five relay groups (evening lights, outdoor, bedroom, pathway, decorative). Include manual overrides that time out after 1 hour and return to the active mode. Require a well-defined state machine, a 100 ms cyclic executive with WCET under 2 ms, a watchdog reset to a safe configuration, and a suite of scenario tests describing at least 10 distinct sequences.

Define a multi-zone heating enable system controlling four boiler relays with priorities and schedules. Modes: Normal, Eco, FreezeProtect, Fault. Enforce that no more than two relays are ON simultaneously, rotate priority daily, and guarantee anti short cycling of 3 minutes. Include power-on self-test, watchdog, and specify verification tests for interlock and priority rotation.

Design an advanced automation controller for a workshop with three enum modes: Workday, AfterHours, Emergency. It controls relays for task lights, dust extraction, and outlet power according to schedules and presence sensors. Include an explicit finite state machine with transition guards, e-stop preemption in under 100 ms, WCET constraints per tick, and a test plan that covers all mode transitions and fault paths.

Create a multi-mode irrigation controller managing six zone relays with schedules, rain sensor lockout, and a master pump relay. Provide modes Manual, Scheduled, RainDelay, Fault. Enforce that the pump relay is ON only when any zone is active and that zones never overlap. Include watchdog supervision, recovery to a known safe state after power loss, and acceptance tests for edge cases like back-to-back zones and rain events mid-cycle.

Specify a comprehensive smart apartment controller for hallway and stairwell lighting with adaptive schedules, occupancy logic, and failsafe rules. Enumerate modes Normal, EnergySaving, NightSafety, Test, Fault. Define a hierarchical state machine, heartbeat watchdog, timing budgets, and thorough self-test at startup, including simulation of sensor stuck-at conditions and validation of relays returning to OFF within 200 ms on Fault.

Create a simple controller where a wall switch toggles a light relay with 50 ms debounce, and an indicator LED mirrors the relay state. On watchdog timeout, ensure the relay goes to OFF and the LED turns off.

When a button is pressed, turn on a lamp relay for 5 minutes; a subsequent press during that interval should turn it off early. If the watchdog ever fires, fail safe by turning the relay off immediately.
Schedule a door chime by closing a relay every day at 07:00 for exactly 2 seconds. Preserve the schedule across power cycles and default the relay to OFF on startup and on any watchdog event.

Use a motion sensor to switch a hallway light on for 30 seconds, retriggering on continued motion. Ignore motion events that occur within 500 ms of the last to avoid noise. If the watchdog trips, turn the light off.
Turn a relay on when ambient light is below 100 lux and off otherwise. Sample the sensor at 5 Hz with a worst-case execution time under 2 ms per cycle. Watchdog failure should force the relay off.
Implement a two-way control where two momentary switches toggle a single light relay. Debounce each input by 30 ms and block any re-toggles that occur within 200 ms to prevent chatter.
Add a delay-on function: when an enable input is asserted, wait 3 seconds before energizing a pump relay; de-energize immediately when the input is deasserted. Fail safe to OFF on watchdog.

Every 15 minutes, energize a relay for 1 second as a periodic pulse. Provide a boolean input to disable the pulses entirely. Any watchdog occurrence should immediately stop pulses and turn the relay off.
When a door opens, turn on a light and keep it on until 20 seconds after the door closes. If the door remains open, keep the light on. Ensure off-on transitions do not exceed once per second.
On power-up, hold a relay OFF for 2 seconds, then restore the last saved ON/OFF state. Save state only after stable changes that persist for 1 second to reduce wear.
Control a fan relay based on temperature: turn on above 30 C and off below 28 C to provide 2 C hysteresis. Sample at 1 Hz. Watchdog failure should drop the relay to OFF.

Turn on a porch light at 18:00 and turn it off at 22:30 daily. A manual toggle input changes the current state, but the next scheduled event should take precedence. Ensure safe off if watchdog expires.

Use a single button to control a relay: short press toggles the relay; long press (over 2 seconds) forces OFF and clears any active timer. Debounce both edges and rate-limit toggling to once per second.
On a rising edge from a sensor, fire a relay for 250 ms (single-shot) and ignore any additional triggers for 1 second. Ensure watchdog timeout leaves the relay off.

Restore the last known on/off state of a smart outlet after power loss, but if it was ON continuously for more than 12 hours prior, start in OFF for safety. Provide an LED that blinks twice on such a safety start.

Build a water heater controller with enum Mode {Auto, Manual}. In Auto, run the relay during 06:00–08:00 and 18:00–22:00; in Manual, a button toggles the relay. Add a safety limit of 15 minutes maximum continuous ON followed by a 5-minute cooldown. Watchdog timeout must force OFF.

Create a staircase light state machine with states Idle, Timing, and Held. Any button press starts a 120 s timer; another press within 5 s cancels and turns off. During the last 10 s, blink an indicator LED at 2 Hz.

Control motorized blinds using two interlocked relays with a state machine: Idle, Opening, Closing, Stopped. Stop after 30 s maximum travel or on endstop input. If the watchdog triggers, transition to Stopped and de-energize both relays.

For garage lighting, turn on when the door opens or motion is detected, but only if ambient light is below 200 lux. Turn off 5 minutes after the door is closed and no motion. A manual wall switch overrides for 30 minutes.

Schedule a 4-zone sprinkler: run zones sequentially with configurable durations and ensure only one valve relay is active at a time. Provide a manual skip input for the next zone and pause irrigation if a rain sensor is active.

Implement a bathroom fan controller with a state machine (Idle, Auto, Boost). Auto turns on above 65% RH and stays on until humidity remains below 55% for 5 minutes. A boost button runs the fan for 15 minutes regardless of humidity.

Manage lighting profiles with enum Mode {Normal, Vacation}. In Vacation, randomly turn on a lamp between 18:00 and 23:00 for durations between 10 and 40 minutes, with no more than 4 cycles per evening. In Normal, follow a fixed schedule. Watchdog should default to OFF.

Turn off a group of accessory outlets if no motion is detected for 30 minutes, unless a load sensor shows >50 W consumption. Restore power immediately when motion is detected. Limit outlet state changes to one per minute.

Design anti-chatter control for a relay: enforce a minimum ON time of 2 seconds and minimum OFF time of 2 seconds regardless of rapid input changes. Use an LED to show when a requested change is being inhibited.

On water leak detection, cut power via a relay and sound a buzzer at 2 Hz until a manual reset is performed. Require the sensor to be dry for 60 seconds before allowing reset. Watchdog failure must force the power relay off.

Create a thermostat with scheduled setpoints: 21 C from 06:00–22:00 and 18 C otherwise. Control a heater relay using ±0.5 C hysteresis. Provide a manual override lasting 1 hour before returning to schedule.

Switch outdoor lights on at civil sunset minus 15 minutes and off at 23:30. A manual override input cancels lighting for the rest of the night only. Implement a state machine to handle schedule vs override cleanly.

Map three buttons to three light relays: each button toggles its relay; long-press any button turns all off; triple-press on button 1 turns all on for 10 minutes. Debounce button events and add a watchdog that forces all off.

Ventilation control: if CO2 exceeds 900 ppm or humidity exceeds 70%, run the fan; turn it off only after both CO2 and humidity stay below thresholds for 10 minutes. Indicate which condition triggered the fan using an LED pattern.

Control a main water valve with a manual button and a nightly close at 23:00. If a leak is detected, force the valve closed and lock out manual opening for 1 hour. Use enum State {Unlocked, Locked} to manage behavior.

Run a pet feeder motor relay for 5 seconds at 08:00 and 18:00. Ignore manual feed requests for 10 minutes after any run. If an overcurrent sensor trips for more than 100 ms, stop the motor immediately and latch a fault that requires reset.

If a window contact is open, disable a heater relay immediately; when it closes, wait 2 minutes before allowing heating. Block heating between 12:00 and 15:00 regardless of demand. Ensure the watchdog forces the heater off.

Implement lighting with Auto and Hold modes: motion turns lights on and they turn off after 15 minutes of no motion. A double-press on the wall switch enables a 1-hour Hold mode, canceled by a long press. Model this as a state machine.

Provide low voltage protection for noncritical relays: if supply falls below 10.5 V for more than 2 seconds, turn them off and blink an indicator; restore only after voltage remains above 11.5 V for 10 seconds. Watchdog should keep outputs off if it expires.

Alternate two sump pump relays on each float switch cycle to balance wear. If the active pump fails to lower the water level within 60 seconds, switch to the other pump and raise an alarm. Enforce a 5-second deadtime between pump activations.

Maintain water temperature at 55 C using a time-proportional PID driving an SSR relay with a 10-second control window. Enforce a minimum OFF time of 5 seconds and switch to a safe OFF state if the temperature sensor fails. Sample at 5 Hz with WCET under 2 ms, and use a watchdog to force OFF on fault.

Fuse PIR motion and sound level to compute an occupancy confidence. Only energize a light relay when confidence exceeds 0.7; decay confidence over time without noise. Use a state machine with Engaged, Probation, and Vacant states. Rate-limit relay toggles to once every 5 seconds and default to Vacant on watchdog.

Implement leak mitigation across up to 8 zones: if two distinct zones detect leaks within 60 seconds, close the main water valve relay and disable the water heater relay, then assert an alarm output. Run a monthly self-test at 10:00 that briefly actuates the valve for 2 seconds unless any zone is wet. Guarantee 20 Hz loop with WCET under 3 ms and safe OFF on watchdog.

Cut power to all appliance relays if a smoke alarm input is active or if temperature exceeds 60 C, and latch a fault until a manual reset. Additionally, detect brownout below 10 V and force OFF. Provide a heartbeat output, and ensure a watchdog supervises the system.

Control a smart door lock with enum states Locked, Unlocked, NightLatch, and Fault. Use two mutually exclusive relays to actuate lock/unlock. Auto-lock 30 seconds after the door closes. Detect jams if actuator current is high for more than 1 second and transition to Fault. Watchdog must force Locked.

Regulate a water heater using two temperature sensors; if they disagree by more than 3 C, select the safer reading (lower temperature) and flag a warning. Use PI control with a 30-second time-proportional window for an SSR relay, and enforce a maximum continuous ON time of 20 minutes followed by a 10-minute cooldown.

Implement load shedding: when measured total current exceeds 12 A for over 2 seconds, shed relays in a defined priority order; restore them in reverse order once current stays below 10 A for 30 seconds. Use a state machine with Normal, Shed1, Shed2, and Fault states, with at most one state change every 10 seconds. Ensure watchdog forces all noncritical relays off.

Build weather-aware irrigation: consult soil moisture (%) and a rain sensor to decide whether to run scheduled zones. Skip watering if soil moisture exceeds 35% or rain is active or it has rained within the last 24 hours. After manual start, cap any zone at 20 minutes. Watchdog must de-energize valves on fault.

Automate a motorized gate with a state machine: Idle, Opening, Closing, Obstructed, Fault. Two interlocked relays drive open/close. Use edge sensors and current spikes to detect obstruction; on obstruction, reverse for 2 seconds then stop. Limit total travel to 20 seconds. Watchdog should bring the system to Idle with both relays off.

Schedule freezer defrost: every 12 hours, energize the defrost heater relay for up to 8 minutes or until coil temperature reaches 5 C; abort early if cabinet temperature rises above -5 C. After defrost, enforce a 3-minute compressor lockout before allowing restart. Include watchdog supervision.

Implement a multi-room lighting system with profiles Normal, Eco, Party, and Night. Use enums and a state machine per room to manage switches, motion, and schedules, and add a supervisor that enforces a maximum total load of 8 A by shedding the lowest-priority rooms. Include watchdog behavior, bounded latencies (input sampling 20 Hz, actuation within 50 ms), and comprehensive tests for race conditions, schedule overlaps, and brownout recovery.

Create a dual-pump septic controller with modes Auto, Manual, and Service. Build a robust state machine that alternates pumps, handles high-level alarms, exercises each pump weekly, and enforces minimum ON/OFF times to prevent thermal overload. Apply a watchdog that drops to a Service-safe mode on timeout. Include fault injection tests for stuck float, failed relay, and power loss mid-cycle, with acceptance criteria and WCET < 3 ms at 100 Hz.

Specify an automation rule engine for a smart apartment controlling up to 16 relays. Support enum-triggered scenes, per-relay minimum ON/OFF times, and a global watchdog that forces a Safe state with all critical outputs off while noncritical outputs remain latched. The state machine must resolve rule conflicts deterministically. Require deterministic execution at 100 Hz with WCET of 1 ms, plus unit and property-based tests ensuring no rule causes relay chatter or deadlocks.
Create a simple relay controller: when a pushbutton is pressed, toggle the relay; use 50 ms debounce; ensure the watchdog forces the relay OFF if it ever expires.

Turn on a light relay when a motion sensor goes HIGH and keep it on for 30 seconds, extending the timer on new motion; ignore retriggers during the first 250 ms to avoid chatter; fail safe OFF on watchdog timeout.

Implement a greenhouse mister on a float switch: if the tank level switch indicates low water, keep the pump relay OFF; otherwise, when a 'mist' button is tapped, run the pump for 20 seconds; watchdog must default the pump relay to OFF.
Drive a fan relay from a simple on/off rocker switch with 30 ms debounce and an LED that mirrors the relay state; if the watchdog ever trips, turn the relay and LED OFF immediately.

Create a countdown outlet: a single button starts a 10-minute ON timer for a relay; pressing the button again cancels and turns it OFF; require a minimal state machine with Idle and Timing states; safe default OFF on watchdog.
Make a hallway nightlight: if ambient light drops below 50 lux, turn the light relay ON; above 80 lux, turn it OFF; include 500 ms sampling rate and watchdog fallback to OFF.
Implement a garage door light: when the door contact opens, turn a light relay ON for 90 seconds; if the door closes, allow the timer to complete; watchdog expiration must release the relay.
Design a sprinkler valve that energizes for exactly 2 minutes when a 'start' button is long-pressed for at least 1 second; short taps do nothing; relay must drop if watchdog expires.
Create a bedside lamp controller: a capacitive touch pad toggles the lamp relay; hold for >1.5 s to turn OFF regardless of current state; debounce 100 ms; watchdog sets OFF.
Implement a simple schedule: turn a coffee machine relay ON at 07:00 and OFF at 07:15 daily; include a watchdog that reinitializes outputs to OFF on any fault.
Use a door PIR sensor to drive a relay buzzer for 500 ms each time motion is detected; ignore triggers that occur within 200 ms of the last; relay must default OFF under watchdog.
Create a power-saving outlet: if no button activity occurs for 30 minutes, ensure relay is OFF; any button tap toggles it; include watchdog that also forces OFF.
Implement a heater enable relay that turns ON when a thermostat contact closes and OFF when it opens; sample at 100 ms; if watchdog is not kicked in 2 seconds, force OFF.
Design a window fan: ON when temperature sensor reads above 28 C, OFF below 26 C; read every 500 ms; if the sensor reading is invalid, or watchdog expires, ensure relay OFF.
Build a timer light: single button cycles between OFF and 'ON for 5 minutes'; use enum modes OFF and TIMED_ON and a tiny state machine; watchdog resets to OFF on timeout.

Create a bathroom fan controller with three enum modes: OFF, AUTO, and ON. In AUTO, turn the fan relay ON when humidity rises 5% above a baseline and keep it on for at least 10 minutes. Provide a pushbutton to cycle modes. Implement a state machine and ensure the watchdog defaults to OFF.

Implement a porch light with both schedule and motion: ON at sunset, OFF at 23:00; after 23:00, only turn ON for 2 minutes when motion is detected. Include an override switch that forces ON for 1 hour. Use a state machine with enum modes and watchdog fail-safe OFF.

Design a multi-relay scene: a 'Goodnight' button turns OFF all three relay channels, but delays the bedroom relay OFF by 20 seconds. Long-press (2 s) arms a security relay. Include watchdog that de-energizes all relays if not serviced.

Create a stairway light system using two 3-way switches at top and bottom: toggling either switch changes the light relay state, with 30 ms debounce and 90-second auto-off if no motion. Use a small state machine and watchdog.

Build an irrigation scheduler for two zones with enum modes MANUAL, SCHEDULE, and RAIN_DELAY. In SCHEDULE, run Zone 1 for 10 minutes then Zone 2 for 12 minutes at 05:30 daily. If a rain sensor is wet, skip. Watchdog must drop all valves.

Implement a heater outlet with safety: ON if temperature below 18 C, OFF above 20 C; but never run more than 45 minutes continuously without a 5-minute cool-down. Include state machine, watchdog to OFF, and sampling at 1 Hz.

Create a laundry room light that is ON when either the door contact is open or motion is detected, with a 2-minute timeout after last activity. A wall switch forces OFF regardless. Include enum modes and watchdog handling.

Design a pool pump relay manager: daily schedule 09:00–11:00 and 15:00–17:00; if water temperature exceeds 30 C, add an extra 1-hour run. Manual override toggles. Watchdog must shut the pump off on fault.

Build a pet feeder motor relay with two inputs: a schedule at 08:00 and 18:00 runs the motor for 6 seconds, and a manual feed button runs for 3 seconds; block re-feeds within 60 seconds. Use a state machine and watchdog.

Implement a garage heater with occupancy logic: if motion is detected and temperature below 12 C, turn ON; turn OFF 20 minutes after last motion or when temp exceeds 15 C. Provide a SAFE_OFF mode via enum that cuts power. Watchdog returns to SAFE_OFF.

Create a dehumidifier outlet controller with hysteresis and window: in AUTO mode, run when humidity > 60% and stop at 55%, but only between 10:00–22:00. A front panel switch cycles OFF/AUTO/ON. Use a state machine and watchdog to force OFF.

Design a whole-house 'Away' scene: when an 'Away' switch is activated, turn OFF selected relays (lights, outlets) and enable a randomize timer that briefly turns a lamp ON for 10 minutes between 19:00–22:00. Cancel when 'Home' is pressed. Watchdog resets to Home=normal OFF.

Implement a UV lamp relay with warm-up: when commanded ON, wait 5 seconds before energizing and enforce a maximum ON duration of 30 minutes. If door contact opens, shut OFF immediately. Include watchdog emergency OFF.

Create a garden light that follows a weekly schedule (different times on weekends). Provide an enum mode for HOLIDAY that twinkles: ON for 1 minute, OFF for 30 seconds, repeating from 18:00–23:00. Watchdog OFF on fault.

Build a smart outlet with energy budget: if current sensor reports >8 A for more than 2 seconds, trip OFF and require manual reset. Normal button toggles. Sample at 50 ms and ensure watchdog forces OFF on lapse.

Implement a ceiling fan with speed control relays (LOW, MED, HIGH) using enum speeds. A chain pull cycles speeds; an ambient temp sensor switches to HIGH above 30 C. Prevent conflicting relays and add watchdog safety.

Design a nursery night light: if sound level exceeds a threshold at night (22:00–06:00), turn ON for 3 minutes; double-tap button locks it OFF until morning. Use a small state machine and watchdog default OFF.

Create a hallway lights controller using a state machine with occupancy detection from both PIR and door contacts; lights stay ON while occupied and turn OFF 90 seconds after last event. Include a manual override enum mode and watchdog.

Implement a water softener regeneration relay schedule: start at 02:00, step through Backwash (12 min), Brine (30 min), Rinse (10 min) states, controlling the valve relay accordingly; abort and go to SAFE_OFF if a fault input is active. Use watchdog to enforce SAFE_OFF.

Build a patio misting system that runs every 20 minutes for 45 seconds when ambient temperature is above 32 C and humidity below 60%. Provide a toggle to enable/disable. Watchdog must shut the valve on timeout.

Develop a boiler circulation pump controller using time-proportional control: compute a 60-second window duty cycle from a PID that drives toward 21 C room temperature, actuating the pump relay accordingly. Include anti-windup, and if any temperature sensor reads invalid, drop to OFF. Sample at 10 Hz; WCET must be under 2 ms per cycle; include a watchdog that expects a heartbeat every 100 ms.

Create a smart attic fan with sensor fusion: combine temperature (C) and humidity (%) to compute a discomfort index; use thresholds with hysteresis to control the fan relay, but suppress operation if outdoor particulate sensor indicates poor air quality. Implement a state machine and a watchdog that forces OFF on missed kicks.

Implement a sump pump automation with two float switches (LOW, HIGH) and a current sensor: pump relay turns ON at HIGH, OFF when LOW is cleared; if current draw exceeds 12 A for >1 s, cut power and lockout for 5 minutes. Include a failure detection state when HIGH persists >5 minutes. Sample at 20 Hz; WCET < 1 ms; watchdog safe-off.

Design a water heater element controller with duty-cycled relay under a PI loop to maintain 55 C at the outlet, with 50 C minimum and 60 C maximum safety clamps. Include a thermal fuse input that forces OFF and latches a FAULT state. Heartbeat watchdog required.

Create an occupancy-driven HVAC bypass damper relay using sensor fusion of PIR, CO2 ppm, and door contact: if any two indicate occupancy, open damper; otherwise close after 10 minutes. Provide MANUAL_OPEN and LOCKED_CLOSED enum modes, and a watchdog that reverts to LOCKED_CLOSED on timeout. Sampling rate 2 Hz.

Build an aquarium lighting relay system with sunrise/sunset ramp using a PID to regulate light intensity via PWM-compatible solid-state relay cycles within a 10-second window, targeting 300 lux at a sensor. Enforce max relay switching rate of 0.5 Hz and WCET < 1 ms. Watchdog fallback OFF.

Implement a whole-house leak mitigation state machine: on leak sensor trigger, immediately cut power to selected appliance relays, close a main valve relay, and send a periodic heartbeat via a status LED. Add a recovery mode that requires two consecutive dry readings over 5 minutes to restore. Watchdog must keep all relays in SAFE_OFF on fault.

Develop a greenhouse irrigation controller that fuses soil moisture (%) and solar radiation (W/m^2) to schedule irrigation windows, using a PI loop to adjust valve ON durations within 15-minute slots. Enforce daily water cap and a watchdog that drops valves on timeout. Execute control at 1 Hz, WCET < 2 ms.

Create a battery backup transfer relay controller: when mains voltage drops below threshold, switch to backup after 200 ms validation; periodically test transfer for 3 seconds weekly at 03:00. Ensure make-before-break interlock, state machine with TEST and EMERGENCY modes, and watchdog emergency OFF if timing uncertain.

Design a smart dryer outlet that cycles a heater relay using PID-based duty within 30-second windows to target 45% relative humidity exhaust, using temperature and humidity sensors; include overtemp cutout at 80 C and watchdog to cut power if loop overruns.

Specify a multi-zone home lighting controller with four relays and enum modes HOME, AWAY, SLEEP, VACATION. Define a state machine that: schedules daily routines per zone, randomizes lights in VACATION between 18:00–23:00, dims behavior simulated via relay patterns, and respects quiet hours 23:00–06:00. Include a watchdog strategy (heartbeat every 200 ms) and require unit-testable timers and mode transitions with deterministic WCET < 1 ms.

Define a comprehensive garage automation system: states include IDLE, ENTRY, EXIT, LOCKDOWN, and FAULT. Control relays for door light, heater, and exhaust based on motion, CO ppm, and door contacts. Provide manual overrides, schedule-based preheat at 06:30, and safety interlocks that prevent heater and exhaust running together. Include watchdog fail-safe OFF, formal test cases for each state transition, and timing: scan rate 10 Hz, WCET 0.5 ms.

Develop an advanced irrigation master with six valve relays, a pump relay, and rain skip using weather input. Modes: OFF, AUTO, MANUAL, FROST_PROTECT. AUTO runs per weekday schedules with per-zone soak cycles; MANUAL allows per-zone jogs; FROST_PROTECT runs brief cycles if temperature < 2 C. Include a pump interlock, flow fault detection, watchdog policies, and provide a test plan covering edge cases (overlap, power loss, watchdog expiry).

Create a household load-shedding controller with priority tiers for five outlet relays. Modes: NORMAL, PEAK_SHED, EMERGENCY. Use a state machine to drop lower-priority loads when total current exceeds thresholds, restore with hysteresis, and honor user schedules and a do-not-disturb window. Include watchdog that reverts to EMERGENCY (all OFF) on missed heartbeats, sampling at 10 Hz with WCET < 1 ms, and require scenario-based tests.

Specify a smart hot water recirculation system with modes OFF, SCHEDULE, DEMAND, and VACATION. In SCHEDULE, run the pump relay in defined windows; in DEMAND, a button or occupancy event runs it for configurable minutes with temperature-based cutoff; VACATION prevents runs except a weekly anti-stagnation cycle. Provide safety constraints, watchdog default OFF, deterministic timers, and a verification checklist for mode logic and timer accuracy.

Teach a beginner: when a pushbutton is held, turn on a single LED; when released, turn it off. Debounce input with a simple 20 ms filter. Add a safety block that forces the LED off if the button signal is stuck on for more than 60 seconds. Include inline tests for press, release, and debounce edge cases.

Make a blink demo that toggles one LED at exactly 1 Hz. Let a variable 'rate_hz' set the blink rate but clamp it between 0.5 and 5 Hz in a safety block. Provide inline tests that verify timing within ±50 ms over 10 cycles.

Read a temperature sensor and turn on a 'HEAT' indicator when temperature drops below 18 Celsius, turn it off at or above 18. Include a safety check that ignores invalid readings below -40 or above 125 C. Add inline tests for boundary values.

Sound a buzzer for 200 ms whenever a toggle switch transitions from off to on. Use rising-edge detection. Safety: ignore any retrigger within 300 ms to protect ears. Include inline tests simulating rapid toggles.
Map a knob (0–100%) to LED brightness using linear scaling. Add a safety clamp to keep brightness between 5% and 95%. Provide inline tests for 0%, 50%, and 100% inputs.

Every time the button is double-clicked (two presses within 400 ms), flip the state of an LED. Single clicks do nothing. Include a simple safety block that resets the click counter after 1 s of inactivity. Add inline tests for double vs single clicks.
Count button presses up to 10 and print the count; after 10, reset to 0. Add a safety rule that ignores any press shorter than 30 ms. Include inline tests that feed a sequence of press durations.

Use a door magnetic sensor: when open, turn on a light; when closed, turn it off. Add a 100 ms debounce and a safety fallback that forces the light off if the sensor reads undefined. Provide inline tests for bouncing transitions.

Trigger a motion-activated chime: when a motion sensor trips, play a 1 s tone, then enforce a 10 s cooldown. Safety: do not re-trigger during cooldown. Add inline tests showing trigger, cooldown, and reset.
On startup, play a 3-second LED pattern (on-off-on at 500 ms each), then leave the LED off. Include inline tests that verify the sequence and total duration within ±50 ms.

Read a light sensor; if ambient light is below a threshold, turn on a night light LED, otherwise turn it off. Add a simple safety clamp on sensor values (0–1023). Include inline tests for near-threshold values.

Generate a random number between 1 and 6 every second and print it like a dice roll. Safety: ensure the generator is seeded only once at startup. Add inline tests that check range and approximate uniformity over 60 rolls.

If temperature exceeds 35 Celsius, sound an alarm; otherwise, keep silent. Safety: silence the alarm if temperature sensor fails self-check. Provide inline tests for normal, high, and failed sensor conditions.

A hold-to-run motor demo: when a student holds a safety button, energize a motor output; release turns it off immediately. Include a safety block that forces motor off at startup until the first valid button read. Add inline tests.

Create a simple timer: when the button is pressed, wait 2 seconds and then turn on an LED. If the button is released before the delay completes, cancel the action. Provide inline tests for hold and cancel scenarios.

Build a three-light traffic signal demo using a finite state machine: Green 5 s, Yellow 1 s, Red 4 s, looping. Add a safety interlock that never allows Green and Red on together. Include inline tests that check state timings and mutual exclusion.

Design a brightness controller with four levels (25%, 50%, 75%, 100%) that cycles to the next level on each debounced button press. Use a small state machine. Safety: cap duty cycle at 100%. Provide inline tests for bounce and wrap-around.

Implement two buttons for adjusting a temperature setpoint shown on a console: one increases by 0.5 C, the other decreases. Clamp the setpoint to 15–30 C in a safety block. Inline tests should cover limits and step behavior.

Create a simple light-following demo: read two light sensors (left/right) and drive two LEDs brighter on the side with more light. Add a safety block that handles sensor disconnect by setting both LEDs to 10%. Provide inline tests with asymmetric inputs.

Use a distance sensor to drive a beep rate: 2 Hz at 50 cm, up to 10 Hz at 5 cm, with linear mapping and saturation. Safety: ignore readings outside 5–200 cm. Include inline tests for mapping and clamping.

Make a metronome that beeps every 500 ms when enabled by a switch. Add a timing constraint so the main tick handler WCET is less than 2 ms. Provide inline tests that measure jitter and enforce the WCET budget.

Write a reaction-time game: after a random delay between 1 and 3 seconds, turn on an LED; the student must press a button quickly. Measure reaction time in milliseconds and keep the best of 5 rounds. Include inline tests for timing and scoring.

Thermostat with hysteresis: maintain 22.0 C by turning a heater ON below 21.5 and OFF at or above 22.5. Safety: if the sensor reports NaN or -99, force heater OFF. Add inline tests for hysteresis transitions.
Ambient day/night demo: drive SUN and MOON indicators based on a light sensor with 5% hysteresis to avoid flicker. Include inline tests that step the sensor through dusk and dawn conditions.

Water level control demo: start a pump when level < 30%, stop when level > 80%, and enforce a minimum off-time of 5 s to protect the pump. Include safety checks for sensor stuck-at values. Provide inline tests.

Single-floor elevator simulation: states Idle, DoorOpen, Moving. Up/Down buttons request movement; do not move unless the door is closed. Add a safety interlock to prevent Moving when DoorOpen. Include inline tests for each transition.

Two-task scheduler exercise: run a fast task at 100 Hz and a slow task at 1 Hz. Ensure tasks never overlap and each meets a WCET budget of 1 ms. Provide inline tests for period, jitter (<5 ms for the slow task), and budget.
PWM fan control with three zones: Low below 25 C, Medium 25–30 C, High above 30 C. Safety: fail-safe to Low if the sensor read fails. Add inline tests including boundary temperatures.

Pedestrian crossing demo: normal traffic cycle, but when a pedestrian button is pressed, insert a WALK phase of 6 s after the next Red. Enforce a minimum 10 s between WALK phases. Include safety to prevent walk and green together. Inline tests required.

Sound level meter: read microphone amplitude, apply a moving average over 200 ms, and drive an LED bar from 0 to 10 segments. Safety: cap values and handle silence. Include inline tests for smoothing behavior.
Logic gate trainer: two switches A and B control three LEDs showing AND, OR, and XOR. Include inline tests that exhaustively check all four input combinations.
Morse code flasher: encode a short uppercase message into blinks (dot 120 ms, dash 3× dot, spaces per standard). Safety: ignore unsupported characters. Add inline tests for a known word like SOS.

Simple stopwatch: Start, Stop, and Reset buttons. Display elapsed time in milliseconds to the console at 10 Hz. Safety: ignore simultaneous Start and Reset presses by prioritizing Reset. Include inline tests for race conditions.
Digital thermostat teacher's aid: show current temp and a flashing indicator if within ±0.3 C of the setpoint. Update at 5 Hz. Safety: clamp display rate to avoid saturation. Provide inline tests.

Proximity night light: fade an LED in proportion to proximity, but include 300 ms hysteresis to prevent flicker near the threshold. Add inline tests that sweep inputs across the threshold forward and backward.

Closed-loop temperature control using PID to maintain 50.0 C. Sample at 10 Hz, output to a heater actuator. Include anti-windup and a safety block that cuts output if temperature exceeds 60 C. Provide inline tests for step response settling within ±1.0 C in 60 seconds.

Speed control for a DC motor using encoder pulses: compute RPM at 20 Hz and use a PID to hold 1200 rpm. Safety: shut down if RPM exceeds 2000 or if encoder stops updating. Include inline tests for setpoint changes and fault conditions.

Tilt estimation with sensor fusion: combine accelerometer and gyro to estimate pitch angle using a complementary filter at 100 Hz (e.g., 98/2 split). Safety: bound the angle to ±90 degrees and detect sensor timeouts. Add inline tests for drift (<2 degrees in 30 s) and step motions.

Fuse two temperature sensors to produce a robust reading: if they agree within 1.0 C, average them; otherwise, trust the one closer to the previous value. Safety: if both are invalid, flag a fault and disable outputs. Include inline tests for agreement, disagreement, and fault cases.

Water tank level regulation with PID controlling a valve to hold 60% level. Enforce actuator rate limits and a safety overflow cutoff at 90%. Run the control loop at 20 Hz. Include inline tests for overshoot (<5%) and recovery from disturbances.

Line-following demo: two reflectance sensors feed a proportional controller that adjusts left and right motor outputs to stay centered on a dark line. Safety: if both sensors read white for >1 s, stop both motors. Add inline tests for curves and loss-of-line scenarios.

Position servo with rate limiting: follow a target position input (0–100%) using a PI controller at 50 Hz. Safety: clamp output and detect stuck actuator. Provide inline tests for step commands, saturation, and recovery.

Simple inertial navigation demo: integrate accelerometer readings to estimate velocity along one axis, zeroing velocity when a contact switch indicates stationary. Safety: bound integration drift by limiting max velocity to 3 m/s. Include inline tests with synthetic motion.

Event logger with integrity: timestamp sensor events, buffer them, and compute a rolling CRC for each batch. Safety: drop oldest data if buffer nearly full and raise a warning flag. Provide inline tests for overflow and CRC mismatches.

Thermal runaway prevention: monitor temperature rise rate; if dT/dt exceeds 5 C/s or absolute temperature exceeds 70 C, cut power and latch an alarm until reset. Add inline tests that simulate rapid heating and normal operation.

Multi-mode classroom robot controller with Manual and Auto modes. Manual: joystick directly drives two motor outputs with deadband and rate limiting. Auto: follow a light source using two sensors and a simple state machine (Search, Track, Lost). Safety: emergency stop input overrides everything. Specify task rates (control at 50 Hz) and WCET budget 2 ms. Include a comprehensive inline test suite covering mode switches, E‑stop, and loss-of-signal scenarios.

Environmental chamber exercise with modes Idle, Heat, Cool, and Safe. Use PID for heat/cool to hold a user setpoint in Celsius. Enter Safe mode on sensor failure or door open signal. Safety: never heat and cool simultaneously. Include timing constraints (10 Hz loop) and a full set of inline tests for transitions, limits, and fault injection.

Centrifuge teaching demo: modes Setup, Spin, Brake, and Fault. Use RPM feedback and a PID to reach target speed, then controlled braking. Safety: lid switch must be closed to spin; emergency stop latches Fault. Provide a scheduler with separate 100 Hz control and 10 Hz monitoring. Add extensive inline tests for normal runs, lid open, E‑stop, and overspeed.

Wind tunnel fan controller for a lab: modes Off, Calibrate, Operate. Fuse two anemometer readings; if they differ by more than 10%, fall back to the lower reading and flag a warning. Use PI control to reach airflow in m/s. Safety: overcurrent input forces Off. Include WCET budgets and a thorough inline test plan with sensor disagreement cases.

Multi-rate classroom scheduler: define three periodic tasks (1 kHz sensor read, 100 Hz control, 10 Hz logging) with CPU budget enforcement and overload handling that degrades to reduced functionality when budgets are exceeded. Safety: ensure critical control continues even under overload. Provide comprehensive inline tests for jitter, missed deadlines, and graceful degradation.

Create a beginner-friendly ReflexScript that turns on an indicator LED only while a pushbutton is held down. Include a simple safety block to debounce presses by ignoring changes within 20 ms and default the LED to off if the input is invalid. Add inline tests that simulate quick bounce patterns and clean presses to verify correct behavior.

Write a tiny classroom demo that blinks one LED at exactly 1 Hz. Run the control logic at a fixed 100 Hz rate with a WCET budget of 0.5 ms. Include a simple safety block to ensure the blink period never goes below 0.4 s or above 3 s, and provide inline tests that assert the LED toggles every 500 ms.

Make a simple light-activated night-light: if a light sensor reads below a chosen threshold in lux, turn on an LED; otherwise turn it off. Add a safety block that clamps sensor readings to 0–10000 lux and defaults the LED off on sensor fault. Include inline tests with example values to validate the threshold and clamping.

Build a small program where pressing a button causes a buzzer to beep for 1.0 s, and any extra presses during that time are ignored. Use straightforward syntax, include a simple safety block to handle stuck buttons, and add inline tests that simulate rapid repeats and long holds.

Create a basic dimmer demo: map a potentiometer input to LED brightness from 0% to 100%. Clamp input and output ranges in a safety block, and add inline tests that feed in 0, mid-scale, and maximum values to verify the mapping and limits.

On power-up, wait for 2.0 s and then turn an LED on solid to indicate ready. Include a safety block that ensures the LED remains off during the delay even if inputs are noisy, and write inline tests that check the exact timing of the transition.

Implement a simple toggle: each time a button press is detected (on the rising edge), flip an LED between on and off. Debounce the input for 25 ms with a safety block, and provide inline tests that simulate quick taps and bouncing to verify only one toggle per press.

Write a motion-activated light demo: when a motion input goes high, turn an LED on for 3 s. Re-triggers extend the on-time, but enforce a safety cap so it can never stay on more than 15 s continuously. Add inline tests for single and repeated triggers.

Create a temperature alarm that turns a buzzer on if the temperature exceeds 30 C and off otherwise. Add a safety block that validates sensor readings between -20 C and 80 C, fails safely with the buzzer off on invalid data, and include inline tests for edge cases and out-of-range inputs.

Make a heartbeat indicator that produces a double-blink on an LED every 2 s. Keep the logic simple, add a safety block to prevent blink intervals below 100 ms, and include inline tests that verify the two short flashes and the pause timing.

Design a ready-busy indicator using one input and one LED: when the input goes high, show busy by turning the LED on for 5 s, then return to ready (LED off). Add a safety block to ignore spurious toggles during the busy period, and include inline tests for timing and edge transitions.

Count button presses up to 9 and report the count using a single LED by flashing the number (short blips) once per second, then repeat. Reset the count to 0 after 5 s with no presses. Include a simple debounce safety block and inline tests that simulate press sequences and idle periods.

Map temperature in Celsius to an LED blink rate: 0.5 Hz at 20 C linearly up to 2.0 Hz at 40 C. Clamp outside this range and default to 0.5 Hz on sensor fault via a safety block. Provide inline tests covering 15 C, 20 C, 30 C, 40 C, and 50 C.
